<L>1<pc>1-001<k1>aMSu<k2>aMSu
{@Aṃśu.@}¦ — I. Name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>2. {@Dhānaṃjayya,@} pupil of {@Amāvāsya Śāṇḍilyāyana,@} according
<div n="lb"/>to the Vaṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) viii. 5, 26. {%Cf.%} Ludwig, Transla-
<div n="lb"/>tion of the Rigveda, 3, 160; Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>17, 89; Sieg, {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>129, suggests that he may be identical
<div n="lb"/>with {@Khela.@}</F>
<F>2) {%Indische Studien,%} 4, 373.</F>

<div n="lb"/>horse’ is the precise sense. {%Cf.%} {@Aśva.@}

<L>4<pc>1-001<k1>akza<k2>akza<h>1
1. {@Akṣa,@}¦ ‘axle,’ is a part of a chariot often referred to in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later. It was apparently<sup>2</sup> fastened to the
<div n="lb"/>body of the chariot ({@Kośa@}) by straps ({%akṣā-nah,%} lit. ‘tied to the
<div n="lb"/>axle,’ though this word is also<sup>3</sup> rendered ‘horse’). The
<div n="lb"/>heating of the axle and the danger of its breaking were known.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The part of the axle round which the nave of the wheel
<div n="lb"/>revolved was called Āṇi, ‘pin.’
<F>1) i. 30, 14; 166, 9; iii. 53, 17; vi.
<div n="lb"/>24, 3; x. 89; 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 246.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 53, 7. {%Cf.%} Roth, St. Peters-
<div n="lb"/>burg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 164, 13.</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-002+ 49]

<L>5<pc>1-002<k1>akza<k2>akza<h>2
2. {@Akṣa.@}¦ — This word occurs frequently, from the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>onwards, both in the singular and plural, meaning ‘die’ and
<div n="lb"/>‘dice.’ Dicing, along with horse-racing, was one of the main
<div n="lb"/>amusements of the Vedic Indian; but, despite the frequent
<div n="lb"/>mention of the game in the literature, there is considerable
<div n="lb"/>difficulty in obtaining any clear picture of the mode in which it
<div n="lb"/>was played.
<div n="P"/>(1) {%The Material.%} — The dice appear normally to have been
<div n="lb"/>made of Vibhīdaka nuts. Such dice are alluded to in both the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> hence being called ‘brown’
<div n="lb"/>({%babhru%}), and ‘born on a windy spot.’<sup>3</sup> In the ritual game of
<div n="lb"/>dice at the Agnyādheya and the Rājasūya ceremonies the
<div n="lb"/>material of the dice is not specified, but it is possible that
<div n="lb"/>occasionally gold imitations of Vibhīdaka nuts were used.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>There is no clear trace in the Vedic literature of the later use
<div n="lb"/>of cowries as dice.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="P"/>(2) {%The Number.%} — In the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> the dicer is described as
<div n="lb"/>‘leader of a great horde’ ({%senānīr mahato gaṇasya%}), and in
<div n="lb"/>another passage<sup>7</sup> the number is given as {%tri-pañcāśaḥ,%} an expres-
<div n="lb"/>sion which has been variously interpreted. Ludwig,<sup>8</sup> Weber,<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and Zimmer<sup>10</sup> render it as fifteen, which is grammatically
<div n="lb"/>hardly possible. Roth<sup>11</sup> and Grassmann<sup>12</sup> render it as ‘con-
<div n="lb"/>sisting of fifty-three.’ Lüders<sup>13</sup> takes it as ‘consisting of one
<div n="lb"/>hundred and fifty,’ but he points out that this may be merely a
<div n="lb"/>vague expression for a large number. For a small number
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>14</sup> cites a reference in the Rigveda<sup>15</sup> to one who fears
<div n="lb"/>‘him who holds four’ ({%caturaś cid dadamānāt%}), but the sense of
<div n="lb"/>that passage is dependent on the view taken of the method of
<div n="lb"/>playing the game.
<div n="P"/>(3) {%The Method of Play.%} — In several passages of the later
[Page1-003+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas lists are given of expressions con-
<div n="lb"/>nected with dicing. The names are Kṛta, Tretā, Dvāpara,
<div n="lb"/>Āskanda, and Abhibhū in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā.<sup>16</sup> In the
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>17</sup> among the victims at the Puruṣamedha,
<div n="lb"/>the {%kitava%} is offered to the Akṣarāja, the {%ādinava-darśa%} to the
<div n="lb"/>Kṛta, the {%kalpin%} to the Tretā, the {%adhi-kalpin%} to the Dvāpara,
<div n="lb"/>the {%sabhā-sthāṇu%} to the Āskanda. The lists in the parallel
<div n="lb"/>version of the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa are {%kitava, sabhāvin, ādinava-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%darśa, bahiḥ-sad,%} and {%sabhā-sthāṇu,%}<sup>18</sup> and Aksarāja, Kṛta, Tretā,
<div n="lb"/>Dvāpara, and Kali. From the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>19</sup> it appears
<div n="lb"/>that another name of Kali was Abhibhū, and the parallel lists
<div n="lb"/>in the Taittirīya and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitās suggest that Abhibhū
<div n="lb"/>and Akṣarāja are identical, though both appear in the late
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa list. The names of some of these throws
<div n="lb"/>go back even to the Rigveda and the Atharvaveda. Kali occurs
<div n="lb"/>in the latter,<sup>20</sup> and Lüders<sup>21</sup> shows that in a considerable number
<div n="lb"/>of passages in the former Kṛta means a ‘throw’ (not ‘a stake’<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or ‘what is won’<sup>23</sup> and this sense is clearly found in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda.<sup>24</sup> Moreover, that there were more throws ({%ayāḥ%})
<div n="lb"/>than one is proved by a passage in the Rigveda,<sup>25</sup> when
<div n="lb"/>the gods are compared to throws as giving or destroying
<div n="lb"/>wealth.
<div n="P"/>The nature of the throws is obscure. The St. Petersburg
<div n="lb"/>Dictionary conjectures that the names given above were applied
<div n="lb"/>either to dice marked 4, 3, 2, or 1, or to the sides of the dice so
<div n="lb"/>marked, and the latter interpretation is supported by some late
<div n="lb"/>commentators.<sup>26</sup> But there is no evidence for the former
<div n="lb"/>interpretation, and, as regards the latter, the shape of the
<div n="lb"/>Vibhīdaka nuts,<sup>27</sup> used as dice, forbids any side being properly
<div n="lb"/>on the top. Light is thrown on the expressions by the descrip-
[Page1-004+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>tion of a ritual game<sup>28</sup> at the Agnyādheya and at the Rājasūya
<div n="lb"/>ceremonies. The details are not certain,<sup>29</sup> but it is clear that
<div n="lb"/>the game consisted in securing even numbers of dice, usually a
<div n="lb"/>number divisible by four, the Kṛta, the other three throws then
<div n="lb"/>being the Tretā, when three remained over after division by
<div n="lb"/>four; the Dvāpara, when two was the remainder; and the Kali,
<div n="lb"/>when one remained. If five were the dividing number, then the
<div n="lb"/>throw which showed no remainder was Kali, the Kṛta was that
<div n="lb"/>when four was left, and so on. The dice had no numerals
<div n="lb"/>marked on them, the only question being what was the total
<div n="lb"/>number of the dice themselves.
<div n="P"/>There is no reason to doubt that the game as played in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda was based on the same principle, though the details
<div n="lb"/>must remain doubtful. The number of dice used was certainly
<div n="lb"/>large,<sup>30</sup> and the reference to throwing fours,<sup>31</sup> and losing by one,
<div n="lb"/>points to the use of the Kṛta as the winning throw. The
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>32</sup> on the other hand, possibly knew of the Kali as
<div n="lb"/>the winning throw. In one respect the ordinary game must
<div n="lb"/>have differed from the ritual game. In the latter the players
<div n="lb"/>merely pick out the number of dice required — no doubt to avoid
<div n="lb"/>ominous errors, such as must have happened if a real game had
<div n="lb"/>been played. In the secular game the dice were thrown,<sup>33</sup>
<div n="lb"/>perhaps on the principle suggested by Lüders:<sup>34</sup> the one
<div n="lb"/>throwing a certain number on the place of playing, and the other
<div n="lb"/>then throwing a number to make up with those already thrown
<div n="lb"/>a multiple of four or five. This theory, at any rate, accounts for
<div n="lb"/>the later stress laid on the power of computation in a player,
<div n="lb"/>as in the Nala.
<div n="P"/>No board appears to have been used, but a depression on which
[Page1-005+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>the dice were thrown ({%adhi-devana, devana,%}<sup>35</sup> {%iriṇa%}<sup>36</sup> ), was made
<div n="lb"/>in the ground. No dice box was used, but reference is made to
<div n="lb"/>a case for keeping dice in ({%akṣa-vapana%}<sup>37</sup> The throw was called
<div n="lb"/>{%graha%}<sup>38</sup> or earlier {%grābha.%}<sup>39</sup> The stake is called {%vij.%}<sup>40</sup> Serious
<div n="lb"/>losses could be made at dicing: in the Rigveda a dicer laments
<div n="lb"/>the loss of all his property, including his wife.<sup>41</sup> Lüders<sup>42</sup> finds
<div n="lb"/>a different form of the game referred to in the Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad.<sup>43</sup>
<F>1) vii. 86, 6; x. 34, 1.</F>
<F>2) Av. Paipp. xx. 4, 6.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 34, 5; Av. vii. 114, 7;
<div n="lb"/>Rv. x. 34, 1.</F>
<F>4) Sāyaṇa on Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 8,

<L>6<pc>1-005<k1>akza<k2>akza<h>3
3. {@Akṣa.@}¦ — In the Chāndogya Upaniṣad (vii. 3, 1) this word
<div n="lb"/>seems to denote the nut of the Vibhīdaka ({%Terminalia bellerica%}).
<LEND>

<L>7<pc>1-005<k1>akzata<k2>akzata
{@Akṣata@}¦ or {@Akṣita.@} — In one passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>dealing with the {@Jāyānya,@} mention is made of a remedy for
<div n="lb"/>sores designated both Akṣita and Sukṣata, or, according to
<div n="lb"/>the reading of the Kauṣika Sūtra, Akṣata and Sukṣata, while
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa has Akṣita and Sukṣita. Bloomfield<sup>2</sup> renders ‘not
<div n="lb"/>caused by cutting’ and ‘caused by cutting.’ Formerly<sup>3</sup> he
<div n="lb"/>suggested ‘tumour’ or ‘boil.’ Whitney<sup>4</sup> thinks that two
<div n="lb"/>varieties of Jāyānya are meant. Ludwig<sup>5</sup> reads with Sāyana
<div n="lb"/>{%akṣita,%} which he renders by ‘not firmly established’ in the
<div n="lb"/>invalid. Zimmer<sup>6</sup> finds in it a disease Kṣata.
<F>1) vii. 76, 4.</F>
<F>2) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 17, 562.</F>
<F>3) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 13, cxvii. {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Atharvaveda
<div n="lb"/>442.</F>
<F>5) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 500.</F>
<F>6) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 377.</F>
<LEND>

<L>9<pc>1-006<k1>akzu<k2>akzu
{@Akṣu.@}¦ — The word occurs in two passages of the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and one of the Rigveda.<sup>2</sup> Roth<sup>3</sup> renders it by ‘net,’ while
<div n="lb"/>Böhtlingk<sup>4</sup> suggests ‘axle of a car.’ Geldner<sup>5</sup> sees in it a stake
<div n="lb"/>or pole used with a fishermen's net ({@Jāla@}),<sup>6</sup> the pole of a wagon,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the pole of a house, whether vertical or horizontal, he leaves
<div n="lb"/>uncertain (see {@Vaṃśa@}).<sup>8</sup> Bloomfield<sup>9</sup> takes it as a covering
<div n="lb"/>of wickerwork stretched across a beam and sloping down to
<div n="lb"/>both sides — like a thatched roof, and this best explains the
<div n="lb"/>epithet ‘thousand-eyed’ ({%i.e.,%} with countless holes) ascribed to
<div n="lb"/>it. In the other Atharvaveda passage<sup>10</sup> he accepts the sense
<div n="lb"/>‘net,’ and doubts if the word in the Rigveda is not an adjective
<div n="lb"/>({%a-kṣu%}) as it is taken by Sāyaṇa. See also {@Gṛha.@}
<F>1) viii. 8, 18 ({%akṣujālābhyām%}); ix. 3, 18.</F>
<F>2) i. 180, 5.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 136.</F>
<F>6) Av. viii. 8, 18.</F>
<F>7) Av. i. 180, 5.</F>
<F>8) ix. 3, 18.</F>
<F>9) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 598.</F>
<F>10) Av. viii. 8, 18.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 153,
<div n="lb"/>265; Whitney, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 506, 526; Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 179.</F>
<LEND>

<L>10<pc>1-006<k1>agasti<k2>agasti
{@Agasti.@}¦ — This form of {@Agastya's@} name occurs once in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> where he appears as a favourite of Mitra and
<div n="lb"/>Varuṇa.
<F>1) iv. 9, 3. {%Cf.%} {@Sieg,@} {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 127, n. 5.</F>
<LEND>

<L>11<pc>1-006<k1>agastya<k2>agastya
{@Agastya.@}¦ — This is the name of a sage, of mythical character,
<div n="lb"/>who plays a great part in the later literature. He was a {@Māna,@}<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and therefore is called {@Mānya@}<sup>2</sup> and son of Māna, and only once
<div n="lb"/>is there a reference<sup>3</sup> to the legend prevalent in latter times that
<div n="lb"/>he was a son of Mitra and Varuṇa.
<div n="P"/>His greatest feat was the reconciliation of Indra and the
<div n="lb"/>Maruts after Indra had been annoyed at his proposing to give
<div n="lb"/>the Maruts an offering to the exclusion of Indra. This feat is
<div n="lb"/>the subject of three hymns of the Rigveda,<sup>4</sup> and is often referred
[Page1-007+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>to in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>5</sup> though the exact details and significance
<div n="lb"/>of the legend are variously treated by Oldenberg,<sup>6</sup> Sieg,<sup>7</sup> Hertel,<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and von Schroeder.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>He also appears in a strange dialogue with Lopāmudrā in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda,<sup>10</sup> which appears to show him as an ascetic who
<div n="lb"/>finally yields to temptation. Von {@Schroeder@}<sup>11</sup> regards it as
<div n="lb"/>a ritual drama of vegetation magic.
<div n="P"/>In another passage of the Rigveda<sup>12</sup> he appears as helping
<div n="lb"/>in the Aśvins’ gift of a leg to Viśpalā. Sāyaṇa holds that be
<div n="lb"/>was the Purohita of {@Khela,@} and Sieg<sup>13</sup> accepts this view, while
<div n="lb"/>Pischel<sup>14</sup> thinks that Khela is a deity, Vivasvant.
<div n="P"/>Geldner<sup>15</sup> shows from the Rigveda<sup>16</sup> that Agastya, as brother
<div n="lb"/>of Vasiṣṭha — both being miraculous sons of Mitra and Varuṇa
<div n="lb"/>-introduces {@Vasiṣṭha@} to the {@Tṛtsus.@} There are two other
<div n="lb"/>references to Agastya in the Rigveda, the one<sup>17</sup> including him
<div n="lb"/>in a long list of persons, the other alluding to his sister's sons
<div n="lb"/>({%nadbhyaḥ%}),<sup>18</sup> apparently {@Bandhu,@} etc. In the Atharvaveda<sup>19</sup>
<div n="lb"/>he appears as connected with witchcraft, and in a long list of
<div n="lb"/>sages.<sup>20</sup> In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>21</sup> cows, with a peculiar
<div n="lb"/>mark on their ears ({%viṣṭya-karṇyaḥ%}), are associated with him.

<div n="lb"/>168, 10; 165, 14; 177, 5; 184, 4 (Mānya);

<L>13<pc>1-008<k1>agnidagDa<k2>agnidagDa
{@Agni-dagdha.@}¦ — This epithet (‘burnt with fire’)<sup>1</sup> applies to
<div n="lb"/>the dead who were burned on the funeral pyre. This is one
<div n="lb"/>of the two normal methods of disposing of the dead, the other
<div n="lb"/>being burial ({%an-agnidagdhāḥ,%} ‘not burnt with fire’).<sup>2</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> adds two further modes of disposal to those — 
<div n="lb"/>viz., casting out ({%paroptāḥ%}), and the exposure of the dead
<div n="lb"/>({%uddhitāḥ%}). The exact sense of these expressions is doubtful.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>4</sup> considers that the former is a parallel to the Iranian
<div n="lb"/>practice of casting out the dead to be devoured by beasts, and
<div n="lb"/>that the latter refers to the old who are exposed when helpless.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Whitney<sup>6</sup> refers the latter expression to the exposure of the
<div n="lb"/>dead body on a raised platform of some sort.
<div n="P"/>Burial was clearly not rare in the Rigvedic period: a whole
<div n="lb"/>hymn<sup>7</sup> describes the ritual attending it. The dead man was
<div n="lb"/>buried apparently in full attire, with his bow in his hand, and
<div n="lb"/>probably at one time his wife was immolated to accompany
<div n="lb"/>him, in accordance with a practice common among savage
<div n="lb"/>tribes. But in the Vedic period both customs appear in a
<div n="lb"/>modified form: the son takes the bow from the hand of the
<div n="lb"/>dead man, and the widow is led away from her dead husband
<div n="lb"/>by his brother or other nearest kinsman. A stone is set
<div n="lb"/>between the dead and the living to separate them. In the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>8</sup> but not in the Rigveda, a coffin ({%vṛkṣa%}) is alluded
<div n="lb"/>to. In both Saṃhitās<sup>9</sup> occur other allusions to the ‘house
<div n="lb"/>of earth’ ({%bhūmi-gṛha%}). To remove the apparent discrepancy
<div n="lb"/>between burning and burial, by assuming that the references to
<div n="lb"/>burial are to the burial of the burned bones, as does Oldenberg,<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>is unnecessary and improbable, as burning and burial subsisted
<div n="lb"/>side by side in Greece for many years.
<div n="P"/>Burning was, however, equally usual, and it grew steadily
<div n="lb"/>in frequency, for in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad<sup>11</sup> the adornment
[Page1-009+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>of the body of the dead with curd ({@Āmikṣā@}), clothes, and
<div n="lb"/>ornaments, in order to win the next world, is referred to as
<div n="lb"/>something erroneous and wrong, and in the funeral Mantras of
<div n="lb"/>the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>12</sup> only burning seems to be contemplated;
<div n="lb"/>the verses which refer to burial here really alluding to the burial
<div n="lb"/>of the ashes in the burying-ground ({%śmaśāna%}).<sup>13</sup> The body was
<div n="lb"/>wrapped in fat,<sup>14</sup> as we learn from the funeral hymn in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, a goat being apparently burned with it,<sup>15</sup> to act as
<div n="lb"/>a guide on the way to the next world. According to the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>16</sup> a draft-ox was burned presumably for the dead
<div n="lb"/>to ride with in the next world. It was expected that the dead
<div n="lb"/>would revive with his whole body and all his limbs ({%sarva-tanūḥ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%sāṅgaḥ%}),<sup>17</sup> although it is also said<sup>18</sup> that the eye goes to the sun,
<div n="lb"/>the breath to the wind, and so forth.
<div n="P"/>Before burial or burning, the corpse was washed,<sup>19</sup> a clog
<div n="lb"/>({%kūdī%}) being tied to the foot to prevent the deceased returning
<div n="lb"/>to earth.<sup>20</sup>
<F>1) Rv. x. 15, 14; Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iii. 1, 1, 7; {%dagdhāḥ,%} Av. xviii.
<div n="lb"/>2, 34.</F>
<F>2) Rv., {%loc. cit.;%} = {%nikhātāḥ,%} Av. xviii.
<div n="lb"/>2, 34.</F>
<F>3) {%Loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 402.</F>
<F>5) Rv. viii. 51, 2.</F>
<F>6) Translation of the Atharvaveda, 841.</F>
<F>7) x. 18. The interpretation of v. 8 is
<div n="lb"/>a famous crux, see Patnī.</F>
<F>8) xviii. 2, 25; 3, 70.</F>
<F>9) Rv. vii. 89, 1; Av. v. 30, 14; xviii.
<div n="lb"/>2, 52.</F>

<F>11) viii. 8. 5.</F>

<div n="lb"/>80 {%et seq.,%} which treats the Atharvaveda
<div n="lb"/>hymns, xviii. 1-3, as intended for
<div n="lb"/>burning only.</F>
<F>13) Av. v. 31, 8; x. 1, 18; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, v. 2, 8, 5; 4, 11, 3.</F>

<L>16<pc>1-010<k1>aGA<k2>aGA
{@Aghā.@}¦ — In the wedding hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> it is said that
<div n="lb"/>cows are slain in the Aghās, and the wedding takes place at the
<div n="lb"/>{@Arjunīs@} (dual). The Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> has the ordinary {@Maghās@}
<div n="lb"/>instead. It is impossible to resist the conclusion that the read-
<div n="lb"/>ing of the Rigveda was deliberately altered because of the con-
<div n="lb"/>nection of the slaughter of kine with sin ({%agha%}) — possibly, too,
<div n="lb"/>with a further desire to emphasize the contrast with {%aghnyā,%}
<div n="lb"/>a name for ‘cow.’ Moreover, in the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>occurs the formula ‘Svāhā to the Maghās, Svāhā to the
<div n="lb"/>Anaghās.’ See also {@Nakṣatra.@}
<F>1) x. 85, 13.</F>
<F>2) xiv. 1, 13.</F>
<F>3) iii. 1, 4, 8.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Naxatra,%} 2, 364; Pro-
<div n="lb"/>ceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1894,

<div n="lb"/>{%rituell,%} 32; Whitney, Translation of the

<L>19<pc>1-010<k1>aNka<k2>aNka
{@Aṅka.@}¦ — The Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>1</sup> and Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> refer to two
<div n="lb"/>Aṅkas and two Nyaṅkas as parts of a chariot. The meaning
<div n="lb"/>of these terms is quite obscure. The commentators refer them
<div n="lb"/>to the sides or wheels. Zimmer<sup>3</sup> compares the Greek <lang n="greek"></lang><sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and thinks that the Aṅkau were the upper border of the body
<div n="lb"/>of the chariot ({%kośa, vandhura%}), and the Nyaṅkau the lower rims
<div n="lb"/>for greater security. Oldenberg<sup>5</sup> confesses that the exact sense
<div n="lb"/>is impossible to make out, but considers that the terms at once
<div n="lb"/>refer to parts of the chariot and to divinities, while Böhtlingk<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>takes the term as referring to divinities alone.
<F>1) i. 7, 7, 2.</F>
<F>2) ii. 7, 8, 1. {%Cf.%} Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 7, 5.</F>

<L>20<pc>1-011<k1>aNga<k2>aNga
{@Aṅga.@}¦ — The name occurs only once in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>connection with the {@Gandhāris, Mūjavants,@} and {@Magadhas,@} as
<div n="lb"/>distinct peoples. They appear also in the Gopatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>in the compound name {%Aṅga-magadhāḥ.%} As in later times they
<div n="lb"/>were settled on the Sone and Ganges,<sup>3</sup> their earlier seat was
<div n="lb"/>presumably there also. See also {@Vaṅga.@}
<F>1) v. 22, 14.</F>
<F>2) ii. 9.</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 35;
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>446, 449; Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Asiatic Society,%} 1908, 852, inclines to
<div n="lb"/>regard them as a non-Aryan people
<div n="lb"/>that came over-sea to Eastern India.
<div n="lb"/>There is nothing in the Vedic litera-
<div n="lb"/>ture to throw light on this hypothesis.</F>

<L>26<pc>1-012<k1>aja<k2>aja
{@Aja, Ajā.@}¦ — This is the ordinary name for goat in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the later literature. The goat is also called {@Basta, Chāga,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Chagala.@} Goats and sheep ({%ajāvayaḥ%}) are very frequently
<div n="lb"/>mentioned together.<sup>2</sup> The female goat is spoken of as pro-
<div n="lb"/>ducing two or three kids,<sup>3</sup> and goat's milk is well known.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The goat as representative of Pūṣan plays an important part
<div n="lb"/>in the ritual of burial.<sup>5</sup> The occupation of a goatherd ({%ajapāla%})
<div n="lb"/>was a recognized one, being distinguished from that of a cow-
<div n="lb"/>herd and of a shepherd.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) {%Aja%} in Rv. x. 16, 4; i. 162, 2. 4;
<div n="lb"/>Av. ix. 5, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi.

<div n="lb"/>71, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii., 56,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 90, 10; Av. viii. 7, 25;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 43, etc.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 1.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 6, 1; v.
<div n="lb"/>1, 7, 4. {%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische%}

<L>27<pc>1-012<k1>aja<k2>aja
{@Aja.@}¦ — The Ajas are named in one verse of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>having been defeated by the {@Tṛtsus@} under {@Sudās.@} They are
<div n="lb"/>there mentioned with the {@Yakṣus@} and {@Śigrus,@} and Zimmer<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>conjectures that they formed part of a confederacy under
<div n="lb"/>Bheda against Sudās. The name has been regarded as a sign
<div n="lb"/>of totemism,<sup>3</sup> but this is very uncertain, and it is impossible to
<div n="lb"/>say if they were or were not Āryans.
<F>1) vii. 18. 19.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>

<L>33<pc>1-013<k1>ajYAtayakzma<k2>ajYAtayakzma
{@Ajñāta-yakṣma,@}¦ the ‘unknown sickness,’ is mentioned in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> and Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā.<sup>3</sup> It is
<div n="lb"/>referred to in connection with Rājayakṣma. Grohmann<sup>4</sup> thinks
<div n="lb"/>that the two are different forms of disease, hypertrophy and
<div n="lb"/>atrophy, the purpose of the spell in the Rigveda being thus the
<div n="lb"/>removal of all disease. From the Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> he deduces its
<div n="lb"/>identity with {@Balāsa.@} Zimmer,<sup>6</sup> however, points out that this
[Page1-014+ 42]
<div n="lb"/>conclusion is unjustified, leaving the disease unidentified, which
<div n="lb"/>seems to accord with its name.

<L>34<pc>1-014<k1>ajina<k2>ajina
{@Ajina.@}¦ — This word denotes generally the skin of an animal
<div n="lb"/>-{%e.g.,%} a gazelle,<sup>1</sup> as well as that of a goat ({@Aja@}).<sup>2</sup> The use
<div n="lb"/>of skins as clothing is shown by the adjective ‘clothed in skins’
<div n="lb"/>({%ajina-vāsin%}) in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> and the furrier's trade
<div n="lb"/>is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>4</sup> The Maruts also
<div n="lb"/>wear deer-skins,<sup>5</sup> and the wild ascetics ({%muni%}) of a late Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>hymn<sup>6</sup> seem to be clad in skins ({@Mala@}).

<L>40<pc>1-014<k1>atiTi<k2>atiTi
{@Atithi@}¦ (‘guest’). — A hymn of the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> celebrates in
<div n="lb"/>detail the merits of hospitality. The guest should be fed before
[Page1-015+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>the host eats, water should be offered to him, and so forth.
<div n="lb"/>The Taittirīya Upaniṣad<sup>2</sup> also lays stress on hospitality, using
<div n="lb"/>the expression ‘one whose deity is his guest’ ({%atithi-deva%}). In
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>3</sup> it is said that only the good are deemed
<div n="lb"/>worthy of receiving hospitality. The guest-offering forms a
<div n="lb"/>regular part of the ritual,<sup>4</sup> and cows were regularly slain in
<div n="lb"/>honour of guests.<sup>5</sup>
<F>1) ix. 6.</F>
<F>2) i. 11, 2.</F>
<F>3) i. 1, 1.</F>
<F>4) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vii. 3, 2, 1.</F>
<F>5) {%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%American Journal of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Philology,%} 17, 426; Hillebrandt, {%Ritual-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%litteratur,%} 79.</F>
<LEND>

<L>41<pc>1-015<k1>atiTigva<k2>atiTigva
{@Atithi-gva.@}¦ — This name occurs frequently in the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>apparently applying, in nearly all cases, to the same king,
<div n="lb"/>otherwise called {@Divodāsa.@} The identity of the two persons
<div n="lb"/>has been denied by Bergaigne,<sup>1</sup> but is certainly proved by a
<div n="lb"/>number of passages, when the two names occur together,<sup>2</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>connection with the defeat of {@Śambara.@} In other passages<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Atithigva is said to have assisted Indra in slaying Parṇaya and
<div n="lb"/>Karañja. Sometimes he is only vaguely referred to, while once<sup>5</sup> he
<div n="lb"/>is mentioned as an enemy of Turvaśa and Yadu. Again<sup>6</sup> Atithigva
<div n="lb"/>is coupled with {@Āyu@} and {@Kutsa@} as defeated by {@Tūrvayāṇa.@}
<div n="P"/>A different Atithigva appears to be referred to in a Dānastuti<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>(‘Praise of Gifts’), where his son, {@Indrota,@} is mentioned.
<div n="P"/>Roth<sup>8</sup> distinguishes three Atithigvas — the Atithigva Divodāsa,
<div n="lb"/>the enemy of Parṇaya and Karañja, and the enemy of Tūrvayāṇa.
<div n="lb"/>But the various passages can be reconciled, especially if it is
<div n="lb"/>admitted that Atithigva Divodāsa was already an ancient hero
<div n="lb"/>in the earliest hymns, and was becoming almost mythical.
<div n="P"/><sup>4</sup>
<F>1) {%Religion Védique,%} 2, 342 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 51, 6; 112, 14; 130, 7;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 26, 3; vi. 47, 22.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 53, 8; x. 48, 8.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 19, 8. There is no ground
<div n="lb"/>for assuming the reference here to be
<div n="lb"/>to a later Atithigva.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 53, 10; ii. 14, 7; vi. 18, 13;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 53, 2.</F>
<F>7) Rv. viii. 68, 16. 17.</F>
<F>8) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, 3, 123; Bloomfield, {%American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of Philology,%} 17, 426, who renders
<div n="lb"/>the name ‘presenting cows to guests.’</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 26, 3.</F>
<LEND>

<L>44<pc>1-016<k1>atka<k2>atka<h>1
1. {@Atka.@}¦ — This word occurs frequently in the Rigveda, but its
<div n="lb"/>sense is doubtful. Roth, Grassmann, Ludwig, Zimmer,<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>others render it as ‘garment’ in several passages,<sup>2</sup> when the
<div n="lb"/>expressions ‘put on’ ({%vyā%} or {%prati muñc%}) or ‘put off’ ({%muñc%}) are
<div n="lb"/>used of it, and when it is said to be ‘woven’ ({%vyuta%})<sup>3</sup> or ‘well-
<div n="lb"/>fitting’ ({%surabhi%}).<sup>4</sup> On the other hand, Pischel<sup>5</sup> denies that this
<div n="lb"/>sense occurs, and otherwise explains the passages. He takes
<div n="lb"/>the term to mean ‘axe’ in four places.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 262.</F>
<F>2) i. 95, 7; ii. 35, 14; iv. 18, 5;
<div n="lb"/>v. 55, 6; 74, 5; vi. 29, 3; viii. 41, 7;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 101, 14; 107, 13; Sāmaveda,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 1193.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 122, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 29, 3; x. 123, 7.</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 193-204.</F>
<F>6) Rv. v. 55, 6; vi. 33, 3; x. 49, 3; 99, 9.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 94, n. 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>45<pc>1-016<k1>atka<k2>atka<h>2
2. {@Atka.@}¦ — In two passages of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> this word is
<div n="lb"/>regarded as a proper name by Roth, Grassmann, and Ludwig.
<div n="lb"/>But Zimmer<sup>2</sup> explains it in these passages as the ‘armour of a
<div n="lb"/>warrior as a whole,’ and Pischel<sup>3</sup> thinks that in both cases an
<div n="lb"/>‘axe’ is meant.
<F>1) x. 49, 3; 99, 9.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 262, 297.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 195.</F>

<L>46<pc>1-016<k1>atyaMhasAruRi<k2>atyaMhasAruRi

<div n="lb"/>(iii. 10, 9, 3-5), this teacher sent a pupil to question {@Plakṣa@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Dayyāṃpati@} as to the Sāvitra (a form of Agni). For this
<div n="lb"/>impertinence his pupil was severely rebuked.

<L>47<pc>1-016<k1>atyarAtijAnaMtapi<k2>atyarAtijAnaMtapi
{@Aty-arāti Jānaṃ-tapi,@}¦ though not a prince, was taught the
<div n="lb"/>Rājasūya by {@Vāsiṣṭha Satyahavya,@} and thereupon conquered
<div n="lb"/>the earth. When Vāsiṣṭha reminded him of his indebtedness,
<div n="lb"/>and claimed a great reward, the warrior replied irascibly that
<div n="lb"/>he intended to conquer the {@Uttara Kurus,@} and that Vāsiṣṭha
<div n="lb"/>would then become King of the Earth, Atyarāti himself being
<div n="lb"/>his general ({%senā-pati%}). Vāsiṣṭha replied that as no mortal man
<div n="lb"/>could conquer the Uttara Kurus he was cheated of his reward.
[Page1-017+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>He consequently procured Atyarāti's defeat and death at the
<div n="lb"/>hands of {@Amitratapana Śuṣmiṇa Śaibya.@}<sup>1</sup>
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 23. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 214.</F>

<L>48<pc>1-017<k1>atri<k2>atri
{@Atri.@}¦ — Neither Atri himself nor the Atris can claim any
<div n="lb"/>historical reality,<sup>1</sup> beyond the fact that Maṇḍala V. of the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>is attributed, no doubt correctly, to the family of the Atris.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The Atris as a family probably stood in close relations with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Priyamedhas@}<sup>3</sup> and {@Kaṇvas,@}<sup>4</sup> perhaps also with the {@Gotamas@}<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and {@Kākṣīvatas.@}<sup>6</sup> The mention of both the {@Paruṣṇī@} and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Yamunā@} in one hymn<sup>7</sup> of the fifth Maṇḍala seems to justify the
<div n="lb"/>presumption that the family was spread over a wide extent of
<div n="lb"/>territory.
<F>1) For Atri in the Rigveda, see Mac-
<div n="lb"/>donell, {%Vedic Mythology,%} 145. {%Cf.%} also
<div n="lb"/>Av. ii. 32, 3; iv. 29, 3; Mantra Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ii. 7, 1; Taittirīya Āraṇyaka,
<div n="lb"/>iv. 36, etc.; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 2, 4.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Rv. v. 39, 5; 67, 5; Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xxiv. 3; Aitareya Āraṇyaka,
<div n="lb"/>ii, 2, 1.</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 45, 3; 139, 9; viii. 5,
<div n="lb"/>25; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 22.</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 118, 7; v. 41, 4;
<div n="lb"/>x. 150, 5.</F>
<F>5) {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 183, 5.</F>
<F>6) {%Cf.%} Rv. x. 143, 1.</F>
<F>7) Rv. v. 52, 9, 17. {%Cf.%} Ludwig,
<div n="lb"/>Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 128,
<div n="lb"/>142; Bergaigne, {%Religion Védique,%} 2,

<L>50<pc>1-017<k1>aTarvan<k2>aTarvan
{@Atharvan.@}¦ — The name in the singular denotes the head of a
<div n="lb"/>semi-divine family of mythical priests,<sup>1</sup> of whom nothing his-
<div n="lb"/>torical can be said. In the plural the family as a whole is
<div n="lb"/>meant. In a few places an actual family seems to be referred
<div n="lb"/>to. Thus, for instance, they are mentioned as recipients of
<div n="lb"/>gifts in the Dānastuti<sup>2</sup> (‘Praise of Gifts’), of {@Aśvattha's@}
[Page1-018+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>generosity; their use of milk mingled with honey in the ritual
<div n="lb"/>is referred to;<sup>3</sup> and a cow that miscarries ({%ava-tokā%}) from accident
<div n="lb"/>is dedicated to the Atharvans, according to the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) See Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>141. In the Vaṃśa of the Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 6, 3, Atharvan
<div n="lb"/>Daiva is characteristically the pupil of
<div n="lb"/>Mṛtyu.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 47, 24.</F>
<F>3) Rv. ix. 11, 2.</F>
<F>4) iii. 4, 11, 1. {%Cf.%} Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, xxx. 15.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} xxxv. {%et seq.,%} who (p. xxxviii)
<div n="lb"/>takes {%avatokā%} as a woman, and the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvans as the hymns; Hillebrandt,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Mythologie,%} 2, 174 {%et seq.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>51<pc>1-018<k1>aTarvARaH<k2>aTarvARaH
{@Atharvāṇaḥ.@}¦ — This expression<sup>1</sup> is used with {@Aṅgirasaḥ,@} to
<div n="lb"/>denote the Atharvaveda. The compound {@Atharvāṅgirasaḥ@} is
<div n="lb"/>employed in the same sense.

<L>52<pc>1-018<k1>aTarvANgirasaH<k2>aTarvANgirasaH
{@Atharvāṅgirasaḥ.@}¦ — This is the collective name of the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda in several passages<sup>1</sup> of the later Brāhmaṇas. It occurs
<div n="lb"/>once in the Atharvaveda itself,<sup>2</sup> while the term Atharvaveda
<div n="lb"/>is not found before the Sūtra period.<sup>3</sup> The compound seems,
<div n="lb"/>according to Bloomfield,<sup>4</sup> to denote the two elements which
<div n="lb"/>make up the Atharvaveda. The former part refers to the aus-
<div n="lb"/>picious practices of the Veda ({%bheṣajāni%});<sup>5</sup> the latter to its hostile
<div n="lb"/>witchcraft, the {%yātu%}<sup>6</sup> or {%abhi-cāra.%}<sup>7</sup> This theory is supported by
<div n="lb"/>the names of the two mythic personages {@Ghora Āṅgirasa@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Bhiṣaj Ātharvaṇa,@} as well as by the connection of Atharvāṇaḥ
<div n="lb"/>and {@Ātharvaṇāni@} with healing ({%bheṣaja%}) in the Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa.<sup>8</sup> Moreover, the term {%bhesajā%} (‘remedies’) designates
<div n="lb"/>in the Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> that Veda itself, while in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>10</sup> {%yātu%} (‘sorcery’) conveys the same meaning. The
<div n="lb"/>evidence, however, being by no means convincing, it remains
<div n="lb"/>probable that there existed no clear differentiation between the
<div n="lb"/>two sages as responsible for the Atharvaveda as a whole.
<F>1) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 12, 8, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, ii. 9; 10; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5, 6, 7; Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 4, 10; iv. 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>5, 11; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iii. 4, 1. 2;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Upaniṣad, ii. 3, 1.</F>
<F>2) x. 7, 20.</F>
<F>3) Śāṅkhāyana Srauta Sūtra, xvi. 2, 9,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>4) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 11, 387 {%et seq.; Hymns of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Atharvaveda,%} xviii. {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) Av. xi. 6, 14.</F>
<F>6) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, x. 5, 2, 20.</F>
<F>7) Kauśika Sūtra, 3, 19.</F>
<F>8) xii. 9, 10; xvi. 10, 10.</F>
<F>9) x. 6, 14.</F>
<F>10) x. 5, 2, 20.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 177.</F>

<L>53<pc>1-019<k1>adfzwa<k2>adfzwa
{@A-dṛṣṭa.@}¦ — ‘The unseen’ is a term used in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> to designate a species of vermin. The
<div n="lb"/>sun is also described as ‘the slayer of the unseen’ ({%adṛṣṭa-han%}),<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and as a counterpart a ‘seen’ ({%dṛṣṭa%}) is mentioned.<sup>4</sup> In one
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>5</sup> the epithets ‘seen’ and ‘unseen’ are applied to the
<div n="lb"/>worm ({@Kṛmi@}), their use being no doubt due to the widespread
<div n="lb"/>theory of diseases being due to worms, whether discernable by
<div n="lb"/>examination or not.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 191, 4 = Av. vi. 52, 2.</F>
<F>2) vi. 52, 3.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 191, 9 = Av. vi. 52, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Av. v. 23, 6.</F>
<F>4) Av. ii. 31, 2; viii. 8, 15.</F>
<F>5) Av. v. 23, 6. 7.</F>
<F>6) Kuhn, {%Zeitschrift für vergleichende%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sprachforschung,%} 13, 135 {%et seq.;%} Bloom-
<div n="lb"/>field, {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 313-
<div n="lb"/>315; Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 98.</F>
<LEND>

<L>54<pc>1-019<k1>admasad<k2>admasad
{@Adma-sad.@}¦ — This expression ({%lit.%} ‘sitting at the meal’), found
<div n="lb"/>several times in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is usually rendered ‘guest at the
<div n="lb"/>feast,’ but Geldner<sup>2</sup> adduces reasons to show that it means ‘a
<div n="lb"/>fly,’ so called because of its settling on food.

<L>55<pc>1-019<k1>adri<k2>adri
{@Adri.@}¦ — Zimmer<sup>1</sup> deduces from the use of this word (‘rock,’
<div n="lb"/>‘stone’) in a passage of the Rigveda,<sup>2</sup> that sling-stones were
<div n="lb"/>used in Vedic fighting. But the passage is mythical, referring
<div n="lb"/>to Indra's aid, and cannot be used with any certainty as
<div n="lb"/>evidence for human war. More probably it merely denotes
<div n="lb"/>Indra's bolt. See also {@Aśani.@}

<L>57<pc>1-019<k1>aDirAja<k2>aDirAja
{@Adhi-rāja.@}¦ — The word occurs fairly often throughout the
<div n="lb"/>early literature,<sup>1</sup> denoting ‘overlord’ among kings or princes.
[Page1-020+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>In no passage is it clear that a real over-king is meant, as
<div n="lb"/>the word {%rājan%} may mean king or merely prince, a person of
<div n="lb"/>royal blood. On the whole it seems most probable that the
<div n="lb"/>word connotes no more than ‘king’ as opposed to ‘prince.’
<F>1) Rv. x. 128, 9 Av. vi. 98, 1; ix. 10,
<div n="lb"/>24; Taiturīya Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 14, 2;

<div n="lb"/>iii. 1, 2, 9 ({%adhirājan%}); Śatapatha Brāh-

<L>58<pc>1-020<k1>aDizavaRa<k2>aDizavaRa
{@Adhi-ṣavaṇa.@}¦ — The two Adhiṣavaṇas<sup>1</sup> are usually understood,
<div n="lb"/>as by Roth<sup>2</sup> and Zimmer,<sup>3</sup> to designate the two boards between
<div n="lb"/>which the Soma was pressed. Hillebrandt,<sup>4</sup> however, shows
<div n="lb"/>from the ritual that the boards were not placed one over the
<div n="lb"/>other, but were placed one behind the other, the two serving
<div n="lb"/>as a foundation upon which the Soma was pressed by a stone.
<div n="lb"/>This theory seems to account best for the etymological sense
<div n="lb"/>of the name ‘over-press,’ as well as for the use of the word as
<div n="lb"/>an adjective (‘used for pressing {%upon%}’). But according to the
<div n="lb"/>procedure as witnessed by Haug<sup>5</sup> in the Deccan, the shoots of
<div n="lb"/>the plant are first placed on the skin, one of the boards being
<div n="lb"/>then laid over them and pounded with a stone. The shoots
<div n="lb"/>are then taken out and placed upon the board, the second
<div n="lb"/>board being then laid over them.
<F>1) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 21;
<div n="lb"/>Av. v. 20, 10; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 9, 4, 1; 5, 3, 22 ({%adhiṣavaṇe%}
<div n="lb"/>{%phalake%}); Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 32
<div n="lb"/>({%adhiṣavaṇaṃ carma,%} ‘the skin upon
<div n="lb"/>which the pressing takes place’;
<div n="lb"/>{%adhiṣavaṇe phalake,%} ‘the boards on
<div n="lb"/>which the pressing takes place,’
<div n="lb"/>etc.).</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 277.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 148 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) See Haug, Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, 2,
<div n="lb"/>p. 488, n. 10.</F>
<LEND>

<L>59<pc>1-020<k1>aDIvAsa<k2>aDIvAsa

<L>65<pc>1-021<k1>anas<k2>anas
{@Anas.@}¦ — This is the term<sup>1</sup> used to designate the draft wagon,
<div n="lb"/>as opposed to the chariot ({%ratha%}) for war or sport, with which
<div n="lb"/>it is sometimes expressly contrasted,<sup>2</sup> though Indra is once said
<div n="lb"/>to be ‘seated in a wagon’ ({%anar-viś%})<sup>3</sup> instead of on a chariot.
<div n="lb"/>Though Uṣas, Goddess of Dawn, sometimes rides on a chariot
<div n="lb"/>({%ratha%}), the wagon is her characteristic vehicle.<sup>4</sup> Of its con-
<div n="lb"/>struction we know little. The bridal wagon on which Sūryā,
<div n="lb"/>the daughter of the Sun, was borne in the marriage hymn in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda had a covering ({@Chadis@}).<sup>5</sup> The axle-box ({@Kha@}) is also
[Page1-022+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>mentioned.<sup>6</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> Vipatha appears to denote a
<div n="lb"/>rough vehicle used for bad tracks. The wagon was usually
<div n="lb"/>drawn by oxen ({@Anaḍvāh@}), as in wedding processions.<sup>8</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>wagon of Dawn is described as drawn by ruddy cows or bulls.<sup>9</sup>

<div n="lb"/>18, etc.; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 1,
<div n="lb"/>2, 5, etc.; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, vii.
<div n="lb"/>15, 1; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, iii. 8,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. iii. 33, 9.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 121, 7.</F>
<F>4) Rv. ii. 15, 6; iv. 30, 11; viii. 91,
<div n="lb"/>7; x. 73, 6; 138, 5.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 85, 10.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii. 91, 7; Jaiminīya Upaniṣad
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 3.</F>

<L>68<pc>1-022<k1>anu<k2>anu
{@Anu, Ānava.@}¦ — Grassmann and Roth<sup>1</sup> see in these words
<div n="lb"/>designations of people foreign to the Aryans. But it is clear<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>that they denote a special people, the Anus, who are mentioned
<div n="lb"/>with the {@Yadus, Turvaśas, Druhyus,@} and {@Pūrus,@}<sup>3</sup> with the
<div n="lb"/>Druhyus,<sup>4</sup> and with the Turvaśas, Yadus, and Druhyus.<sup>5</sup> It
<div n="lb"/>is also a fair conclusion from their mention in a passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>6</sup> that they dwelt on the Paruṣṇī. The inference that
<div n="lb"/>the Bhṛgus were connected with this tribe is much more
<div n="lb"/>doubtful,<sup>7</sup> for it rests solely on the fact that in one place<sup>8</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Bhṛgus and Druhyus are mentioned together, and not Anus and
<div n="lb"/>Druhyus. Ānava is used as an epithet of Agni,<sup>9</sup> but also in the
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘Anu prince,’<sup>10</sup> in one case in conjunction with Turvaśa.<sup>11</sup>

<L>78<pc>1-023<k1>anDra<k2>anDra
{@Andhra@}¦ is the name of a people, and is mentioned with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Puṇḍras, Śabaras, Pulindas,@} and {@Mūtibas,@} as being the outcasts
<div n="lb"/>resulting from the refusal of the fifty eldest sons of {@Viśvāmitra@}
<div n="lb"/>to accept his adoption of {@Śunaḥśepa.@}<sup>1</sup> It may fairly be deduced
[Page1-024+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>from this statement that these people were recognized as non-
<div n="lb"/>Aryan, as the Andhras certainly seem to have been.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 18; Śāṅkh-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Śrauta Sūtra, xv. 26, where
<div n="lb"/>instead of {%udāntyaḥ%} (‘beyond the
<div n="lb"/>borders’) the reading is {%udañcaḥ%} (‘nor-
<div n="lb"/>thern’), but the former is obviously
<div n="lb"/>correct. The Sāṅkhāyana omits the
<div n="lb"/>Pulindas, and has Mūcīpas.</F>
<F>2) Vincent Smith, {%Zeitschrift der Deut-%}

<L>81<pc>1-024<k1>anvAKyAna<k2>anvAKyAna
{@Anvā-khyāna.@}¦ — From the literal translation (‘after-story’) the
<div n="lb"/>meaning of ‘supplementary narrative’ seems to follow. In two<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>of its three occurrences in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa this sense
<div n="lb"/>is hardly felt, the expression being used to indicate a subse-
<div n="lb"/>quent portion of the book itself. But in the third<sup>2</sup> passage it
<div n="lb"/>is distinguished from the {@Itihāsa@} (‘story’) proper, and there
<div n="lb"/>must mean ‘supplementary narrative.’ {%Cf.%} {@Anuvyākhyāna.@}
<F>1) vi. 5, 2, 22; 6, 4, 7 (the reference
<div n="lb"/>is to vi. 6, 4, 8).</F>
<F>2) xi. 1, 6, 9.

<L>82<pc>1-024<k1>apacit<k2>apacit
{@Apa-cit.@}¦ — This word occurs several times in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>It is held by Roth,<sup>2</sup> Zimmer,<sup>3</sup> and others to denote an insect
<div n="lb"/>whose sting produced swellings, etc. ({%glau%}). But Bloomfield<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>shows that the disease, scrofulous swellings, is what is really
<div n="lb"/>meant, as is shown by the rendering ({%gaṇḍa-mālā,%} ‘inflammation
<div n="lb"/>of the glands of the neck’) of Keśava and Sāyaṇa, and by the
<div n="lb"/>parallelism of the later disease, {%apacī,%} the derivation being from
<div n="lb"/>{%apa%} and {%ci,%} ‘to pick off.’
<F>1) vi. 25, 1; 83, 1; vii. 75, 1; 77, 1.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{??} 342, 500.</F>

<L>84<pc>1-025<k1>apaskamBa<k2>apaskamBa

<L>104<pc>1-028<k1>aBizeka<k2>aBizeka
{@Abhi-ṣeka@}¦ (‘besprinkling’). — The Vedic king was conse-
<div n="lb"/>crated after his election with an elaborate ritual, which is fully

<div n="lb"/>the Saṃhitās.<sup>5</sup> The consecration took place by sprinkling with
<div n="lb"/>water ({%abhiṣecanīyā āpaḥ%}).<sup>6</sup> Only kings could be consecrated,
<div n="lb"/>the people not being worthy of it ({%anabhiṣecanīyāḥ%}).<sup>7</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>sprinkler ({%abhiṣektṛ%}) is mentioned in the list of victims at the
<div n="lb"/>Puruṣamedha.<sup>8</sup> The Abhiṣeka is an essential part of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Rājasūya,@} or sacrifice of royal inauguration, being the second
<div n="lb"/>of its component members.

<div n="lb"/>aka Saṃhitā, xv. 6; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, ii. 6; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 1-4.</F>

<L>106<pc>1-029<k1>aByagniEtaSAyana<k2>aByagniEtaSAyana
{@Abhy-agni Aitaśāyana.@}¦ — This man was, according to the
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> unfortunate enough to quarrel with his
<div n="lb"/>father, {@Aitaśa.@} The result was that he and his progeny were
<div n="lb"/>called the worst of the {@Aurvas.@} In the version of the Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> the {@Aitaśāyana Ājāneyas@} take the place of the
<div n="lb"/>Abhyagnis and the {@Bhṛgus@} of the {@Aurvas,@} the latter being
<div n="lb"/>probably a branch of the former family.
<F>1) vi. 33.</F>
<F>2) xxx. 5. {%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 2, 173.</F>

<L>107<pc>1-029<k1>aByAvartincAyamAna<k2>aByAvartincAyamAna
{@Abhyā-vartin Cāyamāna@}¦ appears in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of
<div n="lb"/>Gifts’) in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and as conqueror of the Vṛcīvants
<div n="lb"/>under the leader {@Varaśikha.@} It is probable though not abso-
<div n="lb"/>lutely certain, that he is identical with the {@Sṛñjaya Daivavāta,@}
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the same hymn<sup>2</sup> as having the {@Turvaśas@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Vṛcīvants@} defeated for him by Indra. In this case he would
<div n="lb"/>be prince ({%samrāj%}) of the Sṛñjayas. Daivavāta is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>elsewhere<sup>3</sup> as a worshipper of Agni.
<div n="P"/>Abhyāvartin is also referred to as a Pārthava. Ludwig<sup>4</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt<sup>5</sup> maintained that he is thus a Parthian, the latter
<div n="lb"/>using the evidence of the two places mentioned in the descrip-
<div n="lb"/>tion<sup>6</sup> of Daivavāta's victories, {@Hariyūpīyā@} and {@Yavyāvatī,@} as
<div n="lb"/>proofs for the western position of Abhyāvartin's people in
<div n="lb"/>Arachosia, in Iran. But Zimmer<sup>7</sup> is probably right in holding
<div n="lb"/>that the name Pārthava merely means ‘a descendant of Pṛthu,’
<div n="lb"/>and that its similarity to the Iranian Parthians is only on a par
<div n="lb"/>with the numerous other points of identity between the Indian
<div n="lb"/>and Iranian cultures.
<F>1) vi. 27, 8. 5.</F>
<F>2) vi. 27, 7.</F>
<F>3) iv. 15, 4.</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 198

<L>108<pc>1-030<k1>aBrAtaraH<k2>aBrAtaraH
{@A-bhrātaraḥ@}¦ (‘brotherless’). — The lot of girls without brothers
<div n="lb"/>is referred to in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as unsatisfactory — apparently
<div n="lb"/>they became prostitutes. The Nirukta<sup>2</sup> expressly forbids
<div n="lb"/>marriage with a brotherless maiden, probably because of the
<div n="lb"/>risk of her being made a {%putrikā%} (‘adoptive daughter’) by her
<div n="lb"/>father — that is, any son of hers being counted as belonging to
<div n="lb"/>her father's, instead of to her husband's, family. See {@Ayogū.@}
<F>1) i. 124, 7; iv. 5, 5. {%Cf.%} Av.
<div n="lb"/>i. 17, 1.</F>
<F>2) iii. 5 ({%abhrātrī%}).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 259; Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
<div n="lb"/>328.</F>
<LEND>

<L>109<pc>1-030<k1>aBri<k2>aBri
{@Abhri@}¦ (‘spade’) is a Vedic word<sup>1</sup> of frequent occurrence.
<div n="lb"/>Various possible materials and forms are enumerated in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> It may be made of bamboo or of the wood
<div n="lb"/>of Vikaṅkata or Udumbara. It may be a span or a cubit in size.
<div n="lb"/>It is hollow, and either one or both edges are sharp. From
<div n="lb"/>this it would appear that the handle was made of some wood,
<div n="lb"/>but the head of some metal.
<F>1) Av. iv. 7, 5. 6 ({%abhri-khāte%} is ‘dug
<div n="lb"/>out with a spade,’ not ‘prepared
<div n="lb"/>ground’ with Roth, St. Petersburg
<div n="lb"/>Dictionary, {%s.v.%}); x. 4, 14; {%hiraṇya-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yībhir abhribhiḥ,%} ‘with golden spades’);

<div n="lb"/>xxxvii. 1; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xvi.

<L>119<pc>1-031<k1>ayas<k2>ayas
{@Ayas.@}¦ — The exact metal denoted by this word when used by
<div n="lb"/>itself, as always in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is uncertain. As favouring the
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘bronze’ rather than that of ‘iron’ may perhaps be
<div n="lb"/>cited with Zimmer<sup>2</sup> the fact that Agni is called {%ayo-daṃṣṭra,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘with teeth of Ayas,’<sup>3</sup> with reference to the colour of his flames,
<div n="lb"/>and that the car-seat of Mitra and Varuṇa is called {%ayaḥ-sthūṇa,%}<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>‘with pillars of Ayas’ at the setting of the sun.<sup>5</sup> Moreover,
<div n="lb"/>in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>6</sup> Ayas is enumerated in a list of six
<div n="lb"/>metals: gold ({%hiraṇya%}), Ayas, Śyāma, Loha, lead ({%sīsa%}), tin
<div n="lb"/>({%trapu%}). Here {%śyāma%} (‘swarthy’) and {%loha%} (‘red’) must mean
<div n="lb"/>‘iron’ and ‘copper’ respectively; {%ayas%} would therefore seem to
<div n="lb"/>mean ‘bronze.’ In many passages in the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> and
[Page1-032+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>other books, the Ayas is divided into two species — the {%śyāma%}
<div n="lb"/>(‘iron’) and the {%lohita%} (‘copper’ or ‘bronze’). In the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> a distinction is drawn between Ayas and {%lohāyasa,%}
<div n="lb"/>which may either be a distinction between iron and copper as
<div n="lb"/>understood by Eggeling,<sup>9</sup> or between copper and bronze as held
<div n="lb"/>by Schrader.<sup>10</sup> In one passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>11</sup> the sense of
<div n="lb"/>iron seems certain. Possibly, too, the arrow of the Rigveda,<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>which had a tip of Ayas ({%yasyā ayo mukham%}), was pointed
<div n="lb"/>with iron. Copper, however, is conceivable, and bronze quite
<div n="lb"/>likely.
<div n="P"/>Iron is called {%śyāma ayas%} or {%śyāma%} alone.<sup>13</sup> See also
<div n="lb"/>{@Kārṣṇāyasa.@} Copper is {@Lohāyasa@} or {@Lohitāyasa.@}
<div n="P"/>The smelting ({%dhmā%} ‘to blow’) of the metal is frequently
<div n="lb"/>referred to. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>14</sup> states that if ‘well
<div n="lb"/>smelted’ ({%bahu-dhmātam%}) it is like gold, referring evidently to
<div n="lb"/>bronze. A heater of Ayas is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā,<sup>15</sup> and bowls of Ayas are also spoken of.<sup>16</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 57, 3; 163, 9; iv. 2, 17;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 3, 5.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 52.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 88, 5; x. 87, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. v. 62, 8 ({%cf.%} 7).</F>
<F>5) But this is not convincing, as in
<div n="lb"/>the same verse it is said to be ‘of
<div n="lb"/>golden appearance at the flush of
<div n="lb"/>dawn.’</F>
<F>6) xviii. 13.</F>
<F>7) xi. 3, 1. 7; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iv. 2, 9.</F>
<F>8) v. 4, 1, 2.</F>
<F>9) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 41, 90</F>
<F>10) {%Prehistoric Antiquities,%} 189.</F>
<F>11) v. 28, 1.</F>
<F>12) vi. 75, 15.</F>
<F>13) Av. ix. 5, 4.</F>
<F>14) vi. 1, 3, 5. {%Cf.%} vi. 1, 1, 13; v. 1, 2,
<div n="lb"/>14; xii. 7, 1, 7; 2, 10, etc.</F>
<F>15) xxx. 14; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>10, 1.</F>
<F>16) Av. viii. 10, 22; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, iv. 2, 13.</F>
<LEND>

<L>122<pc>1-033<k1>ayogU<k2>ayogU
{@Ayogū@}¦ is a word of quite doubtful meaning, found in the list
<div n="lb"/>of victims in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>1</sup> It may, like the late
<div n="lb"/>{%āyogava,%} denote a member of a mixed caste (theoretically a
<div n="lb"/>descendant of a Śūdra by a Vaiśya wife).<sup>2</sup> Weber<sup>3</sup> rendered it
<div n="lb"/>as ‘unchaste woman.’<sup>4</sup> Zimmer thinks it denotes a brotherless
<div n="lb"/>maiden who is exposed to the dangers of prostitution ({%cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%āyogava%}).
<F>1) xxx. 5; Taithrīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>1, 1.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Streifen,%} 1, 76, n. b. In the
<div n="lb"/>{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gesellschaft,%} 18, 277, he thought it re-
<div n="lb"/>ferred to dicing ({%ayas%}). Risley, {%Peoples%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of India,%} 250, regards the Āyogavas
<div n="lb"/>as a functional caste of carpenters
<div n="lb"/>({%cf.%} Manu, x. 48).</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 328.</F>

<L>125<pc>1-033<k1>araRya<k2>araRya
{@Araṇya.@}¦ — This term denotes the uncultivated land — not
<div n="lb"/>necessarily forest land — beyond the village. It is contrasted
<div n="lb"/>with home ({%amā%}),<sup>1</sup> and with the plough land ({%kṛṣi%}),<sup>2</sup> being spoken
<div n="lb"/>of as apart ({%tiras%}) from men.<sup>3</sup> It is also contrasted with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Grāma,@}<sup>4</sup> and it is the place where thieves live.<sup>5</sup> The character
<div n="lb"/>of the forest is described in a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> to the
<div n="lb"/>forest spirit (Araṇyānī). The dead are carried there for burial,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and hermits live there.<sup>8</sup> Forest fires were common.<sup>9</sup>
<F>1) Rv. vi. 24, 10.</F>
<F>2) Av. ii. 4, 5.</F>

<F>4) Av. xii. 1, 56; Rv. i. 163, 11;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45; xx. 17.</F>

<div n="lb"/>xiii. 2, 4, 4.</F>

<L>134<pc>1-035<k1>aruRaOpaveSigOtama<k2>aruRaOpaveSigOtama

<L>135<pc>1-035<k1>arunDatI<k2>arunDatI<h>1
1. {@Arundhatī@}¦ is the name of a plant celebrated in several
<div n="lb"/>passages of the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> as possessing healing properties in
<div n="lb"/>case of wounds, as a febrifuge, and as inducing cows to give
<div n="lb"/>milk. The plant was a climber which attached itself to trees
<div n="lb"/>like the {@Plakṣa, Aśvattha, Nyagrodha,@} and {@Parṇa.@}<sup>2</sup> It was
<div n="lb"/>of golden colour ({%hiraṇya-varṇā%}), and had a hairy stem ({%lomaśa-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vakṣaṇā%}).<sup>3</sup> It was also called Silācī, and the {@Lākṣā@} appears to
<div n="lb"/>have been a product of it.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) iv. 12, 1; v. 5, 5. 9; vi. 59, 1. 2;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 7, 6; xix. 38, 1.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 5, 5.</F>
<F>3) Av. v. 5, 7; Pischel, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 1, 174; Bloomfield, {%Zeitschrift%}
<div n="lb"/>{%der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%schaft,%} 48, 574.</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} Whitney's note on Av. iv. 12;
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield, {%Atharvaveda,%} 61.</F>
<LEND>

<L>145<pc>1-037<k1>arya<k2>arya
{@Arya.@}¦ — This word is not common in the older literature, in
<div n="lb"/>places where the quantity of the first vowel is fixed as short, except
<div n="lb"/>in a mere adjectival sense. Geldner,<sup>1</sup> indeed, contends that no
<div n="lb"/>other sense is anywhere needed; but Roth<sup>2</sup> and Zimmer<sup>3</sup> agree
<div n="lb"/>in thinking that in several passages of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the word has the same sense as {@Ārya,@} and this appears probable.
<div n="lb"/>Whether it is necessary to ascribe this sense to the word in the
<div n="lb"/>compound {%arya-patnī%}<sup>5</sup> applied to the waters set free by Indra,
<div n="lb"/>is more doubtful. The commentator, Mahīdhara,<sup>6</sup> suggests
<div n="lb"/>that the word means a {@Vaiśya,@} not an {@Ārya@} generally. This
<div n="lb"/>view is supported by the explanation in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>of one of the passages of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>8</sup> But though
<div n="lb"/>the use of Arya to denote a Vaiśya became common later, it is
<div n="lb"/>not clear that it was original.
<F>1) {%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 96.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 214, 215.</F>
<F>4) xiv. 30; xx. 17; xxiii. 21; xxvi. 2.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} also Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 5;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 3. In
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, xix. 32, 8, an analogous
<div n="lb"/>form occurs, as contrasted with {%brāh-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%maṇa, rājanya,%} and {%śūdra;%} but even
<div n="lb"/>there Whitney renders it as ‘Āryan.’
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} xix. 62, 1; Rv. viii. 94, 3; Pischel,
<div n="lb"/>{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gesellschaft,%} 40, 125.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 6, 5; x. 43, 8.</F>
<F>6) On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii.
<div n="lb"/>30.</F>
<F>7) xiii. 2, 9, 8. Contrast Śāṅkhāyana
<div n="lb"/>Srauta Sūtra, xvi. 4, 4 {%et seq.,%} where
<div n="lb"/>Arya appears to be taken in the wider
<div n="lb"/>sense.</F>
<F>8) xxiii. 30. {%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda, 3, 212; Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} x. 6; Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Noten,%} 1, 126, 363.</F>
<LEND>

<L>162<pc>1-039<k1>avata<k2>avata
{@Avata,@}¦ a word occurring several times in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> denotes
<div n="lb"/>a well, artificially made ({%khan%} ‘to dig’) in contrast with a spring
[Page1-040+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>({%utsa%}), though the latter expression is also applied to an artificial
<div n="lb"/>well. Such wells were covered by the makers,<sup>2</sup> and are described
<div n="lb"/>as unfailing ({%a-kṣita%}) and full of water.<sup>3</sup> The water was raised
<div n="lb"/>by a wheel ({%cakra%}) of stone, to which was fastened a strap
<div n="lb"/>({%varatrā%}), with a pail ({%kośa%})<sup>4</sup> attached to it. When raised it was
<div n="lb"/>poured ({%siñc%}) into buckets ({%āhāva%}) of wood.<sup>5</sup> Sometimes those
<div n="lb"/>wells appear to have been used for irrigation purposes, the water
<div n="lb"/>being led off into broad channels ({%sārmī suṣirā%}).<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) i. 55, 8; 85, 10. 11; 116, 9, 22;
<div n="lb"/>130, 2; iv. 17, 16; 50, 3; viii. 49, 6;
<div n="lb"/>62, 6; 72, 10, 12; x. 25, 4; 101,
<div n="lb"/>5. 7. {%Cf.%} Nirukta, v. 26.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 55, 8.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 101, 6, etc.</F>
<F>4) {%Aṃsatra-kośam,%} Rv. x. 101, 7, is best
<div n="lb"/>thus rendered. For the stone wheel
<div n="lb"/>({%aśma-cakra%}) which was above ({%uccā-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%cakra%}), see Rv. x. 101, 7; viii. 72, 10. For
<div n="lb"/>the {%varatrā,%} see Rv. x. 101, 6. Perhaps
<div n="lb"/>{%kū-cakra%} in Rv. x. 102, 11, is another
<div n="lb"/>name for the wheel, but {%cf.%} St. Peters-
<div n="lb"/>burg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 101, 6. 7.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii. 69, 12. {%Cf.%} Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 156, 157; Geldner,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 14.</F>

<L>168<pc>1-040<k1>avi<k2>avi
{@Avi.@}¦ — ‘Sheep’ are repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda, and
<div n="lb"/>later, often in conjunction with goats ({%aja%}). The wolf ({%vṛka%})
<div n="lb"/>was their great enemy,<sup>1</sup> and they were tended by shepherds.<sup>2</sup>
[Page1-041+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>Sheep as well as kine were captured from the enemy.<sup>3</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Soma sieve was made of sheep's wool, and is repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>referred to ({%avi, meṣī, avya, avyaya%}).<sup>4</sup> Considerable herds
<div n="lb"/>must have existed, as Ṛjrāśva is said<sup>5</sup> to have slain one
<div n="lb"/>hundred rams, and in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’)<sup>6</sup> a hundred
<div n="lb"/>sheep are mentioned as a gift. The ({%meṣa,%}<sup>7</sup> {%vṛṣṇi%}<sup>8</sup> ) ram was
<div n="lb"/>sometimes castrated ({%petva%}).<sup>9</sup> The main use of sheep was their
<div n="lb"/>wool; hence the expression ‘woolly’ ({%ūrṇāvatī%})<sup>10</sup> is employed to
<div n="lb"/>designate a sheep. In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>11</sup> the ram is
<div n="lb"/>described as ‘woolly,’ and as ‘the skin of beasts, quadruped and
<div n="lb"/>biped,’ with reference to the use of its wool as clothing for men
<div n="lb"/>and shelter for animals. Pūṣan is said<sup>12</sup> to weave raiment from
<div n="lb"/>the wool of sheep. Normally the sheep stayed out at pasture;
<div n="lb"/>in an obscure passage of the Rigveda<sup>13</sup> reference appears to be
<div n="lb"/>made to rams in stall. Gandhāra<sup>14</sup> ewes were famous for their
<div n="lb"/>wool. Pischel<sup>15</sup> considers that the {@Paruṣṇī@}<sup>16</sup> was named from
<div n="lb"/>its richness in sheep, {%parus%}<sup>17</sup> denoting the ‘flocks’ of wool.
<F>1) Av. v. 8, 4; Rv. viii. 34, 3; 66, 8.</F>
<F>2) {%Avi-pāla,%} Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx.
<div n="lb"/>11; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iv. 1, 5, 2;
<div n="lb"/>{%avi-pa,%} Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 9, 1.</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 86, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. ix. 109, 16; 36, 4, etc. See
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1,
<div n="lb"/>203.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 116, 17.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii. 67, 3.</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 43, 6; 116, 16, etc.</F>
<F>8) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 7, 4, etc.</F>
<F>9) Rv. vii. 18, 17; Av. iv. 4, 8;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 22, 1; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 58; 59.</F>
<F>10) Rv. viii. 67, 3. {%Cf.%} x. 75, 8; so
<div n="lb"/>{%urā,%} x. 95, 3.</F>
<F>11) xiii. 50.</F>
<F>12) Rv. x. 26, 6.</F>
<F>13) x. 106, 5.</F>
<F>14) Rv. i. 126, 7.</F>
<F>15) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 210.</F>
<F>16) Rv. iv. 22, 2; v. 52, 9.</F>

<div n="lb"/>230; Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 348.</F>

<L>171<pc>1-042<k1>aSva<k2>aSva
{@Aśva@}¦ is the commonest word for ‘horse’ in the Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature. The horse is also called ‘the runner’ ({%atya%}), ‘the
<div n="lb"/>swift’ ({%arvant%}), ‘the strong,’ for pulling ({%vājin%}), ‘the runner’
<div n="lb"/>({%sapti%}), and ‘the speeding’ ({%haya%}). The mare is termed {%aśvā,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%atyā, arvatī, vaḍavā,%} etc. Horses of various colour were known,
<div n="lb"/>dun ({%harita, hari%}), ruddy ({%aruṇa, aruṣa, piśaṅga, rohita%}), dark
<div n="lb"/>brown ({%śyāva%}), white ({%śveta%}), etc. A white horse with black
<div n="lb"/>ears is mentioned in the Atharvaveda as of special value.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Horses were highly prized,<sup>2</sup> and were not rare, as Roth<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thought, for as many as four hundred mares are mentioned in
<div n="lb"/>one Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’).<sup>4</sup> They were on occasion
<div n="lb"/>ornamented with pearls and gold.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="P"/>Mares were preferred for drawing chariots because of their
<div n="lb"/>swiftness and sureness.<sup>6</sup> They were also used for drawing
<div n="lb"/>carts, but were not ordinarily so employed.<sup>7</sup> No mention is
<div n="lb"/>made of riding in battle, but for other purposes it was not
<div n="lb"/>unknown.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>Horses were often kept in stalls,<sup>9</sup> and fed there.<sup>10</sup> But they
<div n="lb"/>were also allowed to go out to grass,<sup>11</sup> and were then hobbled.<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>They were watered to cool them after racing.<sup>13</sup> Their attendants
[Page1-043+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>are frequently referred to ({%aśva-pāla,%}<sup>14</sup> {%aśva-pa,%}<sup>15</sup> {%aśva-pati%}).<sup>16</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Stallions were frequently castrated ({%vadhri%}).<sup>17</sup>
<div n="P"/>Besides reins ({%raśmayaḥ%}), reference is made to halters
<div n="lb"/>({%aśvābhidhānī%}),<sup>18</sup> and whips ({%aśvājani%}).<sup>19</sup> See also {@Ratha.@}
<div n="P"/>Horses from the Indus were of special value,<sup>20</sup> as also horses
<div n="lb"/>from the {@Sarasvatī.@}
<F>1) Av. v. 17, 15.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 83, 1; iv. 32, 17; v. 4, 11;

<L>172<pc>1-043<k1>aSvatara<k2>aSvatara
{@Aśva-tara, Aśva-tarī@}¦ are respectively the masculine and
<div n="lb"/>feminine name of ‘mule.’ These animals are mentioned
<div n="lb"/>frequently from the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> onwards. They were known
<div n="lb"/>not to be fruitful,<sup>2</sup> and were probably considered inferior to
<div n="lb"/>horses,<sup>3</sup> but a mule-car was quite common.<sup>4</sup>

<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 4.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 2. 3.

<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 1, 40.</F>

<L>173<pc>1-043<k1>aSvatTa<k2>aSvatTa<h>1
1. {@Aśva-ttha@}¦ (‘horse-stand’) is one of India's greatest trees,
<div n="lb"/>the {%Ficus religiosa,%} later called {%pippala%}<sup>1</sup> (now Peepal). Vessels
<div n="lb"/>made of the wood of the Aśvattha are mentioned in the Rigveda,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the tree itself is constantly referred to later.<sup>3</sup> Its hard
<div n="lb"/>wood formed the upper of the two pieces of wood used for
<div n="lb"/>kindling fire, the lower being of {@Śamī.@}<sup>4</sup> It planted its roots in
<div n="lb"/>shoots of other trees, especially the {@Khadira,@} and destroyed
<div n="lb"/>them;<sup>5</sup> hence it is called ‘the destroyer’ ({%vaibādha%}). Its berries
[Page1-044+ 37]
<div n="lb"/>are referred to as sweet, and as eaten by birds.<sup>6</sup> The gods are
<div n="lb"/>said to sit under it in the third heaven.<sup>7</sup> It and {@Nyagrodha@}
<div n="lb"/>are styled the ‘crested ones’ ({%śikhaṇḍin%}).<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) The word {%pippala%} as a neuter occurs
<div n="lb"/>once in the Rv. (i. 164, 20) designating
<div n="lb"/>the berry of the Peepal-tree.</F>
<F>2) i. 135, 8; x. 97, 5.</F>
<F>3) Atharvaveda, iii. 6, 1; iv. 37, 4, etc.</F>
<F>4) Av. vi. 11, 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>xi. 5, 1, 13.</F>
<F>5) Av. iii. 6.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 164, 20. 22.</F>
<F>7) Av. v. 4, 3. {%Cf.%} Chāndogya Upani-
<div n="lb"/>ṣad, viii. 5, 3; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, i. 3.</F>
<F>8) Av. iv. 37, 4. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%disches Leben,%} 57, 58.</F>
<LEND>

<L>189<pc>1-045<k1>azwakarRI<k2>azwakarRI
{@Aṣṭa-karṇī@}¦ is an expression which occurs in one passage of
<div n="lb"/>the Ṛigveda,<sup>1</sup> and which Roth<sup>2</sup> was at first inclined to interpret
[Page1-046+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>as a proper name. There can, however, be no doubt that
<div n="lb"/>it means a cow, not a man, as suggested by Grassmann. The
<div n="lb"/>exact reason why a cow should be so described is uncertain.
<div n="lb"/>Roth<sup>3</sup> was later inclined to see in it the sense ‘having pierced
<div n="lb"/>ears,’ similar epithets being at a later period known to Pāṇini<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>({%bhinna-karṇa, chinna-karṇa%}). Grassmann's more obvious
<div n="lb"/>rendering, ‘having the sign for (the number) 8 marked on the ear,’
<div n="lb"/>is supported by the similar epithets, ‘having the mark of a lute on
<div n="lb"/>the ear’ ({%karkari-karṇyaḥ%}), ‘having the mark of a sickle on the ear’
<div n="lb"/>({%dātra-karṇyaḥ%}), ‘having the mark of a stake on the ear’ ({%sthūṇā-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%karṇyaḥ%}), ‘having the ears bored’ ({%chidra-karṇyaḥ%}), and {%viṣtya-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%karṇyaḥ,%} given in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<sup>5</sup> The simple mean-
<div n="lb"/>ing, ‘with marked ears,’ is, however, supported by the same
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Maitrāyaṇī, where the verb {%akṣ%} occurs in the
<div n="lb"/>sense ‘to mark.’ In the Atharvaveda the mark used is the
<div n="lb"/>Mithuna, no doubt as a magical device to secure fertility.
<div n="P"/>The marking of ears was apparently a regular practice. It is
<div n="lb"/>twice referred to in the Atharvaveda.<sup>6</sup> The mark is termed
<div n="lb"/>{%lakṣman,%}<sup>7</sup> and was made with a copper-knife<sup>8</sup> ({%lohita%}). The
<div n="lb"/>Maitrayaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>9</sup> forbids the use of an arrow-shaft ({%tejana%}),
<div n="lb"/>or of iron, but permits that of a stem of sugar-cane ({%ikṣu-kāṇḍa%})
<div n="lb"/>or copper.

<L>200<pc>1-048<k1>ahan<k2>ahan
{@Ahan,@}¦ ‘day.’ Like other peoples, the Indians used night
<div n="lb"/>as a general expression of time as well as day, but by no means
<div n="lb"/>predominantly.<sup>1</sup> Night is also termed the dark ({%kṛṣṇa%}), as
[Page1-049+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>opposed to the light ({%arjuna%}), day.<sup>2</sup> Aho-rātra<sup>3</sup> is a regular
<div n="lb"/>term for ‘day and night’ combined.
<div n="P"/>The day itself is variously divided. In the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>a division into ‘the rising sun’ ({%udyan sūryaḥ%}), ‘the coming
<div n="lb"/>together of the cows’ ({%saṃ-gava%}), ‘midday’ ({%madhyaṃ-dina%}),
<div n="lb"/>‘afternoon’ ({%aparāhṇa%}), and ‘sunset’ ({%astaṃ-yan%}) is found.
<div n="lb"/>In the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> the same series appears with
<div n="lb"/>‘early’ ({%prātar%}) and ‘evening’ ({%sāyāhna%}) substituted for the
<div n="lb"/>first and last members, while a shorter list gives {%prātar,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%saṃgava, sāyam.%} In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>6</sup> there is the
<div n="lb"/>series ‘dawn’ {%(uṣas), saṃgava, madhyaṃdina,%} and {%aparāhṇa.%}
<div n="P"/>The morning is also, according to Zimmer, called {%api-śarvara,%}<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as the time when the dark is just past. It is named {%svasara,%}<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as the time when the cows are feeding, before the first milking
<div n="lb"/>at the {%saṃgava,%} or when the birds are awakening.<sup>9</sup> It is also
<div n="lb"/>called {%pra-pitva,%}<sup>10</sup> according to Zimmer.<sup>11</sup> But Geldner<sup>12</sup> points
<div n="lb"/>out that that term refers to the late midday, which also is
<div n="lb"/>called {%api-śarvara,%} as bordering on the coming night, being the
<div n="lb"/>time when day is hastening to its close, as in a race. From
<div n="lb"/>another point of view, evening is called {%abhi-pitva,%}<sup>13</sup> the time
<div n="lb"/>when all come to rest. Or again, morning and evening are
<div n="lb"/>denoted as the dawning of the sun ({%uditā sūryasya%}), or its
<div n="lb"/>setting ({%ni-mruc%}). The midday is regularly {%madhyam ahnām,%}<sup>14</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{%madhye,%}<sup>15</sup> or {%madhyaṃdina. Saṃgava%}<sup>16</sup> is the forenoon, between
<div n="lb"/>the early morning ({%prātar%}) and midday ({%madhyaṃdina%}).
<div n="P"/>The divisions of time less than the day are seldom precisely
<div n="lb"/>given. In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>17</sup> however, a day and
[Page1-050+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>night make up 30 {%muhūrtas;%} 1 {%muhūrta%} = 15 {%kṣipra;%} 1 {%kṣipra%} =
<div n="lb"/>15 {%etarhi;%} 1 {%etarhi%} = 15 {%idāni;%} 1 {%idāni%} = 15 breathings; 1 breath-
<div n="lb"/>ing = 1 spiration; 1 spiration = 1 twinkling ({%nimeṣa%}), etc. In
<div n="lb"/>the Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka<sup>18</sup> the series is {%dhvaṃsayo, nimeṣāḥ,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%kāṣṭhāḥ, kalāḥ, kṣanā, muhūrtā, ahorātrāḥ.%} A thirtyfold division
<div n="lb"/>of day as well as of night is seen in one passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>19</sup> by Zimmer, who compares the Babylonian sixty-
<div n="lb"/>fold division of the day and night. But the expression used — 
<div n="lb"/>thirty Yojanas — is too vague and obscure — Bergaigne<sup>20</sup> refers
<div n="lb"/>it to the firmament — to build any theory upon with safety.
<div n="P"/>The longer divisions of time are regularly ‘half month’
<div n="lb"/>({%ardha-māsa%}), ‘month’ ({%māsa%}), ‘season’ ({%ṛtu%}), and ‘year’
<div n="lb"/>({%saṃvatsara%}), which often<sup>21</sup> occur in this sequence after
<div n="lb"/>{%ahorātrāṇi%} (‘days and nights’).
<F>1) Rv. iv. 16, 19; viii. 26, 3; i. 70, 4. {%Cf.%} Av. x. 7, 42.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 9. 1.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 190, 2; Av. xiii. 3, 8, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 41, etc.</F>
<F>4) ix. 6, 45.</F>
<F>5) i. 5, 3, 1; 4, 9, 2.</F>
<F>6) iv. 2, 11.</F>
<F>7) Rv. iii. 9, 7; {%cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Noten,%} 1, 230.</F>
<F>8) Rv. ii. 34, 8; ix. 94, 2.</F>
<F>9) Rv. ii. 19, 2; 34, 5.</F>
<F>10) Rv. vii. 41, 4; viii. 1, 29. Sieg.
<div n="lb"/>{%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 127 {%et seq.,%}
<div n="lb"/>interprets {%paritakmyāyām%} (Rv. i. 116, 15)
<div n="lb"/>similarly.</F>
<F>11) {%Altindisches Leben.%} 362.</F>
<F>12) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 155-179.</F>
<F>13) Rv. i. 126, 3; iv. 34, 5.</F>
<F>14) Rv. vii. 41, 4.</F>
<F>15) Rv. viii. 27, 20.</F>
<F>16) {%Cf.%} Rv. v. 76, 3 ({%saṃgave, prātar%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ahno, madhyaṃdine%}); Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ii. 1, 1, 3; Jaiminīya Upaniṣad
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 12, 4; Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iii. 18, 14; Geldner, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 3, 112, 113. Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>362, places it too early — before the
<div n="lb"/>cows are driven out.</F>
<F>17) xii. 3, 2, 5. {%Cf.%} Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iii. 10, 1, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>18) vii. 20. {%Cf.%} Śāṅkhāyana Srauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xiv. 78 {%et seq.;%} Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Streifen,%} 1, 92-95.</F>
<F>19) Rv. i. 123, 8.</F>
<F>20) {%Religion Védique.%} 3, 283 {%et seq.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v. kratu.%}</F>
<F>21) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 15;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 7; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28; Śāṅkhāyana
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, vii. 20; Bṛhadāraṇyaka

<L>202<pc>1-050<k1>ahi<k2>ahi
{@Ahi.@}¦ — This word occurs frequently from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards to denote ‘snake.’ Reference is several times<sup>2</sup> made
<div n="lb"/>to its casting its slough. Mention is also made of the serpent's
<div n="lb"/>peculiar movement,<sup>3</sup> which earns for it the designation<sup>4</sup> of
<div n="lb"/>‘the toothed rope’ ({%datvatī rajjuḥ%}). The poisonous character
[Page1-051+ 39]
<div n="lb"/>of its bite is spoken of,<sup>5</sup> as well as the torpidity of the reptile
<div n="lb"/>in winter, when it creeps into the earth.<sup>6</sup> The cast skin is
<div n="lb"/>used as an amulet against highwaymen.<sup>7</sup> Mention is made of
<div n="lb"/>a mythical horse, Paidva, which the Aśvins gave to Pedu as
<div n="lb"/>a protection against snakes,<sup>8</sup> and which is invoked as a
<div n="lb"/>destroyer of serpents.<sup>9</sup> The ichneumon ({%nakula%}) is regarded
<div n="lb"/>as their deadly enemy, and as immune against their poison
<div n="lb"/>through the use of a healing plant,<sup>10</sup> while men kill them with
<div n="lb"/>sticks<sup>11</sup> or strike off their heads.<sup>12</sup>
<div n="P"/>Many species of snakes are mentioned: see {@Aghāśva,@}

<L>207<pc>1-052<k1>AKu<k2>AKu
{@Ākhu.@}¦ — The exact sense of this word is uncertain. Zimmer<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>renders it ‘mole,’ while Roth<sup>2</sup> prefers ‘mouse’ or ‘rat.’ It is
<div n="lb"/>frequently mentioned in the later Saṃhitās,<sup>3</sup> and is known to
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda,<sup>4</sup> where, however, the word is regarded by Pischel<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as having acquired the secondary sense of ‘thief.’ This is
<div n="lb"/>denied by Hillebrandt.<sup>6</sup>

<div n="lb"/>by Bloomfield. {%Hymns of the Athar-%}

<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda, 317, 318.</F>

<L>208<pc>1-052<k1>AKyAna<k2>AKyAna
{@Ā-khyāna.@}¦ — In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> we hear of the
<div n="lb"/>Śaunaḥśepa Ākhyāna, ‘the story of {@Śunaḥśepa,@}’ which is told
<div n="lb"/>by the Hotṛ priest at the Rājasūya (‘royal inauguration’). The
<div n="lb"/>series of stories<sup>2</sup> used at the Aśvamedha (‘horse sacrifice’)
<div n="lb"/>during the year while the sacrificial horse is allowed to wander
<div n="lb"/>at its will is called the ‘cyclic’ ({%pari-plavam%}). The Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> mentions also Ākhyāna-vids (‘men versed in
<div n="lb"/>tales’), who tell the Sauparṇa legend, elsewhere<sup>4</sup> known as a
<div n="lb"/>{@Vyākhyāna.@} Yāska, in the Nirukta,<sup>5</sup> frequently uses the term,
<div n="lb"/>sometimes in a pregnant sense as denoting the doctrine of the
<div n="lb"/>Aitihāsikas or traditional interpreters of the Rigveda.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) vii. 18, 10. {%Cf.%} Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xv. 27.</F>
<F>2) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa. xiii. 4, 3, 2.
<div n="lb"/>15.</F>
<F>3) iii. 25, 1.</F>
<F>4) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 6. 2. 7.</F>
<F>5) v. 21; vii. 7.</F>
<F>6) xi. 19; 25.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Sieg. {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda.%}
