<L>218<pc>1-053<k1>Aji<k2>Aji
{@Āji@}¦ is constantly used in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the later
<div n="lb"/>literature to express the sense of ‘a race,’ and only seldom
<div n="lb"/>denotes ‘a battle.’ {@Horse@}-racing was one of the favourite
<div n="lb"/>amusements of the {@Vedic@} Indian,<sup>2</sup> the other being dicing
[Page1-054+ 65]
<div n="lb"/>({@Akṣa@}). The racecourse, called Kāṣṭhā<sup>3</sup> or Āji<sup>4</sup> itself, appears
<div n="lb"/>from the Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> to have been a quasi-circular one to
<div n="lb"/>a mark ({%kārṣman%}<sup>6</sup> ) and back again. In the Rigveda the
<div n="lb"/>course is described as broad ({%urvī%}) and the distance as
<div n="lb"/>measured out ({%apāvṛktā aratnayaḥ%}).<sup>7</sup> Prizes ({%dhana%}) were
<div n="lb"/>offered ({%dhā%}),<sup>8</sup> and eagerly competed for. Other words for
<div n="lb"/>victory and the prize are {%kāra%}<sup>9</sup> and {%bhara;%}<sup>10</sup> and to ‘run a
<div n="lb"/>race’ is described by the expressions {%ājim aj, i, dhāv, sṛ.%}<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The person who instituted a race is referred to as {%āji-sṛt,%}<sup>12</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Indra is called {%āji-kṛt%}<sup>13</sup> (‘race-maker’), and {%āji-pati%}<sup>14</sup> (‘lord
<div n="lb"/>of the race’).
<div n="P"/>The swift steeds ({%vājin, atya%}) used for the races were often
<div n="lb"/>washed and adorned.<sup>15</sup> According to Pischel<sup>16</sup> the name of
<div n="lb"/>one swift mare is preserved — viz., Viśpalā,<sup>17</sup> whose broken leg
<div n="lb"/>was replaced by the Aśvins in a race; but the interpretation
<div n="lb"/>is very doubtful. Geldner<sup>18</sup> has also found a comic picture of
<div n="lb"/>a horse-chariot race in the Mudgala hymn in the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>but Bloomfield<sup>19</sup> has shown that that interpretation is un-
<div n="lb"/>sound. Pischel<sup>20</sup> also seeks to show that races were run in
<div n="lb"/>honour of gods, but the evidence for the theory is inadequate.<sup>21</sup>
[Page1-055+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>A formal race, however, is a feature of the ritual of the Rājasūya
<div n="lb"/>or royal consecration.<sup>22</sup>
<F>1) v. 37, 7; vi. 24, 6, etc.</F>
<F>2) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 291;
<div n="lb"/>Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 120; 2.
<div n="lb"/>1 {%seq.%}</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 80, 8; Av. ii. 14, 6.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iv. 24, 8; Av. xiii. 2, 4.</F>
<F>5) ii. 14, 6; xiii. 2, 4.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ix. 36, 1; 74, 8.</F>
<F>7) The sense is doubtful in Rv. viii.
<div n="lb"/>80, 8. Zimmer suggests that it may
<div n="lb"/>mean ‘the course is straight,’ without
<div n="lb"/>twistings, for which idea {%cf.%} Geldner,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 160, quoting the
<div n="lb"/>comparison of the courser's race with
<div n="lb"/>a bowstring (Rv. iii. 53, 24). It is also
<div n="lb"/>rendered ‘the barriers are removed.’</F>

<div n="lb"/>1, 120, n. 2, {%dhana%} is from {%dhan,%} ‘start.’

<div n="lb"/>i. 112, 7. 10; ii. 10, 6; viii. 3, 15, etc.</F>

<L>225<pc>1-056<k1>ARi<k2>ARi
{@Āṇi.@}¦ — This word, which is found in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> but rarely

<L>232<pc>1-057<k1>ATarvaRa<k2>ATarvaRa
{@Ātharvaṇa,@}¦ a patronymic formed from the name of the
<div n="lb"/>mythic Atharvan, is found normally in the plural neuter as a
<div n="lb"/>designation of the hymns of the Atharvans. This use appears
<div n="lb"/>in the late nineteenth book of the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> and in the
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> In the singular the expression
<div n="lb"/>Ātharvaṇa (Veda), though not occurring till the Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad,<sup>3</sup> is earlier than the term ‘Atharvaveda,’ which is
<div n="lb"/>first found in the Sūtras.<sup>4</sup> In the Nidāna Sūtra<sup>5</sup> Ātharvaṇikas,
<div n="lb"/>or ‘followers of the Atharvaveda,’ appear.
<div n="P"/>Specific but mainly mythical Ātharvaṇas are {@Kabandha,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Bṛhaddiva, Bhiṣaj, Dadhyaṅc,@} and {@Vicārin.@}
<F>1) xix. 23, 1.</F>
<F>2) xii. 9, 10.</F>
<F>3) vii. 1, 2, 4; 2, 1; 7, 1.</F>
<F>4) Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xvi. 2,
<div n="lb"/>10, etc.</F>

<L>251<pc>1-060<k1>AyuDa<k2>AyuDa
{@Ā-yudha,@}¦ ‘weapon,’ in its widest sense covers the whole
<div n="lb"/>of a Kṣatriya's warlike equipment, which in the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> is summed up as horse-chariot ({%aśva-ratha%}), bow
<div n="lb"/>and arrows ({%iṣu-dhanva%}), and corselet ({%kavaca%}). As the bow and
<div n="lb"/>arrow ({%iṣu, dhanvan%}) were essential as the main weapons of
<div n="lb"/>the Vedic fighter, they are probably meant when Āyudha is
<div n="lb"/>used specifically of weapons, as often from the Rigveda<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards. The battle hymn in the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> confirms this
<div n="lb"/>view, as it presents to us the warrior armed with bow and
<div n="lb"/>arrow on his chariot, and clad in armour ({@Varman@}), with a
<div n="lb"/>guard ({@Hastaghna@}) on the left arm to avoid the friction of the
<div n="lb"/>bow-string. The corselet was not a single solid piece of metal,
<div n="lb"/>but consisted of many pieces fitted together ({%syūta%});<sup>4</sup> it may
[Page1-061+ 41]
<div n="lb"/>have been made either of metal plates or, as is more likely, of
<div n="lb"/>some stiff material plated with metal. In addition the warrior
<div n="lb"/>wore a helmet ({@Śiprā@}). There is no trace of the use of a
<div n="lb"/>shield, nor is there any clear record of the employment of
<div n="lb"/>greaves or other guard for the feet.<sup>5</sup> Skill in the use of weapons
<div n="lb"/>is referred to in the Rigveda.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>It is doubtful whether sling stones ({@Adri, Aśani@}) were in
<div n="lb"/>ordinary use. The hook ({%aṅkuśa%})<sup>7</sup> also is merely a divine
<div n="lb"/>weapon, and the axe ({%svadhiti,%}<sup>8</sup> {%vāśī, paraśu%}) does not occur in
<div n="lb"/>mortal combats. For the use of the spear see {@Ṛṣṭi, Rambhiṇī,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Śakti, Śaru;@} of the sword, {@Asi, Kṛti.@} Neither weapon can be
<div n="lb"/>considered ordinary in warfare, nor was the club ({@Vajra@}) used.
<div n="lb"/>For the modes of warfare see {@Saṃgrāma.@}
<F>1) vii. 19, 2.</F>
<F>2) i. 39, 2; 61. 13; 92, 1; ii. 30, 9.
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Av. vi. 133, 2, etc.</F>
<F>3) vi. 75.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 31, 15.</F>
<F>5) Grassmann saw greaves in {%vaṭūriṇā%}
<div n="lb"/>{%padā%} in Rv. i. 133, 2, but this is most
<div n="lb"/>improbable.</F>
<F>6) i. 92, 1. {%Cf.%} Geldner, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 3, 183; Hopkins, {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%American Oriental Society,%} 13, 295.</F>
<F>7) Rv. viii. 17, 10; x. 44, 9; 134, 6;
<div n="lb"/>Av. vi. 83, 3. {%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts.%}
<div n="lb"/>5, 87.</F>
<F>8) Rv. v. 32, 10; ix. 67, 30; x. 43, 9.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 298-
<div n="lb"/>301; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts.%} 5, 469-472;
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 13, 281 {%et seq.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>260<pc>1-062<k1>ArjIka<k2>ArjIka
{@Ārjīka@}¦<sup>1</sup> and {@Ārjīkīya@}<sup>2</sup> (masc.), {@Ārjīkīyā@}<sup>3</sup> (fem.). — The two
<div n="lb"/>masculine forms probably denote the people or land, while the
<div n="lb"/>feminine word designates the river of the land. Hillebrandt<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>locates the country in or near Kaśmir, as Arrian<sup>5</sup> mentions
<div n="lb"/>Arsaces, brother of Abhisares, who presumably took his name
<div n="lb"/>from his people, and Abhisāra bordered on Kaśmir. Pischel<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>accepts Ārjīka as designating a country, which he, however,
<div n="lb"/>thinks cannot be identified. But neither Roth<sup>7</sup> nor Zimmer<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>recognizes the word as a proper name. On the other hand,
<div n="lb"/>all authorities agree in regarding Ārjīkīyā as the name of a
[Page1-063+ 38]
<div n="lb"/>river. {@Roth@}<sup>9</sup> does so in one passage<sup>10</sup> only, elsewhere seeing
<div n="lb"/>references to Soma vessels; but it seems necessary to treat the
<div n="lb"/>word alike in all passages containing it. Zimmer does not
<div n="lb"/>locate the river, and Pischel denies the possibility of its
<div n="lb"/>identification. Hillebrandt thinks it may have been the
<div n="lb"/>Upper Indus, or the {@Vitastā@} (the Jhelum), or some other
<div n="lb"/>stream. Grassmann follows Yāska<sup>11</sup> in identifying it with the
<div n="lb"/>the {@Vipāś@} (Beäs), but this is rendered improbable by the
<div n="lb"/>position of the name in the hymn in praise of rivers ({%nadī-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%stuti%}).<sup>12</sup> Brunnhofer<sup>13</sup> identifies it with the Arghesan, a tributary
<div n="lb"/>of the Arghanab.
<F>1) Singular: Rv. viii. 7, 29; ix. 113, 2.
<div n="lb"/>Plural: ix. 65, 23.</F>
<F>2) Rv. viii. 64, 11.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 75, 5.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 126-137.</F>
<F>5) Anabasis, v. 29, 4.</F>
<F>6) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 209, 217.</F>
<F>7) St. Petersburg Dictionary.</F>
<F>8) {%Altindisches Leben.%} 12-14.</F>
<F>9) {%Op. cit., s.v. suṣomā.%}</F>
<F>10) Rv. x. 75, 5.</F>
<F>11) Nirukta, ix. 26.</F>
<F>12) Rv. x. 75.</F>
<F>13) {%Iran und Turan,%} 52.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Max Mūller, {%Sacred Books of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%East,%} 32, 398; 399.</F>

<L>263<pc>1-063<k1>Artava<k2>Artava
{@Ārtava.@}¦ — This expression denotes a portion of the year
<div n="lb"/>consisting of more seasons than one. But it does not bear the
<div n="lb"/>exact sense of ‘half-year,’ as suggested by Zimmer.<sup>1</sup> This is
<div n="lb"/>shown by the fact that it occurs regularly in the plural, not in
<div n="lb"/>the dual. In the Atharvaveda it occurs between seasons and
<div n="lb"/>years ({%hāyana%}),<sup>2</sup> but also in the combinations, ‘seasons, Ārtavas,
<div n="lb"/>months, years,;<sup>3</sup> ‘half-months, months, Ārtavas, seasons’;<sup>4</sup>
[Page1-064+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>‘seasons, Ārtavas, months, half-months, days and nights, day’;<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā ‘months, seasons, Ārtavas, the
<div n="lb"/>year,’<sup>6</sup> or simply with the seasons.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) {%Altindisches Leben.%} 374.</F>
<F>2) iii. 10, 9.</F>
<F>3) iii. 10, 10.</F>
<F>4) xi. 7, 20. {%Cf.%} xv. 6, 6; 17, 6.</F>
<F>5) xvi. 8, 18.</F>
<F>6) xxii. 28.</F>
<F>7) Av. v. 28, 2. 13; x. 6, 18; 7, 5;
<div n="lb"/>xi. 3, 17; 6, 17; Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>vii. 2, 6, 1, 3. Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, i, 3.
<div n="lb"/>cited in this sense in the St. Petersburg
<div n="lb"/>Dictionary, is not so to be understood,
<div n="lb"/>as the word there is merely adjectival.</F>
<LEND>

<L>264<pc>1-064<k1>ArtnI<k2>ArtnI
{@Ārtnī@}¦ denotes the end of the bow to which the bow-string
<div n="lb"/>({%jyā%}) was attached.<sup>1</sup> The string was not normally kept
<div n="lb"/>fastened to both ends of the bow, but when an arrow was to
<div n="lb"/>be shot it was strung taut.<sup>2</sup> On the other hand, the legend
<div n="lb"/>of the death of Viṣṇu, told in the later Saṃhitās<sup>3</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas,<sup>4</sup> expressly contemplates his leaning on his strung
<div n="lb"/>bow, which cleaves his head by the sudden springing apart
<div n="lb"/>of the two ends when the bow-string is gnawed through.
<F>1) Rv. vi. 75, 4; Av. i. 1, 3; Maitrā-
<div n="lb"/>yaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 2; Kāṭhaka Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, xvii. 11; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 9, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 166, 3. {%Cf.%} Av. vi. 42, 1.</F>
<F>3) Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5. 9.</F>
<F>4) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, vii. 5. 6;
<div n="lb"/>Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiv. 1, 1, 7 {%et%}
<div n="lb"/>{%seq.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 297,
<div n="lb"/>298; Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 270.</F>
<LEND>

<L>265<pc>1-064<k1>Arya<k2>Arya
{@Ārya@}¦ is the normal designation in the Vedic literature from
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards of an Āryan, a member of the three
<div n="lb"/>upper classes, {@Brāhmaṇa, Kṣatriya,@} or {@Vaiśya,@} as the formal
<div n="lb"/>division is given in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> The Ārya
<div n="lb"/>stands in opposition to the {@Dāsa,@}<sup>3</sup> but also to the {@Śūdra.@}
<div n="lb"/>Sometimes<sup>4</sup> the expression is restricted to the Vaiśya caste,
[Page1-065+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>the Brāhmaṇa and the Kṣatriya receiving special designations;
<div n="lb"/>but this use is not common, and it is often uncertain also
<div n="lb"/>whether {@Arya@} is not meant. The phrase Śūdrāryau<sup>5</sup> is espe-
<div n="lb"/>cially ambiguous, but appears to have denoted originally the
<div n="lb"/>Śūdra and the Āryan, for in the Mahāvrata ceremony the fight
<div n="lb"/>between a Śūdra and an Ārya is represented in the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa as one between a Brāhmaṇa and a Śūdra, though
<div n="lb"/>the Sūtra treats it as a fight between a Vaiśya and a Śūdra.
<div n="P"/>The word Ārya (fem. Āryā or Ārī) also occurs frequently
<div n="lb"/>used as an adjective to describe the Āryan classes ({%viśaḥ%}),<sup>6</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>name ({%nāman%}),<sup>7</sup> or caste ({%varṇa%}),<sup>8</sup> or dwellings ({%dhāman%});<sup>9</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>again reference is made to the Āryan supremacy ({%vrata%})<sup>10</sup> being
<div n="lb"/>extended over the land. Āryan foes ({%vṛtra%})<sup>11</sup> are referred to
<div n="lb"/>beside Dāsa foes, and there are many<sup>12</sup> references to war
<div n="lb"/>of Āryan versus Āryan, as well as to war of Āryan against
<div n="lb"/>Dāsa. From this it can be fairly deduced that even by the
<div n="lb"/>time of the Rigveda the Āryan communities had advanced
<div n="lb"/>far beyond the stage of simple conquest of the aborigines. In
<div n="lb"/>the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas the wars alluded to seem
<div n="lb"/>mainly Āryan wars, no doubt in consequence of the fusion of
<div n="lb"/>Ārya and Dāsa into one community.
<div n="P"/>Weber<sup>13</sup> considers that the five peoples known to the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>were the Āryans and the four peoples of the quarters ({%diś%})
<div n="lb"/>of the earth, but this is doubtful. Āryan speech ({%vāc%})<sup>14</sup>
<div n="lb"/>is specially referred to in the Aitareya and Śāṅkhāyana
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyakas.
<F>1) Rv. i. 51, 8; 130, 8; 156, 5, etc.</F>
<F>2) iv. 1, 6 (Kāṇva recension).</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 51, 8. 9; 103, 3; vi. 20, 10;
<div n="lb"/>25, 2, 3, etc. (opposed to Dāsa); Av.
<div n="lb"/>iv. 20, 4. 8; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 6,
<div n="lb"/>6; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 30, etc.
<div n="lb"/>(opposed to Sūdra).</F>
<F>4) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 205, 215,
<div n="lb"/>finds this use — understanding Ārya as
<div n="lb"/>meant — in Atharvaveda, xix. 32, 8, and
<div n="lb"/>62, 1, as well as in passages where
<div n="lb"/>Śūdrāryau is found. Lanman, in
<div n="lb"/>Whitney's Translation of the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda, 948, 1003, quotes his view with
<div n="lb"/>approval; but Whitney's version leaves
<div n="lb"/>no doubt that he read and understood
<div n="lb"/>the text as Ārya, the Āryan, not the
<div n="lb"/>Vaiśya. For Whitney's view, Av. iv. 20,
<div n="lb"/>4. 8 may be cited; and so Roth, St.
<div n="lb"/>Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.,%} takes the
<div n="lb"/>passages. In Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 3,
<div n="lb"/>10, 8, Śūdrāryau must mean Sūdra and
<div n="lb"/>Vaiśya; but the Padapāṭha takes it as
<div n="lb"/>Arya, and so does Zimmer.</F>
<F>5) See Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 9, 3,
<div n="lb"/>with Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xiii. 3,
<div n="lb"/>7. 8; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5;
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, v. 5, 17; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 2, 6, 7; Lāṭyāyana
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, iv. 2, 5; Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xvii. 6, 2; Anupada Sūtra, vii. 10.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 77, 3; 96, 31; x. 11, 4;
<div n="lb"/>43, 4, etc.</F>
<F>7) Rv. x; 49, 3.</F>
<F>8) Rv. iii. 34, 9. {%Cf.%} {@Varṇa.@}</F>
<F>9) Rv. ix. 63, 14.</F>
<F>10) Rv. x. 65, 11. So Agni and Indra
<div n="lb"/>are styled Āryan, as supporters of the
<div n="lb"/>Āryan people (Rv. vi. 60, 6).</F>
<F>11) Rv. vi. 33, 3; vii. 83, 1; x.
<div n="lb"/>69, 6.</F>
<F>12) Rv. i. 102, 5; iii. 32, 14; vi. 22,
<div n="lb"/>10; 25, 2. 3; viii. 2, 4. 27; x. 38, 3;
<div n="lb"/>83, 1; 102, 3, etc.</F>
<F>13) {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 288. {%Cf.%} Roth,
<div n="lb"/>St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v. kṛṣṭi,%}
<div n="lb"/>and {@Pañca Janāsaḥ.@}</F>
<F>14) Aitareya Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, viii. 9. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Keith, {%Aitareya Āraṇyaka,%} 196, 255;

<L>276<pc>1-067<k1>ASir<k2>ASir
{@Ā-śir@}¦ (‘admixture’) denotes the mixing, and more especially
<div n="lb"/>the milk mixed with the juice, of the Soma before it was
<div n="lb"/>offered to the gods. In this sense it is not rare from the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards. Not milk alone was employed for this
<div n="lb"/>purpose. The epithet ‘having three admixtures’ applied to
<div n="lb"/>Soma<sup>2</sup> is explained by the other epithets, ‘mixed with milk’
<div n="lb"/>({%gavāśir%}), ‘mixed with curds’ ({%dadhy-āśir%}), and ‘mixed with
<div n="lb"/>grain’ ({%yavāśir%}) — all referring to Soma.
<F>1) i. 134, 6; iii. 53, 14; viii. 2, 10.
<div n="lb"/>11, etc.; Av. ii. 29, 1, etc.; Nirukta,
<div n="lb"/>vi. 8; 32.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>

<L>279<pc>1-068<k1>ASuMga<k2>ASuMga
{@Āśuṃ-ga@}¦ in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> seems to denote some sort of

<L>280<pc>1-068<k1>ASrama<k2>ASrama
{@Ā-śrama@}¦ (‘resting-place’) does not occur in any Upaniṣad
<div n="lb"/>which can be regarded as pre-Buddhistic. Its earliest use as
<div n="lb"/>denoting the stages of a Hindu's life is found in the Śvetāśvatara
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad.<sup>1</sup> In one passage<sup>2</sup> of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad
<div n="lb"/>reference is made only to the {@Brahmacārin@} and householder, to
<div n="lb"/>whom, as a reward for study, the procreation of children, the
<div n="lb"/>practice of Yoga, abstention from injury to living creatures,
<div n="lb"/>and sacrifices, freedom from transmigration are promised. In
<div n="lb"/>another place<sup>3</sup> three states are contemplated, but not as con-
<div n="lb"/>secutive. The Brahmacārin may either become a householder
<div n="lb"/>or become an anchorite, or remain in his teacher's house all his
<div n="lb"/>life. Similarly, reference<sup>4</sup> is made to the death of the anchorite
<div n="lb"/>in the forest, or the sacrifice in the village. In contrast with all
<div n="lb"/>three<sup>5</sup> is the man who stands fast in Brahman (Brahma-
<div n="lb"/>saṃstha). In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>6</sup> the knower of the
<div n="lb"/>Ātman is contrasted with those who (1) study, or (2) sacrifice
<div n="lb"/>and give alms, or (3) are anchorites, and in another place<sup>7</sup> with
<div n="lb"/>those who sacrifice and make benefactions, and those who
<div n="lb"/>practice asceticism. This position of superiority to, and
<div n="lb"/>distinction from, the Āśramas became later a fourth<sup>8</sup> Āśrama,
[Page1-069+ 35]
<div n="lb"/>the {@Gṛhastha,@} or householder, who was in the second stage,
<div n="lb"/>being required to pass not only into the stage of {@Vānaprastha,@}
<div n="lb"/>but also that of the Sannyāsin ({@Bhikṣu, Parivrājaka@}). The
<div n="lb"/>first stage, that of the {@Brahmacārin,@} was still obligatory, but
<div n="lb"/>was no longer allowed to remain a permanent one, as was
<div n="lb"/>originally possible.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Deussen, {%Philosophy of the Upanishads,%} 60, 367 {%et seq.%}
<F>1) {%Atyāśramin,%} Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>vi. 21; Maitrāyaṇī Upaniṣad, iv. 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) viii. 5.</F>
<F>3) ii. 23, 1.</F>
<F>4) v. 10.</F>
<F>5) ii. 23, 1.</F>
<F>6) iv. 2, 22. {%Cf.%} iii. 5.</F>
<F>7) iii. 8, 10.</F>
<F>8) Jābāla Upaniṣad, 4. {%Cf.%} Muṇḍaka
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, ii. 1, 7.</F>
<LEND>

<L>288<pc>1-070<k1>ASvina<k2>ASvina
{@Āśvina,@}¦ or {@Āśvīna,@} designates, in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and two
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas,<sup>2</sup> the length of journey made in a day by a horseman
<div n="lb"/>({%aśvin%}). The exact distance is not defined. In the Atharva it
<div n="lb"/>appears to exceed five leagues, being mentioned immediately
<div n="lb"/>after a distance of three or five {@Yojanas;@} in the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa the heavenly world is placed at a distance of a
<div n="lb"/>thousand {@Āśvinas.@}
<F>1) vi. 131, 3.</F>
<F>2) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 17; Pañ-
<div n="lb"/>caviṃśa Brāhmaṇa in {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 34.</F>

<L>292<pc>1-070<k1>AsaNgaplAyogi<k2>AsaNgaplAyogi

<div n="lb"/>of the Dānastuti<sup>4</sup> gives him a son Svanad-ratha, really a mere
<div n="lb"/>epithet, and makes him a descendant of Yadu.

<L>293<pc>1-071<k1>AsandI<k2>AsandI
{@Ā-sandī.@}¦ — This is a generic term for a seat of some sort,
<div n="lb"/>occurring frequently in the later Saṃhitās<sup>1</sup> and Brāhmaṇas.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>but not in the Rigveda. In the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> the settle brought
<div n="lb"/>for the {@Vrātya@} is described at length. It had two feet, lengths
<div n="lb"/>wise and cross-pieces, forward and cross-cords, showing that it
<div n="lb"/>was made of wood and also cording. It was also covered with
<div n="lb"/>a cushion ({@Āstaraṇa@}) and a pillow ({@Upabarhaṇa@}), had a seat
<div n="lb"/>({@Āsāda@}) and a support ({@Upaśraya@}). Similar seats are described
<div n="lb"/>in the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad<sup>4</sup> and the Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The seat for the king at the royal consecration is described in
<div n="lb"/>very similar terms in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>6</sup> where the
<div n="lb"/>height of the feet is placed at a span, and the lengthwise and
<div n="lb"/>cross-pieces are each to be a cubit, while the interwoven part
<div n="lb"/>({%vivayana%}) is to be of Muñja grass, and the seat of Udumbara
<div n="lb"/>wood. In another passage of the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> Lanman
<div n="lb"/>seems to take the seat meant as a ‘long reclining chair.’ There
<div n="lb"/>also a cushion ({@Upadhāna@}) and coverlet ({@Upavāsana@}) are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa repeatedly describes
<div n="lb"/>the Āsandī in terms showing that it was an elaborate seat. In
<div n="lb"/>one place<sup>8</sup> it is said to be made of Khadira wood, perforated
<div n="lb"/>({%vi-tṛṇṇā%}), and joined with straps ({%vardhra-yutā%}) like that of the
<div n="lb"/>Bhāratas. At the Sautrāmaṇī rite<sup>9</sup> (an Indra sacrifice) the
<div n="lb"/>seat is of Udumbara wood, is knee-high, and of unlimited
<div n="lb"/>width and depth, and is covered with plaited reed-work. The
[Page1-072+ 40]
<div n="lb"/>imperial seat<sup>10</sup> is to be shoulder-high, of Udumbara wood, and
<div n="lb"/>wound all over with cords of Balvaja grass ({%Eleusina indica%}).
<div n="lb"/>Elsewhere<sup>11</sup> the seat is a span high, a cubit in width and
<div n="lb"/>depth, of Udumbara wood, and covered with reed-grass cords,
<div n="lb"/>and daubed with clay.
<F>1) Av. xiv. 2, 65; xv. 3, 2 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 8, 5; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 56; xix. 16; 86,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 5; 6; 12;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 3, 4, 26;
<div n="lb"/>v. 2, 1, 22; 4, 4, 1, etc.</F>
<F>3) xv. 3, 2 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) i. 5. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 397; Keith, {%Śāṅkhāyana Aran-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yaka,%} 19.</F>
<F>5) ii. 24.</F>
<F>6) viii. 5; 6; 12.</F>
<F>7) xiv. 2, 65. See his note in Whit-
<div n="lb"/>ney's Translation of the Atharvaveda,
<div n="lb"/>765.</F>
<F>8) v. 4, 4, 1.</F>
<F>9) xii. 8, 3, 4 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>10) xiv. 1, 3, 8 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>11) vi. 7, 1, 12 {%et seq.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 155.</F>
<LEND>

<L>294<pc>1-072<k1>AsandIvant<k2>AsandIvant

<div n="lb"/>Daivāpa Śaunaka, but in the Aitareya<sup>2</sup> {@Tura Kāvaṣeya.@}

<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xvi. 9, 1. Pāṇini, viii. 2, 12,

<L>303<pc>1-074<k1>AsrAva<k2>AsrAva
{@Ā-srāva@}¦ (‘discharge’) denotes a disease, thrice referred to in
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> the precise nature of which is uncertain.
<div n="lb"/>The Scholiast<sup>2</sup> in one place interprets it as painful urination
<div n="lb"/>({%mūtrātisāra%}), while Lanman<sup>3</sup> suggests diabetes. Bloomfield<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>takes it to be diarrhœa, and Zimmer<sup>5</sup> argues that as the remedy
<div n="lb"/>is called ‘wound healer’ ({%arus-srāṇa%}), the sense is ‘the flux from
<div n="lb"/>unhealed wounds.’ Whitney<sup>6</sup> renders it ‘flux,’ and questions
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield's rendering. Ludwig<sup>7</sup> translates it vaguely by ‘sick-
<div n="lb"/>ness’ and ‘cold.’

<L>308<pc>1-075<k1>ikzvAku<k2>ikzvAku
{@Ikṣvāku.@}¦ — In the Rigveda this name occurs but once,<sup>1</sup> and in

<div n="lb"/>to; in either case he seems to be regarded as an ancient hero.

<div n="lb"/>{@Traidhātva@} Aikṣvāka, who is identical with the {@Tryaruṇa@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Traivṛṣṇa@} of the Bṛhaddevatā,<sup>5</sup> and with {@Tryaruṇa Trasa-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@dasyu@} in the Rigveda.<sup>6</sup> The connection of Trasadasyu with
<div n="lb"/>the Ikṣvākus is confirmed by the fact that {@Purukutsa@} was an
<div n="lb"/>Aikṣvāka, according to the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>7</sup> Thus the
<div n="lb"/>Ikṣvāku line was originally a line of princes of the Pūrus.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>8</sup> places them on the upper Indus, but they may well
<div n="lb"/>have been somewhat further east.<sup>9</sup> Later Ikṣvāku is connected
<div n="lb"/>with Ayodhyā

<L>312<pc>1-076<k1>itihAsa<k2>itihAsa
{@Itihāsa,@}¦ as a kind of literature, is repeatedly mentioned
<div n="lb"/>along with {@Purāṇa@} in the later texts of the Vedic period.
<div n="lb"/>The earliest reference to both occurs in the late fifteenth book
<div n="lb"/>of the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> Itihāsa then appears in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> the Jaiminīya,<sup>3</sup> Bṛhadāraṇyaka,<sup>4</sup> and Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣads.<sup>5</sup> In the latter it is expressly declared with Purāṇa
<div n="lb"/>to make up the fifth Veda, while the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>makes the Itihāsa a Veda and the Purāṇa a Veda. The
<div n="lb"/>Itihāsa-veda and the Purāṇa-veda appear also in the Gopatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>7</sup> while the Śatapatha<sup>8</sup> identifies the Itihāsa as well
<div n="lb"/>as the Purāṇa with the Veda. In one passage {@Anvākhyāna@}
<div n="lb"/>and Itihāsa are distinguished<sup>9</sup> as different classes of works, but
<div n="lb"/>the exact point of distinction is obscure; probably the former
<div n="lb"/>was supplementary. The Taittirīya Āraṇyaka<sup>10</sup> mentions
<div n="lb"/>Itihāsas and Purāṇas in the plural.
<div n="P"/>There is nothing to show in the older literature what dis-
<div n="lb"/>tinction there was, if any, between Itihāsa and Purāṇa; and
<div n="lb"/>the late literature,<sup>11</sup> which has been elaborately examined by
<div n="lb"/>Sieg,<sup>12</sup> yields no consistent result. Geldner<sup>13</sup> has conjectured
<div n="lb"/>that there existed a single work, the Itihāsa-purāṇa, a collection
[Page1-077+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>of the old legends of all sorts, heroic, cosmogonic, genealogical;
<div n="lb"/>but though a work called Itihāsa, and another called Purāṇa,
<div n="lb"/>were probably known to Patañjali,<sup>14</sup> the inaccuracy of Geldner's
<div n="lb"/>view is proved by the fact that Yāska shows no sign of having
<div n="lb"/>known any such work. To him the Itihāsa may be a part of
<div n="lb"/>the Mantra literature itself,<sup>15</sup> Aitihāsikas being merely people
<div n="lb"/>who interpret the Rigveda by seeing in it legends where others
<div n="lb"/>see myths.<sup>16</sup> The fact, however, that the use of the compound
<div n="lb"/>form is rare, and that Yāska regularly has Itihāsa,<sup>17</sup> not
<div n="lb"/>Itihāsa-purāṇa, is against the theory of there ever having been
<div n="lb"/>one work.
<div n="P"/>The relation of Itihāsa to {@Ākhyāna@} is also uncertain. Sieg<sup>18</sup>
<div n="lb"/>considers that the words Itihāsa and Purāṇa referred to the
<div n="lb"/>great body of mythology, legendary history, and cosmogonic
<div n="lb"/>legend available to the Vedic poets, and roughly classed as a
<div n="lb"/>fifth Veda, though not definitely and finally fixed. Thus,
<div n="lb"/>Anvākhyānas, {@Anuvyākhyānas,@} and {@Vyākhyānas@} could arise,
<div n="lb"/>and separate Ākhyānas could still exist outside the cycle,
<div n="lb"/>while an Ākhyāna could also be a part of the Itihāsa-purāṇa.
<div n="lb"/>He also suggests that the word Ākhyāna has special reference
<div n="lb"/>to the form of the narrative. Oldenberg,<sup>19</sup> following Windisch,<sup>20</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and followed by Geldner,<sup>21</sup> Sieg, and others, has found in the
<div n="lb"/>Ākhyāna form a mixture of prose and verse, alternating as
<div n="lb"/>the narrative was concerned with the mere accessory parts of
<div n="lb"/>the tale, or with the chief points, at which the poetic form
<div n="lb"/>was naturally produced to correspond with the stress of the
<div n="lb"/>emotion. This theory has been severely criticized by Hertel<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and von Schroeder.<sup>23</sup> These scholars, in accordance with
<div n="lb"/>older suggestions of Max Müller<sup>24</sup> and Lévi,<sup>25</sup> see in the
[Page1-078+ 34]
<div n="lb"/>so-called Ākhyāna hymns of the Rigveda, in which Oldenberg
<div n="lb"/>finds actual specimens of the supposed literary genus, though
<div n="lb"/>the prose has been lost, actual remains of ritual dramas.
<div n="lb"/>Elsewhere<sup>26</sup> it has been suggested that the hymns in question
<div n="lb"/>are merely literary dialogues.
<F>1) xv. 6, 4 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) xiii. 4, 3, 12. 13, and as com-
<div n="lb"/>pounded in xi. 5, 6, 8; 7, 9.</F>

<L>317<pc>1-078<k1>indrota<k2>indrota<h>1

<L>319<pc>1-079<k1>iBa<k2>iBa<h>1
1. {@Ibha@}¦ is a word of somewhat doubtful sense and inter-
<div n="lb"/>pretation. It is found only in the Saṃhitās,<sup>1</sup> and especially in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda.<sup>2</sup> According to Roth<sup>3</sup> and Ludwig<sup>4</sup> the sense is
<div n="lb"/>‘retainer,’ and Zimmer<sup>5</sup> thinks that it includes not only
<div n="lb"/>dependants and servants, but also the royal family and the
<div n="lb"/>youthful cadets of the chief families. In the opinion of Pischel
<div n="lb"/>and Geldner<sup>6</sup> it denotes ‘elephant.’ This view is supported
<div n="lb"/>by the authority of the commentators Sāyaṇa<sup>7</sup> and Mahīdhara;<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the Nirukta,<sup>9</sup> too, gives ‘elephant’ as one of the senses of the
<div n="lb"/>word. Megasthenes<sup>10</sup> and Nearchos<sup>11</sup> tell us that elephants
<div n="lb"/>were a royal prerogative, and the derivative word {@Ibhya@} may
<div n="lb"/>thus be naturally explained as denoting merely ‘rich’ (lit.,
<div n="lb"/>‘possessor of elephants’).<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 2, 14, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 9.</F>
<F>2) i. 84, 17; iv. 4, 1; ix. 57, 3, and
<div n="lb"/>perhaps vi. 20, 8.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 246,
<div n="lb"/>247.</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 167.</F>
<F>6) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, xv, xvi.</F>
<F>7) On Taittirīya Saṃhitā, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>8) On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>9) vi. 12. It gives also the sense
<div n="lb"/>‘retainer,’ and in Aśoka's Edicts, No. 5,
<div n="lb"/>Bühler, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 37, 279, finds a
<div n="lb"/>Vaiśya denoted by its Pāli form.</F>
<F>10) {%Apud%} Strabo, 704.</F>
<F>11) {%Ibid.,%} 705.</F>
<F>12) But it may equally well be ex-
<div n="lb"/>plained as ‘rich’ from the other sense
<div n="lb"/>of the primary word: ‘possessor of
<div n="lb"/>(many) retainers.’</F>

<L>321<pc>1-080<k1>iBya<k2>iBya
{@Ibhya@}¦ occurs once in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> in the plural, when a king
<div n="lb"/>is said to devour his Ibhyas as the fire the forest; and twice
<div n="lb"/>in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad,<sup>2</sup> in one passage as the first
<div n="lb"/>member of a compound, and in the other as either a proper
<div n="lb"/>name or an adjective. Roth,<sup>3</sup> Ludwig,<sup>4</sup> and Zimmer<sup>5</sup> interpret
<div n="lb"/>the word as ‘retainers’ in the Rigveda, but in the Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad Roth thinks it means ‘rich.’ Pischel and Geldner<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>accept the sense in all passages. Böhtlingk in his trans-
<div n="lb"/>lation of the Chāndogya treats the word as simply a proper
<div n="lb"/>name, ‘Ibhya's village’ ({%ibhya-grāma%}) and ‘Ibhya.’

<L>322<pc>1-080<k1>iriRa<k2>iriRa
{@Iriṇa@}¦ (neut.) occurs not rarely in the later Saṃhitās<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas<sup>2</sup> in the sense of ‘a cleft in the ground,’ usually
<div n="lb"/>natural ({%sva-kṛta%}). The same meaning is also, as Pischel<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>shows, to be ascribed to it in three passages of the Rigveda,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>in one<sup>5</sup> of which the hole is referred to as ‘made by water’
<div n="lb"/>({%apā kṛtam%}). In another passage of the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> the word
<div n="lb"/>refers to the place on which the dice are thrown. Hence
<div n="lb"/>Pischel<sup>7</sup> concludes that the dicing-board must have been
<div n="lb"/>so called because it contained holes into which the dice had
<div n="lb"/>to be thrown if possible. Lüders,<sup>8</sup> however, points out that
<div n="lb"/>this assumption is not necessary; the dice ({@Akṣa@}) were merely
<div n="lb"/>thrown on a space dug out, which could be called {@Iriṇa,@} as
<div n="lb"/>being a hole in the ground, though not a natural one. This
<div n="lb"/>view is supported by the commentary of Sāyaṇa,<sup>9</sup> as well as
<div n="lb"/>by Durga in his note on the Nirukta.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) Av. iv. 15, 12; Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 5, 1, 3; iii. 4, 8, 5; v. 2, 4, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, ix. 16.</F>
<F>2) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 2, 3, 2;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 2, 1, 8.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 222-225.</F>
<F>4) i. 186, 9; viii. 4, 3; 87, 1. 4.</F>
<F>5) viii. 4, 3.</F>
<F>6) x. 34, 1. 9.</F>
<F>7) {%Op. cit.,%} 2, 225.</F>
<F>8) {%Das Würfelspiel im alben Indian,%} 14.</F>
<F>9) On Rv., {%loc. cit. (ā-sphūra).%}</F>
<F>10) ix. 8 ({%āsphuraka-sthāna%}).</F>

<L>325<pc>1-081<k1>izu<k2>izu
{@Iṣu@}¦ is the usual name for ‘arrow’ from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards. Other names are {@Śarya, Śārī,@} and {@Bāṇa.@} In the
<div n="lb"/>hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>2</sup> which gives a catalogue of armour,
<div n="lb"/>two kinds of arrows are distinctly referred to: the one is
<div n="lb"/>poisoned ({%ālāktā%}), and has a head of horn ({%ruru-śīrṣṇī%}); the
<div n="lb"/>other is copper-, bronze-, or iron-headed ({%ayo-mukham%}). Poisoned
<div n="lb"/>({%digdhā%}) arrows are also referred to in the Atharvaveda.<sup>3</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>arrows were feathered.<sup>4</sup> The parts of an arrow are enumerated
<div n="lb"/>in the Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> as the shaft ({%śalya%}), the feather-socket
<div n="lb"/>({%parṇa-dhi%}), the point ({%śṛṅga%}), the neck of the point in which
<div n="lb"/>the shaft is fixed ({%kulmala%}), and the {@Apaskambha@} and {@Apāṣṭha,@}
<div n="lb"/>which are of more doubtful significance. In the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup> the parts of an arrow are given as the point ({%anīka%}),
<div n="lb"/>the {%śalya, tejana,%} and the feathers ({%parṇāni%}), where {%śalya%} and
<div n="lb"/>{%tejana%} must apparently mean the upper and lower parts of the
<div n="lb"/>shaft, since it is reasonable to suppose that the arrow is
<div n="lb"/>described as a whole consecutively. So in the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the arrow of Kāma is described as having feathers, a shaft
[Page1-082+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>({%śalya%}), and a firm fastening ({%kulmala%}).<sup>8</sup> The arrow was shot
<div n="lb"/>from the ear, and so is described in the Rigveda<sup>9</sup> as ‘having
<div n="lb"/>the ear for its place of birth.’
<div n="P"/>As a measure of length, the Iṣu was five spans, say three feet.<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>A regular profession of arrow-making existed ({%iṣu-kṛt,%}<sup>11</sup> {%iṣu-kāra%}).<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) ii. 24, 8; viii. 7, 4, etc.; Av. i. 13,
<div n="lb"/>4, etc.; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 3,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Nirukta, ix. 18.</F>
<F>2) vi. 75, 15.</F>
<F>3) iv. 6, 7; v. 18, 8. 15; 31, 4.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 18, 14; vi. 75, 11; Av.
<div n="lb"/>v. 25, 1.</F>
<F>5) iv. 6.</F>
<F>6) i. 25.</F>
<F>7) Av. iii. 25, 2.</F>
<F>8) See also Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8,
<div n="lb"/>1. 2; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxv. 1.</F>
<F>9) Rv. vi. 75, 3; ii. 24, 8 ({%karṇa-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yoni%}).</F>
<F>10) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, vi. 5, 2, 10.</F>
<F>11) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 46, {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Rv. i. 184, 3.</F>
<F>12) {%Ibid.,%} xxx. 7; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 4, 3, 1.

<L>327<pc>1-082<k1>izuDi<k2>izuDi
{@Iṣu-dhi@}¦ (‘arrow-holder’) is the name of the quiver which was
<div n="lb"/>carried by every bowman. The word is common from the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards. No trace is to be found in Vedic literature
<div n="lb"/>of the later practice of carrying two quivers.<sup>2</sup> According to
<div n="lb"/>Pischel,<sup>3</sup> the curious expression {%iṣu-kṛt%} in the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> means
<div n="lb"/>quiver.

<div n="lb"/>ii. 33, 2; iv. 10, 6, etc.; Nirukta, ix. 13.</F>
<F>2) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 274. Each quiver
<div n="lb"/>held from ten to twenty arrows.</F>

<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 182.</F>

<L>338<pc>1-084<k1>uttarakuru<k2>uttarakuru
{@Uttara Kuru.@}¦ — The Uttara Kurus, who play a mythical part
<div n="lb"/>in the Epic and later literature, are still a historical people in
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> where they are located beyond the
<div n="lb"/>Himālaya ({%pareṇa Himavantam%}). In another passage,<sup>2</sup> how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, the country of the Uttara Kurus is stated by {@Vāsiṣṭha@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Sātyahavya@} to be a land of the gods ({%deva-kṣetra%}), but {@Jānaṃ-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@tapi Atyarāti@} was anxious to conquer it, so that it is still not
<div n="lb"/>wholly mythical. It is reasonable to accept Zimmer's view
<div n="lb"/>that the northern Kurus were settled in Kaśmīr, especially as
<div n="lb"/>{@Kurukṣetra@} is the region where tribes advancing from Kaśmīr
<div n="lb"/>might naturally be found. {%Cf.%} {@Udīcyas.@}
<F>1) viii. 14.</F>
<F>2) viii. 23.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 165;
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 101, 102;

<L>347<pc>1-086<k1>udAja<k2>udAja

<L>348<pc>1-086<k1>udAna<k2>udAna
{@Udāna@}¦ is usually the fifth of the vital breaths ({@Prāṇa@}) when
<div n="lb"/>five are enumerated.<sup>1</sup> Sometimes<sup>2</sup> it appears as the second,
<div n="lb"/>coming after Prāṇa, and followed by Vyāna or Samāna.
<div n="lb"/>Again,<sup>3</sup> it is found simply opposed to Prāṇa, or it simply follows
<div n="lb"/>Prāṇa and Apāna.<sup>4</sup> In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> it is treated
<div n="lb"/>as the breath that consumes food, a notion traceable in
<div n="lb"/>the later Upaniṣads,<sup>6</sup> while it is also regarded as the wind
<div n="lb"/>that rises up by the throat,<sup>7</sup> and leads the spirit forth at
<div n="lb"/>death.<sup>8</sup>

<div n="lb"/>Udāna, Samāna); Bṛhadāraṇyaka

<div n="lb"/>omitted); iii. 9, 26; Chāndogya Upani-

<L>349<pc>1-086<k1>udIcyas<k2>udIcyas
{@Ud-īcyas.@}¦ — The Brāhmaṇas of the northern parts are referred
<div n="lb"/>to in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> as engaging, with {@Svaidāyana@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Śaunaka@} as their spokesman, in a dispute with the Kurupañcāla
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa {@Uddālaka Āruṇi,@} and as vanquishing him. Their
<div n="lb"/>relation to the Kurupañcālas appears also from the fact that in
[Page1-087+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>the same Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> reference is made to the speech of the
<div n="lb"/>north being similar to that of the Kurupañcālas. The speech
<div n="lb"/>of the Northerners was also celebrated for purity; hence
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas used to go to the north for purposes of study,
<div n="lb"/>according to the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> while in the Buddhist
<div n="lb"/>texts the school of Takṣaśilā (in Gandhāra) is famous as a
<div n="lb"/>resort of students.<sup>4</sup> Possibly, too, Sanskrit was specially
<div n="lb"/>developed in Kaśmīr, as suggested by Franke.<sup>5</sup> See also {@Kuru.@}
<F>1) xi. 4, 1, 1. {%Cf.%} Gopatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 6.</F>
<F>2) iii. 2, 3, 15. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 1, 191; Lévi, {%La Doctrine du%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacrifice,%} 35.</F>
<F>3) vii. 6. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%op. cit.,%} 1, 153;
<div n="lb"/>2, 309.</F>
<F>4) Rhys Davids, {%Buddhist India,%} 8, 28,
<div n="lb"/>203.</F>
<F>5) {%Cf. Pāli und Sanskrit%} (1902), 88,
<div n="lb"/>89.</F>
<LEND>

<L>350<pc>1-087<k1>udumbara<k2>udumbara
{@Udumbara.@}¦ — This name of the {%Ficus glomerata%} does not occur
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda, but is often found from the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards. For ritual purposes of all kinds its wood was
<div n="lb"/>constantly used. The sacrificial post ({%yūpa%})<sup>2</sup> and the sacrificial
<div n="lb"/>ladle<sup>3</sup> were made of it, and amulets of Udumbara are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned.<sup>4</sup> Its wood, like that of other kinds of figtree — 
<div n="lb"/>{@Aśvattha, Nyagrodha,@} and {@Plakṣa@} — was considered suitable
<div n="lb"/>for employment at the sacrifice.<sup>5</sup> The sweetness of its fruit is
<div n="lb"/>referred to in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>6</sup> where it is put on the
<div n="lb"/>same level as {@Madhu.@} It is there also spoken of as ripening
<div n="lb"/>three times a year.<sup>7</sup> A forest of Udumbara trees is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) xix. 31, 1; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 1,
<div n="lb"/>1, 6, etc.; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 2,
<div n="lb"/>1, 33; vii. 4, 1, 38, etc.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 6.</F>
<F>3) {%Ibid.,%} v. 4, 7, 3.</F>
<F>4) Atharvaveda, xix. 31, 1.</F>
<F>5) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8, 4.</F>
<F>6) vii. 15.</F>
<F>7) v. 24.</F>
<F>8) xvi. 6, 4.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 59.</F>

<L>351<pc>1-087<k1>uddAlakaAruRi<k2>uddAlakaAruRi
{@Uddālaka Āruṇi.@}¦ — Uddālaka, son of Aruṇa, is one of the
<div n="lb"/>most prominent teachers of the Vedic period. He was a Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa of the Kurupañcālas, according to the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa.<sup>1</sup> This statement is confirmed by the fact that he was
<div n="lb"/>teacher of {@Proti Kausurubindi@} of Kauśāmbī,<sup>2</sup> and that his son
[Page1-088+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>{@Svetaketu@} is found disputing among the Pañcālas.<sup>3</sup> He was a
<div n="lb"/>pupil of Aruṇa, his father,<sup>4</sup> as well as of Patañcala Kāpya,<sup>5</sup> of
<div n="lb"/>Madra, while he was the teacher of the famous Yājñavalkya<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneya and of Kauṣītaki,<sup>7</sup> although the former is represented
<div n="lb"/>elsewhere<sup>8</sup> as having silenced him. He overcame in argument
<div n="lb"/>Prācīnayogya Śauceya,<sup>9</sup> and apparently also Bhadrasena Ājāta-
<div n="lb"/>śatrava,<sup>10</sup> though the text here seems to read the name as
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇi. He was a Gautama,<sup>11</sup> and is often alluded to as such.
<div n="lb"/>As an authority on questions of ritual and philosophy, he is
<div n="lb"/>repeatedly referred to by his patronymic name Āruṇi in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>12</sup> the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>13</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Chāndogya Upaniṣad,<sup>14</sup> and occasionally in the Aitareya,<sup>15</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki,<sup>16</sup> and the Ṣaḍviṃśa<sup>17</sup> Brāhmaṇas, as well as the
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad.<sup>18</sup> In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā he is not
<div n="lb"/>mentioned, according to Geldner,<sup>19</sup> but only his father Aruṇa;
<div n="lb"/>his name does not occur, according to Weber,<sup>20</sup> in the Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, but in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>21</sup> he is, as
<div n="lb"/>Āruṇi, known as a contemporary of {@Divodāsa Bhaimaseni,@} and
<div n="lb"/>in the Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa<sup>22</sup> he is mentioned as
<div n="lb"/>serving {@Vāsiṣṭha Caikitāneya.@} In the Taittirīya tradition he
<div n="lb"/>seldom appears. There is an allusion in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>23</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to Kusurubinda Auddālaki, and according to the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>24</sup> Naciketas was a son of Vājaśravasa Gautama, who
[Page1-089+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>is made out to be Uddālaka by Sāyaṇa.<sup>25</sup> But the episode of
<div n="lb"/>Naciketas, being somewhat unreal, cannot be regarded as of
<div n="lb"/>historical value in proving relationship. Aruṇa is known to the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā. A real son of Uddālaka was the famous
<div n="lb"/>{@Śvetaketu,@} who is expressly reported by Āpastamba<sup>26</sup> to have
<div n="lb"/>been in his time an Avara or later authority, a statement of
<div n="lb"/>importance for the date of Āruṇi.
<F>1) xi. 4, 1, 2. {%Cf.%} Gopatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 6.</F>
<F>2) xii. 2, 2, 13.</F>
<F>3) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Chāndogya Upaniṣad, v. 3, 1.</F>
<F>4) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 4, 33

<L>360<pc>1-090<k1>upajihvikA<k2>upajihvikA
{@Upa-jihvikā, Upa-jīkā, Upa-dīkā@}¦ are all forms of one word
<div n="lb"/>denoting a species of ant.<sup>1</sup> To these ants is attributed in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> the power of penetrating to water which possesses
<div n="lb"/>curative properties. They were accordingly used in all sorts of
<div n="lb"/>spells against poisoning. The belief in their healing qualities
<div n="lb"/>was no doubt due to the well-known properties of the earth of
<div n="lb"/>ant-heaps which contains their water.

<div n="lb"/>2; but {%upacīkā%} in both passages in the
<div n="lb"/>Paippalāda recension; {%upadīkā%} in the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 3, 4; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Āraṇyaka, v. 1, 4; 10, 9; Sata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, xiv. 1, 1, 8.</F>
<F>2) vi. 100, 2.

<L>362<pc>1-091<k1>upaDi<k2>upaDi

<div n="lb"/>vaveda,<sup>2</sup> in conjunction with {@Pradhi,@} denoting part of the
<div n="lb"/>wheel of a chariot. It is impossible to decide exactly what
<div n="lb"/>part is meant. Roth,<sup>3</sup> Zimmer<sup>4</sup> and Bloomfield,<sup>5</sup> agree in

<div n="lb"/>is a rim beneath the felly, or the felly itself as compared with
<div n="lb"/>the tire (ordinarily {@Pavi@}).

<L>363<pc>1-091<k1>upanizad<k2>upanizad
{@Upa-niṣad@}¦ in the Brāhmaṇas<sup>1</sup> normally denotes the ‘secret
<div n="lb"/>sense’ of some word or text, sometimes the ‘secret rule’ of the
<div n="lb"/>mendicant. But in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>2</sup> it is already
<div n="lb"/>used in the plural as the designation of a class of writings, no
<div n="lb"/>doubt actually existing and similar to the Upaniṣads in the
<div n="lb"/>nature of their subject-matter and its treatment. Similarly
<div n="lb"/>the sections of the Taittirīya Upaniṣad end with the words
<div n="lb"/>{%ity upaniṣad.%} The Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>3</sup> commences its third
<div n="lb"/>part with the title ‘The Upaniṣad of the Saṃhitā,’ and the
<div n="lb"/>title occurs also in the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka.<sup>4</sup> The exact
<div n="lb"/>primary sense of the expression is doubtful. The natural
<div n="lb"/>derivation, adopted by Max Müller<sup>5</sup> and usual ever since,
<div n="lb"/>makes the word mean firstly a session of pupils, hence secret
<div n="lb"/>doctrine, and secondly the title of a work on secret doctrine.
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg,<sup>6</sup> however, traces the use of the word to the earlier
[Page1-092+ 42]
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘worship’ ({%cf. upāsana%}). Deussen<sup>7</sup> considers the
<div n="lb"/>original sense to have been ‘secret word,’ next ‘secret text,’
<div n="lb"/>and then ‘secret import,’ but this order of meaning is im-
<div n="lb"/>probable. Hopkins<sup>8</sup> suggests that Upaniṣad denotes a sub-
<div n="lb"/>sidiary treatise, but this sense does not account naturally for
<div n="lb"/>the common use as ‘secret meaning,’ which is far more
<div n="lb"/>frequent than any other.
<F>1) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, x. 3, 5, 12;
<div n="lb"/>4, 5, 1; 5, 1, 1; xii. 2, 2, 23, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Chāndogya Upaniṣad, i. 1, 10; 13, 4;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 8, 4. 5; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 1, 20; iv. 2, 1; v. 5, 3; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 6; 2, 5; Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, ii. 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) ii. 4, 10; iv. 1, 2; 5, 11.</F>
<F>3) iii. 1, 1.</F>
<F>4) vii. 2. {%Cf.%} Taittirīya Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>i. 3, 1.</F>
<F>5) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 1, xxxiii
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq. Cf.%} St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.;%} Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>204.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 50, 457; 54, 70;
<div n="lb"/>{%Die Literatur des alten Indien,%} 72.</F>

<L>368<pc>1-093<k1>upamaSravas<k2>upamaSravas
{@Upama-śravas@}¦ is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>a son of {@Kuruśravaṇa,@} and grandson of {@Medhātithi.@} The
<div n="lb"/>exact force of the reference to him in however, uncertain.
<div n="lb"/>According to the Bṛhaddevatā,<sup>2</sup> followed by Ludwig,<sup>3</sup> and by
<div n="lb"/>Lanman,<sup>4</sup> the poet in the hymn consoles Upamaśravas for the
<div n="lb"/>death of his grandfather, Medhātithi. Geldner,<sup>5</sup> on the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, thinks that the poet, who was {@Kavaṣa Ailūṣa,@} was
<div n="lb"/>ill-treated by his patron's son, Upamaśravas, and cast into
<div n="lb"/>a ditch or well, where he uttered his complaint and appeal for
<div n="lb"/>mercy. But of this there is no adequate evidence, and the
<div n="lb"/>tradition of the Bṛhaddevatā seems sound.

<L>369<pc>1-093<k1>upamit<k2>upamit
{@Upa-mit@}¦ occurs twice in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and once in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> as the designation of some part of a house. The
<div n="lb"/>passages in the Rigveda leave little doubt that the word means
<div n="lb"/>an upright pillar. As it is, in the Atharvaveda, coupled with
<div n="lb"/>{@Parimit@} and {@Pratimit,@} the conclusion is natural that the latter
<div n="lb"/>word denotes the beams supporting the Upamit, presumably by
<div n="lb"/>leaning against it at an angle, while {@Parimit@} denotes the beams
<div n="lb"/>connecting the Upamits horizontally. These interpretations,
<div n="lb"/>however, can only be conjectural. See also {@Gṛha.@}
<F>1) i. 59, 1; iv. 5, 1.</F>
<F>2) ix. 3, 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 153;
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>596; Whitney, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 525.</F>

<L>370<pc>1-093<k1>upara<k2>upara
{@Upara,@}¦ which, according to Pischel,<sup>1</sup> means ‘stone’ in
<div n="lb"/>general, is the technical name of the stone on which the Soma
<div n="lb"/>plant was laid in order to be pounded for the extraction of the
<div n="lb"/>juice by other stones ({%adri, grāvan%}). The word is rare, occur-
<div n="lb"/>ring only thrice in the Rigveda,<sup>2</sup> and once in the Atharvaveda.<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 109. This is the
<div n="lb"/>sense of the form {%upala%} (Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xxv. 8, etc.).</F>

<L>371<pc>1-094<k1>upalaprakziRI<k2>upalaprakziRI
{@Upala-prakṣiṇī@}¦ occurs once in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where it desig-
<div n="lb"/>nates the occupation of a woman, as opposed to that of her
<div n="lb"/>son, who is a poet ({%kāru%}), and to that of his father, who is a
<div n="lb"/>physician ({%bhiṣaj%}). Yāska<sup>2</sup> renders the word by ‘maker of
<div n="lb"/>groats’ ({%saktu-kārikā%}), and Roth,<sup>3</sup> Grassmann,<sup>4</sup> Zimmer,<sup>5</sup> as well
<div n="lb"/>as others, connect it with the operation of grinding corn.
<div n="lb"/>Pischel,<sup>6</sup> however, who points out that corn was not ground
<div n="lb"/>between two stones, but beaten on a stone with a pestle ({%dṛṣad%}),
<div n="lb"/>considers that Upala-prakṣiṇī denotes a woman that assisted at
<div n="lb"/>the crushing of Soma ({%cf.%} {@Upara@}). Von Schroeder,<sup>7</sup> who more
<div n="lb"/>correctly points out that there is no objection to regarding
<div n="lb"/>{%upala%} as the mortar in which the corn was placed and then
<div n="lb"/>beaten with the pestle, renders the word literally as ‘one who
<div n="lb"/>fills the (lower) stone (with corn).’
<F>1) ix. 112, 3.</F>
<F>2) Nirukta, vi. 5.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Ibid., s.v.,%} ‘fitting the upper (to the
<div n="lb"/>lower) millstone.’</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 269. {%Cf.%} Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt, {%Vedaschrestomathie, s.v.,%} who,
<div n="lb"/>taking {%pṛc%} in the sense of ‘fill,’ explains
<div n="lb"/>the compound as ‘filling the upper mill-
<div n="lb"/>stone,’ an interpretation which as it
<div n="lb"/>stands is unintelligible.</F>

<div n="lb"/>view that the mother of the singer is
<div n="lb"/>alluded to; but it seems impossible to
<div n="lb"/>draw any other conclusion from the
<div n="lb"/>language of the passage, and his own
<div n="lb"/>explanation of the word as refer-
<div n="lb"/>ring to a corn-mother is very im-
<div n="lb"/>probable; {%cf.%} Keith, {%Journal of the Royal%}

<L>375<pc>1-095<k1>upaSrI<k2>upaSrI

<L>377<pc>1-096<k1>upasti<k2>upasti
{@Upa-sti@}¦ denotes both in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> a
<div n="lb"/>‘dependent,’ just as later in the Epic<sup>3</sup> the subordination of the
<div n="lb"/>Vaiśya to the two superior castes is expressed by the verb
<div n="lb"/>{%upa-sthā,%} ‘stand under,’ ‘support.’ The word also appears,
<div n="lb"/>with the same sense, in the form of Sti, but only in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>4</sup> The exact nature of the dependence connoted by
<div n="lb"/>the term is quite uncertain. Zimmer<sup>5</sup> conjectures that the
<div n="lb"/>‘dependents’ were the members of defeated Aryan tribes who
<div n="lb"/>became clients of the king, as among the Greeks, Romans, and
<div n="lb"/>Germans, the term possibly including persons who had lost
<div n="lb"/>their freedom through dicing.<sup>6</sup> The evidence of the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda<sup>7</sup> shows that among the Upastis were included the
<div n="lb"/>chariot-makers ({%ratha-kāra%}), the smiths ({%takṣan%}), and the
<div n="lb"/>charioteers ({%sūta%}), and troop-leaders ({%grāma-ṇī%}), while the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda passages negative the possibility of the ‘subjects’ ({%sti%})
<div n="lb"/>being the whole people. It is therefore fair to assume that
<div n="lb"/>they were the clients proper of the king, not servile, but
<div n="lb"/>attached in a special relation to him as opposed to the ordinary
<div n="lb"/>population. They may well have included among them not
<div n="lb"/>only the classes suggested by Zimmer, but also higher elements,
<div n="lb"/>such as refugees from other clans, as well as ambitious men
<div n="lb"/>who sought advancement in the royal service. Indeed, the
<div n="lb"/>Sūta and the Grāmaṇī were, as such, officers of the king's house-
<div n="lb"/>hold — kingmakers, not themselves kings, as they are described
<div n="lb"/>in the Atharvaveda.<sup>8</sup> The use of the word in the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā,<sup>9</sup> the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>10</sup> and the Kāṭhaka,<sup>11</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>purely metaphorical, as well as in the one passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda in which it occurs. In the Paippalāda recension of
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda,<sup>12</sup> Vaiśya, Śūdra, and Ārya are referred to as
<div n="lb"/>Upastis, perhaps in the general sense of ‘subject.’
<F>1) x. 97, 23 (= Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xii. 101; Av. vi. 15, 1).</F>
<F>2) iii. 5, 6.</F>
<F>3) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 92.</F>
<F>4) vii. 19, 11; x. 148, 4; {%sti-pa,%} vii. 66,
<div n="lb"/>3; x. 69, 4.</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 184, 185.</F>
<F>6) Rv. x. 34.</F>
<F>7) Av. iii. 5, 6. 7.</F>
<F>8) iii. 5, 7.</F>
<F>9) vii. 2, 5, 4. {%Cf.%} vi. 5, 8, 2.</F>
<F>10) iii. 3, 5, 4.</F>
<F>11) xxxi. 9.</F>
<F>12) iii. 5, 7.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 246; Whitney, Translation of
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda, 92; Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 17, 196 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>384<pc>1-097<k1>uBayAdant<k2>uBayAdant
{@Ubhayā-dant,@}¦ ‘having incisors in both jaws,’ is an expression
<div n="lb"/>employed to distinguish, among domestic animals, the horse,
[Page1-098+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>the ass, etc., from the goat, the sheep, and cattle. The
<div n="lb"/>distinction occurs in a late hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and is several
<div n="lb"/>times alluded to in the later Saṃhitās<sup>2</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>In one passage of the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup> man is classed with
<div n="lb"/>the horse as {%ubhayā-dant.%} The opposite is {%anyato-dant,%} ‘having
<div n="lb"/>incisors in one jaw only,’ a term regularly applied to cattle,<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the eight incisors of which are, in fact, limited to the lower jaw.
<div n="lb"/>The ass is styled {%ubhayā-dant%} in the Atharvaveda.<sup>6</sup> In one
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>7</sup> however, the epithet is applied to
<div n="lb"/>a ram; but the sense here is that a marvel occurs, just as in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>8</sup> a ram destroys a lioness. Bloomfield<sup>9</sup> suggests
<div n="lb"/>in the Atharvaveda passage another reading which would mean
<div n="lb"/>‘horse.’ A parallel division of animals is that of the Taittirīya<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitās<sup>11</sup> into ‘whole-hoofed’ ({%eka-śapha%}) and
<div n="lb"/>‘small’ ({%kṣudra%}).
<div n="P"/>Zimmer<sup>12</sup> seeks to show from the Greek <lang n="greek"></lang><sup>13</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>Latin {%ambidens%}<sup>14</sup> that the Indo-European was familiar with
<div n="lb"/>the division of the five sacrificial animals into the two classes
<div n="lb"/>of man and horse on the one hand, and cattle, sheep, and
<div n="lb"/>goats on the other. But this supposition is not necessary.
<F>1) x. 90, 10.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 6, 3;
<div n="lb"/>v. 1, 2, 6; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 8, 1.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 3, 30
<div n="lb"/>({%ubhayato-dant%}).</F>
<F>4) ii. 2, 6, 3.</F>
<F>5) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 5; v. 1,
<div n="lb"/>2, 6; 5, 1, 3.</F>
<F>6) v. 31, 3.</F>
<F>7) v. 19, 2.</F>
<F>8) viii. 18, 17.</F>

<L>389<pc>1-099<k1>urvarA<k2>urvarA
{@Urvarā@}¦ is with {@Kṣetra@} the regular expression, from the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards, denoting a piece of ‘ploughland’ (<lang n="greek"></lang>).
<div n="lb"/>Fertile ({%apnasvatī%}) fields<sup>2</sup> are spoken of as well as waste fields
<div n="lb"/>({%ārtanā%}).<sup>3</sup> Intensive cultivation by means of irrigation is
<div n="lb"/>clearly referred to both in the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> and in the Atharva-
<div n="lb"/>veda,<sup>5</sup> while allusion is also made to the use of manure.<sup>6</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>fields ({%kṣetra%}) were carefully measured according to the Rigveda.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>This fact points clearly to individual ownership in land for the
<div n="lb"/>plough, a conclusion supported by the reference of Apālā, in
<div n="lb"/>a hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>8</sup> to her father's field ({%urvarā%}), which
<div n="lb"/>is put on the same level as his head of hair as a personal
<div n="lb"/>possession. Consistent with this are the epithets ‘winning
<div n="lb"/>fields’ ({%urvarā-sā, urvarā-jit, kṣetra-sā%}),<sup>9</sup> while ‘lord of fields’
<div n="lb"/>used of a god<sup>10</sup> is presumably a transfer of a human epithet
<div n="lb"/>({%urvarā-pati%}). Moreover, fields are spoken of in the same
[Page1-100+ 66]
<div n="lb"/>connexion as children,<sup>11</sup> and the conquest of fields ({%kṣetrāṇi%}
<div n="lb"/>{%saṃ-ji%}) is often referred to in the Saṃhitās.<sup>12</sup> Very probably, as
<div n="lb"/>suggested by Pischel,<sup>13</sup> the ploughland was bounded by grass
<div n="lb"/>land (perhaps denoted by {@Khila, Khilya@}) which in all likelihood
<div n="lb"/>would be joint property on the analogy of property elsewhere.
<div n="lb"/>There is no trace in Vedic literature of communal property
<div n="lb"/>in the sense of ownership by a community of any sort,<sup>14</sup> nor is
<div n="lb"/>there mention of communal cultivation. Individual property
<div n="lb"/>in land seems also presumed later on. In the Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad<sup>15</sup> the things given as examples of wealth include
<div n="lb"/>fields and houses ({%āyatanāni%}). The Greek evidence<sup>16</sup> also
<div n="lb"/>points to individual ownership. The precise nature of the
<div n="lb"/>ownership is of course not determined by the expression
<div n="lb"/>‘individual ownership.’ The legal relationship of the head
<div n="lb"/>of a family and its members is nowhere explained, and can
<div n="lb"/>only be conjectured (see {@Pitṛ@}). Very often a family may have
<div n="lb"/>lived together with undivided shares in the land. The rules
<div n="lb"/>about the inheritance of landed property do not occur before the
<div n="lb"/>Sūtras.<sup>17</sup> In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>18</sup> the giving of land as
<div n="lb"/>a fee to priests is mentioned, but with reproof: land was no
<div n="lb"/>doubt even then a very special kind of property, not lightly to
<div n="lb"/>be given away or parted with.<sup>19</sup>
[Page1-101+ 39]
<div n="P"/>On the relation of the owners of land to the king and
<div n="lb"/>others see {@Grāma;@} on its cultivation see {@Kṛṣi.@}
<F>1) i. 127, 6; iv. 41, 6; v. 33, 4;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 25, 4; x. 30, 3; 142, 3, etc.; Av.
<div n="lb"/>x. 6, 33; 10, 8; xiv. 2, 14, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 127, 6.</F>
<F>3) {%Ibid.%}</F>
<F>4) vii. 49, 2.</F>
<F>5) i. 6, 4; xix. 2, 2.</F>
<F>6) Av. iii. 14, 3, 4; xix. 31, 3.</F>
<F>7) i. 110, 5.</F>
<F>8) viii. 91, 5.</F>
<F>9) Rv. iv. 38, 1, and vi. 20, 1; ii. 21, 1;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 38, 1.</F>
<F>10) viii. 21, 3. {%Cf.%} {@Kṣetra.@}</F>
<F>11) Rv. iv. 41, 6, etc.</F>
<F>12) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 8, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, v. 2; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iv. 12, 3.</F>
<F>13) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 204-207.</F>
<F>14) {%Cf.%} Baden Powell, {%Indian Village%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Community%} (1899); Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%disches Leben,%} 236; Mrs. Rhys Davids,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1901,
<div n="lb"/>860.</F>
<F>15) vii. 24, 2.</F>
<F>16) {%Cf.%} Diodorus, ii. 40; Arrian, {%Indica,%}
<div n="lb"/>11; Strabo, p. 703; Hopkins, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the American Oriental Society,%} 13, 87
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq. Cf. ibid.,%} 20, 22, 23.</F>
<F>17) {%Cf.%} Gautama Dharma Sūtra, xviii.
<div n="lb"/>5 {%et seq.;%} Baudhāyana Dharma Sūtra, ii.
<div n="lb"/>2, 3; Āpastamba Dharma Sūtra, ii. 6, 14.
<div n="lb"/>Of course, the rules probably go back
<div n="lb"/>to the earlier period, but how far it is
<div n="lb"/>impossible to say. With the settlement
<div n="lb"/>of the country, however, inheritance of
<div n="lb"/>land and its partition must have become
<div n="lb"/>inevitable.</F>
<F>18) xiii. 6, 2, 18; 7, 1, 13. 15.</F>
<F>19) It is significant that in the famous
<div n="lb"/>episode (Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 9, 4)
<div n="lb"/>of Manu's division of his property,
<div n="lb"/>from which Nābhānediṣṭha was ex-
<div n="lb"/>cluded, this exclusion is made good by
<div n="lb"/>the son's obtaining cattle ({%paśavaḥ%}). It
<div n="lb"/>is clear that cattle, not land, was the
<div n="lb"/>real foundation of wealth, just as in
<div n="lb"/>Ireland, Italy ({%cf. pecunia%}), Greece, etc.
<div n="lb"/>Cattle could be, and were, used indi-
<div n="lb"/>vidually, but land was not open to a
<div n="lb"/>man's free disposal; no doubt, at any
<div n="lb"/>rate, the consent of the family or the
<div n="lb"/>community might be required, but we
<div n="lb"/>are reduced to reliance on analogy in
<div n="lb"/>view of the silence of the texts. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Schrader, {%Prehistoric Antiquities,%} 289;
<div n="lb"/>Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte,%} 94-96; Rhys
<div n="lb"/>Davids, {%Buddhist India,%} 48 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>395<pc>1-102<k1>ulUka<k2>ulUka

<div n="lb"/>roosted there.

<L>402<pc>1-103<k1>uSInara<k2>uSInara
{@Uśīnara@}¦ — In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇā<sup>1</sup> the Kuru-Pañcālas are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned as dwelling together in the ‘Middle Country’ with
<div n="lb"/>the Vaśas and the Uśīnaras. In the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad<sup>2</sup> also
<div n="lb"/>the Uśīnaras are associated with the Kuru-Pañcālas and Vaśas,
<div n="lb"/>but in the Gopatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> the Uśīnaras and Vaśas are re-
<div n="lb"/>garded as northerners. In the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> the people is alluded to
<div n="lb"/>in one passage by reference to their queen, Uśīnarāṇī. Zimmer<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thinks that the Uśīnaras earlier lived farther to the north-west,
<div n="lb"/>but for this there is no clear evidence. His theory is based
<div n="lb"/>merely on the fact that the Anukramaṇī (Index) of the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>ascribes one hymn<sup>6</sup> to Śibi Auśīnara, and that the Śibis were
<div n="lb"/>known to Alexander's followers as <lang n="greek"></lang>,<sup>7</sup> living between the
<div n="lb"/>Indus and the Akesines (Chenab). But this is in no way
<div n="lb"/>conclusive, as the Śibis, at any rate in Epic times,<sup>8</sup> occupied
<div n="lb"/>the land to the north of Kurukṣetra, and there is no reason
<div n="lb"/>whatever to show that in the Vedic period the Uśīnaras were
<div n="lb"/>farther west than the ‘Middle Country.’
<F>1) viii. 14.</F>
<F>2) iv. 1. See Keith {%Śāṅkhāyana%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Āranyaka,%} 36.</F>
<F>3) ii 9.</F>
<F>4) x. 59, 10.</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 130.</F>
<F>6) Rv. x. 179.</F>
<F>7) Diodorus, xvii. 19.</F>
<F>8) See Pargiter's map. {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1908. p. 322.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 213, 419;
<div n="lb"/>Hultzsch {%Indian Antiquary,%} 34, 179.</F>

<L>413<pc>1-106<k1>UrRA<k2>UrRA
{@Ūrṇā,@}¦ ‘wool,’ is very frequently mentioned from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards. The Paruṣṇī country was famous for its wool,<sup>2</sup> like

<div n="lb"/>{%parvan%}<sup>4</sup> or {%parus.%}<sup>5</sup> ‘Soft as wool’ ({%ūrṇa-mradas%})<sup>6</sup> is not a rare
<div n="lb"/>epithet. The sheep is called ‘woolly’ ({%ūrṇāvatī%}).<sup>7</sup> ‘Woollen
<div n="lb"/>thread’ ({%ūrṇā-sūtra%}) is repeatedly referred to in the later
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās<sup>8</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>9</sup> The word {%ūrṇā%} was not
<div n="lb"/>restricted to the sense of sheep's wool,<sup>10</sup> but might denote goat's
<div n="lb"/>hair also.<sup>11</sup>

<L>426<pc>1-109<k1>fRa<k2>fRa
{@Ṛṇa,@}¦ ‘debt,’ is repeatedly mentioned from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards, having apparently been a normal condition among
<div n="lb"/>the Vedic Indians. Reference is often made<sup>2</sup> to debts con-
<div n="lb"/>tracted at dicing. To pay off a debt was called {%ṛṇaṃ saṃ-nī.%}<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Allusion is made to debt contracted without intention of
<div n="lb"/>payment.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>The result of non-payment of a debt might be very serious:
<div n="lb"/>the dicer might fall into slavery.<sup>5</sup> Debtors, like other male-
<div n="lb"/>factors, such as thieves, were frequently bound by their
<div n="lb"/>creditors to posts ({%dru-pada%}),<sup>6</sup> presumably as a means of
<div n="lb"/>putting pressure on them or their friends to pay up the
<div n="lb"/>debt.
<div n="P"/>The amount of interest payable is impossible to make out.
<div n="lb"/>In one passage of the Rigveda and Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> an eighth
<div n="lb"/>({%śapha%}) and a sixteenth ({%kalā%}) are mentioned as paid, but it is
<div n="lb"/>quite uncertain whether interest or an instalment of the
<div n="lb"/>principal is meant. Presumably the interest would be paid
<div n="lb"/>in kind.
<div n="P"/>How far a debt was a heritable interest or obligation does
<div n="lb"/>not appear. The Kauśika Sūtra<sup>8</sup> regards three hymns of the
[Page1-110+ 64]
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> as applicable to the occasion of the payment of
<div n="lb"/>a debt after the creditor's decease. For the payment of a debt.
<div n="lb"/>by a relation of the debtor the evidence is still less clear.<sup>10</sup>
<div n="P"/>Zimmer<sup>11</sup> thinks that payments of debt were made in the
<div n="lb"/>presence of witnesses who could be appealed to in case of
<div n="lb"/>dispute. This conclusion is, however, very uncertain, resting
<div n="lb"/>solely on a vague verse in the Atharvaveda.<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) ii. 27, 4, etc., usually in a meta-
<div n="lb"/>phorical sense.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 34, 10; Av. vi. 119, 1.</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 47, 17 = Av. vi. 46, 3.</F>
<F>4) Av. vi. 119, 1.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 34. {%Cf.%} Lüders, {%Das Wūrfel-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%spiel im alten Indien,%} 61.</F>
<F>6) Rv. x. 34, 4, seems to refer rather
<div n="lb"/>to the binding and taking away as a
<div n="lb"/>slave, though Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 228, explains it as the binding of a
<div n="lb"/>debtor for non-payment, interpreting
<div n="lb"/>the obscure verse i. 169, 7, in the same
<div n="lb"/>way. But Av. vi. 115, 2, 3, may refer
<div n="lb"/>to debt, and if this is the meaning the
<div n="lb"/>allusion to binding to a post as a punish-
<div n="lb"/>ment is clear. See, however, Bloom-
<div n="lb"/>field, {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 528,
<div n="lb"/>n. 1; Whitney, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 364, who interprets the
<div n="lb"/>hymn as referring only to sin. Rv.
<div n="lb"/>i. 24, 13. 15; Av. vi. 63, 3 = 84, 4;
<div n="lb"/>121, 1 {%et seq.,%} are general; while Rv.
<div n="lb"/>vii. 86, 5; Av. xix. 47, 9; 50, 1, refer
<div n="lb"/>to the binding of thieves in the
<div n="lb"/>stocks. {%Cf.%} {@Taskara.@}</F>
<F>7) Rv. viii. 47, 17 = Av. vi. 46, 3.</F>
<F>8) xlvi. 36-40. See Caland, {%Altindisches%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Zauberritual,%} 154; Bloomfield, {%op. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>528.</F>
<F>9) vi. 117-119. The name for unpaid
<div n="lb"/>debt is in Av. vi. 117, 1, {%apamityam%}
<div n="lb"/>{%apratītam.%} In the Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 3, 8, 1, {%kusīdam apratīttam;%} in the
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 14, 17, and
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, ii. 3, 1, 8, {%kusīdam%}
<div n="lb"/>{%apratītam;%} in the Mantra Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 3. 20, {%apradattam.%}</F>
<F>10) {%Cf.%} Rv. iv. 3, 13 (a brother's sin

<F>11) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 181. This sug-

<L>428<pc>1-110<k1>ftu<k2>ftu
{@Ṛtu,@}¦ ‘season,’ is a term repeatedly mentioned from the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards, Three seasons of the year are often
<div n="lb"/>alluded to,<sup>2</sup> but the names are not usually specified. In one
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> spring ({%vasanta%}), summer ({%grīṣma%}), and
<div n="lb"/>autumn ({%śarad%}) are given. The Rigveda knows also the rainy
<div n="lb"/>season ({%prā-vṛṣ%}) and the winter ({%himā, hemanta%}). A more
<div n="lb"/>usual<sup>4</sup> division (not found in the Rigveda) is into five seasons,
[Page1-111+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>{%vasanta, grīṣma, varṣā, śarad, hemama-siśira,%} but occasionally
<div n="lb"/>the five are otherwise divided, {%varṣā-śarad%} being made one
<div n="lb"/>season.<sup>5</sup> Sometimes six<sup>6</sup> seasons are reckoned, {%hemanta%} and
<div n="lb"/>{%śiśira%} being divided, so that the six seasons can be made
<div n="lb"/>parallel to the twelve months of the year. A still more
<div n="lb"/>artificial arrangement<sup>7</sup> makes the seasons seven, possibly by
<div n="lb"/>reckoning the intercalary month as a season, as Weber and
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>8</sup> hold, or more probably because of the predilection
<div n="lb"/>for the number seven, as Roth<sup>9</sup> suggests. Occasionally the
<div n="lb"/>word {%ṛtu%} is applied to the months.<sup>10</sup> The last season,
<div n="lb"/>according to the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>11</sup> is {%hemanta.%}
<div n="P"/>The growth of the division of the seasons from three to five
<div n="lb"/>is rightly explained by Zimmer<sup>12</sup> as indicating the advance of
<div n="lb"/>the Vedic Indians towards the east. It is not Rigvedic, but
<div n="lb"/>dominates the later Saṃhitās. Traces of an earlier division of
<div n="lb"/>the year into winter and summer do not appear clearly in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, where the appropriate words {%himā%} and {%samā%} are
<div n="lb"/>merely general appellations of the year, and where {%śarad%}<sup>13</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>commoner than either as a designation of the year, because it
<div n="lb"/>denotes the harvest, a time of overwhelming importance to a
<div n="lb"/>young agricultural people. The division of the year in one
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Atharvaveda<sup>14</sup> into two periods of six months
<div n="lb"/>is merely formal, and in no way an indication of old
<div n="lb"/>tradition.
<F>1) i. 49, 3; 84, 18, etc.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 164, 2 ({%tri-nābhi%}), 48 ({%trīṇi%}
<div n="lb"/>{%nabhyāni%}); also perhaps the Ṛbhus as
<div n="lb"/>the genii of the three seasons and the
<div n="lb"/>three dawns. {%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Mythology,%} p. 133; Hillebrandt, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Mythologie,%} 2, 33 {%et seq.:%} Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, xiv. 1, 1, 28, and the {%cāturmāsyāni,%}
<div n="lb"/>or four-monthly sacrifices performed at
<div n="lb"/>the beginning of the seasons in the
<div n="lb"/>ritual (Weber, {%Naxatra,%} 2, 329 {%et seq.%}).</F>
<F>3) x. 90, 6. Hillebrandt, {%op. cit.,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>35, finds in Rv. v. 14, 4: ix. 91, 6,
<div n="lb"/>reference to three seasons in the triad
<div n="lb"/>{%gāvaḥ%} (? spring), {%āpaḥ%} (rains), {%svar%}
<div n="lb"/>{%(= gharma),%} and in the ritual literature
<div n="lb"/>(Āpastamba Śrauta Sūtra, viii. 4, 2) in
<div n="lb"/>the threefold division into {%ṛta, gharma,%}
<div n="lb"/>and {%oṣadhi.%}</F>
<F>4) Av. viii. 2, 22; 9, 15; xiii. 1, 18;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 6, 2, 3; iv. 3, 3,
<div n="lb"/>1. 2; v. 1, 10, 3; 3, 1, 2; 4. 12, 2;
