<L>430<pc>1-112<k1>ftvij<k2>ftvij
{@Ṛtv-ij@}¦ is the regular term for ‘sacrificial priest,’ covering all
<div n="lb"/>the different kinds of priests employed at the sacrifice. It
<div n="lb"/>appears certain that all the priests were Brāhmaṇas.<sup>1</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>number of priests officiating at a sacrifice with different functions
<div n="lb"/>was almost certainly seven. The oldest list, occurring in one
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Rigveda,<sup>2</sup> enumerates their names as Hotṛ, Potṛ,
<div n="lb"/>Neṣṭṛ, Agnīdh, Praśāstṛ, Adhvaryu, Brahman, besides the
<div n="lb"/>institutor of the sacrifice. The number of seven probably
<div n="lb"/>explains the phrase ‘seven Hotṛs’ occurring so frequently in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, and is most likely connected with that of the
<div n="lb"/>mythical ‘seven Ṛṣis.’ It may be compared with the eight of
<div n="lb"/>Iran.<sup>3</sup> The chief of the seven priests was the Hotṛ, who was
<div n="lb"/>the singer of the hymns, and in the early times their composer
<div n="lb"/>also. The Adhvaryu performed the practical work of the
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice, and accompanied his performance with muttered
<div n="lb"/>formulas of prayer and deprecation of evil. His chief assist-
<div n="lb"/>ance was derived from the Agnīdh, the two performing the
<div n="lb"/>smaller sacrifices without other help in practical matters. The
<div n="lb"/>Praśāstṛ, Upavaktṛ, or Maitrāvaruṇa, as he was variously
<div n="lb"/>called, appeared only in the greater sacrifices as giving in-
<div n="lb"/>structions to the Hotṛ, and as entrusted with certain litanies.
<div n="lb"/>The Potṛ, Neṣṭṛ, and Brahman belonged to the ritual of the
<div n="lb"/>Soma sacrifice, the latter being later styled Brāhmaṇāc-
<div n="lb"/>chaṃsin to distinguish him from the priest who in the later
[Page1-113+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>ritual acted as supervisor. Other priests referred to in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>4</sup> are the singers of Sāmans or chants, the Udgātṛ
<div n="lb"/>and his assistant the Prastotṛ, while the Pratihartṛ, another
<div n="lb"/>assistant, though not mentioned, may quite well have been
<div n="lb"/>known. Their functions undoubtedly represent a later stage
<div n="lb"/>of the ritual, the development of the elaborate series of
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial calls on the one hand, and on the other the use
<div n="lb"/>of long hymns addressed to the Soma plant. Other priests,
<div n="lb"/>such as the Achāvāka,<sup>5</sup> the Grāvastut, the Unnetṛ, and the
<div n="lb"/>Subrahmaṇya, were known later in the developed ritual of the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas, making in all sixteen priests, who were technically
<div n="lb"/>and artificially classed in four groups<sup>6</sup> Hotṛ, Maitrāvaruṇa,
<div n="lb"/>Achāvāka, and Grāvastut; Udgātṛ, Prastotṛ, Pratihartṛ, and
<div n="lb"/>Subrahmaṇya; Adhvaryu, Pratisthātṛ, Neṣṭṛ, and Unnetṛ;
<div n="lb"/>Brahman, Brāhmaṇācchaṃsin, Agnīdhra, and Petṛ.
<div n="P"/>Apart from all these priests was the {@Purohita,@} who was
<div n="lb"/>the spiritual adviser of the king in all his religious duties.
<div n="lb"/>Geldner<sup>7</sup> holds that, as a rule, when the Purohita actually
<div n="lb"/>took part in one of the great sacrifices he played the part of
<div n="lb"/>the Brahman, in the sense of the priest who superintended the
<div n="lb"/>whole conduct of the ritual. He sees evidence for this view in
<div n="lb"/>a considerable number of passages of the Rigveda<sup>8</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>later literature,<sup>9</sup> where Purohita and Brahman were combined
<div n="lb"/>or identified. Oldenberg,<sup>10</sup> however, more correctly points out
[Page1-114+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>that in the earlier period this was not the case: the Purohita
<div n="lb"/>was then normally the Hotṛ, the singer of the most important
<div n="lb"/>of the songs; it was only later that the Brahman, who in the
<div n="lb"/>capacity of overseer of the rite is not known to the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>acquired the function of general supervision hitherto exercised
<div n="lb"/>by the Purohita, who was {%ex officio%} skilled in the use of magic
<div n="lb"/>and in guarding the king by spells which could also be applied
<div n="lb"/>to guarding the sacrifice from evil demons. With this agrees
<div n="lb"/>the fact that Agni, pre-eminently<sup>11</sup> the Purohita of men, is also
<div n="lb"/>a Hotṛ, and that the two divine Hotṛs of the Āprī hymns are
<div n="lb"/>called<sup>12</sup> the divine Purohitas. On the other hand, the rule
<div n="lb"/>is explicitly recognized in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>13</sup> that a
<div n="lb"/>Kṣatriya should have a Brahman as a Purohita; and in
<div n="lb"/>the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>14</sup> the Vasiṣṭha family have a special
<div n="lb"/>claim to the office of Brahman-Purohita, perhaps an indi-
<div n="lb"/>cation that it was they who first as Purohitas exchanged the
<div n="lb"/>function of Hotṛs for that of Brahmans in the sacrificial
<div n="lb"/>ritual.
<div n="P"/>The sacrifices were performed for an individual in the great
<div n="lb"/>majority of cases. The Sattra,<sup>15</sup> or prolonged sacrificial session,
<div n="lb"/>was, however, performed for the common benefit of the priests
<div n="lb"/>taking part in it, though its advantageous results could only be
<div n="lb"/>secured if all the members actually engaged were consecrated
<div n="lb"/>({%dīkṣita%}). Sacrifices for a people as such were unknown. The
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice for the king was, it is true, intended to bring about
<div n="lb"/>the prosperity of his people also; but it is characteristic that
<div n="lb"/>the prayer<sup>16</sup> for welfare includes by name only the priest and
<div n="lb"/>the king, referring to the people indirectly in connexion with
<div n="lb"/>the prosperity of their cattle and agriculture.
<F>1) This is assumed throughout the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic texts, and is accompanied by
<div n="lb"/>the rule that no Kṣatriya can eat of
<div n="lb"/>the sacrificial offering ({%Cf.%} Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vii. 26): no doubt because
<div n="lb"/>only the Brāhmaṇas were sufficiently
<div n="lb"/>holy to receive the divine essence of
<div n="lb"/>the sacrifice into which, by partaking
<div n="lb"/>of it, the deity has entered in part.</F>
<F>2) ii. 1, 2. {%Cf.%} Oldenberg. {%Rdigion%}
<div n="lb"/>{%des Veda,%} 383.</F>

<div n="lb"/>lxx {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) Rv. viii. 81. 5.</F>
<F>5) {%Cf.,%} for the Achāvāka, Kauṣītaki

<div n="lb"/>{%Recherches sur l'histoire de la liturgie%}
<div n="lb"/>{%védique,%} 47; Oldenberg. {%Religion des%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Veda,%} 397, n. 2. The other three occur
<div n="lb"/>in the Aitareya and other Brāhmaṇas.

<LEND>

<L>435<pc>1-115<k1>fzi<k2>fzi
{@Ṛṣi,@}¦ ‘seer,’ is primarily a composer of hymns to the gods.
<div n="lb"/>In the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> reference is often made to previous singers
<div n="lb"/>and to contemporary poets. Old poems were inherited and
<div n="lb"/>refurbished by members of the composer's family,<sup>2</sup> but the
<div n="lb"/>great aim of the singers was to produce new and approved
<div n="lb"/>hymns.<sup>3</sup> It is not till the time of the Brāhmaṇas that the
[Page1-116+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>composition of hymns appears to have fallen into disuse,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>though poetry was still produced, for example, in the form of
<div n="lb"/>{@Gāthās,@} which the priests were required to compose them-
<div n="lb"/>selves<sup>5</sup> and sing to the accompaniment of the lute at the
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice. The Ṛṣi was the most exalted of Brāhmaṇas,<sup>6</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>his skill, which is often compared with that of a carpenter,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>was regarded as heaven-sent.<sup>8</sup> The Purohita, whether as Hotṛ
<div n="lb"/>or as Brahman (see {@Ṛtvij@}), was a singer.<sup>9</sup> No doubt the Ṛṣis
<div n="lb"/>were normally<sup>10</sup> attached to the houses of the great, the petty
<div n="lb"/>kings of Vedic times, or the nobles of the royal household.
<div n="lb"/>Nor need it be doubted that occasionally<sup>11</sup> the princes them-
<div n="lb"/>selves essayed poetry: a Rājanyarṣi, the prototype of the later
<div n="lb"/>Rājarṣi or ‘royal seer,’ who appears in the Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>12</sup> though he must be mythical as Oldenberg<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>points out, indicates that kings cultivated poetry<sup>14</sup> just as later
<div n="lb"/>they engaged in philosophic disputations.<sup>15</sup> Normally, how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, the poetical function is Brahminical, Viśāmitra and others
<div n="lb"/>not being kings, but merely Brāhmaṇas, in the Rigveda.
<div n="P"/>In the later literature the Ṛṣis are the poets of the hymns
<div n="lb"/>preserved in the Saṃhitās. a Ṛṣi being regularly<sup>16</sup> cited when
<div n="lb"/>a Vedic Saṃhitā is quoted. Moreover, the Ṛṣis become the
<div n="lb"/>representatives of a sacred past, and are regarded as holy sages,
[Page1-117+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>whose deeds are narrated as if they were the deeds of gods or
<div n="lb"/>Asuras.<sup>17</sup> They are typified by a particular group of seven,<sup>18</sup>
<div n="lb"/>mentioned four times in the Rigveda,<sup>19</sup> several times in the
<div n="lb"/>later Saṃhitās,<sup>20</sup> and enumerated in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad<sup>21</sup> as Gotama, Bharadvāja, Viśvāmitra, Jamadagni,
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭha, Kaśyapa, and Atri. In the Rigveda itself Kutsa,<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Atri,<sup>23</sup> Rebha,<sup>24</sup> Agastya,<sup>25</sup> the Kuśikas,<sup>26</sup> Vasiṣṭha,<sup>27</sup> Vyaśva,<sup>28</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and others appear as Ṛṣis; and the Atharvaveda<sup>29</sup> contains a
<div n="lb"/>long list, including Aṅgiras, Agastī, Jamadagni, Atri, Kaśyapa,
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭha, Bharadvāja, Gaviṣṭhira, Viśvāmitra, Kutsa, Kakṣīvant,
<div n="lb"/>Kaṇva, Medhātithi, Triśoka, Uśanā Kāvya, Gotama, and
<div n="lb"/>Mudgala.
<div n="P"/>Competition among the bards appears to have been known.
<div n="lb"/>This is one of the sides of the riddle poetry ({@Brahmodya@}) that
<div n="lb"/>forms a distinctive feature<sup>30</sup> of the Vedic ritual of the Aśva-
<div n="lb"/>medha, or horse sacrifice. In the Upaniṣad period such
<div n="lb"/>competitions were quite frequent. The most famous was that
<div n="lb"/>of Yājñavalkya, which was held at the court of Janaka of
<div n="lb"/>Videha, as detailed in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>31</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>which was a source of annoyance to {@Ajātaśatru@} of {@Kāśī.@}<sup>32</sup>
<div n="lb"/>According to an analogous practice, a Brāhmaṇa, like {@Uddālaka@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Aruṇi,@} would go about disputing with all he came across, and
<div n="lb"/>compete with them for a prize of money.<sup>33</sup>
<F>1) i. 1, 2; 45, 3; viii. 43, 13, etc.</F>
<F>2) i. 89, 3; 96, 2; iii. 39, 2; viii. 6.
<div n="lb"/>11. 43; 76, 6, etc.</F>
<F>3) i. 109, 2; ii. 18, 3; iii. 62, 7;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 50, 6; vii. 14, 4; 93, 1; viii. 23,
<div n="lb"/>14, etc.</F>
<F>4) Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 151.</F>
<F>5) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 4, 2, 8;
<div n="lb"/>3, 5.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ix. 96, 6, etc. {%Cf.%} Satapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xii. 4, 4, 6, where pre-
<div n="lb"/>eminence is assigned to a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>descended from a Ṛṣi.</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 130, 6; v. 2, 11; 29, 15; 73,
<div n="lb"/>10; x. 39, 14. So a poet is a Kāru-
<div n="lb"/>(if from {%kṛ,%} ‘make,’ but usually derived
<div n="lb"/>from {%kṛ,%} ‘commemorate’), and makes
<div n="lb"/>({%kṛ,%} Rv. ii. 39. 8; viii. 62, 4) as well as
<div n="lb"/>creates ({%jan,%} Rv. vii. 15, 4; viii. 88, 4)

<L>444<pc>1-119<k1>ekAzwakA<k2>ekAzwakA

<div n="lb"/>‘sole Aṣṭakā,’ must denote not merely any Aṣṭakā, but some
<div n="lb"/>particular one. Sāyaṇa, in his commentary on the Atharva-

<div n="lb"/>the date meant by the term as the eighth day in the dark half
<div n="lb"/>of the month of Māgha (January — February). The Ekāṣṭakā,
<div n="lb"/>is declared in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup> to be the time for the
<div n="lb"/>consecration ({%dīkṣā%}) of those who are going to perform a year
<div n="lb"/>long sacrifice. See also {@Māsa.@}
<F>1) xv. 16, 2. {%Cf.%} Satapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, vi. 2, 2, 23; 4, 2, 10.</F>
<F>2) iii. 10.</F>
<F>3) vii. 4, 8 1. {%Cf.%} iii. 3, 8, 4; iv. 3,
<div n="lb"/>11, 1; v. 7, 2, 2; Pañcaviṃśa Brāl
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, v. 9, 4.

<L>458<pc>1-122<k1>EtihAsika<k2>EtihAsika

<L>463<pc>1-123<k1>EzAvIra<k2>EzAvIra
{@Aiṣā-vīra.@}¦ — The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa once<sup>1</sup> refers to the
<div n="lb"/>Aiṣā-vīras as officiating at a sacrifice, with the implication that
<div n="lb"/>they were bad sacrificers. Sāyaṇa regards the word as a
<div n="lb"/>proper name (‘descendants of Eṣavīra’), denoting the members
<div n="lb"/>of a despised family. But Roth may be right in explaining
<div n="lb"/>the word both in the passage mentioned above and elsewhere
<div n="lb"/>as meaning ‘weak’<sup>2</sup> or ‘insignificant man.’<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) xi. 2, 7, 32.</F>
<F>2) In the St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) In Böhtlingk's Dictionary, {%s.v.%}
<div n="lb"/>(‘one who wishes to be a man, but is
<div n="lb"/>not’). {%Cf.%} Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ix. 5,
<div n="lb"/>1, 16; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, where,
<div n="lb"/>however, Lindner's edition reads {%saiṣā%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vīra iva. Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 228; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%East,%} 44, 45.</F>

<L>465<pc>1-123<k1>ogaRa<k2>ogaRa
{@Ogaṇa@}¦ is a word occurring only once, as a plural, in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where it appears to indicate persons hostile to the

<L>466<pc>1-123<k1>otu<k2>otu
{@Otu@}¦ in Vedic literature<sup>1</sup> denotes the ‘woof’ in weaving and
<div n="lb"/>corresponds to {@Tantu,@} ‘the warp,’ the roots {%vā,%}<sup>2</sup> ‘to weave,’
<div n="lb"/>and {%tan,%}<sup>3</sup> to stretch,’ from which these two terms are derived,
<div n="lb"/>being used in parallel senses. In the process of weaving a
<div n="lb"/>shuttle ({@Tasara@}) was used. The ‘weaver’ is termed {%vāya,%}<sup>4</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>the ‘loom’ {%veman.%}<sup>5</sup> A wooden peg ({@Mayūkha@}) was used to
[Page1-124+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>stretch the web on, while lead was employed as a weight to
<div n="lb"/>extend it.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>The work of weaving was probably the special care of
<div n="lb"/>women.<sup>7</sup> A metaphor in the Atharvaveda<sup>8</sup> personifies Night
<div n="lb"/>and Day as two sisters weaving the web of the year, the
<div n="lb"/>nights serving as warp, the days as woof.
<F>1) Rv. vi. 9, 2. 3; Av. xiv. 2, 51;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 9, 2. etc.</F>
<F>3) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 80;
<div n="lb"/>Rv. x. 130, 2; Av. x. 7, 43, etc.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 26, 6, etc.</F>
<F>5) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 83.</F>
<F>6) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 80.</F>
<F>7) Av. x. 7, 42; xiv. 2, 51. {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 92. 3.</F>
<F>8) x. 7, 42; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 5, 5, 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 254,
<div n="lb"/>255; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 465.</F>
<LEND>

<L>468<pc>1-124<k1>opaSa<k2>opaSa
{@Opaśa@}¦ is a word of somewhat doubtful sense, occurring in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> and occasionally later.<sup>3</sup> It
<div n="lb"/>probably means a ‘plait’ as used in dressing the hair, especially
<div n="lb"/>of women,<sup>4</sup> but apparently, in earlier times,<sup>5</sup> of men also.
<div n="lb"/>The goddess Sinīvālī is called {%svaupaśā,%}<sup>6</sup> an epithet of doubtful
<div n="lb"/>sense, from which Zimmer<sup>7</sup> conjectures that the wearing of
[Page1-125+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>false plaits of hair was not unknown in Vedic times. What
<div n="lb"/>was the difference between the braids referred to in the
<div n="lb"/>epithets {%pṛthu ṣṭuka,%}<sup>8</sup> ‘having broad braids,’ and {%viṣita-ṣṭuka,%}<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>‘having loosened braids,’ and the Opaśa cannot be made out
<div n="lb"/>from the evidence available. Geldner<sup>10</sup> thinks that the original
<div n="lb"/>sense was ‘horn,’ and that when the word applies to Indra<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>it means ‘diadem.’
<F>1) x. 85. 8, {%Cf.%} i. 173, 6; viii. 14, 5;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 71. 1.</F>
<F>2) vi. 138, 1. 2; ix. 3, 8, where it is
<div n="lb"/>applied metaphorically in describing
<div n="lb"/>the roof of a house.</F>
<F>3) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, iv. 1, 1.</F>
<F>4) Av. vi. 138. 1, 2.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 173, 6; viii. 14, 5.</F>
<F>6) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 5, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 5; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 56. The reading
<div n="lb"/>is uncertain. Bloomfield (see below)
<div n="lb"/>assumes {%sv-opaśā%} to be the correct form
<div n="lb"/>(‘having a fair {%opaśa%}’).</F>
<F>7) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 264.</F>
<F>8) Rv. x. 86, 8.</F>
<F>9) Rv. i. 167, 5 (of Rodasī).</F>
<F>10) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 131, quoting
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 4, 3, where
<div n="lb"/>{%dvy-epaśāḥ%} is used of cattle; but the
<div n="lb"/>sense may be figurative.</F>
<F>11) Rv. viii. 14, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 538, 539; Whitney, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Atharvaveda, 348.</F>

<L>469<pc>1-125<k1>ozaDi<k2>ozaDi
{@Oṣadhi.@}¦ — Roughly speaking, the vegetable world is divided
<div n="lb"/>in Vedic literature<sup>1</sup> between Oṣadhi or {@Vīrudh@} ‘plants’ and
<div n="lb"/>{@Vana@} or {@Vṛkṣa@} ‘trees.’ Oṣadhi is employed in opposition to
<div n="lb"/>Vīrudh to denote plants as possessing a healing power or some
<div n="lb"/>other quality useful to men, while Vīrudh is rather a generic
<div n="lb"/>term for minor vegetable growths, but sometimes,<sup>2</sup> when occur-
<div n="lb"/>ring beside Oṣadhi, signifies those plants which do not possess
<div n="lb"/>medicinal properties.
<div n="P"/>A list of the minor parts of which a plant is made up is given
<div n="lb"/>in the later Saṃhitās.<sup>3</sup> It comprises the root ({%mūla%}), the
<div n="lb"/>panicle ({%tūla%}), the stem ({%kāṇḍa%}), the twig ({%valśa%}), the flower
<div n="lb"/>({%puṣpa%}), and the fruit ({%phala%}), while trees<sup>4</sup> have, in addition, a
<div n="lb"/>corona ({%skandha%}), branches ({%śākhā%}), and leaves ({%parṇa%}). The
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> gives an elaborate, though not very intelligible,
<div n="lb"/>division of plants into those which expand ({%pra-stṛṇatīḥ%}), are
<div n="lb"/>bushy ({%stambinīḥ%}), have only one sheath ({%eka-śuṅgāḥ%}), are
<div n="lb"/>creepers ({%pra-tanvatīḥ%}), have many stalks ({%aṃśumatīḥ%}), are
[Page1-126+ 35]
<div n="lb"/>jointed ({%kāṇḍinīḥ%}), or have spreading branches ({%vi-śākhāḥ%}). In
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> plants are termed ‘fruitful’ ({%phalinīḥ%}), ‘blossom-
<div n="lb"/>ing’ ({%puṣpavatīḥ%}), and ‘having flowers’ ({%pra-sūvarīḥ%}).
<F>1) Rv. x. 97 and {%passim. Oṣadhi-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vanaspati%} is a frequent compound, from
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa (vi. 1, 1, 12)
<div n="lb"/>onwards. The medicinal properties of
<div n="lb"/>plants account for the epithet ‘of
<div n="lb"/>manifold powers’ ({%nānā-vīryā%}) applied
<div n="lb"/>to them in Av. xii. 1, 2.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 3, 2.</F>
<F>3) {%Ibid.,%} vii. 3, 19, 1; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xxii. 28.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 20, 1.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Rv. i. 32, 5; Av. x. 7, 38.</F>
<F>5) viii. 7, 4, with Whitney's notes.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Atharva-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%veda,%} 579; Henry, {%Les livres VIII. et%}
<div n="lb"/>{%IX. de l' Atharvavéda,%} 58 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>6) x. 97. 3. 15. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben.%} 57.</F>
<LEND>

<L>487<pc>1-129<k1>Orva<k2>Orva
{@Aurva,@}¦ ‘descendant of Uru or Urva,’ appears in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>in close connexion with {@Bhṛgu,@} being probably a Bhṛgu
<div n="lb"/>himself. As in one passage of the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>descendants of Aitaśa are called the worst of the Aurvas, while
<div n="lb"/>the parallel version of the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> calls them the
<div n="lb"/>worst of the Bhṛgus, the Aurvas must have been a branch of
<div n="lb"/>the larger family of the Bhṛgus. Aurva himself is said in the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup> to have received offspring from Atri. In
<div n="lb"/>the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> two Aurvas are referred to as
<div n="lb"/>authorities. See also {@Kutsa.@}
<F>1) viii. 102, 4.</F>
<F>2) vi. 33.</F>
<F>3) xxx. 5.</F>

<L>495<pc>1-131<k1>kakuha<k2>kakuha
{@Kakuha,@}¦ a word occurring several times in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>understood by Roth<sup>2</sup> to designate part of a chariot, perhaps the
<div n="lb"/>seat. Ludwig,<sup>3</sup> again, regards it in one passage<sup>4</sup> as the proper
<div n="lb"/>name of a Yādava prince who took spoil from {@Tirindira,@} the
<div n="lb"/>{@Parśu,@} but this view is hardly probable.<sup>5</sup> It is, on the whole,
<div n="lb"/>most likely that the word always means ‘chief,’ ‘pre-eminent,’
<div n="lb"/>being applied as an epithet to horses, chariots, princes, etc.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>This is the only sense given by Grassmann,<sup>7</sup> and later adopted
<div n="lb"/>by Roth.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) i. 46, 3; 181 5; 184, 3; ii. 34, 11;

<L>498<pc>1-131<k1>kakzIvant<k2>kakzIvant
{@Kakṣīvant@}¦ is the name of a Ṛṣi mentioned frequently in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and occasionally elsewhere.<sup>2</sup> He appears to have
<div n="lb"/>been a descendant of a female slave named Uśij.<sup>3</sup> He must
<div n="lb"/>have been a {@Pajra@} by family, as he bears the epithet Pajriya,<sup>4</sup>
[Page1-132+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>and his descendants are called Pajras.<sup>5</sup> In a hymn of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>6</sup> he celebrates the prince {@Svanaya Bhāvya,@} who
<div n="lb"/>dwelt on the {@Sindhu@} (Indus), as having bestowed magnificent
<div n="lb"/>gifts on him; and the list of Nārāśaṃsas (‘Praises of Heroes’)
<div n="lb"/>in the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>7</sup> mentions one by Kakṣīvant
<div n="lb"/>Auśija in honour of Svanaya Bhāvayavya. In his old age he
<div n="lb"/>obtained as a wife the maiden {@Vṛcayā.@}<sup>8</sup> He appears to have
<div n="lb"/>lived to be a hundred,<sup>9</sup> the typical length of life in the Vedas.
<div n="lb"/>He seems always to be thought of as belonging to the past, and
<div n="lb"/>in a hymn of the fourth book of the Rigveda<sup>10</sup> he is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>with the semi-mythical {@Kutsa@} and {@Kavi Uśanas.@} Later, also,
<div n="lb"/>he is a teacher of bygone days.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>In Vedic literature he is not connected with {@Dīrghatamas@}
<div n="lb"/>beyond being once mentioned along with him in a hymn of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>12</sup> But in the Bṛhaddevatā<sup>13</sup> he appears as a son of
<div n="lb"/>Dīrghatamas by a slave woman, Uśij.
<div n="P"/>Weber<sup>14</sup> considers that Kakṣīvant was originally a Kṣatriya,
<div n="lb"/>not a Brāhmaṇa, quoting in favour of this view the fact that
<div n="lb"/>he is mentioned beside kings like {@Para Āṭṇāra, Vītahavya@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Śrāyasa,@} and {@Trasadasyu Paurukutsya.@}<sup>15</sup> But that these are
<div n="lb"/>all kings is an unnecessary assumption: these persons are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the passages in question undoubtedly only as
<div n="lb"/>famous men of old, to whom are ascribed mythical sacrificial
<div n="lb"/>performances, and who thus gained numerous sons.
<F>1) i. 18, 1; 51, 13; 112, 11; 116, 7;
<div n="lb"/>117, 6; 126, 3; iv. 26, 1; viii. 9, 10;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 74, 8; x. 25, 10; 61, 16.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 29, 5, and passage noted
<div n="lb"/>below.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 18, 1; perhaps also i, 112,
<div n="lb"/>11, but Auśija may there be a separate
<div n="lb"/>name (see Auśija). {%Cf.%} Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xiv. 11, 16.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 116, 7; 117, 6.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 126, 4.</F>
<F>6) i. 126.</F>
<F>7) xvi. 4, 5.</F>
<F>8) Rv. i. 51, 13.</F>
<F>9) Rv. ix. 74, 8.</F>
<F>10) iv. 26, 1.</F>
<F>11) Av. iv. 29, 5; xviii. 3, 15; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 21, 6. 7; Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 11.</F>
<F>12) viii. 9, 10</F>
<F>13) iv. 11 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>14) {%Episches im vedischen Ritual,%} 22-25.</F>
<F>15) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 6, 5, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxii. 3; Pancaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xxv. 16, 3, {%Cf.%} xiv. 11, 16.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 221,
<div n="lb"/>236, n. 1; Ludwig Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, 3, 102; Geldner, {%Rigveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Kommentar,%} 23, 24.</F>

<L>505<pc>1-134<k1>kaRva<k2>kaRva
{@Kaṇva@}¦ is the name of an ancient Ṛṣi repeatedly referred to
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda and later.<sup>1</sup> His sons and descendants,<sup>2</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Kaṇvas, are also often mentioned, especially in the eighth
<div n="lb"/>book of the Rigveda, the authorship of that book, as well as of
<div n="lb"/>part of the first, being attributed to this family. A descendant
<div n="lb"/>of Kaṇva is also denoted by the name in the singular, either
<div n="lb"/>alone<sup>3</sup> or accompanied by a patronymic, as Kaṇva Nārṣada<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and Kaṇva Śrāyasa,<sup>5</sup> besides in the plural the Kaṇvas Sauśra-
<div n="lb"/>vasas.<sup>6</sup> The Kaṇva family appears to have been connected with
<div n="lb"/>the Atri family,<sup>7</sup> but not to have been of great importance.<sup>8</sup> In
<div n="lb"/>one passage of the Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> they seem to be definitely
<div n="lb"/>regarded with hostility.

<L>508<pc>1-135<k1>kanaknaka<k2>kanaknaka
{@Kanaknaka,@}¦ a word occurring once in the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>either denotes a poison or is an adjective qualifying {%kāṇḍā-viṣa,%}
<div n="lb"/>a species of poison.
<F>1) x. 4, 22. {%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Atharvaveda,%} 604; Whitney,
<div n="lb"/>Translation of the Atharvaveda,
<div n="lb"/>578.</F>

<L>509<pc>1-135<k1>kanA<k2>kanA
{@Kanā, Kanyā.@}¦ — Both these words, of which the former is
<div n="lb"/>very rare,<sup>1</sup> while the latter is the normal term from the Rigveda<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards, denote ‘maiden’ or ‘young woman.’ It is doubtful
<div n="lb"/>whether Kanīnakā (accented on the final syllable) has this
<div n="lb"/>meaning,<sup>3</sup> or only denotes the pupil of the eye,<sup>4</sup> which is the
<div n="lb"/>sense of {%kanīnakā%} or {%kanīnikā%} (both accented on the ante-
<div n="lb"/>penultimate) in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas. See
<div n="lb"/>also {@Strī.@}
<F>1) Rv. x. 61, 5, etc.</F>
<F>2) i. 123, 10; 161, 5; iii. 23, 10, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Av. i. 14, 2; xi. 5, 18; xii, 1, 25,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>3) Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.,%} cites in this sense Rv. iv. 32,
<div n="lb"/>23; x. 40, 9; Nirukta, iv. 15; but
<div n="lb"/>neither of the Rv. passages is at all
<div n="lb"/>clear.</F>
<F>4) See Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 401; Keith, {%Aitareya Āraṇyāka,%}
<div n="lb"/>207. Other rare forms are {%kanyanā,%}
<div n="lb"/>Rv. viii. 35, 5; {%kauyalā,%} Av. v. 5, 3;
<div n="lb"/>xiv. 2, 52.</F>
<LEND>

<L>511<pc>1-135<k1>kaparda<k2>kaparda
{@Kaparda,@}¦ ‘braid,’ {@Kapardin,@} ‘wearing braids.’ These words
<div n="lb"/>refer to the Vedic custom of wearing the hair in braids or
<div n="lb"/>plaits. Thus a maiden is said to have her hair in four plaits
<div n="lb"/>({%catuṣ-kapardā%}),<sup>1</sup> and the goddess Sinīvālī is described as ‘wear-
<div n="lb"/>ing fair braids’ ({%su-kapardā%}).<sup>2</sup> Men also wore their hair in this
<div n="lb"/>style, for both Rudra<sup>3</sup> and Pūṣan<sup>4</sup> are said to have done so,
<div n="lb"/>while the {@Vasiṣṭhas@}<sup>5</sup> were distinguished by wearing their hair
<div n="lb"/>in a plait on the right ({%dakṣiṇatas-kaparda%}). The opposite was
<div n="lb"/>to wear one's hair ‘plain’ ({%pulasti%}).<sup>6</sup> See also {@Opaśa.@}
<F>1) Rv. x. 114, 3.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 56.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 114, 1. 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, xvi. 10. 29. 43. 48. 59.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 55, 2; ix. 67. 11.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 33, 1. {%Cf.%} 83, 8.</F>
<F>6) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 43.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 264,
<div n="lb"/>265; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} v. 462; Max
<div n="lb"/>Müller, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 424.</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-136+ 53]

<L>512<pc>1-136<k1>kapi<k2>kapi<h>1
1. {@Kapi,@}¦ ‘monkey,’ occurs only once in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> with
<div n="lb"/>reference to Vṛṣā-kapi, the ‘Man-ape,’ in the dialogue of Indra
<div n="lb"/>and Indrāṇī in the presence of Vṛṣākapi. There the ape is
<div n="lb"/>termed the ‘tawny’ ({%harita%}). In the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> the monkey
<div n="lb"/>is mentioned several times as hairy, and an enemy of dogs.
<div n="lb"/>That the ape was tamed appears from its position in the
<div n="lb"/>Vṛṣākapi hymn, and from the mention, in the Taittirīya Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā,<sup>3</sup> of a {@Mayu@} as belonging to the forest. See also {@Mayu,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Markaṭa,@} and {@Puruṣa Hastin.@}
<F>1) x. 86. 5. {%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Religion%}
<div n="lb"/>{%des Veda,%} 174; Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 22 {%et seq.;%} von Schroeder, {%Mysterium%}
<div n="lb"/>{%und Mimus,%} 304 {%et seq.;%} Schirmeisen,
<div n="lb"/>{%Die Arischen Göttergestalten,%} 218 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Tilak, {%Orion,%} 170-197.</F>
<F>2) iii. 9, 4; iv. 32, 11; vi. 49, 1.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} also Chāndogya Upaniṣad, i. 6, 7
<div n="lb"/>({%kapy-āsa,%} ‘seat of an ape’).</F>
<F>3) iv. 2, 10, 1. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%disches Leben,%} 85, 86.</F>
<LEND>

<L>513<pc>1-136<k1>kapi<k2>kapi<h>2

<div n="lb"/>another name for Luśa Khārgali in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā
<div n="lb"/>(xxx. 2), but the name appears rather to be {@Luśākapi.@}

<L>517<pc>1-137<k1>kapota<k2>kapota
{@Kapota@}¦ is the name of a bird, probably the ‘pigeon’ (its
<div n="lb"/>sense in the later language), occurring from the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>onwards.<sup>1</sup> It is associated in some passages<sup>2</sup> with the owl
<div n="lb"/>({@Ulūka@}) as a messenger of Nirṛti (‘dissolution,’ ‘misfortune’).
<div n="lb"/>This aspect of the pigeon as a bird of evil omen is probably
<div n="lb"/>based on an ancient belief which is also found beyond the
<div n="lb"/>confines of India.<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 30, 4; Av. xx. 135, 12;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 4; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 23. 38.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 165, 1-5; Av. vi. 29, 2.</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Schrader, {%Prchistoric Antiquities,%}
<div n="lb"/>253.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 89;
<div n="lb"/>St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>

<L>521<pc>1-138<k1>kamboja<k2>kamboja
{@Kamboja. — Yāska,@}¦ in the Nirukta,<sup>1</sup> refers to the speech of
<div n="lb"/>the Kambojas as differing from that of the other Āryas. The
<div n="lb"/>Kambojas were later settled to the north-west of the Indus, and
<div n="lb"/>are known as Kambujiya in the old Persian inscriptions. A
<div n="lb"/>teacher, {@Kāmboja Aupamanyava,@} pupil of {@Madragāra,@} is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Vaṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> This points to a possible
<div n="lb"/>connexion of the Madras, or more probably the {@Uttara Madras,@}
<div n="lb"/>with the Kambojas, who probably had Iranian as well as Indian
<div n="lb"/>affinities.
<F>1) ii. 2.</F>
<F>2) {%Indische Studien,%} 4, 372.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 102;
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Indische Streifen,%} 2, 493; 3, 384;
<div n="lb"/>{%Indische Studien,%} 10, 7; {%Episches im%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vedischen Ritual,%} 45; Max Müller, {%Zeit-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%schrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gesellschaft,%} 7, 373. On the relation of
<div n="lb"/>Indian and Iranian, see also Jacobi,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1909,
<div n="lb"/>721 {%et seq.;%} 1910, 457 {%et seq.;%} Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%ibid.,%} 1095 {%et seq.;%} Keith, {%ibid.,%} 1100 {%et%}
<div n="lb"/>{%seq.;%} Kennedy, {%ibid.,%} 1107 {%et seq.;%} and
<div n="lb"/>see {@Parśu.@}</F>

<L>523<pc>1-138<k1>karamBa<k2>karamBa

<div n="lb"/>of porridge made of grain ({@Yava@}), which was unhusked, parched
<div n="lb"/>slightly, and kneaded.<sup>2</sup> It was the especial sacrificial portion of
<div n="lb"/>Pūṣan, no doubt in his capacity of an agricultural deity.
<div n="lb"/>Karmabha was also made of barley ({@Upavāka@})<sup>3</sup> or of sesame
<div n="lb"/>({@Tirya@}).<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 187, 16; iii. 52, 7; vi. 56, 1;
<div n="lb"/>57, 2; viii. 102, 2; Av. iv. 7, 2. 3;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 16, 1; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 10,
<div n="lb"/>2; vi. 5, 11, 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 5, 2, 14;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 2, 4, 18. {%Cf.%} Schrader, {%Prehistoric%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Antiquities,%} 317; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the East,%} 12, 395, n. 1.</F>
<F>3) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 22.</F>
<F>4) Av. iv. 7, 3, but see Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 377; Whit-
<div n="lb"/>ney, Translation of the Atharvaveda,
<div n="lb"/>155.

<L>533<pc>1-140<k1>karmAra<k2>karmAra
{@Karmāra,@}¦ the ‘smith,’ is several times mentioned with
<div n="lb"/>approval in the Vedic Saṃhitās.<sup>1</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> smiths
<div n="lb"/>appear with fishermen ({%dhīvānaḥ%}) and chariot-builders ({%ratha-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%kārāḥ%}), all being classified as clever workers ({%manīṣiṇaḥ%}):
<div n="lb"/>possibly a quasi-caste of smiths was already developing from
<div n="lb"/>the guild organization that probably existed.<sup>3</sup>
<div n="P"/>Little is known of the smith's methods of work and of his
<div n="lb"/>tools. No doubt he smelted ({%dhmā%}) the ore in the fire; hence
<div n="lb"/>he is called {%dhmātṛ,%} the ‘smelter.’<sup>4</sup> Mention is also made of
[Page1-141+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>his bellows of birds' feathers.<sup>5</sup> He made metal vessels ({%gharma%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ayasmaya%})<sup>6</sup> to be put on the fire: even the Soma cup could
<div n="lb"/>occasionally be made of hammered metal ({%ayo-hata%}).<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) Rv. x. 72, 2; Av. iii. 5, 6; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xvii. 13; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 9, 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;
<div n="lb"/>xxx. 7. {%Cf. karmāra,%} Rv. ix. 112, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 3, 1.</F>
<F>2) iii. 5, 6. The exact sense of the
<div n="lb"/>passage is doubtful. Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%disches Leben,%} 252; Bloomfield, {%Hymns%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Atharvaveda,%} 144; and Whitney,
<div n="lb"/>Translation of the Atharvaveda, 92,
<div n="lb"/>take the reference to be to ‘skilled
<div n="lb"/>chariot-makers’ ({%dhīvāno ratha-kārāḥ%})
<div n="lb"/>and ‘clever smiths,’ but this is perhaps
<div n="lb"/>less likely. The commentator interprets
<div n="lb"/>{%dhīvānaḥ%} as ‘fishermen’ (in the later
<div n="lb"/>language {%dhīvara%} means both a ‘clever
<div n="lb"/>man’ and a ‘fisherman’).</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Fick, {%Die sociale Gliederung,%} 182.</F>
<F>4) Rv. v. 9. 5.</F>
<F>5) Rv. ix. 112, 2.</F>
<F>6) Rv. v. 30, 15.</F>
<F>7) Rv. ix. 1, 2.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 252, 253; Weber,
<div n="lb"/>{%Indische Studien,%} 17, 196 {%et seq.; Über%}
<div n="lb"/>{%den Rājasūya,%} 19 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>540<pc>1-142<k1>kali<k2>kali<h>2
2. {@Kali@}¦ occurs in the Rigveda, twice in the singular<sup>1</sup> as the
<div n="lb"/>name of a protégé of the Aśvins, and once in the plural.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The persons meant in the latter passage seem to be different
<div n="lb"/>from the former one. The Kalis are once mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> beside the Gandharvas.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) i. 112, 15; x. 39, 8.</F>
<F>2) viii. 66, 15.</F>
<F>3) x. 10, 13.</F>
<F>4) These Kalis may be connected with
<div n="lb"/>dicing, as in the Atharvaveda the
<div n="lb"/>Apsarases, the wives of the Gandharvas,
<div n="lb"/>are fond of dice, and bestow luck at
<div n="lb"/>play. See Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 135.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 17, 89; Ludwig, Trans-
<div n="lb"/>lation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</F>

<L>545<pc>1-143<k1>kavaza<k2>kavaza
{@Kavaṣa@}¦ is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as one of
<div n="lb"/>those whom, together with the {@Druhyu@} king, Indra overthrew
<div n="lb"/>for the {@Tṛtsus.@} The Anukramaṇī (Index) also attributes to
<div n="lb"/>him the authorship of several hymns of the Rigveda, including
<div n="lb"/>two (x. 32. 33) that deal with a prince {@Kuruśravaṇa@} and his
<div n="lb"/>descendant {@Upamaśravas.@} There seems no reason to doubt
<div n="lb"/>this attribution, which is accepted by both Zimmer<sup>2</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Geldner.<sup>3</sup> The former holds that Kavaṣa was the Purohita of
<div n="lb"/>the joint tribes named {@Vaikarṇa,@} in whom he sees the Kuru-
<div n="lb"/>Krivi (Pañcāla) peoples, and that Kavaṣa in that capacity is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Rigveda as representative of those peoples.
<div n="lb"/>He also suggests that the language of Rigveda x. 33, 4 is best
<div n="lb"/>explained by the reduced position in which the Kuru-Krivis
<div n="lb"/>found themselves on their defeat by the Tṛtsus. Ludwig,<sup>4</sup> on
<div n="lb"/>the other hand, thinks that Kavaṣa was the priest of the five
<div n="lb"/>peoples. Geldner<sup>5</sup> holds that Kavaṣa was the Purohita of
<div n="lb"/>Kuruśravaṇa, by whose son, Upamaśravas, he was ill-treated,
<div n="lb"/>and that he composed Rigveda x. 33 to deprecate the anger of
<div n="lb"/>his royal master. Hopkins<sup>6</sup> thinks that he was a king.
<div n="P"/>In the Brāhmaṇas of the Rigveda<sup>7</sup> mention is made of
[Page1-144+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>Kavaṣa Ailūṣa, who was a Brāhmaṇa born of a female slave,
<div n="lb"/>and was reproached on this ground by the other Ṛṣis. He is
<div n="lb"/>possibly identical with the Kavaṣa of the Rigveda.
<F>1) vii. 18, 12.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 127.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 150.</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139.</F>
<F>5) {%Loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>6) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 15, 261, 263.</F>
<F>7) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 19; Kauṣī-
<div n="lb"/>taki Brāhmaṇa, xii. 1, 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 3, 459;
<div n="lb"/>Lanman, {%Sanskrit Reader,%} 386, 387;
<div n="lb"/>Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1910, 50.</F>
<LEND>

<L>589<pc>1-150<k1>kAru<k2>kAru
{@Kāru,@}¦ ‘poet,’ is a word almost confined to the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>There is evidence that the poet was regarded as a professional
<div n="lb"/>man, just as much as the physician ({@Bhiṣaj@}).<sup>2</sup> The poets, no
<div n="lb"/>doubt, mainly lived at the courts of princes amid their re-
<div n="lb"/>tainers,<sup>3</sup> though they would probably also sing the praises of rich
<div n="lb"/>merchants. There was probably no essential connexion between
<div n="lb"/>the priest and the poet. Though the priest was often a poet,
<div n="lb"/>yet poetry can hardly have been restricted to the priestly caste.
<div n="lb"/>Indeed, at the horse sacrifice (Aśvamedha) the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> expressly requires that one of the singers of pane-
<div n="lb"/>gyrics should be a Rājanya, while the other was a Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>both singing verses of their own composition. The Anukra-
<div n="lb"/>maṇī (Index) in several cases<sup>5</sup> attributes hymns of the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>to princes; and even though this may often be merely the
<div n="lb"/>same sort of procedure<sup>6</sup> as has made Śūdraka the author of
<div n="lb"/>the Mṛcchakaṭikā, or Harṣa of the Ratnāvalī, and has given
<div n="lb"/>us royal teachers of the Brahman doctrine,<sup>7</sup> still the Indian
<div n="lb"/>tradition evidently saw nothing odd in the idea of non-
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas as poets. Most of the non-sacred poetry has,
[Page1-151+ 37]
<div n="lb"/>however, disappeared, for the epic is a product, as it stands,
<div n="lb"/>of a later period. See also {@Ṛṣi.@}
<F>1) i. 148, 2; 165, 12; 177, 5; 178, 3;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 43, 1; iii. 33, 8; 39, 7; v. 33, 7;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 27; 68, 9; 72, 4, etc.: Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, i. 8, 7; Gopatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>i. 2, 21.</F>
<F>2) ix. 112. 3.</F>
<F>3) vii. 73. 1.</F>
<F>4) xiii. 1, 5, 1; 4, 3, 5.</F>
<F>5) {%E.g.,%} x. 92 is attributed to Śāryāta
<div n="lb"/>Mānava.</F>
<F>6) See Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 202.</F>
<F>7) Weber, {%Episches im vedischen Ritual,%}
<div n="lb"/>20, n. 4, sees in Av. xx. a recension
<div n="lb"/>of Kṣatriya character. He also finds
<div n="lb"/>Kṣatriyas in {@Viśvāmitra@} and {@Kakṣīvant,@}
<div n="lb"/>but hardly with reason. {%Cf.%} {@Varṇa.@}</F>
<LEND>

<L>596<pc>1-152<k1>kAla<k2>kAla
{@Kāla,@}¦ the generic expression for ‘time,’ first occurs in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where, however, it is used only once, in the late
<div n="lb"/>tenth book. It is known to the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> where Kāla has
<div n="lb"/>already developed the sense of time as fate. The word is
<div n="lb"/>frequent in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>3</sup> superseding the earlier use of {@Ṛtu.@}
<div n="lb"/>The more general division of time is into ‘past’ ({%bhūta%}),
<div n="lb"/>‘present’ ({%bhavat%}), and ‘future’ ({%bhaviṣyat%}).<sup>4</sup> For other divisions
<div n="lb"/>see {@Ahan, Māsa, Saṃvatsara.@}
<F>1) x. 42, 9.</F>
<F>2) xix. 53. 54.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 3, 3;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 4, 2, 4; iii. 8, 3, 36; vii. 2, 2, 21,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>4) {%E.g.,%} Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, vii. 20.</F>
<LEND>

<L>598<pc>1-152<k1>kAlakAYja<k2>kAlakAYja
{@Kāla-kāñja.@}¦ — In the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> mention is made of the
<div n="lb"/>Kālakāñjas as being in the sky. Both Roth<sup>2</sup> and Zimmer<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>hold that some constellation is meant. But as the defeat of
<div n="lb"/>the Kālakāñjas is one of Indra's exploits,<sup>4</sup> it is doubtful whether
<div n="lb"/>any stress can be laid on that interpretation of the passage in
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda. Whitney<sup>5</sup> suggests that the three stars of
<div n="lb"/>Orion are meant, Bloomfield<sup>6</sup> that the galaxy or the stars in
<div n="lb"/>general are intended.

<L>602<pc>1-153<k1>kASi<k2>kASi
{@Kāśi, Kāśya.@}¦ — The name Kāśi denotes (in the plural<sup>1</sup>) the
<div n="lb"/>people of Kāśi (Benares), and Kāśya, the king of Kāśi. The
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> tells of {@Dhṛtarāṣṭra,@} king of Kāśi, who
<div n="lb"/>was defeated by {@Śatānīka Sātrājita,@} with the result that the
<div n="lb"/>Kāśis, down to the time of the Brāhmaṇa, gave up the kindling
<div n="lb"/>of the sacred fire. Sātrājita was a {@Bharata.@} We hear also of
<div n="lb"/>{@Ajātaśatru@} as a king of Kāśi;<sup>3</sup> and no doubt {@Bhadrasena@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Ajātaśatrava,@} a contemporary of {@Uddālaka,@} was also a king of
<div n="lb"/>Kāśi.
<div n="P"/>The Kāśis and {@Videhas@} were closely connected, as was
<div n="lb"/>natural in view of their geographical position. The compound
<div n="lb"/>name Kāśi-Videha occurs in the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad;<sup>4</sup> in the
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>5</sup> {@Gārgī@} describes Ajātaśatru as either
<div n="lb"/>a Kāśi or a Videha king. The Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>6</sup>
[Page1-154+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>mentions one Purohita as acting for the kings of Kāśi, Kosala,
<div n="lb"/>and Videha; and the Baudhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>7</sup> mentions Kāśi
<div n="lb"/>and Videha in close proximity. Weber,<sup>8</sup> indeed, throws out
<div n="lb"/>the suggestion that the Kāśis and the Videhas together con-
<div n="lb"/>stitute the {@Uśīnaras,@} whose name is very rare in Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature.
<div n="P"/>As Kosala and Videha were in close connexion, Kāśi and
<div n="lb"/>Kosala are found combined in the compound name Kāśi-
<div n="lb"/>Kauśalyas of the Gopatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>Though Kāśi is a late word, it is quite possible that the town
<div n="lb"/>is older, as the river {@Varaṇāvatī@} referred to in the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda<sup>10</sup> may be connected with the later Vārāṇasī (Benares).
<div n="P"/>It is significant that while the Kāśis, Kosalas, and Videhas
<div n="lb"/>were united, any relations which the Kuru-Pañcala peoples
<div n="lb"/>may have had with them were hostile. It is a fair conclusion
<div n="lb"/>that between these two great groups of peoples there did exist
<div n="lb"/>some political conflict as well as probably a difference of culture
<div n="lb"/>in some degree. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>11</sup> in the story of the
<div n="lb"/>advance of Āryan civilization over Kosala and Videha, preserves
<div n="lb"/>a clear tradition of this time, and a piece of evidence that in
<div n="lb"/>the Kuru-Pañcāla country lay the real centre of the Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>culture (see also {@Kuru-Pañcāla@}). That the Kosala-Videhas
<div n="lb"/>were originally settlers of older date than the Kuru-Pañcālas
<div n="lb"/>is reasonably obvious from their geographical position, but the
<div n="lb"/>true Brāhmaṇa culture appears to have been brought to them
<div n="lb"/>from the Kuru-Pañcala country. It is very probable that the
<div n="lb"/>East was less Āryan than the West, and that it was less
<div n="lb"/>completely reduced under Brahmin spiritual supremacy, as the
<div n="lb"/>movement of Buddhism was Eastern, and the Buddhist texts<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>reveal a position in which the Kṣatriyas rank above Brāhmaṇas.
<div n="lb"/>With this agrees the fact that the later Vedic texts<sup>13</sup> display
[Page1-155+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>towards the people of Magadha a marked antipathy, which
<div n="lb"/>may be reasonably explained by that people's lack of orthodoxy,
<div n="lb"/>and which may perhaps be traced as far back as the Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā.<sup>14</sup> It is, of course, possible that the Kosala-Videhas
<div n="lb"/>and Kāśis actually were merely offshoots of the tribes later
<div n="lb"/>known as the Kuru-Pañcālas, and that they by reason of
<div n="lb"/>distance and less complete subjugation of the aborigines lost
<div n="lb"/>their Brahminical culture. This hypothesis, however, appears
<div n="lb"/>less likely, though it might be supported by a literal inter-
<div n="lb"/>pretation of the legend of the Aryan migration in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa.<sup>15</sup>
<F>1) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 5, 4,
<div n="lb"/>19. 21. The plural occurs also in
<div n="lb"/>the Paippalāda recension of the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda, v. 22, 14.</F>
<F>2) xiii. 5, 4, 19.</F>
<F>3) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 8, 2; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, iv. 1.</F>
<F>4) Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>5) iii. 8, 2.</F>
<F>6) xvi. 29, 5.</F>
<F>7) xxi. 13.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 212,
<div n="lb"/>213.</F>
<F>9) i. 2, 9.</F>
<F>10) iv. 7. 1. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Leben,%} 20; Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Atharvaveda,%} 376.</F>
<F>11) i. 4, 1, 10 {%et seq. Cf.%} Weber,
<div n="lb"/>{%Indische Studien,%} 1, 170 {%et seq.;%} Eggeling,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 12, xlii {%et seq.,%}
<div n="lb"/>104, n. 1.</F>
<F>12) See Fick, {%Die seciale Gliederung,%}
<div n="lb"/>chap. iv.</F>
<F>13) Kātyāyana Srauta Sūtra, xxii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>22; Lāṭyāyana Śrauta Sūtra, viii. 6,
<div n="lb"/>28. See Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10,
<div n="lb"/>99; Fick, {%op. cit.,%} 140, n. 1; and {%of.%}
<div n="lb"/>{@Magadha.@}</F>
<F>14) xxx. 5. 22. See {@Magadha.@}</F>
<F>15) {%Cf.%} Eggeling, {%loc. cit.,%} 104, n. 1.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Grierson, {%Journal of the Royal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Asiatic Society,%} 1908, 837, 1143; Keith,
<div n="lb"/>{%ibid.,%} 831, 1138; Oldenberg, {%Buddha,%}
<div n="lb"/>402 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>611<pc>1-156<k1>kitava<k2>kitava
{@Kitava,@}¦ ‘the gambler,’ is frequently referred to in the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> A father is represented as chastising his son
<div n="lb"/>for gambling.<sup>3</sup> The gambler seems at times to have fallen,
<div n="lb"/>along with his family, into servitude, presumably by selling
<div n="lb"/>himself to pay his debts.<sup>4</sup> Technical names<sup>5</sup> for different sorts
<div n="lb"/>of gamblers given in the Yajurveda Saṃhitās are Ādinava-darśa,
[Page1-157+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>Kalpin, Adhi-kalpin, and Sabhā-sthāṇu. None of these can be
<div n="lb"/>safely<sup>6</sup> explained, though the last has usually<sup>7</sup> been taken as a
<div n="lb"/>satirical name derived from the gambler's devotion to the dicing
<div n="lb"/>place ({@Sabhā@}), ‘pillar of the dicing hall.’ The first literally
<div n="lb"/>means ‘seeing ill-luck,’<sup>8</sup> and may refer to the quickness of the
<div n="lb"/>dicer to note an error on the part of his antagonist, or to his
<div n="lb"/>eagerness to see the defeat of his rival.

<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ii. 19, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. ii. 29, 5. {%Cf.%} {@Pitṛ.@}</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 34. {%Cf.%} perhaps the {%bhakta-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%dāsa,%} ‘slave for hire,’ of the Mānava
<div n="lb"/>Dharma Sāstra, viii. 415; Fick, {%Die%}

<L>614<pc>1-157<k1>kirAta<k2>kirAta<h>1
1. {@Kirāta@}¦ is a name applied to a people living in the caves
<div n="lb"/>of the mountains, as appears clearly from the dedication of the
<div n="lb"/>Kirāta to the caves ({%guhā%}) in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>from the reference in the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> to a Kirāta girl ({%kairā-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%tikā%}), who digs a remedy on the ridges of the mountains.
[Page1-158+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>Later<sup>3</sup> the people called Kirātas were located in Eastern Nepal,
<div n="lb"/>but the name seems to have been applied to any hill folk, no
<div n="lb"/>doubt aborigines, though the Mānava Dharma Śāstra<sup>4</sup> regards
<div n="lb"/>them as degraded Kṣatriyas.
<F>1) xxx. 16; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 12, 1.</F>
<F>2) x. 4, 14.</F>
<F>3) Lassen, {%Indische Alterthumskunde,%} 1^2,
<div n="lb"/>530, 534.</F>
<F>4) x. 44.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 32;
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3,
<div n="lb"/>207; V. Smith, {%Journal of the Royal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Asiatic Socicty,%} 1909, 258, n. 1; Lévi,
<div n="lb"/>{%Le Népal,%} 2, 77.</F>
<LEND>

<L>615<pc>1-158<k1>kirAta<k2>kirAta<h>2
2. {@Kirāta.@}¦ — In the story of {@Asamāti@} there appear, as the two
<div n="lb"/>priests who are opposed to the {@Gaupāyanas,@} Kirāta and {@Akuli@}
<div n="lb"/>according to the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> or Kilāta and Ākuli
<div n="lb"/>according to the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> No doubt the name is
<div n="lb"/>chosen, not as that of a historic person, but as a suitable
<div n="lb"/>designation of a hostile priest; for it is probably identical with
<div n="lb"/>the name of the mountaineers described in the preceding article.
<F>1) xiii. 12, 5 (where the text reads
<div n="lb"/>{%kirāta-kulyau%}). Böhtlingk, Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.,%} takes the word, with Sāyaṇa, as
<div n="lb"/>an adjective, {%kirāta-kula,%} ‘of the family
<div n="lb"/>of Kirāta.’ The reading in the Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>devatā (vii. 86) is {%kirātākulī.%}</F>
<F>2) i. 1, 4, 14 (where the text reads
<div n="lb"/>{%kilātākulī%}). {%Cf.%} also Sāṭyāyanaka Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa {%apud%} Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 57, 1;

<L>618<pc>1-159<k1>kIkawa<k2>kIkawa
{@Kīkaṭa.@}¦ — The name of this people occurs only in one passage
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda, where they appear as hostile to the singer and
<div n="lb"/>as under the leadership of {@Pramaganda.@} Yāska<sup>2</sup> declares that
<div n="lb"/>Kīkaṭa was the name of a non-Āryan country, and later<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Kīkaṭa is given as a synonym of Magadha. Hence Zimmer<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>concludes that the Kīkaṭas were a non-Āryan people living in
<div n="lb"/>the country later known as Magadha. Weber<sup>5</sup> holds that this
<div n="lb"/>people were located in Magadha, but were Āryan, though at
<div n="lb"/>variance with other Āryan tribes, perhaps because of heretical
<div n="lb"/>tendencies, for Magadha was later a seat of Buddhism. But
<div n="lb"/>the identification is uncertain, and is doubted by Oldenberg<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and Hillebrandt.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="P"/>^1 iii. 53, 14.
<F>2) Nirukta, vi. 32.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 31, 118. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Geldner, {%Rigveda, Kommentar,%} 58.</F>
<F>5) {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 186; {%Indian%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Literature,%} 79, n. *.</F>
<F>6) {%Buddha,%} 402, 403; {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1,
<div n="lb"/>253.</F>

<L>631<pc>1-161<k1>kutsa<k2>kutsa
{@Kutsa@}¦ is the name of a hero frequently mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, which, however, gives practically no information
<div n="lb"/>about him, for he was no doubt already a figure of the mythic
<div n="lb"/>past. He is several times<sup>1</sup> called Ārjuneya, ‘descendant of
<div n="lb"/>Arjuna,’ and is usually<sup>2</sup> associated with Indra in the exploit of
<div n="lb"/>defeating the demon Śuṣṇa and winning the sun. He is said<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to have defeated {@Smadibha, Tugra,@} and the {@Vetasus,@} but, on the
<div n="lb"/>other hand, he is several times<sup>4</sup> mentioned with {@Atithigva@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Āyu@} as being vanquished by Indra, his defeat in one passage<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>being attributed to {@Tūrvayāṇa.@} Elsewhere<sup>6</sup> he appears with
<div n="lb"/>Atithigva as a friend of Indra's. In the later literature he is
<div n="lb"/>seldom<sup>7</sup> mentioned except in connexion with the myth of his
<div n="lb"/>binding Indra, which is found in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>8</sup> and which is
<div n="lb"/>based on an obscure verse in the Rigveda.<sup>9</sup>
[Page1-162+ 41]
<div n="P"/>The Kutsas, or descendants of Kutsa, are mentioned in one
<div n="lb"/>hymn of the Rigveda.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) Rv. iv. 26, 1; vii. 19, 2; viii. 1,
<div n="lb"/>11.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 63, 3; 121, 19; 174, 5;
<div n="lb"/>175, 4; iv. 30, 4; v. 29, 4; vi. 20, 5;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 19, 2; x. 99, 9.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 49, 4.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 53, 10; ii. 14, 7; viii. 53, 2.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} iv. 26, 1.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 53, 10.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 51, 6; vi. 26, 3.</F>
<F>7) {%E.g.,%} Av. iv. 29, 5; Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xiv. 11, 26.</F>
<F>8) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, ix. 2, 22;
<div n="lb"/>Śāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 38,
<div n="lb"/>5; Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 228; Oertel.
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>18, 31.</F>
<F>9) x. 38, 5.</F>

<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 113, 148; Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift%}
<div n="lb"/>{%der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%schaft,%} 42, 210, 211; Hillebrandt,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Mythologie,%} 3, 284 {%et seq.,%} who
<div n="lb"/>suggests that perhaps two Kutsas — one
<div n="lb"/>a friend of Indra, and the other a foe
<div n="lb"/> — may be distinguished; Geldner,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 171; Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Arts and Sciences,%} 15, 57, n. 1.</F>

<F>5) Gopatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 21
<div n="lb"/>(= vaitāna Sūtra, xi. 22), cited by
<div n="lb"/>Geldner, is quite vague.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 265;
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Atharanaveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>539; Whitney, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 348; Caland, {%Über das%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vituelle Sūtra des Baudhāyana,%} 59.</F>

<L>644<pc>1-164<k1>kurIrin<k2>kurIrin
{@Kurīrin@}¦ (‘having a {@Kurīra@}’) is a word occurring in an
<div n="lb"/>ambiguous passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> in which it may be
<div n="lb"/>taken either as a noun meaning a ‘crested animal,’ perhaps as
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>2</sup> suggests the ‘peacock,’ or as an epithet of the word
<div n="lb"/>{@Aja,@} ‘goat,’ in which case it might mean ‘horned.’ But even
<div n="lb"/>in the latter alternative a metaphorical application of the word
<div n="lb"/>seems sufficient, just as in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> {@Opaśa@}
<div n="lb"/>is used of the horns of cattle, and thus renders unnecessary
<div n="lb"/>the adoption of Geldner's<sup>4</sup> view that the original meaning of
<div n="lb"/>{@Kurīra@} is ‘horn.’
<F>1) v. 31, 2.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 91.</F>
<F>3) xiii. 4, 3.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 130.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 457, 539; Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 18, 285; Whitney, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Atharvaveda, 279.</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-165+ 63]

<L>645<pc>1-165<k1>kuru<k2>kuru
{@Kuru.@}¦ — The Kurus appear as by far the most important
<div n="lb"/>people in the Brāhmaṇa literature. There is clear evidence
<div n="lb"/>that it was in the country of the Kurus, or the allied Kuru-
<div n="lb"/>Pañcālas, that the great Brāhmaṇas were composed.<sup>1</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Kurus are comparatively seldom mentioned alone, their name
<div n="lb"/>being usually coupled with that of the Pañcālas on account of
<div n="lb"/>the intimate connexion of the two peoples. The Kuru-Pañcālas
<div n="lb"/>are often expressly referred to as a united nation.<sup>2</sup> In the land
<div n="lb"/>of the Kuru-Pañcālas speech is said to have its particular
<div n="lb"/>home;<sup>3</sup> the mode of sacrifice among the Kuru-Pañcālas is
<div n="lb"/>proclaimed to be the best;<sup>4</sup> the Kuru-Pañcāla kings perform
<div n="lb"/>the Rājasūya or royal sacrifice;<sup>5</sup> their princes march forth on
<div n="lb"/>raids in the dewy season, and return in the hot season.<sup>6</sup> Later
<div n="lb"/>on the Kuru-Pañcāla Brahmins are famous in the Upaniṣads.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Weber<sup>8</sup> and Grierson<sup>9</sup> have sought to find traces in Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature of a breach between the two tribes, the latter scholar
<div n="lb"/>seeing therein a confirmation of the theory that the Kurus
<div n="lb"/>belonged to the later stream of immigrants into India, who
<div n="lb"/>were specially Brahminical, as opposed to the Pañcālas, who
<div n="lb"/>were anti-Brahminical. In support of this view, Weber refers
<div n="lb"/>to the story in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>10</sup> of a dispute between
<div n="lb"/>{@Vaka Dālbhya@} and {@Dhṛtarāṣṭra Vaicitravīrya,@} the former
<div n="lb"/>being held to be by origin a Pañcāla, while the latter is held
[Page1-166+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>to be a Kuru. But there is no trace of a quarrel between
<div n="lb"/>Kurus and Pañcālas in the passage in question, which merely
<div n="lb"/>preserves the record of a dispute on a ritual matter between a
<div n="lb"/>priest and a prince: the same passage refers to the Naimiṣīya
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice among the Kuru-Pañcālas, and emphasizes the close
<div n="lb"/>connexion of the two peoples.<sup>11</sup> Secondly, Weber conjectures
<div n="lb"/>in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>12</sup> that {@Subhadrikā@} of {@Kāmpila@} was
<div n="lb"/>the chief queen of the king of a tribe living in the neighbour-
<div n="lb"/>hood of the clan, for whose king the horse sacrifice described
<div n="lb"/>in the Saṃhitā was performed. But the interpretation of this
<div n="lb"/>passage by Weber is open to grave doubt;<sup>13</sup> and in the Kāṇva
<div n="lb"/>recension of the Saṃhitā<sup>14</sup> a passage used at the Rājasūya
<div n="lb"/>shows that the Kuru-Pañcālas had actually one king. More-
<div n="lb"/>over, there is the evidence of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>15</sup> that
<div n="lb"/>the old name of the Pañcālas was {@Krivi.@} This word looks very
<div n="lb"/>like a variant of Kuru, and Zimmer<sup>16</sup> plausibly conjectures that
<div n="lb"/>the Kurus and Krivis formed the {@Vaikarṇa@}<sup>17</sup> of the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>especially as both peoples are found about the Sindhu and the
<div n="lb"/>Asiknī.<sup>18</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Kurus alone are chiefly mentioned in connexion with
<div n="lb"/>the locality which they occupied, {@Kurukṣetra,@} We are told,
<div n="lb"/>however, of a domestic priest ({@Purohita@}) in the service of both
<div n="lb"/>the Kurus and the {@Sṛñjayas,@}<sup>19</sup> who must therefore at one time
<div n="lb"/>have been closely connected.<sup>20</sup> In the Chāndogya Upaniṣad
<div n="lb"/>reference is made to the Kurus being saved by a mare ({%aśvā%}),<sup>21</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and to some disaster which befel them owing to a hailstorm.<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>In the Sūtras, again, a ceremony (Vājapeya) of the Kurus is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned.<sup>23</sup> There also a curse, which was pronounced on them
<div n="lb"/>and led to their being driven from Kurukṣetra, is alluded to.<sup>24</sup>
[Page1-167+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>This possibly adumbrates the misfortunes of the Kauravas in
<div n="lb"/>the epic tradition.
<div n="P"/>In the Rigveda the Kurus do not appear under that name as
<div n="lb"/>a people. But mention is made of a prince, {@Kuruśravaṇa@}
<div n="lb"/>(‘Glory of the Kurus’),<sup>25</sup> and of a {@Pākasthāman Kaurayāṇa.@}<sup>26</sup>
<div n="lb"/>In the Atharvaveda<sup>27</sup> there occurs as a king of the Kurus
<div n="lb"/>{@Parikṣit,@} whose son, {@Janamejaya,@} is mentioned in the Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa<sup>28</sup> as one of the great performers of the horse
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice.
<div n="P"/>It is a probable conjecture of Oldenberg's<sup>29</sup> that the Kuru
<div n="lb"/>people, as known later, included some of the tribes referred to
<div n="lb"/>by other names in the Rigveda. Kuruśravaṇa, shown by his
<div n="lb"/>name to be connected with the Kurus, is in the Rigveda called
<div n="lb"/>Trāsadasyava, ‘descendant of {@Trasadasyu,@}’ who is well known
<div n="lb"/>as a king of the {@Pūrus.@} Moreover, it is likely that the Tṛtsu-
<div n="lb"/>{@Bharatas,@} who appear in the Rigveda as enemies of the Pūtus,
<div n="lb"/>later coalesced with them to form the Kuru people.<sup>30</sup> Since the
<div n="lb"/>Bharatas appear so prominently in the Brāhmaṇa texts as a
<div n="lb"/>great people of the past, while the later literature ignores them
<div n="lb"/>in its list of nations, it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that
<div n="lb"/>they became merged in some other tribe. Moreover, there is
<div n="lb"/>evidence that the Bharatas occupied the territory in which the
<div n="lb"/>Kurus were later found. Two of them are spoken of in a hymn
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda<sup>31</sup> as having kindled fire on the {@Dṛṣadvatī,@} the
<div n="lb"/>{@Āpayā,@} and the {@Sarasvatī@} — that is to say, in the sacred places
<div n="lb"/>of the later Kurukṣetra. Similarly, the goddess Bhāratī
<div n="lb"/>(‘belonging to the Bharatas’) is constantly mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Āprī (‘propitiatory’) hymns together with Sarasvatī.<sup>32</sup> Again,
<div n="lb"/>according to the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, one Bharata king was
<div n="lb"/>victorious over the Kāśis,<sup>33</sup> and another made offerings to
<div n="lb"/>Gaṅgā and Yamunā,<sup>34</sup> while raids of the Bharatas against the
<div n="lb"/>{@Satvants@} are mentioned in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>35</sup> Nor is it
[Page1-168+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>without importance that the Bharatas appear as a variant for
<div n="lb"/>the Kuru Pañcālas in a passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>36</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and that in the list of the great performers of the horse sacrifice
<div n="lb"/>the names of one Kuru and two Bharata princes are given
<div n="lb"/>without any mention of the people over which they ruled,
<div n="lb"/>while in other cases that information is specifically given.<sup>37</sup>
<div n="P"/>The territory of the Kuru-Pañcālas is declared in the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa to be the middle country ({@Madhyadeśa@}).<sup>38</sup> A group
<div n="lb"/>of the Kuru people still remained further north — the {@Uttara@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Kurus@} beyond the Himālaya. It appears from a passage of
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa that the speech of the Northerners — 
<div n="lb"/>that is, presumably, the Northern Kurus — and of the Kuru-
<div n="lb"/>Pañcālas was similar, and regarded as specially pure.<sup>39</sup> There
<div n="lb"/>seems little doubt that the Brahminical culture was developed
<div n="lb"/>in the country of the Kuru-Pañcālas, and that it spread thence
<div n="lb"/>east, south, and west. Traces of this are seen in the Vrātya
<div n="lb"/>Stomas (sacrifices for the admission of non-Brahminical
<div n="lb"/>Āryans) of the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>40</sup> and in the fact that in
<div n="lb"/>the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka it is unusual for a Brahmin to dwell
<div n="lb"/>in the territory of {@Magadha.@}<sup>41</sup> The repeated mention of Kuru-
<div n="lb"/>Pañcāla Brahmins is another indication of their missionary
<div n="lb"/>activity.<sup>42</sup>
<div n="P"/>The geographical position of the Kuru-Pañcālas renders it
<div n="lb"/>probable that they were later immigrants into India than the
<div n="lb"/>{@Kosala-Videha@} or the {@Kāśis,@}<sup>43</sup> who must have been pushed
[Page1-169+ 71]
<div n="lb"/>into their more eastward territories by a new wave of Āryan
<div n="lb"/>settlers from the west. But there is no evidence in Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature to show in what relation of time the immigration of
<div n="lb"/>the latter peoples stood to that of their neighbours on the west.
<div n="lb"/>It has, however, been conjectured,<sup>44</sup> mainly on the ground of
<div n="lb"/>later linguistic phenomena, which have no cogency for the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic period, that the Kurus were later immigrants, who,
<div n="lb"/>coming by a new route, thrust themselves between the original
<div n="lb"/>Āryan tribes which were already in occupation of the country
<div n="lb"/>from east to west. {%Cf.%} also {@Kṛtvan.@} For other Kuru princes
<div n="lb"/>see {@Kauravya.@}

<L>646<pc>1-169<k1>kurukzetra<k2>kurukzetra
{@Kuru-kṣetra@}¦ (‘land of the Kurus’) is always regarded in the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa texts<sup>1</sup> as a particularly sacred country. Within its
<div n="lb"/>boundaries flowed the rivers {@Dṛṣadvatī@} and {@Sarasvatī,@} as well
<div n="lb"/>as the {@Āpayā.@}<sup>2</sup> Here, too, was situated {@Śaryaṇāvant,@}<sup>3</sup> which
[Page1-170+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>appears to have been a lake, like that known to the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa by the name of {@Anyataḥ-plakṣā.@}<sup>4</sup> According to
<div n="lb"/>Pischel, there was also in Kurukṣetra a stream called {@Pastyā,@}<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>which he sees in certain passages of the Rigveda. The boun-
<div n="lb"/>daries of Kurukṣetra are given in a passage of the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka<sup>6</sup> as being Khāṇḍava on the south, the Tūrghna on
<div n="lb"/>the north, and the Parīṇah on the west. Roughly speaking, it
<div n="lb"/>corresponded to the modern Sirhind.
<F>1) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxv. 10;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iv. 1, 5, 13;
<div n="lb"/>xi. 5, 1, 4; xiv. 1, 1, 2; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vii. 30; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, ii. 1, 4; iv. 5, 9; Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iii. 126 ({%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%American Oriental Society,%} 11, cxlvi);
<div n="lb"/>Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xv. 16, 11,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Rv. iii. 23; Pischel, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 2, 218.</F>
<F>3) See Pischel, {%loc. cit.,%} and {%cf.%} {@Ārjī-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@kīyā.@}</F>
<F>4) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5, 1, 4.</F>

<L>647<pc>1-170<k1>kuruNga<k2>kuruNga

<L>651<pc>1-171<k1>kula<k2>kula
{@Kula, Kula-pā.@}¦ — As an uncompounded word, Kula does not
<div n="lb"/>occur before the period of the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>1</sup> It denotes the
<div n="lb"/>‘home’ or ‘house of the family,’ and by metonymy the family
<div n="lb"/>itself, as connected with the home. The Kula-pā (lit. ‘house
<div n="lb"/>protector’), or chief of the family, is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as inferior to and attendant on the {@Vrājapati@} in war, the latter
<div n="lb"/>being perhaps the leader of the village contingent of the clan.
<div n="lb"/>In the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> a girl is ironically called Kulapā, because
<div n="lb"/>she is left without a husband in the world, and has only Yama
<div n="lb"/>(the god of death) for a spouse.
<div n="P"/>The use of the term Kula points clearly to a system of
<div n="lb"/>individual families, each no doubt consisting of several members
<div n="lb"/>under the headship of the father or eldest brother, whose Kula
<div n="lb"/>the dwelling is. As distinct from {@Gotra,@} Kula seems to mean
<div n="lb"/>the family in the narrower sense of the members who still
<div n="lb"/>live in one house, the undivided family. {%Cf.%} {@Gṛha, Grāma,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Jana, Viś.@}
<F>1) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 2, 22;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 1, 4, 4; 4, 1, 14; xi. 5, 3, 11; 8, 1, 3;
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 4, 2, 17; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>i. 5, 32; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iii., 13,
<div n="lb"/>6, etc.</F>
<F>2) x. 179, 2.</F>
<F>3) i. 14, 3. {%Cf.%} Whitney, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Atharvaveda, 15; Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%Hymns of the Athcrvaveda,%} 252, correcting
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 314.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 162.</F>
<LEND>

<L>672<pc>1-175<k1>kuzWa<k2>kuzWa<h>1
1. {@Kuṣṭha@}¦ is the name of a plant ({%Costus speciosus%} or {%arabicus%})<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>which is prominent in the Atharvaveda.<sup>2</sup> It grew especially on
<div n="lb"/>the mountains, along with the Soma, on the high peaks of the
<div n="lb"/>Himālaya ({%Himavant%}) where the eagles nest, and was thence
<div n="lb"/>brought east to men.<sup>3</sup> Like Soma, it is said to have grown in
<div n="lb"/>the third heaven under the famous {@Aśvattha@} tree, where the
<div n="lb"/>gods were wont to assemble, and thence it was brought in a
<div n="lb"/>golden ship.<sup>4</sup> As a remedy, it held the highest place among
<div n="lb"/>herbs, being called by the auspicious names Nagha-māra and
<div n="lb"/>Naghā-riṣa, and styled the offspring of Jīvala and Jīvalā, the
<div n="lb"/>‘lively’ ones.<sup>5</sup> It cured headache ({%śīrṣāmaya%}), diseases of the
<div n="lb"/>eyes, bodily affliction,<sup>6</sup> but especially fever — hence called ‘fever-
<div n="lb"/>destroyer’ ({%takma-nāśana%}) — and consumption ({@Yakṣma@}). From
<div n="lb"/>its general properties it was also named ‘all-healing’ ({%viśva-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%bheṣaja%}).<sup>7</sup> Its aromatic qualities were apparently known, as it
<div n="lb"/>is classed with ‘salve’ ({@Āñjana@}) and ‘nard’ ({@Nalada@}).<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) Or {%Saussurea auriculata,%} Hillebreandt.
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 65.</F>
<F>2) v. 4; vi. 102; xix. 139.</F>
<F>3) v. 4, 1. 2. 8; xix. 39, 1.</F>
<F>4) v. 4, 3-6; vi. 75, 1. 2; xix. 39, 6-8.</F>
<F>5) v. 4, 1; xix. 39, 4.</F>
<F>6) v. 4, 10.</F>
<F>7) xix. 39, 9.</F>
<F>8) vi. 102, 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Grohmann, {%Indische, Studien,%} 9,
<div n="lb"/>420 {%et seq.;%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
<div n="lb"/>63, 64; Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 415, 680; Whitney, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Atharvaveda, 227, 228.</F>
<LEND>

<L>674<pc>1-176<k1>kusIdin<k2>kusIdin
{@Kusīdin@}¦ is a designation of the ‘usurer’ found in the Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> and the Nirukta,<sup>2</sup> and often in the Sūtras.
<div n="lb"/>Jolly,<sup>3</sup> referring doubtless to the expression {%kusīda apratītta,%}<sup>4</sup> ‘a
<div n="lb"/>loan not yet repaid,’ occurring in connexion with {%an-ṛṇa,%} ‘free
<div n="lb"/>from debt,’ appears to be right in taking Kusīda to have the
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘loan’ in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā. The rate of interest
<div n="lb"/>on loans is not specified before the Sūtra period.<sup>5</sup> {%Cf.%} {@Ṛṇa.@}
<F>1) xiii. 4, 3, 11.</F>

<L>690<pc>1-179<k1>kftvan<k2>kftvan
{@Kṛtvan.@}¦ — In one passage of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> the word Kṛtvan in
<div n="lb"/>the plural is mentioned with the {@Ārjīkas@} and the five peoples.
<div n="lb"/>Pischel<sup>2</sup> thinks that it means a people, and Sāyaṇa expressly
<div n="lb"/>says that the Kṛtvans designate a country.<sup>3</sup> The name in that
<div n="lb"/>case would point to some connexion with the {@Kurus@} or {@Krivis.@}
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt,<sup>4</sup> however, thinks that the word is an adjective
<div n="lb"/>which qualifies Ārjīkas and designates this people as magicians,
<div n="lb"/>being applied to them by an opponent. In favour of this view,
<div n="lb"/>he quotes Hiouen Thsang's statement<sup>5</sup> that the neighbouring
<div n="lb"/>kings held the base Kaśmīrians in such scorn as to refuse all
<div n="lb"/>alliance with them, and to give them the name of Ki-li-to, or
<div n="lb"/>Kṛtyas. He suggests that the Ārjīkas settled in Kasmīr in
<div n="lb"/>ancient times already had the same evil reputation as their
<div n="lb"/>successors in later days.
<F>1) ix. 65, 23.</F>
<F>2) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 209.</F>
<F>3) {%Kṛtvāna iti deśābhidhānam.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 136, 137</F>
<F>5) Cunningham, {%Aneient Gevgraphy of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%India,%} 93.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Roth, St. Petersburg Dic-
<div n="lb"/>tionary, {%s.v.%}</F>

<L>692<pc>1-179<k1>kfmi<k2>kfmi
{@Kṛmi,@}¦ ‘worm.’ In the later Saṃhitās,<sup>1</sup> and especially in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> worms play a considerable part. They are
[Page1-180+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>regarded as poisonous, and are spoken of as found in the
<div n="lb"/>mountains, in forests, in waters, in plants, and in the human
<div n="lb"/>body. In accordance with widespread primitive ideas, they
<div n="lb"/>are considered to be the causes of disease in men and animals.
<div n="lb"/>The Atharvaveda contains three hymns<sup>2</sup> as charms directed
<div n="lb"/>against them. The first of these hymns is of a general character,
<div n="lb"/>the second is meant to destroy worms in cattle, and the third is
<div n="lb"/>intended to cure children of worms. When found in men,
<div n="lb"/>worms are said to have their place in the head and ribs,<sup>3</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>to creep into the eyes, nose, and teeth.<sup>4</sup> They are described as
<div n="lb"/>dark brown, but white in the fore part of the body, with black
<div n="lb"/>ears, and as having three heads.<sup>5</sup> They are given many specific
<div n="lb"/>names: {@Alāṇḍu, Ejatka, Kaṣkaṣa, Kīṭa, Kurūru, Nīlaṅgu,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Yevāṣa, Vaghā, Vṛkṣasarpī, Śaluna, Śavarta, Śipavitnuka,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Stega.@}
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 11; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30; Mantra Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ii. 7; Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, iv. 36;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 4, 1, 2; and
<div n="lb"/>{%of.%} Rv. i. 191.</F>
<F>2) ii. 31. 32; v. 23.</F>
<F>2) ii. 31, 32; v. 23.</F>
<F>3) Av. ii. 31, 4.</F>
<F>4) Av. v. 23, 3.</F>
<F>5) Av. v. 23, 4 {%et seq.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 98,
<div n="lb"/>393; Kuhn, {%Zeitschrift für vergleichende%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sprachforschung,%} 13, 49 {%et seq.;%} 113
