<L>697<pc>1-181<k1>kfzi<k2>kfzi
{@Kṛṣi,@}¦ ‘ploughing.’ The cultivation of the soil was no doubt
<div n="lb"/>known to the Indians before they separated from the Iranians,
<div n="lb"/>as is indicated by the identity of the expressions {%yavaṃ kṛṣ%} and
<div n="lb"/>{%sasya%} in the Rigveda with {%yao karesh%} and {%hahya%} in the Avesta,
<div n="lb"/>referring to the ploughing in of the seed and to the grain
<div n="lb"/>which resulted.<sup>1</sup> But it is not without significance that the
<div n="lb"/>expressions for ploughing occur mainly in the first<sup>2</sup> and tenth<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>books of the Rigveda, and only rarely in the so-called ‘family’
<div n="lb"/>books (ii.-vii.).<sup>4</sup> In the Atharvaveda {@Pṛthī Vainya@} is credited
<div n="lb"/>with the origination of ploughing,<sup>5</sup> and even in the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>the Aśvins are spoken of as concerned with the sowing of grain
<div n="lb"/>by means of the plough.<sup>6</sup> In the later Saṃhitās and the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas ploughing is repeatedly referred to.<sup>7</sup>
[Page1-182+ 51]
<div n="P"/>Even in the Rigveda<sup>8</sup> there is clear proof of the importance
<div n="lb"/>attached to agriculture. In the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>{@Vrātyas,@} Hindus without the pale of Brahminism, are de-
<div n="lb"/>scribed as not cultivating the soil.
<div n="P"/>The plough land was called {@Urvarā@} or {@Kṣetra;@} manure
<div n="lb"/>({@Śakan, Karīṣa@}) was used, and irrigation was practised ({@Khani-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@tra@}). The plough ({@Lāṅgala, Sīra@}) was drawn by oxen, teams of
<div n="lb"/>six, eight, or even twelve being employed.<sup>10</sup> The operations of
<div n="lb"/>agriculture are neatly summed up in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as ‘ploughing, sowing, reaping, and threshing’ ({%kṛṣantaḥ,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vapantaḥ, lunantaḥ, mṛṇantaḥ%}). The ripe grain was cut with
<div n="lb"/>a sickle ({@Dātra, Sṛṇi@}), bound into bundles<sup>12</sup> ({@Parṣa@}), and beaten
<div n="lb"/>out on the floor of the granary ({@Khala@}).<sup>13</sup> The grain was then
<div n="lb"/>separated from the straw and refuse either by a sieve ({@Titau@})
<div n="lb"/>or a winnowing fan ({@Śūrpa@}).<sup>14</sup> The winnower was called
<div n="lb"/>{@Dhānyākṛt,@}<sup>15</sup> and the grain was measured in a vessel called
<div n="lb"/>{@Urdara.@}<sup>16</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Rigveda leaves us in doubt as to the kind of grain
<div n="lb"/>grown, for {@Yava@} is a word of doubtful signification, and {@Dhānā@}
<div n="lb"/>is also vague. In the later Saṃhitās<sup>17</sup> things are different.
<div n="lb"/>Rice ({@Vrīhi@}) appears, Yava means barley, with a species
<div n="lb"/>styled {@Upavāka.@} Beans ({@Mudga, Māṣa@}), sesamum ({@Tila@}), and
<div n="lb"/>other grains ({@Aṇu, Khalva, Godhūma, Nīvāra, Priyaṅgu,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Masūra, Śyāmāka@}) are mentioned, while cucumbers ({@Urvārū,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Uryārūka@}) were known. It is uncertain whether fruit trees
<div n="lb"/>({@Vṛkṣa@}) were cultivated, or merely grew wild;<sup>18</sup> but frequent
<div n="lb"/>mention is made of the jujube ({@Karkandhu, Kuvala, Badara.@}).
<div n="P"/>The seasons for agriculture are briefly summed up in a
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Taittirīya Saṃhitā:<sup>19</sup> barley ripened in summer,
<div n="lb"/>being no doubt sown, as in modern India, in winter; rice
[Page1-183+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>ripened in autumn, being sown in the beginning of the rains;
<div n="lb"/>beans and sesamum, planted at the time of the summer rains,
<div n="lb"/>ripened in the winter and the cool season. There were two
<div n="lb"/>harvests ({@Sasya@}) a year according to the Taittirīya Saṃhitā;<sup>20</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the winter crop was ripe by the month of Caitra (March-April)
<div n="lb"/>according to the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa.<sup>21</sup>
<div n="P"/>The farmer had plenty of trouble of his own: moles destroyed
<div n="lb"/>the seed, birds and various kinds of reptiles ({@Upakvasa, Jabhya,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Tarda, Pataṅga@}) injured the young shoots, excessive rain or
<div n="lb"/>drought might damage the crops. The Atharvaveda contains
<div n="lb"/>spells to prevent these evils.<sup>22</sup>
<F>1) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 235;
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 17, 85.</F>
<F>2) Forms of the root {%kṛṣ,%} ‘to plough,’
<div n="lb"/>occur in Rv. i. 23, 15; 176, 2.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 34, 13; 117, 7. In x. 146, 6,
<div n="lb"/>{%akṛṣīvala,%} ‘not agricultural,’ occurs.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} x. 101, 4.</F>
<F>4) {%Kṛṣ%} is also found in viii. 20, 19; 22,
<div n="lb"/>6; in the family books only in iv. 57,
<div n="lb"/>4, and as {%vi-kṛṣ%} in iv. 57, 8.</F>
<F>5) viii. 10, 24.</F>

<L>698<pc>1-183<k1>kfzwi<k2>kfzwi
{@Kṛṣṭi@}¦ denotes ‘people’ in general from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards.
<div n="lb"/>Its common and regular use in this sense appears to show that
<div n="lb"/>the Āryans, when they invaded India, were already agricul-
<div n="lb"/>turists, though the employment of the words referring to
<div n="lb"/>ploughing mentioned under {@Kṛṣi@} indicates that not all of the
<div n="lb"/>people devoted themselves equally to that occupation. Indra
<div n="lb"/>and Agni are {%par excellence%} the lords of men (Kṛṣṭi).<sup>2</sup> Some-
<div n="lb"/>times the word is further defined by the addition of an adjective
<div n="lb"/>meaning ‘belonging to mankind,’ ‘of men’ ({%mānuṣīḥ,%}<sup>3</sup> {%mānavīḥ%}).<sup>4</sup>

<div n="lb"/>({%pañca kṛṣṭayaḥ%}). The exact sense of this expression is doubtful.

<L>701<pc>1-184<k1>kfzRadevakIputra<k2>kfzRadevakIputra<h>3
3. {@Kṛṣṇa Devakī-putra@}¦ is mentioned in the Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad<sup>1</sup> as a pupil of the mythical {@Ghora Āṅgirasa.@}
<div n="lb"/>Tradition,<sup>2</sup> and several modern writers like Grierson, Garbe,
<div n="lb"/>and von Schroeder, recognize in him the hero Kṛṣṇa, who later
<div n="lb"/>is deified. In their view he is a Kṣatriya teacher of morals, as
<div n="lb"/>opposed to Brahminism.<sup>3</sup> This is extremely doubtful. It
<div n="lb"/>appears better either to regard the coincidence of name as
<div n="lb"/>accidental, or to suppose that the reference is a piece of
<div n="lb"/>Euhemerism. To identify this Kṛṣṇa with the preceding,
<div n="lb"/>as does the St. Petersburg Dictionary, seems to be quite
<div n="lb"/>groundless.
<F>1) iii. 17, 6.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indian Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>169.</F>
<F>3) Von Schroeder, {%Vienna Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal,%} 19, 414, 415; Grierson, {%Encyclo-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%padia of Religions,%} article ‘Bhakti’;
<div n="lb"/>Garbe, {%Bhagavadgītā.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%op. cit.,%} 71; 148; Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1905,
<div n="lb"/>386.</F>

<L>716<pc>1-187<k1>keSindArBya<k2>keSindArBya<h>2
2. {@Keśin Dārbhya@}¦<sup>1</sup> or {@Dālbhya@}<sup>2</sup> (‘descendant of Darbha’) is a
<div n="lb"/>somewhat enigmatic figure. According to the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>3</sup> and the Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmana<sup>4</sup> he was a king,
<div n="lb"/>sister's son of {@Uccaiḥśravas,@} according to the latter authority.
<div n="lb"/>His people were the {@Pañcālas,@} of whom the Keśins must there-
<div n="lb"/>fore have been a branch, and who are said to have been threefold
<div n="lb"/>({%tryanīka%}).<sup>5</sup> A story is told of his having a ritual dispute with
<div n="lb"/>{@Ṣaṇḍika@} in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>6</sup> this appears in another
<div n="lb"/>form in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>3</sup> He was a contemporary
<div n="lb"/>of a fellow sage, {@Keśin Sātyakāmi,@} according to the Maitrā-
<div n="lb"/>yaṇī<sup>7</sup> and Taittirīya<sup>8</sup> Saṃhitās. The Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>attributes to him a Sāman or chant, and the Kauṣītaki Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>10</sup> tells how he was taught by a golden bird.
<div n="P"/>In view of the fact that the early literature always refers to
<div n="lb"/>Dārbhya as a sage, it seems doubtful whether the commentator
<div n="lb"/>is right in thinking that the Śatapatha refers to a king and
<div n="lb"/>a people, when a sage alone may well be meant, while the
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa is of no great authority. The
<div n="lb"/>latter work may have assumed that the reference in the Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>11</sup> to the Keśin people signifies kingship, but this is
<div n="lb"/>hardly necessary.
<F>1) This is the form of the name in
<div n="lb"/>the Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, and the Kauṣītaki Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa; also later in the Bṛhaddevatā.</F>
<F>2) This is the form in the Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa. It also appears later in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda Anukramaṇī.</F>
<F>3) xi. 8, 4, 1 {%et seq.,%} as explained by
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa.</F>
<F>4) iii. 29, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxx. 2 (Weber
<div n="lb"/>{%Indische Studien,%} 3, 471); Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, {%loc. cit.;%} Baudh-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Śrauta Sūtra, xx. 25.</F>
<F>6) i. 4, 12 (von Schroeder gives no
<div n="lb"/>variant reading; but {%ṣ%} and {%kh%} are con-
<div n="lb"/>stantly confused in manuscripts).</F>
<F>3) xi. 8, 4, 1 {%et seq.,%} as explained by
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa.</F>
<F>7) i. 6, 5.</F>
<F>8) ii. 6, 2, 3.</F>
<F>9) xiii. 10, 8.</F>
<F>10) vii. 4.</F>
<F>11) xxx. 2.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 193,
<div n="lb"/>209; 2, 308; Hopkins, {%Transactions of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}

<div n="lb"/>{%des Ṛgveda,%} 62, n. 2.</F>

<L>735<pc>1-190<k1>kosala<k2>kosala
{@Kosala@}¦ is the name of a people not occurring in the earliest
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature. In the story of the spread of Āryan culture
<div n="lb"/>told in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> the Kosala-Videhas, as the
<div n="lb"/>offspring of {@Videgha Māthava,@} appear as falling later than the
<div n="lb"/>Kuru-Pañcālas under the influence of Brahminism. The same
<div n="lb"/>passage gives the {@Sadānīrā@} as the boundary of the two peoples
<div n="lb"/> — Kosala and Videha. Elsewhere<sup>2</sup> the Kausalya, or Kosala
<div n="lb"/>king, {@Para Āṭṇāra Hairaṇyanābha,@} is described as having
<div n="lb"/>performed the great Aśvamedha, or horse sacrifice. Connexion
<div n="lb"/>with {@Kāśi@} and {@Videha@} appears also from a passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra.<sup>3</sup> Weber<sup>4</sup> points out that Āśvalāyana,
<div n="lb"/>who was very probably a descendant of {@Aśvala,@} the Hotṛ priest
<div n="lb"/>of Videha, is called a Kosala in the Praśna Upaniṣad.<sup>5</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>later distinction of North and South Kosala is unknown to
<div n="lb"/>both Vedic and Buddhist literature.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>Kosala lay to the north-east of the Ganges, and corresponded
<div n="lb"/>roughly to the modern Oudh.
<F>1) i. 4, 1, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 5, 4, 4.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Hiraṇya-nābha, a Rājaputra, in
<div n="lb"/>Praśna Upaniṣad, iii. 2, and Śāṅkhā-
<div n="lb"/>yana Śrauta Sūtra, xvi. 9, 13, as a
<div n="lb"/>Kausalya, while {%ibid.,%} 11, Para is styled
<div n="lb"/>Vaideha.</F>
<F>3) xvi. 29, 5.</F>
<F>4) {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 182, 441.</F>
<F>5) vi. 1.</F>
<F>6) Oldenberg, {%Buddha,%} 393, n.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} von Schroeder, {%Indiens Literatur%}
<div n="lb"/>{%und Cultur,%} 167; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the East,%} 12, xlii; Weber, {%Indian%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Literature,%} 39, 132 {%et seq.;%} Macdonell,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sanskrit Literature,%} 213-215; Rhys
<div n="lb"/>Davids, {%Buddhist India,%} 25.</F>
<LEND>

<L>771<pc>1-196<k1>kraya<k2>kraya
{@Kraya,@}¦ ‘sale,’ is a word which does not actually occur in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, though the verb {%krī,%} from which this noun is derived,
<div n="lb"/>is found there.<sup>1</sup> Both noun and verb are common in the later
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās.<sup>2</sup> Sale appears to have regularly consisted in barter
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda:<sup>3</sup> ten cows are regarded as a possible price for
<div n="lb"/>an (image of) Indra to be used as a fetish, while elsewhere not
<div n="lb"/>a hundred, nor a thousand, nor a myriad are considered as an
<div n="lb"/>adequate price ({%śulka%}) for the purchase of Indra.<sup>4</sup> The Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda<sup>5</sup> mentions, as possible objects of commerce, garments
<div n="lb"/>({%dūrśa%}), coverlets ({%pavasta%}), and goatskins ({%ajina%}). The haggling
<div n="lb"/>of the market was already familiar in the days of the Rigveda,<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and a characteristic hymn of the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> is directed to
<div n="lb"/>procuring success in trade. The ‘price’ was called {@Vasna,@} and
<div n="lb"/>the ‘merchant’ {@Vaṇij.@} his greed being well known.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>There is little evidence of a standard of value in currency
<div n="lb"/>having been adopted. When no specific mention is made of
<div n="lb"/>the standard, the unit was probably the cow.<sup>9</sup> In a consider-
<div n="lb"/>able number of passages of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>10</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>elsewhere,<sup>11</sup> however, the expression {%hiraṇyaṃ śata-mānam%}
<div n="lb"/>suggests that there must have been some standard other than
[Page1-197+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>cows, though it might in all these passages be rendered as
<div n="lb"/>‘gold worth a hundred cows.’ But the use of the {@Kṛṣṇala@} as a
<div n="lb"/>measure of weight<sup>12</sup> suggests that the meaning is ‘gold weighing
<div n="lb"/>a hundred Kṛṣṇalas,’ and this seems the more probable explana-
<div n="lb"/>tion. This unit seems not to be known in the Rigveda, where
<div n="lb"/>the meaning of the term {@Manā,@} which occurs once, is mysterious,
<div n="lb"/>and where necklets ({@Niṣka@}) seem to have been one of the more
<div n="lb"/>portable forms of wealth, like jewellery in modern India, and
<div n="lb"/>may perhaps have served as a means of exchange.
<F>1) iv. 24, 10.</F>
<F>2) {%Kraya:%} Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 1,
<div n="lb"/>2, 1; vi. 1, 3, 3; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>viii. 55; xix. 13; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 3, 2, 10, etc.; {%krī:%} Av. iii. 15, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 10, 3; vii. 1,
<div n="lb"/>6, 2, etc.; {%apa-krī:%} Av. viii. 7, 11;
<div n="lb"/>{%pari-krī:%} Av. iv. 7, 6, etc.; {%vi-krī:%}
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 49, etc.</F>
<F>3) iv. 24, 10.</F>
<F>4) Rv. viii. 1, 5.</F>
<F>5) iv. 7, 6.</F>
<F>6) iv. 24, 9. See Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Noten,%} 1, 419, 420, correcting Sieg, {%Die%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 91, and Geldner's
<div n="lb"/>{%Kommentar%} on iv. 24.</F>
<F>7) iii. 15. See Bloomfield, {%Hymns of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the Atharvaveda,%} 352; Whitney, Trans-
<div n="lb"/>lation of the Atharvaveda, 111, 112.</F>
<F>8) Rv. i. 33, 3, and See {@Paṇi.@}</F>
<F>9) {%Cf.%} Harisvāmin on Satapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, xiii. 4, 2, 1, where he renders
<div n="lb"/>{%sahasrārha%} as equal to ‘worth a thousand
<div n="lb"/>cows,’ in which Eggeling follows him;
<div n="lb"/>Saṃkṣiptasāra on Kātyāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xxii. 10, 33.</F>
<F>10) xii. 7, 2, 13; 9, 1, 4; xiii. 1, 1, 4;
<div n="lb"/>2, 3, 2; 4, 1, 13; xiv. 3, 1, 32. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>v. 5, 5, 16; xiii. 4, 1, 6.</F>
<F>11) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xviii. 3, 2,
<div n="lb"/>where a long series of compounds of
<div n="lb"/>numerals with {%-māna%} occurs; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, viii. 5; xiv. 8; xxii. 8.</F>
<F>12) {%Cf.%} Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xi. 4; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 6, 7; Anupada
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, ix. 6: Weber, {%Indische Streifen,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 99-103.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 255-
<div n="lb"/>260. Barter had for the most part
<div n="lb"/>passed away by the time of the Jātakas,
<div n="lb"/>an illustration of the modern character
<div n="lb"/>of the society they represent. See Mrs.
<div n="lb"/>Rhys Davids, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1901, 874 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>772<pc>1-197<k1>kravaRa<k2>kravaRa
{@Kravaṇa,@}¦ a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>understood by Ludwig<sup>2</sup> as the name of the Hotṛ priest or the
<div n="lb"/>sacrificer. Roth considered it an adjective without at first<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>assigning a sense, but afterwards<sup>4</sup> as meaning ‘timid.’ Sāyaṇa
<div n="lb"/>interprets it as ‘worshipping.’ Oldenberg<sup>5</sup> considers the meaning
<div n="lb"/>uncertain, suggesting as possible ‘the slayer of the victim.’

<L>773<pc>1-197<k1>kravya<k2>kravya
{@Kravya,@}¦ ‘raw flesh,’ is never mentioned in Vedic literature
<div n="lb"/>as eaten by men. Demons alone are spoken of as consuming it,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>apart from Agni being called {%kravyād,%} ‘eating raw flesh,’ as
<div n="lb"/>consumer of the bodies of the dead.<sup>2</sup> The man who in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda is compelled by starvation to eat dog's flesh, never-
<div n="lb"/>theless cooks it.<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) Rv. vii. 104, 2; x. 87, 2. 19; 162, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Av. iii. 28, 2; iv. 36, 3: v. 29 10, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 16, 9. 10. See Macdonell,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedic Mythology,%} pp. 97, 165.</F>
<F>3) iv. 18, 13.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 270,
<div n="lb"/>271.</F>

<L>776<pc>1-198<k1>krivi<k2>krivi
{@Krivi@}¦ is asserted in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> to have been
<div n="lb"/>the older name of the {@Pañcālas.@} This statement is supported
<div n="lb"/>by the name of the king there mentioned, {@Kraivya Pāñcāla,@}
<div n="lb"/>The Krivis appear in the Rigveda<sup>2</sup> as settled on the {@Sindhu@}
<div n="lb"/>and the {@Asiknī.@} It is a plausible conjecture of Zimmer's<sup>3</sup> that
<div n="lb"/>with the {@Kurus@} they made up the {@Vaikarṇa@} people.<sup>4</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>importance of the Pañcālas, and the insignificance of the
<div n="lb"/>Krivis, may be explained in part by the fact that the later
<div n="lb"/>Kuru-Pañcāla alliance included the {@Bharatas.@} It is also
<div n="lb"/>probable, as Oldenberg<sup>5</sup> suggests, from the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa,<sup>6</sup> that the {@Turvaśas@} were included in the Pañcālas, and
<div n="lb"/>as the latter name indicates, probably other tribes also. Or, if
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins' view<sup>7</sup> is accepted that Turvaśa was king of the
<div n="lb"/>Yadus, the latter may in part have been allied with the Krivis
<div n="lb"/>to form the Pañcālas.
<F>1) xiii. 5, 4, 7.</F>
<F>2) viii. 20, 24; 22, 12. Elsewhere-
<div n="lb"/>Krivi is doubtful in sense. In several
<div n="lb"/>passages (i. 30, 1; viii. 87, 1; ix. 9, 6,
<div n="lb"/>and perhaps i. 166, 6, where {%krivir-datī%}
<div n="lb"/>is an epithet of lightning) Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} i. 166, 341, understands
<div n="lb"/>the word to mean ‘horse.’ Elsewhere
<div n="lb"/>(ii. 17, 6; 22, 2; viii. 51, 8) he takes it
<div n="lb"/>to be a proper name, while in v. 44, 4,
<div n="lb"/>he is doubtful. In the passages last
<div n="lb"/>cited this view may very well be
<div n="lb"/>correct.</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 103.</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} {@Kavaṣa.@}</F>
<F>5) {%Buddha,%} 404.</F>
<F>6) xiii. 5, 4, 16.</F>
<F>7) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 15, 258 {%et seq.%} This view is
<div n="lb"/>hardly convincing, while the disappear-
<div n="lb"/>ance of the Turvaśas is easily to be
<div n="lb"/>accounted for by their being merged,
<div n="lb"/>along with the Krivis, in the Pañcālas.
<div n="lb"/>The name of Krivi is lost in the Epic
<div n="lb"/>as completely as that of Turvaśa
<div n="lb"/>(Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1910, 48, notes 4, 5).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>155, 157; Grierson, {%Journal of the Royal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Astatic Society,%} 1908, 602-607; Keith,
<div n="lb"/>{%ibid.,%} 831 {%et seq.;%} Ludwig, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda, 3, 152, 153; Eggeling,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 12, xli.; Max

<L>793<pc>1-202<k1>kzatra<k2>kzatra<h>1

<L>796<pc>1-202<k1>kzatriya<k2>kzatriya
{@Kṣatriya.@}¦ — As the origin of caste, the relation of the castes,
<div n="lb"/>intermarriage, and cognate matters may most conveniently be
<div n="lb"/>discussed under {@Varṇa,@} this article will be confined to deter-
<div n="lb"/>mining, as far as possible, the real character of the class called
<div n="lb"/>Kṣatriyas, or collectively {@Kṣatra.@}
<div n="P"/>The evidence of the Jātakas<sup>1</sup> points to the word Khattiya
[Page1-203+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>denoting the members of the old Āryan nobility who had led
<div n="lb"/>the tribes to conquest, {@as well@} as those families of the aborigines
<div n="lb"/>who had managed to maintain their princely status in spite
<div n="lb"/>of the conquest. In the epic<sup>2</sup> also the term Kṣatriya seems to
<div n="lb"/>include these persons, but it has probably a wider signification
<div n="lb"/>than Khattiya, and would cover all the royal military vassals
<div n="lb"/>and feudal chiefs, expressing, in fact, pretty much the same
<div n="lb"/>as the {%barones%} of early English history. Neither in the
<div n="lb"/>Jātakas<sup>3</sup> nor in the epic<sup>4</sup> is the term co-extensive with all
<div n="lb"/>warriors; the army contains many besides the Kṣatriyas, who
<div n="lb"/>are the leaders or officers, rather than the rank and file.
<div n="P"/>In the later Saṃhitās<sup>5</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas<sup>6</sup> the Kṣatriya
<div n="lb"/>stands as a definite member of the social body, distinct from
<div n="lb"/>the priest, the subject people, and the slaves, {@Brāhmaṇa,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Vaiśya,@} and {@Śūdra.@} It is significant that Rājanya is a variant
<div n="lb"/>to Kṣatriya, and an earlier one. Hence it is reasonable to
<div n="lb"/>suppose that the Kṣatriya and Rājanya are both of similar
<div n="lb"/>origin, being princely or connected with royalty. Moreover,
<div n="lb"/>the early use of Kṣatriya in the Rigveda<sup>7</sup> is exclusively con-
<div n="lb"/>nected with royal authority or divine authority.
<div n="P"/>It is impossible to say exactly what persons would be in-
<div n="lb"/>cluded in the term Kṣatriya. That it covered the royal house
<div n="lb"/>and the various branches of the royal family may be regarded
<div n="lb"/>as certain. It, no doubt, also included the nobles and their
<div n="lb"/>families: this would explain the occasional opposition of
<div n="lb"/>Rājanya and Kṣatriya, as in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>8</sup> where
<div n="lb"/>a Rājanya asks a Kṣatriya for a place for sacrifice ({%deva-yajana%}).
<div n="lb"/>Thus, when strictly applied, Kṣatriya would have a wider
<div n="lb"/>denotation than Rājanya. As a rule, however, the two
<div n="lb"/>expressions are identical, and both are used as evidence in
<div n="lb"/>what follows. That Kṣatriya ever included the mere fighting
[Page1-204+ 72]
<div n="lb"/>man has not been proved: in the Rigveda<sup>9</sup> and later<sup>10</sup> others
<div n="lb"/>than Kṣatriyas regularly fought; but possibly if the nobles had
<div n="lb"/>retinues as the kings had, Kṣatriya would embrace those
<div n="lb"/>retainers who had military functions. The term did not apply
<div n="lb"/>to all members of the royal entourage; for example, the
<div n="lb"/>{@Grāmaṇī@} was usually a Vaiśya.
<div n="P"/>The connexion of the Kṣatriyas with the Brahmins was very
<div n="lb"/>close. The prosperity of the two is repeatedly asserted<sup>11</sup> to
<div n="lb"/>be indissolubly associated, especially in the relation of king
<div n="lb"/>({@Rājan@}) and domestic priest ({@Purohita@}). Sometimes there was
<div n="lb"/>feud between Kṣatriya and Brahmin.<sup>12</sup> His management of the
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice then gave the Brahmin power to ruin the Kṣatriya by
<div n="lb"/>embroiling him with the people<sup>13</sup> or with other Kṣatriyas.<sup>14</sup>
<div n="P"/>Towards the common people, on the other hand, the Kṣa-
<div n="lb"/>triya stood in a relation of well-nigh unquestioned superiority.<sup>15</sup>
<div n="lb"/>There are, however, references to occasional feuds between
[Page1-205+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>the people and the nobles,<sup>16</sup> in which no doubt the inferior
<div n="lb"/>numbers of the latter were compensated by their superior arms
<div n="lb"/>and prowess. In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>17</sup> the Vaiśya is
<div n="lb"/>described as tributary to another ({%anyasya bali-kṛt%}), to be
<div n="lb"/>devoured by another ({%anyasyādya%}), and to be oppressed at will
<div n="lb"/>({%yathākāma-jyeya%}). Probably these epithets apply most strictly
<div n="lb"/>to the relation of the king and his people, but the passage
<div n="lb"/>shows that the people were greatly at the mercy of the nobles.
<div n="lb"/>No doubt the king granted to them the right, which may have
<div n="lb"/>been hereditary, to be supported by the common people,
<div n="lb"/>whose feudal superiors they thus became. In return for these
<div n="lb"/>privileges the Kṣatriyas had probably duties of protection to
<div n="lb"/>perform, as well as some judicial functions, to judge from an
<div n="lb"/>obscure passage of the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā.<sup>18</sup>
<div n="P"/>The main duty of the Kṣatriya in the small states<sup>19</sup> of the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic period was readiness for war. The bow is thus his
<div n="lb"/>special attribute,<sup>20</sup> just as the goad is that of the agriculturist;
<div n="lb"/>for the bow is the main weapon of the Veda. Whether the
<div n="lb"/>Kṣatriyas paid much attention to mental occupations is
<div n="lb"/>uncertain. In the latest stratum of the Brāhmaṇa literature
<div n="lb"/>there are references to learned princes like {@Janaka@} of {@Videha,@}
<div n="lb"/>who is said to have become a Brahmin ({%brahmā%}), apparently in
<div n="lb"/>the sense that he had the full knowledge which a Brahmin
<div n="lb"/>possessed.<sup>21</sup> Other learned Kṣatriyas of this period were
[Page1-206+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>{@Pravāhaṇa Jaivali,@}<sup>22</sup> {@Aśvapati Kaikeya,@}<sup>23</sup> and Ajātaśatru.<sup>24</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Garbe,<sup>25</sup> Grierson,<sup>26</sup> and others believe they are justified in
<div n="lb"/>holding the view that the Ksatriyas developed a special
<div n="lb"/>philosophy of their own as opposed to Brahminism, which
<div n="lb"/>appears later as Bhakti, or Faith. On the other hand, there
<div n="lb"/>is clear evidence<sup>27</sup> that the opinion of Ksatriyas on such topics
<div n="lb"/>were held in little respect, and it must be remembered that to
<div n="lb"/>attribute wisdom to a king was a delicate and effective piece
<div n="lb"/>of flattery. There are earlier references to royal sages ({%rājan-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yarṣi%}),<sup>28</sup> but it is very doubtful if much stress can be laid on
<div n="lb"/>them, and none can be laid on the later tradition of Sāyaṇa.<sup>29</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Again, the Nirukta<sup>30</sup> gives a tradition relating how {@Devāpi,@}
<div n="lb"/>a king's son, became the Purohita of his younger brother
<div n="lb"/>{@Śaṃtanu;@} but it is very doubtful if the story can really be
<div n="lb"/>traced with Sieg<sup>31</sup> in the Rigveda<sup>32</sup> itself. In any case, the
<div n="lb"/>stories refer only to a few selected Kṣatriyas of high rank,
<div n="lb"/>while there is no evidence that the average Kṣatriya was
<div n="lb"/>concerned with intellectual pursuits. Nor is there any
<div n="lb"/>reference to Kṣatriyas engaging in agriculture or in trade
<div n="lb"/>or commerce. It may be assumed that the duties of
<div n="lb"/>administration and war were adequate to absorb his atten-
<div n="lb"/>tion. On the other hand, we do hear of a Rājanya
[Page1-207+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>as a lute player and singer at the Aśvamedha or horse
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice.<sup>33</sup>
<div n="P"/>Of the training and education of a Kṣatriya we have no
<div n="lb"/>record; presumably, as in fact if not in theory later on, he was
<div n="lb"/>mainly instructed in the art of war, the science of the bow, and
<div n="lb"/>the rudimentary administrative functions which would devolve
<div n="lb"/>on him. At this early state of the development of the nobility
<div n="lb"/>which appears to be represented in the Rigveda, it was probably
<div n="lb"/>not unusual or impossible for a Vaiśya to become a Kṣatriya;
<div n="lb"/>at least, this assumption best explains the phrase<sup>34</sup> ‘claiming
<div n="lb"/>falsely a Kṣatriya's rank’ ({%kṣatriyaṃ mithuyā dhārayantam%}).
<div n="P"/>The king and the Kṣatriyas must have stood in a particularly
<div n="lb"/>close relation. The former being the Kṣatriya {%par excellence,%}
<div n="lb"/>it is to him rather than to the ordinary Kṣatriya that we must
<div n="lb"/>refer passages like that in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>35</sup> where it
<div n="lb"/>is said that the Kṣatriya, with the consent of the clansmen,
<div n="lb"/>gives a settlement to a man: clearly a parallel to the rule found
<div n="lb"/>among many peoples that the chief, but only with the consent of
<div n="lb"/>the people, can make a grant of unoccupied land. In the same
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>36</sup> it is said that a Kṣatriya consecrates a Kṣatriya, a
<div n="lb"/>clear reference, as the commentator explains, to the practice of
<div n="lb"/>the old king consecrating the prince ({%kumāra%}) who is to succeed
<div n="lb"/>him; and again,<sup>37</sup> the Kṣatriya and the Purohita are regarded
<div n="lb"/>as alone complete in contrast with other people, the parallel
<div n="lb"/>with the Purohita here suggesting that the Kṣatriya {%par excellence%}
<div n="lb"/>is meant. On the other hand, the king is sometimes con-
<div n="lb"/>trasted with the Rājanya.<sup>38</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Sūtra literature contains elaborate rules<sup>39</sup> for the educa-
[Page1-208+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>tion and occupations of Kṣatriyas, but their contents cannot
<div n="lb"/>always be traced in the Brāhmaṇa literature, and their value is
<div n="lb"/>questionable.

<L>797<pc>1-208<k1>kzapAvan<k2>kzapAvan
{@Kṣa-pāvan,@}¦ ‘protector of the earth,’<sup>1</sup> is an epithet of a king,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or denotes a king<sup>3</sup> in the Rigveda. The word is significant, as
<div n="lb"/>showing the function of the king as the protector of the tribal
<div n="lb"/>territory.
<F>1) The word occurs only in the
<div n="lb"/>nominative singular as {%kṣapāvān,%} which
<div n="lb"/>would be the regular form from a stem
<div n="lb"/>{%kṣapāvant;%} but it is probably an irregu-
<div n="lb"/>larity for {%kṣapāvā. Cf.%} Oldenberg.
<div n="lb"/>{%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 72.</F>
<F>2) iii. 55, 17.</F>
<F>3) i. 70, 5; vii. 10, 5; viii. 71, 2;
<div n="lb"/>x. 29, 1.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf. kṣiti-pa,%} ‘guardian of earth,’
<div n="lb"/>‘king,’ in later Sanskrit.</F>

<L>798<pc>1-208<k1>kziti<k2>kziti
{@Kṣiti@}¦ is in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> a regular word for ‘dwelling,’ and in
<div n="lb"/>particular the {%kṣitir dhruvā,%} ‘the secure dwelling,’ is mentioned<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>in a context that shows it, to be equivalent to the {@Vṛjana@} or
<div n="lb"/>{@Grāma@} regarded as a stronghold. From this sense is developed
<div n="lb"/>that of the peoples occupying the settlements,<sup>3</sup> and in particular
<div n="lb"/>the five peoples<sup>4</sup> (for whom see {@Pañca Janāsaḥ@}).
<F>1) i. 65, 3; iii. 13, 4; v. 37. 4,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) i. 73, 4 ({%cf.%} 2); vii. 88, 7. See
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 142.</F>
<F>3) Rv. iii. 38, 1; iv. 24, 4; 38, 5; v. 1,
<div n="lb"/>10, etc.</F>
<F>4) i. 7, 9; 176, 3; v. 35, 2; vi. 46, 7;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 75, 4; 79, 1.</F>

<L>801<pc>1-208<k1>kzIra<k2>kzIra
{@Kṣīra,@}¦ ‘milk,’ also called {@Go@} or {@Payas,@} played a large part in
<div n="lb"/>the economy of the Vedic Indians.<sup>1</sup> It was taken warm ({%pakva%}
[Page1-209+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>as it came from the cow,<sup>2</sup> or was used with grain to make a
<div n="lb"/>‘mess cooked with milk’ ({%kṣīra-pākam odanam%}).<sup>3</sup> It was also
<div n="lb"/>used for mixing with Soma ({@Abhiśrī, Āśir@}). From it butter
<div n="lb"/>({@Ghṛta@}) was made. Milk was also curdled, the {@Pūtīkā@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Kvala@} plants, among others, being used for the purpose.<sup>4</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>curdled milk ({@Dadhi@}) was undoubtedly used for food; and a
<div n="lb"/>kind of cheese is perhaps referred to in one passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>5</sup> Goat's milk ({%aja-kṣīra%}) is also mentioned.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) The word {%kṣīra%} does not occur in
<div n="lb"/>Rv. ii. vii. It is found in i. 109, 3;
<div n="lb"/>164, 7; viii. 2, 9; ix. 67, 32; x. 87,
<div n="lb"/>16 (= Av. viii. 3, 15). See Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>17, 64, 73 {%et seq.%} See also Av. ii. 26, 4;
<div n="lb"/>v. 19, 5; x. 9, 12, etc.; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8, 7, etc.</F>
<F>2)i. 62, 9; 180, 3; iii. 30, 4.</F>
<F>3)Rv. viii. 77, 10; Av. xiii. 2, 20.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf. kṣīra-śrī,%} ‘milk-mixed,’ Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 0, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, viii. 57, etc.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 3, 5.</F>
<F>5) vi. 48, 18.</F>
<F>6) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiv. 1, 2, 13;
<div n="lb"/>see {@Aja.@}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 63,
<div n="lb"/>226, 226, 268.</F>

<L>804<pc>1-209<k1>kzumpa<k2>kzumpa
{@Kṣumpa@}¦ is a word occurring only in one passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where it seems to mean a ‘bush.’ The Nirukta<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>identifies it with the Ahichatraka, a ‘mushroom.’
<F>1) i. 84, 8.</F>
<F>2) v. 16. {%Cf.%} Benfey, {%Sāmaveda, Glossar,%} 53.</F>
<LEND>

<L>805<pc>1-209<k1>kzura<k2>kzura
{@Kṣura@}¦ occurs three times in the Rigveda. The word appears
<div n="lb"/>to have the general sense of ‘blade’<sup>1</sup> in one passage,<sup>2</sup> possibly
<div n="lb"/>also in another,<sup>3</sup> where it is said that the hare swallowed a
[Page1-210+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>Kṣura, and where the sense ‘blade’ is adequate. In the third
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>4</sup> there seems to be a reference to the sharpening of a
<div n="lb"/>razor on a grindstone<sup>5</sup> ({%bhurijos,%} the dual denoting precisely, as
<div n="lb"/>Pischel<sup>6</sup> points out, the two sides of the apparatus, between
<div n="lb"/>which the stone revolved like the modern grindstone). But
<div n="lb"/>Muir,<sup>7</sup> following another view of Roth,<sup>8</sup> adopts the sense ‘the
<div n="lb"/>edge of scissors,’ which, however, hardly suits the other
<div n="lb"/>passage, one in the Atharvaveda,<sup>9</sup> where a Kṣura is described
<div n="lb"/>as moving about on the {%bhurijos,%}<sup>10</sup> as the tongue on the lip. The
<div n="lb"/>meaning ‘razor’ is perfectly clear in the Atharvaveda,<sup>11</sup> where
<div n="lb"/>shaving by means of it is mentioned; in many other passages<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>either sense is adequate. A {%kṣuro bhṛjvān%} occurs in the Yajur-
<div n="lb"/>veda:<sup>13</sup> it seems to denote, as Bloomfield<sup>14</sup> suggests, a razor
<div n="lb"/>with a strop (in the shape of a small grinding apparatus).
<div n="lb"/>Kṣura-dhārā<sup>15</sup> denotes ‘the edge of a razor,’ like {%kṣurasya%}
<div n="lb"/>{%dhārā.%}<sup>16</sup> In the Upaniṣads<sup>17</sup> a razor-case (Kṣura-dhāna) is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned. See also {@Śmaśru.@}
<F>1) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 17, 61, 69. {%Cf.%} 13, 292
<div n="lb"/>(as ‘knife’ in the Epic).</F>
<F>2) i. 166, 10 ({%paviṣu kṣurāḥ%} on the
<div n="lb"/>fellies of the Maruts' car; possibly
<div n="lb"/>‘razors’ may be meant, as Max Müller
<div n="lb"/>says in his note on this passage, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 32, 235, n. 4).</F>
<F>3) x. 28, 9, where Sāyaṇa renders it
<div n="lb"/>as meaning ‘having claws.’ The later
<div n="lb"/>tradition ascribes the swallowing to a
<div n="lb"/>goat.</F>
<F>4) viii. 4, 16 ({%saṃ naḥ śiśīhi bhurijor%}
<div n="lb"/>{%iva kṣuram,%} ‘sharpen us like a razor on
<div n="lb"/>a grindstone or stropping apparatus’).</F>
<F>5) Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.%}</F>
<F>6) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 243.</F>
<F>7) {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 466.</F>
<F>8) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%bhurij.%}</F>
<F>9) xx. 127, 4.</F>
<F>10) Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 197, translates {%bhurijos%} by ‘on
<div n="lb"/>a strop.’</F>
<F>11) vi. 68, 1. 3; viii. 2, 7.</F>
<F>12) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 4, 5;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 1, 2, 7; {%kṣura-pavi,%} Av. xii. 5, 20.
<div n="lb"/>55; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 5, 7;
<div n="lb"/>5, 5, 6; v. 6, 6, 1; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iii. 6, 2, 9. etc.; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, i. 10, 14; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xxxvi. 8; Nirukta, v. 5.</F>
<F>13) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 12, 3.

<L>806<pc>1-210<k1>kzetra<k2>kzetra
{@Kṣetra,@}¦ ‘field.’ The use of this word in the Rigveda points
<div n="lb"/>clearly to the existence of separate fields<sup>1</sup> carefully measured
<div n="lb"/>off,<sup>2</sup> though in some passages the meaning is less definite,
[Page1-211+ 64]
<div n="lb"/>indicating cultivated land generally.<sup>3</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>later the sense of a separate field is clearly marked, though the
<div n="lb"/>more general use is also found.<sup>5</sup> The deity Kṣetrasya Pati,<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>‘Lord of the Field,’ should probably be understood as the god
<div n="lb"/>presiding over each field, just as Vāstoṣ Pati presides over each
<div n="lb"/>dwelling.<sup>7</sup> It is a fair conclusion from the evidence that the
<div n="lb"/>system of separate holdings already existed in early Vedic
<div n="lb"/>times.^8 See also {@Urvarā, Khilya.@}
<F>1) x. 33, 6. {%Cf.%} iii. 31, 15; v. 62, 7.</F>
<F>2) i. 110, 5.</F>
<F>3) i. 100, 18; ix. 85, 4; 91, 6; {%Kṣetra-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%jeṣa,%} i. 33, 15, ‘acquisition of land’;
<div n="lb"/>{%kṣetrā-sā,%} iv. 38, 1, ‘gaining land’;
<div n="lb"/>{%kṣetraṃ-jaya,%} ‘conquering cultivated
<div n="lb"/>land,’ Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 11.
<div n="lb"/>The wider sense of ‘place’ also occurs,
<div n="lb"/>v. 2, 3; 45, 9; vi. 47, 20, etc., and
<div n="lb"/>often later.</F>
<F>4) iv. 18, 5; v. 31, 4; x. 1, 18; xi. 1,
<div n="lb"/>22; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Chāndogya Upaniṣad, vii. 24, 2, etc.</F>
<F>5) Av. ii. 29, 3; xiv. 2, 7; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 1, 15. 16, etc.</F>
<F>6) Rv. iv. 37, 1, 2; vii. 35, 10; x. 66,
<div n="lb"/>13; Av. ii. 8, 5; {%kṣetrasya patnī,%} ‘Mis-
<div n="lb"/>tress of the Field,’ 12, 1; {%kṣetrāṇāṃ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%patiḥ,%} ‘Lord of Fields,’ Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xvi. 18.</F>
<F>7) Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%} p. 138.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 236;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vii. 1, 1, 8, where
<div n="lb"/>the Kṣatriya, with the consent of the
<div n="lb"/>people, gives a settlement to a man:
<div n="lb"/>that is, presumably assigns to him a
<div n="lb"/>definite Kṣetra for his own, probably
<div n="lb"/>measured out as recorded in Rv.
<div n="lb"/>i. 110, 5.</F>

<L>807<pc>1-211<k1>kzetriya<k2>kzetriya
{@Kṣetriya@}¦ is a disease which is mentioned several times in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, and against which three hymns are specially
<div n="lb"/>directed.<sup>1</sup> It is also mentioned in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>2</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>3</sup> The commentators on the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda agree in taking it to be a hereditary disease. The word
<div n="lb"/>may mean ‘organic,’<sup>4</sup> or possibly ‘produced in the field,’ as a
<div n="lb"/>theory of its origin. What disease is really intended is quite
<div n="lb"/>uncertain. Weber<sup>5</sup> considered that the aim of the Atharvan
<div n="lb"/>hymns was to drive away injury threatening the fields, but this
<div n="lb"/>is improbable. Bloomfield<sup>6</sup> suggests ‘scrofula’ or ‘syphilis.’
<div n="lb"/>The remedies mentioned throw no light on the symptoms.
<F>1) ii. 8. 10; iii. 7. {%Cf.%} ii. 14, 5;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 18, 7.</F>
<F>2) xv. 1.</F>
<F>3) ii. 5, 6, 1-3, where the form is
<div n="lb"/>Kṣetrī, explained as a demon causing
<div n="lb"/>illness, merely an incorrect version of
<div n="lb"/>Av. iii. 10.</F>
<F>4) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>5) {%Indische Studien,%} 5, 145; 13, 150
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.:%} 17, 208; {%Naxatra,%} 2, 292.</F>
<F>6) {%Atharvaveda,%} 60.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 286 {%et seq.;%} Whitney, Transia-
<div n="lb"/>tion of the Atharvaveda, 48, 49;
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 391, 392;
<div n="lb"/>Speijer, {%De ceremonia apud Indos quœ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%jātakarma vocatur,%} 76-83; Pāṇini, v. 2,
<div n="lb"/>92, with the Kāśikā Vṛtti.</F>

<L>813<pc>1-213<k1>Ka<k2>Ka
{@Kha@}¦ denotes in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> the hole in the nave
<div n="lb"/>of the wheel in which the axle is inserted. There was a
<div n="lb"/>difference, it seems, in the size of the hole in the wheel of
<div n="lb"/>a cart ({@Anas@}) and of a chariot ({@Ratha@}).<sup>3</sup> See also 1. {@Yuga.@}

<div n="lb"/>axle-hole,’ ‘running easily’; later,
<div n="lb"/>‘agreeable.’</F>

<L>817<pc>1-213<k1>Kadira<k2>Kadira
{@Khadira@}¦ is mentioned frequently from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as a tree with hard wood<sup>3</sup> — the {%Acacia catechu.%} The {@Aśvattha@}
<div n="lb"/>is referred to as engrafting itself upon it in the Atharvaveda,<sup>4</sup>
[Page1-214+ 42]
<div n="lb"/>and from it the climbing plant {@Arundhatī@} is said to have sprung.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The {%sruva%} or sacrificial ladle is spoken of as having been made
<div n="lb"/>from it,<sup>6</sup> no doubt because of its hardness. It is in the same
<div n="lb"/>passage also said to have sprung from the sap ({%rasa%}) of the
<div n="lb"/>Gāyatrī. There is no clear reference to Catechu having been
<div n="lb"/>prepared from its core,<sup>7</sup> as it was later. The core ({%sāra%}) was
<div n="lb"/>used for making amulets.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) iii. 53, 19.</F>
<F>2) Av. iii. 6, 1; v. 5, 5; viii. 8, 3;
<div n="lb"/>x. 6, 6; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 9, 3,
<div n="lb"/>etc. So {%khādira,%} ‘made of Khadira
<div n="lb"/>wood,’ Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 7, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 1; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 3, 20; iii. 6, 2, 12
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>3) Av. x. 6, 6.</F>
<F>4) iii. 6, 1. {%Cf.%} viii. 8, 3.</F>
<F>5) Av. v. 5. 5.</F>
<F>6) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 7, 1.</F>
<F>7) It is called {%bahu-sāra,%} ‘of great
<div n="lb"/>strength,’ in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,

<L>826<pc>1-215<k1>Kalva<k2>Kalva
{@Khalva@}¦ is some sort of grain or leguminous plant, perhaps, as
<div n="lb"/>Weber<sup>1</sup> thinks, the {%Phaselus radiatus.%} It is mentioned with
<div n="lb"/>other grains of all sorts in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>2</sup> and as
<div n="lb"/>being crushed with the {@Dṛṣad@} in the Atharvaveda.<sup>3</sup> It occurs
<div n="lb"/>also in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>4</sup> where Śaṅkara glosses
<div n="lb"/>it with {%niṣpāva.%}
<F>1) {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 355.</F>
<F>2) xviii. 12, where Mahīdhara glosses
<div n="lb"/>it by {%caṇaka,%} ‘chick-pea.’</F>
<F>3) ii. 31. 1; v. 23, 8.</F>
<F>4) vi. 3. 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3,
<div n="lb"/>13 Kāṇva).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 241.</F>

<L>831<pc>1-216<k1>Kila<k2>Kila<h>1
1. {@Khila,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Khilya@}<sup>2</sup> appear to have the same meaning.
<div n="lb"/>According to Roth,<sup>3</sup> these terms denote the waste land lying
<div n="lb"/>between cultivated fields; but he admits that this sense does
<div n="lb"/>not suit the passage of the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> in which it is said that
<div n="lb"/>the god places the worshipper on an unbroken Khilya ({%abhinne%}
<div n="lb"/>{%khilye%}), and he accordingly conjectures the reading {%akhilya-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%bhinne,%} ‘land unbroken by barren strips.’ Pischel<sup>5</sup> thinks that
<div n="lb"/>the meaning intended is broad lands, which were used for the
<div n="lb"/>pasturing of the cattle of the community, and were not broken
<div n="lb"/>up by cultivated fields. Oldenberg,<sup>6</sup> however, points out that
<div n="lb"/>the sense is rather the land which lay between cultivated fields,
<div n="lb"/>but which need not be deemed to have been unfertile, as
<div n="lb"/>Roth thought. This agrees with the fact that in Vedic
<div n="lb"/>times separate fields were already known: see {@Kṣetra.@}
<F>1) Av. vii. 115, 4; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, viii. 3, 4, 1.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 28, 2; x. 142, 3.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} So
<div n="lb"/>Whitney on Av., {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>4) vi. 28, 2.</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 205.</F>
<F>6) {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 385, 386.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 236;
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig. Translation of the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>3, 499; Keith, {%Journal of the Royal Asiutic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1910, 228.</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-217+ 44]

<div n="lb"/>received text of the Rigveda occurs only in the Sūtra period.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The term is a metaphorical application of the preceding word,
<div n="lb"/>‘a space not filled up,’ ‘a supplement.’

<L>833<pc>1-217<k1>Kfgala<k2>Kfgala
{@Khṛgala,@}¦ or, as the Paippalāda recension of the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>has it, Khugila, is an obscure expression found in two passages

<div n="lb"/>latter Sāyaṇa glosses it by ‘armour’ ({%tanu-trāṇa%}), but the sense

<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda, 98.</F>

<L>834<pc>1-217<k1>Kela<k2>Kela

<L>835<pc>1-217<k1>gaNgA<k2>gaNgA
{@Gaṅgā,@}¦ the modern Ganges, is mentioned directly in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda only once, in the Nadī-stuti or ‘Praise of Rivers.’<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>But it is also referred to in the derivative form {%gāṅgyaḥ%} as an
<div n="lb"/>epithet of {@Urukakṣa.@}<sup>3</sup> The name of this river does not occur
<div n="P"/><sup>2</sup>
[Page1-218+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>in the other Saṃhitā, but appears in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>where victories of {@Bharata Dauḥṣanti@} on both Gaṅgā and
<div n="lb"/>{@Yamunā@} are referred to, and in the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>especial honour is assigned to those who dwell between the
<div n="lb"/>Gaṅgā and the Yamunā, this being. To doubt, the region in
<div n="lb"/>which that text originated. The identification of the Gaṅgā
<div n="lb"/>with the Apayā<sup>6</sup> made by Ludwig<sup>7</sup> must be rejected: see
<div n="lb"/>{@Āpayā.@}
<F>1) x. 75, 5.</F>
<F>3) The reference to the Gaṅgā re-
<div n="lb"/>mains, even if with Oldenberg ({%Ṛgveda-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Noten,%} 1, 396) we assume that a thicket
<div n="lb"/>i meant, and not a proper name
<div n="lb"/>({%cf.%} Wackernagel, {%Altindische Grammatik,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 288). See also Weber, Proceed-
<div n="lb"/>ings of the Berlin Academy, 1898, 563,
<div n="lb"/>n. 1.</F>
<F>2) vi. 45, 31.</F>
<F>4) xiii. 5, 4, 11. The victory on the
<div n="lb"/>Gaṅgā represents the farthest extent
<div n="lb"/>of Bharata or Kuru rule. {%Cf.%} Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, viii. 23, and a verse in the
<div n="lb"/>Vaitāna Sūtra, xxxiv. 9, where the
<div n="lb"/>Sarasvatī is also referred to.</F>
<F>5) ii. 20.</F>
<F>6) Rv. iii. 23, 4.</F>
<F>7) Translation of the Rigveda, 3,
<div n="lb"/>200.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
<div n="lb"/>4. 5.</F>

<L>840<pc>1-219<k1>ganDAri<k2>ganDAri
{@Gandhāri@}¦ is the name of a people in the north-west of India.
<div n="lb"/>In the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> the good wool of the sheep of the Gandhāris
<div n="lb"/>is referred to. The Gandhāris are also mentioned with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Mūjavants, Angas,@} and {@Magadhas@} in the Atharvaveda.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Gandhāris<sup>3</sup> or Gāndhāris<sup>4</sup> are also spoken of in the Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtras.<sup>5</sup> Zimmer<sup>6</sup> considers that they were settled in Vedic
<div n="lb"/>times on the south bank of the {@Kubhā@} up to its mouth in the
<div n="lb"/>Indus, and for some distance down the east side of the Indus
<div n="lb"/>itself. They later formed a portion of the Persian empire,
<div n="lb"/>and detachments of Gandarians accompanied Xerxes in his
<div n="lb"/>expedition against Greece.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) i. 126, 7.</F>
<F>2) v. 22, 14. The latter two tribes
<div n="lb"/>are apparently the Eastern limit of
<div n="lb"/>the poet's knowledge, the two former
<div n="lb"/>the Northern.</F>
<F>3) Hiraṇyakeśi Śrauta Sūtra, xvii. 6;
<div n="lb"/>Āpastamba Śrauta Sūtra, xxii. 6, 18.</F>
<F>4) Baudhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xxi. 13.</F>
<F>5) See Caland, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 56, 553.</F>
<F>6) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 30, 31.</F>
<F>7) Keith, {%Aitareya Āraṇyaka,%} 23.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 206.</F>
<LEND>

<L>849<pc>1-221<k1>gardaBa<k2>gardaBa
{@Gardabha,@}¦ ‘the ass,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as inferior
<div n="lb"/>to the horse. In the Taittirīya Saṃhitā he again appears as
<div n="lb"/>inferior to the horse,<sup>2</sup> but at the same time as the best bearer
<div n="lb"/>of burdens ({%bhāra-bhāritama%}) among animals.<sup>3</sup> The same
<div n="lb"/>authority styles the ass {%dvi-retas,%} ‘having double seed,’<sup>4</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>allusion to his breeding with the mare as well as the she-ass.
<div n="lb"/>The smallness of the young of the ass, and his capacity for
<div n="lb"/>eating, are both referred to.<sup>5</sup> The disagreeable cry of the
<div n="lb"/>animal is mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<sup>6</sup> and in allusion to
<div n="lb"/>this the term ‘ass’ is applied opprobriously to a singer in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>7</sup> A hundred asses are spoken of as a gift to a singer
<div n="lb"/>in a Vālakhilya hymn.<sup>8</sup> The mule ({%aśvatara%}) is the offspring of
<div n="lb"/>an ass and a mare, the latter, like the ass, being called {%dvi-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%retas,%}<sup>9</sup> ‘receiving double seed,’ for similar reasons. The male
<div n="lb"/>ass is often also termed {@Rāsabha.@} The female ass, Gardabhī,
<div n="lb"/>is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<sup>10</sup> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad.<sup>11</sup>
<F>1) iii. 53, 23. A car drawn by asses
<div n="lb"/>is referred to in the Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iv. 9; see also {@Khara.@}</F>
<F>2) v. 1, 2, 1. 2.</F>

<L>866<pc>1-224<k1>gATA<k2>gATA
{@Gāthā@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> usually means only ‘song,’ ‘verse,’
<div n="lb"/>like Gātu.<sup>2</sup> In one passage,<sup>3</sup> however, it already has a more
<div n="lb"/>special sense, as it is classed with {@Nārāśaṃsī@} and {@Raibhī,@} a
<div n="lb"/>collocation repeatedly found later.<sup>4</sup> The commentators identify
<div n="lb"/>the three terms with certain verses of the Atharvaveda,<sup>5</sup> but
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg<sup>6</sup> has shown that this identification is incorrect for
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda. Gāthās are often mentioned elsewhere,<sup>7</sup> and are
<div n="lb"/>referred to as metrical in the Aitareya Āraṇyaka,<sup>8</sup> where the
<div n="lb"/>{@Ṛc, Kumbyā,@} and Gāthā are classed as forms of verse. The
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> distinguishes between Ṛc and Gāthā as
<div n="lb"/>divine and human respectively. According to the usage of the
[Page1-225+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas and the liturgical literature, as stated by the St.
<div n="lb"/>Petersburg Dictionary, the Gāthās are, though religious in
<div n="lb"/>content, distinguished from Ṛc, Yajus, and Sāman as non-
<div n="lb"/>Vedic — that is, are not Mantras. This view is consistent with
<div n="lb"/>the fact that the phrase {@Yajña-gāthā,@} meaning a verse
<div n="lb"/>summarizing a sacrificial usage, is not rare. The Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>10</sup> preserves several Gāthās, which generally accord
<div n="lb"/>with this description as epitomizing the sacrifices of famous
<div n="lb"/>kings, and the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>11</sup> states that a Gāthā is
<div n="lb"/>sung at a wedding. Sometimes<sup>12</sup> Gāthā is qualified as
<div n="lb"/>Nārāśaṃsī, where it must be a eulogy of a generous donor.
<F>1) viii. 32, 1; 71, 14; 98, 9; ix. 99, 4;
<div n="lb"/>{%gātha,%} i. 167, 6; ix. 11, 4; {%gātha-pati,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘lord of song,’ i. 43, 4; {%gāthā-nī,%} ‘lead-
<div n="lb"/>ing a song,’ i. 190, 1; viii. 92, 2; {%ṛju-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%gātha,%} ‘singing correctly,’ v. 44, 5;
<div n="lb"/>{%gāthin,%} ‘singer,’ i. 7, 1. {%Cf.%} Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>17, 65.</F>
<F>2) i. 151, 2; ii. 20, 5; iii. 4, 4; iv. 4, 6;
<div n="lb"/>v. 87, 8; x. 20, 4; 122, 2.</F>
<F>3) x. 85, 6.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 11, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, Aśvamedha, v. 2;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vi. 32; Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xxx. 5; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, xi. 5, 6, 8, where Raibhī does
<div n="lb"/>not occur; Gopatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6,
<div n="lb"/>12.</F>
<F>5) Viz., Gāthā = Av. xx. 127, 12 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Nārāśaṃsī = Av. xx. 127, 1-3; Raibhī
<div n="lb"/>= Av. xx. 127, 4-6; while {%ibid.,%} 7-10,
<div n="lb"/>are known as Pārikṣityaḥ ({%scil., ṛcaḥ%}).</F>
<F>6) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 238. Bloom-
<div n="lb"/>field, {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 689
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.,%} seems to accept the identification
<div n="lb"/>even for the Rigveda.</F>
<F>7) Av. x. 10, 20; xv. 6, 4 (distinct
<div n="lb"/>from Nārāśaṃsī); Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iii. 2, 4, 16; xi. 5, 7, 10; xiii. 1,
<div n="lb"/>5, 6; 4, 2, 8; 5, 4, 2; Taittirīya Āraṇ-
<div n="lb"/>yaka, ii. 10 (distinct from Nārāśaṃsī);
<div n="lb"/>Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iv. 17, 9, etc.</F>
<F>8) ii. 3, 6, with Keith's note; Sata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5, 7, 10.</F>
<F>9) vii. 18. The story of Śunaḥśepa
<div n="lb"/>is described as {%śata-gātham,%} ‘told in a
<div n="lb"/>hundred Gāthās.’</F>
<F>10) xiii. 5, 4, etc., and see xiii. 4, 2, 8,
<div n="lb"/>where the Gāthās are plainly Dānas-
<div n="lb"/>tutis, or ‘praises of gifts,’ just as the
<div n="lb"/>Nārāśaṃsī verses are declared to be in
<div n="lb"/>the Bṛhaddevatā, iii. 154.</F>
<F>11) iii. 7, 3.</F>
<F>12) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 2, 6.
<div n="lb"/>So Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>44, 98, takes Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5,
<div n="lb"/>6, 8, where Sāyaṇa hesitates between
<div n="lb"/>identifying the two and distinguishing
<div n="lb"/>them. It seems reasonable to regard
<div n="lb"/>Gāthā as the wider term which covers,
<div n="lb"/>but is not coextensive with, Nārāśaṃsī.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Sāyaṇa's example of a Gāthā in
<div n="lb"/>his commentary on Aitareya Āraṇyaka,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 3, 6: {%prātaḥ prātar anṛtaṃ te vadanti,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘they every morning tell an untruth,’
<div n="lb"/>which is clearly not a Nārāśaṃsī.

<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 689 {%et seq.;%} Weber, {%Episches im%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedischen Ritual,%} 4 {%et seq.;%} Max Müller,
<div n="lb"/>{%Ancient Sanskrit Literature,%} 493.</F>

<L>873<pc>1-226<k1>gArgya<k2>gArgya
{@Gārgya,@}¦ ‘descendant of Garga,’ is the patronymic of {@Bālāki@}
<div n="lb"/>in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka<sup>1</sup> and the Kauṣītaki<sup>2</sup> Upaniṣads. Two
<div n="lb"/>Gārgyas are mentioned in the second Vaṃśa (list of teachers)

<div n="lb"/>in the ritual Sūtras. Thus the family was evidently long
<div n="lb"/>connected with the development of liturgy and grammar.

<L>877<pc>1-227<k1>giri<k2>giri
{@Giri,@}¦ ‘mountain’ or ‘height,’ is a word that occurs repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> Thus reference is made to the trees on the
<div n="lb"/>hills, hence called ‘tree-haired’ ({%vṛkṣa-keśāḥ%}),<sup>2</sup> and to the
<div n="lb"/>streams proceeding from the hills to the sea ({%samudra%}).<sup>3</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>term is frequently coupled with the adjectival {%parvata.%}<sup>4</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda mentions the waters from the hills,<sup>5</sup> and the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda<sup>6</sup> refers to the snowy mountains. Actual names of
<div n="lb"/>mountains, as {@Mūjavant, Trikakud, Himavant,@} are very rare.
<div n="lb"/>References to {@Krauñca, Mahāmeru,@} and {@Maināga,@} are confined
<div n="lb"/>to the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, while {@Nāvaprabhraṃśana@} can no
<div n="lb"/>longer be considered a proper name.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) i. 56, 3; 61, 14; 63, 1; iv. 20, 6;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 24, 8, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. v. 41, 11.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 95, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 56, 4; viii. 64, 5; Av.
<div n="lb"/>iv. 7, 8; vi. 12, 3; 17, 3; ix. 1, 18,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vi. 66, 11, on which passage,
<div n="lb"/>see Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 411;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 32, 4; x. 68, 1, etc.</F>
<F>6) xii. 1, 11. See {@Himavant.@}</F>
<F>7) Av. xix. 37, 8, with Whitney's note
<div n="lb"/>in his Translation; Macdonell, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1909, 1107.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 47.</F>
<LEND>

<L>880<pc>1-228<k1>guggulu<k2>guggulu

<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> as produced by the Sindhu<sup>2</sup> and by the sea. The

<div n="lb"/>borne trade, bdellium being the gum of a tree, not a product of

<div n="lb"/>other substance may be meant. The word in this form also
<div n="lb"/>occurs elsewhere in the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup> and later;<sup>5</sup> it is often<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the older form of {@Gulgulu,@} between which and
<div n="lb"/>Guggulu the manuscripts constantly vary

<L>884<pc>1-228<k1>gftsamada<k2>gftsamada

<div n="lb"/>kramaṇī attributes the authorship of the second Maṇḍala of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda. This tradition is supported by the Aitareya Brāh-
[Page1-229+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>1</sup> and the Aitareya Araṇyaka.<sup>2</sup> The Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>speaks of him as a {@Bhārgava,@} ‘descendant of Bhṛgu,’ with a
<div n="lb"/>variant {@Bābhrava,@} ‘descendant of Babhru,’ but the later
<div n="lb"/>tradition keeps to the former patronymic.<sup>4</sup> The Gṛtsamadas
<div n="lb"/>are often mentioned in the second Maṇḍala of the Rigveda,<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and are also called Śunahotras,<sup>6</sup> but never Gārtsamadas or
<div n="lb"/>Śaunahotras, and Gṛtsamada himself never occurs there.<sup>7</sup>

<L>887<pc>1-229<k1>gfha<k2>gfha
{@Gṛha@}¦ is used in the singular,<sup>1</sup> or oftener in the plural,<sup>2</sup> to
<div n="lb"/>denote the ‘house’ of the Vedic Indian. {@Dama@} or {@Dam@} has
[Page1-230+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>the same sense, while {@Pastyā@} and {@Harmya@} denote more
<div n="lb"/>especially the home with its surroundings, the family settle-
<div n="lb"/>ment. The house held not only the family, which might be of
<div n="lb"/>considerable size, but also the cattle<sup>3</sup> and the sheep<sup>4</sup> at night.
<div n="lb"/>It was composed of several rooms, as the use of the plural
<div n="lb"/>indicates, and it could be securely shut up.<sup>5</sup> The door ({@Dvār,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Dvāra@}) is often referred to, and from it the house is called
<div n="lb"/>{@Duroṇa.@} In every house the fire was kept burning.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>Very little is known of the structure of the house. Presum-
<div n="lb"/>ably stone was not used,<sup>7</sup> and houses were, as in Megasthenes'
<div n="lb"/>time,<sup>8</sup> built of wood. The hymns of the Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> give
<div n="lb"/>some information about the construction of a house, but the
<div n="lb"/>details are extremely obscure, for most of the expressions used
<div n="lb"/>do not recur in any context in which their sense is clear.
<div n="lb"/>According to Zimmer,<sup>10</sup> four pillars ({@Upamit@}) were set up on a
<div n="lb"/>good site, and against them beams were leant at an angle as
<div n="lb"/>props ({@Pratimit@}). The upright pillars were connected by cross
<div n="lb"/>beams ({@Parimit@}) resting upon them. The roof was formed of
<div n="lb"/>ribs of bamboo cane ({%vaṃśa%}),<sup>11</sup> a ridge called {@Viṣūvant,@} and a
<div n="lb"/>net ({@Akṣu@}), which may mean a thatched covering<sup>12</sup> over the
<div n="lb"/>bamboo ribs. The walls were filled up with grass in bundles
<div n="lb"/>({%palada%}), and the whole structure was held together with ties of
[Page1-231+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>various sorts ({%nahana, prāṇāha, saṃdaṃśa, pariṣvañjalya%}).<sup>13</sup> In
<div n="lb"/>connexion with the house, mention is made of four terms which,
<div n="lb"/>though primarily sacrificial in meaning, seem to designate parts
<div n="lb"/>of the building: Havirdhāna, ‘oblation-holder’; Agniśāla,<sup>14</sup> ‘fire-
<div n="lb"/>place’; Patnīnāṃ Sadana, ‘wives’ room’; and Sadas, ‘sitting
<div n="lb"/>room.’ Slings or hanging vessels ({@Śikya@}) are also mentioned.<sup>15</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Reedwork ({%iṭa%}) is spoken of, no doubt as part of the finishing
<div n="lb"/>of the walls of the house.<sup>16</sup> The sides are called {@Pakṣa.@} The
<div n="lb"/>door with its framework was named {@Ātā.@}
<F>1) Rv. iii. 53, 6; iv. 49, 6; viii. 10. 1,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Av. vii. 83, 1; x. 6, 4; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, viii. 21.</F>
<F>2) Rv. ii. 42, 3; v. 76, 4; x. 18, 12;
<div n="lb"/>85, 26; 142, 4; 165, 2; Av. i. 27, 4;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 10, 11; vi. 137, 1; Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ii. 31; viii. 26; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 32; iv. 33; xviii. 44;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 2, 22; 6, 1,
<div n="lb"/>19, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 56, 16; Av. i. 3, 4; ix. 3,
<div n="lb"/>13.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 106, 5; Av. iii. 3.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 85, 6.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 69, 2. {%Cf.%} the Gārhapatya
<div n="lb"/>Agni, Av. v. 31, 5; vi. 120, 1; 121, 2;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 102; ix. 6, 30; xii. 2, 34; xviii. 4, 8;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā. iii. 39; xix. 18;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 6. 12; Kauṣīt
<div n="lb"/>taki Brāhmaṇa, ii. 1; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iii. 6, 1, 28; vii. 1, 1,
<div n="lb"/>6, etc.</F>
<F>7) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 153.
<div n="lb"/>Muir's view, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 461, that
<div n="lb"/>clay was used can only apply to the
<div n="lb"/>minor finishing of the walls of a house.</F>
<F>8) Arrian, {%Indica,%} x. 2.</F>
<F>9) iii. 12; ix. 3. See Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 343 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 234 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Whitney, Translation of the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda, 525 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>10) {%Op. cit.,%} 153. No certainty can
<div n="lb"/>attach to the rendering of the words.</F>
<F>11) It seems likely that, as the ribs
<div n="lb"/>were of bamboo and were probably
<div n="lb"/>fixed in the ridge, the roof was wagon
<div n="lb"/>headed, like the huts of the Todas at the
<div n="lb"/>present day (see illustrations in Rivers,
<div n="lb"/>{%The Todas,%} pp. 25, 27, 28, 51), and the
<div n="lb"/>rock-cut Chaityas, or Assembly Halls, of
<div n="lb"/>the Buddhists in Western India, in some
<div n="lb"/>of the earliest of which the wooden
<div n="lb"/>ribs of the arched roof are still pre-
<div n="lb"/>served. See Fergusson, {%History of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Indian Architecture,%} 22, 135, {%cf.%} 126.</F>
<F>12) Av. ix. 3, 8, where Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%op. cit.,%} 598, thinks of a wickerwork
<div n="lb"/>roof; Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 136,
<div n="lb"/>of a pole with countless holes.</F>
<F>13) Av. ix. 3, 4. 5.</F>
<F>14) Zimmer conjecturally identifies
<div n="lb"/>the Agniśāla with the central room,
<div n="lb"/>the Havirdhāna with a place for keep-
<div n="lb"/>ing the grain, etc. ({%e.g.,%} Av. iii. 3, 4),
<div n="lb"/>the Patnīnāṃ Sadana with the women's
<div n="lb"/>apartments, and the Sadas with the
<div n="lb"/>subsidiary buildings.</F>
<F>15) Av. ix. 3, 6. See Whitney, {%op. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>526; Bloomfield, {%op. cit.,%} 597.</F>
<F>16) Av. ix. 3, 17.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 148-156.</F>

<L>891<pc>1-231<k1>go<k2>go<h>1
1. {@Go@}¦ ({%a%}), ‘ox’ or ‘cow.’<sup>1</sup> These were among the chief
<div n="lb"/>sources of wealth to the Vedic Indian, and are repeatedly
[Page1-232+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>referred to from the Rigveda onwards.<sup>2</sup> The milk ({@Kṣīra@}) was
<div n="lb"/>either drunk fresh or made into butter ({@Ghṛta@}) or curds ({@Dadhi@}),
<div n="lb"/>or was mixed with {@Soma@} or used for cooking with grain
<div n="lb"/>({@Kṣīraudana@}). The cows were milked thrice a day, early
<div n="lb"/>({%prātar-doha%}), in the forenoon ({@Saṃgava@}), and in the evening
<div n="lb"/>({%sāyaṃ-doha%}).<sup>3</sup> Thrice a day they were driven out to graze,
<div n="lb"/>according to the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> ({%prātaḥ, saṃgave, sāyam%}).
<div n="lb"/>The first milking was productive, the last two scanty.<sup>3</sup> According
<div n="lb"/>to the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>5</sup> among the Bharatas the herds in
<div n="lb"/>the evening are in the {@Goṣṭha,@} at midday in the {@Saṃgavīnī.@}
<div n="lb"/>This passage Sāyaṇa expands by saying that the herds go home
<div n="lb"/>to the Śālā, or house for animals, at night so far as they consist
<div n="lb"/>of animals giving milk, while the others stayed out in the
<div n="lb"/>Goṣṭha, or open pasturage; but both were together in the
<div n="lb"/>cattle-shed during the heat of the day. The time before
<div n="lb"/>the Saṃgava, when the cows were grazing freely on the
<div n="lb"/>pastureland, was called {@Svasara.@}<sup>6</sup> When the cows were out
<div n="lb"/>feeding they were separated from the calves, which were, how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, allowed to join them at the Saṃgava,<sup>7</sup> and sometimes in
<div n="lb"/>the evening.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>While grazing the cattle were under the care of a herdsman
<div n="lb"/>({@Gopā, Gopāla@}) armed with a goad,<sup>9</sup> but they were liable to all sorts
<div n="lb"/>of dangers, such as being lost, falling into pits, breaking limbs,<sup>10</sup>
[Page1-233+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>and being stolen. The marking of the ears of cattle was
<div n="lb"/>repeatedly adopted, no doubt, to indicate ownership.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>Large herds of cattle were well-known, as is shown by the
<div n="lb"/>Dānastutis, or ‘praises of gifts,’ in the Rigveda,<sup>12</sup> even when
<div n="lb"/>allowances are made for the exaggeration of priestly gratitude.
<div n="lb"/>The importance attached to the possession of cattle is shown<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>by the numerous passages in which the gods are asked to prosper
<div n="lb"/>them, and by the repeated prayers<sup>14</sup> for wealth in kine. Hence,
<div n="lb"/>too, forays for cattle ({@Gaviṣṭi@}) were well known; the Bharata
<div n="lb"/>host is called the ‘horde desiring cows’ ({%gavyan grāmaḥ%}) in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda;<sup>15</sup> and a verbal root {%gup,%}<sup>16</sup> ‘to protect,’ was evolved as
<div n="lb"/>early as the Rigveda from the denominative {%go-pāya,%} ‘to guard
<div n="lb"/>cows.’ The Vedic poets<sup>17</sup> do not hesitate to compare their
<div n="lb"/>songs with the lowing of cows, or to liken the choir of the
<div n="lb"/>singing Apsarases to cows.<sup>18</sup>
<div n="P"/>The cattle of the Vedic period were of many colours: red
<div n="lb"/>({%rohita%}), light ({%śukra%}), dappled ({%pṛśni%}), even black ({%kṛṣṇa%}).<sup>19</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>20</sup> sees a reference to cows with blazes on the face in one
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Rigveda,<sup>21</sup> but this is uncertain.
<div n="P"/>Oxen were regularly used for ploughing or for drawing
<div n="lb"/>wagons ({%anaḍvāh%}), in which case they were, it seems, usually
<div n="lb"/>castrated.<sup>22</sup> Cows were not properly used for drawing carts,
<div n="lb"/>though they at times did so.<sup>23</sup> The flesh of both cows and
<div n="lb"/>bulls was sometimes eaten ({@Māmsa@}). Cattle were certainly the
[Page1-234+ 44]
<div n="lb"/>objects of individual ownership, and they formed one of the
<div n="lb"/>standards of exchange and valuation (see {@Kraya@}).
<div n="P"/>({%b%}) The term {@Go@} is often applied to express the products of
<div n="lb"/>the cow. It frequently means the milk,<sup>1</sup> but rarely the flesh<sup>2</sup> of
<div n="lb"/>the animal. In many passages it designates leather used as the
<div n="lb"/>material of various objects, as a bowstring,<sup>3</sup> or a sling,<sup>4</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>thongs to fasten part of the chariot,<sup>5</sup> or reins,<sup>6</sup> or the lash
<div n="lb"/>of a whip.<sup>7</sup> See also {@Carman,@} with which Go is sometimes
<div n="lb"/>synonymous.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>({%c%}) {@Gāvaḥ@} means the stars of heaven in two passages of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> according to Roth.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) i. 83, 1; 135, 8; ii. 23, 18, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>{%gāva ukṣaṇaḥ,%} i. 168, 2; Av. iii. 11, 8;
<div n="lb"/>{@Vājasaṇeyi@} Saṃhitā, xxi. 20; {%gāvo%}
<div n="lb"/>{%dhenavaḥ,%} Rv. i. 173. 1; vi. 45. 28;
<div n="lb"/>x. 95, 6; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 19.
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) The five sacrificial animals are
<div n="lb"/>man, goat, sheep, ox, horse, Sāṅkh-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Śrauta Sūtra, ix. 23, 4; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 4, 3, 13; iii. 1, 2,

<L>894<pc>1-234<k1>gotama<k2>gotama
{@Gotama@}¦ is mentioned several times in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> but
<div n="lb"/>never in such a way as to denote personal authorship of any
<div n="lb"/>hymn.<sup>2</sup> It seems clear that he was closely connected with the
[Page1-235+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>Aṅgirases, for the Gotamas frequently refer to {@Aṅgiras.@}<sup>3</sup> That
<div n="lb"/>he bore the patronymic Rāhūgaṇa is rendered probable by one
<div n="lb"/>hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>4</sup> and is assumed in the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa,<sup>5</sup> where he appears as the Purohita, or domestic priest, of
<div n="lb"/>{@Māthava Videgha,@} and as a bearer of Vedic civilization. He
<div n="lb"/>is also mentioned in the same Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup> as a contemporary of
<div n="lb"/>{@Janaka@} of {@Videha,@} and {@Yājñavalkya,@} and as the author of
<div n="lb"/>a Stoma.<sup>7</sup> He occurs, moreover, in two passages of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Gotamas are mentioned in several passages of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>9</sup> {@Vāmadeva@} and {@Nodhas@} being specified as sons of
<div n="lb"/>Gotama. They include the {@Vājaśravases.@} See also {@Gautama.@}
<F>1) Rv. i. 62, 13; 78, 2; 84, 5; 85, 11;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 4, 11.</F>
<F>2) Oldenberg. {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 215.</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 62, 1; 71, 2; 74, 5;
<div n="lb"/>75, 2; 78, 3; iv. 2, 5; 16, 8, etc.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 78, 5. {%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%loc.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%cit.,%} 236, n. 1.</F>
<F>5) i. 4, 1, 10 {%et seq.;%} xi. 4, 3, 20.

<L>896<pc>1-235<k1>gotra<k2>gotra
{@Gotra@}¦ occurs several times in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> in the account of
<div n="lb"/>the mythic exploits of Indra. Roth<sup>2</sup> interprets the word as
<div n="lb"/>‘cowstall,’ while Geldner<sup>3</sup> thinks ‘herd’ is meant. The latter
<div n="lb"/>sense seems to explain best the employment which the term
<div n="lb"/>shows in the later literature as denoting the ‘family’ or ‘clan,’
<div n="lb"/>and which is found in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Gṛhya Sūtras<sup>5</sup> stress is laid on the prohibition of
[Page1-236+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>marriage within a Gotra, or with a Sapiṇḍa of the mother of
<div n="lb"/>the bridegroom — that is to say, roughly, with agnates and
<div n="lb"/>cognates. Senart<sup>6</sup> has emphasized this fact as a basis of caste,
<div n="lb"/>on the ground that marriage within a {%curia, phratria,%} or caste
<div n="lb"/>({@Varṇa@}) was Indo-European, as was marriage outside the circle
<div n="lb"/>of agnates and cognates. But there is no evidence at all<sup>7</sup> to
<div n="lb"/>prove that this practice was Indo-European, while in India the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha<sup>8</sup> expressly recognizes marriage within the third or
<div n="lb"/>fourth degree on either side. According to Sāyaṇa, the Kāṇvas
<div n="lb"/>accepted marriage in the third degree, the Saurāṣṭras only in
<div n="lb"/>the fourth, while the scholiast on the Vajrasūcī<sup>9</sup> adḍs to the
<div n="lb"/>Kāṇvas the Andhras and the Dākṣiṇātyas, and remarks that
<div n="lb"/>the Vājasaneyins forbade marriage with the daughter of the
<div n="lb"/>mother's brother. All apparently allowed marriage with the
<div n="lb"/>daughter of a paternal uncle, which later was quite excluded.
<div n="lb"/>Change of Gotra was quite possible, as in the case of {@Śunaḥ-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@śepa@} and {@Gṛtsamada,@} who, once an Aṅgirasa, became a
<div n="lb"/>Bhārgava.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) i. 51, 3; ii. 17, 1; 23, 18; iii. 39, 4;
<div n="lb"/>43, 7; viii. 74, 5; x. 48, 2; 103, 7.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 275, 276, where
<div n="lb"/>he divides the passages according as
<div n="lb"/>real or mythical herds are meant.</F>
<F>4) iv. 4, 1. So Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra; i. 4, 16, etc.; Āśvalāyana Gṛhya
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, iv. 4, etc.; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>xxv. 15.</F>
<F>5) Gobhila Gṛhya Sūtra, iii. 4, 4;
<div n="lb"/>Āpastamba Dharma Sūtra, ii. 5, 11,
<div n="lb"/>15. 16, in Max Müller, {%Ancient Sanskrit%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Literature,%} 387. For {%sapiṇḍa,%} see Gau-
<div n="lb"/>tama Dharma Sūtra, xiv. 13; Vasiṣṭha
<div n="lb"/>Dharma Sūtra, iv. 17-19.</F>
<F>6) {%Les Castes dans l'Inde,%} 210 {%et seq.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} De la Vallée Poussin, {%Le Védisme,%}
<div n="lb"/>15.</F>
<F>7) Keith, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1909, 471, 472.</F>
<F>8) i. 8, 3, 6.</F>
<F>9) See Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10,
<div n="lb"/>73-76.</F>
<F>10) Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>157; {%Festgruss an Roth,%} 108.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte,%} 61 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 323.</F>

<L>897<pc>1-236<k1>godAna<k2>godAna
{@Go-dāna@}¦ appears to mean ‘the whiskers’ in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> where the person, being consecrated, first shaves

<div n="lb"/>vidhi, or ceremony of shaving the head, is a regular part of the
<div n="lb"/>initiation of a youth on the attainment of manhood and on
<div n="lb"/>marriage;<sup>2</sup> but though the ceremony is recognized in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>3</sup> the name<sup>4</sup> does not occur there.

<L>900<pc>1-237<k1>gopati<k2>gopati

<div n="lb"/>denote any lord or master, a natural usage considering that
<div n="lb"/>cattle formed the main species of wealth.
<F>1) i. 101, 4; iv. 24, 1; vi. 45, 21; vii. 18, 4, etc. Av. iii. 14, 6, etc.</F>

<L>902<pc>1-238<k1>gopA<k2>gopA

<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later, but the former is usually metaphorical in
<div n="lb"/>sense, applying to any protector, while the latter has the literal
<div n="lb"/>force of ‘cow-herd.’

<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘guardian,’ occurs in the
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxiv. 18, in a
<div n="lb"/>compound. {%Gopītha,%} in the sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘protection,’ occurs in Rv. v. 65, 6;
<div n="lb"/>x. 35, 14, etc. {%Goptṛ,%} ‘protector,’ first
<div n="lb"/>occurs in Av. x. 10, 5, and is thereafter

<L>904<pc>1-238<k1>gomatI<k2>gomatI
{@Go-matī,@}¦ ‘possessing cows,’ is mentioned as a river in the
<div n="lb"/>Nadī-stuti, or ‘Praise of Rivers,’ in the tenth Maṇḍala of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> In that hymn a river flowing into the Indus must
<div n="lb"/>be meant, and its identification<sup>2</sup> with the Gomal, a western
<div n="lb"/>tributary of the Indus, cannot be doubted. In one other passage
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> the accentuation of Gomati shows that a river is
<div n="lb"/>meant. It is possible that in a third passage<sup>4</sup> the reading
<div n="lb"/>should be changed to {%gomatír%} from {%gómatīr.%} Geldner<sup>5</sup> suggests
<div n="lb"/>that in the two last passages the Gumti, or rather its four
<div n="lb"/>upper arms (hence the use of the plural) is meant: this accords
<div n="lb"/>well with the later use of the name and with the general
<div n="lb"/>probability of the river here intended being in {@Kurukṣetra,@} as
<div n="lb"/>the centre of Vedic civilization.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) x. 75, 6.</F>
<F>2) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 14;
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>3, 200.</F>
<F>3) viii. 24. 30.</F>
<F>4) v. 61, 19. See Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Noten.%} 1, 355, 356.</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 152, n. 2.</F>
<F>6) Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 218;
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 19, 19 {%et seq.;%} Macdonell,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sanskrit Literature,%} 174; Keith, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1908, 1141.</F>
