<L>927<pc>1-243<k1>graha<k2>graha
{@Graha@}¦ (‘seizing’) is a term applied to the sun in the Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> most probably not in the later sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘planet,’ but to denote a power exercising magical influence.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The sense of ‘planet’ seems first to occur in the later literature,
<div n="lb"/>as in the Maitrāyaṇī Upaniṣad.<sup>3</sup> The question whether the
<div n="lb"/>planets were known to the Vedic Indians is involved in
<div n="lb"/>obscurity. Oldenberg<sup>4</sup> recognizes them in the Ādityas, whose
<div n="lb"/>number is, he believes, seven; sun, moon, and the five planets.
<div n="lb"/>But this view, though it cannot be said to be impossible or even
<div n="lb"/>unlikely, is not susceptible of proof, and has been rejected by
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt,<sup>5</sup> Pischel,<sup>6</sup> von Schroeder,<sup>7</sup> Macdonell,<sup>8</sup> and Bloom-
<div n="lb"/>field,<sup>9</sup> among others. Hillebrandt<sup>10</sup> sees the planets in the five
<div n="lb"/>Adhvaryus mentioned in the Rigveda,<sup>11</sup> but this is a mere con-
<div n="lb"/>jecture. The five bulls ({%ukṣāṇaḥ%}) in another passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>12</sup> have received a similar interpretation with equal
<div n="lb"/>uncertainty,<sup>13</sup> and Durga, in his commentary on the Nirukta,<sup>14</sup>
<div n="lb"/>even explains the term {%bhūmija,%} ‘earth-born,’ which is only men-
<div n="lb"/>tioned by Yāska, as meaning the planet Mars.<sup>15</sup> Thibaut,<sup>16</sup>
<div n="lb"/>who is generally sceptical as to the mention of planets in the
<div n="lb"/>Veda, thinks that Bṛhaspati there refers to Jupiter; but this is
<div n="lb"/>extremely improbable, though in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>17</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhaspati is made the regent of Tiṣya. A reference to the
[Page1-244+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>planets is much more probable in the seven suns ({%sapta sūryāḥ%})
<div n="lb"/>of the late Taittirīya Āraṇyaka.<sup>18</sup> On the other hand, Ludwig's
<div n="lb"/>efforts to find the five planets with the sun, the moon, and the
<div n="lb"/>twenty-seven Nakṣatras (lunar mansions) in the Rigveda, as
<div n="lb"/>corresponding to the number thirty-four used in connexion with
<div n="lb"/>light<sup>19</sup> ({%jyotis%}) and the ribs of the sacrificial horse,<sup>20</sup> is far-
<div n="lb"/>fetched. See also {@Śukra, Manthin, Vena.@}

<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.;%}

<L>929<pc>1-244<k1>grAma<k2>grAma
{@Grāma.@}¦ — The primitive sense of this word, which occurs
<div n="lb"/>frequently from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards, appears to have been
<div n="lb"/>‘village.’ The Vedic Indians must have dwelt in villages which
<div n="lb"/>were scattered over the country, some close together,<sup>2</sup> some far
<div n="lb"/>apart, and were connected by roads.<sup>3</sup> The village is regularly
<div n="lb"/>contrasted with the forest ({%araṇya%}), and its animals and plants
<div n="lb"/>with those that lived or grew wild in the woods.<sup>4</sup> The villages
<div n="lb"/>contained cattle, horses, and other domestic animals, as well as
<div n="lb"/>men.<sup>5</sup> Grain was also stored in them.<sup>6</sup> In the evening the
<div n="lb"/>cattle regularly returned thither from the forest.<sup>7</sup> The villages
<div n="lb"/>were probably open, though perhaps a fort ({@Pur@}) might on
[Page1-245+ 58]
<div n="lb"/>occasion be built inside.<sup>8</sup> Presumably they consisted of
<div n="lb"/>detached houses with enclosures, but no details are to be found
<div n="lb"/>in Vedic literature. Large villages ({%mahāgrāmāḥ%}) were known.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>The relation of the villagers is difficult to ascertain with
<div n="lb"/>precision. In several passages<sup>10</sup> the word occurs with what
<div n="lb"/>appears to be the derivative sense of ‘body of men.’ This
<div n="lb"/>sense presumably started from the use of the word to denote
<div n="lb"/>the ‘village folk,’ as when {@Śaryāta Mānava@} is said in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup> to have wandered about with his
<div n="lb"/>‘village’ ({%grāmeṇa%}); but, as Zimmer<sup>12</sup> observes, this restricted
<div n="lb"/>sense nowhere appears clearly in the Rigveda,<sup>13</sup> where indeed
<div n="lb"/>the ‘folk’ ({%jana%})<sup>14</sup> of the Bharatas is in one passage<sup>15</sup> called
<div n="lb"/>the ‘horde seeking cows’ ({%gavyan grāmaḥ%}). Zimmer<sup>16</sup> tends to
<div n="lb"/>regard the Grāma as a clan, and as standing midway between
<div n="lb"/>the family and the tribe ({@Viś@}). The Grāma may, however,
<div n="lb"/>perhaps be regarded more correctly<sup>17</sup> as an aggregate of several
<div n="lb"/>families, not necessarily forming a clan, but only part of a clan
<div n="lb"/>({@Viś@}), as is often the case at the present day.<sup>18</sup>
<div n="P"/>Vedic literature tells us very little about the social economy
<div n="lb"/>of the village. There is nothing to show that the community
<div n="lb"/>as such held land. What little evidence there is indicates that
<div n="lb"/>individual tenure of land was known (see {@Urvarā, Kṣetra@}), but
<div n="lb"/>this, in effect though not in law, presumably meant tenure by a
<div n="lb"/>family rather than by an individual person. The expression
[Page1-246+ 58]
<div n="lb"/>‘desirous of a village’ ({%grāma-kāma%}), which occurs frequently in
<div n="lb"/>the later Saṃhitās,<sup>19</sup> points, however, to the practice of the king's
<div n="lb"/>granting to his favourites his royal prerogatives over villages so
<div n="lb"/>far as fiscal matters were concerned. Later<sup>20</sup> the idea developed
<div n="lb"/>that the king was owner of all the land, and parallel with that
<div n="lb"/>idea the view that the holders of such grants were landlords.
<div n="lb"/>But of either idea there is no vestige in Vedic literature beyond
<div n="lb"/>the word {%grāma-kāma,%} which much more probably refers to the
<div n="lb"/>grant of regalia than to the grant of land, as Teutonic parallels
<div n="lb"/>show.<sup>21</sup> Such grants probably tended to depress the position
<div n="lb"/>of the actual cultivators, and to turn them into tenants, but
<div n="lb"/>they can hardly have had this effect to any appreciable extent
<div n="lb"/>in early times.
<div n="P"/>The village does not appear to have been a unit for legal
<div n="lb"/>purposes in early days,<sup>22</sup> and it can hardly be said to have been
<div n="lb"/>a political unit. The village no doubt, as later, included in its
<div n="lb"/>members various menials, besides the cultivating owners, and
<div n="lb"/>also the Brāhmaṇas and Kṣatriyas who might hold interest
<div n="lb"/>in it by royal grant or usage without actually cultivating land,
<div n="lb"/>such as chariot-makers ({@Ratha-kāra@}), carpenters ({@Takṣan@}),
<div n="lb"/>smiths ({@Karmāra@}), and others, but they did not presumably, in
<div n="lb"/>any sense, form part of the brotherhood.<sup>23</sup> All alike were
<div n="lb"/>politically subject to the king, and bound to render him food or
<div n="lb"/>service or other tribute, unless he had transferred his rights to
[Page1-247+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>others of the royal family or household, as was no doubt often
<div n="lb"/>the case, either in whole or part. The king's share in a village
<div n="lb"/>is referred to as early as the Atharvaveda.<sup>24</sup>
<div n="P"/>At the head of the village was the Grāma-ṇī, or ‘leader of
<div n="lb"/>the village,’ who is referred to in the Rigveda,<sup>25</sup> and often in
<div n="lb"/>the later Saṃhitās and in the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>26</sup> The exact
<div n="lb"/>meaning of the title is not certain. By Zimmer<sup>27</sup> the Grāmaṇī
<div n="lb"/>is regarded as having had military functions only, and he is
<div n="lb"/>certainly often connected with the {@Senānī,@} or ‘leader of an
<div n="lb"/>army.’ But there is no reason so to restrict the sense: pre-
<div n="lb"/>sumably the Grāmaṇī was the head of the village both for civil
<div n="lb"/>purposes and for military operations. He is ranked in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>28</sup> as inferior to the {@Sūta,@} or ‘charioteer,’
<div n="lb"/>with whom, however, he is associated<sup>29</sup> as one of the {@Ratnins,@}
<div n="lb"/>the ‘jewels’ of the royal establishment. The post was especially
<div n="lb"/>valuable to a Vaiśya, who, if he attained it, was at the summit
<div n="lb"/>of prosperity ({%gataśrī%}).<sup>30</sup> The Grāmaṇī's connexion with the
<div n="lb"/>royal person seems to point to his having been a nominee of
<div n="lb"/>the king rather than a popularly elected officer. But the post
<div n="lb"/>may have been sometimes hereditary, and sometimes nomi-
<div n="lb"/>nated or elective: there is no decisive evidence available.
<div n="lb"/>The use of the singular presents difficulties: possibly the
<div n="lb"/>Grāmaṇī of the village or city where the royal residence was
<div n="lb"/>situated was specially honoured and influential.<sup>31</sup>

<L>941<pc>1-250<k1>Gfta<k2>Gfta
{@Ghṛta,@}¦ the modern Ghee or ‘clarified butter,’ is repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> both as in ordinary use
<div n="lb"/>and as a customary form of sacrifice. According to a citation
<div n="lb"/>in Sāyaṇa's commentary on the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> the dis-
<div n="lb"/>tinction between Ghṛta and {@Sarpis@} consisted in the latter being
<div n="lb"/>butter fully melted, while the former was butter melted and
<div n="lb"/>hardened ({%ghanī-bhūta%}), but this distinction cannot be pressed.
<div n="lb"/>Because the butter was thrown into the fire, Agni is styled
<div n="lb"/>‘butter-faced’ ({%ghṛta-pratīka%}),<sup>4</sup> ‘butter-backed’ ({%ghṛta-pṛṣṭha%}),<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and ‘propitiated with butter’ ({%ghṛta-prasatta%}),<sup>6</sup> and ‘found of
<div n="lb"/>butter’ ({%ghṛta-prī%}).<sup>7</sup> Water was used to purify the butter: the
<div n="lb"/>waters were therefore called ‘butter-cleansing’ ({%ghṛta-pū%}).<sup>8</sup> In
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa^9 it is said that Ājya, Ghṛta, Āyuta, and
<div n="lb"/>Navanīta pertain to gods, men, Pitṛs, and embryos respectively.
<F>1) i. 134, 6; ii. 10, 4; iv. 10, 6; 58,
<div n="lb"/>5. 7. 9; v. 12, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 22, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Av. iii. 13, 5, etc.; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 8, 1, 7 (with Dadhi, Mastu,
<div n="lb"/>Amikṣā); ix. 2, 1, 1 (Dadhi, Madhu,
<div n="lb"/>Ghṛta), etc.</F>
<F>3) i. 3 (p. 240, edition Aufrecht).</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 143, 7; iii. 1, 18; v. 11, 1;
<div n="lb"/>x. 21, 7, etc.</F>

<div n="lb"/>4, etc.</F>

<F>7) Av. xii. 1, 20; xviii. 4, 41.</F>

<L>946<pc>1-251<k1>GozA<k2>GozA
{@Ghoṣā@}¦ is mentioned as a protégée of the Aśvins in two
<div n="lb"/>passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> probably as the recipient of a husband,
<div n="lb"/>who is perhaps referred to in another passage<sup>2</sup> as Arjuna,
<div n="lb"/>though this is not likely. Sāyaṇa finds a reference there to
<div n="lb"/>a skin disease, which is considered in the later tradition of the
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhaddevatā<sup>3</sup> to have been the cause of her remaining unwed,
<div n="lb"/>but this view is not tenable. According to Sāyaṇa, her son,
<div n="lb"/>Suhastya, is alluded to in an obscure verse of the Rigveda;<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg,<sup>5</sup> however, here sees a reference to Ghoṣā herself,
<div n="lb"/>while Pischel<sup>6</sup> thinks that the form ({%ghoṣe%}) is not a noun at all,
<div n="lb"/>but verbal.

<F>4) i. 120, 5.</F>

<div n="lb"/>invented from x. 41, 3, probably assisted
<div n="lb"/>by the fact that Vadhrimatī was given

<L>948<pc>1-252<k1>cakra<k2>cakra
{@Cakra,@}¦ the ‘wheel’ of a chariot or wagon, is repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>mentioned from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards, often in a metaphorical
<div n="lb"/>sense. The wheel was fixed on the axle ({@Akṣa@}) when the
<div n="lb"/>chariot was required for use; this required considerable
<div n="lb"/>strength, as is shown by a reference in the Rigveda.<sup>2</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>wheel consisted normally of spokes ({@Ara@}), and a nave ({@Nābhi@}),<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>in the opening ({@Kha@}) of which the end of the axle ({@Āṇi@}) was
<div n="lb"/>inserted. An indication of the importance attached to the
<div n="lb"/>strength of the wheel is the celebration of the car of the god
<div n="lb"/>Pūṣan as having a wheel that suffers no damage.<sup>4</sup> The usual
<div n="lb"/>number of wheels was two,<sup>5</sup> but in seven passages of the Rigveda<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>a chariot is called ‘three-wheeled,’ in a few others ‘seven-
<div n="lb"/>wheeled,’<sup>7</sup> while in one of the Atharvaveda<sup>8</sup> it is styled ‘eight-
<div n="lb"/>wheeled.’ Zimmer<sup>9</sup> argues that these epithets do not refer to
<div n="lb"/>real chariots, pointing out that in all the passages where
<div n="lb"/>{%tri-cakra,%} ‘three-wheeled,’ occurs there is a mythical reference.
<div n="lb"/>On the other hand, Weber<sup>10</sup> thinks that there might have been
<div n="lb"/>chariots with three wheels, one being in the centre between the
<div n="lb"/>two occupants. This is not very conclusive; at any rate, the
<div n="lb"/>seven-wheeled and the eight-wheeled chariots can hardly be
<div n="lb"/>regarded as indicating the existence of real vehicles with that
<div n="lb"/>number of wheels.
<div n="P"/>In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup> the potter's wheel ({%kaulāla-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%cakra%}) is referred to.
<F>1) i. 130, 9; 155, 6; 164, 2. 11. 14;
<div n="lb"/>174, 5; iv. 1, 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. xi. 7, 4; xix. 53, 1. 2, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 41, 6.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 54, 3.</F>
<F>5) Rv. viii. 5, 29; Chāndogya Upani-
<div n="lb"/>ṣad, iv. 16, 5; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, i. 4.</F>
<F>6) i. 118, 2; 157, 3; 183, 1; viii. 58, 3;
<div n="lb"/>x. 41, 1; 85, 14 (all of the Aśvins'
<div n="lb"/>chariot); iv. 36, 1 (of a chariot made
<div n="lb"/>by the Ṛbhus, who are three in
<div n="lb"/>number).</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 164, 3, 12; ii. 40, 3.</F>
<F>8) xi. 4, 22.</F>
<F>9) {%Altindisches Leben,%} viii., ix.</F>
<F>10) {%Proceedings of the Berlin Acadcmy,%}
<div n="lb"/>1898, 564, quoting Virchow, {%Zeistchrift%}
<div n="lb"/>{%für Ethnologie,%} 5, 200.</F>
<F>11) xi. 8, 1, 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 247.</F>

<L>950<pc>1-253<k1>cakzus<k2>cakzus
{@Cakṣus,@}¦ ‘eye.’ The ‘evil eye’ ({%ghoraṃ cakṣus%}) was well
<div n="lb"/>known in the Atharvaveda, which contains spells to counteract
<div n="lb"/>its influence.<sup>1</sup> As remedies against it are mentioned salve from
<div n="lb"/>Mount {@Trikakubh@}<sup>2</sup> and the {@Jaṅgiḍa@} plant.<sup>3</sup> In the wedding
<div n="lb"/>ceremony the wife is entreated not to have the evil eye ({%aghora-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%cakṣus%}).<sup>4</sup> The structure of the eye, and its division into white
<div n="lb"/>({%śukla%}), dark ({%kṛṣṇa%}), and the pupil ({%kanīn ikā%}) are repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>referred to in the later Brāhmaṇas.<sup>5</sup> The desease {@Alaji@} appears
<div n="lb"/>to have been an affection of the eyes.
<F>1) ii. 7; xix. 45, are so employed in
<div n="lb"/>the ritual.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 9, 6.</F>
<F>3) Av. xix. 35, 3.</F>
<F>4) Pāraskara Gṛhya Sūtra, i. 4; Śāṅkh-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Gṛhya Sūtra, i. 16.</F>
<F>5) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xii. 8, 2,
<div n="lb"/>26; Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 254. 324;
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 26, 1;
<div n="lb"/>34, 1; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 2, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Āraṇyaka, ii. 1, 5, etc. So
<div n="lb"/>the man ({@puru 1@}) in the eye is repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>mentioned: Chāndogya Upaniṣad, i. 7,
<div n="lb"/>5; iv. 15, 1; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 3, 5; iv. 2, 2; v. 5, 2. 4, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 27, 2.
<div n="lb"/>The Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 2, 3,
<div n="lb"/>adds the water ({%āpaḥ%}) in the eye, the
<div n="lb"/>upper and the lower lids ({%vartanī%}), and
<div n="lb"/>seven red lines ({%lohinyo rājayaḥ%}).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 13, 149.</F>

<L>953<pc>1-254<k1>candra<k2>candra<h>1
1. {@Candra,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Candra-mas,@}<sup>2</sup> are the names of the ‘moon,’ the
<div n="lb"/>latter occurring from the Rigveda onwards, but the former
<div n="lb"/>being first used in this sense by the Atharvaveda. Very little is
<div n="lb"/>said about the moon in Vedic literature, except as identified
<div n="lb"/>with {@Soma,@}<sup>3</sup> both alike being described as waxing and waning.
<div n="lb"/>Reference is, however, made to the regular changes of the
<div n="lb"/>moon, and to its alternation with the sun,<sup>5</sup> to which it, as Soma,
<div n="lb"/>is declared in the Rigveda to be married.<sup>6</sup> Mention is also
<div n="lb"/>made of its disappearance at the time of new moon,<sup>7</sup> and of its
<div n="lb"/>birth from the light of the sun.<sup>8</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> reference
<div n="lb"/>is made to demons eclipsing the moon ({%grahāś cāndramāsāḥ%}).
<div n="P"/>For the phases of the moon, and the month as a measure of
<div n="lb"/>time, see {@Māsa.@} For the moon and its mansions, see {@Nakṣatra.@}
<div n="P"/>^4) Rv. x. 55, 5. {%Cf.%} Av. x. 8, 32.
<F>1) Av. ii. 15, 2; 22, 1; iii. 31, 6, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28; xxxix. 2;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vi. 2, 2, 16, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 105, 1; viii. 82, 8; x. 64, 3;
<div n="lb"/>85, 19; Av. xi. 6, 7; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, i. 28; xxiii. 10. 59, etc.</F>
<F>3) See Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>pp. 112, 113. The identification is
<div n="lb"/>clearly found in the later parts of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 68, 10. {%Cf.%} i. 62, 8; 72, 10.</F>
<F>6) x. 85, 18. 19.</F>
<F>7) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 4, 18;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 6, 7, 12; xi. 1, 6, 19; xiv. 4, 2, 13;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 28, 8; perhaps
<div n="lb"/>Rv. x. 138, 4.</F>
<F>8) Rv. ix. 71, 9; 76, 4; 86, 32;
<div n="lb"/>Sāmaveda, ii. 9, 2, 12, 1; Hillebrandt,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 463 {%et seq. Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Sūrya.</F>
<F>9) xix. 9, 10. Av. vi. 128 is also
<div n="lb"/>regarded by the Kauśika Sūtra, c. 3,
<div n="lb"/>as referring to an eclipse of the moon.
<div n="lb"/>See Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 533.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 349,
<div n="lb"/>350, 352.</F>

<L>957<pc>1-255<k1>camU<k2>camU
{@Camū@}¦ is a term of somewhat doubtful sense occurring
<div n="lb"/>repeatedly in the Rigveda, and connected with the preparation
<div n="lb"/>of Soma. Zimmer<sup>1</sup> considers that in the dual it denotes the
<div n="lb"/>two boards between which, in his opinion, the Soma was
<div n="lb"/>crushed ({%cf.%} {@Adhiṣavaṇa@}). Roth,<sup>2</sup> however, appears to be right
<div n="lb"/>in taking the normal sense to designate a vessel into which the
<div n="lb"/>Soma was poured from the press, and Hillebrandt<sup>3</sup> shows
<div n="lb"/>clearly that when it occurs in the plural<sup>4</sup> it always has this
<div n="lb"/>sense, corresponding to the Graha-pātras of the later ritual,
<div n="lb"/>and that sometimes it is so used in the singular<sup>5</sup> or dual<sup>6</sup> also.
<div n="lb"/>In some cases,<sup>7</sup> however, he recognizes its use as denoting the
<div n="lb"/>mortar in which the Soma was pressed: he may be right here,
<div n="lb"/>as this mode of preparation was probably Indo-Iranian.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>In a derivative sense Camū appears in the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>9</sup> to denote a trough, either of solid stone or consisting of
[Page1-256+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>bricks, used by the Eastern people to protect the body of the
<div n="lb"/>dead from contact with the earth, like modern stone-lined
<div n="lb"/>graves or vaults.
<F>1) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 277, 278.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v. Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Grassmann, {%Rigveda,%} 1, 15.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 164-175.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iii. 48, 5; viii. 2, 8; 82, 7. 8;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 20, 6; 62, 16; 63, 2; 92, 2; 93, 3;
<div n="lb"/>97, 21. 37. 46; 99, 6. 8.</F>
<F>5) Rv. ix. 107, 18; x. 91, 15.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ix. 69, 5; 71, 1; 72, 5; 86, 47;
<div n="lb"/>96, 20. 21; 97 2. 48; 103, 4; 107, 10;
<div n="lb"/>108. 10.</F>

<div n="lb"/>76, 10; ix. 46, 3; x. 24, 1. Dual:
<div n="lb"/>i. 28, 9; iv. 18, 3; vi. 57, 2; ix. 36, 1.</F>

<L>958<pc>1-256<k1>caraka<k2>caraka

<div n="lb"/>ritual feud.

<L>962<pc>1-257<k1>carman<k2>carman
{@Carman,@}¦ denoting ‘hide’ in general, is a common expression
<div n="lb"/>from the Rigveda onwards.<sup>1</sup> The oxhide was turned to many
<div n="lb"/>uses, such as the manufacture of bowstrings, slings, and reins
<div n="lb"/>(see {@Go@}). It was especially often employed to place above the
<div n="lb"/>boards<sup>2</sup> on which the Soma was pressed with the stones.<sup>3</sup> It
<div n="lb"/>was possibly also used for making skin bags.<sup>4</sup> Carmaṇya
<div n="lb"/>denotes leather-work generally in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>5</sup>

<div n="lb"/>Details of the process are lacking, but the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>refers to stretching out a hide with pegs ({%śañkubhiḥ%}), and the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>9</sup> mentions the wetting of the hide.
<F>1) Rv. i. 85, 5; 110, 8; 161, 7;

<div n="lb"/>x. 9, 2; xi. 1, 9, etc.; Taittirīya Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, iii. 1, 7, 1; vi. 1, 9, 2, etc. The
<div n="lb"/>stem {%carma,%} neuter (loc., {%carme%}), is found

<F>2) Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1,
<div n="lb"/>148-150; 181-183.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 94, 9; 116, 4.</F>

<L>969<pc>1-259<k1>cAturmAsya<k2>cAturmAsya
{@Cātur-māsya,@}¦ ‘four-monthly,’ denotes the festival of the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic ritual held at the beginning of the three seasons of four
<div n="lb"/>months each, into which the Vedic year was artificially divided.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>It is clear that the sacrifices commenced with the beginning
<div n="lb"/>of each season,<sup>2</sup> and it is certain that the first of them, the
<div n="lb"/>Vaiśvadeva, coincided with the Phālgunī full moon,<sup>3</sup> the second,
<div n="lb"/>the Varuṇa-praghāsas, with the Āṣāḍhī full moon,<sup>4</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>third, the Sāka-medha, with the Kārttikī full moon.<sup>5</sup> There
<div n="lb"/>were, however, two alternative datings: the festivals could also
<div n="lb"/>be held in the Caitrī, the Śrāvaṇī, and Āgrahāyaṇī (Mārgaśīrṣī)
<div n="lb"/>full moons,<sup>6</sup> or in the Vaiśākhī, Bhādrapadī, and Pauṣī full
<div n="lb"/>moons.<sup>7</sup> Neither of the later datings is found in a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>text, but each may well have been known early, since the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>8</sup> and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> both
<div n="lb"/>recognize the full moon in the month Caitra as an alternative
<div n="lb"/>to the full moon in the month Phālguna, for the beginning of
<div n="lb"/>the year.
<div n="P"/>Jacobi considers that the commencement of the year with the
<div n="lb"/>full moon in the asterism Phalgunī, which is supported by other
<div n="lb"/>evidence,<sup>10</sup> indicates that the year at one time began with the winter
<div n="lb"/>solstice with the moon in Phalgunī, corresponding to the summer
<div n="lb"/>solstice when the sun was in Phalgunī. These astronomical
<div n="lb"/>conditions, he believes, existed in the time of the Rigveda,<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and prevailed in the fourth millennium B.C. The alternative
[Page1-260+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>dates would then indicate periods when the winter solstice
<div n="lb"/>coincided with the Caitrī or the Vaiśākhī full moon. But
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg<sup>12</sup> and Thibaut<sup>13</sup> seem clearly right in holding that
<div n="lb"/>the coincidence of Phālgunī with the beginning of spring,<sup>14</sup>
<div n="lb"/>which is certain, is fatal to this view, and that there is no
<div n="lb"/>difficulty in regarding this date as consistent with the date of
<div n="lb"/>the winter solstice in the new moon of Māgha, which is given
<div n="lb"/>by the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa,<sup>15</sup> and which forms the basis of
<div n="lb"/>the calculations of the Jyotiṣa.<sup>16</sup> The full moon in Phālguna
<div n="lb"/>would be placed about one month and a half after the winter
<div n="lb"/>solstice, or, say, in the first week of February, which date,
<div n="lb"/>according to Thibaut, may reasonably be deemed to mark the
<div n="lb"/>beginning of a new season in India about 800 B.C. At the
<div n="lb"/>same time it must be remembered that the date was necessarily
<div n="lb"/>artificial, inasmuch as the year was divided into three seasons,
<div n="lb"/>each of four months, and the Indian year does not in fact
<div n="lb"/>consist of three equal seasons. The variations of the other
<div n="lb"/>datings would then not be unnatural if any school wished to
<div n="lb"/>defer its spring festival, the Vaiśvadeva, to the time when
<div n="lb"/>spring had really manifested itself. See also {@Saṃvatsara.@}
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 6, 5, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 9, 5; ii. 2,
<div n="lb"/>2, 2; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 3, 36;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 5, 2, 48; 6, 4, 1; v. 2, 3, 10; xiii. 2,
<div n="lb"/>5, 2; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, v. 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 3, 36
<div n="lb"/>({%cf.%} xiv. 1, 1, 28); Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>v. 1.</F>
<F>3) In the month Phālguna, or Feb-
<div n="lb"/>ruary-March.</F>
<F>4) In the month Āṣāḍhā, or June-
<div n="lb"/>July.</F>
<F>5) That is, in the month Kārttika,
<div n="lb"/>when the moon is in the asterism
<div n="lb"/>Kṛttikā: Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 3,
<div n="lb"/>13; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, v. 1, etc.</F>

<L>975<pc>1-261<k1>citraraTa<k2>citraraTa
{@Citra-ratha@}¦ (‘having a brilliant car’) is the name of two
<div n="lb"/>persons.
<div n="P"/>({%a%}) It designates an Āryan prince, who, with Arṇa, was
<div n="lb"/>defeated by Indra for the Turvaśa-Yadus on the {@Sarayu@} (per-
<div n="lb"/>haps the modern Sarju in Oudh), according to the Rigveda (iv.
<div n="lb"/>30, 18). The locality would accord with the close connexion
<div n="lb"/>of Turvaśa and {@Krivi@} or {@Pañcāla.@}
[Page1-262+ 46]
<div n="P"/>({%b%}) Citraratha is also the name of a king for whom the
<div n="lb"/>{@Kāpeyas@} performed a special kind of sacrifice ({%dvirātra%}), with
<div n="lb"/>the result, according to the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> that in the
<div n="lb"/>Caitrarathi family only one member was a Kṣatra-pati, the rest
<div n="lb"/>dependents. Apparently this must mean that the Caitrarathis
<div n="lb"/>were distinguished from other families of princes by the fact
<div n="lb"/>that the chief of the clan received a markedly higher position
<div n="lb"/>than in most cases, in which probably the heads of the family
<div n="lb"/>were rather an oligarchy than a monarch and his dependents.
<div n="lb"/>See {@Rājan.@}
<F>1) xx. 12, 5. {%Cf.%} Hopkins. {%Transactions%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sciences,%} 15, 52, 53; Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 1, 32; {%Indian Literature,%} 68, n.</F>
<LEND>

<div n="lb"/>seems not to be Āryan.<sup>3</sup>

<L>993<pc>1-264<k1>cyavana<k2>cyavana
{@Cyavana,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Cyavāna,@}<sup>2</sup> are variant forms of the name of an
<div n="lb"/>ancient Ṛṣi, or seer. The Rigveda<sup>3</sup> represents him as an old
<div n="lb"/>decrepit man, to whom the Aśvins restored youth and strength,
<div n="lb"/>making him acceptable to his wife, and a husband of maidens.
[Page1-265+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>The legend is given in another form in the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa,<sup>4</sup> where Cyavana is described as wedding Sukanyā,
<div n="lb"/>the daughter of {@Śaryāta.@} He is there called a Bhṛgu or
<div n="lb"/>Āṅgirasa, and is represented as having been rejuvenated by
<div n="lb"/>immersion in a pond — the first occurrence of a motive, later
<div n="lb"/>very common in Oriental literature. Another legend about
<div n="lb"/>Cyavāna is apparently alluded to in an obscure hymn of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> where he seems to be opposed to the {@Paktha@} prince
<div n="lb"/>{@Tūrvayāṇa,@} an Indra worshipper, while Cyavāna seems to
<div n="lb"/>have been specially connected with the Aśvins. This explana-
<div n="lb"/>tion of the hymn, suggested by Pischel,<sup>6</sup> is corroborated by the
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>7</sup> which relates that {@Vidanvant,@} another
<div n="lb"/>son of Bhṛgu, supported Cyavana against Indra, who was
<div n="lb"/>angry with him for sacrificing to the Aśvins; it is also note-
<div n="lb"/>worthy that the Aśvins appear in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>obtaining a share in the sacrifice on the suggestion of Sukanyā.
<div n="lb"/>But a reconciliation of Indra and Cyavana must have taken
<div n="lb"/>place, because the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> relates the inauguration
<div n="lb"/>of {@Śāryāta@} by Cyavana with the great Indra consecration
<div n="lb"/>({%aindreṇa mahābhiṣekeṇa%}). In the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇā<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Cyavana is mentioned as a seer of Sāmans or Chants.
<F>1) This form is found even in the
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta (iv. 19), regularly in all
<div n="lb"/>the Vedic texts other than the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>and in the Epic.</F>
<F>2) The Rv. has this form through-
<div n="lb"/>out.</F>
<F>3) i. 116, 10; 117, 13; 118, 6; v. 74, 5;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 68, 6; 71, 5; x. 39, 4.</F>
<F>4) iv. 1, 5, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) x. 61, 1-3.</F>
<F>6) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 71-77; accepted
<div n="lb"/>by Griffith, {%Hymns of the Rigveda,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>465.</F>
<F>7) iii. 121-128; {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 11, cxlvi; 26, 43 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>8) iv. 1, 5, 13 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>9) viii. 21, 4; Pischel, {%op. cit.,%} 1, 75.</F>
<F>10) xiii. 5, 12; xix. 3, 6; xiv. 6, 10;
<div n="lb"/>xi. 8, 11.

<L>996<pc>1-266<k1>Candas<k2>Candas<h>1
1. {@Chandas@}¦ in the Rigveda usually denotes a ‘song of
<div n="lb"/>praise’ or ‘hymn.’<sup>1</sup> The original sense of the word, as derived
<div n="lb"/>from the verb {%chand,%} ‘to please,’ was probably ‘attractive
<div n="lb"/>spell,’ ‘magic hymn,’<sup>2</sup> which prevailed on the gods. In a very
<div n="lb"/>late hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>3</sup> as well as in one of the Atharvaveda,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the word is mentioned in the plural ({%chandāṃsi%}), beside Ṛc
<div n="lb"/>({%ṛcaḥ%}), Sāman ({%sāmāni%}), and Yajus, and seems to retain its
<div n="lb"/>original meaning, not improbably with reference to the magical
<div n="lb"/>subject-matter of the Atharvaveda. From denoting a (metrical)
<div n="lb"/>hymn it comes to mean ‘metre’ in a very late verse of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> in which the ‘Gāyatrī, the Triṣṭubh, and all ({%sarvā%})
<div n="lb"/>the metres ({%chandāṃsi%}) are mentioned. In the later Saṃhitās
<div n="lb"/>three<sup>6</sup> or seven<sup>7</sup> metres are enumerated, and in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> eight. By the time of the Rigveda Prātiśākhya<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the metres were subjected to a detailed examination, though
<div n="lb"/>much earlier references are found to the number of syllables in
<div n="lb"/>the several metres.<sup>10</sup> Later the word definitely denotes a Vedic
<div n="lb"/>text generally, as in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>11</sup>
<F>1) Rv. x. 85, 8 (an obscure verse);
<div n="lb"/>114, 5; Av. iv. 34, 1; v. 26, 5;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 124, 1; xi. 7, 8, etc.</F>

<div n="lb"/>tionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 90, 9.</F>
<F>4) Av. xi. 7, 24.</F>
<F>5) x. 14, 16.</F>
<F>6) Av. xviii. 1, 17; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, i. 27, etc.</F>
<F>7) Av. viii. 9, 17. 19, etc.</F>
<F>8) viii. 3, 3, 6, etc.</F>
<F>9) xvi. 1 {%et seq. Cf.%} Max Müller,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, xcv. {%et%}

<L>999<pc>1-267<k1>Cardis<k2>Cardis
{@Chardis@}¦ occurs often in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and occasionally later,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>denoting a secure dwelling-place. The word appears to be
<div n="lb"/>incorrectly written, because the metre shows that the first
<div n="lb"/>syllable is always short. Roth<sup>3</sup> accordingly suggested that
<div n="lb"/>{@Chadis@} should be read instead. But Chadis means ‘roof,’ while
<div n="lb"/>Chardis never has that sense. Bartholomae<sup>4</sup> is therefore prob-
<div n="lb"/>ably right in suggesting some other form, such as Chaḍis.

<L>1002<pc>1-268<k1>jaNgiqa<k2>jaNgiqa

<div n="lb"/>hymns of the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> It was used as an amulet against

<div n="lb"/>of healing powers.<sup>4</sup> It is said to be produced from the juices
<div n="lb"/>({%rasa%}) of ploughing ({%kṛṣi%}),<sup>5</sup> but this need only mean that it grew
<div n="lb"/>in cultivated land, not that it was itself cultivated. What plant
<div n="lb"/>the name designates is quite uncertain, for it disappears in the
<div n="lb"/>later literature. Caland<sup>6</sup> takes it in the Kauśika Sūtra to be
<div n="lb"/>the {%Terminalia arjuneya.%}

<L>1004<pc>1-269<k1>jana<k2>jana
{@Jana,@}¦ besides meaning ‘man’ as an individual, with a
<div n="lb"/>tendency to the collective sense, commonly denotes a ‘people’
<div n="lb"/>or ‘tribe’ in the Rigveda and later. Thus, the ‘five tribes’
<div n="lb"/>({@Panca Janāḥ@} or {@Janāsaḥ@}) are frequently referred to, and in
<div n="lb"/>one hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> the ‘people of Yadu’ ({%yādva jana%})
<div n="lb"/>and the {@Yadus@} ({%yādvāḥ%}) are synonymous. Again, the king
<div n="lb"/>({%rājan%}) is described as ‘protector ({%gopā%}) of the people ({%janasya%}),’<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and there are other references to king and Jana.<sup>3</sup> The people
<div n="lb"/>of the {@Bharatas@} ({%bhārata jana%}) is also mentioned;<sup>4</sup> there is no
<div n="lb"/>ground to assume with Hopkins<sup>5</sup> that Jana in this case means
<div n="lb"/>a clan or horde ({@Grāma@}), as distinguished from a people.
<div n="P"/>It is difficult to say exactly how a people was divided.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>6</sup> argues from a passage in the Rigveda<sup>7</sup> that a people
<div n="lb"/>was divided into cantons ({@Viś@}), cantons into joint families or
<div n="lb"/>clans, or village communities ({@Grāma, Vṛjana@}), and these again
<div n="lb"/>into single families. He thinks that the four divisions are
<div n="lb"/>reflected in the passage in question. by Jana, Viś, Janman, and
<div n="lb"/>Putrāḥ, or sons, and argues that each village community was
<div n="lb"/>originally founded on relationship. But it is very doubtful
<div n="lb"/>whether this precise division of the people can be pressed. The
<div n="lb"/>division of the Jana into several Viś may be regarded as
<div n="lb"/>probable, for it is supported by the evidence of another passage
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda,<sup>8</sup> which mentions the Viś as a unit of the fighting
<div n="lb"/>men, and thus shows that, as in Homeric times and in ancient
<div n="lb"/>Germany, relationship was deemed a good principle of military
<div n="lb"/>arrangement. But the subdivision of the Viś into several
<div n="lb"/>Grāmas is very doubtful. Zimmer<sup>9</sup> admits that neither Grāma<sup>10</sup>
[Page1-270+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>nor {@Vṛjana@}<sup>11</sup> has the special sense of a subdivision of the Viś
<div n="lb"/>when used for war, for both words only denote generally an
<div n="lb"/>armed host. He finds other designations of the village host in
<div n="lb"/>{@Vrā@}<sup>12</sup> and in {@Vrāja,@}<sup>13</sup> but it is sufficient to say that the former
<div n="lb"/>passage is of extremely doubtful import,<sup>14</sup> and that the latter
<div n="lb"/>has no reference to war at all. It is therefore impossible to state
<div n="lb"/>in what exact relation the Grāma in Vedic times stood to the
<div n="lb"/>Viś or to the family (Kula or Gotra). The confusion is increased
<div n="lb"/>by the vagueness of the sense of both Grāma and Viś. If the
<div n="lb"/>latter be regarded as a local division, then no doubt the Grāma
<div n="lb"/>must have been a part of a district; but if a Viś was a unit of
<div n="lb"/>relationship, then a Grāma may have contained families of
<div n="lb"/>different Viśes, or may have sometimes coincided with a
<div n="lb"/>Viś, or have contained only a part of a Viś. But in any
<div n="lb"/>case the original state of affairs must have been greatly
<div n="lb"/>modified by the rise of the system of caste, and the substitu-
<div n="lb"/>tion of a hierarchical for a political point of view. The
<div n="lb"/>elements of the people were represented by the family — either
<div n="lb"/>as an individual family inhabiting one home ({@Kula@}), and con-
<div n="lb"/>sisting often, no doubt, of a joint family of brothers, or as a
<div n="lb"/>patriarchal family of sons who still lived with their father — and
<div n="lb"/>by the clan, the later {@Gotra,@} which included all those who
<div n="lb"/>claimed a common ancestor. The Gotra may be regarded as
<div n="lb"/>roughly corresponding to the Latin {%gens%} and the Greek <lang n="greek"></lang>,
<div n="lb"/>and possibly the Viś may be the equivalent of the {%curia%} and
<lang n="greek"></lang>, and the Jana of the {%tribus%} and <lang n="greek"></lang> or <lang n="greek"></lang>.<sup>15</sup> These
<div n="lb"/>three divisions may also be seen in the Viś, Zantu, and Daqyu
<div n="lb"/>of the Iranian world, where the use of Viś suggests that in the
<div n="lb"/>Indian Viś a relationship based on blood rather than locality is
<div n="lb"/>meant — and perhaps even in the {%vicus, pagus,%} and {%civitas%} of the
<div n="lb"/>old German polity described in the Germania<sup>16</sup> of Tacitus.
<div n="lb"/>The family in some form appears as the third element of the
<div n="lb"/>Jana in a passage of the Rigveda,<sup>17</sup> where the house ({%gṛha%}) is
[Page1-271+ 44]
<div n="lb"/>contrasted with the Jana and the Viś. Possibly, too, another
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>18</sup> contrasts the {%adhvara,%} or family sacrifice, with that of
<div n="lb"/>the Jana or Viś, rather than, as Zimmer<sup>19</sup> thinks, the village
<div n="lb"/>with the two larger units. But it is significant of the particu-
<div n="lb"/>larism of the Vedic Indians that while the king maintained a
<div n="lb"/>fire which might be regarded as the sacred fire of the tribe,
<div n="lb"/>there is no sure trace<sup>20</sup> of any intermediate cult between that of
<div n="lb"/>the king and that of the individual householder. The real
<div n="lb"/>elements in the state are the Gotra and the Jana, just as
<div n="lb"/>ultimately the {%gens%} and {%tribus,%} the <lang n="greek"></lang> and <lang n="greek"></lang> are alone
<div n="lb"/>important. It may be that Viś sometimes represents in the
<div n="lb"/>older texts what later was known as the Gotra. See {@Viś.@}
<div n="P"/>This appears clearly when the constitution of society in the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa period is considered. The tribe or people still exists,
<div n="lb"/>and is presupposed, but the division into Viś disappears. The
<div n="lb"/>real division is now the separate castes ({@Varṇa@}), but the
<div n="lb"/>numerous sections into which each of them is divided appear to
<div n="lb"/>be based in part on the ancient Gotra.
<F>1) viii. 6, 46. 48.</F>
<F>2) Rv. iii. 43, 5. So Soma is called
<div n="lb"/>{%gopati janasya,%} ‘protector of the people,’
<div n="lb"/>Rv. ix. 35, 5.</F>
<F>3) Rv. v. 58, 4.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iii. 53, 12. See also {@Bharata.@}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} also x. 174, 5 = Av. i. 29, 6.</F>
<F>5) {%Religions of India,%} 26, 27. It is true
<div n="lb"/>that the Bharatas are called a {%gavyan%}
<div n="lb"/>{%grāmaḥ,%} ‘a horde eager for booty,’ in
<div n="lb"/>Rv. iii. 33, 11; but Grāma has there
<div n="lb"/>merely a general application. Seen. 10.</F>
<F>6) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 159, 160.</F>
<F>7) ii. 26, 3.</F>
<F>8) x. 84, 4. {%Viśaḥ%} may have the same
<div n="lb"/>sense in several other passages — iv. 24,
<div n="lb"/>4; v. 61, 1; vi. 26, 1; vii. 79, 2;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 12, 29 — but it need not necessarily
<div n="lb"/>bear this sense. But in x. 91, 2, there
<div n="lb"/>is a clear contrast between Viś and
<div n="lb"/>Jana.</F>
<F>9) {%Op. cit.,%} 161. He also relies on
<div n="lb"/>Rv. v. 53, 11, where the Maruts are
<div n="lb"/>divided into {%śardha, vrāta,%} and {%gaṇa;%}
<div n="lb"/>but these words are vague.</F>
<F>10) Rv. iii. 33. 11. See n. 5.</F>
<F>11) Rv. vii. 32, 27; x. 42, 10.</F>
<F>12) Rv. i. 126, 5 ({%viśyā iva vrāḥ%}).</F>
<F>13) Rv. x. 179, 2=Av. vii. 72, 2.</F>
<F>14) {%Cf.%} Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 121,
<div n="lb"/>319.</F>
<F>15) {%Cf. Iliad,%} 2, 362.</F>
<F>16) Chap. vii. Zimmer gives other
<div n="lb"/>equations, for which {%cf.%} Schrader,
<div n="lb"/>{%Prehistoric Antiquities,%} 393 {%et seq.%} The
<div n="lb"/>exact parallelism cannot in any case
<div n="lb"/>be pressed.</F>
<F>17) x. 91, 2, where {%janaṃ janam%} and
<div n="lb"/>{%viśaṃ viśam%} occur, and where a con-
<div n="lb"/>trast must be meant.</F>
<F>18) Rv. vii. 82, 1.</F>
<F>19) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 435.</F>
<F>20) Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>126.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>158; von Schroeder, {%Indiens Literatur%}
<div n="lb"/>{%und Cultur,%} 32, 33; Jolly, {%Zeitschrift%}
<div n="lb"/>{%der Dcutschen Morgenländischen Gesell-%}

<L>1005<pc>1-271<k1>janaSArkarakzya<k2>janaSArkarakzya<h>2

<div n="lb"/>mentioned as a teacher in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa (x. 6, 1, 1
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}) and the Chāndogya Upaniṣad (v. 11, 1; 15, 1). He was
<div n="lb"/>a contemporary of {@Aśvapati Kaikeya,@} and of {@Aruṇa Aupaveśi@}
<div n="lb"/>and his son {@Uddālaka Āruṇi.@}
<LEND>

<L>1006<pc>1-271<k1>janaka<k2>janaka
{@Janaka,@}¦ king of Videha, plays a considerable part in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as well as in the Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> and the Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad.<sup>4</sup> He was a contemporary of {@Yājñavalkya Vāja-@}
[Page1-272+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>{@saneya,@}<sup>5</sup> of {@Śvetaketu Āruṇeya,@} and of other sages.<sup>6</sup> He had
<div n="lb"/>become famous for his generosity and his interest in the dis-
<div n="lb"/>cussion of the nature of Brahman, as ultimate basis of reality,
<div n="lb"/>in the life-time of {@Ajātaśatru@} of Kāśi.<sup>7</sup> It is significant that
<div n="lb"/>he maintained a close intercourse with the Brahmins of the
<div n="lb"/>Kuru-Pañcālas, such as Yājñavalkya and Śvetaketu; for this
<div n="lb"/>indicates that the home of the philosophy of the Upaniṣads
<div n="lb"/>was in the Kuru-Pañcāla country rather than in the east.
<div n="lb"/>There is a statement in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> that he
<div n="lb"/>became a Brahmin ({%brahmā%}). This does not, however, signify
<div n="lb"/>a change of caste, but merely that in knowledge he became
<div n="lb"/>a Brahmin (see {@Kṣatriya@}). Janaka is occasionally mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in later texts: in the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> he has already
<div n="lb"/>become quite mythical; in the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>a {%sapta-rātra%} or seven nights' rite is ascribed to him.
<div n="P"/>It is natural to attempt to date Janaka by his being a con-
<div n="lb"/>temporary of Ajātaśatru, and by identifying the latter with the
<div n="lb"/>Ajātasattu of the Pāli texts:<sup>11</sup> this would make the end of the
<div n="lb"/>sixth century B.C. the approximate date of Janaka.<sup>12</sup> But it is
<div n="lb"/>very doubtful whether this identification can be supported:
<div n="lb"/>Ajātaśatru was king of Kāśi, whereas Ajātasattu was king of
<div n="lb"/>Magadha, and his only connexion with Kāśi was through his
<div n="lb"/>marriage with the daughter of Pasenadi of Kosala.<sup>13</sup> More-
<div n="lb"/>over, the acceptance of this chronology would be difficult to
<div n="lb"/>reconcile with the history of the development of thought; for
<div n="lb"/>it would make the rise of Buddhism contemporaneous with the
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣads, whereas it is reasonably certain that the older
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣads preceded Buddhism.<sup>14</sup> Nor do the Vedic texts know
<div n="lb"/>anything of Bimbisāra or Pasenadi, or any of the other princes
<div n="lb"/>famed in Buddhist records.
[Page1-273+ 54]
<div n="P"/>The identification<sup>15</sup> of Janaka of Videha and the father of
<div n="lb"/>Sītā is less open to objection, but it cannot be proved, and is
<div n="lb"/>somewhat doubtful. In the Sūtras Janaka appears as an
<div n="lb"/>ancient king who knew of a time when wifely honour was less
<div n="lb"/>respected than later.<sup>16</sup>
<F>1) xi. 3, 1, 2; 4, 3, 20; 6, 2, 1
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) iii. 1, 1; iv. 1, 1; 2, 1; 4, 7; v.
<div n="lb"/>14, 8.</F>
<F>3) i. 19, 2 ({%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 23, 329); ii. 76 ({%ibid.,%}
<div n="lb"/>15, 238).</F>
<F>4) iv. 1.</F>
<F>5) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 3, 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>4, 3, 20; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, {%loc.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%cit.;%} Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, {%loc. cit.%}</F>

<L>1009<pc>1-273<k1>janamejaya<k2>janamejaya<h>1
1. {@Janam-ejaya@}¦ (‘man-impelling’) is the name of a king,
<div n="lb"/>a {@Pārikṣita,@}<sup>1</sup> famous towards the end of the Brāhmaṇa period.
<div n="lb"/>He is mentioned in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> as owning
<div n="lb"/>horses which when wearied were refreshed with sweet drinks,
<div n="lb"/>and as a performer of the Aśvamedha, or horse sacrifice.<sup>3</sup> His
<div n="lb"/>capital, according to a Gāthā quoted in the Śatapatha<sup>4</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Brāhmaṇas,<sup>5</sup> was {@Āsandīvant.@} His brothers
<div n="lb"/>{@Ugrasena, Bhīmasena,@} and {@Śrutasena@} are mentioned as having
[Page1-274+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>by the horse sacrifice purified themselves from sin. The priest
<div n="lb"/>who performed the sacrifice for him was {@Indrota Daivāpi@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Śaunaka.@}<sup>6</sup> On the other hand the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>7</sup> which
<div n="lb"/>also mentions his Aśvamedha, names {@Tura Kāvaṣeya@} as his
<div n="lb"/>priest. It also contains an obscure tale stating that at one
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice of his he did not employ the {@Kaśyapas,@} but the
<div n="lb"/>{@Bhūtavīras,@} being, however, induced by the {@Asitamṛgas@} to
<div n="lb"/>have recourse to the Kaśyapas again.<sup>8</sup> He was a {@Kuru@} prince;
<div n="lb"/>see {@Parikṣit.@} The Gopatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> tells an absurd tale
<div n="lb"/>about him, evidently as of an ancient hero.
<F>1) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 5, 4,
<div n="lb"/>1 {%et seq.;%} Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 34;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 11. 21; Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra,
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 8, 27, etc.</F>
<F>2) xi. 5, 5, 13.</F>
<F>3) xiii. 5, 4, 1-3.</F>
<F>4) xiii. 5, 4, 2.</F>
<F>5) viii. 21.</F>
<F>6) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 5, 4, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, {%loe. cit.%}</F>
<F>7) viii. 21. {%Cf.%} iv. 27; vii. 34.</F>
<F>8) vii. 27. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 204; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 12, 438,
<div n="lb"/>n. 229; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%East,%} 43, 345, n.</F>
<F>9)i. 2, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indian Literature,%} 123-
<div n="lb"/>125; 134-136; Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%}
<div n="lb"/>37, 65 {%et seq.;%} 42, 239; Pargiter, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1910, 28
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>

<L>1012<pc>1-274<k1>jani<k2>jani
{@Jani, Janī.@}¦ — These words appear to denote ‘wife,’ usually
<div n="lb"/>applying to her in relation to her husband ({@Pati@}). The more
<div n="lb"/>general sense of ‘woman’ is doubtful; for when Uṣas is called
<div n="lb"/>a fair {@Janī,@}<sup>1</sup> ‘wife’ may be meant, and the other passage<sup>2</sup> cited
<div n="lb"/>for this sense by Delbrück,<sup>3</sup> which refers to the begetting of
<div n="lb"/>children, seems to demand the sense of ‘wives.’ Since the
<div n="lb"/>words usually appear in the plural,<sup>4</sup> it is possible they may
[Page1-275+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>refer not to ‘wives’ proper, but to Hetairai. This is, how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, rendered unlikely because the Rigveda<sup>5</sup> uses the phrase
<div n="lb"/>{%patyur janitvam,%} denoting ‘wifehood to a husband,’ as well
<div n="lb"/>as the expression {%janayo na patnīḥ,%}<sup>6</sup> ‘like wives (who are)
<div n="lb"/>mistresses,’<sup>7</sup> besides containing passages in which the word has
<div n="lb"/>reference to marriage.<sup>8</sup> The singular occurs in the dialogue of
<div n="lb"/>Yama and Yamī.<sup>9</sup>
<F>1) Rv. iv. 52, 1.</F>
<F>2) v. 61, 3.</F>
<F>3) {%Die indogermanischen Verwandschafts-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%namen,%} 413.</F>
<F>4) i. 85, 1; iv. 5, 5; 19, 5; vii. 18, 2;
<div n="lb"/>26, 3; ix. 86, 32; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xii. 35; xx. 40. 43, etc. {%Cf.%} Rv. x. 43, 1.
<div n="lb"/>In x. 110, 5, the phrase is {%patibhyo na%}
<div n="lb"/>{%janayaḥ,%} where both plurals may be
<div n="lb"/>generic</F>
<F>5) x. 18, 8. {%Cf. janitvana%} in viii. 2,
<div n="lb"/>42.</F>
<F>6) i. 62, 10; 186, 7.</F>
<F>7) The distinction of sense was prob-
<div n="lb"/>ably this: {%jani%} meant ‘wife,’ as bearing
<div n="lb"/>children (from {%jan,%} ‘beget’), while
<div n="lb"/>{%patnī%} was ‘wife,’ as being mistress
<div n="lb"/>of the house (feminine of {%pati,%} ‘lord,’
<div n="lb"/>‘husband’).</F>
<F>8) v. 61, 3. So in x. 40, 10, the word
<div n="lb"/>seems certainly to refer to marriage.</F>
<F>9) x. 10, 3.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1019<pc>1-276<k1>jamadagni<k2>jamadagni
{@Jamad-agni@}¦ is one of the somewhat mythical sages of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, where he is frequently mentioned. In some passages<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>his name occurs in such a way as to indicate that he is the
<div n="lb"/>author of the hymn; once<sup>2</sup> he is thus associated with {@Viśvā-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@mitra.@} In other passages<sup>3</sup> he is merely referred to, and the
<div n="lb"/>Jamadagnis are mentioned once.<sup>4</sup> In the Atharvaveda,<sup>5</sup> as well
<div n="lb"/>as the Yajurveda Saṃhitās<sup>6</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>7</sup> he is quite a
<div n="lb"/>frequent figure. Here he appears as a friend of Viśvāmitra<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and a rival of {@Vasiṣṭha.@}<sup>9</sup> He owed his prosperity to his {%catū-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%rātra,%} or ‘four-night’ ritual, with which his family were also
<div n="lb"/>very successful.<sup>10</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>11</sup> Jamadagni is connected
<div n="lb"/>with {@Atri@} and {@Kaṇva,@} as well as {@Asita@} and {@Vitahavya.@} He was
<div n="lb"/>Adhvaryu priest at the proposed sacrifice of {@Śunaḥśepa.@}<sup>12</sup>

<L>1020<pc>1-276<k1>jamBa<k2>jamBa
{@Jambha@}¦ occurs twice in the Atharvaveda as the name of a
<div n="lb"/>disease or a demon of disease. In one passage<sup>1</sup> it is said to be

<div n="lb"/>while Caland<sup>6</sup> thinks it denotes ‘tetanus.’ Whitney<sup>7</sup> decides
<div n="lb"/>for ‘lockjaw’ or ‘convulsions.’
<F>1) ii. 4, 2.</F>

<L>1024<pc>1-277<k1>jarAboDa<k2>jarAboDa
{@Jarā-bodha,@}¦ a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>of doubtful meaning. It is held by Ludwig<sup>2</sup> to be the name of
[Page1-278+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>a seer. Roth<sup>3</sup> regards it as a mere adjective meaning ‘attending
<div n="lb"/>to the invocation,’ which is perhaps the most probable inter-
<div n="lb"/>pretation. Oldenburg,<sup>4</sup> however, thinks that the word is a
<div n="lb"/>proper name, the literal sense being ‘alert in old age.’

<div n="lb"/>10.</F>

<L>1025<pc>1-278<k1>jarAyu<k2>jarAyu
{@Jarāyu@}¦ is found once in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> in the sense of
<div n="lb"/>a ‘serpent's skin.’ Usually<sup>2</sup> it denotes the outer covering
<div n="lb"/>(chorion) of the embryo, as opposed to the {%ulva,%} the inner
<div n="lb"/>covering (amnion).
<div n="P"/>Living things are occasionally classified according to their
<div n="lb"/>mode of origin. In the Chāndogya Upaniṣad<sup>3</sup> they are divided
<div n="lb"/>into {%(a) āṇḍa-ja,%} ‘egg-born’; {%(b) jīva-ja,%} ‘born alive,’ or born
<div n="lb"/>from the womb; {%(c) udbhij-ja,%} ‘propagated by sprouts.’ In the
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>4</sup> the division is fourfold: {%(a) āṇḍa-ja;%}
<div n="lb"/>{%(b) jāru-ja,%} that is, {%jarāyu-ja%} (found in the Atharvaveda,<sup>5</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>needlessly read here by Böhtlingk);<sup>6</sup> {%(c) udbhij-ja;%} and {%(d)%}
<div n="lb"/>{%svcda-ja,%} ‘sweat-born,’ explained as ‘insects.’
<F>1) i. 27, 1.</F>
<F>2) Rv. v. 78, 8; Av. i. 11, 4; vi. 49, 1;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 4, 4; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 6, 3;

<L>1026<pc>1-278<k1>jaritf<k2>jaritf<h>1
1. {@Jaritṛ@}¦ is the regular term in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and occasion-
<div n="lb"/>ally later,<sup>2</sup> for a singer of hymns of praise or worshipper.
<F>1) i. 2, 2; 165, 14; ii. 33, 11; iii. 60,
<div n="lb"/>7, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 11, 8; xx. 135, 1, etc.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1027<pc>1-278<k1>jaritf<k2>jaritf<h>2
2. {@Jaritṛ.@}¦ According to Sieg,<sup>1</sup> mention is made in one
<div n="lb"/>hymn of the Rigveda<sup>2</sup> of Jaritṛ, one of the Śārṅgas. That
<div n="lb"/>hymn he seeks to bring into connexion with the epic<sup>3</sup> tradition
[Page1-279+ 35]
<div n="lb"/>of the Ṛṣi Mandapāla, who wedded Jaritā, a female Śārṅga
<div n="lb"/>bird — apparently a hen sparrow ({%caṭakā%}) — and had four sons.
<div n="lb"/>These being abandoned by him and exposed to the danger of
<div n="lb"/>being consumed by a forest fire, prayed to Agni with the hymn
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda x. 142. This interpretation is very doubtful, though
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa<sup>4</sup> appears to have adopted it.
<F>1) {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 44 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) x. 142.</F>
<F>3) Mahābhārata, i. 222, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) On Rv. x. 142, 7. 8.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1028<pc>1-279<k1>jarUTa<k2>jarUTa
{@Jarūtha,@}¦ mentioned in three passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>appears to denote a {@demon@} defeated by Agni.<sup>2</sup> Ludwig, how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, followed by Griffith,<sup>3</sup> sees in him a foe slain in a battle in
<div n="lb"/>which {@Vasiṣṭha,@} the traditional author of the seventh Maṇḍala
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda, was Purohita, or domestic priest.
<F>1) vii. 1, 7; 9, 6; x. 80. 3.</F>
<F>2) Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.;%} Nirukta, vi. 17.</F>
<F>3) {%Hymns of the Rigveda,%} 2, 11, n.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1029<pc>1-279<k1>jartila<k2>jartila
{@Jartila,@}¦ ‘wild sesamum,’ is mentioned in the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā (v. 4, 3, 2) as an unsuitable sacrificial offering. In
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa (ix. 1, 1, 3) sesamum seeds are
<div n="lb"/>regarded as combining the qualities of cultivation (viz.,
<div n="lb"/>edibility) with those of wild growth (because they are produced
<div n="lb"/>on unploughed land).

<L>1035<pc>1-280<k1>jahnu<k2>jahnu
{@Jahnu@}¦ occurs only in the plural in the legend of {@Śunaḥśepa,@}
<div n="lb"/>who is said to have obtained, as Devarāta, both the lordship
<div n="lb"/>of the Jahnus and the divine lore of the Gāthins.<sup>1</sup> A {@Jāhnava,@}
<div n="lb"/>or descendant of Jahnu, was, according to the Pañcaviṃśa
[Page1-281+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> {@Viśvāmitra,@} who is said, by means of a certain
<div n="lb"/>{%catū-rātra%} or ‘four-night’ ritual, to have secured the kingdom
<div n="lb"/>for the Jahnus in their conflict with the {@Vṛcīvants.@} He is
<div n="lb"/>here described as a king. Again, in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Viśvāmitra is addressed as a {%rāja-putra,%} ‘prince,’ and {%Bharata-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%rṣabha,%} ‘bull of the Bharatas.’ It is therefore clear that the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas, though not the Saṃhitās, saw in him at once a
<div n="lb"/>priest and a prince by origin, though there is no trace whatever
<div n="lb"/>of their seeing in him a prince who won Brahmanhood as in
<div n="lb"/>the version of the later texts.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>A Jahnāvī is mentioned twice in the Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> being either
<div n="lb"/>the wife of Jahnu, or, as Sāyaṇa thinks, the race of Jahnu.
<div n="lb"/>The family must clearly once have been a great one, later
<div n="lb"/>merged in the Bharatas.
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 18 ({%Jah-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%nūnām cādhipatye daive vede ca Gāthinām%});
<div n="lb"/>Asvalāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xii. 14;
<div n="lb"/>Sāṅkhāyana Srauta Sūtra, xv. 27 (p. 195,
<div n="lb"/>1. 21, ed. Hillebrandt, where the read-
<div n="lb"/>ing is different and the sense altered:
<div n="lb"/>{%Jahnūnāṃ cādhitasthire daive vede ca%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gāthinaḥ.%} The two {%ca%}'s cannot be
<div n="lb"/>justified, and the text must be in-
<div n="lb"/>correct).</F>
<F>2) xxi. 12. {%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%Transactions%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sciences,%} 15, 54, who correctly explains
<div n="lb"/>the passage which Sāyaṇa misunder-
<div n="lb"/>stands.</F>
<F>3) vii. 17, 6, 7.</F>
<F>4) Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1, 337 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) i. 116, 19; iii. 58, 6. {%Cf.%} Ludwig,
<div n="lb"/>Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 153.</F>

<L>1038<pc>1-281<k1>jAti<k2>jAti

<L>1052<pc>1-284<k1>jAmi<k2>jAmi
{@Jāmi,@}¦ a word which appears originally to have meant
<div n="lb"/>‘related in blood,’ is not rarely used as an epithet of ‘sister’
<div n="lb"/>({@Svasṛ@}), and sometimes even denotes ‘sister’ itself, the
<div n="lb"/>emphasis being on the blood-relationship.<sup>1</sup> So it appears in
<div n="lb"/>a passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> where ‘brotherless sisters’
[Page1-285+ 39]
<div n="lb"/>({%abhrātara iva jāmayaḥ%}) are referred to. The word is similarly
<div n="lb"/>used in the dispute occurring in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> as to
<div n="lb"/>the precedence of Rākā, or of the wives of the gods, in a certain
<div n="lb"/>rite. One party is there described as holding that the sister
<div n="lb"/>should be preferred ({%jāmyai vai pūrva-peyam%}) — apparently at a
<div n="lb"/>ceremonial family meal — to the wife, presumably as being of
<div n="lb"/>one blood with the husband, while the wife is not (being {%anyo-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%daryā,%} ‘of another womb’).<sup>4</sup> In the neuter<sup>5</sup> the word means
<div n="lb"/>‘relationship,’ like {%jāmi-tva,%} which also occurs in the Rigveda.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) {%Cf.%} Delbrück, {%Dic indogermanischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Verwandtschaftsnamen,%} 463, 464. As ‘rela-
<div n="lb"/>tion,’ it occurs, {%e.g.,%} Rv. i. 31, 10;
<div n="lb"/>75, 3. 4; 100, 11; 124, 6, etc.; as
<div n="lb"/>‘sister,’ Rv. i. 65, 7; x. 10, 10, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>with {%svasā,%} i. 123, 5; 185, 5; iii. 1, 11;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 65, 1; 89, 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) i. 17, 1.</F>
<F>3) iii. 37.</F>
<F>4) Delbrück, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>5) Rv. iii. 54, 9; x. 10, 4; {%jāmi-kṛt,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘making relationship,’ Av. iv. 19, 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Altareya Brāhmaṇa, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>6) i. 105, 9; 166, 13; x. 55, 4; 64, 13.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1056<pc>1-285<k1>jAyA<k2>jAyA
{@Jāyā@}¦ regularly denotes ‘wife,’ and, as opposed to {@Patnī,@} wife
<div n="lb"/>as an object of marital affection, the source of the continuance
[Page1-286+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>of the race.<sup>1</sup> So it is used of the wife of the gambler, and of
<div n="lb"/>the wife of the Brāhmaṇa in the Rigveda;<sup>2</sup> it is also frequently
<div n="lb"/>combined with {@Pati,@} ‘husband,’<sup>3</sup> both there and in the later
<div n="lb"/>literature.<sup>4</sup> Patnī, on the other hand, is used to denote the
<div n="lb"/>wife as partner in the sacrifice;<sup>5</sup> when no share in it is assigned
<div n="lb"/>to her, she is called Jāyā.<sup>6</sup> The distinction is, of course,
<div n="lb"/>merely relative; hence one text<sup>7</sup> calls Manu's wife Jāyā,
<div n="lb"/>another<sup>8</sup> Patnī. Later on Jāyā is superseded by Dāra.
<F>1) Delbrück, {%Die indogermanischen Ver-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%wandtschaftsnamen,%} 411, 412. {%Cf.%} Rv.
<div n="lb"/>i. 105, 2; 124, 7; iii. 53, 4; iv. 3, 2;
<div n="lb"/>18, 3; ix. 82, 4; x. 10, 7; 17, 1; 71, 4,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Av. iii. 30, 2; vi. 60, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) x. 34, 2. 3. 13, and x. 109.</F>
<F>3) Rv. iv. 3, 2; x. 149, 4.</F>
<F>4) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 23, 1. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>vii. 13, 10; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iv. 6, 7, 9. {%Cf.%} Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>i. 6, 12.</F>
<F>5) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 9, 2, 14.</F>
<F>6) i. 1, 4, 13.</F>
<F>7) {%Ibid.,%} i. 1, 4, 16.</F>
<F>8) Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 8, 1.</F>

<L>1083<pc>1-291<k1>jyA<k2>jyA
{@Jyā@}¦ is the regular word for ‘bowstring’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later.<sup>2</sup> The making of bowstrings was a special craft, as
<div n="lb"/>is shown by the occurrence of the Jyā-kāra, or ‘maker of bow-
<div n="lb"/>strings,’ among the victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice, in the Yajurveda.<sup>3</sup> The bowstring consisted of a
<div n="lb"/>thong of ox-hide.<sup>4</sup> It was not usually kept taut,<sup>5</sup> but was
<div n="lb"/>specially tightened when the bow was to be used.<sup>6</sup> The sound
<div n="lb"/>of the bowstring ({%jyā-ghoṣa%}) is referred to in the Atharvaveda.<sup>7</sup>

<L>1091<pc>1-293<k1>jyotiza<k2>jyotiza

<div n="lb"/>has frequently been discussed since.<sup>2</sup> Its date is unknown, but

<L>1095<pc>1-294<k1>takman<k2>takman
{@Takman@}¦ is a disease repeatedly mentioned in the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda, but later not known under this name. It is the subject
<div n="lb"/>of five hymns<sup>1</sup> of the Atharvaveda, and is often mentioned else-
<div n="lb"/>where.<sup>2</sup> Weber<sup>3</sup> first identified it with ‘fever,’ and Grohmann<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>showed that all the symptoms pointed to that ailment.<sup>5</sup> Refer-
<div n="lb"/>ence is made to the alternate hot and shivering fits of the
<div n="lb"/>patient,<sup>6</sup> to the yellow colour of the jaundice which accompanies
<div n="lb"/>the fever,<sup>7</sup> and to its peculiar periodicity. The words used to
<div n="lb"/>describe its varieties are {%anye-dyuḥ,%}<sup>8</sup> {%ubhaya-dyuḥ,%}<sup>9</sup> {%tṛtīyaka,%}<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{%vi-tṛtīya,%}<sup>11</sup> and {%sadaṃ-di,%}<sup>12</sup> the exact sense of most of which
<div n="lb"/>terms is somewhat uncertain. It is agreed<sup>13</sup> that the first
<div n="lb"/>epithet designates the fever known as {%quotidianus,%} which recurs
<div n="lb"/>each day at the same hour, though the word is curious (lit.
[Page1-295+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>‘on the other — {%i.e.,%} next, day’). The {%ubhaya-dyuḥ%} (‘on both
<div n="lb"/>days’) variety appears to mean a disease recurring for two suc-
<div n="lb"/>cessive days, the third being free; this corresponds to the {%rhythmus%}
<div n="lb"/>{%quartanus complicatus.%}<sup>14</sup> But Sāyaṇa considers that it means a
<div n="lb"/>fever recurring on the third day, the ‘tertian.’ The {%tṛtīyaka,%}
<div n="lb"/>however, must be the ‘tertian’ fever,<sup>15</sup> though Zimmer<sup>16</sup> suggests
<div n="lb"/>that it may mean a fever which is fatal at the third paroxysm.
<div n="lb"/>Grohmann<sup>17</sup> regards the {%vi-tṛtīyaka%} as equivalent to the {%tertiana%}
<div n="lb"/>{%duplicata,%} a common form in southern countries, in which the
<div n="lb"/>fever occurs daily, but with a correspondence in point of time
<div n="lb"/>or severity of attack on alternate days. Bloomfield<sup>18</sup> suggests
<div n="lb"/>that it is identical with the {%ubhaya-dyuḥ%} variety. The {%sadaṃ-di%}<sup>19</sup>
<div n="lb"/>type appears to be the kind later known as {%saṃtata-jvara%}
<div n="lb"/>(‘continuous fever’), in which there are attacks of several days’
<div n="lb"/>duration, with an interval followed by a fresh period of attack.
<div n="lb"/>Fever occurred at different seasons, in the autumn ({%śārada%}), in
<div n="lb"/>the hot weather ({%graiṣma%}), in the rains ({%vārṣika%}),<sup>20</sup> but was
<div n="lb"/>especially prevalent in the first, as is indicated by the epithet
<div n="lb"/>{%viśva-śārada,%} ‘occurring every autumn.’<sup>21</sup>
<div n="P"/>The disease is said to arise when Agni enters the waters.<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>From this Weber<sup>23</sup> deduced that it was considered to be the
<div n="lb"/>result of a chill supervening on heat, or the influence of heat on
<div n="lb"/>marshy land. Grohmann<sup>24</sup> preferred to see in this connexion
<div n="lb"/>of the origin of the disease with Agni's entering the waters<sup>25</sup>
<div n="lb"/>an allusion to the fact that fever arises in the rainy season, the
<div n="lb"/>time when Agni, as lightning, descends to earth with the rain.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer.<sup>26</sup> who accepts this view, further refers to the prevalence
[Page1-296+ 41]
<div n="lb"/>of fever in the Terai, and interprets {%vanya,%} an epithet of fever
<div n="lb"/>found in the Atharvaveda,<sup>27</sup> as meaning ‘sprung from the
<div n="lb"/>forest,’ pointing out that fever is mentioned as prevalent among
<div n="lb"/>the {@Mūjavants@} and {@Mahāvṛṣas,@} two mountain tribes of the
<div n="lb"/>western Himālaya.<sup>28</sup> There is no trace of fever having been
<div n="lb"/>observed to be caused by the bite of the {%anopheles%} mosquito,
<div n="lb"/>which breeds in stagnant water: this theory has without reason
<div n="lb"/>been held to be known to classical Indian medicine.<sup>29</sup>
<div n="P"/>Among the symptoms of Takman, or among complications
<div n="lb"/>accompanying it, are mentioned ‘itch’ ({@Pāman@}), ‘headache’
<div n="lb"/>({%śīrṣa-śoka%}),<sup>30</sup> ‘cough’ ({@Kāsikā@}), and ‘consumption,’ or perhaps
<div n="lb"/>some form of itch ({@Balāsa@}).
<div n="P"/>It is perhaps significant that the Takman does not appear
<div n="lb"/>until the Atharvaveda. It is quite possible that the Vedic
<div n="lb"/>Āryans, when first settled in India, did not know the disease,
<div n="lb"/>which would take some generations to become endemic and
<div n="lb"/>recognized as dangerous. What remedies they used against it
<div n="lb"/>is quite uncertain, for the Atharvaveda mentions only spells
<div n="lb"/>and the {@Kuṣṭha,@} which can hardly have been an effective
<div n="lb"/>remedy, though still used in later times. Fever must, even in
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvan period, have claimed many victims, or it would
<div n="lb"/>not be mentioned so prominently.
<F>1) i. 25; v. 22; vi. 20; vii. 116;
<div n="lb"/>xix. 39 ({%cf.%} v. 4).</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 9, 8; v. 4. 1. 9; 30, 16;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 8, 6; xi. 2, 22. 26, etc.</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Studien,%} 4, 119; Roth, {%Zur%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Litteratur und Geschishte des Weda,%} 39,
<div n="lb"/>had, from the use of Kuṣṭha as a
<div n="lb"/>remedy, regarded it as denoting
<div n="lb"/>‘leprosy,’ and was followed by Pictet,
<div n="lb"/>Kuhn's {%Zeitschrift%} 5, 337. Muir, {%Sanskrit%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Texts,%} 4, 280, thought ‘consumption’
<div n="lb"/>was meant.</F>
<F>4) {%Indische Studien,%} 9, 381 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) See also Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Atharvaveda,%} 451 {%et seq.;%} Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%disches Leben,%} 379-385, and compare the
<div n="lb"/>{%jvara%} (a non-Vedic word) of the classical
<div n="lb"/>medicine, Wise, {%Hindu System of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Medicine,%} 219 {%et seq.;%} Jolly, {%Medicin,%}
<div n="lb"/>70-72. Dārila and Keśava, the com-
<div n="lb"/>mentators on the Kauśika Sūtra, every-
<div n="lb"/>where equate {%takman%} and {%jvara.%}</F>
<F>6) Av. i. 25, 2-4; v. 22, 2. 7. 10;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 20, 3; vii. 116, 1.</F>
<F>7) Av. i. 25, 2; v. 22, 2; vi. 20, 3.</F>
<F>8) Av. i. 25, 4; vii. 116, 2.</F>
<F>9) {%Ibid.%}</F>
<F>10) Av. i. 25, 4; v. 22, 13; xix. 39,
<div n="lb"/>10.</F>
<F>11) Av. v. 22, 13.</F>
<F>12) Av. v. 22, 13; xix. 39, 10.</F>
<F>13) Grohmann, {%op. cit.,%} 387; Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%op. cit.,%} 382; Bloomfield, {%op. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>274.</F>
<F>14) Grohmann, 388; Zimmer, 382;
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield, 274. It may conceivably
<div n="lb"/>be the form styled Cāturthaka Vipar-
<div n="lb"/>yaya (Wise, {%op. cit.,%} 232), in which the
<div n="lb"/>paroxysm occurs every fourth day,
<div n="lb"/>and lasts for two days.</F>
<F>15) Sāyaṇa on Av. i. 25, 4; Bloom-
<div n="lb"/>field, 451. It is the {%jvara tṛtīyaka%} of
<div n="lb"/>Suśruta (2, 404, 7).</F>

<L>1098<pc>1-297<k1>takzan<k2>takzan<h>1
1. {@Takṣan,@}¦ ‘carpenter,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>often later.<sup>2</sup> He was employed to do all sorts of work in
<div n="lb"/>wood, such as the making of chariots ({@Ratha@}) and wagons
<div n="lb"/>({@Anas@}). Carved work of a finer type seems also to have fallen
<div n="lb"/>to his lot.<sup>3</sup> The axe ({%kuliśa,%}<sup>4</sup> {%paraśu%})<sup>5</sup> is mentioned as one of
<div n="lb"/>his tools, and perhaps the {@Bhurij,@} a word which is, however,
<div n="lb"/>uncertain in sense. In one passage of the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> reference
<div n="lb"/>seems to be made to the pains of the carpenter in bending
<div n="lb"/>over his work. That the carpenters were a low caste, or
<div n="lb"/>formed a separate class of the people, is certainly not true of
<div n="lb"/>Vedic times.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) ix. 112, 1.</F>
<F>2) Av. x. 6, 3; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xii. 10; xviii. 13; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 9, 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;
<div n="lb"/>xxx. 6; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>2, 1; Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 3, 12;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 6, 4, 4, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 86, 5; Av. xix. 49, 8. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Rv. i. 161, 9; iii. 60. 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iii. 2, 1.</F>
<F>5) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xii. 10.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 105, 18. {%Cf.%} Roth, {%Nirukta,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Erläuterungen,%} 67; Oldenberg. {%Ṛgveda-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Noten,%} 1, 100.</F>
<F>7) Fick, {%Die sociale Gliederung,%} 210,
<div n="lb"/>n. 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 245,
<div n="lb"/>253.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1106<pc>1-298<k1>tantu<k2>tantu
{@Tantu@}¦ appears properly to mean ‘thread,’ and in particular
<div n="lb"/>the ‘warp’ of a piece of weaving, as opposed to {@Otu,@} the ‘woof.’
<div n="lb"/>Both senses are found in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> In the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> the ‘warp’ is called {%anuchāda,%} the ‘woof’ {%paryāsa,%}
<div n="lb"/>the {%tantavaḥ%} being the ‘threads.’ In the Taittirīya Saṃhitā,<sup>3</sup>
[Page1-299+ 38]
<div n="lb"/>on the other hand, the ‘warp’ is {%prācīna-tāna,%} the ‘woof’ {%otu.%}
<div n="lb"/>The threads or cords of the throne ({@Pary ṅka@}) are referred to
<div n="lb"/>in the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Rigveda the word is used only metaphorically, and
<div n="lb"/>this is its most frequent use even in the Brāhmanas.<sup>5</sup> See
<div n="lb"/>also {@Vāṇa.@}
<F>1) xiv. 2, 51 (opposed to {%otu%}); xv. 3, 6
<div n="lb"/>(the {%prāñcaḥ%} and {%tiryañcaḥ%} threads or
<div n="lb"/>cords of the throne of the Vrātya
<div n="lb"/>[{@Āsandī@}]).</F>
<F>2) iii. 1, 2, 18; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the East,%} 26, 8, 9.</F>
<F>3) vi. 1, 1, 4.</F>
<F>4) i. 5; Keith, {%Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka,%}
<div n="lb"/>20, n. 2.</F>
<F>5) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} It
<div n="lb"/>is applied to the filaments of plants in
<div n="lb"/>Rv. x. 134, 5; to the spider's web in
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upanisad. ii. 1, 23.</F>

<L>1124<pc>1-302<k1>taskara<k2>taskara
{@Taskara@}¦ occurs in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and frequently later,<sup>2</sup> denoting
<div n="lb"/>‘thief’ or ‘robber.’ It appears to be practically synonymous
<div n="lb"/>with {@Stena,@} in connexion with which it is often mentioned.<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The Stena and the Taskara are contrasted in the Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup> with the {@Malimlu,@} who is a burglar or house-breaker,
<div n="lb"/>while they are highwaymen, or, as the Rigveda<sup>5</sup> puts it, ‘men
<div n="lb"/>who haunt the woods and risk their lives’ ({%tanū-tyajā vanar-gū%}).
<div n="lb"/>In another passage of the Rigveda,<sup>6</sup> however, the dog is told to
<div n="lb"/>bark at the Taskara or the Stena, which clearly points to an
<div n="lb"/>attempt at house-breaking. The thief goes about at night,<sup>7</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>knows the paths<sup>8</sup> on which he attacks his victim. In one
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Rigveda<sup>9</sup> the use of cords is mentioned, but
<div n="lb"/>whether to bind the thieves when captured, or to bind the
[Page1-303+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>victim, is not clear.<sup>10</sup> The Atharvaveda<sup>11</sup> refers to the Stena
<div n="lb"/>and the Taskara as cattle and horse thieves.<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) i. 191, 5; vi. 27, 3; vii. 55, 3;

<L>1125<pc>1-303<k1>tAyu<k2>tAyu
{@Tāyu@}¦ was another name for thief, perhaps of a less
<div n="lb"/>distinguished and more domestic character than the highway-
<div n="lb"/>man, for though he is referred to as a cattle-thief,<sup>13</sup> he is also
<div n="lb"/>alluded to as a stealer of clothes ({%vastra-mathi%})<sup>14</sup> and as a
<div n="lb"/>debtor.<sup>15</sup> In one passage the Tāyus are said to disappear at
<div n="lb"/>the coming of dawn (which is elsewhere called {%yāvayad-dveṣas,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘driving away hostile beings,’ and {%ṛta-pā,%} ‘guardian of order’),
<div n="lb"/>like the stars of heaven ({%nakṣatra%}).<sup>16</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Śatarudriya litany of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>17</sup> Rudra
<div n="lb"/>is called lord of assailers ({%ā-vyādhin%}), thieves ({%stena%}), robbers
<div n="lb"/>({%taskara%}), pickpockets ({%stāyu%}), stealers ({%muṣṇant%}), and cutters
<div n="lb"/>({%vi-kṛnta%}); and designations of sharpers ({%gṛtsa%}) and bands
<div n="lb"/>({%gaṇa, vrāta%}), apparently of robbers, are mentioned.<sup>18</sup> It is
<div n="lb"/>therefore not surprising that the Rigveda<sup>19</sup> should contain
<div n="lb"/>many prayers for safety at home or on the way, or that
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda should devote several hymns to night<sup>20</sup>
<div n="lb"/>chiefly for protection against the evil doings of thieves and
<div n="lb"/>robbers.
<div n="P"/>Pischel<sup>21</sup> suggests that in one passage of the Rigveda<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{@Vasiṣṭha@} is represented as a burglar, but the admits that, since
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭha was attacking the house of his father Varuṇa, he was
<div n="lb"/>only seeking to obtain what he may have regarded as his own.
<div n="lb"/>But the interpretation of the hymn is not certain.<sup>23</sup>
<div n="P"/>Sāyaṇa's explanation of one passage of the Rigveda,<sup>24</sup> as
[Page1-304+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>referring to professional cattle-trackers, like the Khojis of the
<div n="lb"/>Panjab, seems quite probable.<sup>25</sup>
<div n="P"/>The punishment of thieves appears primarily to have been
<div n="lb"/>left to the action of the robbed. The practice of binding them
<div n="lb"/>in stocks<sup>26</sup> seems clearly referred to. But later, at any rate — 
<div n="lb"/>and in all probability earlier also, as in other countries — a more
<div n="lb"/>severe penalty could be exacted, and death inflicted by the
<div n="lb"/>king.<sup>27</sup> There is no hint in Vedic literature of the mode of
<div n="lb"/>conviction; a fire ordeal is not known to the Atharvaveda,<sup>28</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the ordeal known to the Chāndogya Upaniṣad<sup>29</sup> is not said
<div n="lb"/>to be used in the case of theft. No doubt the stolen property
<div n="lb"/>was recovered by the person robbed if he could obtain it.
<div n="lb"/>Nothing is known as to what happened if the property had
<div n="lb"/>passed from the actual thief into the possession of another
<div n="lb"/>person.
<F>13) Rv. i. 65, 1; vii. 86, 5.</F>
<F>14) Rv. iv. 38, 5.</F>
<F>15) Rv. vi. 12, 5. No doubt this theft
<div n="lb"/>is the result of despair at being in debt,
<div n="lb"/>which might lead to loss of liberty (Ṛṇa).</F>
<F>16) Rv. i. 50, 2. {%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Mythology,%} p. 47.</F>
<F>17) xvi. 20, 21. {%Cf.%} Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iv. 5, 4, 1; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 4.</F>
<F>18) xvi. 25.</F>
<F>19) i. 129, 9; ii. 23, 16; vi. 24, 10;
<div n="lb"/>41, 5; 51, 15; x. 63, 16.</F>

<div n="lb"/>trast 1, 106.</F>

<div n="lb"/>337 {%et seq.;%} Lanman, {%Sanskrit Reader,%}

<div n="lb"/>Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 11 {%et seq.,%} with Mac-

<L>1134<pc>1-306<k1>tAnva<k2>tAnva<h>1

<L>1144<pc>1-308<k1>tArpya<k2>tArpya

<div n="lb"/>of the word is ‘silken garment,’ which Eggeling<sup>5</sup> is inclined
<div n="lb"/>to accept.^6

<L>1147<pc>1-309<k1>tittira<k2>tittira
{@Tittira, Tittiri,@}¦ is the name of the partridge in the later
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās<sup>1</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>2</sup> being presumably an onomato-
<div n="lb"/>poetic formation. The bird is described as having variegated
<div n="lb"/>plumage ({%bahu-rūpa%}). It is usually associated with the {@Kapiñ-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@jala@} and {@Kalaviṅka.@}
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>v. 5, 16, 1; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xii. 10; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30, 36. The form Tittira
<div n="lb"/>occurs in the Maitrāyaṇī Samhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 14, 1.</F>
<F>2) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 3, 5;
<div n="lb"/>v. 5, 4, 6; Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 154, 6 (Oertel, {%Transactions of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,%}
<div n="lb"/>15, 181).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 91;
<div n="lb"/>Schrader, {%Prehistoric Antiquities,%} 251.</F>
