<L>1154<pc>1-310<k1>tirindira<k2>tirindira
{@Tirindira@}¦ is mentioned in a Dānastuti, or ‘Praise of Gifts,’
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as having, along with {@Parśu,@} bestowed gifts
<div n="lb"/>on the singer. In the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>2</sup> this state-
<div n="lb"/>ment is represented by a tale that the Kaṇva Vatsa obtained
<div n="lb"/>a gift from Tirindira Pāraśavya, Tirindira and Parśu being
<div n="lb"/>in this version thus treated as one and the same man.
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig<sup>3</sup> sees in the Rigvedic passage a proof that the Yadus
<div n="lb"/>had gained a victory over Tirindira, and gave a part of the
<div n="lb"/>booty to the singers; but there is no proof whatever of the
<div n="lb"/>correctness of this interpretation, which Zimmer<sup>4</sup> shows to be
<div n="lb"/>most unlikely. Yadu princes must be meant by Tirindira and
[Page1-311+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>Parśu, though Weber<sup>5</sup> thinks that the singers were Yadus, not
<div n="lb"/>the princes. The latter he holds to have been Iranian ({%cf.%}
<lang n="greek"></lang>, and see {@Parśu@}), and he thinks that in this there is
<div n="lb"/>evidence of continual close relations between India and Iran.
<div n="lb"/>This is perfectly possible, but the evidence for it is rather
<div n="lb"/>slight.
<div n="P"/>6 For the recent controversy as to
<div n="lb"/>Iranian names found at Boghaz-kiöi,
<div n="lb"/>{%cf.%} Jacobi, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1909, 721 {%et seq.;%} Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%ibid.,%} 1095-1100; Keith, {%ibid.,%} 1100-1106;
<div n="lb"/>Sayce, {%ibid.,%} 1106, 1107; Kennedy,
<div n="lb"/>{%ibid.,%} 1107-1119. Hillebrandt, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Mythologie,%} 1, 94 {%et seq.,%} argues in favour
<div n="lb"/>of an early connexion of Iranians and
<div n="lb"/>Indians in Arachosia, where he places
<div n="lb"/>part of the action of the Rigveda.
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 17, 16, 277, holds that traces of
<div n="lb"/>Iranian connexion are signs of late
<div n="lb"/>date; Arnold, {%ibid.,%} 18, 205 {%et seq.,%}
<div n="lb"/>opposes this view.
<F>1) viii. 6, 46-48.</F>
<F>2) xvi. 11. 20.</F>
<F>3) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 160,
<div n="lb"/>161; 5, 142.</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 136, 137.</F>
<F>5) {%Indische Studien,%} 4, 356, n.; {%Indian%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Literature,%} 3, 4; {%Episches im vedischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Ritual,%} 37, 38.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1158<pc>1-312<k1>tila<k2>tila

<div n="lb"/>porridge ({%tilaudana%}<sup>7</sup>) for food.

<L>1167<pc>1-314<k1>turakAvazeya<k2>turakAvazeya
{@Tura Kāvaṣeya@}¦ is mentioned in the Vaṃśa (list of teachers)
<div n="lb"/>at the end of the tenth book of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>the source of the doctrine set forth in that book, and as
<div n="lb"/>separated, in the succession of teachers, from {@Śāṇḍilya@} by
<div n="lb"/>{@Yajñavacas@} and {@Kuśri.@} In the same Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> he is quoted
<div n="lb"/>by Śāṇḍilya as having erected a fire-altar on the {@Kārotī.@} In
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> he appears as a Purohita, or ‘domestic
<div n="lb"/>priest,’ of {@Janamejaya Pārikṣita,@} whom he consecrated king.
<div n="lb"/>In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>4</sup> and a Khila<sup>5</sup> he appears as
<div n="lb"/>an ancient sage. Oldenberg,<sup>6</sup> no doubt rightly, assigns him
<div n="lb"/>to the end of the Vedic period. He is probably<sup>7</sup> identical with
<div n="lb"/>Tura, the {%deva-muni,%} ‘saint of the gods,’ who is mentioned in
<div n="lb"/>the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) x. 6, 5, 9.</F>
<F>2) ix. 5, 2, 15.</F>
<F>3) iv. 27; vii. 34; viii. 21.</F>
<F>4) vi. 5, 4 (Kāṇva, not in Mādhyaṃ-
<div n="lb"/>dina).</F>
<F>5) i. 9, 6; Scheftelowitz, {%Die Apokryphen%}

<L>1170<pc>1-314<k1>turva<k2>turva
{@Turva@}¦ occurs only once in the Rigveda (x. 62, 10), doubtless
<div n="lb"/>as a name of the {@Turvaśa@} people or king.
<LEND>
[Page1-315+ 55]

<L>1171<pc>1-315<k1>turvaSa<k2>turvaSa
{@Turvaśa@}¦ occurs frequently in the Rigveda as the name of
<div n="lb"/>a man or of a people, usually in connexion with {@Yadu.@} The
<div n="lb"/>two words usually occur in the singular without any connecting
<div n="lb"/>particle, {%Turvaśa Yadu%} or {%Yadu Turvaśa.%}<sup>2</sup> In a plural form
<div n="lb"/>the name Turvaśa occurs once with the Yadus,<sup>3</sup> and once
<div n="lb"/>alone<sup>4</sup> in a hymn in which the singular has already been used.
<div n="lb"/>In one passage<sup>5</sup> the dual {%Turvaśā-Yadū%} actually occurs, and
<div n="lb"/>in another<sup>6</sup> {%Yadus Turvaś ca,%} ‘Yadu and Turva.’ In other
<div n="lb"/>passages<sup>7</sup> Turvaśa appears alone, while in one<sup>8</sup> Turvaśa and
<div n="lb"/>Yādva occur.
<div n="P"/>From these facts Hopkins<sup>9</sup> deduces the erroneousness of the
<div n="lb"/>ordinary view,<sup>10</sup> according to which Turvaśa is the name of
<div n="lb"/>a tribe, the singular denoting the king, and regards Turvaśa
<div n="lb"/>as the name of the Yadu king. But the evidence for this is
<div n="lb"/>not conclusive. Without laying any stress on the argument
<div n="lb"/>based on the theory<sup>11</sup> that the ‘five peoples’ of the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>are the {@Anus, Druhyus,@} Turvaśas, Yadus, and {@Pūrus,@} it is
<div n="lb"/>perfectly reasonable to hold that the Turvaśas and Yadus were
<div n="lb"/>two distinct though closely allied tribes. Such they evidently
<div n="lb"/>were to the seers of the hymns which mention in the dual the
<div n="lb"/>{%Turvaśā-Yadū%} and speak of {%Yadus Turvaś ca.%} This explanation
<div n="lb"/>also suits best the use of the plural of Turvaśa in two Rigvedic
<div n="lb"/>hymns.
<div n="P"/>In the Rigveda the chief exploit of Turvaśa was his partici-
<div n="lb"/>pation in the war against {@Sudās,@} by whom he was defeated.<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins<sup>13</sup> suggests that he may have been named Turvaśa
<div n="lb"/>because of his fleet ({%tura%}) escape from the battle. His escape
<div n="P"/>1 i. 36, 18; 54, 6; 174, 9; vi. 20,
<div n="lb"/>12; 45, 1; viii. 4, 7; 7, 18; 9, 14;
<div n="lb"/>45, 27; x. 49, 8. In vii. 18, 6, Turvaśa
<div n="lb"/>is joined with Yakṣu, apparently a con-
<div n="lb"/>temptuous variant of Yadu (Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>15, 261). {%Cf.%} {@Tṛtsu.@}
[Page1-316+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>may have been assisted by Indra, for in some passages<sup>14</sup> Indra's
<div n="lb"/>aid to Turvaśa (and) Yadu is referred to; it is also significant
<div n="lb"/>that the Anu, and apparently the Druhyu, kings are mentioned
<div n="lb"/>as having been drowned in the defeat, but not the Turvaśa
<div n="lb"/>and Yadu kings, and that Turvaśa appears in the eighth book
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda as a worshipper of Indra with the Anu prince,
<div n="lb"/>the successor, presumably, of the one who was drowned.<sup>15</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Griffith,<sup>16</sup> however, proposes to refer these passages to a defeat
<div n="lb"/>by Turvaśa and Yadu of Arṇa and Citraratha on the {@Sarayu;@}<sup>17</sup>
<div n="lb"/>but the evidence for this is quite inadequate.
<div n="P"/>Two passages of the Rigveda<sup>18</sup> seem to refer to an attack by
<div n="lb"/>Turvaśa and Yadu on {@Divodāsa,@} the father of Sudās. It is
<div n="lb"/>reasonable to suppose that this was an attack of the two
<div n="lb"/>peoples on Divodāsa, for there is some improbability of the
<div n="lb"/>references being to the Turvaśa, who was concerned in the
<div n="lb"/>attack on Sudās, the son.
<div n="P"/>Zimmer<sup>19</sup> considers that the Turvaśas were also called {@Vṛcī-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@vants.@} This view is based on a hymn<sup>20</sup> in which reference
<div n="lb"/>is made to the defeat of the Vṛcīvants on the {@Yavyāvatī@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Hariyūpīyā@} in aid of Daivarāta, and of Turvaśa in aid of
<div n="lb"/>{@Sṛñjaya,@} the latter being elsewhere<sup>21</sup> clearly the son of Deva-
<div n="lb"/>rāta. But as this evidence for the identification of the Turvaśas
<div n="lb"/>with the Vṛcīvants is not clear, it seems sufficient<sup>22</sup> to assume
<div n="lb"/>that they were allies.
<div n="P"/>Later, in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>23</sup> the Turvaśas appear
<div n="lb"/>as allies of the Pañcālas, Taurvaśa horses, thirty-three in
<div n="lb"/>number, and armed men, to the number of 6,000, being
<div n="lb"/>mentioned.<sup>24</sup> But otherwise the name disappears: this lends
[Page1-317+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>probability to Oldenberge's conjecture<sup>25</sup> that the Turvaśas
<div n="lb"/>became merged in the {@Pañcāla@} people. Hopkins<sup>26</sup> considers
<div n="lb"/>that in the Śatapatha passage the horses were merely named
<div n="lb"/>from the family of Turvaśa; but this view is less likely, since
<div n="lb"/>it ignores the difficulty involved in the reference to the men.
<div n="P"/>It is impossible to be certain regarding the home of the
<div n="lb"/>Turvaśas at the time of their conflict with Sudās. They
<div n="lb"/>apparently crossed the {@Paruṣṇī,@}<sup>27</sup> but from which side is dis-
<div n="lb"/>puted. The view of Pischel<sup>28</sup> and Geldner,<sup>29</sup> that they advanced
<div n="lb"/>from the west towards the east, where the {@Bharatas@} were (see
<div n="lb"/>{@Kuru@}), is the more probable.
<F>2) v. 31, 8.</F>
<F>3) i. 108, 8.</F>
<F>4) viii. 4, 18; singular with Ānava in
<div n="lb"/>viii. 4, 1.</F>
<F>5) iv. 30, 17.</F>
<F>6) x. 62, 10. {%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda, 3, 166; Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gesellschaft,%} 42, 220, n. 1.</F>
<F>7) i. 4, 77; vi. 27, 7. {%Cf.%} viii. 4, 1.</F>
<F>8) vii. 19, 8.</F>
<F>9) {%Op. cit.,%} 258 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>10) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 122,
<div n="lb"/>124; Oldenberg, {%Buddha,%} 404; Ludwig,
<div n="lb"/>{%op. cit.,%} 153; Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 64; {%Sanskrit Literature,%} 153 {%et seq.,%}
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>11) Zimmer, 122, 124; Macdonell,
<div n="lb"/>153, 154.</F>

<div n="lb"/>he appears as Atithigva).</F>

<F>21) iv. 15, 4.</F>

<div n="lb"/>obscure.</F>

<div n="lb"/>Ludwig for {%tūrvath%} hey are connected

<L>1172<pc>1-317<k1>turvIti<k2>turvIti

<L>1173<pc>1-317<k1>tulA<k2>tulA
{@Tulā,@}¦ ‘scales,’ is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> also speaks of the balance in con-
<div n="lb"/>nexion with the weighing of a man's good and evil deeds in
<div n="lb"/>the next and in this world. This differs very considerably
<div n="lb"/>from the later balance<sup>3</sup> ordeal, in which a man was weighed
<div n="lb"/>twice, and was pronounced guilty or innocent according as, on
<div n="lb"/>the second occasion, he was more or less heavy than on the
[Page1-318+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>first. It is not possible to read the later practice into the
<div n="lb"/>earlier.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) xxx. 17.</F>
<F>2) xi. 2, 7, 33.</F>
<F>3) Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte,%} 145.</F>
<F>4) Weber, {%Indische Streifen,%} 1, 21;
<div n="lb"/>2, 363, quotes Schlagintweit as giving
<div n="lb"/>this passage as an example of the
<div n="lb"/>balance ordeal. {%Cf.%} Eggeling, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 44, 45, n. 4.</F>

<L>1180<pc>1-319<k1>tUrvayARa<k2>tUrvayARa

<div n="lb"/>identical with {@Suśravas.@}<sup>5</sup>

<L>1187<pc>1-320<k1>tftsu<k2>tftsu
{@Tṛtsu@}¦ occurs in the Rigveda, once in the singular<sup>1</sup> and several
<div n="lb"/>times in the plural,<sup>2</sup> as a proper name. The Tṛtsus were
<div n="lb"/>clearly helpers of {@Sudās@} in the great battle against the ten
<div n="lb"/>kings, {@Śimyu,@} the {@Turvaśa,@} the {@Druhyu, Kavaṣa,@} the {@Pūru,@}
<div n="lb"/>the {@Anu, Bheda, Śambara,@} the two {@Vaikarṇas,@} and perhaps
<div n="lb"/>the {@Yadu,@} who led with them as allies<sup>3</sup> the {@Matsyas, Pakthas,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Bhalānas, Alinas, Viṣāṇins, Śivas, Ajas, Śigrus,@} and perhaps
<div n="lb"/>Yakṣus.<sup>4</sup> The defeat of the ten kings is celebrated in one
[Page1-321+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> and is evidently alluded to in two
<div n="lb"/>others.<sup>6</sup> The great battle took place on the {@Paruṣṇī,@} but there
<div n="lb"/>was also a fight on the {@Yamunā@} with Bheda, the Ajas, Śigrus,
<div n="lb"/>and Yakṣus. As the Yamunā and the Parusṇī represent
<div n="lb"/>opposite ends of the territory of the Tṛtsus (for we cannot
<div n="lb"/>with Hopkins<sup>7</sup> safely identify the streams), it is difficult to see
<div n="lb"/>exactly how the ten kings could be confederated, but it should
<div n="lb"/>be noted that the references to the ten kings occur in the two
<div n="lb"/>later hymns,<sup>6</sup> and not in the hymn<sup>5</sup> describing the battle itself;
<div n="lb"/>besides, absolute numerical accuracy cannot be insisted upon.
<div n="P"/>It is difficult exactly to determine the character of the
<div n="lb"/>Tṛtsus; especially in their relation to the Bharatas, who under
<div n="lb"/>Viśvāmitra's guidance are represented as prospering and as
<div n="lb"/>advancing to the {@Vipāś@} and {@Śutudrī.@}<sup>8</sup> Roth ingeniously
<div n="lb"/>brought this into connexion with the defeat of his enemies
<div n="lb"/>by Sudās, which is celebrated in the seventh book of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda — a book attributed to the Vasiṣṭha family — and thought
<div n="lb"/>that there was a reference in one verse<sup>9</sup> to the defeat of the
<div n="lb"/>Bharatas by Sudās. But it seems certain that the verse is
<div n="lb"/>mistranslated, and that the Bharatas are really represented as
<div n="lb"/>victors with Sudās.<sup>10</sup> Ludwig<sup>11</sup> accordingly identifies the
<div n="lb"/>Tṛtsus and the Bharatas. Oldenberg,<sup>12</sup> after accepting this
<div n="lb"/>view at first,<sup>13</sup> later expressed the opinion that the Tṛtsus were
<div n="lb"/>the priests of the Bharata people, and therefore identical with
<div n="lb"/>the Vasiṣṭhas. This view is supported by the fact that in one
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>14</sup> the Tṛtsus are clearly described as wearing their
<div n="lb"/>hair in the peculiar manner affected by the Vasiṣṭhas,<sup>15</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>would in that passage thus seem to represent the Vasiṣṭhas.
[Page1-322+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>But Geldner<sup>16</sup> has suggested with great probability that Tṛtsu,
<div n="lb"/>who is once mentioned in the singular,<sup>17</sup> means the Tṛtsu
<div n="lb"/>king — that is, Sudās.<sup>18</sup> This explanation alone justifies the
<div n="lb"/>description<sup>19</sup> of the Bharatas as {%Tṛtsūnāṃ viśaḥ,%}<sup>20</sup> ‘subjects of
<div n="lb"/>the Tṛtsus,’ meaning the Tṛtsu Gotra or family, for the people
<div n="lb"/>could not be said to be subjects of a body of priests. The
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭhas might be called Tṛtsus because of their close con-
<div n="lb"/>nexion with the royal house of that people. The reverse
<div n="lb"/>process is also quite possible, but is rendered improbable by
<div n="lb"/>the fact that the {@Pratṛdaḥ@} are referred to as receiving Vasiṣṭha.<sup>21</sup>
<div n="lb"/>This name of the Tṛtsu dynasty is probably older than its
<div n="lb"/>connexion with Vasiṣṭha in the time of Sudās, a conclusion
<div n="lb"/>supported by the name of {@Pratardana,@} who is mentioned later
<div n="lb"/>as a descendant of Divodāsa,<sup>22</sup> an ancestor of Sudās. The
<div n="lb"/>Tṛtsu dynasty could therefore hardly have been referred to as
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭhas. For the further history of the dynasty and its
<div n="lb"/>relation with Vasiṣṭha and Viśvāmitra, see {@Sudās.@}
<div n="P"/>If the Tṛtsus and their subjects, the Bharatas, were in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigvedic period at war with the tribes on either side of the
<div n="lb"/>territory between the Paruṣṇī and the Yamunā, it is clear<sup>23</sup>
<div n="lb"/>that later on they coalesced with the Pūrus and probably
<div n="lb"/>others of those tribes to form the {@Kuru@} people. Already in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>24</sup> the Tṛtsus are allied with the {@Sṛñjayas,@} and in
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>25</sup> one Purohita serves both Kurus
<div n="lb"/>and Sṛñjayas.
[Page1-323+ 50]
<div n="P"/>Hillebrandt<sup>26</sup> considers that the Tṛtsus cannot be identified
<div n="lb"/>with the Bharatas, but that Sudās and the Bharatas represent
<div n="lb"/>an invading body, which, however, became allied with the
<div n="lb"/>Tṛtsus and the Vasiṣṭha priests. He also thinks that the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda reveals a time when {@Divodāsa,@} the grandfather or
<div n="lb"/>ancestor of Sudās, was living in Arachosia, on the {@Sarasvatī,@}
<div n="lb"/>and warring against the {@Paṇis,@} whom he identifies with the
<div n="lb"/>Parnians. But this conjecture<sup>27</sup> cannot be regarded as
<div n="lb"/>probable. In the Sarasvatī<sup>28</sup> it is not necessary to see any
<div n="lb"/>other river than the later Sarasvatī, in the middle country,
<div n="lb"/>which flowed within the boundaries of the Tṛtsus: it is also
<div n="lb"/>significant that there are references<sup>29</sup> to contests between
<div n="lb"/>{@Turvaśa Yadu@} and Atithigva or Divodāsa. Thus there is no
<div n="lb"/>reason to doubt that Divodāsa and the Bharatas were in the
<div n="lb"/>middle country, and not in Iran.
<F>1) vii. 18, 13.</F>
<F>2) vii. 18, 7. 15. 19; 33, 5. 6; 83, 4. 6. 8.</F>
<F>3) They were regarded as enemies of
<div n="lb"/>the kings by Roth, {%Zur Litteratur und%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Geschichte des Weda,%} 95, and by Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%op. cit.,%} 126, The latter, however,
<div n="lb"/>altered his view (see pp. 430, 431,
<div n="lb"/>which Hopkins, {%op. cit.,%} 260, has over-
<div n="lb"/>looked), and there is no doubt that
<div n="lb"/>the later opinion is correct. {%Cf.%} also

<div n="lb"/>3, 173; Hopkins, 260, 261. Of these
<div n="lb"/>tribes the Pakthas, Alinas, Bhalānas,
<div n="lb"/>Viṣāṇins, and Śivas, were probably
<div n="lb"/>settled in the north-west, to the west
<div n="lb"/>of the Indus, and around the Kabul
<div n="lb"/>River. The Anus, Pūrus, Turvaśas,

<div n="lb"/>sion, instead of Turvaśa, the Yadu,

<div n="lb"/>king of the Yadus, ridiculous as a
<div n="lb"/>member of an insignificant people, and
<div n="lb"/>alluding to him also as a sacrificial
<div n="lb"/>victim (as it were, {%yaṣṭavya,%} ‘to be
<div n="lb"/>offered’; {%of puroḍāś,%} ‘cake of sacrifice,’
<div n="lb"/>in verse 6, as a pun on {%purogās,%} ‘leader’).
<div n="lb"/>Whether Yakṣu is used contemptuously
<div n="lb"/>for Yadu or not, it seems hard not to
<div n="lb"/>believe that the Yadus are referred

<L>1200<pc>1-326<k1>tOgrya<k2>tOgrya

<L>1206<pc>1-327<k1>trasadasyu<k2>trasadasyu
{@Trasa-dasyu,@}¦ son of {@Purukutsa,@}<sup>1</sup> is mentioned in the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>as king of the Pūrus.<sup>2</sup> He was born to Purukutsa by his wife,
<div n="lb"/>{@Purukutsānī,@} at a time of great distress;<sup>3</sup> this, according to
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa, refers to Purukutsa's captivity: possibly his death is
<div n="lb"/>really meant. Trasadasyu was also a descendant of Girikṣit,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and Purukutsa was a descendant of Durgaha. The genealogy,
<div n="lb"/>therefore, appears to be: Durgaha, Girikṣit, Purukutsa, Trasa-
<div n="lb"/>dasyu. Trasadasyu was the ancestor of {@Tṛkṣi,@}<sup>5</sup> and, according
<div n="lb"/>to Ludwig,<sup>6</sup> had a son Hiraṇin. Trasadasyu's chronological
<div n="lb"/>position is determined by the fact that his father, Purukutsa,
<div n="lb"/>was a contemporary of Sudās, either as an opponent<sup>7</sup> or as
<div n="lb"/>a friend.<sup>8</sup> That Purukutsa was an enemy of Sudās is more
<div n="lb"/>probable, because the latter's predecessor, Divodāsa, was
<div n="lb"/>apparently<sup>9</sup> at enmity with the Pūrus, and in the battle of the
<div n="lb"/>ten kings Pūrus were ranged against Sudās and the Tṛtsus.
<div n="lb"/>Trasadasyu himself seems to have been an energetic king.
<div n="lb"/>His people, the Pūrus, were settled on the {@Sarasvatī,@}<sup>10</sup> which
<div n="lb"/>was, no doubt, the stream in the middle country, that locality
<div n="lb"/>according well with the later union of the Pūrus with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Kuru@} people, who inhabited that country. This union is
<div n="lb"/>exemplified in the person of {@Kuruśravaṇa,@} who is called
<div n="lb"/>Trāsadasyava, ‘descendant of Trasadasyu,’ in the Rigveda,<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>whose father was {@Mitrātithi,@} and whose son was {@Upamaśravas.@}
<div n="lb"/>The relation of Mitrātithi to Tṛkṣi does not appear.
<div n="P"/>Another descendant of Trasadasyu was {@Tryaruṇa Traivṛṣṇa,@}
<div n="lb"/>who is simply called Trasadasyu in a hymn of the Rigveda.<sup>12</sup>
[Page1-328+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>He was not only a ‘descendant of Trivṛṣan,’ but, according
<div n="lb"/>to the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>13</sup> he was also Traidhātva,
<div n="lb"/>‘descendant of Tridhātu.’ The order of these two predecessors
<div n="lb"/>of Tryaruṇa cannot be determined in any way from Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature. According to the later tradition,<sup>14</sup> a prince named
<div n="lb"/>Tridhanvan preceded Tryaruṇa in the succession. Vedic tradi-
<div n="lb"/>tion further fails to show in what precise relation Trasadasyu
<div n="lb"/>stood to Trivṛṣan or Tryaruṇa.
<div n="P"/>Trasdasyu Paurukutsa appears in several Brāhmaṇas<sup>15</sup> as a
<div n="lb"/>famous sacrificer of ancient times, together with {@Para Āṭṇāra,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Vītahavya Śrāyasa,@} and {@Kakṣīvant Auśija,@} who in the
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa<sup>16</sup> are called ‘ancient great
<div n="lb"/>kings’ ({%pūrve mahārājāḥ%}).
<F>1) Rv. v. 33, 8; vii. 19, 3; viii. 19,
<div n="lb"/>36; iv. 42, 8 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) Rv. iv. 38, 1 {%et seq.;%} vii. 19, 3.
<div n="lb"/>He is merely alluded to in i. 63, 7;
<div n="lb"/>112, 4; viii. 8, 21; 36, 7; 37, 7; 49, 10.</F>
<F>3) Rv. iv. 42, 8 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) Rv. v. 33, 8.</F>
<F>5) Rv. viii. 22, 7. He was a Pūru
<div n="lb"/>king. See vi. 46, 8.</F>
<F>6) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155,
<div n="lb"/>with reference to Rv. v. 33, 7 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>7) So Ludwig, 3, 174, who alters
<div n="lb"/>{%Sudāsam%} to {%Sudāse,%} in support of this
<div n="lb"/>view, in Rv. i. 63, 7. {%Cf.%} Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gesellschaft,%} 42, 204, 205, 219, {%Ṛgveda-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Noten,%} 1, 63; Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 153; Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 112, n. 1. Foy, Kuhn's {%Zeitschrift,%}
<div n="lb"/>34, 242, denies that the word in this
<div n="lb"/>passage is a proper name at all.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>9) Rv. i. 130, 7; Ludwig, 3, 114; but
<div n="lb"/>see Hillebrandt, 1, 113, 114.</F>
<F>10) Rv. vii. 95, 96; Ludwig, 3, 175;
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt, 1, 115.</F>
<F>11) x. 33, 4. {%Cf.%} Lanman, {%Sanskrit%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Reader,%} 386 {%et seq.;%} Geldner, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 2, 150, 184.</F>
<F>12) v. 27.</F>
<F>13) xiii. 3, 12. The Tāṇḍaka, cited
<div n="lb"/>by Sāyaṇa (Sieg, {%Die Sagenstoffe des%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Ṛgveda,%} 67), has Trasadasyu, like the Rv.</F>
<F>14) Harivaṃśa, 714 {%et seq.,%} where the
<div n="lb"/>name (716) is also misread as Tridhar-
<div n="lb"/>man. Traidhātva cannot reasonably
<div n="lb"/>be taken as representing a patronymic
<div n="lb"/>from Tridhanvan, as Sieg, {%op. cit.,%} 74-
<div n="lb"/>76, seems to do. Trivṛṣan has entirely
<div n="lb"/>disappeared from the Epic tradition;
<div n="lb"/>there is thus no way of assigning a
<div n="lb"/>relative priority to either Trivṛṣan or
<div n="lb"/>Tridhanvan.</F>
<F>15) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxv. 16;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxii. 3 ({%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 3, 473); Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>v. 6, 5, 3.</F>
<F>16) ii. 6, 11.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 217
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.;%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 111-116; 2, 165, n. 4; Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 10, 25; Lanman, {%Sanskrit Reader,%}

<L>1217<pc>1-330<k1>triyuga<k2>triyuga
{@Tri-yuga,@}¦ neut., is an expression occurring in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>where it is said that the plants ({%oṣadhi%}) were born ‘three ages’
<div n="lb"/>before the gods ({%devebhyas triyugaṃ purā%}). The commentator
<div n="lb"/>on the Nirukta<sup>2</sup> thinks that the ages here meant are the Yugas
<div n="lb"/>of the later Indian chronology, the sense of the passage being
<div n="lb"/>that the plants were born in the first Yuga. The author of
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> understands three seasons — spring,
<div n="lb"/>the rains, and autumn — to be meant in the verse, taking the
<div n="lb"/>two words {%triyugaṃ purā%} separately as ‘formerly, in the three
<div n="lb"/>seasons.’ The vague sense ‘three ages’ is quite adequate:
<div n="lb"/>the use of ‘three’ in such cases is a favourite feature in
<div n="lb"/>folklore. {%Cf.%} {@Yuga.@}
<F>1) x. 97, 1 = Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv.
<div n="lb"/>2, 6, 1, and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā; xii. 75.</F>
<F>2) ix. 28.</F>
<F>3) vii. 2, 4, 26.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>41, 340.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1229<pc>1-332<k1>tryaruRatrEvfzRatrasadasyu<k2>tryaruRatrEvfzRatrasadasyu
{@Try-aruṇa Trai-vṛṣṇa Trasadasyu@}¦ is the name of a prince
<div n="lb"/>whose generosity to a singer is celebrated in a hymn of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> In the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> he appears as
<div n="lb"/>{@Tryaruṇa Traidhātva Aikṣvāka,@} and is the hero of the
<div n="lb"/>following story. He was out in his chariot with his Purohita,
<div n="lb"/>or domestic priest, {@Vṛśa Jāna,@} and by excessive speed in driving
<div n="lb"/>killed a Brahmin boy. This sin was atoned for by the Puro-
<div n="lb"/>hita's using his Vārśa Sāman (chant). The Śāṭyāyana Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, cited by Sāyaṇa,<sup>3</sup> elaborates the tale. As Vṛśa had
<div n="lb"/>held the reins, king and priest accused each other of the murder.
<div n="lb"/>The Ikṣvākus being consulted threw the responsibility for the
<div n="lb"/>crime on Vṛśa, who thereupon revived the boy by the Vārśa
<div n="lb"/>Sāman. In consequence of this unfairness of theirs — being
<div n="lb"/>Kṣatriyas they were partial to a Kṣatriya — Agni's glow ceased
<div n="lb"/>to burn in their houses. In response to their appeal to restore
<div n="lb"/>it, Vṛśa came to them, saw the Piśācī (demoness), who, in the
<div n="lb"/>form of Trasadasyu's wife, had stolen the glow, and succeeded
<div n="lb"/>in restoring it to Agni. This version with some variations
<div n="lb"/>occurs also in the Bṛhaddevatā,<sup>4</sup> which connects the story with
<div n="lb"/>a hymn of the Rigveda.<sup>5</sup> Sieg's attempt<sup>6</sup> to show that the
<div n="lb"/>hymn really refers to this tale is not at all successful.<sup>7</sup>
[Page1-333+ 44]
<div n="P"/>It is clear that Trasadasyu must here mean ‘descendant of
<div n="lb"/>Trasadasyu,’ and not King Trasadasyu himself. The difference
<div n="lb"/>of the patronymics, Traivṛṣṇa and Traidhātva, by which he is
<div n="lb"/>referred to can best be explained by assuming that there were
<div n="lb"/>two kings, Trivṛṣan and Tridhātu (or possibly Tridhanvan),
<div n="lb"/>from whom Tryaruṇa was descended.<sup>8</sup> The connexion with the
<div n="lb"/>Ikṣvākus is important (see {@Ikṣvāku@}).
<F>1) v. 27, 1-3.</F>
<F>2) xiii. 3, 12. {%Cf.%} the Tāṇḍaka recen-
<div n="lb"/>sion, cited in Sāyaṇa, on Rv. v. 2,
<div n="lb"/>where Trasadasyu is given as the king's
<div n="lb"/>name.</F>
<F>3) On Rv., {%loc. cit.%} See also the
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa version in Oertel,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>18, 20.</F>
<F>4) v. 14 {%et seq.,%} with Macdonell's notes.</F>
<F>5) v. 2.</F>
<F>6) {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 64-76.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Geldner, {%Festtgruss an Roth,%} 192.</F>
<F>7) See Oldenberg, {%Sacred Books of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%East,%} 46, 366 {%et seq.; Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1,
<div n="lb"/>312; Hillebrandt, {%Göttingische Gelehrte%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Anzeigen,%} 1903, 240 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>8) See Sieg, {%op. cit.,%} 74-76, and {@Trasadasyu.@}</F>

<L>1232<pc>1-333<k1>tvac<k2>tvac
{@Tvac,@}¦ ‘skin,’ ‘hide,’ ({%a%}) denotes specially in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>

<div n="lb"/>to catch the drops of juice, not above, as Pischel<sup>3</sup> thought.

<div n="lb"/>applied to the aboriginal enemies of the invading Āryans.<sup>5</sup>

<L>1235<pc>1-334<k1>tsaru<k2>tsaru
{@Tsaru,@}¦ — ({%a%}) This word seems to denote some sort of crawling
<div n="lb"/>animal in one passage of the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="P"/>({%b%}) In the later literature the word means a ‘handle,’ as of
<div n="lb"/>a beaker ({@Camasa@}).<sup>1</sup> In this sense also it seems to occur in the
<div n="lb"/>description of the plough ({@Lāṅgala@}) in the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>the later Saṃhitās.<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) vii. 50, 1. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 99.</F>
<F>1) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxv. 4.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Lāṭyāyana Srauta Sūtra, x. 12, 12,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) iii. 17, 3, where the ordinary text
<div n="lb"/>has {%soma-satsaru%} (so the Pada text), and
<div n="lb"/>the Paippalāda recension has {%soma-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%pitsalam.%}</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 5, 6, has
<div n="lb"/>{%sumati-tsaru;%} Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7,
<div n="lb"/>12; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvi. 12; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 71; Vasiṣṭha
<div n="lb"/>Dharma Sūtra, ii. 34, have {%somapitsaru,%}
<div n="lb"/>which Vasiṣṭha renders as ‘provided
<div n="lb"/>with a handle for the drinker of Soma’
<div n="lb"/>({%i.e., somapi-tsaru%}). Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 17, 255, suggests {%soma-sa-tsaru,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘with ({%sa-%}) strap ({%uman,%} a conjectural
<div n="lb"/>word) and handle’ ({%tsaru%}). Whitney,
<div n="lb"/>Translation of the Atharvaveda, 116,
<div n="lb"/>prefers to read throughout {%sumati-tsaru,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘with well-smoothed handle,’ from the
<div n="lb"/>root seen in {%matī-kṛ,%} etc. {%Cf.%} Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 236; Bühler, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 14, 13.</F>

<L>1243<pc>1-336<k1>dakziRA<k2>dakziRA
{@Dakṣiṇā@}¦ appears repeatedly in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> as the
<div n="lb"/>designation of the gift presented to priests at the sacrifice,
<div n="lb"/>apparently because a cow — a prolific ({%dakṣiṇā%}) one — was the
<div n="lb"/>usual ‘fee’<sup>3</sup> on such an occasion.<sup>4</sup> The later Dāna-stutis, or
<div n="lb"/>‘Praises of Gifts,’ in the Rigveda immensely exaggerate these
<div n="lb"/>donations, and the exaggeration grows in the Brāhmaṇas. It
<div n="lb"/>is important to notice that these enumerations of gifts in the
<div n="lb"/>main include nothing but articles of personal property, such as
<div n="lb"/>kine, horses, buffaloes, or camels ({%uṣṭra%}), ornaments, and so
<div n="lb"/>forth, but not land.<sup>5</sup> Reference is, however, made in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup> to land as a Dakṣiṇā, but with dis-
<div n="lb"/>approval, probably because the land came to be regarded as
<div n="lb"/>inalienable without the consent of the clansmen.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) A whole hymn, Rv. x. 107, is
<div n="lb"/>devoted to its praise. {%Cf.%} i. 168, 7; vi.
<div n="lb"/>27, 8; viii. 24, 29; 39, 5; x. 62, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 11, 4; v. 7, 11; xi. 7, 9;
<div n="lb"/>8, 22; xiii. 1, 52; xviii. 4, 8, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 7, 3, 1; 8, 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 19, 23; xix. 30;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 3, 3 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 9, 3, 1 {%et seq.%}
<div n="lb"/>The verses ({%gāthā nārāśaṃsī,%} either as
<div n="lb"/>a single expression or as two separate
<div n="lb"/>terms) used to win these Dakṣiṇās were
<div n="lb"/>notoriously false. See Kāṭhaka Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, xiv. 5; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 3,
<div n="lb"/>2, 6. 7; Nirukta, i. 7; xi. 2.</F>
<F>3) The transition of meaning is similar
<div n="lb"/>in the use of the English word ‘fee’;
<div n="lb"/>‘cattle,’ ‘money,’ ‘payment for service’
<div n="lb"/>(see Murray's English Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.%} ‘fee’). {%Cf.%} also {@Go-dāna,@} n. 4.</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} the rule that when nothing is
<div n="lb"/>specified a cow is the Dakṣiṇā, Kāty-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Śrauta Sūtra, xv. 2, 13; Lāṭy-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Śrauta Sūtra, viii. 1, 2.</F>
<F>5) So, {%e.g.,%} Rv. i. 126, 1-4; v. 30,
<div n="lb"/>12-15; viii. 1, 32. 33; 3, 21 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>4, 19-21; 5, 37-39; 6, 46-48; 55; 56;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 18, 21-24, and the full list in
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>3, 273-277. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>10, 49 {%et seq.%} Clothes ({%vāsas%}) and gold
<div n="lb"/>are mentioned as a Dakṣiṇā in Av. ix. 5,
<div n="lb"/>14. The four Dakṣiṇās, according to
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iv. 3, 4, 7,
<div n="lb"/>are gold, a cow, clothes, and a horse.
<div n="lb"/>This is practically exhaustive if the
<div n="lb"/>trappings of the horse and ornaments
<div n="lb"/>are included.</F>
<F>6) xiii. 7, 1, 13, with which compare
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 6, 2, 18, where the Brahmin's land
<div n="lb"/>is excluded; and see xiii. 7, 1, 15, where
<div n="lb"/>the gift of land is disapproved.</F>
<F>7) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vii. 1, 1, 4.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} above, pp. 100, n. 19, 246; below,
<div n="lb"/>pp. 351, 352.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 169-
<div n="lb"/>171; Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte,%} 104, 105;
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Indische Streifen,%} 1, 96-98;
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield, {%Religion of the Veda,%} 69-74;
<div n="lb"/>{%Atharvaveda,%} 76 {%et seq.,%} 100, 121.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1244<pc>1-336<k1>dakziRApaTa<k2>dakziRApaTa

<L>1248<pc>1-337<k1>daRqa<k2>daRqa

<div n="lb"/>ordinary sense; for example, when used for driving cattle<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>({%go-ajanāsaḥ%}), or as a weapon.<sup>2</sup> A staff was given to a man
<div n="lb"/>on consecration for driving away demons, according to the
<div n="lb"/>Satapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>3</sup> The staff also played a part in the
<div n="lb"/>initiation ({%upanayana%}) of a youth on attaining manhood.<sup>4</sup> In
<div n="lb"/>a modified sense the word is used to denote the handle of a
<div n="lb"/>ladle or similar implement.<sup>5</sup>
[Page1-338+ 49]
<div n="P"/>({%b%}) The ‘staff’ as the symbol of temporal power, implying
<div n="lb"/>punishment, is applied by the king ({%rāja-preṣito daṇḍaḥ%}).<sup>1</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>king, in modern phraseology, was the source of criminal law;
<div n="lb"/>and he clearly retained this branch of law in his own hands
<div n="lb"/>even in later times.<sup>2</sup> The punishment of the non-guilty
<div n="lb"/>({%a-daṇḍya%}) is given as one of the characteristics of the non-
<div n="lb"/>Brahminical {@Vrātyas@} in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>3</sup> See
<div n="lb"/>also {@Dharma.@}
<F>1) Rv. vii. 33, 6.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 5, 4. {%Cf.%} Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 35; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 5, 4, 6, etc.</F>
<F>3) iii. 2, 1, 32.</F>
<F>4) Āśvalāyana Gṛhya Sūtra, i. 19; 22;
<div n="lb"/>Sāṅkhāyana Gṛhya Sūtra, ii. 1, 6, 11, etc.</F>
<F>5) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 5; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, vii. 4, 1, 36. Of a
<div n="lb"/>musical instrument, Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇ-
<div n="lb"/>yaka, viii. 9; Śrauta Sūtra, xvii. 3, 1 {%et%}
<div n="lb"/>{%seq.%}</F>
<F>1) Pāraskara Gṛhya Sūtra, iii. 15.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 4, 4, 7,
<div n="lb"/>where the king, being himself ‘exempt
<div n="lb"/>from punishment’ ({%a-daṇḍya%}), inflicts
<div n="lb"/>judicial punishment ({%daṇḍa-vadha%}).</F>
<F>2) Foy, {%Die königliche Gewalt,%} 21 {%et%}
<div n="lb"/>{%seq.%}</F>
<F>3) xvii. 1, 9; Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 33.</F>

<L>1255<pc>1-339<k1>dant<k2>dant
{@Dant, Danta,@}¦ ‘tooth,’ is frequently mentioned from the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda onwards.<sup>1</sup> Cleansing ({%dhāv%}) the teeth was an ordinary
<div n="lb"/>act, especially in preparation for a sacrifice, and accompanied
<div n="lb"/>bathing, shaving of the hair and beard ({%keśa-śmaśru%}), and the
<div n="lb"/>cutting of the nails.<sup>2</sup> A hymn of the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> celebrates
<div n="lb"/>the appearance of the first two teeth of a child, though its
<div n="lb"/>exact interpretation is doubtful.<sup>4</sup> In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>there is a reference to a child's first teeth falling out. The
<div n="lb"/>word seems in the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> once to denote an elephant's tusk.
<div n="lb"/>Whether dentistry was practised is doubtful. The occurrence
<div n="lb"/>in the Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>7</sup> of {@Hiraṇya-dant,@} ‘gold-toothed,’ as
<div n="lb"/>the name of a man, is perhaps significant, especially as it is
<div n="lb"/>certain that the stopping of teeth with gold was known at
<div n="lb"/>Rome as early as the legislation of the Twelve Tables.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) Rv. vii. 55, 2; x. 68, 6; Av. v. 23,
<div n="lb"/>3; 29, 4; vi. 56, 3, etc. The more
<div n="lb"/>usual form is Danta, Rv. iv. 6, 8;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 75, 11; Av. iv. 3, 6, etc.</F>
<F>2) Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 2 (not
<div n="lb"/>exactly paralleled in Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>vi. 1, 1, 2 {%et seq.%}).</F>
<F>3) vi. 140.</F>
<F>4) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 321;
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 5, 224; Grill,
<div n="lb"/>{%Hundert Lieder,%}^2 176; Bloomfield, {%Hymns%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Atharvaveda,%} 540, 541; {%Atharva-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%veda,%} 71; Whitney, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 386.</F>
<F>5) vii. 14; Śāṅkhāyana Srauta Sūtra,
<div n="lb"/>xv. 18.</F>
<F>6) iv. 6, 8; Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 99; Oldenberg, {%Sacred Books of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%East,%} 46, 341, 342.</F>

<L>1266<pc>1-342<k1>daSan<k2>daSan
{@Daśan,@}¦ ‘ten,’ forms the basis of the numerical system of the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic Indians, as it does of the Āryan people generally. But
<div n="lb"/>it is characteristic of India<sup>1</sup> that there should be found at a
<div n="lb"/>very early period long series of names for very high numerals,
<div n="lb"/>whereas the Āryan knowledge did not go beyond 1,000. In
<div n="lb"/>the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>2</sup> the list is 1; 10; 100; 1,000; 10,000
<div n="lb"/>({%ayuta%}); 100,000 ({%niyuta%}); 1,000,000 ({%prayuta%}); 10,000,000 ({%arbuda%});
<div n="lb"/>100,000,000 ({%nyarbuda%}); 1,000,000,000 ({%samudra%}); 10,000,000,000
<div n="lb"/>({%madhya%}); 100,000,000,000 ({%anta%}); 1,000,000,000,000 ({%parārdha%}).
<div n="lb"/>In the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup> the list is the same, but {%niyuta%} and
<div n="lb"/>{%prayuta%} exchange places, and after {%nyarbuda%} a new figure
<div n="lb"/>({%badva%}) intervenes, thus increasing {%samudra%} to 10,000,000,000,
<div n="lb"/>and so on. The Taittirīya Saṃhitā has in two places<sup>4</sup> exactly
<div n="lb"/>the same list as the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā. The Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>5</sup> has the list {%ayuta, prayuta,%} then {%ayuta%} again, {%arbuda,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%nyarbuda, samudra, madhya, anta, parārdha.%} The Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup> has the Vājasaneyi list up to {%nyarbuda%} inclusive,
<div n="lb"/>then follow {%nikharvaka, badva, akṣita,%} and apparently {%go%} =
<div n="lb"/>1,000,000,000,000. The Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup> list
[Page1-343+ 58]
<div n="lb"/>replaces {%nikharvaka%} by {%nikharva, badva%} by {%padma,%} and ends
<div n="lb"/>with {%akṣitir vyomāntaḥ.%} The Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>8</sup> con-
<div n="lb"/>tinues the series after {%nyarbuda%} with {%nikharvāda, samudra,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%salila, antya, ananta%} (= 10 billions).
<div n="P"/>But beyond {%ayuta%}<sup>9</sup> none of these numbers has any vitality.
<div n="lb"/>{%Badva,%} indeed, occurs in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>10</sup> but it
<div n="lb"/>cannot there have any precise numerical sense;<sup>11</sup> and later on
<div n="lb"/>the names of these high numerals are very much confused.
<div n="P"/>An arithmetical progression of some interest is found in the
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>12</sup> where occurs a list of sacrificial gifts
<div n="lb"/>in which each successive figure doubles the amount of the
<div n="lb"/>preceding one. It begins with {%dvādaśa-mānaṃ hiraṇyam,%} ‘gold
<div n="lb"/>to the value of 12’ (the unit being uncertain, but probably the
<div n="lb"/>{@Kṛṣṇala@}),<sup>13</sup> followed by ‘to the value of 24, 48, 96, 192, 384,
<div n="lb"/>768, 1,536, 3072,’ then {%dve aṣṭāviṃśati-śata-māne,%} which must
<div n="lb"/>mean 2×128×24 (the last unit being not a single {%māna,%} but
<div n="lb"/>a number of 24 {%mānas%}) = 6,144, then 12,288, 24,576, 49,152,
<div n="lb"/>98,304, 196,608, 393, 216. With these large numbers may be
<div n="lb"/>compared the minute theoretical subdivision of time found
<div n="lb"/>in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>14</sup> where a day is divided into
<div n="lb"/>15 {%muhūrtas%} — 1 {%muhūrta%} = 15 {%kṣipras,%} 1 {%kṣipra%} = 15 {%etarhis,%}
<div n="lb"/>1 {%etarhi%} = 15 {%idānis,%} 1 {%idāni%} = 15 {%prāṇas.%} The Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra<sup>15</sup> has a decimal division of the day into 15 {%muhūrtas%} — 
<div n="lb"/>1 {%muhūrta%} = 10 {%nimeṣas,%} 1 {%nimeṣa%} = 10 {%dhvaṃsis.%}
<div n="P"/>Few fractions are mentioned in Vedic literature. {%Ardha,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%pāda, śapha,%} and {%kalā%} denote (1/2), (1/4), (1/8), (1/16) respectively, but only
[Page1-344+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>the first two are common. {%Tṛtīya%} denotes the third part.<sup>16</sup>
<div n="lb"/>In the Rigveda<sup>17</sup> Indra and Viṣṇu are said to have divided
<div n="lb"/>1,000 by 3, though how they did so is uncertain. {%Tri-pād%}
<div n="lb"/>denotes ‘three-fourths.’<sup>18</sup>
<div n="P"/>There is no clear evidence that the Indians of the Vedic
<div n="lb"/>period had any knowledge of numerical figures, though it is
<div n="lb"/>perfectly possible.<sup>19</sup>

<L>1269<pc>1-344<k1>daSamI<k2>daSamI
{@Daśamī@}¦ denotes in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and the Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> the period of life between 90 and 100 years
[Page1-345+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>which the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> calls the {%daśama yuga,%} ‘the tenth stage
<div n="lb"/>of life.’ Longevity seems not to have been rare among the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic Indians, for the desire to live a ‘hundred autumns’
<div n="lb"/>({%śaradaḥ śatam%}) is constantly expressed.<sup>4</sup> {@Dīrghatamas@} is said
<div n="lb"/>to have lived 100 years,<sup>5</sup> and {@Mahidāsa Aitareya@} is credited
<div n="lb"/>with 116.<sup>6</sup> Onesikritos<sup>7</sup> reported that they sometimes lived
<div n="lb"/>130 years, a statement with which corresponds the wish
<div n="lb"/>expressed in the Jātaka<sup>8</sup> for a life of 120 years. Probably the
<div n="lb"/>number was always rather imaginary than real, but the com-
<div n="lb"/>parative brevity of modern life in India<sup>9</sup> may be accounted for
<div n="lb"/>by the cumulative effect of fever, which is hardly known to the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda. See {@Takman.@}
<F>1) iii. 4, 7.</F>
<F>2) xxii. 14.</F>
<F>3) i. 158, 6.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 89, 9; x. 18, 10, and {%passim.%}
<div n="lb"/>See Lanman, {%Sanskrit Reader,%} 384;
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield, {%Atharvaveda,%} 62, 63.</F>
<F>5) Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, ii. 17.</F>
<F>6) Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iii. 16, 7;
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, iv. 2,

<L>1279<pc>1-347<k1>dasyu<k2>dasyu
{@Dasyu,@}¦ a word of somewhat doubtful origin, is in many
<div n="lb"/>passages of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> clearly applied to superhuman
<div n="lb"/>enemies. On the other hand, there are several passages in
<div n="lb"/>which human foes, probably the aborigines, are thus designated.
<div n="lb"/>This may be regarded as certain in those passages where the
<div n="lb"/>Dasyu is opposed to the Āryan, who defeats him with the aid
<div n="lb"/>of the gods.<sup>2</sup> The great difference between the Dasyus and
<div n="lb"/>the Āryans was their religion: the former are styled ‘not
<div n="lb"/>sacrificing,’ ‘devoid of rites,’ ‘addicted to strange vows,’ ‘god-
<div n="lb"/>hating,’ and so forth.<sup>3</sup> As compared with the {@Dāsa,@} they are
<div n="lb"/>less distinctively a people: no clans ({%viśaḥ%}) of the Dasyus are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned, and while Indra's {%dasyu-hatya,%} ‘slaughter of the
<div n="lb"/>Dasyus,’ is often spoken of, there is no corresponding use of
<div n="lb"/>{%dāsa-hatya.%} That the Dasyus were real people is, however,
<div n="lb"/>shown by the epithet {%anās%} applied to them in one passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>5</sup> The sense of this word is not absolutely certain: the
<div n="lb"/>Pada text and Sāyaṇa both take it to mean ‘without face’ ({%an-ās%}),<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>but the other rendering, ‘noseles’ ({%a-nās%}), is quite possible,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="P"/>4 Rv. i. 51, 5, 6; 103, 4; x. 95, 7;
<div n="lb"/>99, 7; 105, 11. {%Cf. dasyu-han.%} ‘Dasyu-
<div n="lb"/>slaying,’ i. 100, 12; vi. 45, 24; viii. 76,
<div n="lb"/>11; 77, 3; x. 47, 4 (all of Indra);
<div n="lb"/>vi. 16, 15; viii. 39, 8 (of Agni), etc.
[Page1-348+ 68]
<div n="lb"/>and would accord well with the flat-nosed aborigines of the
<div n="lb"/>Dravidian<sup>8</sup> type, whose language still persists among the Brahuis,
<div n="lb"/>who are found in the north-west. This interpretation would
<div n="lb"/>receive some support from Vṛtra's being called ‘broken-nosed’
<div n="lb"/>if this were a correct explanation of the obscure word {%rujānās.%}<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>The other epithet of the Dasyus is {%mṛdhra-vāc,%} which
<div n="lb"/>occurs with {%anās,%}<sup>10</sup> and which has been rendered<sup>11</sup> ‘of stam-
<div n="lb"/>mering, or unintelligible speech.’ This version is by no
<div n="lb"/>means certain, and since the epithet is elsewhere<sup>12</sup> applied
<div n="lb"/>to Āryans, its correct meaning is more probably ‘of hostile
<div n="lb"/>speech.’
<div n="P"/>Dasyu corresponds with the Iranian {%daṅhu, daqyu,%} which
<div n="lb"/>denotes a ‘province.’ Zimmer<sup>13</sup> thinks that the original
<div n="lb"/>meaning was ‘enemy,’ whence the Iranians developed the
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘hostile country,’ ‘conquered country,’ ‘province,’
<div n="lb"/>while the Indians, retaining the signification of ‘enemy,’ ex-
<div n="lb"/>tended it to include demon foes. Roth<sup>14</sup> considers that the
<div n="lb"/>meaning of human enemy is a transfer from the strife of gods
[Page1-349+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>and demons. Lassen<sup>15</sup> attempted to connect the contrast
<div n="lb"/>{%daqyu: dasyu%} with that of {%daeva: deva,%} and to see in it a result
<div n="lb"/>of the religious differences which, according to Haug's theory,
<div n="lb"/>had separated the Iranians and the Indians. The word may
<div n="lb"/>have originally meant ‘ravaged land’<sup>16</sup> as a result of invasion;
<div n="lb"/>hence ‘enemies’ country,' then ‘hostile people,’ who as human
<div n="lb"/>foes were more usually called by the cognate name of {@Dāsa.@}
<div n="P"/>Individual Dasyus are {@Cumuri, Śambara, Śuṣṇa,@} etc.
<div n="P"/>In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>17</sup> the word has, as later,<sup>18</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>sense of uncivilized peoples generally.
<F>1) i. 34, 7; 100, 18; ii. 13, 9, etc.
<div n="lb"/>See Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%} pp. 157,
<div n="lb"/>158.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 51, 8; 103, 3; 117, 21;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 11, 18, 19; iii. 34, 9; vi. 18, 3;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 5, 6; x. 49, 3. Probably also in
<div n="lb"/>v. 70, 3; x. 83, 6, people are meant.</F>
<F>3) The Dasyu is called {%a-karman,%} ‘rite-
<div n="lb"/>less,’ x. 22, 8; {%a-devayu,%} ‘indifferent to
<div n="lb"/>the gods,’ viii. 70, 11; {%a-brahman,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘without devotion,’ iv. 16, 9; {%a-yajvan,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘not sacrificing,’ viii. 70, 11; {%a-yajyu,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%id.,%} vii. 6, 3; {%a-vrata,%} ‘lawless,’ i. 51,
<div n="lb"/>8; 175, 3; vi. 14, 3; ix. 41, 2; {%anya-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vrata,%} ‘following strange ordinances,’
<div n="lb"/>viii. 70, 11; {%deva-pīyu,%} ‘reviling the
<div n="lb"/>gods,’ Av. xii. 1, 37. It is impossible
<div n="lb"/>in all cases to be certain that people
<div n="lb"/>are meant.</F>
<F>5) Rv. v. 29, 10.</F>
<F>6) This sense allows of two inter-
<div n="lb"/>pretations: ‘misfeatured,’ which seems
<div n="lb"/>that of Roth, St. Petersburg Dic-
<div n="lb"/>tionary, {%s.v.,%} and Grassmann, {%Wörter-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%buch;%} or ‘speechless’ (that is, unable
<div n="lb"/>to speak the language of the Āryans),
<div n="lb"/>which is that of Bollensen, {%Zeitschrift%}
<div n="lb"/>{%der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%schaft,%} 41, 496.</F>
<F>7) This view is supported by Mega-
<div n="lb"/>sthenes' report as to natives who were
<lang n="greek"></lang>: see Strabo, p. 711; Pliny,
<div n="lb"/>{%Nat. Hist.,%} vii. 2, 18, cited by Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 430. See also Ludwig,

<div n="lb"/>5, 95; Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}

<div n="lb"/>52; Wackernagel, {%Altindische Gram-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%matik,%} 2, 293 (accent).</F>
<F>8) The suggestion in the {%Indian Empire,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 390, that the modern Brahui type is
<div n="lb"/>the true Dravidian, while the modern
<div n="lb"/>Dravidian is the result of fusion with
<div n="lb"/>Muṇḍā-speaking tribes, would render
<div n="lb"/>this theory improbable. But it seems
<div n="lb"/>more probable that the Brahuis in
<div n="lb"/>speech preserve the tradition of Dra-
<div n="lb"/>vidian settlements in North India.</F>
<F>9) See Bloomfield, {%American Journal of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Philology,%} 17, 415 (who takes {%rujānāḥ%} of
<div n="lb"/>Rv. i. 32, 8, as = {%rujāna-nāḥ%}); Olden-
<div n="lb"/>berg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 31, 32 (who

<div n="lb"/>word as {%rujā-anāḥ%}). But {%cf.%} Lanman,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sanskrit Reader,%} 361, who suggests the
<div n="lb"/>emendation {%rujānaḥ%} as nominative
<div n="lb"/>singular of the simple participle
<div n="lb"/>‘broken’; Macdonell, {%Vedic Grammar,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 59, n. 1.</F>
<F>10) Rv. v. 29, 10.</F>
<F>11) {%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 2^2, 393
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>
<F>12) The expression is used of the
<div n="lb"/>Āryan Pūrus in vii. 18, 13; of the Paṇis

<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%} This theory is now generally dis-

<L>1285<pc>1-350<k1>dAna<k2>dAna<h>1
1. {@Dāna,@}¦ ‘giving,’ ‘gift,’ is a word of frequent occurrence in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, especially in the Dāna-stutis<sup>1</sup> (‘Praises of Gifts’)
<div n="lb"/>of generous patrons (see {@Dakṣiṇā@}). One of the characteristics
<div n="lb"/>of the {@Brāhmaṇa@} is his right to receive gifts, which it is
<div n="lb"/>obligatory on the other castes to present.<sup>2</sup> The gift of a
<div n="lb"/>daughter ({%kanyāyā dānam%}) was a form of marriage<sup>3</sup> (see {@Vivāha@}),
<div n="lb"/>because in it the girl was ‘given’ away by her father or
<div n="lb"/>brother.
<F>1) The term seems first to occur in
<div n="lb"/>the Bṛhaddevatā, vi. 45, 92, and in
<div n="lb"/>similar works.</F>
<F>2) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5, 7, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10, 47-61.</F>
<F>3) Nirukta, iii. 4.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1286<pc>1-350<k1>dAna<k2>dAna<h>2
2. {@Dāna@}¦ (‘distribution’)<sup>1</sup> seems in several passages of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>2</sup> to be a designation of the sacrificial feast to which
[Page1-351+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>the god is invited ({%cf.%} <lang n="greek"></lang>). In one passage<sup>3</sup> Sāyaṇa
<div n="lb"/>thinks that it denotes the {%mada-jalāni,%} ‘drops of water falling
<div n="lb"/>from the temples of a rutting elephant,’<sup>4</sup> but this is doubtful.
<div n="lb"/>In another passage<sup>5</sup> Roth thinks that ‘pasture land’ is meant.
<F>1) From {%dā,%} ‘divide.’</F>
<F>2) i. 55, 7; 48, 4; 180, 5; viii. 46, 26;
<div n="lb"/>60, 8; 99, 4, etc. {%Cf.,%} however, Pischel
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 100.</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 33, 8; Ludwig, Transla-
<div n="lb"/>tion of the Rigveda, 5, 157.</F>

<div n="lb"/>the post-Vedic language, is probably
<div n="lb"/>derived from {%dā,%} ‘divide,’ meaning
<div n="lb"/>originally ‘secretion.’</F>
<F>5) ii. 13, 7.</F>

<L>1289<pc>1-351<k1>dAya<k2>dAya
{@Dāya@}¦ occurs in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> only in the sense of ‘reward’
<div n="lb"/>of exertion ({%śrama%}), but later it means ‘inheritance’ — that is,
<div n="lb"/>a father's property which is to be divided among his sons
<div n="lb"/>either during his lifetime or after his death. The passages all
<div n="lb"/>negative the idea that the property of the family was legally
<div n="lb"/>family property: it is clear that it was the property of the head
<div n="lb"/>of the house, usually the father, and that the other members
<div n="lb"/>of the family only had moral claims upon it which the father
<div n="lb"/>could ignore, though he might be coerced by his sons if they
<div n="lb"/>were physically stronger.
<div n="P"/>Thus {@Manu@} is said in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>2</sup> to have divided
<div n="lb"/>his property among his sons. He omitted {@Nābhānediṣṭha,@}
[Page1-352+ 66]
<div n="lb"/>whom he afterwards taught how to appease the Aṅgirases, and
<div n="lb"/>to procure cows. This is a significant indication that the
<div n="lb"/>property he divided was movable property, rather than land
<div n="lb"/>({@Urvarā@}). In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> the division is said to
<div n="lb"/>have been made during Manu's lifetime by his sons, who left
<div n="lb"/>only their aged father to Nābhānediṣṭha. According to the
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>4</sup> again, four sons divided the inheritance
<div n="lb"/>while their old father, Abhipratārin, was still alive. It is,
<div n="lb"/>of course, possible to regard Dāya as denoting the heritable
<div n="lb"/>property of the family, but the developed {%patria potestas%} of the
<div n="lb"/>father, which was early very marked, as shown by the legend
<div n="lb"/>of {@Śunaḥśepa,@} is inconsistent with the view that the sons
<div n="lb"/>were legally owners with their father, unless and until. they
<div n="lb"/>actually insisted on a division of the property.<sup>5</sup> Probably — 
<div n="lb"/>there is no evidence of any decisive character — land was not
<div n="lb"/>divided at first, but no doubt its disposal began to follow the
<div n="lb"/>analogy of cattle and other movable property as soon as the
<div n="lb"/>available supply of arable land became limited.
<div n="P"/>As for the method of division, it is clear from the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>6</sup> that the elder son was usually preferred; perhaps
[Page1-353+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>this was always the case after death. During the father's life-
<div n="lb"/>time another might be preferred, as appears from a passage
<div n="lb"/>of the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>7</sup> Women were excluded from
<div n="lb"/>partition or inheritance, according to the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the Nirukta.<sup>9</sup> They were, no doubt, supported by their
<div n="lb"/>brothers; but if they had none they might be reduced to prosti-
<div n="lb"/>tution.<sup>10</sup> Detailed rules of inheritance appear in the Sūtras.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>The heir is called Dayada,<sup>12</sup> ‘receiver ({%ā-da%}) of inheritance.’
<F>1) x. 114, 10.</F>
<F>2) iii. 1, 9, 4 {%et seq. Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Texts,%} 1^2, 191-194; Lévi, {%La Doctrine du%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacrifice,%} 67, 68.</F>
<F>3) v. 14.</F>
<F>4) iii. 156 ({%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 26, 61, 62).</F>
<F>5) The same question has been raised
<div n="lb"/>as to the origin of English or Teutonic
<div n="lb"/>property in land generally. Against
<div n="lb"/>any idea even of family ownership in
<div n="lb"/>a strict sense of the word, see Fustel
<div n="lb"/>de Coulanges, {%Recherches sur quelques%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Problèmes d'Histoire,%} 322 {%et seq.;%} Ashley,
<div n="lb"/>in Fustel de Coulanges, {%Origin of Pro-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%perty in Land,%} xvi-xxi; Pollock and
<div n="lb"/>Maitland, {%History of English Law,%} 2, 237
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%} The older view, which accepted
<div n="lb"/>family and communal ownership, repre-
<div n="lb"/>sented in different forms by Maine ({%Vil-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%lage Communities in the East and West%}),
<div n="lb"/>Stubbs, Green, and others, is defended
<div n="lb"/>in a new form by Vinogradoff, {%Villanage%}
<div n="lb"/>{%in England.%} See also Keith, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the African Society,%} 6, 201 {%et seq.%}
<div n="lb"/>Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte,%} 93-96, does not
<div n="lb"/>accept the communal ownership of land,
<div n="lb"/>but, {%ibid.,%} 80, is inclined to believe in
<div n="lb"/>the joint ownership of a family. He
<div n="lb"/>admits that this is inconsistent with the
<div n="lb"/>strict rule of {%patria potestas,%} which still
<div n="lb"/>exists in Bengal; Baden Powell, {%Village%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Communities in India,%} 133 {%et seq.,%} doubts
<div n="lb"/>the existence in early India of such a
<div n="lb"/>{%patria potestas.%} But the facts seem clearly
<div n="lb"/>to show that there was such a power,
<div n="lb"/>and that the father owned the property.
<div n="lb"/>His sons, as they grew up, came to
<div n="lb"/>claim the property, and he might have
<div n="lb"/>to divide it; hence the idea naturally
<div n="lb"/>developed that every child on birth had
<div n="lb"/>a legal share in the property. No doubt
<div n="lb"/>also from the first the right to part with
<div n="lb"/>land was one which grown-up sons and
<div n="lb"/>the rest of the community could object
<div n="lb"/>to, once the village had acquired a fixed
<div n="lb"/>existence. This would account ade-
<div n="lb"/>quately for the later system. {%Cf.%} also
<div n="lb"/>pp. 100, n. 19; 336, n. 7, and {@Rājanya.@}</F>
<F>6) ii. 5, 2, 7.</F>
<F>7) xvi. 4, 4.</F>
<F>8) iv. 4, 2, 13.</F>
<F>9) iii. 4.</F>
<F>10) {%Cf.%} {@Ztrī.@}</F>
<F>11) Inheritance is also alluded to in
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 17; Śāṅkh-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Śrauta Sūtra, xv. 27, 3; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 2, 22; iii. 2, 1, 18.
<div n="lb"/>For the Sūtra rules, see Jolly, {%Recht%}
<div n="lb"/>{%und Sitte,%} 80 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>12) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xii. 4, 3, 9;
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta, iii. 4; metaphorically, Av.
<div n="lb"/>v. 18, 6, 14.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1295<pc>1-354<k1>dArvAGAta<k2>dArvAGAta

<L>1305<pc>1-356<k1>dAsa<k2>dAsa
{@Dāsa,@}¦ like {@Dasyu,@} sometimes denotes enemies of a demoniac
<div n="lb"/>character in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> but in many passages<sup>2</sup> the word
<div n="lb"/>refers to human foes of the Āryans. The Dāsas are described
<div n="lb"/>as having forts ({%puraḥ%}),<sup>3</sup> and their clans ({%viśaḥ%}) are mentioned.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>It is possible that the forts, which are called ‘autumnal’
<div n="lb"/>({%śaradīḥ%}),<sup>5</sup> may be mythical, but it is not essential, for the
<div n="lb"/>epithet may allude to their being resorted to in the autumn
<div n="lb"/>season. The Dāsa colour ({@Varṇa@})<sup>6</sup> is probably an allusion to
<div n="lb"/>the black skin of the aborigines, which is also directly men-
<div n="lb"/>tioned.<sup>7</sup> The aborigines (as Dasyus) are called {%anās,%} ‘nose-
<div n="lb"/>less’(?),<sup>8</sup> and {%mṛdhra-vāc,%} ‘of hostile speech,’<sup>9</sup> and are probably
<div n="lb"/>meant by the phallus-worshippers ({%śiśna-devāḥ,%} ‘whose deity
<div n="lb"/>is a phallus’) of the Rigveda.<sup>10</sup> It is significant that constant
[Page1-357+ 67]
<div n="lb"/>reference is made to the differences in religion between Ārva
<div n="lb"/>and Dāsa or Dasyu.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>Since the Dāsas were in many cases reduced to slavery, the
<div n="lb"/>word Dāsa has the sense of ‘slave’ in several passages of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>12</sup> Dāsī, the feminine, always has this sense from
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda<sup>13</sup> onwards. Aboriginal women were, no doubt,
<div n="lb"/>the usual slaves, for on their husbands being slain in battle
<div n="lb"/>they would naturally have been taken as servants. They would
<div n="lb"/>sometimes also become concubines; thus {@Kavaṣa@} was taunted
<div n="lb"/>with being the son of a female slave ({%dāsyāḥ putraḥ%}) in the
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>14</sup>
<div n="P"/>Ludwig<sup>15</sup> considers that in some passages<sup>16</sup> Dāsa is applied,
<div n="lb"/>in the sense of ‘enemy,’ to Āryan foes, but this is uncertain.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>17</sup> and Meyer<sup>18</sup> think that Dāsa<sup>19</sup> originally meant
<div n="lb"/>‘enemy’ in general, later developing in Iran into the name of
<div n="lb"/>the Dahae<sup>20</sup> of the Caspian steppes, and in India into a desig-
<div n="lb"/>nation of the aborigines. On the other hand, Hillebrandt<sup>21</sup>
<div n="lb"/>argues that, as the Dāsas and the Paṇis are mentioned together,<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>they must be deemed to be closely related tribes, identifying
[Page1-358+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>the Paṇis with the Parnians and the Dāsas of the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>with the Dahae. This view, of course, necessitates a transfer
<div n="lb"/>of the scenes of the Rigveda, where Dāsas are prominent, and
<div n="lb"/>especially those in which Divodāsa — ‘the heavenly Dāsa’ — plays
<div n="lb"/>an important part,<sup>23</sup> to the far west. Hillebrandt justifies this
<div n="lb"/>by regarding the scene of the sixth book of the Rigveda as
<div n="lb"/>quite different from that of the seventh and third, in which
<div n="lb"/>Sudās, the Bharatas, Vasiṣṭha, and Viśvāmitra appear. The
<div n="lb"/>Sarasvatī of the sixth book he locates in Arachosia, that of the
<div n="lb"/>seventh in the ‘Middle Country.’ It is, however, extremely
<div n="lb"/>doubtful whether this theory can be upheld. That Divodāsa
<div n="lb"/>should have been a Dāsa, and yet have fought against other
<div n="lb"/>Dāsas, is not in itself likely, especially when his son Sudās
<div n="lb"/>appears as a protagonist of Āryan civilization. It also seems
<div n="lb"/>unreasonable to seek in Arachosia for the river {@Sarasvati,@}
<div n="lb"/>which it is natural to locate in the ‘Middle Country.’
<div n="P"/>The wealth of the Dāsas was no doubt considerable,<sup>24</sup> but in
<div n="lb"/>civilization there is no reason to suppose that they were ever
<div n="lb"/>equal to the invaders.<sup>25</sup> Leading Dāsas were {@Ilībiśa, Cumuri@}
<div n="lb"/>and {@Dhuni, Pipru, Varcin, Śambara.@} For names of aboriginal
<div n="lb"/>tribes, see {@Kirāta, Kīkaṭa, Caṇḍāla, Parṇaka, Śiṃyu.@}
<F>1) {%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 157.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Rv. v. 34, 6; vi. 22, 10; 33, 3;
<div n="lb"/>50, 6; vii. 83, 1; x. 38, 3; 69, 6;
<div n="lb"/>3, 1; Av. v. 11, 3.</F>
<F>3) ii. 20, 8 (called {%āyasīḥ,%} ‘made of
<div n="lb"/>iron’); i. 103, 3; iii. 12, 6; iv. 32, 10.
<div n="lb"/>They are called {%śāradīḥ,%} ‘autumnal,’
<div n="lb"/>in 1. 131, 4; 174, 2; vi. 20, 10. {%Cf.%} also
<div n="lb"/>{%dehyaḥ,%} ‘ramparts,’ in vi. 47, 2.</F>
<F>4) ii. 11, 4; iv. 28, 4; vi. 25, 2.</F>
<F>5) {%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 60.</F>
<F>6) ii. 12, 4; Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra,
<div n="lb"/>viii. 25, 6. {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 101, 1; 130, 8;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 20, 7; iv. 16, 13; vi. 47, 21; vii. 5, 3.
<div n="lb"/>The Ārya colour is mentioned in iii. 34,
<div n="lb"/>9, and the Dāsa is contrasted with the
<div n="lb"/>Varṇa (of the singers) in i. 104, 2. The
<div n="lb"/>‘white-hued ({%śvitnya%}) friends’ who, in

<div n="lb"/>See also Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 140;
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10, 10, 11.</F>
<F>7) {%kṛṣṇā tvac,%} ‘black skin,’ i. 130, 8;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 41, 1.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} {@Dasyu,@} notes 6, 7.</F>
<F>9) v. 29, 10. See {@Dasyu;@} Geldner,
<div n="lb"/>{%Rigveda, Glossar,%} 138.</F>

<F>11) Rv. i. 33, 4. 5; iv. 16, 9; v. 7, 10;
<div n="lb"/>42, 9; vi. 14, 3; viii. 70, 10; x. 22,

<L>1310<pc>1-359<k1>diDizu<k2>diDizu
{@Didhiṣu@}¦ in the Rigveda denotes a ‘wooer.’ It is applied<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to the relative, probably brother-in-law,<sup>2</sup> who takes the place
<div n="lb"/>of the husband at the funeral rite, and who, as in the Hebraic
<div n="lb"/>levirate, is to beget a child by the brother's wife if there is
<div n="lb"/>no son.<sup>3</sup> Hillebrandt<sup>4</sup> and Lanman<sup>5</sup> consider that the word
<div n="lb"/>originally meant only ‘wooer,’ and applied to the king who,
<div n="lb"/>after the chief queen had lain beside the dead victim in the
<div n="lb"/>Puruṣamedha or ‘human sacrifice,’ claimed her again; but this
<div n="lb"/>view is hardly plausible.<sup>6</sup> The term is also applied to the god
<div n="lb"/>Pūṣan<sup>7</sup> as the wooer of his mother, apparently Sūryā.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) x. 18, 18 = Av. xviii. 3, 2 (where
<div n="lb"/>{%didhiṣus%} is merely a bad reading) =
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, vi. 1, 3.</F>
<F>2) Āśvalāyana Śrauta Sūtra, iv. 2, 18,
<div n="lb"/>where are mentioned the brother-in-law
<div n="lb"/>({%devṛ%}), a representative of the husband
<div n="lb"/>(there is nothing to show whether he
<div n="lb"/>is identical with the preceding or not),
<div n="lb"/>a pupil, or an aged servant ({%jarad-dāsa%}).</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Rv. x. 40, 2; Kaegi, {%Der Rigveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>n. 51.</F>

<L>1311<pc>1-359<k1>diDizUpati<k2>diDizUpati
{@Didhiṣū-pati@}¦ occurs in the Kāṭhaka<sup>1</sup> and Kapiṣṭhala Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitās,<sup>2</sup> as well as in the Āpastamba,<sup>3</sup> Gautama,<sup>4</sup> and Vasiṣṭha
[Page1-360+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>Dharma Sūtras,<sup>5</sup> in lists of people who have committed sin
<div n="lb"/>({%enas%}). The traditional rendering<sup>6</sup> is ‘husband of a woman
<div n="lb"/>married a second time’; Manu<sup>7</sup> seems to apply the term to the
<div n="lb"/>brother-in-law who is ‘married’ to his sister-in-law after his
<div n="lb"/>brother's death for the purpose of begetting a child, if he
<div n="lb"/>displays conjugal affection to her ({%anurajyate kāmataḥ%}).<sup>8</sup> This
<div n="lb"/>sense would be possible, since {@Didhiṣu@} denotes a ‘wooer,’ and
<div n="lb"/>a widow could be regarded as a ‘wooer’ when able to control
<div n="lb"/>her own choice of a spouse. But another tradition<sup>9</sup> holds that
<div n="lb"/>Didhiṣū means the elder sister whose younger sister has
<div n="lb"/>married before her. This view is supported by a passage in the
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭha Dharma Sūtra,<sup>10</sup> and by the use of the word {%agre-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%didhiṣū-pati,%}<sup>11</sup> which must mean the ‘husband of a younger
<div n="lb"/>sister married before the elder.’ In this case also Didhiṣū
<div n="lb"/>would mean ‘wooer,’ the elder sister being so called because,
<div n="lb"/>if her parents do not arrange a marriage for her, she is,
<div n="lb"/>according to Viṣṇu,<sup>12</sup> to make her own choice of a husband
<div n="lb"/>({%kuryāt svayaṃvaram%}). See also {@Edidhiṣuḥpati@} and {@Daidhi-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@ṣavya.@}
<F>1) xxxi. 7, quoted in Delbrück, {%Die%}
<div n="lb"/>{%indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,%}
<div n="lb"/>579.</F>

<L>1312<pc>1-360<k1>div<k2>div
{@Div,@}¦ ‘sky.’ The world as a whole is regarded as divided
<div n="lb"/>into the three domains of ‘earth,’ ‘air’ or ‘atmosphere,’ and
<div n="lb"/>‘heaven’ or ‘sky’ ({%div%}),<sup>1</sup> or alternatively into ‘heaven and
<div n="lb"/>earth’ ({%dyāvā-pṛthivī%}),<sup>2</sup> which two are then considered as com-
<div n="lb"/>prising the universe, the atmosphere being included in the sky.
<div n="lb"/>Lightning, wind, and rain belong to the atmosphere, solar and
[Page1-361+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>similar phenomena to the sky. In some passages<sup>3</sup> the vault
<div n="lb"/>({%nāka%}) of the sky is added after the usual triad, and before the
<div n="lb"/>celestial light ({%svar, jyotis%}).
<div n="P"/>The threefold division of the universe is reflected in a three-
<div n="lb"/>fold division of the three elements — earth, air, and sky. Thus
<div n="lb"/>a highest ({%uttama,%}<sup>4</sup> {%uttara,%}<sup>5</sup> {%pārya%}<sup>6</sup> ), a middle, and a lowest
<div n="lb"/>heaven are specified.<sup>4</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> the three heavens
<div n="lb"/>are distinguished as ‘rich in water’ ({%udanvatī%}), as {%pīlumatī%} (of
<div n="lb"/>uncertain meaning), and as the {%pradyaus,%} where the Fathers sit.
<div n="lb"/>Heaven is frequently called {%vyoman%} as well as {%rocana%}<sup>8</sup> (properly
<div n="lb"/>the ‘luminous space’ of heaven), and the dividing firmament
<div n="lb"/>which separates the visible upper world from the highest
<div n="lb"/>heaven is called, besides {%nāka,%} ‘vault,’ {%sānu,%} ‘summit,’ {%viṣṭap,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘surface,’ and {%pṛṣṭha,%} ‘ridge,’ and even ‘ridge of the vault,’<sup>9</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>‘summit of the vault.’<sup>10</sup>
<div n="P"/>Similarly three atmospheres ({%rajas%}), or oftener two, are
<div n="lb"/>alluded to,<sup>11</sup> but the division here is merely artificial. In one
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>12</sup> six {%rajāṃsi,%} ‘regions,’ are referred to, the heavens
<div n="lb"/>and the earths no doubt being meant. The usual name for the
<div n="lb"/>atmosphere is {%antarikṣa.%}
<div n="P"/>The three earths are equally artificial, the origin of the triad
<div n="lb"/>being probably the use of {%pṛthivī%} in the plural<sup>13</sup> to denote the
<div n="lb"/>three divisions of the universe (just as {%pitarau,%} ‘two fathers,’
<div n="lb"/>denotes ‘father and mother’).<sup>14</sup> The earth is called {%kṣam, kṣā,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%gmā,%} or designated by the epithets {%mahī,%} ‘the great,’ {%pṛthivī%} or
<div n="lb"/>{%urvī,%} ‘the broad,’ {%uttānā,%} ‘the extended,’ and is regularly con-
<div n="lb"/>trasted as {%idam,%} ‘this world here,’ with the upper sphere.<sup>15</sup>
[Page1-362+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>The shape of the earth is compared with a wheel in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>16</sup> and is expressly called ‘circular’ ({%pari-maṇḍala%}) in
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>17</sup> When earth is conjoined with
<div n="lb"/>heaven, the two are conceived as great bowls ({%camvā%}) turned
<div n="lb"/>towards each other.<sup>18</sup> In the Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>19</sup> the two are
<div n="lb"/>regarded as halves of an egg. The distance of heaven from
<div n="lb"/>the earth is given by the Atharvaveda<sup>20</sup> as a thousand days'
<div n="lb"/>journey for the sun-bird, by the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>21</sup> as a
<div n="lb"/>thousand days' journey for a horse, while the Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>22</sup> whimsically estimates the distance as equivalent
<div n="lb"/>to a thousand cows standing one on the top of the other.
<div n="P"/>According to Zimmer,<sup>23</sup> the Vedic poets conceived the
<div n="lb"/>atmosphere to be above the earth in its upper division only,
<div n="lb"/>but below it in its lower stratum. The evidence,<sup>24</sup> however, for
<div n="lb"/>the latter assumption is quite insufficient.<sup>25</sup> The theory of
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>26</sup> is that the sun merely reverses its
<div n="lb"/>bright side at night, turning its light on the stars and the moon
<div n="lb"/>while it retraverses its course to the east; and it has been
<div n="lb"/>shown<sup>25</sup> that this is probably the doctrine of the Rigveda also.<sup>27</sup>
<div n="lb"/>literature. The Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>See also {@Sūrya@} and {@Candramās.@} For the Vedic knowledge
<div n="lb"/>of the planets, see {@Graha.@}
<div n="P"/>There is no geographical division of the earth in Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature. The Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa<sup>28</sup> states that
<div n="lb"/>the centre of the earth is a span north of the {@Plakṣa Prāsravaṇā,@}
<div n="lb"/>and that the centre of the sky is the constellation of the seven
<div n="lb"/>Ṛṣis, the Great Bear. For the quarters, see {@Diś.@}

<L>1313<pc>1-363<k1>divodAsaatiTigva<k2>divodAsaatiTigva
{@Divodāsa Atithigva@}¦ is one of the leading princes of the
<div n="lb"/>early Vedic age. He was a son of Vadhryaśva,<sup>1</sup> and father,
<div n="lb"/>or more probably grandfather, of {@Sudās,@} the famous king of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Tṛtsu@} family, among the {@Bharatas.@} Probably Pijavana was
<div n="lb"/>the son and Sudās the grandson. Divodāsa was naturally a
<div n="lb"/>{@Bharata,@}<sup>2</sup> and, like Sudās, was an opponent of the {@Turvaśas@}
<div n="lb"/>and {@Yadus.@}<sup>3</sup> His great enemy was {@Śambara,@} the {@Dāsa,@} who
<div n="lb"/>was apparently chief of a mountain people,<sup>4</sup> and whom he
<div n="lb"/>repeatedly defeated.<sup>5</sup> He was also, it seems, like his father
<div n="lb"/>Vadhryaśva,<sup>6</sup> an energetic supporter of the fire ritual, for Agni
<div n="lb"/>is once called by his name in the Rigveda.<sup>7</sup> On the other hand,
<div n="lb"/>he was defeated, with {@Āyu@} and {@Kutsa,@} by Indra's aid. In
<div n="lb"/>several passages he seems closely connected with the singer
<div n="lb"/>family, the {@Bharadvājas.@}<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>From one passage,<sup>9</sup> where Divodāsa is said to have fought
<div n="lb"/>against the {@Paṇis,@} the {@Pārāvatas,@} and {@Bṛsaya,@} Hillebrandt<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>has inferred that he was engaged in conflicts with the tribes
<div n="lb"/>of Arachosia, and interpreting the name as the ‘heavenly
<div n="lb"/>Dāsa’<sup>11</sup> conjectures that he was himself a Dāsa. This con-
<div n="lb"/>clusion is not probable, for the {@Sarasvatī@} on which the battle
<div n="lb"/>in question took place, and which can hardly be the Haraqaiti
<div n="lb"/>of Arachosia, would naturally designate the later Sarasvatī,
<div n="lb"/>while the Pārāvatas are mentioned in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa,<sup>12</sup> as in the east, about the {@Yamunā.@} Bergaigne's
[Page1-364+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>opinion<sup>13</sup> that Divodāsa and Atithigva were different people
<div n="lb"/>cannot be supported in view of the complete parallelism in the
<div n="lb"/>acts of the two persons.<sup>14</sup> See also {@Pratardana.@}
<div n="P"/>The people of Divodāsa are referred to in a hymn of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>15</sup>

<L>1315<pc>1-364<k1>divya<k2>divya
{@Divya,@}¦ ‘ordeal,’ is a term not found until the later literature,
<div n="lb"/>but several references to the practice of ordeals have been seen
<div n="lb"/>in Vedic literature. The fire ordeal seen in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>by Schlagintweit,<sup>2</sup> Weber,<sup>3</sup> Ludwig,<sup>4</sup> Zimmer,<sup>5</sup> and others, has
<div n="lb"/>been disproved by Grill,<sup>6</sup> Bloomfield,<sup>7</sup> and Whitney.<sup>8</sup> But such
<div n="lb"/>an ordeal appears in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>9</sup> and an ordeal
<div n="lb"/>with a glowing axe<sup>10</sup> occurs in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad as
<div n="lb"/>applied in an accusation of theft. Geldner<sup>11</sup> suggests that this
<div n="lb"/>usage is referred to even in the Rigveda,<sup>12</sup> but this is most
<div n="lb"/>improbable.<sup>13</sup> Ludwig<sup>14</sup> and Griffith<sup>15</sup> discover in another
[Page1-365+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Rigveda<sup>16</sup> references to {@Dīrghatamas'@} having
<div n="lb"/>been subjected to the fire and water ordeals, but this view
<div n="lb"/>cannot be supported. According to Weber,<sup>17</sup> the ‘balance’
<div n="lb"/>ordeal is referred to in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>18</sup> but see {@Tulā.@}
<F>1) ii. 12.</F>
<F>2) {%Die Gottesurtheile der Indier,%} 13 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Studien,%} 13, 168.</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 445.</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 184.</F>
<F>6) {%Hundert Lieder,%}^2 45, 87.</F>
<F>7) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 13, ccxxi; {%American Journal of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Philology,%} 11, 334, 335; {%Hymns of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Atharvaveda,%} 294.</F>
<F>8) Translation of the Atharvaveda.
<div n="lb"/>54.</F>
<F>9) xiv. 6, 6.</F>

<L>1317<pc>1-365<k1>diS<k2>diS
{@Diś,@}¦ ‘direction,’ is a word very frequently used in the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>and later<sup>1</sup> to denote a quarter of the sky. As a general rule,
<div n="lb"/>four quarters are mentioned — east, south, west, north.<sup>2</sup> But
<div n="lb"/>the number of the ‘directions’ is sometimes increased up to
<div n="lb"/>ten by the addition to these four of various others. The five
<div n="lb"/>points include the zenith ({%ūrdhvā%});<sup>3</sup> the six, the zenith and
<div n="lb"/>the nadir ({%ūrdhvā%} and {%avācī%});<sup>4</sup> the seven, the zenith, the
<div n="lb"/>ground on which one stands ({%dhruvā%}), and the air ({%antarikṣa%})
<div n="lb"/>between these two ({%vyadhvā%});<sup>5</sup> the eight include the inter-
<div n="lb"/>mediate quarters (S.E., S.W., N.E., N.W.);<sup>6</sup> the nine add to
<div n="lb"/>these the zenith;<sup>7</sup> the ten, zenith and nadir.<sup>8</sup> The number
[Page1-366+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>five is sometimes made up by the ground beneath the observer's
<div n="lb"/>feet ({%dhruvā%}),<sup>9</sup> and the number six by that point ({%dhruvā%}) and
<div n="lb"/>the zenith ({%ūrdhvā%});<sup>10</sup> the ‘lofty’ ({%bṛhatī%})<sup>11</sup> sometimes taking
<div n="lb"/>the place of the ‘vertical’ ({%ūrdhvā%}).
<F>1) Rv. i. 124, 3; 183, 5; iii. 30, 12;
<div n="lb"/>Av. iii. 31, 4; xi. 2, 12, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vii. 72, 5; x. 36, 14; 42, 11;
<div n="lb"/>Av. xv. 2, 1 {%et seq.,%} etc.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 15;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 8, 9.</F>
<F>4) Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 8;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 24; Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iv. 2, 4.</F>
<F>5) Rv. ix. 114, 3; Av. iv. 40, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vii. 4, 1, 20;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 5, 2, 8; Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, i. 7.</F>
<F>6) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 15;
<div n="lb"/>Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 8, 1, 40, etc.</F>
<F>7) Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xvi.
<div n="lb"/>28, 2.</F>
<F>8) Rv. i. 164, 14; viii. 101, 13; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, vi. 2, 2, 34; viii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>2, 13, etc.</F>
<F>9) Av. viii. 9, 15; xiii. 3, 6; xv. 14,
<div n="lb"/>1-5; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 32;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ix. 4, 3, 10, and
<div n="lb"/>{%cf.%} {@Dhruvā.@}</F>
<F>10) Av. iii. 27, 1; iv. 14, 8; xii. 3,
<div n="lb"/>55; xv. 4, 1 {%et seq.;%} xviii. 3, 34;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 14, etc. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Rv. x. 14, 16.</F>
<F>11) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 13,
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvii. 8.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 359;
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Proceedings of the Berlin Academy,%}
<div n="lb"/>1895, 846; {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 293.

<div n="lb"/>tionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
