<L>1318<pc>1-366<k1>dIrGatamas<k2>dIrGatamas
{@Dīrgha-tamas@}¦ (‘long darkness’) {@Māmateya@} (‘son of Mamatā’)
<div n="lb"/>{@Aucathya@} (‘son of Ucatha’) is mentioned as a singer in one
<div n="lb"/>hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and is referred to in several passages<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>by his metronymic, Māmateya, alone. He is said, both in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and in the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka,<sup>3</sup> to have attained
<div n="lb"/>the tenth decade of life. In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> he
<div n="lb"/>appears as the priest of {@Bharata.@} The Bṛhaddevatā<sup>5</sup> contains
<div n="lb"/>a preposterous legend made up of fragments of the Rigveda,<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>according to which Dīrghatamas was born blind, but recovered
<div n="lb"/>his sight; in old age he was thrown into a river by his servants,
<div n="lb"/>one of whom, {@Traitana,@} attacked him, but killed himself
<div n="lb"/>instead. Carried down by the stream, he was cast up in the
<div n="lb"/>Aṅga country, where he married Uśij, a slave girl, and begot
<div n="lb"/>{@Kakṣīvant.@} The two legends here combined are not even con-
<div n="lb"/>sistent, for the second ignores Dīrghatamas' recovery of sight.
<div n="lb"/>To attach any historical importance to them, as does Pargiter,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>would seem to be unwise.
<F>1) i. 158, 1. 6.</F>
<F>2) i. 147, 3; 152, 6; iv. 4, 13. In
<div n="lb"/>viii. 9, 10, Dīrghatamas is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>with Kakṣīvant, but not as a relative.</F>
<F>1) i. 158, 1. 6.</F>
<F>3) ii. 17; Keith, {%Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaha,%}
<div n="lb"/>14.</F>
<F>4) viii. 23.</F>
<F>5) iv. 11-15; 21-25, with Macdonell's
<div n="lb"/>notes.</F>
<F>6) From i. 140-164, which hymns are
<div n="lb"/>traditionally attributed to Dīrghatamas.
<div n="lb"/>But see Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Deutschen Morgenländischn Gesellschaft,%}
<div n="lb"/>42, 221.</F>
<F>7) {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society.%}
<div n="lb"/>1910, 44.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rig
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 164, 165; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%}
<div n="lb"/>1^2, 226, 232, 247, 268, 279.</F>

<L>1322<pc>1-367<k1>dIrGAyutva<k2>dIrGAyutva
{@Dīrghāyutva,@}¦ ‘longevity,’ is a constant object of the prayers
<div n="lb"/>of the Vedic Indians,<sup>1</sup> and length of life is never deprecated in
<div n="lb"/>the Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas, while the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> is full
<div n="lb"/>of spells intended to prolong existence ({%āyuṣyāṇi%}).
<F>1) Rv. x. 62, 2; Av. i. 22, 2, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 6; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, i. 9, 1, 13, etc. So
<div n="lb"/>the adjective {%dīrghāyus,%} Rv. iv. 15, 9.
<div n="lb"/>10; x. 85, 39; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xii. 100, etc. The Brāhmaṇas regularly
<div n="lb"/>express the reward for ritual actions
<div n="lb"/>by the phrase {%sarvam āyur eti,%} ‘he lives
<div n="lb"/>all his days.’ The ideal of life is 100
<div n="lb"/>years. See Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 17,
<div n="lb"/>193; {%Festgruss an Roth,%} 137; Lanman,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sanskrit Reader,%} 384.</F>
<F>2) ii. 13; 28; 29; vii. 32, and many
<div n="lb"/>other hymns. See Bloomfield, {%Hymns%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Atharvaveda,%} 49 {%et seq.; Atharva-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%veda,%} 63-65.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1326<pc>1-368<k1>dunduBi<k2>dunduBi
{@Dundubhi,@}¦ apparently an onomatopoetic word, means ‘drum,’
<div n="lb"/>as used in both war and peace. It is often mentioned from
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards.<sup>2</sup> A special sort of drum was the ‘earth
<div n="lb"/>drum,’ made by digging a hole in the ground and covering it
<div n="lb"/>with a hide. This was employed in the Mahāvrata, a rite
<div n="lb"/>performed at the winter solstice, for the purpose of driving
<div n="lb"/>away influences hostile to the return of the sun.<sup>3</sup> A ‘drum-
<div n="lb"/>beater’ is included in the list of sacrificial victims at the
<div n="lb"/>Puruṣamedha or ‘human sacrifice.’<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) i. 28, 5; vi. 47, 29. 31.</F>

<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 3, 6, 2; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,

<div n="lb"/>the drum,’ Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi.
<div n="lb"/>35.</F>

<L>1330<pc>1-369<k1>durgaha<k2>durgaha

<div n="lb"/>his grandsons are lauded for their generosity, though Sāyaṇa
<div n="lb"/>renders the word adjectivally.<sup>2</sup> In another passage of the

<div n="lb"/>interpretation. On the other hand, the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup>

<div n="lb"/>Dadhikrāvan, with Pischel<sup>7</sup> and Ludwig,<sup>8</sup> a real horse, the
<div n="lb"/>charger of Trasadasyu. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa's inter-
<div n="lb"/>pretation of Daurgaha is, however, doubtful, and cannot be
<div n="lb"/>regarded as receiving support from the case of Dadhikrāvan,
<div n="lb"/>who was probably a divinity, and not a real horse at all.<sup>9</sup>

<div n="lb"/>Sarasvatī are the scene of special sacrifices. In Manu<sup>4</sup> these
<div n="lb"/>two rivers form the western boundary of the Middle Country.

<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as the ancestor of {@Sudās,@} apparently his grand-
<div n="lb"/>father; or if {@Pijavana@} be accepted as Sudās' father, and
<div n="lb"/>{@Divodāsa@} as his grandfather, then his great-great-grandfather,
<div n="lb"/>and father of {@Vadhryaśva.@} The succession in the latter case
<div n="lb"/>would then be Devavant, Vadhryaśva, Divodāsa, Pijavana,
<div n="lb"/>Sudās.
<F>1) vii. 18, 22. {%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 171; Geldner,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 138.</F>
<LEND>
[Page1-377+ 38]

<L>1375<pc>1-377<k1>devApiArzwizeRa<k2>devApiArzwizeRa
{@Devāpi Ārṣṭiṣeṇa@}¦ (‘descendant of Ṛṣṭiṣeṇa’) is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and in the Nirukta.<sup>2</sup> According to
<div n="lb"/>the latter source there were two brothers, {@Devāpi@} and {@Śantanu,@}
<div n="lb"/>princes of the Kurus. The elder was Devāpi, but Śantanu got
<div n="lb"/>himself anointed king, whereupon no rain fell for twelve years.
<div n="lb"/>The drought being attributed by the Brahmins to his having
<div n="lb"/>superseded his elder brother, Śantanu offered the kingdom to
<div n="lb"/>Devāpi. The latter, however, refused, but acting as Purohita,
<div n="lb"/>or domestic priest, for his brother, obtained rain. The Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>devatā<sup>3</sup> tells much the same tale, but adds that the reason for
<div n="lb"/>Devāpi's exclusion from the throne was the fact that he suffered
<div n="lb"/>from a skin disease. The Epic and later legends further
[Page1-378+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>develop the story, presenting two somewhat discrepant accounts.
<div n="lb"/>According to the one version,<sup>4</sup> the ground of Devāpi's being
<div n="lb"/>passed over was leprosy, while in the other his devoting
<div n="lb"/>himself to asceticism in his youth was the cause of his brother's
<div n="lb"/>taking his place. The Epic,<sup>5</sup> moreover, treats him as a son of
<div n="lb"/>Pratīpa, and names as his brothers Bāhlīka<sup>6</sup> and Āṛṣṭiṣeṇa,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>who is a new figure developed from the patronymic of Devāpi
<div n="lb"/>Possibly Sieg<sup>8</sup> is right in holding that two stories, those of
<div n="lb"/>Devāpi, Pratīpa's son, and of Devāpi, Ṛṣṭiṣeṇa's son, have been
<div n="lb"/>confused; but in any case it is impossible to extract history
<div n="lb"/>from them.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Rigvedic hymn certainly appears to represent Devāpi
<div n="lb"/>as sacrificing for Śantanu, who seems to be called {@Aulāna.@}<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>But there is no trace in it of the brotherhood of the two men,
<div n="lb"/>nor is there anything to show that Devāpi was not a Brahmin,
<div n="lb"/>but a Kṣatriya. Sieg,<sup>11</sup> who interprets the hymn by the
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta, thinks that he was a Kṣatriya, but on this occasion
<div n="lb"/>was enabled by the favour of Bṛhaspati to officiate as priest,
<div n="lb"/>and that the hymn shows clear recognition of the unusual
<div n="lb"/>character of his action; but this view seems very improbable.
<F>1) x. 98.</F>
<F>2) ii. 10.</F>
<F>3) vii. 148 {%et seq.,%} with Macdonell's
<div n="lb"/>notes.</F>
<F>4) Mahābhārata, v. 5054 {%et seq.%} (= 149,
<div n="lb"/>15 {%et seq.%}), where Śāntanu is (as also in
<div n="lb"/>the Agni, cclxxvii. 34, the Brahma,
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 114, 118, and the Viṣṇu Purāṇas)
<div n="lb"/>the form of the name; Matsya Purāṇa,
<div n="lb"/>l, 39 {%et seq.,%} in which, as well as in the
<div n="lb"/>Bhāgavata, ix. 22, 12, 13, and the
<div n="lb"/>Vāyu Purāṇa, xcix. 234, 237, the form
<div n="lb"/>is Śantanu.</F>
<F>5) Mahābhārata, i. 3751 (= 94, 62);
<div n="lb"/>ix. 2285 (= 40, 1); Vāyu Purāṇa,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 37, 230, etc.</F>
<F>6) Mahābhārata, cited in n. 4; Hari-
<div n="lb"/>vaṃśa, 1819.</F>
<F>7) {%Ibid.,%} cited in n. 5.</F>
<F>8) {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 136.</F>
<F>9) As does Pargiter, {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1910, 52, 53.</F>
<F>10) Rv. x. 98, 11.</F>
<F>11) {%Op. cit.,%} 129-142.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 272
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.;%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 203;
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3,
<div n="lb"/>192 {%et seq.;%} Macdonell, {%Bṛhaddevatā,%} 1,
<div n="lb"/>xxix; Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 131,
<div n="lb"/>132.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1376<pc>1-378<k1>devf<k2>devf
{@Devṛ@}¦ is a rare word denoting the wife's ‘brother-in-law’
<div n="lb"/>(that is, the husband's brother). He is included with the
<div n="lb"/>sisters of the husband among those over whom the wife of the
<div n="lb"/>husband — his elder brother — rules;<sup>1</sup> at the same time the wife
<div n="lb"/>is to be devoted to him,<sup>2</sup> and friendly to him.<sup>3</sup> After the death
[Page1-379+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>of the husband the Devṛ could perform the duty of begetting
<div n="lb"/>a son for him.<sup>4</sup> No word occurs for the wife's brother
<div n="lb"/>corresponding to Devṛ.
<F>1) Rv. x. 85, 46. {%Cf.%} {@Pati.@}</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 85, 44.</F>
<F>3) Av. xiv. 2, 18. {%Cf.%} xiv. 1, 39.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 40, 2. {%Cf.%} x. 18, 8; Kaegi,
<div n="lb"/>{%Der Rigveda,%} n. 51; Lanman, {%Sanskrit%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Reader,%} 385; Whitney, Translation of
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda, 948. {%Cf.%} Delbrück,
<div n="lb"/>{%Die indogermanischen Verwandtschafts-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%namen,%} 516.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1377<pc>1-379<k1>deSa<k2>deSa
{@Deśa,@}¦ ‘land,’ is a word that does not come into use till the
<div n="lb"/>time of the Upaniṣads and Sūtras,<sup>1</sup> excepting one occurrence
<div n="lb"/>in the latest period of the Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> literature, and one in
<div n="lb"/>a much-discussed passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<sup>3</sup> where
<div n="lb"/>the {@Sarasvatī@} is mentioned as having five tributaries. This
<div n="lb"/>passage militates against the view that Sarasvatī was a name
<div n="lb"/>of the Indus, because the use of Deśa here seems to indicate<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>that the seer of the verse placed the Sarasvatī in the Madhya-
<div n="lb"/>deśa or ‘Middle Country,’ to which all the geographical data
<div n="lb"/>of the Yajurvedas point.<sup>5</sup>
<F>1) Where its use becomes common;
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iv. 1, 16;
<div n="lb"/>2, 3; Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, iv. 14,
<div n="lb"/>6; Kātyāyana Srauta Sūtra, xv. 4, 17,
<div n="lb"/>etc. So the adjective {%deśīya,%} ‘belong-
<div n="lb"/>ing to a land,’ Kātyāyana, xxii. 4, 22;
<div n="lb"/>Lāṭyāyana Srauta Sūtra, viii. 6, 28.</F>
<F>2) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 10 (a late
<div n="lb"/>passage).</F>
<F>3) xxxiv. 11.</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 10,
<div n="lb"/>who thinks that the word crept into
<div n="lb"/>the text, where the Sarasvatī originally
<div n="lb"/>meant the Indus, with the five tribu-
<div n="lb"/>taries of the Panjab.</F>
<F>5) Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>174.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1384<pc>1-380<k1>dEvavAta<k2>dEvavAta
{@Daiva-vāta,@}¦ ‘descendant of {@Devavāta,@}’ is the patronymic of
<div n="lb"/>{@Sṛñjaya,@} probably the Sṛñjaya king, in the Rigveda. He is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned<sup>1</sup> as a devotee of the fire cult, and as victorious over
<div n="lb"/>the {@Turvaśa@} king and the {@Vṛcīvants.@}<sup>2</sup> According to Zimmer,<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>his name was {@Abhyāvartin Cāyamāna Pārthava@} (‘descendant
<div n="lb"/>of Pṛthu’), but Hillebrandt<sup>4</sup> recognizes this as doubtful, though
<div n="lb"/>he none the less places the Sṛñjayas to the west of the Indus
<div n="lb"/>with {@Divodāsa.@} What is more important is to note that the
<div n="lb"/>name suggests connexion with the Bharata {@Devavāta,@} and as
<div n="lb"/>{@Kurus@} and Sṛñjayas were closely connected<sup>5</sup> this is not
<div n="lb"/>immaterial.
<F>1) Rv. iv. 15, 4.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 27, 7.</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 133, 134.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 105, 106.</F>
<F>5) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 4, 4, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Buddha,%} 402, 405;
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>3, 153.</F>

<L>1397<pc>1-382<k1>dyotana<k2>dyotana
{@Dyotana@}¦ is, according to Sāyaṇa, the name of a prince in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> This is probably correct, though the word may
<div n="lb"/>also<sup>2</sup> be interpreted as denoting ‘glorification’ but it is not
<div n="lb"/>clear what relation existed between Dyotana and the other
<div n="lb"/>persons mentioned in the same passage, {@Vetasu, Daśoṇi,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Tūtuji,@} and {@Tugra.@}

<L>1398<pc>1-383<k1>drapsa<k2>drapsa
{@Drapsa@}¦ is a common word from the Rigveda onwards<sup>1</sup> for
<div n="lb"/>a ‘drop’: according to Sāyaṇa,<sup>2</sup> a ‘thick drop’ as opposed to
<div n="lb"/>{%stoka,%} a ‘small drop.’ Hence there frequently occurs the ex-
<div n="lb"/>pression {%dadḥi-drapsa,%}’ ‘drop of curds.’<sup>3</sup> In the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> the word
<div n="lb"/>normally denotes the thick drops of Soma or the Soma itself.
<div n="P"/>In two passages<sup>5</sup> Roth<sup>6</sup> sees the sense of ‘banner,’ which is
<div n="lb"/>adopted by Oldenberg.<sup>7</sup> Geldner,<sup>8</sup> on the other hand, con-
<div n="lb"/>siders that ‘dust’ is meant, but this interpretation is not very
<div n="lb"/>probable. Max Müller<sup>9</sup> renders the word ‘rain-drop’ in one
<div n="lb"/>of the passages.
<F>1) Rv. i. 94, 11 (perhaps a ‘drop’ of
<div n="lb"/>fire); v. 63, 4 (‘rain-drop’); vii. 33,
<div n="lb"/>11 (= {%retas%}); Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vi. 1,
<div n="lb"/>2, 6; {%drapsin%} (‘thick-flowing’), xi. 4,
<div n="lb"/>1, 15.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, 1, p. 70, 7.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} the epithet {%uru-drapsa,%} Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 10, 2; Sāyaṇa, on
<div n="lb"/>Av. xviii. 4, 18, takes {%drapsa%} to mean
<div n="lb"/>‘drops of curd’; so Agnisvāmin on
<div n="lb"/>Lāṭyāyana Śrauta Sūtra, iii. 2, 4.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ix. 2, 3,
<div n="lb"/>40.</F>
<F>4) ix. 78, 4; 85, 10; 89, 2; 97, 56;
<div n="lb"/>108, 8; x. 11, 4; 17, 11. 12. {%Cf.%} Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 9. 1.</F>
<F>5) iv. 13, 2, and {%drapsin%} in i. 64, 2.</F>
<F>6) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%satvan;%} Böhtlingk, Dictionary, {%s.v.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%drapsa, drapsin.%}</F>
<F>7) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 46, 357:
<div n="lb"/>{%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 64, 65.</F>

<L>1401<pc>1-384<k1>druGaRa<k2>druGaRa

<L>1406<pc>1-385<k1>druhyu<k2>druhyu
{@Druhyu@}¦ is the name of a people mentioned several times in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda. In one passage<sup>1</sup> it occurs, in the plural, with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Yadus, Turvaśas, Anus,@} and {@Pūrus,@} suggesting that these are
<div n="lb"/>the famous five peoples of the Rigveda.<sup>2</sup> Again, the Druhyu
<div n="lb"/>king shared in the defeat of his allies by {@Sudās,@} and appears to
<div n="lb"/>have perished in the waters.<sup>3</sup> In a second passage Druhyu,
<div n="lb"/>Anu, Turvaśa, and Yadu are all mentioned in the singular,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>while in another Pūru and Druhyu occur.<sup>5</sup> From the tribal
<div n="lb"/>grouping it is probable that the Druhyus were a north-western
<div n="lb"/>people,<sup>6</sup> and the later tradition of the Epic connects Gāndhāra
<div n="lb"/>and Druhyu.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) i. 108, 8.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 122,
<div n="lb"/>125; Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 15, 258 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) vii. 18.</F>
<F>4) viii. 10, 5.</F>
<F>5) vi. 46, 8.</F>
<F>6) Roth, {%Zur Litteratur und Geschichte%}
<div n="lb"/>{%des Weda,%} 131-133.</F>

<div n="lb"/>veda,<sup>1</sup> but only metaphorically of the clouds in the atmosphere.
<div n="lb"/>Dhanū is found in the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> where it seems to denote
<div n="lb"/>a sandbag used to prevent bleeding.<sup>3</sup> {%Cf.%} {@Dhanvan.@}
<F>1) i. 33, 4; 144, 5; viii. 3, 19; x. 4, 3;
<div n="lb"/>27, 17.</F>
<F>2) i. 17, 4.</F>
<F>3) Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 4, 411;
<div n="lb"/>Whitney, Translation of the Atharva-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 18; Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Atharvaveda,%} 259, 260.</F>

<L>1427<pc>1-388<k1>Danus<k2>Danus
{@Dhanus,@}¦ the ‘bow,’ frequently mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later,<sup>2</sup> was the chief weapon of the Vedic Indian.<sup>3</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>last act of the funeral rite included the removal of the bow from
[Page1-389+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>the right hand of the dead man.<sup>4</sup> The weapon was composed
<div n="lb"/>of a stout staff bent into a curved shape ({%vakra%}),<sup>5</sup> and of a bow-
<div n="lb"/>string ({@Jyā@}) made of a strip of cowhide<sup>6</sup> which joined the ends.
<div n="lb"/>The tips of the bow, when the string was fastened, were called
<div n="lb"/>{@Ārtnī.@} Relaxed when not in actual use, the bow was specially
<div n="lb"/>strung up when needed for shooting.<sup>7</sup> The stages of the
<div n="lb"/>process are given in detail in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā:<sup>8</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>stringing ({%ā-tan%}) of the bow, the placing ({%prati-dhā%}) of the
<div n="lb"/>arrow, the bending ({%ā-yam%}) of the bow, and the shooting ({%as%}).
<div n="lb"/>The arrow was discharged from the ear,<sup>9</sup> and is hence called
<div n="lb"/>{%karṇa-yoni,%}<sup>10</sup> ‘having the ear as its point of origin.’<sup>10</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>making of bows was a regular profession ({%dhanuṣ-kāra,%}<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{%dhanuṣ-kṛt%}).<sup>12</sup> For the arrow see {@Iṣu,@} and for the handguard
<div n="lb"/>{@Hastaghna.@}
<F>1) viii. 72, 4; 77, 11; ix. 99, 1; x. 18,
<div n="lb"/>9; 125, 6.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 4, 6; 6, 6; v. 18, 8; vii. 50.
<div n="lb"/>9; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 10; Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, vii. 5, 6; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vii. 14; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 5, 4, 6; v. 3, 1, 11, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vi. 75, 2. Practically no other
<div n="lb"/>weapon plays any substantial part in
<div n="lb"/>Vedic warfare.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 18, 9.</F>
<F>5) Av. iv. 6, 4.</F>
<F>6) Rv. vi. 75, 11; Av. i. 2, 3.</F>
<F>7) Rv. x. 166, 3; Av. vi. 42, 1.</F>
<F>8) xvi. 22.</F>
<F>9) Rv. vi. 75, 2 {%et seq.%} So also in the
<div n="lb"/>Epic, Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 271. The Homeric
<div n="lb"/>method is to draw to the breast — {%e.g.,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Iliad,%} iv. 123.</F>
<F>10) Rv. ii. 24, 8.</F>
<F>10) Rv. ii. 24, 8.</F>

<div n="lb"/>299; Hopkins, {%op. cit.,%} 13, 270 {%et seq.%}
<div n="lb"/>The Epic bow is about 5(1/2) feet, and the
<div n="lb"/>arrow 3 feet in length.</F>

<div n="lb"/>and later.<sup>2</sup> Death from thirst in the desert was not rare,<sup>3</sup> and

<L>1431<pc>1-390<k1>DaruRa<k2>DaruRa
{@Dharuṇa@}¦ in one passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (viii. 51)
<div n="lb"/>denotes a ‘sucking calf.’
<LEND>

<L>1432<pc>1-390<k1>Darma<k2>Darma
{@Dharma,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Dharman,@}<sup>2</sup> are the regular words, the latter in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and both later,<sup>2</sup> for ‘law’ or ‘custom.’ But there is
<div n="lb"/>very little evidence in the early literature as to the administra-
<div n="lb"/>tion of justice or the code of law followed. On the other hand,
<div n="lb"/>the Dharma Sūtras<sup>3</sup> contain full particulars.
<div n="P"/>(1) {%Criminal Law.%} — The crimes recognized in Vedic litera-
<div n="lb"/>ture vary greatly in importance, while there is no distinction
<div n="lb"/>adopted in principle between real crimes and what now are
<div n="lb"/>regarded as fanciful bodily defects or infringements of merely
[Page1-391+ 80]
<div n="lb"/>conventional practices.<sup>4</sup> The crimes enumerated include the
<div n="lb"/>slaying of an embryo ({%bhrūṇa%}),<sup>5</sup> the slaying of a man ({%vīra%}),<sup>6</sup> and
<div n="lb"/> the slaying of a Brahmin,<sup>7</sup> a much more serious crime.
<div n="lb"/>Treachery is mentioned in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>8</sup> as being
<div n="lb"/>punishable by death, as it was punished later.<sup>9</sup> But there is no
<div n="lb"/>trace of an organized criminal justice vested either in the
<div n="lb"/>king or in the people. There still seems to have prevailed the
<div n="lb"/>system of wergeld ({@Vaira@}), which indicates that criminal justice
<div n="lb"/>remained in the hands of those who were wronged. In the
<div n="lb"/>Sūtras,<sup>10</sup> on the other hand, the king's peace is recognized as
<div n="lb"/>infringed by crimes, a penalty being paid to him, or, according
<div n="lb"/>to the Brahminical textbooks, to the Brahmins. It may there-
[Page1-392+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>fore reasonably be conjectured that the royal power of jurisdic-
<div n="lb"/>tion steadily increased; the references in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa to the king as wielding punishment ({@Daṇḍa@}) confirm
<div n="lb"/>this supposition. Whether, as the analogy of other systems
<div n="lb"/>suggests, the king was assisted in his judicial duties, as he
<div n="lb"/>undoubtedly was later, by assessors, presumably of the Brahmin
<div n="lb"/>caste, cannot be made out clearly.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>The procedure adopted in deciding cases is quite uncertain.
<div n="lb"/>In the Chāndogya Upaniṣad<sup>12</sup> the ordeal of the red-hot axe is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned as applied in an accusation of theft. It must
<div n="lb"/>apparently be understood to have been inflicted by the direction
<div n="lb"/>of the king. But no other judicial ordeal is known to Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature (see {@Divya@}). The punishment of theft was in some
<div n="lb"/>cases at least death, probably when the thief was taken red-
<div n="lb"/>handed;<sup>13</sup> in other cases binding to posts was the penalty,<sup>14</sup>
<div n="lb"/>presumably accompanied by the return of the stolen goods. In
<div n="lb"/>the Chāndogya Upaniṣad<sup>15</sup> the list of sins given as apparently
<div n="lb"/>equal in wickedness is stealing gold, drinking spirits, defiling a
<div n="lb"/>Guru's bed, and the murder of a Brahmin.
<div n="P"/>(2) {%Civil Law.%} — There is little recorded as to civil law in
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature. The relations of the family and the question
<div n="lb"/>of family property are dealt with under {@Urvarā, Kṣetra, Pati;@}
<div n="lb"/>succession and partition of property are treated under {@Dāya.@}
<div n="lb"/>As regards the transfer of chattels — for land as transferable
<div n="lb"/>{%inter vivos%} is hardly yet recognized, save exceptionally as a
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial fee ({@Dakṣiṇā@}), and then disapproved<sup>16</sup> — the recognized
<div n="lb"/>modes are gift ({@Dāna@}) and barter or sale ({@Kraya@}), which includes
<div n="lb"/>exchange. Original acquisition of land was no doubt brought
[Page1-393+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>about by occupation and apportionment among the tribesmen,<sup>17</sup>
<div n="lb"/>while chattels were acquired by taking possession of them,
<div n="lb"/>provided that they were found on one's own land or on
<div n="lb"/>unoccupied land, and did not belong to any other person
<div n="lb"/>originally. The Sūtras<sup>18</sup> contain rules for the disposal of lost
<div n="lb"/>property, which tend to give it to the king, with the deduction
<div n="lb"/>of a percentage for the finder, unless the latter is a Brahmin,
<div n="lb"/>who keeps it all. As for contract, save in regard to money-
<div n="lb"/>lending (for which see {@Ṛṇa@}), practically nothing is to be gathered
<div n="lb"/>from Vedic literature, doubtless because of the primitive
<div n="lb"/>conditions prevailing in that early period. Much of the labour,
<div n="lb"/>which would in a more developed society have been done by
<div n="lb"/>workers for hire, would be performed by slaves ({%cf.%} {@Dāsa,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Śūdra@}), while the technical workers of the village — of whom
<div n="lb"/>long lists are given in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>19</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>20</sup> — may have been recompensed not by
<div n="lb"/>any sum based on each piece of work done, but by fixed allow-
<div n="lb"/>ances, much as the village servants are in modern times.<sup>21</sup> But
<div n="lb"/>this must remain a matter of conjecture, and it is uncertain
<div n="lb"/>what exact status the carpenter or smith held in the village.
<div n="lb"/>Similarly it is impossible to trace in the early literature any
<div n="lb"/>legal theory or practice as to torts, but rules as to penalties for
<div n="lb"/>insults appear in the Sūtras.<sup>22</sup>
<div n="P"/>Very little is recorded as to procedure. The list<sup>23</sup> of victims
<div n="lb"/>at the Puruṣamedha, or ‘horse sacrifice,’ includes a {%praśnin,%}
<div n="lb"/>an {%abhi-praśnin,%} and a {%praśna-vivāka,%} in whom it is not un-
<div n="lb"/>reasonable to see the plaintiff, the defendant, and the arbitrator
<div n="lb"/>or judge: the terms may refer to what is probably an early
[Page1-394+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>form of judicial procedure, a voluntary arbitration. The same
<div n="lb"/>idea may be conveyed by the word {%madhyama-śī,%} ‘lying in the
<div n="lb"/>midst,’ which occurs in the Rigveda,<sup>24</sup> and which Roth,<sup>25</sup>
<div n="lb"/>followed by Zimmer,<sup>26</sup> understood to mean an arbitrator or
<div n="lb"/>judge, the expression being derived from the judge acting with
<div n="lb"/>other judicial persons,<sup>27</sup> and being surrounded by the assembly
<div n="lb"/>of the people. But this interpretation is uncertain; Whitney<sup>28</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thinks that the word merely alludes to a chief round whom
<div n="lb"/>his men encamp. The king is later the chief civil judge, and
<div n="lb"/>may presumably have been so earlier, no doubt in conjunction
<div n="lb"/>with the elders of the tribe, but for this we are reduced to
<div n="lb"/>conjecture.<sup>29</sup>
<div n="P"/>The use of witnesses as evidence is uncertain (see {@Jñātṛ@}),
<div n="lb"/>and the ordeal is not recorded as deciding any civil matter
<div n="lb"/>except the dispute between {@Vatsa@} and his rival as to the true
<div n="lb"/>Brahminical descent of the former, which was settled by his
<div n="lb"/>walking unharmed through the flame of a fire.<sup>30</sup> But it is
<div n="lb"/>probable on analogy that the ordeal may have been used for
<div n="lb"/>the purpose of deciding disputes. Whether the oath was
<div n="lb"/>so used cannot be certainly shown. It appears, however, that
<div n="lb"/>a Brahmin was preferred in legal matters to a non-Brahmin.<sup>31</sup>
<div n="P"/>There are very few references to police officials: no doubt
<div n="lb"/>the king employed some of his dependents to execute sentences
<div n="lb"/>and arrest offenders (see {@Ugra, Jīvagṛbh@}).
<div n="P"/>(3) {%Morality.%} — It is convenient to notice under this head
[Page1-395+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>several points bearing on the moral condition of the people:
<div n="lb"/>({%a%}) the exposure of children; ({%b%}) the exposure of the aged;
<div n="lb"/>({%c%}) prostitution; ({%d%}) adultery; ({%e%}) incest.
<div n="P"/>({%a%}) The exposure of girl infants is asserted by Zimmer<sup>32</sup> on
<div n="lb"/>the strength of a passage in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,<sup>33</sup> but it
<div n="lb"/>seems clear that the passage has been misunderstood,<sup>34</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>that it refers merely to laying the child aside, not exposing it,
<div n="lb"/>while a boy was lifted up. It is, however, true that the birth
<div n="lb"/>of a girl was not at all popular, not an unnatural sentiment in
<div n="lb"/>an early society, and paralleled among other Āryan peoples.<sup>35</sup>
<div n="P"/>({%b%}) The exposure of the aged is also inferred by Zimmer<sup>36</sup>
<div n="lb"/>from a passage of the Rigveda,<sup>37</sup> and from the mention of
<div n="lb"/>persons exposed ({%ud-hitāḥ%}) in the Atharvaveda.<sup>38</sup> The latter
<div n="lb"/>passage may well refer merely to the bodies being exposed
<div n="lb"/>after death to the elements (as is done by the Parsis). The
<div n="lb"/>former passage merely refers to the individual case of some
<div n="lb"/>person who may have been cast out, and proves absolutely
<div n="lb"/>nothing as to a habitual or recognized custom, nor can such a
<div n="lb"/>custom be inferred from, {%e.g.,%} the legend of {@Cyavāna.@}
<div n="P"/>({%c%}) That prostitution existed in Rigvedic times is certain,
<div n="lb"/>but its extent is disputed. Brotherless girls were frequently
<div n="lb"/>reduced to becoming prostitutes;<sup>39</sup> the putting away of an
<div n="lb"/>illegitimate child is referred to in the Rigveda;<sup>40</sup> besides the
[Page1-396+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>terms {%puṃścalī%}<sup>41</sup> and {%mahānagnī,%}<sup>42</sup> which undoubtedly mean
<div n="lb"/>‘harlot,’ there are other clear references to prostitution;<sup>43</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>expressions like {%kumārī-putra,%} ‘son of a maiden,’<sup>44</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>‘son of an unmarried girl’ ({%agrū%}), spoken of in the Rigveda<sup>45</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as exposed and attacked by animals, point in the same
<div n="lb"/>direction. The Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>46</sup> seems to recognize
<div n="lb"/>prostitution as a profession. Pischel<sup>47</sup> sees many references
<div n="lb"/>to Hetairai in the Rigveda, which as Geldner<sup>48</sup> insists reflects in
<div n="lb"/>its imagery the court life of Indian princes. But the correct-
<div n="lb"/>ness of the view of these two scholars on this point is not by
<div n="lb"/>any means certain.<sup>49</sup>
<div n="P"/>({%d%}) Adultery was generally regarded among Āryan peoples
<div n="lb"/>as a serious offence against the husband of the woman affected.
<div n="lb"/>We accordingly find in the legal literature of India traces of
<div n="lb"/>the rule that an adulterer can be slain with impunity if taken
<div n="lb"/>in the act.<sup>50</sup> Weber,<sup>51</sup> however, has adduced some material
<div n="lb"/>indicating an indifference to these matters in Vedic times, and
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig<sup>52</sup> has adopted the same view. But, as Delbrück<sup>53</sup> has
<div n="lb"/>clearly shown, the evidence is not convincing; the cited pre-
<div n="lb"/>scriptions<sup>54</sup> forbidding connexion with another man's wife
<div n="lb"/>during a certain rite do not imply that such connexion would
<div n="lb"/>otherwise be allowed: the ritual of the Varuṇa-praghāsas,<sup>55</sup>
<div n="lb"/>when a wife names her lover or lovers, seems originally to have
<div n="lb"/>been a solemn means of banishing the evil brought on a family
<div n="lb"/>by a wife's fall; {@Yājñavalkya's@} famous saying<sup>56</sup> that no one
[Page1-397+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>cares whether a wife is ‘unchaste’ ({%paraḥ-puṃsā%}) or not is a
<div n="lb"/>mere mistranslation,<sup>57</sup> the expression {%paraḥ-puṃsā%} really mean-
<div n="lb"/>ing ‘removed from the male persons.’ And the uncertainty
<div n="lb"/>asserted in some passages<sup>58</sup> as to origin from a Ṛṣi is not a
<div n="lb"/>sign of doubtful descent, but is due to the fact that Ṛṣihood
<div n="lb"/>was a difficult matter to ascertain. None the less woman's
<div n="lb"/>position was lowered by the prevalence of polygamy, and such
<div n="lb"/>stories as that of Ahalyā and Indra<sup>59</sup> are not compatible with
<div n="lb"/>a very high standard of morality. A similar conclusion is
<div n="lb"/>pointed to by references in the Yajurveda<sup>60</sup> to relations between
<div n="lb"/>the Ārya man and the Śūdrā woman, and by a spell given in
<div n="lb"/>the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>61</sup> to expiate relations with the
<div n="lb"/>wife of a Śrotriya (Brahmin theologian).
<div n="P"/>({%e%}) Incest was recognized in the marriage of brother and
<div n="lb"/>sister as appears from the legend of Yama and Yamī in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>62</sup> which clearly shows that such a marriage was not
<div n="lb"/>approved by the feeling of the Vedic age. There is also another
<div n="lb"/>hymn<sup>63</sup> in which reference to such intercourse appears to be
<div n="lb"/>made. Mention is further made in the Rigveda<sup>64</sup> to the
<div n="lb"/>wedlock of Prajāpati and his daughter, which is, however,
<div n="lb"/>interpreted mythologically in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>65</sup> an interpre-
<div n="lb"/>tation which may be correct. That incest, however, actually
<div n="lb"/>did take place is clear from the Atharvaveda;<sup>66</sup> but even though
<div n="lb"/>the mythological interpretation of the passage were not justi-
<div n="lb"/>fied, no conclusion could be drawn from the hymn as to the
<div n="lb"/>normal occurrence of such relations.
<F>1) i. 22, 18; 164, 43, 50; iii. 3, 1;
<div n="lb"/>17, 1; 60, 6; v. 26, 6; 63, 7; 72, 2,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Av. xiv. 1, 51; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, x. 29, etc. {%Cf.%} Geldner, {%Rigveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Glossar,%} 90.</F>
<F>2) Dharma is found in Av. xi. 7, 17;
<div n="lb"/>xii. 5, 7; xviii. 3, 1; Taittirīya Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, iii. 5, 2, 2; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xv. 6; xx. 9; xxx. 6, etc.</F>
<F>1) i. 22, 18; 164, 43, 50; iii. 3, 1;
<div n="lb"/>17, 1; 60, 6; v. 26, 6; 63, 7; 72, 2,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Av. xiv. 1, 51; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, x. 29, etc. {%Cf.%} Geldner, {%Rigveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Glossar,%} 90.</F>
<F>2) Dharma is found in Av. xi. 7, 17;
<div n="lb"/>xii. 5, 7; xviii. 3, 1; Taittirīya Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, iii. 5, 2, 2; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xv. 6; xx. 9; xxx. 6, etc.</F>
<F>3) See Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte;%} Foy,
<div n="lb"/>{%Die königliche Gewalt nach den altindischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Rechtsbüchern;%} Bühler, {%Sacred Books of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the East,%} 2 and 14.</F>
<F>4) Compare the list in Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 9; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xxxi. 7; Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvii. 7;
<div n="lb"/>and Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 2, 8, 11
<div n="lb"/>(see Delbrück. {%Die indogermanischen Ver-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%wandtschaftsnamen,%} 579 {%et seq.%}), where
<div n="lb"/>bodily defects (bad nails and discoloured
<div n="lb"/>teeth), marrying a younger daughter
<div n="lb"/>when her elder sister was unmarried,
<div n="lb"/>are coupled with murder, though not
<div n="lb"/>equated with it. See also Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, v. 11, 5, where Aśvapati's

<L>1433<pc>1-397<k1>Dava<k2>Dava<h>1

<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup>

<L>1434<pc>1-398<k1>Dava<k2>Dava<h>2
2. {@Dhava,@}¦ ‘man,’ is not found before the Nirukta.<sup>1</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>word clearly owes its existence merely to {%vidhavā,%} ‘widow,’
<div n="lb"/>wrongly interpreted as {%vi-dhavā,%} ‘without a husband.’
<F>1) iii. 15. {%Cf.%} Naighaṇṭuka, ii. 3.</F>
<LEND>

<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka,<sup>2</sup> denotes a ‘fan’ of hide or leather for
<div n="lb"/>blowing the sacrificial fire.

<L>1438<pc>1-398<k1>DAnya<k2>DAnya
{@Dhānya@}¦ (neut.), a derivative from the preceding word,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>denotes ‘grain’ in general. It is found in the Rigveda<sup>2</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>later.<sup>3</sup> According to the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>4</sup> there are
<div n="lb"/>ten cultivated ({%grāmyāṇi%}) kinds of grain: rice and barley ({%vrīhi-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yavāḥ%}), sesamum and beans ({%tila-māṣāḥ%}), Panicum Miliaceum
<div n="lb"/>and Italicum ({%aṇu-priyaṅgavaḥ%}), maize ({%godhūmāḥ%}), lentils
<div n="lb"/>({%masūrāḥ%}), Khalvāḥ and Dolichos uniflorus ({%khala-kulāḥ%}). The
[Page1-399+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>horse is called ‘corn-eating’ ({%dhānyāda%}) in the Aitareya<sup>5</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha<sup>6</sup> Brāhmaṇas, and men are mentioned as ‘purifying
<div n="lb"/>corn’ ({%dhānyā-kṛt%}) in the Rigveda.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>7 Lit., ‘preparing corn.’
<F>1) Primarily as an adjective, ‘con-
<div n="lb"/>sisting of grain.’</F>
<F>2) vi. 13, 4.</F>
<F>3) Av. iii. 24, 2. 4; v. 29, 7; vi. 50, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xi. 8; Ṣaḍviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, v. 5, etc.</F>
<F>4) vi. 3, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = 13 Kāṇva).</F>
<F>5) viii. 21.</F>
<F>6) xiii. 5, 4, 2.</F>
<F>8) x. 94, 13.</F>

<L>1440<pc>1-399<k1>DAman<k2>DAman

<div n="lb"/>order.’ Hillebrandt<sup>6</sup> sees in one passage<sup>7</sup> the sense of
<div n="lb"/>{@Nakṣatra.@}

<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, ii. 7, 2.</F>

<L>1442<pc>1-399<k1>DizaRA<k2>DizaRA
{@Dhiṣaṇā,@}¦ according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, denotes<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>an implement used in preparing the Soma, ‘bowl’ or ‘vat,’

<L>1449<pc>1-401<k1>Dur<k2>Dur
{@Dhur@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> denotes, according to the
<div n="lb"/>St. Petersburg Dictionary, that part of the yoke which is
<div n="lb"/>placed on the shoulders of the animals drawing the chariot or
<div n="lb"/>cart, whence they are called {%dhūr-ṣāh,%} ‘yoke-bearing,’ in the
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<sup>3</sup> In one passage of the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>sense is uncertain: Roth<sup>5</sup> takes it to mean the pin at either
<div n="lb"/>end of the axle ({@Akṣa@}) which goes through the nave of the
<div n="lb"/>wheel, and would thus be equivalent to {@Āṇi,@} and Oldenberg<sup>6</sup>
[Page1-402+ 42]
<div n="lb"/>seems to adopt the same view. Monier Williams<sup>7</sup> seems to
<div n="lb"/>think that ‘load’ is meant, but this is not probable. It is
<div n="lb"/>possible that Dhur has the sense of ‘pole,’<sup>8</sup> and then more
<div n="lb"/>generally still the pole and the axle together regarded as the
<div n="lb"/>drawing part of the chariot: this might explain the use in the
<div n="lb"/>doubtful passage of the Rigveda.
<F>1) i. 84, 16; 100, 16; 134, 3; 164, 19;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 18, 7; iii. 35, 2; v. 55. 6; vii. 34, 4,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 17, 18; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa

<div n="lb"/>10; 4, 4, 13, etc.; Aitareya Āraṇyaka
<div n="lb"/>i. 5, 2 (the Dhur is the end), etc.</F>
<F>3) iv. 33. {%Cf.%} {@Uara.@}</F>
<F>4) v. 43. 8.</F>
<F>5) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.,%} 2.</F>
<F>6) {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 339; Griffith.

<div n="lb"/>Srauta Sūtra, xi. 6, 5; Kātyāyana

<L>1455<pc>1-403<k1>DftarAzwravEcitravIrya<k2>DftarAzwravEcitravIrya<h>2
2. {@Dhṛtarāṣṭra Vaicitra-vīrya@}¦ (‘descendant of Vicitra-
<div n="lb"/>vīrya’) is mentioned in a passage of the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>which is, unhappily, far from intelligible. But there is no
<div n="lb"/>ground for supposing that he was a Kuru-Pañcāla king; he
<div n="lb"/>seems rather to have lived at some distance from the Kuru-
<div n="lb"/>Pañcālas. There is no good reason to deny his identity<sup>2</sup> with
<div n="lb"/>the Dhṛtarāṣṭra of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> king of {@Kāśi,@} who
<div n="lb"/>was defeated, when he attempted to offer a horse sacrifice, by
<div n="lb"/>{@Sātrājita Śatānīka.@} The fact that the latter was a {@Bharata@}
<div n="lb"/>also points to Dhṛtarāṣṭra's not having been a Kuru-Pañcāla at
<div n="lb"/>all. In the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā he appears as having a dispute
<div n="lb"/>with {@Vaka Dālbhi;@} but even assuming that the latter was
<div n="lb"/>a Pañcāla, there is nothing to hint that the former was a Kuru
<div n="lb"/>or that this dispute is a sign of an early hostility of Kuru and
<div n="lb"/>Pañcāla.<sup>4</sup> It is true that in the Epic {@Śantanu@} and Vicitravīrya
<div n="lb"/>and Dhṛtarāṣṭra himself are all connected, but this connexion
<div n="lb"/>seems to be due, as so often in the Epic, to a confused derange-
<div n="lb"/>ment of great figures of the past.
<F>1) x. 6. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>3, 469 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) As does Weber, {%Indian Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>90, 114, 125; {%Episches im vedischen Ritual,%}
<div n="lb"/>7, 8. Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.,%} treats them as identical.</F>
<F>3) xiii. 5, 4, 22.</F>
<F>4) Keith, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1908, 831 {%et seq.%} This argument
<div n="lb"/>is independent of the identification of
<div n="lb"/>the two Dhṛtarāṣṭras, but is confirmed
<div n="lb"/>by it.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1461<pc>1-405<k1>DmAtf<k2>DmAtf
{@Dhmātṛ@}¦ (lit. ‘blower’) occurs twice in one passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> in the two forms, {%dhmātā,%} nom. ‘smelter,’ and

<div n="lb"/>Geldner,<sup>3</sup> Bartholomae,<sup>4</sup> and Oldenburg<sup>5</sup> regard the latter form
<div n="lb"/>as a locative infinitive, ‘in the smelting.’ Ludwig<sup>6</sup> and Neisser<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>think {%dhmātarī%} is a nom. sing. masc. used in the same sense as
<div n="lb"/>{%dhmātā.%} Smelting is also clearly referred to,<sup>8</sup> and the smelter
<div n="lb"/>is described as using the wings of birds ({%parṇa śakunānām%}) to
<div n="lb"/>fan the flame.<sup>9</sup> That the art was widely applied is shown by
<div n="lb"/>the fact that reference is made to arrows with points of {@Ayas,@}<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to kettles which were fashioned of the same metal and could be
<div n="lb"/>placed upon a fire,<sup>11</sup> and to Soma cups of beaten Ayas.<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) v. 9. 5.</F>
<F>2) Macdonell, {%Journal of the Royal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Asiatic Society,%} 1893, 446.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 146, n, 1.</F>
<F>4) {%Indogermanische Forschungen,%} 1, 496.
<div n="lb"/>n. 2.</F>
<F>5) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 46, 388.</F>
<F>6) {%Infinitiv im Veda,%} 9; Translation of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, 4, 334.</F>
<F>7) Bezzenberger's {%Beitrāge,%} 20, 40.</F>
<F>8) Rv. iv. 2, 17. In the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vi. 1, 3. 5, {@Ayas@} is smelted
<div n="lb"/>from the ore ({%aśman%}), and gold from

<L>1463<pc>1-405<k1>Druva<k2>Druva
{@Dhruva@}¦ in the Sūtras<sup>1</sup> denotes the pole star, being mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in connexion with the marriage ritual, in which the star is
<div n="lb"/>pointed out to the bride as an emblem of constancy. In the
[Page1-406+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Upaniṣad,<sup>2</sup> a late work, the movement of the
<div n="lb"/>Dhruva ({%dhruvasya pracalanam%}) is mentioned, but this can hardly
<div n="lb"/>be interpreted as referring to an actual observed motion of the
<div n="lb"/>nominal pole star,<sup>3</sup> but rather to an extraordinary event, such
<div n="lb"/>as a destruction of the world, as Cowell understood the
<div n="lb"/>expression.<sup>4</sup> Jacobi<sup>5</sup> sees in the motion of the Dhruva the
<div n="lb"/>possibility of fixing a date, on the ground that the only star
<div n="lb"/>which could have been deemed a pole star, as ‘immovable,’ was
<div n="lb"/>one ({%a%} Draconis) of the third millennium B.C. But this attempt
<div n="lb"/>to extract chronology from the name of the star is of very
<div n="lb"/>doubtful validity.<sup>6</sup>

<div n="lb"/>Lāṭyāyana Śrauta Sūtra, iii. 3, 6, etc.
<div n="lb"/>It is to be noted that the marriage
<div n="lb"/>Mantras, of which we have a great
<div n="lb"/>many, do not include any reference to
<div n="lb"/>the Dhruva; but it is not possible to
<div n="lb"/>say definitely whether the practice is
<div n="lb"/>really an old one or not</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 2, 396.</F>
<F>3) As understood by Weber, {%Indian%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Literature,%} 98, n. 103; Bühler, {%Indian%}

<L>1469<pc>1-407<k1>Dvasra<k2>Dvasra

<L>1474<pc>1-409<k1>nakzatra<k2>nakzatra
{@Nakṣatra@}¦ is a word of obscure origin and derivation. The
<div n="lb"/>Indian interpreters already show a great divergence of opinion
<div n="lb"/>as to its primary meaning. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> re-
<div n="lb"/>solves it into {%na-kṣatra%} (‘no power’), explaining it by a legend.
<div n="lb"/>The Nirukta<sup>2</sup> refers it to the root {%nakṣ,%} ‘obtain,’ following the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>3</sup> Aufrecht<sup>4</sup> and Weber<sup>5</sup> derived it from
<div n="lb"/>{%nakta-tra,%} ‘guardian of night,’ and more recently<sup>6</sup> the derivation
<div n="lb"/>from {%nak-kṣatra,%} ‘having rule over night,’ seems to be gaining
<div n="lb"/>acceptance. The generic meaning of the word therefore seems
<div n="lb"/>to be ‘star.’
<div n="P"/>{%The Nakṣatras as Stars in the Rigveda and Later.%} — The sense
<div n="lb"/>of ‘star’ appears to be adequate for all or nearly all the passages
<div n="lb"/>in which Nakṣatra occurs in the Rigveda.<sup>7</sup> The same sense
<div n="lb"/>occurs in the later Saṃhitās also: the sun and the Nakṣatras are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned together,<sup>8</sup> or the sun, the moon, and the Nakṣatras,<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or the moon and the Nakṣatras,<sup>10</sup> or the Nakṣatras alone;<sup>11</sup>
[Page1-410+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>but there is no necessity to attribute to the word the sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘lunar mansion’ in these passages.
<div n="P"/>On the other hand, the names of at least three of the
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatras in the later sense occur in the Rigveda. Tiṣya,<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>however, does not seem to be mentioned as a lunar mansion.
<div n="lb"/>With {@Aghās@} (plur.) and {@Arjunī@} (dual)<sup>13</sup> the case is different:
<div n="lb"/>it seems probable that they are the later lunar mansions called
<div n="lb"/>Maghās (plur.) and Phalgunī (dual). The names appear to
<div n="lb"/>have been deliberately changed in the Rigveda, and it must be
<div n="lb"/>remembered that the hymn in which they occur, the wedding
<div n="lb"/>hymn of Sūryā, has no claim to great age.<sup>14</sup> Ludwig<sup>15</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>16</sup> have seen other references to the Nakṣatras as
<div n="lb"/>27 in the Rigveda,<sup>17</sup> but these seem most improbable. Nor
<div n="lb"/>do the adjectives {%revatī%} (‘rich’) and {%punarvasā%} (‘bringing
<div n="lb"/>wealth again’) in another hymn<sup>18</sup> appear to refer to the
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatras.
<div n="P"/>{%The Nakṣatras as Lunar Mansions.%} — In several passages of the
<div n="lb"/>later Saṃhitās the connexion of the moon and the Nakṣatras
<div n="lb"/>is conceived of as a marriage union. Thus in the Kāṭhaka<sup>19</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and Taittirīya Saṃhitās<sup>20</sup> it is expressly stated that Soma was
<div n="lb"/>wedded to the mansions, but dwelt only with Rohiṇī; the
<div n="lb"/>others being angry, he had ultimately to undertake to live with
<div n="lb"/>them all equally. Weber<sup>21</sup> hence deduced that the Nakṣatras
<div n="lb"/>were regarded as of equal extent, but this is to press the texts
<div n="lb"/>unduly, except in the sense of approximate equality. The
<div n="lb"/>number of the mansions is not stated as 27 in the story told in
<div n="lb"/>the two Saṃhitās: the Taittīriya has 33, and the Kāṭhaka no
[Page1-411+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>number; but 27 appears as their number in the list which is
<div n="lb"/>found in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>22</sup> and elsewhere.<sup>23</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>number 28 is much less well attested: in one passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>24</sup> Abhijit is practically marked as a new
<div n="lb"/>comer, though in a later book,<sup>25</sup> in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<sup>26</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and in the Atharvaveda list,<sup>27</sup> it has found acceptance. It is
<div n="lb"/>perfectly possible that 28 is the earlier number, and that Abhijit
<div n="lb"/>dropped out because it was faint, or too far north, or because
<div n="lb"/>27 was a more mystic (3×3×3) number: it is significant that
<div n="lb"/>the Chinese Sieou and the Arabic Manāzil are 28 in number.<sup>28</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Weber,<sup>29</sup> however, believes that 27 is the older number in
<div n="lb"/>India.
<div n="P"/>The meaning of the number is easily explained when it is
<div n="lb"/>remembered that a periodic month occupies something between
<div n="lb"/>27 and 28 days, more nearly the former number. Such a month
<div n="lb"/>is in fact recognized in the Lāṭyāyana<sup>30</sup> and Nidāna Sūtras<sup>31</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as consisting of 27 days, 12 months making a year of 324 days,
<div n="lb"/>a Nakṣatra year, or with an intercalary month, a year of
<div n="lb"/>351 days. The Nidāna Sūtra<sup>32</sup> makes an attempt to introduce
<div n="lb"/>the Nakṣatra reckoning into the civil or solar ({%sāvana%}) year
<div n="lb"/>of 360 days, for it holds that the sun spends 13(1/3) days in
<div n="lb"/>each Nakṣatra (13(1/3)×27 = 360). But the month of 27 or
<div n="lb"/>28 days plays no part in the chronological calculations of the
<div n="lb"/>Veda.<sup>33</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%The Names of the Nakṣatras.%} — In addition to the two men-
<div n="lb"/>tioned in the Rigveda, the earlier Atharvaveda<sup>34</sup> gives the
[Page1-412+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>names of Jyeṣṭhaghnī<sup>35</sup> (the later Jyeṣṭhā) and Vicṛtau,<sup>36</sup> which
<div n="lb"/>are mentioned as in close connexion, and of Revatīs (plural)
<div n="lb"/>and Kṛttikās.<sup>37</sup> With reference to possible times for the
<div n="lb"/>ceremony of the Agnyādhāna, or ‘laying of the sacred fires,’
<div n="lb"/>the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,<sup>38</sup> the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<sup>39</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>40</sup> mention the Nakṣatras called Kṛttikās,
<div n="lb"/>Rohiṇī, Phalgunyas, Hasta; the latter Brāhmaṇa adds Punar-
<div n="lb"/>vasū, and in an additional remark<sup>41</sup> excludes Pūrve Phalgunī
<div n="lb"/>in favour of Uttare Phalgunī. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>42</sup>
<div n="lb"/>adds Mṛgaśīrṣa and Citrā as possibilities. On the other hand,
<div n="lb"/>Punarvasū is recommended by all authorities<sup>43</sup> as suitable for
<div n="lb"/>the Punarādheya, ‘relaying of the sacred fires,’ which takes
<div n="lb"/>place if the first fire has failed to effect the aim of its existence,
<div n="lb"/>the prosperity of the sacrificer.<sup>44</sup> The Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,<sup>45</sup>
<div n="lb"/>however, allows Anurādhās also.
<div n="P"/>In the ceremony of the Agnicayana, or ‘piling of the fire-
<div n="lb"/>altar,’ the bricks are assumed to be equal in number to the
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatras. The bricks number 756, and they are equated to
<div n="lb"/>27 Nakṣatras multiplied by 27 secondary Nakṣatras, reckoned
<div n="lb"/>as 720 (instead of 729), with the addition of 36 days, the length
<div n="lb"/>of an intercalary month. Nothing can be usefully derived
<div n="lb"/>from this piece of priestly nonsense.<sup>46</sup> But in connexion with
<div n="lb"/>this ceremony the Yajurveda Saṃhitās<sup>47</sup> enumerate the 27
[Page1-413+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatras, and these lists<sup>48</sup> may be given {%in extenso%} as
<div n="lb"/>follows:
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>{%Taittirīya Saṃhitā.%} <C n="2"/>{%Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhita.%} <C n="3"/>{%Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā.%}
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>1. Kṛttikās (fem. plur.) ... <C n="2"/>Kṛttikās ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Kṛttikās
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>2. Rohiṇī ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Rohiṇī ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Rohiṇī
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>3. Mṛgaśīrṣa (neut.) ... <C n="2"/>Invagā ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Invakā
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>4. Ārdrā ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Bāhu ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Bāhu

<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>6. Tiṣya ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Tiṣya ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Tiṣya
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>7. Āśreṣās (fem. plur.) ... <C n="2"/>Āśleṣās(plur.; Pada Aśleṣā) <C n="3"/>Āśleṣās (or Aśleṣās)

<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>10. Phalgunī (fem. dual) ...<C n="2"/>Phalgunīs (plur.) ... ... <C n="3"/>Uttarāḥa Phalgunīs
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>11. Hasta ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Hasta ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Hastau (dual)
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>12. Citrā ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Citrā ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Citrā
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>13. Svātī ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Niṣṭya (neut.) ... ... <C n="3"/>Niṣṭyā
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>14. Viśākhe (fem. dual) ... <C n="2"/>Viśākha (neut. sing.) ... <C n="3"/>Viśākhā (fem. sing.)
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>15. Anūrādhās (plur.) ... <C n="2"/>Anūrādhā (Pada Anu-Anūrādhās (masc.
<div n="lb"/>rādhā) <C n="3"/>Anūrādhās (masc.
<div n="lb"/>plur.)
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>16. Rohiṇī ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Jyeṣṭhā ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Jyeṣṭhā
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>17. Vicṛtau ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Mūla (neut.) ... ... <C n="3"/>Mūla
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>18. Aṣāḍhās (fem. plur.) ... <C n="2"/>Aṣāḍhās ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Aṣāḍhās
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>19. Aṣāḍhās (fem. plur.) ... <C n="2"/>Aṣāḍhās ... ... ...<C n="3"/>Uttarā Aṣāḍhās
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>20. <C n="2"/>Abhijit ... ... ...
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>21. Śroṇā ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Śroṇā ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Aśvattha
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>22. Śraviṣṭhās (plur.) ... <C n="2"/>Śraviṣṭhās ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Śraviṣṭhās
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>23. Śatabhiṣaj ... ... <C n="2"/>Śatabhiṣaj ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Śatabhiṣaj
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>24. Proṣṭhapadās (masc. plur.) <C n="2"/>Proṣṭhapadās ... ... <C n="3"/>Proṣṭhapadās
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>25. Proṣṭhapadās(masc. plur.) <C n="2"/>Proṣṭhapadās ... ... <C n="3"/>Uttare Proṣṭhapadās
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>26. Revatī ... ... ... <C n="2"/>Revatī ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Revatī
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>27. Aśvayujau (dual) ... <C n="2"/>Aśvayujau ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Aśvayujau
<div n="lb"/><C n="1"/>28. Apabharaṇīs (fem. plur.) <C n="2"/>Bharaṇīs ... ... ... <C n="3"/>Apabharaṇīs
<div n="P"/>The Taittirīya Brahmaṇa<sup>49</sup> has a list of the Nakṣatras
<div n="lb"/>which agrees generally with the list of the Saṃhitās. It runs
<div n="lb"/>as follows: Kṛttikās, Rohiṇī, Invakās, Bāhū (dual), Tiṣya,
<div n="lb"/>Āśleṣās, Maghās, Pūrve Phalgunī, Uttare Phalgunī, Hasta,
<div n="lb"/>Citrā, Niṣṭyā, Viśākhe, Anūrādhās, Rohiṇī, Mūlabarhaṇī,
<div n="lb"/>Pūrvā Aṣāḍhās, Uttarā Aṣāḍhās, Śroṇā, Śraviṣṭhās, Śatabhiṣaj,
<div n="lb"/>Pūrve Proṣṭhapadās, Uttare Proṣṭhapadās, Revatī, Aśvayujau,
<div n="lb"/>Apabharaṇīs. In a later book,<sup>50</sup> however, the list grows to 28,
[Page1-414+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>and the full moon is inserted after number 14, and the new
<div n="lb"/>moon after number 28, as an attempt to bring the Nākṣatra
<div n="lb"/>(lunar) month into accordance with the Sāvana (solar) month
<div n="lb"/>of 30 days. The names in this second list are as in the
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās with the following exceptions. The seven stars of
<div n="lb"/>the Kṛttikās are named as Ambā, Dulā, Nitatnī, Abhrayantī,
<div n="lb"/>Meghayantī, Varṣayantī, Cupuṇīkā, names found also in the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya<sup>51</sup> and Kāṭhaka Saṃhitās.<sup>52</sup> Beside Mṛgaśīrṣa, Invakās
<div n="lb"/>are also mentioned.<sup>53</sup> Then come Ārdrā, Punarvasū, Tiṣya,
<div n="lb"/>Āśreṣās, Maghās (beside which Anaghās, Agadās, and Arun-
<div n="lb"/>dhatīs are also mentioned), Phalgunyas (but elsewhere in the
<div n="lb"/>dual, Phalgunyau),<sup>54</sup> Phalgunyas, Hasta, Citrā, Niṣṭyā, Viśākhe,
<div n="lb"/>Anūrādhās, Jyeṣṭhā, Mūla, Aṣāḍhās, Aṣāḍhās, Abhijit, Śronā,
<div n="lb"/>Śraviṣṭhās, Śatabhiṣaj, Proṣṭhapadās, Proṣṭhapadās, Revatī,
<div n="lb"/>Aśvayujau, Bharaṇyas, but also Apabharaṇīs.<sup>55</sup> Abhijit, which
<div n="lb"/>occurs also in an earlier part of the Brāhmaṇa,<sup>56</sup> is perhaps
<div n="lb"/>interpolated. But Weber's<sup>57</sup> argument that Abhijit is out of
<div n="lb"/>place in this list because Brāhmaṇa is here mentioned as the
<div n="lb"/>28th Nakṣatra, loses some force from the fact (of course unknown
<div n="lb"/>to him) that the list in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>58</sup> contains
<div n="lb"/>28 Nakṣatras, including Abhijit, and adds Brāhmaṇa at the end
<div n="lb"/>as another.
<div n="P"/>In another passage<sup>59</sup> the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa divides the
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatras into two sets, the Deva Nakṣatras and the Yama
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatras, being 1-14 and 15-27 (with the omission of Abhijit)
<div n="lb"/>respectively. This division corresponds with one in the third
<div n="lb"/>book of the Brāhmaṇa<sup>60</sup> where the days of the light half of
<div n="lb"/>the month and those of the dark half are equated with the
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatras. The Brāhmaṇa treats the former series as south,
<div n="lb"/>the latter as north; but this has no relation to facts, and
<div n="lb"/>can only be regarded as a ritual absurdity.
<div n="P"/>The late nineteenth book of the Atharvaveda contains a
<div n="lb"/>list<sup>61</sup> of the Nakṣatras, including Abhijit. The names here
[Page1-415+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>given are: Kṛttikās, Rohiṇī, Mṛgaśiras, Ārdrā, Punarvasū,
<div n="lb"/>Puṣya, Āśleṣās, Maghās, Pūrvā Phalgunyau ({%sic%}),<sup>62</sup> Hasta,
<div n="lb"/>Citrā, Svāti (masc.),<sup>63</sup> Viśākhe, Anurādhā,<sup>64</sup> Jyeṣṭhā, Mūla,
<div n="lb"/>Pūrvā Aṣāḍhās,<sup>65</sup> Uttarā Aṣāḍhās, Abhijit, Śravaṇa, Śraviṣṭhās,
<div n="lb"/>Śatabhiṣaj, Dvayā Proṣṭhapadā, Revatī, Aśvayujau, Bharaṇyas.
<div n="P"/>{%The Position of the Nakṣatras.%} — There is nothing definite in
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature regarding the position of most of the Nakṣatras,
<div n="lb"/>but the later astronomy precisely locates all of them, and its
<div n="lb"/>statements agree on the whole satisfactorily with what is said
<div n="lb"/>in the earlier texts, though Weber<sup>66</sup> was inclined to doubt this.
<div n="lb"/>The determinations adopted below are due to Whitney<sup>67</sup> in his
<div n="lb"/>notes on the Sūrya Siddhānta.

<L>1475<pc>1-415<k1>kfttikAs<k2>kfttikAs<h>1
1. {@Kṛttikās@}¦ are unquestionably <lang n="greek"></lang> Tauri, etc., the Pleiades.
<div n="lb"/>The names of the seven stars forming this constellation, and
<div n="lb"/>given above from Yajurveda texts,<sup>68</sup> include three — {%abhrayantī,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘forming clouds’; {%meghayantī,%} ‘making cloudy’; {%varṣayantī,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘causing rain’ — which clearly refer to the rainy Pleiades. The
<div n="lb"/>word {%kṛttikā%} possibly means ‘web,’ from the root {%kṛt,%} ‘spin.’
<F>68) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 5, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xl. 4; Taittīrīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iii. 1, 4, 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1476<pc>1-415<k1>rohiRI<k2>rohiRI<h>2
2. {@Rohiṇī,@}¦ ‘ruddy,’ is the name of the conspicuously reddish
<div n="lb"/>star, {%a%} Tauri or Aldebaran, and denotes the group of the
<div n="lb"/>Hyades, <lang n="greek"></lang> Tauri. Its identification seems absolutely
<div n="lb"/>assured by the legend of Prajāpati in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>69</sup>
<div n="lb"/>He is there represented as pursuing his daughter with incestuous
<div n="lb"/>intention, and as having been shot with an arrow ({@Iṣu Trikāṇḍā,@}
<div n="lb"/>‘the belt of Orion’) by the ‘huntsman’ ({@Mṛgavyādha,@}
<div n="lb"/>‘Sirius’). Prajāpati is clearly Orion (Mṛgaśiras being the
<div n="lb"/>name of the little group of stars in Orion's head).
<F>69) iii. 33. {%Cf.%} Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 1, 2, 8; Tilak, {%Orion,%} 98 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>1485<pc>1-417<k1>svAtI<k2>svAtI<h>13
13. {@Svātī@}¦ or {@Niṣṭyā@} is later clearly the brilliant star Arcturus
<div n="lb"/>or <lang n="greek"></lang> Bootis, its place in the north being assured by the notice
<div n="lb"/>in the Śāntikalpa,<sup>83</sup> where it is said to be ‘ever traversing the
<div n="lb"/>northern way’ ({%nityam uttara-mārgagam%}). The Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>84</sup> however, constructs an asterismal Prajāpati,
<div n="lb"/>giving him Citrā ({%a%} Virginis) for head, Hasta (Corvus) for
<div n="lb"/>hand, the Viśākhe ({%a%} and <lang n="greek"></lang> Libræ) for thighs, and the
<div n="lb"/>Anurādhās (<lang n="greek"></lang>, and <lang n="greek"></lang> Scorpionis) for standing place, with
<div n="lb"/>Niṣṭyā for heart. But Arcturus, being 30º out, spoils this
<div n="lb"/>figure, while, on the other hand, the Arabic and Chinese
<div n="lb"/>systems have respectively, instead of Arcturus, <lang n="greek"></lang>, and <lang n="greek"></lang>
<div n="lb"/>Virginis and <lang n="greek"></lang> Virginis, which would well fit into the Prajāpati
<div n="lb"/>figure. But in spite of the force of this argument of Weber's,<sup>85</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Whitney<sup>86</sup> is not certain that Niṣṭyā here must mean a star in
<div n="lb"/>Virgo, pointing out that the name Niṣṭyā, ‘outcast,’ suggests
<div n="lb"/>the separation of this Nakṣatra from the others in question.
<F>83) 3.</F>
<F>84) i. 5, 2. {%Cf.%} Tilak, {%Orion,%} 204.</F>
<F>85) {%Op. cit.,%} 2, 307, 308.</F>
<F>86) {%Op. cit.,%} 409.</F>

<div n="lb"/>which is after or follows Rādhā.’<sup>88</sup>

<L>1489<pc>1-418<k1>vicftO<k2>vicftO<h>17

<div n="P"/>18, 19. {@Aṣāḍhās@} (‘unconquered’), distinguished as {@Pūrvās,@}
<div n="lb"/>‘former,’ and {@Uttarās,@} ‘latter,’ are really two constellations, of
<div n="lb"/>which the former is composed of <lang n="greek"></lang>, and <lang n="greek"></lang> Sagittarii, or of
<lang n="greek"></lang> and <lang n="greek"></lang> only, and the latter of <lang n="greek"></lang>, and <lang n="greek"></lang> Sagittarii, or of two,
<lang n="greek"></lang> and <lang n="greek"></lang>, only. It is probable that originally only four stars
<div n="lb"/>forming a square were meant as included in the whole con-
<div n="lb"/>stellation<sup>89</sup> — viz., <lang n="greek"></lang> and <lang n="greek"></lang>, with <lang n="greek"></lang> and <lang n="greek"></lang>.
<div n="P"/>20. {@Abhijit@} is the brilliant star <lang n="greek"></lang> Lyræ with its two com-
<div n="lb"/>panions <lang n="greek"></lang> and <lang n="greek"></lang>. Its location in 60º north latitude is completely
<div n="lb"/>discordant with the position of the corresponding Arabian and
<div n="lb"/>Chinese asterisms. This fact is considered by Oldenberg<sup>90</sup> to
<div n="lb"/>support the view that it was a later addition to the system; its
<div n="lb"/>occurrence, however, as early as the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<sup>91</sup>
<div n="lb"/>which he does not note, somewhat invalidates<sup>92</sup> that view. In
<div n="lb"/>the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>93</sup> Abhijit is said to be ‘over Aṣāḍhās,
<div n="lb"/>under Śroṇā,’ which Weber<sup>94</sup> held to refer to its position in

<div n="lb"/>that of the Arab Manāzil and the Chinese Sieou — viz., <lang n="greek"></lang>,
<div n="lb"/>Capricorni. But Whitney<sup>95</sup> argues effectively that the words
<div n="lb"/>‘over’ and ‘under’ really refer to the place of Abhijit in the
<div n="lb"/>list, ‘after’ Aṣāḍhās and ‘before’ Śroṇā.
<F>89) {%Cf.%} Thibaut, {%Journal of the Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society of Bengal,%} 63, 156.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%der Wissenschaften zu Göttingen,%} 1909,
<div n="lb"/>551, 552.</F>
<F>91) ii. 13, 20.</F>
<F>92) It is at the same time to be noted
<div n="lb"/>that Abhijit is wanting both in the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā and in the Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā lists.</F>

<F>94) {%Op. cit.,%} 1, 320, 321; 2, 307;
