<L>1495<pc>1-419<k1>apaBaraRIs<k2>apaBaraRIs<h>28
28. {@Apabharaṇīs, Bharaṇīs,@}¦ or {@Bharaṇyas,@} ‘the bearers,’ is
<div n="lb"/>the name of the small triangle in the northern part of the Ram
<div n="lb"/>known as Musca or 35, 39, and 41 Arietis.
<div n="P"/>{%The Nakṣatras and the Months.%} — In the Brāhmaṇas the
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatra names are regularly used to denote dates. This is
<div n="lb"/>done in two ways. The name, if not already a feminine, may
<div n="lb"/>be turned into a feminine and compounded with {%pūrṇa-māsa,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘the full moon,’ as in {%Tiṣyā-pūrṇamāsa,%} ‘the full moon in the
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatra Tiṣya.’<sup>103</sup> Much more often, however, it is turned
<div n="lb"/>into a derivative adjective, used with {%paurṇamāsī,%} ‘the full
[Page1-420+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>moon (night),’ or with {%amāvāsyā,%} ‘the new moon (night),’ as in
<div n="lb"/>{%Phālgunī paurṇamāsī,%} ‘the full-moon night in the Nakṣatra
<div n="lb"/>Phalgunī’;<sup>104</sup> or, as is usual in the Sūtras, the Nakṣatra adjec-
<div n="lb"/>tive alone is used to denote the full-moon night. The month
<div n="lb"/>itself is called by a name derived<sup>105</sup> from that of a Nakṣatra,
<div n="lb"/>but only Phālguna,<sup>106</sup> Caitra,<sup>107</sup> Vaiśākha,<sup>108</sup> Taiṣya,<sup>109</sup> Māgha<sup>110</sup>
<div n="lb"/>occur in the Brāhmaṇas, the complete list later being Phālguna,
<div n="lb"/>Caitra, Vaiśākha, Jyaiṣṭha, Āṣāḍha, Śrāvaṇa, Prauṣṭhapada,
<div n="lb"/>Āśvayuja, Kārttika, Mārgaśīrṣa, Taiṣya, Māgha. Strictly
<div n="lb"/>speaking, these should be lunar months, but the use of a lunar
<div n="lb"/>year was clearly very restricted: we have seen that as early as
<div n="lb"/>the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa there was a tendency to equate lunar
<div n="lb"/>months with the twelve months of thirty days which made up
<div n="lb"/>the solar year (see {@Māsa@}).
<div n="P"/>{%The Nakṣatras and Chronology.%} — (1) An endeavour has been
<div n="lb"/>made to ascertain from the names of the months the period at
<div n="lb"/>which the systematic employment of those names was intro-
<div n="lb"/>duced. Sir William Jones<sup>111</sup> refers to this possibility, and
<div n="lb"/>Bentley, by the gratuitous assumption that Śrāvaṇa always
<div n="lb"/>marked the summer solstice, concluded that the names of the
<div n="lb"/>months did not date before B.C. 1181. Weber<sup>112</sup> considered
<div n="lb"/>that there was a possibility of fixing a date by this means, but
<div n="lb"/>Whitney<sup>113</sup> has convincingly shown that it is an impossible
<div n="lb"/>feat, and Thibaut<sup>114</sup> concurs in this view. Twelve became
<div n="lb"/>fixed as the number of the months because of the desire,
<div n="lb"/>evident in the Brāhmaṇas, somehow or other to harmonize
<div n="lb"/>lunar with solar time; but the selection of twelve Nakṣatras
<div n="lb"/>out of twenty-seven as connected with the night of full moon
<div n="lb"/>can have no chronological significance, because full moon at
[Page1-421+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>no period occurred in those twelve only, but has at all periods
<div n="lb"/>occurred in every one of the twenty-seven at regularly re-
<div n="lb"/>current intervals.
<div n="P"/>(2) All the lists of the Nakṣatras begin with Kṛttīkās. It is
<div n="lb"/>only fair to suppose that there was some special reason for this
<div n="lb"/>fact. Now the later list of the Nakṣatras begins with Aśvinī,
<div n="lb"/>and it was unquestionably rearranged because at the time of its
<div n="lb"/>adoption the vernal equinox coincided with the star <lang n="greek"></lang> Piscium
<div n="lb"/>on the border of Revatī and Aśvinī,<sup>115</sup> say in the course of the
<div n="lb"/>sixth century A.D. Weber<sup>116</sup> has therefore accepted the view
<div n="lb"/>that the Kṛttikās were chosen for a similar reason, and the
<div n="lb"/>date at which that Nakṣatra coincided with the vernal equinox
<div n="lb"/>has been estimated at some period in the third millennium B.C.<sup>117</sup>
<div n="lb"/>A very grave objection to this view is its assumption that the
<div n="lb"/>sun, and not the moon, was then regarded as connected with
<div n="lb"/>the Nakṣatras; and both Thibaut<sup>118</sup> and Oldenberg<sup>119</sup> have
<div n="lb"/>pronounced decidedly against the idea of connecting the
<div n="lb"/>equinox with the Kṛttikās. Jacobi<sup>120</sup> has contended that in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>121</sup> the commencement of the rains and the summer
<div n="lb"/>solstice mark the beginning of the new year and the end of the
<div n="lb"/>old, and that further the new year began with the summer
<div n="lb"/>solstice in Phalgunī.<sup>121</sup> He has also referred to the distinction
<div n="lb"/>of the two sets of Deva and Yama Nakṣatras in the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>122</sup> as supporting his view of the connexion of the
<div n="lb"/>sun and the Nakṣatras. But this view is far from satisfactory:
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda passages cannot yield the sense required except
<div n="lb"/>by translating the word {%dvādaśa%}<sup>123</sup> as ‘the twelfth (month)’
<div n="lb"/>instead of ‘consisting of twelve parts,’ that is, ‘year,’ the accepted
[Page1-422+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>interpretation; and the division of the Nakṣatras is not at all
<div n="lb"/>satisfactorily explained by a supposed connexion with the sun. It
<div n="lb"/>may further be mentioned that even if the Nakṣatra of Kṛttikās
<div n="lb"/>be deemed to have been chosen because of its coincidence with
<div n="lb"/>the vernal equinox, both Whitney<sup>124</sup> and Thibaut<sup>125</sup> are pre-
<div n="lb"/>pared to regard it as no more than a careless variant of the date
<div n="lb"/>given by the Jyotiṣa, which puts the winter solstice in Māgha.
<div n="P"/>(3) The winter solstice in Māgha is assured by a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>text, for the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa<sup>126</sup> expressly places it in the
<div n="lb"/>new moon of Māgha ({%māghasyāmāvāsyāyām%}). It is not very
<div n="lb"/>important whether we take this with the commentators<sup>127</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>the new moon in the middle of a month commencing with the
<div n="lb"/>day after full moon in Taiṣa, or, which is much more likely, as
<div n="lb"/>the new moon beginning the month and preceding full moon in
<div n="lb"/>Māgha. The datum gives a certain possibility of fixing an epoch
<div n="lb"/>in the following way. If the end of Revatī marked the vernal
<div n="lb"/>equinox at one period, then the precession of the equinoxes would
<div n="lb"/>enable us to calculate at what point of time the vernal equinox
<div n="lb"/>was in a position corresponding to the winter solstice in Māgha,
<div n="lb"/>when the solstitial colure cut the ecliptic at the beginning of
<div n="lb"/>Śraviṣṭhās. This would be, on the strict theory, in the third
<div n="lb"/>quarter of Bharaṇī, 6(3/4) asterisms removed from Śraviṣṭhās, and
<div n="lb"/>the difference between that and the beginning of Aśvinī=
[Page1-423+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>1(3/4) asterisms = 23(1/3)º (27 asterisms being = 360º). Taking the
<div n="lb"/>starting-point at 499 A.D., the assured period of Varāha Mihira,
<div n="lb"/>Jones<sup>128</sup> arrived at the date B. C. 1181 for the vernal equinox
<div n="lb"/>corresponding to the winter solstice in Māgha — that is, on the
<div n="lb"/>basis of 1º = 72 years as the precession. Pratt<sup>129</sup> arrived at
<div n="lb"/>precisely the same date, taking the same rate of precession and
<div n="lb"/>adopting as his basis the ascertained position in the Siddhāntas
<div n="lb"/>of the junction star<sup>130</sup> of Maghā, <lang n="greek"></lang> Leonis or Regulus. Davis<sup>131</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and Colebrooke<sup>132</sup> arrived at a different date, B.C. 1391, by
<div n="lb"/>taking as the basis of their calculation the junction star of Citrā,
<div n="lb"/>which happens to be of uncertain position, varying as much as
<div n="lb"/>3º in the different textbooks. But though the twelfth century
<div n="lb"/>has received a certain currency as the epoch of the observation
<div n="lb"/>in the Jyotiṣa,<sup>133</sup> it is of very doubtful value. As Whitney
<div n="lb"/>points out, it is impossible to say that the earlier asterisms
<div n="lb"/>coincided in position with the later asterisms of 13(1/3)º extent
<div n="lb"/>each. They were not chosen as equal divisions, but as groups
<div n="lb"/>of stars which stood in conjunction with the moon; and the
<div n="lb"/>result of subsequently making them strictly equal divisions
<div n="lb"/>was to throw the principal stars of the later groups altogether
<div n="lb"/>out of their asterisms.<sup>134</sup> Nor can we say that the star <lang n="greek"></lang> Piscium
<div n="lb"/>early formed the eastern boundary of Revatī; it may possibly
<div n="lb"/>not even have been in that asterism at all, for it is far remote
<div n="lb"/>from the Chinese and Arabic asterisms corresponding to Revatī.
<div n="lb"/>Added to all this, and to the uncertainty of the starting-point — 
<div n="lb"/>582 A.D., 560 A.D., or 491 A.D. being variants<sup>135</sup> — is the fact that
<div n="lb"/>the place of the equinox is not a matter accurately determin-
<div n="lb"/>able by mere observation, and that the Hindu astronomers of
<div n="lb"/>the Vedic period cannot be deemed to have been very accurate
<div n="lb"/>observers, since they made no precise determination of the
[Page1-424+ 78]
<div n="lb"/>number of days of the year, which even in the Jyotiṣa they do
<div n="lb"/>not determine more precisely than as 366 days, and even
<div n="lb"/>the Sūrya Siddhānta<sup>136</sup> does not know the precession of the
<div n="lb"/>equinoxes. It is therefore only fair to allow a thousand years
<div n="lb"/>for possible errors,<sup>137</sup> and the only probable conclusion to be
<div n="lb"/>drawn from the datum of the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa is that it
<div n="lb"/>was recording an observation which must have been made some
<div n="lb"/>centuries B.C., in itself a result quite in harmony with the
<div n="lb"/>probable date of the Brāhmaṇa literature,<sup>138</sup> say B.C. 800-600.
<div n="P"/>(4) Another chronological argument has been derived from
<div n="lb"/>the fact that there is a considerable amount of evidence for
<div n="lb"/>Phālguna having been regarded as the beginning of the year,
<div n="lb"/>since the full moon in Phalgunī is often described as the
<div n="lb"/>‘mouth ({%mukham%}) of the year.’<sup>139</sup> Jacobi<sup>140</sup> considers that this
[Page1-425+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>was due to the fact that the year was reckoned from the winter
<div n="lb"/>solstice, which would coincide with the month of Phālguna
<div n="lb"/>about B.C. 4000. Oldenberg<sup>141</sup> and Thibaut,<sup>142</sup> on the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, maintain that the choice of Phālguna as the ‘mouth’ of
<div n="lb"/>the year was due to its being the first month of spring. This
<div n="lb"/>view is favoured by the fact that there is distinct evidence<sup>143</sup>
<div n="lb"/>of the correspondence of Phālguna and the beginning of spring:
<div n="lb"/>as we have seen above in the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, the new
<div n="lb"/>moon in Māgha is placed at the winter solstice,<sup>144</sup> which puts
<div n="lb"/>the full moon of Phalgunī at a month and a half after the
<div n="lb"/>winter solstice, or in the first week of February, a date not in
<div n="lb"/>itself improbable for about B.C. 800, and corresponding with
<div n="lb"/>the February 7 of the {%veris initium%} in the Roman Calendar.
<div n="lb"/>This fact accords with the only natural division of the year
<div n="lb"/>into three periods of four months, as the rainy season lasts from
<div n="lb"/>June 7-10 to October 7-10, and it is certain that the second set
<div n="lb"/>of four months dates from the beginning of the rains (see
<div n="lb"/>{@Cāturmāsya@}). Tilak,<sup>145</sup> on the other hand, holds that the
<div n="lb"/>winter solstice coincided with Māghī full moon at the time of the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā (B.C. 2350), and had coincided with Phālgunī
<div n="lb"/>and Caitrī in early periods — viz., B.C. 4000-2500, and B.C. 6000-
<div n="lb"/>4000.
<div n="P"/>(5) The passages of the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>146</sup> and the Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>147</sup> which treat the full moon in Phālguna as
<div n="lb"/>the beginning of the year, give as an alternative the full moon
<div n="lb"/>in Caitra. Probably the latter month was chosen so as to
<div n="lb"/>secure that the initial day should fall well within the season of
<div n="lb"/>spring,<sup>148</sup> and was not, as Jacobi believes, a relic of a period
[Page1-426+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>when the winter solstice corresponded with Caitra. Another
<div n="lb"/>alternative is the Ekāṣṭakā, interpreted by the commentators as
<div n="lb"/>the eighth day after the full moon in Maghās, a time which
<div n="lb"/>might, as being the last quarter of the waning half of the old
<div n="lb"/>year, well be considered as representing the end of the year.
<div n="lb"/>A fourth alternative is the fourth day before full moon; the full
<div n="lb"/>moon meant must be that of Caitra, as Ālekhana quoted by
<div n="lb"/>Āpastamba held, not of Māgha, as Āśmarathya, Laugākṣi and
<div n="lb"/>the Mīmāṃsists believed, and as Tilak believes.<sup>149</sup>
<div n="P"/>(6) Others, again, according to the Gṛhya ritual, began the
<div n="lb"/>year with the month Mārgaśīrṣa, as is shown by its other name
<div n="lb"/>Āgrahāyaṇa<sup>150</sup> (‘belonging to the commencement of the year’).
<div n="lb"/>Jacobi and Tilak<sup>151</sup> think that this one denoted the autumn
<div n="lb"/>equinox in Mṛgaśiras, corresponding to the winter solstice in
<div n="lb"/>Phalgunī. But, as Thibaut<sup>152</sup> shows clearly, it was selected as
<div n="lb"/>the beginning of a year that was taken to commence with
<div n="lb"/>autumn, just as some took the spring to commence with Caitra
<div n="lb"/>instead of Phālguna.<sup>153</sup>
<div n="P"/>(7) Jacobi has also argued, with the support of Bühler,<sup>154</sup>
<div n="lb"/>from the terms given for the beginning of Vedic study in the
<div n="lb"/>Gṛhya Sūtras, on the principle that study commenced with the
<div n="lb"/>rains (as in the Buddhist {%vassā%}) which mark the summer
<div n="lb"/>solstice. He concludes that if Bhādrapada appears as the
<div n="lb"/>date of commencing study in some texts, it was fixed thus
<div n="lb"/>because at one time Proṣṭhapadās (the early name of Bhadra-
<div n="lb"/>padās) coincided with the summer solstice, this having been the
<div n="lb"/>case when the winter solstice was in Phālguna. But Whitney<sup>155</sup>
<div n="lb"/>has pointed out that this argument is utterly illegitimate; we
<div n="lb"/>cannot say that there was any necessary connexion between the
<div n="lb"/>rains and learning — a month like Śrāvaṇa might be preferred
[Page1-427+ 89]
<div n="lb"/>because of its connexion with the word Śravaṇa, ‘ear’ — and
<div n="lb"/>in view of the precession of the equinoxes, we must assume that
<div n="lb"/>Bhādrapada was kept because of its traditional coincidence
<div n="lb"/>with the beginning of the rains after it had ceased actually so
<div n="lb"/>to coincide.<sup>156</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%The Origin of the Nakṣatras.%} — As we have seen, there is no
<div n="lb"/>evidence showing the process by which the Nakṣatras may
[Page1-428+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>have originated in India. They are mentioned only as stars in
<div n="lb"/>the earlier parts of the Rigveda, then the names of three of
<div n="lb"/>them are found in the latest parts of that Saṃhitā, and finally
<div n="lb"/>in the later Atharvaveda and in the Yajurveda Saṃhitās the
<div n="lb"/>full list appears. It may also be noted that the Vedic Indians
<div n="lb"/>show (see {@Graha@}) a remarkably small knowledge of the other
<div n="lb"/>astronomical phenomena; the discovery of a series of 27 lunar
<div n="lb"/>mansions by them would therefore be rather surprising. On
<div n="lb"/>the other hand, the nature of such an operation is not very
<div n="lb"/>complicated; it consists merely in selecting a star or a star
<div n="lb"/>group with which the moon is in conjunction. It is thus
<div n="lb"/>impossible {%a priori%} to deny that the Vedic Indians could have
<div n="lb"/>invented for themselves a lunar Zodiac.<sup>157</sup>
<div n="P"/>But the question is complicated by the fact that there exist
<div n="lb"/>two similar sets of 28 stars or star groups in Arabia and in
<div n="lb"/>China, the Manāzil and the Sieou. The use of the Manāzil in
<div n="lb"/>Arabia is consistent and effective; the calendar is regulated by
<div n="lb"/>them, and the position of the asterisms corresponds best with
<div n="lb"/>the positions required for a lunar Zodiac. The Indians might
<div n="lb"/>therefore have borrowed the system from Arabia, but that is a
<div n="lb"/>mere possibility, because the evidence for the existence of the
<div n="lb"/>Manāzil is long posterior to that for the existence of the
<div n="lb"/>Nakṣatras, while again the Mazzaroth or Mazzaloth of the Old
<div n="lb"/>Testament<sup>158</sup> may really be the lunar mansions.<sup>159</sup> That the
<div n="lb"/>Arabian system is borrowed from India, as Burgess<sup>160</sup> held, is,
<div n="lb"/>on the other hand, not at all probable.
<div n="P"/>Biot, the eminent Chinese scholar, in a series of papers
<div n="lb"/>published by him between 1839 and 1861,<sup>161</sup> attempted to prove
[Page1-429+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>the derivation of the Nakṣatra from the Chinese Sieou. The
<div n="lb"/>latter he did not regard as being in origin lunar mansions at all.
<div n="lb"/>He thought that they were equatorial stars used, as in modern
<div n="lb"/>astronomy, as a standard to which planets or other stars
<div n="lb"/>observed in the neighbourhood can be referred; they were, as
<div n="lb"/>regards twenty-four of them, selected about B.C. 2357 on
<div n="lb"/>account of their proximity to the equator, and of their having
<div n="lb"/>the same right ascension as certain circumpolar stars which had
<div n="lb"/>attracted the attention of Chinese observers. Four more were
<div n="lb"/>added in B.C. 1100 in order to mark the equinoxes and solstices
<div n="lb"/>of the period. He held that the list of stars commenced with
<div n="lb"/>Mao (= Kṛttikās), which was at the vernal equinox in B.C. 2357.
<div n="lb"/>Weber,<sup>162</sup> in an elaborate essay of 1860, disputed this theory,
<div n="lb"/>and endeavoured to show that the Chinese literary evidence for
<div n="lb"/>the Sieou was late, dating not even from before the third
<div n="lb"/>century B.C. The last point does not appear<sup>163</sup> to be correct,
<div n="lb"/>but his objections against the basis of Biot's theory were rein-
<div n="lb"/>forced by Whitney,<sup>164</sup> who insisted that Biot's supposition of
<div n="lb"/>the Sieou's not having been ultimately derived from a system of
<div n="lb"/>lunar mansions, was untenable. This is admitted by the latest
<div n="lb"/>defender of the hypothesis of borrowing from China, Léopold
<div n="lb"/>de Saussure,<sup>165</sup> , but his arguments in favour of a Chinese origin
<div n="lb"/>for the Indian lunar mansions have been refuted by Oldenberg,<sup>166</sup>
<div n="lb"/>who has also pointed out<sup>167</sup> that the series does not begin with
<div n="lb"/>Mao (= Kṛttikās).
<div n="P"/>There remains only the possibility that a common source for
<div n="lb"/>all the three sets — Nakṣatra, Manāzil, and Sieou — may be
<div n="lb"/>found in Babylonia. Hommel<sup>168</sup> has endeavoured to show
<div n="lb"/>that recent research has established in Babylonia the existence
<div n="lb"/>of a lunar zodiac of twenty-four members headed by the
[Page1-430+ 120]
<div n="lb"/>Pleiades (= Kṛttikās); but Thibaut's researches<sup>169</sup> are not
<div n="lb"/>favourable to this claim. On the other hand, Weber,<sup>170</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Whitney,<sup>171</sup> Zimmer,<sup>172</sup> and Oldenberg<sup>173</sup> all incline to the
<div n="lb"/>view that in Babylonia is to be found the origin of the system,
<div n="lb"/>and this must for the present be regarded as the most probable
<div n="lb"/>view, for there are other traces of Babylonian influence in
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature, such as the legend of the flood, perhaps the
<div n="lb"/>Ādityas,<sup>174</sup> and possibly the word {@Manā.@}

<F>156) Mention should here be made of
<div n="lb"/>the following points: (1) Jacobi's argu-
<div n="lb"/>ment from the word Dhruva, the name
<div n="lb"/>of the star pointed out to the bride in
<div n="lb"/>the marriage ritual. The word does
<div n="lb"/>not occur in the literature anterior to
<div n="lb"/>the Gṛhya Sūtras, and it must remain
<div n="lb"/>an undecided question whether the
<div n="lb"/>practice was or was not old. Jacobi
<div n="lb"/>urges that Dhruva means ‘fixed,’ and
<div n="lb"/>that it must originally have referred to
<div n="lb"/>a real fixed pole star, and he thinks
<div n="lb"/>that such a star could only be found
<div n="lb"/>in the third millennium B.C. Whitney
<div n="lb"/>and Oldenberg definitely reject this
<div n="lb"/>view on the ground that too much
<div n="lb"/>must not be made out of a piece of
<div n="lb"/>folk-lore, and that the marriage ritual
<div n="lb"/>requirements would be satisfied by any
<div n="lb"/>star of some magnitude which was
<div n="lb"/>approximately polar. This conclusion
<div n="lb"/>seems convincing. {%Cf.%} Keith, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1909, 1102;
<div n="lb"/>1910, 465; {%contra,%} Jacobi, {%ibid.,%} 1909,
<div n="lb"/>726 {%et seq.;%} 1910, 464. (2) The Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 1, 2, 3, asserts
<div n="lb"/>that the Kṛttikās do not move from
<div n="lb"/>the eastern quarter, which the others
<div n="lb"/>do; and stress has been laid (by Jacobi,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1910,
<div n="lb"/>463, 464) upon this assertion as giving
<div n="lb"/>a date of the third millennium B.C. for
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha observation. But this
<div n="lb"/>notice is quite inadequate to support
<div n="lb"/>any such result, and its lack of trust-
<div n="lb"/>worthiness as a chronological guide is
<div n="lb"/>increased by the fact that the Baudhā-
<div n="lb"/>yana Śrauta Sūtra, xviii 5, has a similar
<div n="lb"/>notice, coupled with another notice,
<div n="lb"/>which, according to Barth, would only
<div n="lb"/>be true somewhere in or after the sixth
<div n="lb"/>century A.D., the equatorial point being
<div n="lb"/>placed between Citrā and Svātī, which
<div n="lb"/>in the early period were both very
<div n="lb"/>much north of the equator (see Caland,
<div n="lb"/>{%Über das rituelle Sūtra des Baudhāyana,%}
<div n="lb"/>37-39). The same passage of the Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 1, 2, 2, in the
<div n="lb"/>Mādhyaṃdina recension, states that
<div n="lb"/>the number of the Kṛttikās is greater
<div n="lb"/>than that of the stars in any of the
<div n="lb"/>other Nakṣatras, which consist of one,
<div n="lb"/>two, three, or four stars, or which,
<div n="lb"/>according to the Kāṇva recension (see
<div n="lb"/>Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 12,
<div n="lb"/>282, n. 2), have four stars. It is not
<div n="lb"/>possible to put much faith in this asser-
<div n="lb"/>tion, for Hasta later has five stars, and
<div n="lb"/>its name (with reference to the fingers)
<div n="lb"/>suggests five ({%cf.%} Weber, {%Naxatra,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>368, 381), and that number is possibly
<div n="lb"/>referred to in the Rigveda (i. 105, 10).
<div n="lb"/>See Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 177.
<div n="lb"/>(3) Attempts have been made to regard
<div n="lb"/>the names of the Nakṣatras as signifi-
<div n="lb"/>cant of their position in the list. Thus
<div n="lb"/>Bentley, {%Historical View,%} 2, thought
<div n="lb"/>Viśākhā was so called because the
<div n="lb"/>equinoctial colure divided the equator
<div n="lb"/>about 1426 B.C.; this is refuted by
<div n="lb"/>Tilak, {%Orion,%} 57 {%et seq.%} Jyeṣṭhaghnī
<div n="lb"/>has been interpreted as ‘slaying the
<div n="lb"/>eldest’ — {%i.e.,%} as marking the new year
<div n="lb"/>by putting an end to the old year.
<div n="lb"/>Tilak, 90, suggests that Mūla was so
<div n="lb"/>called because its acronycal rising
<div n="lb"/>marked the beginning of the year when
<div n="lb"/>the vernal equinox was near Mṛgaśiras.
<div n="lb"/>More probable is Whitney's view, {%Sārya%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Siddhānta,%} 194, that it was the most
<div n="lb"/>southern, and so, as it were, the basis
<div n="lb"/>of the asterisms.</F>

<L>1496<pc>1-431<k1>nakzatradarSa<k2>nakzatradarSa
{@Nakṣatra-darśa@}¦ (‘gazer at the lunar mansions’), an ‘astro-
<div n="lb"/>loger,’ is mentioned in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha,
<div n="lb"/>or ‘human sacrifice,’ in the Yajurveda.<sup>1</sup> A notice in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> indicates that that work regarded the
<div n="lb"/>practice of choosing a particular Nakṣatra under which to set
<div n="lb"/>up the sacrificial fires as an idle one, because it decides in
<div n="lb"/>favour of choosing the sun as one's Nakṣatra.
<F>1) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 10; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 4, 1.</F>
<F>2) ii. 1, 2, 19, and {%cf.%} the Kāṇva text
<div n="lb"/>in Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>xii, 288, n. 3.</F>

<L>1498<pc>1-431<k1>naKa<k2>naKa
{@Nakha@}¦ denotes either the ‘nail’ of a man,<sup>1</sup> or the ‘claw’ of
<div n="lb"/>a wild beast, such as a tiger.<sup>2</sup> The trimming ({%nikṛntana%})<sup>3</sup> of
<div n="lb"/>the nails was a regular part of the toilet of the Vedic Indian,
<div n="lb"/>especially on occasions of special sanctity, when it accompanied
<div n="lb"/>the cleansing of the teeth.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 162, 9; x. 163, 5; Av. ii. 33,
<div n="lb"/>6, etc.</F>

<div n="lb"/>eagle's talon.</F>

<L>1505<pc>1-432<k1>naciketas<k2>naciketas
{@Na-ciketas@}¦ occurs in the well-known legend of the Taitti-
<div n="lb"/>rīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> (where he is a Gotama, the son of {@Vāja-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@śravasa@}), and in the Kaṭha Upaniṣad.<sup>2</sup> His historical reality
<div n="lb"/>is extremely doubtful: in the Upaniṣad he is called son of
<div n="lb"/>Āruṇi Auddālaki or Vājaśravasa, an impossible attribution, and
<div n="lb"/>one due only to a desire to give Naciketas a connexion with
<div n="lb"/>the famous Āruṇi.
<F>1) iii. 11, 8.</F>
<F>2) i. 1, etc. {%Cf.%} Geldner, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 3, 154, n, 1; Weber, {%Indian%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Literature,%} 157; Macdonell, {%Vedic Myth-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ology,%} p. 168.</F>

<L>1506<pc>1-433<k1>naqa<k2>naqa<h>1
1. {@Naḍa,@}¦ ‘reed,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as growing in
<div n="lb"/>lakes, and in the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> is described as {%vārṣika,%} ‘pro-
<div n="lb"/>duced in the rains.’ Reeds were used, after being split, for
<div n="lb"/>making mats, a work carried out by women.<sup>3</sup> They are
<div n="lb"/>frequently mentioned elsewhere.<sup>4</sup> See also {@Nada.@}
<F>1) viii. 1, 33.</F>
<F>2) iv. 19, 1.</F>
<F>3) Av. vi. 138, 5.</F>
<F>4) Av. vi. 137, 2; xii. 2, 1, 19. 50. 54;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxv. 7; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 4, 19; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, vi. 7, 10.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 71.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1507<pc>1-433<k1>naqanEzaDa<k2>naqanEzaDa<h>2
2. {@Naḍa Naiṣadha@}¦ is mentioned in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>where he seems to be<sup>2</sup> a human king who is compared with
<div n="lb"/>Yama, the god of death, because of his conquests. Being
<div n="lb"/>there identified with the southern sacrificial fire, he was pre-
<div n="lb"/>sumably a king of the south, just as Yama is connected with
<div n="lb"/>the south.
<F>1) ii. 2, 2, 1. 2.</F>
<F>2) Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 225-227,
<div n="lb"/>followed by Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the East,%} 12, 338, notes 4 and 5. The
<div n="lb"/>printed text has Naiṣidha by error.</F>

<L>1509<pc>1-433<k1>nada<k2>nada
{@Nada@}¦ is found in several passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> but its
<div n="lb"/>sense is still obscure. It is identified by Pischel<sup>2</sup> with {@Naḍa,@}
<div n="lb"/>being explained by him in one passage<sup>3</sup> as a reed boat, which
<div n="lb"/>is split, and over which the waters go; in another<sup>4</sup> as a reed
<div n="lb"/>whip, of which the sharp points ({%karṇa%}) are used to urge horses
<div n="lb"/>on; and in others<sup>5</sup> again as figuratively designating the penis.
<div n="lb"/>Roth<sup>6</sup> takes the sense to be ‘bull’ (either literally or meta-
[Page1-434+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>phorically) in all passages. Once at least<sup>7</sup> the ‘neigher’ (from
<div n="lb"/>the root {%nad,%} ‘sound’) seems to be meant with reference to
<div n="lb"/>Indra's horse. In the phrase {%nadasya karṇaiḥ%}^8 the sense is,
<div n="lb"/>perhaps, ‘through the ears of the (side) horse’ (that is, by their
<div n="lb"/>being ready to hear the word of command) of their chariot,
<div n="lb"/>the Maruts ‘hasten on with their swift steeds’ ({%turayanta%}
<div n="lb"/>{%āśubhiḥ%}).
<F>1) i. 32, 8; 179, 4; ii. 34, 3; viii. 69, 2;
<div n="lb"/>x. 11, 2; 105, 4. {%Cf.%} Nirukta, v. 2.</F>
<F>2) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 35, 717 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 183 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) i. 32, 8. Here Caland and Henry,
<div n="lb"/>{%L'Agniṣṭoma,%} 312, n., would read {%naḷam.%}
<div n="lb"/>See also Wackernagel, {%Altindische Gram-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%matik,%} 1, 173.</F>
<F>4) ii. 34, 3, followed by Max Müller,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 301 (who,
<div n="lb"/>however, does not construe {%āśubhiḥ,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘sharp,’ with {%karṇaiḥ%} as Pischel does
<div n="lb"/>in {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 190). He sees
<div n="lb"/>‘reed’ also in x. 11, 2, but ‘horse’ in
<div n="lb"/>x. 105, 4.</F>
<F>5) i. 179, 4; viii. 69, 2.</F>
<F>6) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} The
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘bull’ seems imperative in
<div n="lb"/>viii. 89, 2; it is admissible in i. 179, 4,
<div n="lb"/>where ‘bull’ may denote a man, and
<div n="lb"/>in x. 11, 2, and possibly in i. 32, 8,
<div n="lb"/>but ‘reed’ there seems far more likely.</F>
<F>7) x. 105, 4. and in x. 11, 2. The
<div n="lb"/>latter passage suggests that ‘river’
<div n="lb"/>may, after all, be the sense there.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 32,
<div n="lb"/>178, 215.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1510<pc>1-434<k1>nadI<k2>nadI
{@Nadī,@}¦ ‘stream,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Reference is made to shallows ({%gādha%})<sup>3</sup> in the river's bed, to
<div n="lb"/>the opposite bank ({%pāra%}),<sup>4</sup> and to the bathing of horses in
<div n="lb"/>streams.<sup>5</sup> Rivers are also mentioned in close connexion with
<div n="lb"/>mountains.<sup>6</sup> The title Nadī-pati, ‘lord of rivers,’<sup>7</sup> is once
<div n="lb"/>used to express ‘ocean’ or ‘sea-water.’
<F>1) i. 158, 5; ii. 35, 3; iii. 33, 4; v. 46,
<div n="lb"/>6, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. iii. 13, 1; xiv. 1, 43.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 60, 7.</F>
<F>4) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 1, 6, 6.</F>
<F>5) Rv. viii. 2, 2.</F>
<F>6) Rv. v. 55, 7; x. 64, 8.</F>
<F>7) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 3, 4, 10.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1513<pc>1-435<k1>napAt<k2>napAt
{@Napāt@}¦ in Vedic literature apparently has both the wider
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘descendant,’<sup>1</sup> and the narrower one of ‘grandson’ in
<div n="lb"/>the Saṃhitās.<sup>2</sup> In the Brāhmaṇas the word seems hardly to
<div n="lb"/>have the sense of ‘descendant’ at all, while it denotes not
<div n="lb"/>only ‘grandson,’<sup>3</sup> but also ‘great-grandson’ in the sequence
<div n="lb"/>‘sons, grandsons, great-grandsons’ ({%putrān, pautrān, naptṝn%}).<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>‘Grandson’ is also expressed by Pautra (‘son's son’) in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda and later,<sup>5</sup> while the sense of ‘great-grandson’ is
<div n="lb"/>accurately conveyed as early as the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> by Pra-ṇapāt,
<div n="lb"/>used beside Napāt, ‘grandson.’ Naptī, the feminine, is practi-
<div n="lb"/>cally limited to the Saṃhitās,<sup>7</sup> and denotes ‘daughter.’ The
<div n="lb"/>use in the Veda throws no light on the original use of the
<div n="lb"/>word.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) It is equivalent to ‘son’ in a
<div n="lb"/>number of mythological epithets such
<div n="lb"/>as {%apāṃ napāt,%} ‘son of waters.’</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 10, 1, clearly ‘son’; vi. 20,
<div n="lb"/>11, may be ‘grandson.’ Most passages,
<div n="lb"/>vi. 50, 15; vii. 18, 22; viii. 65, 12;
<div n="lb"/>102, 7; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 61;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxii. 2, require ‘de-
<div n="lb"/>scendant.’</F>
<F>3) As in Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 48;
<div n="lb"/>{%putra-naptāraḥ.%} ‘sons and grandsons.’
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Nirukta, viii. 5.</F>
<F>4) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 10, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Āpastamba Śrauta Sūtra, x. 11, 5.</F>
<F>5) Av. ix. 5, 30; xi. 7, 16; Aitarey
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vii. 10, 3; Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ii. 1, 8, 3.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii. 17, 13, with {%napāt.%}</F>
<F>7) Rv. iii. 31, 1 (Nirukta, iii. 4);
<div n="lb"/>viii. 2, 42. {%Cf.%} i. 50, 9; ix. 9, 1; 14, 5;
<div n="lb"/>69, 3; Av. i. 28, 4; ii. 14, 1; vii. 82, 6.</F>
<F>8) Delbrück, {%Die indogermanischen Ver-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%wandtschaftsnamen,%} 403-405; Lanmann,
<div n="lb"/>{%Festgruss an Böhtlingk,%} 77.</F>

<L>1528<pc>1-438<k1>nahus<k2>nahus
{@Nahus@}¦ occurs several times in the Rigveda, but the exact
<div n="lb"/>sense is not certain. Ludwig<sup>1</sup> sees in the Nahus a tribe on
<div n="lb"/>the {@Sindhu@} (Indus)<sup>2</sup> or {@Sarasvatī,@}<sup>3</sup> rich in horses,<sup>4</sup> allied with
<div n="lb"/>the {@Bharatas@} and {@Śimyus,@}<sup>5</sup> connected with {@Kakṣīvant@} and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Vārṣāgiras,@}<sup>6</sup> and having as kings {@Maśarśāra@} and {@Āyavasa.@}<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Roth,<sup>8</sup> on the other hand, sees in Nahus the general sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘neighbour’ as opposed to a member of one's own people ({@Viś@});
<div n="lb"/>this interpretation is supported by the occurrence of the phrase
<div n="lb"/>{%nahuṣo nahuṣṭara,%}<sup>9</sup> ‘closer than a neighbour.’ Nahuṣa has the
<div n="lb"/>same sense as Nahus in two passages of the Rigveda,<sup>10</sup> but in
[Page1-439+ 58]
<div n="lb"/>one it seems to be intended for the proper name of a man.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Possibly Nahus was originally a man like Manu.<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 206.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 31, 11; vi. 22, 10; 46, 7;
<div n="lb"/>x. 80, 6.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 95, 2. {%Cf.%} ix. 88, 2; 91, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. viii. 6, 24.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 100, 18; vii. 18, 5.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 100, 16. 17.</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 122, 15. {%Cf.%} also {%nahuṣo%}
<div n="lb"/>{%viśaḥ,%} Rv. vii. 6, 5; x. 49, 8; 99, 7,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>8) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>9) Rv. x. 49, 8. {%Cf.%} also viii. 8, 3.</F>
<F>10) i. 31, 11; v. 12, 6.</F>
<F>11) Rv. viii. 46, 27.</F>
<F>12) Oldenberg, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>46, 28; Bergaigne, {%Religion Védique,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>324. But Nahus, if it was originally
<div n="lb"/>the name of a mythic forefather, cannot
<div n="lb"/>have been that of a forefather recog-
<div n="lb"/>nized by all the tribes, for there is no
<div n="lb"/>passage in which it applies to all men.
<div n="lb"/>Geldner, {%Ṛgveda, Glossar,%} 92, regards
<div n="lb"/>Nahus as a tribe, Nahuṣa as a king.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 128, leaves
<div n="lb"/>the question open. {%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Texts,%} 1^2, 165, n. 7; 179 {%et seq.;%} 307
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>1529<pc>1-439<k1>nAka<k2>nAka<h>1
1. {@Nāka@}¦ denotes the ‘firmament’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>It is often used with the epithet ‘highest’ ({%uttama%})<sup>3</sup> or ‘third’
<div n="lb"/>({%tṛtīya%})<sup>4</sup> referring to the threefold division of heaven, parallel
<div n="lb"/>to the threefold division of earth, atmosphere, and sky ({@Div@}).
<div n="lb"/>The Nāka is said to be on the third ridge ({%pṛṣṭha%}), above the
<div n="lb"/>luminous space ({%rocana%}) of the sky.<sup>5</sup> Elsewhere<sup>6</sup> the series
<div n="lb"/>earth, atmosphere, sky, and the firmament ({%nāka%}), heaven
<div n="lb"/>({%svar%}), the celestial light ({%jyotis%}), occurs. The word {%nāka%}
<div n="lb"/>is explained in the Brāhmaṇas<sup>7</sup> as derived from {%na,%} ‘not,’
<div n="lb"/>and {%aka,%} ‘pain,’ because those who go there are free from
<div n="lb"/>sorrow.
<F>1) i. 60, 10; 125, 5; iii. 2, 12; iv. 13,
<div n="lb"/>5; vii. 86, 1; 99, 2; viii. 103, 2;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 73, 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. vii. 18, 1; xviii. 2, 47; xiii. 1, 7;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 10; Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xviii. 7, 10; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, viii. 5, 3, 4, etc.</F>
<F>3) Av. iv. 14, 6; xi. 1, 4; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ix. 10; xii. 63.</F>
<F>4) Av. vi. 122, 4; ix. 5, 1. 4; xviii. 4, 3.</F>
<F>5) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 50.</F>
<F>6) Av. iv. 14, 3; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xvii. 67. In Rv. x. 121, 5, the earth
<div n="lb"/>and sky ({%dyauḥ%}), and heaven ({%svar%}), and
<div n="lb"/>the firmament ({%nāka%}), are all mentioned.</F>
<F>7) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, x. 1, 18;
<div n="lb"/>Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, viii. 4, 1, 24;
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta, ii. 14; and {%cf.%} Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, ii. 10, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%} p. 9;
<div n="lb"/>Max Müller, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>32, 50, 56, 57.</F>

<L>1543<pc>1-442<k1>nABAnedizWa<k2>nABAnedizWa
{@Nābhā-nediṣṭha@}¦ (‘nearest in descent’) {@Mānava@} (‘descendant
<div n="lb"/>of Manu’) is famous in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>for the way in which he was treated when his father {@Manu@}
<div n="lb"/>divided his property among his sons, or they divided it:
<div n="lb"/>Nābhānediṣṭha was left out, but was solaced by obtaining,
<div n="lb"/>through his father's advice, cows from the Aṅgirases, a feat
<div n="lb"/>which is regarded in the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>2</sup> as on a
<div n="lb"/>level with the exploits of other seers who celebrated their
<div n="lb"/>patrons in hymns, and as giving rise to the hymn, Rigveda x. 62.
<div n="lb"/>Nābhānediṣṭha's hymn is repeatedly mentioned in the Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇas,<sup>3</sup> but beyond its authorship nothing is recorded of him.
<div n="lb"/>In the Saṃhitā<sup>4</sup> itself he seems to be spoken of as a poet in
<div n="lb"/>one passage, which is, however, of quite uncertain meaning.
<div n="P"/>Nābhānediṣṭha is etymologically connected in all probability
<div n="lb"/>with Nabānazdiṣta in the Avesta, which refers to the Fravaṣi
<div n="lb"/>of the paoiryō-ṭkaēsha and the Fravaṣi of the Nabānazdiṣta.
<div n="lb"/>Lassen<sup>5</sup> saw in the legend a reminiscence of an Indo-Iranian
<div n="lb"/>split; but Roth<sup>6</sup> showed conclusively that this was impossible,
<div n="lb"/>and that Nābhānediṣṭha meant simply ‘nearest in birth,’ and
[Page1-443+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>Weber<sup>7</sup> admits that the connexion of the words is not one of
<div n="lb"/>borrowing on either side, but that in the Avesta it has kept its
<div n="lb"/>original sense of ‘nearest relation,’ while in the Rigveda it has
<div n="lb"/>become a proper name.
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 1. 9. 4-6;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, v. 14. {%Cf.%} Muir,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 191 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) xvi. 11. 28-30.</F>
<F>3) Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xxviii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>merely refers to him as connected with
<div n="lb"/>the Aṅgirases. See also {%ibid.,%} xxx. 4;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vi. 30. 31; Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xx. 9, 4.</F>
<F>4) x. 61, 18.</F>
<F>5) {%Indische Alterthumskunde,%} 1, 520, and
<div n="lb"/>{%Addenda,%} p. lxxvii.</F>
<F>6) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 6, 243 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>7) {%Episches im vedischen Ritual,%} 40-50. {%Cf.%} also {@Dāya.@}</F>
<LEND>

<L>1547<pc>1-443<k1>nAman<k2>nAman
{@Nāman,@}¦ ‘name,’ is a common word from the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>onwards. The Gṛhya Sūtras<sup>1</sup> give elaborate rules for the
<div n="lb"/>formation of the names of children, but more important is
<div n="lb"/>the distinction between the secret ({%guhya%}) and the ordinary
<div n="lb"/>name, though the rules as to the secret name are not at all
<div n="lb"/>consistent. The secret name is already recognized in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>2</sup> and is referred to in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>3</sup> one secret
<div n="lb"/>name, that of Arjuna for Indra, being given in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa.<sup>4</sup> It is to be noted that the rule as to giving the
[Page1-444+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>designation of a Nakṣatra (lunar asterism) as the secret name
<div n="lb"/>or otherwise is not illustrated by a single recorded name of a
<div n="lb"/>teacher in the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup> several times mentions the
<div n="lb"/>adoption of a second name with a view to securing success,
<div n="lb"/>and also refers to the adoption of another name for purposes
<div n="lb"/>of distinction.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="P"/>In actual practice two names are usually found in the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas, the second being a patronymic or a metronymic,
<div n="lb"/>as in {@Kakṣīvant Auśija@}<sup>8</sup> (if the story of the slave woman Uśij
<div n="lb"/>as his mother is correct), or {@Bṛhaduktha Vāmneya,@}<sup>9</sup> ‘son of
<div n="lb"/>Vāmnī,’ though the relationship may, of course, be not direct
<div n="lb"/>parentage, but more remote descent.<sup>10</sup> Three names are less
<div n="lb"/>common — for example, {@Kūśāmba Svāyava Lātavya,@}<sup>11</sup> ‘son of
<div n="lb"/>Svāyu, of the Lātavya (son of Latu) family,’ or {@Devataras@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Śyāvasāyana Kāśyapa,@}<sup>12</sup> where the patronymic and the Gotra
<div n="lb"/>name are both found. In other cases the names probably
<div n="lb"/>have a local reference — {%e.g.,%} {@Kauśāmbeya@} and {@Gāṅgya.@} Fre-
<div n="lb"/>quently the patronymic only is given, as {@Bhārgava, Maudgalya,@}
<div n="lb"/>etc., or two patronymics are used. The simple name is often
<div n="lb"/>used for the patronymic — {%e.g.,%} {@Trasadasyu.@}<sup>13</sup> In a few cases
<div n="lb"/>the name of the wife is formed from the husband's name,<sup>14</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>{@Uśīnarāṇī, Purukutsānī, Mudgalānī.@}
<F>1) Weber, {%Naxatra,%} 2, 316 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt, {%Rituallitteratur,%} 46, 47;
<div n="lb"/>Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte,%} 152.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} x. 55, 2; 71, 1, as explained in
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Āraṇyaka, i. 3, 3.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vi. 1, 3, 9
<div n="lb"/>(the name is given to a child at birth);
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 4, 25.</F>
<F>4) ii. 1, 2, 11; v. 4, 3, 7; Weber, 2,
<div n="lb"/>317, n. 3.</F>
<F>5) Weber, 2, 318, 319. See {@Aṣāḍha,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Rauhiṇa, Rauhiṇāyana.@}</F>
<F>6) iii. 6, 2, 24; v. 3, 3, 14; ix. 4, 3, 3,

<div n="lb"/>derived from a feast performed by the

<L>1551<pc>1-445<k1>nArASaMsI<k2>nArASaMsI
{@Nārāśaṃsī@}¦ (scil. Ṛc), ‘(verse) celebrating men,’ is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>as early as the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and is distinguished from {@Gāthā@} in
<div n="lb"/>a number of passages in the later literature.<sup>2</sup> The Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā,<sup>3</sup> while distinguishing the two, asserts that both are
<div n="lb"/>false ({%anṛtam%}). It is hardly probable that the two were abso-
<div n="lb"/>lutely distinct, for the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> has the phrase
<div n="lb"/>‘a Gāthā celebrating men’ ({%nārāśaṃsī%}). What such verses
<div n="lb"/>were may be seen from the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra,<sup>5</sup> which
<div n="lb"/>enumerates the {%Nārāśaṃsāni%} at the Puruṣamedha, or ‘human
[Page1-446+ 63]
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice.’ They may legitimately be reckoned as a source of
<div n="lb"/>the epic.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>The term Nārāśaṃsī is restricted in some passages<sup>7</sup> to a
<div n="lb"/>particular group of three verses of the Atharvaveda,<sup>8</sup> but
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg<sup>9</sup> must be right in holding that the restricted sense
<div n="lb"/>is not to be read into the Rigveda.<sup>10</sup> Not even in the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>11</sup> is the technical sense certain, and the Bṛhaddevatā<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>gives the word a general application.
<F>1) x. 85, 6.</F>
<F>2) Av. xv. 6, 4; Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>vii. 5, 11, 2; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,

<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, v. 5, 2; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, ii. 10, etc.; Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 5, 78. The passage, Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5, 6, 8, is uncertain.
<div n="lb"/>See Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>44, 98, n. 5.</F>
<F>3) xiv. 5; Weber, {%Indische Streifen,%} 1,
<div n="lb"/>98.</F>
<F>4) i. 3, 2, 6.</F>
<F>5) xvi. 11, 1 {%et seq.;%} Weber, {%Episches%}
<div n="lb"/>{%im vedischen Ritual,%} 10 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>6) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 15, 264, n. Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%Atharvaveda,%} 100 ({%cf. Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 688, 689), lays stress rather on

<L>1552<pc>1-446<k1>nArI<k2>nArI

<div n="lb"/>husband’); vii. 20. 5; x. 18, 7 ({%avidhavāḥ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%supatnīḥ,%} ‘not widowed, with noble
<div n="lb"/>husbands’), etc.</F>
<F>3) i. 73, 3 ({%pati-juṣṭā,%} ‘dear to her

<L>1557<pc>1-447<k1>nAvapraBraMSana<k2>nAvapraBraMSana
{@Nāva-prabhraṃśana,@}¦ the ‘sliding down of the ship,’ is read
<div n="lb"/>in Whitney and Roth's text of the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> and has been
<div n="lb"/>connected by Weber<sup>2</sup> and others<sup>3</sup> with Manor Avasarpaṇa, the

<div n="lb"/>on which Manu's ship settled on the subsidence of the deluge.

<div n="lb"/>pretation is highly improbable, and this view is accepted by

<div n="lb"/>Macdonell.<sup>7</sup> The expression is analyzed as {%na ava-prabhraṃśana%}
<div n="lb"/>by the Pada text and the commentator alike, and is never found
<div n="lb"/>elsewhere with reference to the descent of a boat or ship.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) xix. 39, 8, where the reading {%nāva-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%prabhráṃśana%} is a conjectural emendā-
<div n="lb"/>tion, the manuscripts of the Saṃhitā
<div n="lb"/>text all having two accents, {%nāvapra-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%bhráṃśana%} (one of them reading {%nāvaḥ-%}).</F>
<F>2) {%Indische Streifen,%} 1, 11.</F>

<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, 3, 198; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books%}

<div n="lb"/>961.</F>

<div n="lb"/>1907, 1107, where his acceptance of
<div n="lb"/>Weber's interpretation in his {%Sanskrit%}

<L>1584<pc>1-452<k1>nivid<k2>nivid
{@Ni-vid@}¦ denotes a brief invocation of the deity that is invited
<div n="lb"/>in a liturgy in honour of the god. The Brāhmaṇas<sup>1</sup> repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>mention Nivids as inserted in the Śastras (recitations), and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Khilas@} of the Rigveda<sup>2</sup> preserve among them a set of Nivids.
<div n="lb"/>But it is doubtful<sup>3</sup> whether the habit of using such brief
<div n="lb"/>formulas — the Nivid is usually not more than a Pada or
<div n="lb"/>quarter-verse in length — is known to the Rigveda, though it
<div n="lb"/>has been seen even there,<sup>4</sup> and the word Nivid is several times
<div n="lb"/>found in that Saṃhitā,<sup>5</sup> but hardly in the technical sense of
<div n="lb"/>the Brāhmaṇas. In the later Saṃhitās<sup>6</sup> the technical sense is
<div n="lb"/>common.
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 33. 34;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 10. 11; vi. 33. 35; Kauṣītaki Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, xiv. 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 9, 3, 28; xiii. 5, 1. 9, etc.; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, i. 5, 2; Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇ-
<div n="lb"/>yaka, i. 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) See Scheftelowitz, {%Die Apokryphen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%des Ṛgveda,%} 137-143.</F>
<F>3) The antiquity of the Nivids was
<div n="lb"/>asserted by Haug, {%Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 26 {%et seq.,%} and often since, {%e.g.,%} by
<div n="lb"/>Tilak, {%Orion,%} 206; Scheftelowitz, {%op. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>3. It is shown to be most improbable
<div n="lb"/>by Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 9, 265, 355,
<div n="lb"/>and Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 242
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.; Göttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,%}
<div n="lb"/>1907, 232, 233.</F>
<F>4) i. 86, 4; Bezzenberger's {%Beiträge,%}
<div n="lb"/>9, 192. So Oldenberg, {%Sacred Books of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the East,%} 46, 119, 122, takes Rv. i. 96,
<div n="lb"/>2, to refer to the Nivids in the technical
<div n="lb"/>sense, but not to the Nivids as pre-
<div n="lb"/>served.</F>
<F>5) i. 89, 3; 96, 2; 175, 6; ii. 36, 6;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 18, 7; vi. 67, 10.</F>
<F>6) Av. v. 26, 4; xi. 7, 19; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xix, 25, etc.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Rituallitteratur,%} 102;
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg, {%Religion des Veda,%} 387, n. 2;
<div n="lb"/>Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 241.</F>

<L>1588<pc>1-453<k1>nizaNgin<k2>nizaNgin
{@Ni-ṣaṅgin@}¦ is found three times in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where,

<L>1589<pc>1-453<k1>nizAda<k2>nizAda
{@Ni-ṣāda@}¦ is found in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The word seems to denote not so much a particular tribe, but
<div n="lb"/>to be the general term for the non-Āryan tribes who were not
<div n="lb"/>under Āryan control, as the Śūdras were, for Aupamanyava<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>took the five peoples ({%pañca janāḥ%}) to be the four castes ({%catvāro%}
[Page1-454+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>{%varṇāḥ%}) and the Niṣādas, and the commentator Mahīdhara
<div n="lb"/>explains the word where it occurs in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as meaning a Bhilla, or Bhīl. A village of Niṣādas is men-
<div n="lb"/>tioned in the Lāṭyāyana Śrauta Sūtra,<sup>4</sup> and a Niṣāda {@Sthapati,@}
<div n="lb"/>a leader of some kind, is referred to in the Kātyāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra<sup>5</sup> and in a Brāhmaṇa cited by the scholiast on that
<div n="lb"/>passage. Weber<sup>6</sup> thinks that the Niṣādas were the settled
<div n="lb"/>aborigines (form {%ni,%} ‘down,’ and {%sad,%} ‘settle’), a view sup-
<div n="lb"/>ported by the fact that the ritual of the Viśvajit sacrifice<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>requires a temporary residence with Niṣādas; for the Niṣādas
<div n="lb"/>who would permit an Āryan to reside temporarily amongst
<div n="lb"/>them must have been partially amenable to Āryan influence.
<div n="lb"/>But the name might easily be applied to the whole body of
<div n="lb"/>aborigines outside the Āryan organization. Von Schroeder<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thinks that the Niṣādas were most probably identical with the
<div n="lb"/>Nysæans, who, according to the Greek account, sent an
<div n="lb"/>embassy to Alexander when he was in the territory of the
<div n="lb"/>Aśvakas, but this identification is doubtful.
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 4, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvii. 13; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 27; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 11;
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xvi. 6, 8, etc.</F>
<F>2) In Yāska, Nirukta, iii. 8.</F>
<F>3) xvi. 27. {%Cf.%} xxx. 8.</F>
<F>4) viii. 2, 8.</F>
<F>5) i. 1, 12; Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>10, 13.</F>
<F>6) {%Indische Studien,%} 9, 340. {%Cf.%} 10, 13,
<div n="lb"/>16.</F>
<F>7) See Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xxv. 15;
<div n="lb"/>Lāṭyāyana, {%loc. cit.;%} Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>8) {%Indiens Literatur und Cultur,%} 366.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 39,
<div n="lb"/>119. In the later system (Manu, x. 8)
<div n="lb"/>the Niṣāda is the offspring of a Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa and of a Śūdra woman, while the
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhatsaṃhitā of Varāhamihira (xiv. 10)
<div n="lb"/>recognizes a kingdom ({%rāṣṭra%}) of Niṣādas
<div n="lb"/>in the south-east of Madhyadeśa. In the
<div n="lb"/>Pāli texts (Fick, {%Die sociale Gliederung,%}
<div n="lb"/>12, 160, 206 {%et seq.%}) they are wild
<div n="lb"/>hunters and fishers. {%Cf.%} also Muir,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 301, 303, 366, n. 164,
<div n="lb"/>403, 481.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1590<pc>1-454<k1>nizka<k2>nizka

<div n="lb"/>adornment. Later the use of Niṣkas as currency is quite clear.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} also {@Kṛṣṇala.@}

<div n="lb"/>xiii. 4, 1, 7. 11, etc.</F>

<F>4) Rv. v. 19, 3; Av. v. 17, 14.</F>
<F>5) xvii. 1, 14, as worn by the Vrātya

<L>1593<pc>1-455<k1>nihAkA<k2>nihAkA
{@Nihākā@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>2</sup> appears

<L>1607<pc>1-457<k1>nftU<k2>nftU
{@Nṛtū@}¦ occurs once in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> denoting a female ‘dancer.’
<div n="lb"/>In another passage<sup>2</sup> Nṛti is found coupled with {%hāsa,%} ‘laughter,’
<div n="lb"/>in the description of the funeral ritual; but though it is clear
<div n="lb"/>that a joyful celebration is meant (like the Irish ‘wake’ or the
[Page1-458+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>old-fashioned feasting in Scotland after a funeral), it is difficult
<div n="lb"/>to be certain that actual dancing is here meant. Dancing is,
<div n="lb"/>however, often referred to in the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> and later. Nṛtta-
<div n="lb"/>gīta, ‘dance and song,’ are mentioned in the Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> as found in the sixth world. See also {@Śailūṣa.@}
<F>1) i. 92, 4 (where Uṣas, Goddess of Dawn, is compared to a dancer).</F>
<F>2) x. 18, 3. {%Cf.%} 29, 2.</F>
<F>3) i. 10, 1; 92, 4, etc. See Weber,
<div n="lb"/>{%Indian Literature,%} 196 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) i. 42 ({%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 15, 235).</F>

<div n="lb"/>temporary with the defeat of {@Purukutsa.@} He was a {@Gotama.@}<sup>5</sup>

<L>1626<pc>1-461<k1>nO<k2>nO
{@Nau@}¦ is the regular word in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> for a
<div n="lb"/>‘boat’ or ‘ship.’ In the great majority of cases the ship was
<div n="lb"/>merely a boat for crossing rivers, though no doubt a large boat
<div n="lb"/>was needed for crossing many of the broad rivers of the Panjab
<div n="lb"/>as well as the {@Yamunā@} and {@Gaṅgā.@} Often no doubt the Nau
<div n="lb"/>was a mere dug-out canoe ({%dāru%}).<sup>3</sup> It is certainly against the
<div n="lb"/>theory<sup>4</sup> of the existence in Vedic times of an extensive sea
<div n="lb"/>trade that there is no mention of any of the parts of a ship, such
<div n="lb"/>as masts and sails, except the oar ({@Aritra@}), Yet there are some
<div n="lb"/>allusions indicating a trade more extensive than that implied
<div n="lb"/>by boats used for crossing rivers. The Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> compares
<div n="lb"/>the ruin of a kingdom where Brahmins are oppressed to the
[Page1-462+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>sinking of a ship which is leaking ({%bhinnā%}); though the language
<div n="lb"/>here employed can be made to fit the theory that the ship was
<div n="lb"/>only a canoe, it cannot naturally be so interpreted. Moreover,
<div n="lb"/>there is mention made in the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> of men who go to the
<div n="lb"/>ocean ({@Samudra@}) eager for gain ({%saniṣyavaḥ%}). It is not altogether
<div n="lb"/>satisfactory to restrict such references with Zimmer<sup>7</sup> to the
<div n="lb"/>broad stream of the Indus after the union of that river with
<div n="lb"/>the tributaries of the Panjab. In the Rigveda<sup>8</sup> too it is said
<div n="lb"/>that the Aśvins rescued {@Bhujyu@} in the ocean with a ship of
<div n="lb"/>a hundred oars ({%śatāritra%}). It is not easy to refuse to recognize
<div n="lb"/>here the existence of larger vessels with many oars used for
<div n="lb"/>sea voyages. The Baudhāyana Dharma Sūtra,<sup>9</sup> at any rate,
<div n="lb"/>clearly refers to maritime navigation. See also {@Samudra.@}
<F>1) i. 131, 2; ii. 39, 4; viii. 42, 3;
<div n="lb"/>83, 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. ii. 36, 5; v. 19. 8; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, v. 3, 10, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, x. 19; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iv. 13;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 6. 21; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 8,
<div n="lb"/>1, 4; iv. 2, 5, 10, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 155, 3.</F>
<F>4) Wilson, {%Rigveda,%} 1, xli.</F>
<F>5) v. 19, 8. {%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of Philology,%} 19, 139. So per-
<div n="lb"/>haps the passage, Rv. i. 32, 8, {%nadaṃ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%na bhinnam,%} refers to a ship. See
<div n="lb"/>{@Naḍa.@}</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 56, 2; iv. 55, 6.</F>
<F>7) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 22, 23.</F>
<F>8) i. 116, 3 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>9) i. 2, 4; ii. 2, 2. But it is not of
<div n="lb"/>very early date.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 255-257.</F>

<L>1627<pc>1-462<k1>nyagroDa<k2>nyagroDa
{@Nyag-rodha,@}¦ ‘growing downwards,’ is the name of the
<div n="lb"/>{%Ficus indica,%} a tree remarkable for sending down from its
<div n="lb"/>branches fibres which take root and form new stems. Though
<div n="lb"/>the tree is not mentioned by name in the Rigveda, it appears
<div n="lb"/>to have been known, as Pischel<sup>1</sup> has shown from a hymn<sup>2</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>which its characteristics may be recognized. It is frequently
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> and the later literature.<sup>4</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial bowls ({@Camasa@}) were made of its wood.<sup>5</sup> It was
<div n="lb"/>doubtless of the greatest importance, as in modern times, to
<div n="lb"/>the Vedic village. The sister tree, the {@Aśvattha@} ({%Ficus religiosa%}),
<div n="lb"/>already occurs in the Rigveda.
<F>1) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 113, 114.</F>
<F>2) i. 24, 7, where {%stūpa%} seems to
<div n="lb"/>denote the crest or crown of the tree
<div n="lb"/>above the main trunk.</F>
<F>3) iv. 37, 4; v. 5, 5.</F>
<F>4) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 30. 31;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 3, 5, 13
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 2, 7, 3; Chāndogya Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>vi. 12, 1, etc.</F>
<F>5) Taittirīya Samhitā, vii. 4, 12, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 13.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 58.</F>

<L>1633<pc>1-463<k1>pakTa<k2>pakTa
{@Paktha@}¦ is the name of a people in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where they
<div n="lb"/>appear as one of the tribes that opposed<sup>2</sup> the {@Tṛtsu-Bharatas@} in
<div n="lb"/>the {@Dāśarājña.@} or ‘battle of the ten kings.’ Zimmer<sup>3</sup> compares
[Page1-464+ 44]
<div n="lb"/>them with the tribe of <lang n="greek"></lang> and their country <lang n="greek"></lang>,
<div n="lb"/>mentioned as in the north-west of India by Herodotus,<sup>4</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>with the modern Pakhthūn in Eastern Afghanistan, holding
<div n="lb"/>that they were a northern tribe; this is probable, since the
<div n="lb"/>Bharatas seem to have occupied the Madhyadeśa, or ‘Middle
<div n="lb"/>Land.’ In three passages of the Rigveda<sup>5</sup> a Paktha is referred
<div n="lb"/>to as a protégé of the Aśvins. The second connects him with
<div n="lb"/>{@Trasadasyu,@} whose tribe, the {@Pūrus,@} were aided by the Pakthas
<div n="lb"/>in their unsuccessful onslaught on {@Sudās.@} In the third passage
<div n="lb"/>he seems specified as {@Tūrvāyaṇa,@} and appears as an opponent
<div n="lb"/>of {@Cyavāna.@}<sup>6</sup> Probably, therefore, Paktha in all cases denotes
<div n="lb"/>the king of the Paktha people.
<F>1) vii. 18. 7.</F>
<F>2) Roth, {%Zur Litteratur und Geschichte%}
<div n="lb"/>{%des Weda,%} 95, thought that the Pakthas
<div n="lb"/>were allies of the Trtsus, but this view
<div n="lb"/>is certainly incorrect. {%Cf.%} Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>15, 260.</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 430, 431.</F>
<F>4) vii. 65 (<lang n="greek"></lang>); iii. 102 and iv. 44
<div n="lb"/>(<lang n="greek"></lang>).</F>
<F>5) viii. 22, 10; 49, 10; x. 61, 1.</F>
<F>6) Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 71-77.</F>

<L>1641<pc>1-466<k1>pajra<k2>pajra
{@Pajra@}¦ is the name of the family from which {@Kakṣīvant@}

<div n="lb"/>Roth<sup>5</sup> sees a Pajra called Sāmaṅ. This is uncertain, but in
<div n="lb"/>any case a Pajra seems clearly alluded to. Elsewhere<sup>6</sup> it is
<div n="lb"/>very doubtful whether the word is a proper name at all. In
<div n="lb"/>the Śāṭyāyana<sup>7</sup> the Pajras are declared to be Aṅgirases.
<F>1) i. 117, 10; 122, 7. 8; 126, 4. 5.</F>
<F>2) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 97, 98.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 127, 8, where Roth (St.
<div n="lb"/>Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}) thinks this
<div n="lb"/>compound is probably a proper name.</F>
<F>4) Rv. viii. 4, 17; 6, 47.</F>
<F>5) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v. pajra.%}</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 190, 5, where the reference

<L>1644<pc>1-466<k1>paYcajanAH<k2>paYcajanAH
{@Pañca-janāḥ,@}¦ the ‘five peoples,’ are mentioned under various
<div n="lb"/>names in Vedic literature.<sup>1</sup> Who are meant by the five is very
<div n="lb"/>uncertain. The Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> explains the five to be
<div n="lb"/>gods, men, Gandharvas and Apsarases, snakes, and the Fathers.
[Page1-467+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>Aupamanyava<sup>3</sup> held that the four castes ({@Varṇa@}) and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Niṣādas@} made up the five, and Sāyaṇa<sup>4</sup> is of the same opinion.
<div n="lb"/>Yāska<sup>5</sup> thinks that the five are the Gandharvas, fathers, gods,
<div n="lb"/>Asuras, and Rakṣases. No one of these explanations can be
<div n="lb"/>regarded as probable. Roth<sup>6</sup> and Geldner<sup>7</sup> think that all the
<div n="lb"/>peoples of the earth are méant: just as there are four quarters
<div n="lb"/>({@Diś@}), there are peoples at the four quarters (N. E. S. W.), with
<div n="lb"/>the Āryan folk in the middle. Zimmer<sup>8</sup> opposes this view on
<div n="lb"/>the ground that the inclusion of all peoples in one expression is
<div n="lb"/>not in harmony with the distinction so often made between
<div n="lb"/>Āryan and Dāsa; that neither {%janāsaḥ,%} ‘men,’<sup>9</sup> nor {%mānuṣāḥ,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘people,’<sup>10</sup> could be used of non-Āryans; that the Soma is
<div n="lb"/>referred to as being among the five tribes;<sup>11</sup> that the five tribes
<div n="lb"/>are mentioned as on the {@Sarasvatī,@}<sup>12</sup> and that Indra is {%pāñca-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%janya,%}<sup>13</sup> ‘belonging to the five peoples.’ He concludes that
<div n="lb"/>Āryans alone are meant, and in particular the five tribes of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Anus, Druhyus, Yadus, Turvaśas,@} and {@Pūrus,@} who are all
<div n="lb"/>mentioned together in one or perhaps two hymns of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>14</sup> and four of whom occur in another hymn.<sup>15</sup> But he
<div n="lb"/>admits that the expression might easily be used more generally
<div n="lb"/>later. Hopkins<sup>16</sup> has combated Zimmer's view, but his own
<div n="lb"/>opinion rests mainly on his theory that there was no people
<div n="lb"/>named Turvaśa, but only a king of the Yadus called Turvaśa,
<div n="lb"/>and that theory is not very probable.

<div n="lb"/>work<sup>19</sup> seven peoples are alluded to.

<L>1646<pc>1-468<k1>paYcanada<k2>paYcanada
{@Pañca-nada,@}¦ ‘having five streams,’ is not found until the
<div n="lb"/>epic period as the name of the Panjāb, which has no desig-
<div n="lb"/>nation in the earlier literature. The importance of the Panjāb
<div n="lb"/>as the home<sup>1</sup> of the Rigveda has been greatly diminished by
<div n="lb"/>recent research, Hopkins,<sup>2</sup> Pischel,<sup>3</sup> and Geldner<sup>4</sup> having on
<div n="lb"/>different grounds shown reason for believing that the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>at least in great part, was composed farther east, in the
<div n="lb"/>{@Madhyadeśa,@} which admittedly was the home of the later Vedic
<div n="lb"/>culture. Hillebrandt<sup>5</sup> considers that the Rigveda belongs in
<div n="lb"/>part to the Panjāb, or rather to Arachosia, and in part to the
<div n="lb"/>Middle Country. See also {@Kuru, Tṛtsu.@}
<F>1) See, {%e.g.,%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}

<L>1648<pc>1-468<k1>paYcAla<k2>paYcAla
{@Pañcāla@}¦ is the later name<sup>1</sup> of the people called {@Krivi@} in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda. The Pañcālas are rarely referred to except in con-
<div n="lb"/>nexion with the {@Kurus,@} and the kings of the Kuru-Pañcālas
<div n="lb"/>are mentioned in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> In the Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup> the Pañcālas appear as the people of {@Keśin Dālbhya.@}
[Page1-469+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>In the Upaniṣads and later<sup>4</sup> the Brahmins of the Pañcālas
<div n="lb"/>figure as taking part in philosophical and philological dis-
<div n="lb"/>cussions. The Saṃhitopaniṣad Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> makes mention of
<div n="lb"/>the Prācya-Pañcālas.
<div n="P"/>The Pañcālas, no doubt, included other tribes besides the
<div n="lb"/>Krivis. The name seems to refer to five tribes, and it has
<div n="lb"/>been suggested<sup>6</sup> that the Pañcālas represent the five tribes of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, but the suggestion is not very probable. There
<div n="lb"/>is no trace in Vedic literature of the Epic division of the
<div n="lb"/>Pañcālas into northern ({%uttara%}) and southern ({%dakṣiṇa%}). The
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup> mentions their town {@Paricakrā;@} other
<div n="lb"/>towns to which allusion seems to be made were {@Kāmpīla@} and
<div n="lb"/>kauśāmbī.<sup>8</sup> Of their kings and chiefs, as distinguished from
<div n="lb"/>kings of the Kuru-Pañcālas, we hear of {@Kraivya, Durmukha,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Pravāhaṇa Jaivali,@} and {@Śona.@}
<F>1) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 5, 4, 7.</F>
<F>2) viii. 14</F>
<F>3) xxx. 2 ({%Indische Studien,%} 3, 471).</F>
<F>4) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 1, 1
<div n="lb"/>(Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1 Kāṇva);
<div n="lb"/>Chāndogya Upaniṣad, v. 3, 1; Ṛgveda
<div n="lb"/>Prātiśākhya, ii. 12, 44; Nidāna Sūtra,
<div n="lb"/>i. 6; Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xii. 13,
<div n="lb"/>6, etc.</F>

<L>1655<pc>1-470<k1>paqbISa<k2>paqbISa
{@Paḍ-bīśa,@}¦ the ‘foot-fetter’ of a horse in five passages, two
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and one each in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the Chāndogya Upaniṣad,<sup>3</sup> and the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka.<sup>4</sup>

<div n="lb"/>literal sense is ‘foot-fastening’ ({%paḍ%} being = {%pad,%} ‘foot,’ and
<div n="lb"/>{%bīśa,%} written {%vīśa%} in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, being connected
<div n="lb"/>with the Latin {%vincire,%} ‘bind’). Pischel<sup>7</sup> objects that the
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘foot-fastening’ involves the absurdity, in the Upaniṣad
<div n="lb"/>passages, of a fine horse from the {@Sindhu@} (Indus) being spoken
<div n="lb"/>of as tearing up the peg to which it is fastened. He suggests
<div n="lb"/>instead the meaning of ‘hobble,’ which must be right.<sup>8</sup>

<F>2) vi. 2, 13 (Mādhyaṃdina).</F>
<F>3) v. 1, 12.</F>
<F>4) ix. 7; Keith, {%Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka,%}
<div n="lb"/>57, n. 3.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 97, 16; Av. viii. 1, 4; xii. 5,
<div n="lb"/>15; xvi. 8, 27; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>i. 6, 10, 3; Mantra Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 10.</F>
<F>6) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>

<div n="lb"/>word as derived from {%paś,%} ‘tie.’ {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Macdoneli, {%Vedic Grammar,%} p. 34 (top).
<div n="lb"/>But the form {%paḍ%} may be due to a
<div n="lb"/>false analogy, and the sense of ‘foot-
<div n="lb"/>fastener’ may express ‘hobble’ quite
<div n="lb"/>satisfactorily; it is not confined to a
<div n="lb"/>rope tied to a peg in the ground.</F>

<L>1657<pc>1-471<k1>paRi<k2>paRi
{@Paṇi@}¦ in the Rigveda appears to denote a person who is
<div n="lb"/>rich, but who does not give offerings to the gods, or bestow
<div n="lb"/>{@Dakṣiṇās@} on the priests, and who is therefore an object of
<div n="lb"/>intense dislike to the composers of the Saṃhitā.<sup>1</sup> Hence the
<div n="lb"/>gods are asked to attack the Paṇis, who are also referred to
<div n="lb"/>as being defeated with slaughter.<sup>2</sup> The Paṇi is opposed to the
<div n="lb"/>pious sacrificer as a niggard,<sup>3</sup> and is spoken of as a wolf,<sup>4</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>symbol of enmity. In some passages<sup>5</sup> the Paṇis definitely
<div n="lb"/>appear as mythological figures, demons who withhold the cows
<div n="lb"/>or waters of heaven, and to whom Saramā goes on a mission
<div n="lb"/>from Indra.<sup>6</sup> Among the Paṇis {@Bṛbu@} was apparently important.
<div n="lb"/>In one passage of the Rigveda<sup>7</sup> they are described as {@Beka-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@nāṭas,@} or ‘usurers’ (?). In another<sup>8</sup> they are called {@Dasyus,@}
<div n="lb"/>and styled {%mṛdhra-vāc,%} probably ‘of hostile speech,’ and {%grathin,%}
<div n="lb"/>a word of uncertain meaning. Hillebrandt<sup>9</sup> thinks that the
<div n="lb"/>latter epithet refers to the continuous flow of a speech which
[Page1-472+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>is not understood, and that {%mṛdhra-vāc%} means ‘śpeaking an
<div n="lb"/>enemy's speech,’ though not necessarily with reference to
<div n="lb"/>non-Āryans.<sup>10</sup> In two passages<sup>11</sup> the Paṇis appear as {@Dāsas,@}
<div n="lb"/>and in one<sup>12</sup> a Paṇi is mentioned in connexion with wer-
<div n="lb"/>geld ({@Vaira@}), being apparently regarded as equal to a man
<div n="lb"/>merely in the price put on his life, but in other respects as
<div n="lb"/>inferior.
<div n="P"/>It is difficult to be certain exactly who a Paṇi was. Roth<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thinks that the word is derived from {%paṇ,%} ‘barter,’ and that
<div n="lb"/>the Paṇi is properly the man who will give nothing without
<div n="lb"/>return, hence the niggard, who neither worships the gods nor
<div n="lb"/>rewards their priests. This view is accepted by Zimmer<sup>14</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>by Ludwig.<sup>15</sup> The latter scholar thinks the apparent references
<div n="lb"/>to fights with Paṇis are to be explained by their having been
<div n="lb"/>aboriginal traders who went in caravans — as in Arabia and
<div n="lb"/>Northern Africa — prepared to fight, if need be, to protect their
<div n="lb"/>goods against attacks which the Āryans would naturally deem
<div n="lb"/>quite justified. He supports this explanation by the references
<div n="lb"/>to the Paṇis as Dasyus and Dāsas. It is, however, hardly
<div n="lb"/>necessary to do more than regard the Paṇis generally as
<div n="lb"/>non-worshippers of the gods favoured by the singers; the term
<div n="lb"/>is wide enough to cover either the aborigines or hostile Āryan
<div n="lb"/>tribes, as well as demons. Hillebrandt,<sup>16</sup> however, thinks that
<div n="lb"/>a real tribe is meant, the Parnians of Strabo, and that they
<div n="lb"/>were associated with the Dahae ({@Dāsa@}). Moreover, he finds
<div n="lb"/>them associated in one passage<sup>17</sup> with the {@Pārāvatas,@} whom
[Page1-473+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>he identifies with the <lang n="greek"></lang> of Ptolemy,<sup>18</sup> and with {@Bṛṣaya,@}
<div n="lb"/>whom he connects with <lang n="greek"></lang> of Arrian;<sup>19</sup> he also con-
<div n="lb"/>siders that the frequent<sup>20</sup> mention of the Paṇis as opponents
<div n="lb"/>of {@Divodāsa@} shows that the latter was on the Arachosian
<div n="lb"/>Haraqaiti ({@Sarasvatī@}) fighting against the Parnians and Dahae,
<div n="lb"/>as well as other Iranian tribes. But the identification of Paṇi
<div n="lb"/>and the Parnians is needless, especially as the root {%paṇ,%} which
<div n="lb"/>is found also in the Greek <lang n="greek"></lang>, shows a satisfactory deri-
<div n="lb"/>vation, while the transfer of Divodāsa to the Haraqaiti is
<div n="lb"/>improbable. See also {@Divodāsa@} and {@Bekanāṭa.@}
<F>1) Rv. i. 33, 3; 83, 2; 151, 9; 180, 7;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 28, 7; v. 34, 5-7; 61, 8; vi. 13, 3;
<div n="lb"/>53, 3; viii. 64, 2; 97, 2; x. 60, 6;
<div n="lb"/>Av. v. 11, 7; xx. 128, 4; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xxxv. 1.</F>
<F>2) Rv. 1, 83, 4; 184, 2; iii. 58, 2; v.
<div n="lb"/>34, 7; 61, 8; vi. 13, 3; 20, 4; 33, 2;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 64, 11.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 124, 10; iv. 51, 3; viii. 45,
<div n="lb"/>14 (where the sense is doubtful). {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>i. 93, 4; v. 61, 1.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 51, 14.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 32, 11; ii. 24, 6; iv. 58, 4;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 44, 22; vii. 9, 2; x. 67, 6; 92, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Av. iv. 23, 5; xix. 46, 2; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 8, 2, 3. It is im-
<div n="lb"/>possible definitely to decide in which
<div n="lb"/>passages the mythical sense is meant,
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%} p. 157.</F>
<F>6) Rv. x. 108.</F>
<F>7) Rv. viii. 66, 10.</F>
<F>8) Rv. vii. 6, 3.</F>
<F>9) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 89.</F>
<F>10) See Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 2,
<div n="lb"/>1, 23; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 2^2, 114;
<div n="lb"/>Davidson, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Mor-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%genländischen Gesellschaft,%} 37, 23; Eggel-
<div n="lb"/>ing, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 26, 31,
<div n="lb"/>n. 3.</F>
<F>11) Rv. v. 34, 5-7; Av. v. 11, 6.</F>
<F>12) Rv. v. 61, 8. {%Cf.%} Roth, {%Zeitschrift%}
<div n="lb"/>{%der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%schaft,%} 41, 673; Max Müller, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 32, 361, who thinks
<div n="lb"/>that the Paṇi is compared unfavourably
<div n="lb"/>with a generous woman, but this is
<div n="lb"/>unlikely; Hillebrandt, 1, 92, n. 3;

<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 364.</F>
