<L>1664<pc>1-474<k1>pati<k2>pati
{@Pati, Patnī.@}¦ — Under these words denoting primarily, as the
<div n="lb"/>evidence collected in the St. Petersburg Dictionary shows,
<div n="lb"/>‘lord’ and ‘lady,’ and so ‘husband’ and ‘wife,’ it is convenient
<div n="lb"/>to consider the marital relations of the Vedic community.
<div n="P"/>{%Child Marriage.%} — Marriage in the early Vedic texts appears
<div n="lb"/>essentially as a union of two persons of full development. This
<div n="lb"/>is shown by the numerous references<sup>1</sup> to unmarried girls who
<div n="lb"/>grow old in the house of their fathers ({%amā-jur%}), and who adorn
<div n="lb"/>themselves in desire of marriage, as well as to the paraphernalia
<div n="lb"/>of spells and potions used in the Atharvavedic tradition<sup>2</sup> to
<div n="lb"/>compel the love of man or woman respectively, while even the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>3</sup> itself seems to present us with a spell by which a
[Page1-475+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>lover seeks to send all the household to sleep when he visits his
<div n="lb"/>beloved. Child wives first occur regularly in the Sūtra period,
<div n="lb"/>though it is still uncertain to what extent the rule of marriage
<div n="lb"/>before puberty there obtained.<sup>4</sup> The marriage ritual also quite
<div n="lb"/>clearly presumes that the marriage is a real and not a nominal
<div n="lb"/>one: an essential feature is the taking of the bride to her
<div n="lb"/>husband's home, and the ensuing cohabitation.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%Limitations on Marriage.%} — It is difficult to say with certainty
<div n="lb"/>within what limits marriage was allowed. The dialogue of
<div n="lb"/>Yama and Yamī in the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> seems clearly to point to a
<div n="lb"/>prohibition of the marriage of brother and sister. It can
<div n="lb"/>hardly be said, as Weber<sup>7</sup> thinks, to point to a practice that
<div n="lb"/>was once in use and later became antiquated. In the Gobhila
<div n="lb"/>Gṛhya Sūtra<sup>8</sup> and the Dharma Sūtras<sup>9</sup> are found prohibitions
<div n="lb"/>against marriage in the {@Gotra@} (‘family’) or within six degrees
<div n="lb"/>on the mother's or father's side, but in the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>10</sup> marriage is allowed in the third or fourth generation,
<div n="lb"/>the former being allowed, according to Harisvamin,<sup>11</sup> by the
<div n="lb"/>Kāṇvas, and the second by the Saurāṣṭras, while the Dākṣi-
<div n="lb"/>ṇātyas allowed marriage with the daughter of the mother's
<div n="lb"/>brother or the son of the father's sister, but presumably not
<div n="lb"/>with the daughter of the mother's sister or the son of the
<div n="lb"/>father's brother. The prohibition of marriage within the
<div n="lb"/>Gotra cannot then have existed,<sup>12</sup> though naturally marriages
[Page1-476+ 64]
<div n="lb"/>outside the Gotra were frequent.<sup>13</sup> Similarity of caste was also
<div n="lb"/>not an essential to marriage, as hypergamy was permitted even
<div n="lb"/>by the Dharma Sūtras,<sup>14</sup> so that a Brāhmaṇa could marry
<div n="lb"/>wives of any lower caste, a Kṣatriya wives of the two lowest
<div n="lb"/>castes as well as of his own caste, a Vaiśya a Śūdrā as well as
<div n="lb"/>a Vaiśyā, although the Śūdrā marriages were later disapproved
<div n="lb"/>{%in toto.%} Instances of such intermarriage are common in the
<div n="lb"/>Epic, and are viewed as normal in the Bṛhaddevatā.<sup>15</sup>
<div n="P"/>It was considered proper that the younger brothers and
<div n="lb"/>sisters should not anticipate their elders by marrying before
<div n="lb"/>them. The later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas<sup>16</sup> present a series
<div n="lb"/>of names expressive of such anticipation, censuring as sinful
<div n="lb"/>those who bear them. These terms are the {%pari-vividāna,%}<sup>17</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>perhaps {%agre-dadhus,%}<sup>18</sup> the man who, though a younger brother,
<div n="lb"/>marries before his elder brother, the latter being then called the
<div n="lb"/>{%parivitta;%}<sup>19</sup> the {%agre-didhiṣu,%}<sup>20</sup> the man who weds a younger
<div n="lb"/>daughter while her elder sister is still unmarried; and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Didhiṣū-pati,@}<sup>21</sup> who is the husband of the latter. The passages
<div n="lb"/>do not explicitly say that the exact order of birth must always
<div n="lb"/>be followed, but the mention of the terms shows that the order
<div n="lb"/>was often broken.
<div n="P"/>{%Widow Remarriage.%} — The remarriage of a widow was
[Page1-477+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>apparently permitted. This seems originally to have taken the
<div n="lb"/>form of the marriage of the widow to the brother or other
<div n="lb"/>nearest kinsman of the dead man in order to produce children.
<div n="lb"/>At any rate, the ceremony is apparently alluded to in a funeral
<div n="lb"/>hymn of the Rigveda;<sup>22</sup> for the alternative explanation, which
<div n="lb"/>sees in the verse a reference to the ritual of the Puruṣamendha
<div n="lb"/>(‘human sacrifice’), although accepted by Hillebrandt<sup>23</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Delbrück,<sup>24</sup> is not at all probable, while the ordinary view is
<div n="lb"/>supported by the Sūtra evidence.<sup>25</sup> Moreover, another passage
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda<sup>26</sup> clearly refers to the marriage of the widow
<div n="lb"/>and the husband's brother ({%devṛ%}), which constitutes what the
<div n="lb"/>Indians later knew as Niyoga.<sup>27</sup> This custom was probably
<div n="lb"/>not followed except in cases where no son was already born.
<div n="lb"/>This custom was hardly remarriage in the strict sense, since
<div n="lb"/>the brother might — so far as appears — be already married
<div n="lb"/>himself. In the Atharvaveda,<sup>28</sup> a verse refers to a charm which
<div n="lb"/>would secure the reunion, in the next world, of a wife and her
<div n="lb"/>second husband. Though, as Delbrück<sup>29</sup> thinks, this very
<div n="lb"/>possibly refers to a case in which the first husband was still
<div n="lb"/>alive,<sup>30</sup> but was impotent or had lost caste ({%patita%}),<sup>31</sup> still it is
<div n="lb"/>certain that the later Dharma Sūtras<sup>32</sup> began to recognize
<div n="lb"/>ordinary remarriage in case of the death of the first husband.
[Page1-478+ 67]
<div n="lb"/>Pischel<sup>33</sup> finds some evidence in the Rigveda<sup>34</sup> to the effect
<div n="lb"/>that a woman could remarry if her husband disappeared and
<div n="lb"/>could not be found or heard of.
<div n="P"/>{%Polygamy.%} — A Vedic Indian could have more than one wife.
<div n="lb"/>This is proved clearly by many passages in the Rigveda;<sup>35</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Manu, according to the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<sup>36</sup> had ten wives;
<div n="lb"/>and the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>37</sup> explains polygamy by a
<div n="lb"/>characteristic legend. Moreover, the king regularly has four
<div n="lb"/>wives attributed to him, the Mahiṣī,<sup>38</sup> the Parivṛktī,<sup>39</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Vāvātā,<sup>40</sup> and the Pālāgalī.<sup>41</sup> The Mahiṣī appears to be the
<div n="lb"/>chief wife, being the first one married according to the Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>42</sup> The Parivṛktī, ‘the neglected,’ is explained
<div n="lb"/>by Weber<sup>43</sup> and Pischel<sup>44</sup> as one that has had no son. The
<div n="lb"/>Vāvātā is ‘the favourite,’ while the Pālāgalī is, according to
<div n="lb"/>Weber, the daughter of the last of the court officials. The
<div n="lb"/>names are curious, and not very intelligible, but the evidence
<div n="lb"/>points to the wife first wedded alone being a wife in the fullest
<div n="lb"/>sense. This view is supported by the fact emphasized by
[Page1-479+ 63]
<div n="lb"/>Delbrück,<sup>45</sup> that in the sacrifice the Patnī is usually mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in the singular, apparent exceptions being due to some mytho-
<div n="lb"/>logical reason.<sup>46</sup> Zimmer<sup>47</sup> is of opinion that polygamy is
<div n="lb"/>dying out in the Rigvedic period, monogamy being developed
<div n="lb"/>from polygamy; Weber,<sup>48</sup> however, thinks that polygamy is
<div n="lb"/>secondary, a view that is supported by more recent anthro-
<div n="lb"/>pology.<sup>49</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%Polyandry.%} — On the other hand, polyandry is not Vedic.<sup>50</sup>
<div n="lb"/>There is no passage containing any clear reference to such
<div n="lb"/>a custom. The most that can be said is that in the Rigveda<sup>51</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the Atharvaveda<sup>52</sup> verses are occasionally found in which
<div n="lb"/>husbands are mentioned in relation to a single wife. It is
<div n="lb"/>difficult to be certain of the correct explanation of each separate
<div n="lb"/>instance of this mode of expression; but even if Weber's<sup>53</sup>
<div n="lb"/>view, that the plural is here used {%majestatis causā,%} is not
<div n="lb"/>accepted, Delbrück's<sup>54</sup> explanation by mythology is probably
<div n="lb"/>right. In other passages<sup>55</sup> the plural is simply generic.
<div n="P"/>{%Marital Relations.%} — Despite polygamy, however, there is
<div n="lb"/>ample evidence that the marriage tie was not, as Weber<sup>56</sup> has
<div n="lb"/>suggested, lightly regarded as far as the fidelity of the wife
<div n="lb"/>was concerned. There is, however, little trace of the husband's
<div n="lb"/>being expected to be faithful as a matter of morality. Several
[Page1-480+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>passages,<sup>57</sup> indeed, forbid, with reference to ritual abstinence,
<div n="lb"/>intercourse with the {%strī%} of another. This may imply that
<div n="lb"/>adultery on the husband's part was otherwise regarded as
<div n="lb"/>venial. But as the word {%strī%} includes all the ‘womenfolk,’
<div n="lb"/>daughters and slaves, as well as wife, the conclusion can hardly
<div n="lb"/>be drawn that intercourse with another man's ‘wife’ was
<div n="lb"/>normally regarded with indifference.<sup>58</sup> The curious ritual of
<div n="lb"/>the Varuṇapraghāsās,<sup>59</sup> in which the wife of the sacrificer is
<div n="lb"/>questioned as to her lovers, is shown by Delbrück<sup>60</sup> to be a
<div n="lb"/>part of a rite meant to expiate unchastity on the part of a wife,
<div n="lb"/>not as a normal question for a sacrificer to put to his own wife.
<div n="lb"/>Again, Yājñavalkya's doctrine in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>61</sup>
<div n="lb"/>which seems to assert that no one cares if a wife is unchaste
<div n="lb"/>({%paraḥ-puṃsā%}) or not, really means that no one cares if the wife
<div n="lb"/>is away from the men who are sacrificing, as the wives of
<div n="lb"/>the gods are apart from them during the particular rite in
<div n="lb"/>question. Monogamy is also evidently approved,<sup>62</sup> so that
<div n="lb"/>some higher idea of morality was in course of formation. On
<div n="lb"/>the other hand, no Vedic text gives us the rule well known to
<div n="lb"/>other Indo-Germanic<sup>63</sup> peoples that the adulterer taken in the
<div n="lb"/>act can be killed with impunity, though the later legal literature
<div n="lb"/>has traces of this rule.<sup>64</sup> There is also abundant evidence that
<div n="lb"/>the standard of ordinary sexual morality was not high.
<div n="P"/>{%Hetairai.%} — In the Rigveda<sup>65</sup> there are many references to
<div n="lb"/>illegitimate love and to the abandonment of the offspring of
[Page1-481+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>such unions,<sup>66</sup> especially in the case of a protégé of Indra,
<div n="lb"/>often mentioned as the {%parāvṛkta%} or {%parāvṛj.%}<sup>67</sup> The ‘son of
<div n="lb"/>a maiden’ ({%kumārī-putra%}) is already spoken of in the Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā.<sup>68</sup> Such a person appears with a metronymic in the
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad period:<sup>69</sup> this custom may be the origin of metro-
<div n="lb"/>nymics such as those which make up a great part of the lists
<div n="lb"/>of teachers (Vaṃśas) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad.<sup>70</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>71</sup> refers to illicit unions of Śūdra and Ārya,
<div n="lb"/>both male and female, besides giving in its list of victims at
<div n="lb"/>the Puruṣamedha, or ‘human sacrifice,’ several whose desig-
<div n="lb"/>nations apparently mean ‘courtesan’ ({%atītvarī%})<sup>72</sup> and ‘procuress
<div n="lb"/>of abortion’ ({%atiṣkadvarī%}),<sup>73</sup> while the ‘dyeing woman’ ({%rajayitrī%})
<div n="lb"/>is dedicated to sensuality.<sup>74</sup> Pischel and Geldner also see
<div n="lb"/>many references to Hetairai in other passages of the Rigveda,<sup>75</sup>
<div n="lb"/>especially where mention is made of Uṣas, the goddess of
<div n="lb"/>Dawn, who in their view is the characteristic Hetaira. At any
<div n="lb"/>rate, there is little doubt that the ‘dancer’ ({%nṛtū%}) referred to in
<div n="lb"/>one passage of the Rigveda<sup>76</sup> was a Hetaira. When women
<div n="lb"/>are referred to as going to the {@Samana,@} or ‘place of meeting,’
<div n="lb"/>Hetairai are probably also meant.<sup>77</sup> Grave cases of immorality
<div n="lb"/>are alluded to in the Rigveda.<sup>78</sup> The love of father and
<div n="lb"/>daughter, as shown in the myth of Prajāpati,<sup>79</sup> is evidently
<div n="lb"/>censured, but the actual existence of this form of incest is
<div n="lb"/>recognized in the Atharvaveda.<sup>80</sup> Girls who had lost their
[Page1-482+ 76]
<div n="lb"/>natural protectors — father or brother<sup>81</sup> — were apt to be reduced
<div n="lb"/>to live by immorality.
<div n="P"/>{%Forms of Marriage.%} — The state of society revealed in the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic age seems to point to considerable freedom on the part
<div n="lb"/>of both man and woman in selecting a wife or a husband.
<div n="lb"/>At any rate, it is not clear that either the father or the mother
<div n="lb"/>controlled the marriage of son or daughter of mature age,<sup>82</sup>
<div n="lb"/>though no doubt the parents or parent often arranged a suit-
<div n="lb"/>able match.<sup>83</sup> The marriage was frequently arranged through
<div n="lb"/>an intermediary, the ‘wooer’ ({%vara%}),<sup>84</sup> presumably after those
<div n="lb"/>concerned had in effect come to an agreement. The sale of
<div n="lb"/>a daughter was not unknown,<sup>85</sup> but a certain amount of dis-
<div n="lb"/>credit would seem to have attached to it,<sup>86</sup> and sons-in-law in
<div n="lb"/>such cases were sometimes stingy. On the other hand, dowries
<div n="lb"/>were not infrequently given, especially no doubt when damsels
<div n="lb"/>Suffered from bodily defects.<sup>87</sup> Occasionally marriages by
[Page1-483+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>capture may have taken place, but only as knightly feats, as
<div n="lb"/>when {@Vimada@} carried off {@Purumitra's@} daughter against her
<div n="lb"/>father's wish, but very possibly with her own consent.<sup>88</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>later law-books and the Epic describe in much detail various
<div n="lb"/>forms of marriage, but they all seem reducible to three types:
<div n="lb"/>({%a%}) that which is based on mutual consent, the {%prājāpatya%}
<div n="lb"/>(‘connected with Prajāpati’); ({%b%}) that in which a price is paid
<div n="lb"/>for the bride, the {%āsura%} (‘Asura-like’), {%ārṣa%} (‘connected with
<div n="lb"/>the Ṛṣis’), {%brāhma%} (‘relating to Brahman’), or {%daiva%} (‘divine’);
<div n="lb"/>({%c%}) those which consist in stealing the bride, the {%kṣātra%}
<div n="lb"/>(‘warrior-like’) or the {%rākṣasa%} (‘demon-like’) mode, of all of
<div n="lb"/>which traces are found in Vedic literature.<sup>89</sup> For instance,
<div n="lb"/>the gift of a maiden for services rendered or other object is
<div n="lb"/>exemplified in the story of {@Cyavana@} in the Jaiminīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa,<sup>90</sup> and in that of {@Śyāvāśva@} in the Bṛhaddevatā.<sup>91</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%Wedding Ceremony.%} — In normal marriages the bridal was
<div n="lb"/>celebrated by an elaborate ceremony which bears in essentials
<div n="lb"/>and details the strongest resemblance to the form observed by
<div n="lb"/>other Indo-Germanic as well as non-Indo-Germanic peoples,<sup>92</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and which was destined to secure the stability and fruitfulness
<div n="lb"/>of the union. The ceremony commenced at the bride's house,<sup>93</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to which the bridegroom with his friends and relations repaired,
<div n="lb"/>and in which he met the friends and relations of the bride.<sup>94</sup>
<div n="lb"/>A cow or cows were slain for the entertainment of the guests.<sup>95</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The bridegroom having caused the bride to mount a stone,
<div n="lb"/>formally grasped her hand, and led her round the household
[Page1-484+ 64]
<div n="lb"/>fire.<sup>96</sup> This act constituted the marriage, the husband hence
<div n="lb"/>being called ‘he who takes by the hand’ ({%hasta-grābha%}).<sup>97</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>festivities being over,<sup>98</sup> the bridegroom took the bride to his
<div n="lb"/>home on a car in a marriage procession,<sup>99</sup> all to the accom-
<div n="lb"/>paniment of suitable stanzas. Then followed cohabitation.<sup>100</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%Wife's Property and Status.%} — We have very little information
<div n="lb"/>as to the legal relations of wife and husband after marriage.
<div n="lb"/>It may be assumed that the husband appropriated the wife's
<div n="lb"/>dowry, if any, as well as her earnings, if any: even in the
<div n="lb"/>Epic<sup>101</sup> the rise of the recognition of women's property as
<div n="lb"/>their own ({%strī-dhana%}) is only slow. That the husband was
<div n="lb"/>absolute master of a wife as of a slave is not probable, though
<div n="lb"/>he doubtless exercised the same power of correction as was
<div n="lb"/>expressly allowed in the eighteenth century by English law.
<div n="lb"/>The poetical ideal<sup>102</sup> of the family was decidedly high, and we
<div n="lb"/>have no reason to doubt that it was often actually fulfilled.
<div n="lb"/>Moreover, the wife on her marriage was at once given an
<div n="lb"/>honoured position in the house; she is emphatically mistress
<div n="lb"/>in her husband's home, exercising authority over her father-
<div n="lb"/>in-law, her husband's brothers, and her unmarried sisters.<sup>103</sup>
<div n="lb"/>No doubt the case contemplated is one in which the eldest son
[Page1-485+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>of a family has become its head owing to the decrepitude<sup>104</sup> of
<div n="lb"/>the parents, his wife then taking the place of the mistress
<div n="lb"/>of the joint family while the brothers and sisters are still
<div n="lb"/>unmarried. It is not inconsistent with the great stress else-
<div n="lb"/>where<sup>105</sup> laid on the respect due to a father-in-law, who then
<div n="lb"/>is probably regarded as still in full possession of his faculties,
<div n="lb"/>and controls the house while his son continues to live with
<div n="lb"/>him. The respect would no doubt equally apply if the son
<div n="lb"/>had set up a separate family of his own.<sup>106</sup>
<div n="P"/>Moreover, the wife was a regular participator in the offerings
<div n="lb"/>of the husband. In this connexion the term {@Patnī@} regularly
<div n="lb"/>applies to her in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>107</sup> where {@Jāyā@} designates her
<div n="lb"/>in her conjugal capacity, not in that of sharer in the sacrifice.
<div n="lb"/>In this respect her position gradually deteriorated: thus the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>108</sup> describes a certain ceremony in which
<div n="lb"/>the wife ({%jāyā%}) alone offered the oblation in former times, while
<div n="lb"/>later a priest might do so instead. The same Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>shows other traces of a lowering in the position of women,
<div n="lb"/>probably due to the growing sense of the importance of cere-
<div n="lb"/>monial priority.<sup>109</sup> So in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>110</sup> women
<div n="lb"/>generally are classed with dice and drink as three chief evils,
<div n="lb"/>and woman is declared to be ‘untruth,’<sup>111</sup> and connected with
<div n="lb"/>Nirṛti, ‘calamity.’<sup>112</sup> A woman too, according to the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā,<sup>113</sup> is inferior even to a bad man, and a sarcastic
<div n="lb"/>reference is made in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>114</sup> to her power of
[Page1-486+ 58]
<div n="lb"/>getting things from her husband by cajolery at night. On the
<div n="lb"/>other hand must be set the encomia on woman: a woman is
<div n="lb"/>half her husband,<sup>115</sup> and completes him;<sup>116</sup> and in the Rigveda<sup>117</sup>
<div n="lb"/>attacks on women mingle with the general assumption of their
<div n="lb"/>good qualities. None the less, the Brāhmaṇas clearly indicate
<div n="lb"/>a gradual decline in their position, which is evident from the
<div n="lb"/>rule that requires the wife to eat after her husband.<sup>118</sup> Scolds
<div n="lb"/>were also known: the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>119</sup> praises the wife
<div n="lb"/>‘who does not answer back’ ({%aprativādinī%}). Women bore no
<div n="lb"/>part in political life: men go to the assembly, not women, the
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>120</sup> expressly says. On the other hand,
<div n="lb"/>with the advance of education, women shared in the intel-
<div n="lb"/>lectual interests of the day, as is exemplified by Yājñavalkya's<sup>121</sup>
<div n="lb"/>two wives, of whom one was interested in his philosophical
<div n="lb"/>discussions, the other not. Other women are also referred to
<div n="lb"/>in the Upaniṣads as teachers, but whether they were married
<div n="lb"/>is not certain.<sup>122</sup>
<div n="P"/>But the main object of a woman's marriage was the pro-
<div n="lb"/>duction of children, this being repeatedly asserted in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda and later.<sup>123</sup> The desire for offspring, as was natural
<div n="lb"/>in a society which mainly counted relationship through the
<div n="lb"/>father, took the form of a wish for a son to perform the
<div n="lb"/>necessary funeral rites for the father, and to continue his line.
<div n="lb"/>It was no doubt possible to adopt a son, but in the Rigveda<sup>124</sup>
<div n="lb"/>this custom is plainly viewed as unsatisfactory. The practice
[Page1-487+ 67]
<div n="lb"/>is recognized,<sup>125</sup> as we have seen above of Niyoga, in the
<div n="lb"/>appointment of a brother to beget children with the wife of
<div n="lb"/>a dead man, or perhaps of a man who is childless. ‘Sonless-
<div n="lb"/>ness’ ({%avīratā%}) is placed on the same level as lack of property
<div n="lb"/>({%amati%}), and Agni is besought to protect from it.<sup>126</sup> The birth
<div n="lb"/>of a daughter was certainly not specially welcome: the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda<sup>127</sup> in one hymn distinctly invokes the birth of a son,
<div n="lb"/>and deprecates that of a daughter, while the Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>128</sup> contains an old verse which says that a daughter is
<div n="lb"/>a misery ({%kṛpaṇam%}), while a son is a light in the highest heaven
<div n="lb"/>({%jyotir ha putraḥ parame vyoman%}). But there is no proof that
<div n="lb"/>the Vedic Indians practised the exposure of female children.
<div n="lb"/>This conclusion, deduced from certain passages in the later
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās<sup>129</sup> by Zimmer<sup>130</sup> and Delbrück,<sup>131</sup> has been disproved
<div n="lb"/>by Böhtlingk.
<div n="P"/>{%Child Life.%} — No doubt the care of a child was left to
<div n="lb"/>the mother, but we learn little from the earlier litera-
<div n="lb"/>ture<sup>132</sup> of the life of the young. The length of the period
<div n="lb"/>of pregnancy is frequently placed at ten (doubtless lunar)
<div n="lb"/>months.<sup>133</sup> On birth the child was first fed with milk or ghee,
<div n="lb"/>and then given the breast.<sup>134</sup> On the eighth day after birth
[Page1-488+ 78]
<div n="lb"/>the infant was washed.<sup>135</sup> The cutting of the teeth was also
<div n="lb"/>a solemn occasion,<sup>136</sup> and is the subject of a hymn in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda. Reference is also made to children's learning
<div n="lb"/>to speak, which the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>137</sup> ascribes to the end
<div n="lb"/>of the first year of life. The Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>138</sup> asserts that
<div n="lb"/>the words {@Tata@} and {@Tāta,@} onomatopoetic words like ‘dada,’<sup>139</sup>
<div n="lb"/>are the first words of a child's speech, giving therein perhaps
<div n="lb"/>an unfair prominence to the father. The Atharvaveda<sup>140</sup>
<div n="lb"/>further contains at least one hymn for the ceremony of the
<div n="lb"/>first shaving of the young man's beard. The giving of a name
<div n="lb"/>was also an occasion of importance, a second one being often
<div n="lb"/>added.<sup>141</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%Satī.%} — On the death of her husband, in some cases the
<div n="lb"/>widow burned herself or was burned by his relations.<sup>142</sup> This
<div n="lb"/>is clearly implied in the reference to this ancient custom in
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda.<sup>143</sup> On the other hand, the Rigveda does not
<div n="lb"/>contemplate the custom anywhere, but on the contrary con-
<div n="lb"/>siders the widow as married apparently to the brother of the
<div n="lb"/>dead man.<sup>144</sup> The custom of Suttee would therefore appear
<div n="lb"/>during the Vedic age to have been in abeyance, at least as
<div n="lb"/>a general rule. At all times the practice seems to have been
<div n="lb"/>mainly usual among families of the warrior class, to judge
<div n="lb"/>from the other Indo-Germanic parallels.<sup>145</sup> In other classes
[Page1-489+ 31]
<div n="lb"/>the survival of wives was more necessary, and the remarriage of
<div n="lb"/>widows, whether prohibited or allowed in the texts, is proof
<div n="lb"/>that there were widows who could be remarried.<sup>146</sup>

<F>86) Rv. i. 109, 2, refers to the gods
<div n="lb"/>Indra and Agni as more generous than
<div n="lb"/>a {%vijāmātṛ,%} ‘son-in-law,’ or a {%syāla,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘brother-in-law.’ The force of {%vi%} in
<div n="lb"/>the former word must be unfavourable,
<div n="lb"/>and the sense, as indicated by Pischel,
<div n="lb"/>is no doubt, that a son-in-law who was
<div n="lb"/>not in other respects altogether suitable
<div n="lb"/>might have to buy his bride at a heavy
<div n="lb"/>cost. The {%vijāmātṛ%} is, in fact, the
<div n="lb"/>{%aśrīro jāmātā,%} the ‘ignoble son-in-law,’
<div n="lb"/>of Rv. viii. 2, 20. {%Cf.%} Yāska, Nirukta,

<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 15, 255.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 329; Geldner, {%Rig-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%veda, Kommentar,%} 154.</F>
<F>143) Av. xviii. 3, 1.</F>
<F>144) x. 18, 7. 8.</F>
<F>145) {%Cf.%} Herodotos, v. 5 (of the
<div n="lb"/>Thracians); iv. 71 (of the Scythians);
<div n="lb"/>Procopius, {%De Bello Gothico,%} ii. 14 (of
<div n="lb"/>the Heruli). So in Germany Brynhild
<div n="lb"/>and Nanna are instances ({%cf.%} Weinhold,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altnordisches Leben,%} 476 {%et seq.%}). The
<div n="lb"/>universality of the custom must not be
<div n="lb"/>exaggerated, as Zimmer, 331, is inclined
<div n="lb"/>to do. To burn all the wives of a king
<div n="lb"/>would, in primitive ages, have been a
<div n="lb"/>wasteful action; even the chief wife
<div n="lb"/>would often have had to be spared on
<div n="lb"/>one ground or another. The Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>already reveals a state of society in
<div n="lb"/>which the actual burning of the wife
<div n="lb"/>was avoided by a semblance of it in
<div n="lb"/>the funeral ritual of ({%cf.%} Macdonell,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sanskrit Literature,%} 126). The reward
<div n="lb"/>of a good wife was to go to the world
<div n="lb"/>of her husband ({%pati-loka%}) after death
<div n="lb"/>({%cf.%} Av. xiv. 1, 64; xviii. 3, 1; Rv.
<div n="lb"/>x. 85, 43). A Vedic citation in the
<div n="lb"/>scholiast on Pāṇini, iii. 2, 8, Vārttika, 2,
<div n="lb"/>says that a Brahmin woman who drinks
<div n="lb"/>{@Surā,@} an intoxicating liquor, does not
<div n="lb"/>go to the world of her husband after
<div n="lb"/>death.</F>
<F>146) {%Cf.%} perhaps the {%gartāruh%} of Rv.
<div n="lb"/>i. 124, 7, as explained by Yāska,
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta, iii. 5; Geldner, {%Rigveda, Kom-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%mentar,%} 22.</F>

<L>1668<pc>1-489<k1>paTikft<k2>paTikft
{@Pathi-kṛt,@}¦ ‘path-maker,’ is not a rare epithet in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later,<sup>2</sup> showing clearly the importance naturally attached
<div n="lb"/>in primitive times to the finding of roads. The frequency
[Page1-490+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>with which the epithet is applied to Agni<sup>3</sup> suggests that there
<div n="lb"/>is here an allusion to fire burning the primæval forest and
<div n="lb"/>rendering advance possible. The god Pūṣan is {%pathi-kṛt,%} as
<div n="lb"/>guarding the flocks.<sup>4</sup> The Ṛṣis,<sup>5</sup> or seers, as ‘path-makers,’
<div n="lb"/>may be compared with the Roman Pontifices.
<F>1) ii. 23, 6; vi. 21, 12; ix. 106, 5; x. 14, 15; 111, 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. xviii. 2, 53; 3, 25, etc.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 1, 5, 5; xii.
<div n="lb"/>4, 4, 1; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, iv. 3,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>4) Sāṅkhāyana Srauta Sūtra, iii. 4, 9;
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 1, 17. The Sūtra, xvi. 1, 18, ex-
<div n="lb"/>plains {%pathi-kṛt%} merely as {%adhipati,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘lord’; but the sense must be more
<div n="lb"/>pregnant than that.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 14, 15, where the expression
<div n="lb"/>refers to their finding the way to the
<div n="lb"/>heavenly world; but it is probably a
<div n="lb"/>transfer of an epithet of terrestrial
<div n="lb"/>application.</F>

<L>1679<pc>1-492<k1>parAvfj<k2>parAvfj
{@Parā-vṛj@}¦ is a term found in four passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup>

<div n="lb"/>view that the word is a proper name is most unlikely, while
<div n="lb"/>Grassmann's<sup>4</sup> explanation of it as ‘cripple’ is still less probable.

<div n="lb"/>passage which refers to the Parāvṛj as going south. Zimmer<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>accepts Roth's view for this passage, but in the others sees
<div n="lb"/>a reference to the child of a maiden exposed by her and in
<div n="lb"/>danger of being eaten by insects ({%vamrī%}). This view is sup-
<div n="lb"/>ported by the fact that {%parāvṛkta%} seems to have the same
<div n="lb"/>sense,<sup>7</sup> and is accepted by Oldenberg.<sup>8</sup>

<L>1681<pc>1-493<k1>parikzit<k2>parikzit
{@Pari-kṣit@}¦ appears in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> as a king in whose
<div n="lb"/>realm, that of the Kurus, prosperity and peace abound. The
<div n="lb"/>verses in which he is celebrated are later<sup>2</sup> called {%Pārikṣityaḥ,%}
<div n="lb"/>and the Brāhmaṇas explain that Agni is {%pari-kṣit%} because he
<div n="lb"/>dwells among men. Hence Roth<sup>3</sup> and Bloomfield<sup>4</sup> regard
<div n="lb"/>Parikṣit in the Atharvaveda not as a human king at all. This
<div n="lb"/>may be correct, but it is not certain. Both Zimmer<sup>5</sup> and
[Page1-494+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg<sup>6</sup> recognize Parikṣit as a real king, a view supported
<div n="lb"/>by the fact that in the later Vedic literature King {@Janamejaya@}
<div n="lb"/>bears the patronymic {@Pārikṣita.@} If this be so, Parikṣit
<div n="lb"/>belonged to the later period, since the Atharvan passage in
<div n="lb"/>which his name occurs is certainly late, and none of the other
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās know Parikṣit at all. The Epic<sup>7</sup> makes him grandfather
<div n="lb"/>of Pratiśravas and great-grandfather of Pratīpa, and Zimmer,<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>probably with justice, compares the Prātisutvana and Pratīpa
<div n="lb"/>found in another late Atharvan passage.<sup>8</sup> But {@Devāpi@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Śantanu@} cannot be brought into connexion with Pratīpa.<sup>9</sup>
<F>1) xx. 127, 7-10. See also Scheftelo-
<div n="lb"/>witz, {%Die Apokryphen des Veda,%} 156,
<div n="lb"/>157, and the verses in the Vaitāna
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xxxiv. 9. The Vedic spelling is
<div n="lb"/>Parikṣit, not Parīkṣit.</F>
<F>2) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vi. 32, 10;
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xxx. 5; Gopatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 12; Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xii. 17.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 690, 691.
<div n="lb"/>but see {%Atharvaveda,%} 101, n. 9.</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 131.</F>
<F>6) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%lāndischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 237; {%Buddha,%}
<div n="lb"/>396.</F>
<F>7) See Zimmer, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 131.</F>
<F>8) xx. 129.</F>
<F>9) Devāpi is really a Brahmin, son
<div n="lb"/>of Ṛṣṭiṣeṇa, and not connected directly

<L>1702<pc>1-497<k1>parizad<k2>parizad

<div n="lb"/>senses is the word found in the early literature, though the
<div n="lb"/>institutions indicated by it must have existed at least in
<div n="lb"/>embryo.

<L>1712<pc>1-499<k1>paruzRI<k2>paruzRI
{@Paruṣṇī@}¦ is the name of a river which is mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Nadī-stuti (‘Praise of Rivers’),<sup>1</sup> and in the song of Sudās’
<div n="lb"/>victory over the ten kings,<sup>2</sup> which seems to have been made
<div n="lb"/>decisive by the rise of the river drowning the fugitives.<sup>3</sup> In
<div n="lb"/>these passages and one of the eighth book of the Rigveda,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>where it is called a ‘great stream’ ({%mahenadi%}), the name is
<div n="lb"/>certainly that of the river later called Ravi (Irāvatī), as recog-
<div n="lb"/>nized by Yāska.<sup>5</sup> Pischel<sup>6</sup> sees a reference to it in two other
<div n="lb"/>passages of the Rigveda,<sup>7</sup> where ‘wool’ ({%ūṛṇā%}) is connected
<div n="lb"/>with the word {%paruṣṇī,%} and the allusion to the river is accepted
<div n="lb"/>by Max Müller<sup>8</sup> and Oldenberg,<sup>9</sup> though they are not fully
<div n="lb"/>agreed as to the exact sense of the passages in question.
<div n="lb"/>Pischel suggests that the name is derived from the ‘flocks’
<div n="lb"/>({%parus%}) of wool, not from the bends of the river, as understood
<div n="lb"/>by the Nirukta,<sup>5</sup> or from its reeds, as Roth<sup>10</sup> suggests.
[Page1-500+ 47]
<div n="P"/>The mention of the Paruṣṇī and the Yamunā in the hymn
<div n="lb"/>celebrating the victory of Sudās has given rise to the conjectures
<div n="lb"/>of Hopkins,<sup>11</sup> that the Yamunā in that hymn is merely another
<div n="lb"/>name for the Paruṣṇī, and of Geldner,<sup>12</sup> that the Paruṣṇī there
<div n="lb"/>is merely a tributary of the Yamunā (Jumna). But neither
<div n="lb"/>interpretation is either essential or even probable. The hymn
<div n="lb"/>is a condensed one, and may well be taken as celebrating two
<div n="lb"/>great victories of Sudās. There is a doubtful reference to the
<div n="lb"/>Paruṣṇī in the Atharvaveda.<sup>13</sup>
<F>1) x. 75, 5.</F>
<F>2) vii. 18, 8. 9.</F>
<F>3) It is impossible to decide precisely
<div n="lb"/>what part the river played in the battle.
<div n="lb"/>It is usually held that the enemies of
<div n="lb"/>Sudās tried to divert the stream, but
<div n="lb"/>failed, and were drowned in its current.
<div n="lb"/>So Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 11;
<div n="lb"/>Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Literature,%} 154;
<div n="lb"/>Geldner, {%Rigveda, Kommentar,%} 103, holds
<div n="lb"/>that Sudās was caught between two
<div n="lb"/>opposing armies, and had to escape
<div n="lb"/>over the Paruṣṇī, that his enemies
<div n="lb"/>tried to divert it to render him more
<div n="lb"/>accessible to their attack, but failed,
<div n="lb"/>and were overwhelmed in the river.
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins, {%India, Old and New,%} 52 {%et seq.,%}
<div n="lb"/>may be right in rejecting {%in toto%} the
<div n="lb"/>theory of the attempted diversion of
<div n="lb"/>the waters, though in the {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%American Oriental Society,%} 15, 261 {%et seq.,%}
<div n="lb"/>he accepted the traditional view.</F>
<F>4) viii. 74, 15.</F>
<F>5) Nirukta, ix. 26.</F>
<F>6) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 208-210.</F>
<F>7) iv. 22, 2; v. 52, 9.</F>
<F>8) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 315,
<div n="lb"/>323.</F>
<F>9) {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 348.</F>
<F>5) Nirukta, ix. 26.</F>
<F>10) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 4{%a.%}</F>
<F>11) {%Op. cit.,%} 52.</F>
<F>12) {%Ṛgveda, Glossar,%} 106.</F>
<F>13) vi. 12, 3. {%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Atharvaveda,%} 462; Whitney,
<div n="lb"/>Translation of the Atharvaveda, 289.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1713<pc>1-500<k1>parus<k2>parus
{@Parus@}¦ means first a ‘limb’ or ‘member’ of the body,<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>is then applied metaphorically to the divisions of the sacrifice<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or of the year<sup>3</sup> ({%cf.%} {@Parvan@}).
<F>1) Rv. i. 162, 18; x. 97, 12; 100, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Av. i. 12, 3; iv. 12, 2. 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 53, 1; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>i. 6, 9, 1.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 6, 1.</F>

<L>1714<pc>1-500<k1>parRa<k2>parRa<h>1
1. {@Parṇa@}¦ denotes the ‘wing’ of a bird in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>later.<sup>2</sup> It also means the ‘feather’ of an arrow in a late passage
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda,<sup>3</sup> and more often later;<sup>4</sup> and the ‘leaf’ of a tree
<div n="lb"/>from the Rigveda onwards.<sup>5</sup>

<div n="lb"/>4, etc.</F>

<L>1715<pc>1-500<k1>parRa<k2>parRa<h>2
2. {@Parṇa@}¦ denotes the tree {%Butea frondosa,%} later usually called
<div n="lb"/>{@Palāśa.@} It occurs in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> in connexion with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Aśvattha,@} and with that tree as well as the {@Nyagrodha@} in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> which mentions both amulets<sup>3</sup> and the cover of
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial dishes<sup>4</sup> as made from its wood. Its use for the
[Page1-501+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>making of sacrificial implements like the ladle ({%juhū%}),<sup>5</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial posts,<sup>6</sup> or the small ladle called {%sruva,%}<sup>7</sup> is mentioned.
<div n="lb"/>The Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>8</sup> ascribes its origin to the loss of a
<div n="lb"/>feather by the Gāyatrī when winning the Soma. The tree is
<div n="lb"/>also often mentioned elsewhere.<sup>9</sup> Reference too is sometimes
<div n="lb"/>made to its bark ({%parṇa-valka%}).<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) x. 97, 5.</F>
<F>2) v. 5, 5.</F>
<F>3) iii. 5, 4. 8.</F>
<F>4) xviii. 4, 53.</F>

<F>6) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxi. 4, 13.</F>

<div n="lb"/>8, 7.</F>

<L>1716<pc>1-501<k1>parRaka<k2>parRaka
{@Parṇaka@}¦ is the name of a man included in the list of victims
<div n="lb"/>at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>1</sup> and the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> According to Mahī-
<div n="lb"/>dhara,<sup>3</sup> a Bhilla is meant — {%i.e.,%} presumably a wild hillman, for
<div n="lb"/>he glosses {@Niṣāda@} in the same way.<sup>4</sup> Sāyaṇa<sup>5</sup> explains the
<div n="lb"/>word as meaning ‘one who catches fish by putting over the
<div n="lb"/>water a {%parṇa%} with poison,’ but this is apparently a mere
<div n="lb"/>etymological guess. Weber's<sup>6</sup> rendering of the term as refer-
<div n="lb"/>ring to a savage ‘wearing feathers’ is ingenious, but uncertain.
<F>1) xxx. 16.</F>
<F>2) iii. 4, 12, 1.</F>
<F>3) On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>4) On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27.</F>
<F>5) On Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>6) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ländiscnen Gesellschaft,%} 18, 281.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 119.</F>

<L>1721<pc>1-502<k1>parvata<k2>parvata<h>1
1. {@Parvata@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> is con-
<div n="lb"/>joined with {%giri%} in the sense of ‘hill’ or ‘mountain.’ From
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> onwards<sup>4</sup> it is common in this sense as connected
<div n="lb"/>with the waters of rivers which flow in the hills.<sup>5</sup> The legend
<div n="lb"/>of the mountains having wings is already found in the
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās.<sup>6</sup> In the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad<sup>7</sup> are mentioned the
<div n="lb"/>southern ({%dakṣiṇa%}) and the northern ({%uttara%}) mountains, evidently
<div n="lb"/>in allusion to the Himālaya and the Vindhya ranges. The
<div n="lb"/>plants ({%oṣadhi%}) and aromatic products ({%añjana%}) of the mountains
<div n="lb"/>are referred to in the Atharvaveda,<sup>8</sup> and their mineral treasures
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda.<sup>9</sup>
<F>1) i. 37, 7; v. 56, 4.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 6, 8; vi. 12, 3; 17, 3; ix. 1,
<div n="lb"/>18; xii. 1, 11.</F>
<F>3) i. 39, 5; 52, 2; 155; 1; 191, 9;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 12, 2, 3; 17, 5, etc.</F>
<F>4) Av. i. 14, 1; iii. 21, 10; iv. 9, 8;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 7, 17; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>5, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 1;
<div n="lb"/>xviii. 13, etc.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 34, 23; 35, 8; viii. 18, 16;
<div n="lb"/>31, 10; x. 35, 2; 36, 1, etc.; Pischel,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} i. 80; 2, 66.</F>
<F>6) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 9; Mai-
<div n="lb"/>trāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 10, 13; and Rv.
<div n="lb"/>iv. 54, 5, as explained by Pischel,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 174.</F>
<F>7) ii. 13; Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1,
<div n="lb"/>407; Keith, {%Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka,%} 28,
<div n="lb"/>n. 1.</F>

<L>1724<pc>1-503<k1>parvan<k2>parvan

<L>1729<pc>1-504<k1>parSu<k2>parSu<h>4
4. {@Parśu@}¦ occurs in one passage in a Dānastuti (‘praise of
<div n="lb"/>gifts’) in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as the name of a man. It is not certain
<div n="lb"/>that he is identical with {@Tirindira,@} but the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra<sup>2</sup> mentions Tirindira Pāraśavya as the patron of {@Vatsa@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Kāṇva.@} In another passage occurring in the Vṛṣākapi hymn,<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Parśu Mānavī occurs, apparently as a woman, daughter of
<div n="lb"/>Manu, but who is meant it is quite impossible to say. Excepting
<div n="lb"/>these two, there are no other occurrences in which the word has
<div n="lb"/>with any probability the value of a proper name in the Rigveda.
<div n="P"/>Ludwig,<sup>4</sup> however, sees in several other places an allusion to
<div n="lb"/>the Parśus. Thus in one passage of the Rigveda<sup>5</sup> he finds a
<div n="lb"/>reference to the defeat of {@Kuruśravaṇa@} by the Parśus; in
<div n="lb"/>another<sup>6</sup> he finds a reference to the Pṛthus and Parśus — {%i.e.,%} the
<div n="lb"/>Parthians and the Persians. He also sees the Parthians in
<div n="lb"/>{@Pārthava,@} a name found in one hymn.<sup>7</sup> The same view is
<div n="lb"/>taken by Weber,<sup>8</sup> who holds that historical connexions with the
[Page1-505+ 38]
<div n="lb"/>Persians are referred to. But Zimmer<sup>9</sup> points out that this
<div n="lb"/>conclusion is not justified; the Parśus were known to Pāṇini<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as a warrior tribe; the Pāraśavas were a tribe in south-west
<div n="lb"/>{@Madhyadeśa;@} and the {%Periplus%}<sup>11</sup> knows a tribe of Parthoi in
<div n="lb"/>north India. At most the only conclusion to be drawn is that
<div n="lb"/>the Indians and Iranians were early connected, as was of
<div n="lb"/>course the case. Actual historical contact cannot be asserted
<div n="lb"/>with any degree of probability.
<F>1) viii. 6, 46.</F>
<F>2) xvi. 11, 20.</F>
<F>3) x. 86, 23. Apparently Vārttika 2,
<div n="lb"/>on Pāṇini, iv. 1, 177, where Parśu is
<div n="lb"/>explained as a feminine, Princess of
<div n="lb"/>the Parśus, refers to this passage. On
<div n="lb"/>the sense, {%cf.%} Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 42; {%Rigveda, Glossar,%} 107; and Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 2, 2, 2, where the
<div n="lb"/>expression occurs, but where the sense
<div n="lb"/>is very dubious.</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 196
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) x. 33, 2. The sense here is, no
<div n="lb"/>doubt, ‘ribs.’ See Geldner, {%op. cit.,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>184, n. 3; Bergaigne, {%Religion Védique,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 362, n.</F>
<F>6) vii. 83, 1, {%pṛthu-parśavaḥ,%} which
<div n="lb"/>really means either ‘with large ribs’ — 
<div n="lb"/>{%i.e.,%} ‘strong,’ as Roth, with Sāyaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>inclines to take it — or ‘with broad axes,’
<div n="lb"/>according to Zimmer.</F>
<F>7) vi. 27, 8.</F>
<F>8) {%Indische Studien,%} 4, 379; {%Indian%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Literature,%} 4; {%Episches im vedischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Ritual,%} 36 {%et seq.%} He confines his view
<div n="lb"/>to the equation of Parśu in Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>viii. 6, 46, and the Persians. Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt, who is inclined to see relations
<div n="lb"/>with Iran in early times (see {@Paṇi,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Pārāvata, Sṛñjaya@}), does not in this
<div n="lb"/>connexion quote Parśu at all, and,
<div n="lb"/>though he mentions Pārthava, does not
<div n="lb"/>regard it as probably referring to a
<div n="lb"/>Parthian ({%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 105).
<div n="lb"/>Brunnhofer, in his various works ({%Iran%}
<div n="lb"/>{%und Turan,%} 1889; {%vom Pontus bis zum%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Indus,%} 1890, etc.), finds constant refer-
<div n="lb"/>ences in the Veda to events in Iran,
<div n="lb"/>but his theories must be regarded as
<div n="lb"/>definitely unscientific. See also Hop-
<div n="lb"/>kins, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 15, 264, n.</F>
<F>9) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 134 {%et seq.;%} 433.
<div n="lb"/>{%Ibid.,%} 434, 435, he refutes conclusively
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig's extraordinary view that Pṛthu
<div n="lb"/>and Parśu are dialectical forms of the
<div n="lb"/>same word.</F>
<F>10) v. 3, 117.</F>
<F>11) c. 38.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1731<pc>1-505<k1>palada<k2>palada
{@Palada@}¦ occurs twice in one hymn of the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> in the
<div n="lb"/>description of a house. It seems to mean bundles of straw or
<div n="lb"/>reeds used to thatch the house and render the sides wind and

<L>1733<pc>1-505<k1>palAla<k2>palAla

<L>1736<pc>1-506<k1>palita<k2>palita
{@Palita,@}¦ ‘grey-haired,’ occurs frequently from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards.<sup>2</sup> It is the distinctive sign of old age. Those who,
<div n="lb"/>like certain descendants of {@Jamadagni,@} do not grow old,<sup>3</sup> are
<div n="lb"/>said not to become grey-haired, while {@Bharadvāja@} is described
<div n="lb"/>as having in his old age become thin and grey-haired.<sup>4</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> in one passage observes that grey hairs
<div n="lb"/>appear first on the head, and elsewhere<sup>6</sup> alludes to the hair on
<div n="lb"/>the arms having become grey.
<F>1) i. 144, 4; 164, 1; iii. 55, 9; x. 4, 5,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 15, etc.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 9, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxi. 10, 6. {%Cf.%}

<div n="lb"/>{%Academy of Arts and Sciences,%} 15, 54, and
<div n="lb"/>Rv. iii. 53, 16, where {%palasti%} seems to
<div n="lb"/>mean {%palita.%}</F>
<F>4) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 49.</F>
<F>5) xi. 4, 1, 6. 14.</F>
<F>6) iii. 8, 2, 25.</F>

<L>1742<pc>1-507<k1>pavi<k2>pavi
{@Pavi@}¦ denotes the ‘tire’ of the wheel of a chariot in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> Reference is made<sup>3</sup> to the necessity for
<div n="lb"/>fastening it on firmly, and the epithet {%su-pavi,%} ‘having a good
<div n="lb"/>tire,’ is found in the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup> with {%su-nābhi,%} ‘having a good
<div n="lb"/>nave,’ and {%su-cakra,%} ‘having a good wheel.’ The tires were, of
<div n="lb"/>course, of metal,<sup>5</sup> and being sharp,<sup>6</sup> could serve on occasion as
<div n="lb"/>weapons.<sup>7</sup> The St. Petersburg Dictionary in one passage of
[Page1-508+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>8</sup> takes Pavi to mean a metal rim on the
<div n="lb"/>stone for pounding Soma, but this seems improbable, because
<div n="lb"/>no such metal attachment is elsewhere alluded to. Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt<sup>9</sup> seems clearly right in accepting the sense of ‘sharp
<div n="lb"/>edge’ in this passage, especially as the stones in the Rigveda<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>are, in allusion to their rolling action, styled ‘rims without
<div n="lb"/>horses and without chariots’ ({%anaśvāsaḥ pavayo 'rathāḥ%}).
<div n="P"/>The Nirukta<sup>11</sup> ascribes to Pavi the sense of arrow ({%śalya%}), but
<div n="lb"/>this is very uncertain. The St. Petersburg Dictionary cites for
<div n="lb"/>this use two passages of the Rigveda,<sup>12</sup> but in one the secondary
<div n="lb"/>sense of sharp-edged weapon with reference to the bolt of Indra
<div n="lb"/>is quite likely, and in the other, where the expression {%vāṇasya%}
<div n="lb"/>{%pavi%} occurs, the sharp-edged pounding-stone of the ‘reed,’<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>meaning the stalk of the Soma plant, may be meant. Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt<sup>14</sup> thinks a reference to the shape of the Soma plant is
<div n="lb"/>intended. Pavī-nasa, the name of a demon mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>15</sup> seems to throw no light on this point, for while
<div n="lb"/>the St. Petersburg Dictionary takes it to mean ‘whose nose is
<div n="lb"/>like a spearhead,’ it is translated as ‘rim-nosed’ (presumably in
<div n="lb"/>allusion to the curved shape of the nose) by Whitney.<sup>16</sup>
<F>1) i. 34, 2; 88, 2; 139, 3; 166, 10,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Nirukta, v. 5.</F>
<F>2) Sāmaveda, ii. 7, 1, 15, 3, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vi. 54, 3.</F>
<F>4) Av. iv. 12, 6.</F>
<F>5) Of gold in the case of the Aśvins
<div n="lb"/>and the Maruts, Rv. i. 64, 11; 180, 1.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 166, 10.</F>
<F>7) Rv. v. 52, 9. {%Cf.%} vi. 8, 5, and
<div n="lb"/>x 180, 2.</F>
<F>8) vi. 30. {%Cf.%} Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 9, 4, 5. Mahīdhara, on the Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, takes {%pavinā%} as {%vajra-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%sadṛśena,%} ‘like a thunderbolt,’ and
<div n="lb"/>Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 26,
<div n="lb"/>239, 240, renders {%pavi%} by ‘bolt.’</F>
<F>9) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 44.</F>
<F>10) v. 31. 5.</F>
<F>11) xii. 30.</F>

<L>1746<pc>1-509<k1>paSu<k2>paSu
{@Paśu@}¦ means ‘animal’ generally, including man. There is
<div n="lb"/>frequent mention<sup>1</sup> of the five sacrificial animals — the horse, the
<div n="lb"/>cow, the sheep, the goat, and man. Seven such domestic
<div n="lb"/>animals are spoken of in the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> and later;<sup>3</sup> probably,
<div n="lb"/>as Whitney<sup>4</sup> observes, merely as a sacred mystic number, not,
<div n="lb"/>as the commentator<sup>5</sup> explains, the usual five with the ass and
<div n="lb"/>the camel added. Animals are also referred to as {%ubhayadant%}
[Page1-510+ 63]
<div n="lb"/>and {%anyatodant.%} They are further<sup>6</sup> classified as those which
<div n="lb"/>take hold with the hand ({%hastādānāḥ%}), man ({%puruṣa%}), elephant
<div n="lb"/>({%hastin%}), and ape ({%markaṭa%}), and those which grasp by the mouth
<div n="lb"/>({%mukhādānāḥ%}). Another division is that of biped ({%dvipād%}) and
<div n="lb"/>quadruped ({%catuṣpād%}).<sup>7</sup> Man is a biped;<sup>8</sup> he is the first ({%pra-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%thama%}) of the beasts;<sup>9</sup> he alone of animals lives a hundred
<div n="lb"/>years ({%śatāyus%}),<sup>10</sup> and he is king of the animals.<sup>11</sup> He possesses
<div n="lb"/>speech ({%vāc%}) in conjunction with the other animals.<sup>12</sup> In the
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>13</sup> an elaborate distinction is drawn between
<div n="lb"/>vegetables, animals, and man in point of intellect.
<div n="P"/>Of animals apart from man a threefold division is offered in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>14</sup> — into those of the air ({%vāyavya%}), those of the
<div n="lb"/>jungle ({%āraṇya%}), and those of the village ({%grāmya%}), or tame
<div n="lb"/>animals. The division into {%āraṇya%} and {%grāmya%} animals is quite
<div n="lb"/>common.<sup>15</sup> In the Yajurveda Saṃhitās<sup>16</sup> is found a division
<div n="lb"/>into {%eka-śapha,%} ‘whole-hoofed’; {%kṣudra,%} ‘small’; and {%āraṇya,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘wild,’ the two former classes denoting the tame animals.<sup>16</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The horse and the ass are {%eka-śapha;%}<sup>17</sup> the {%kṣudra%} are the sheep,
<div n="lb"/>the goat, and the ox: this distinction being parallel to that of
<div n="lb"/>{%ubhayadant%} and {%anyatodant.%}<sup>18</sup> Zimmer<sup>19</sup> sees in a passage of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>20</sup> a division of wild animals ({%āraṇya%}) into five
<div n="lb"/>classes: (1) those of the jungle described as the ‘dread beasts
[Page1-511+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>which are in the wood’ ({%mṛgā bhīmā vane hitāḥ%}); (2) winged
<div n="lb"/>creatures, represented by the {@Haṃsa,@} ‘gander,’ {@Suparṇa,@}
<div n="lb"/>‘eagle,’ {@Śakuna,@} ‘bird’; (3) amphibia — {@Śiṃśumāra,@} ‘alligator,’
<div n="lb"/>and {@Ajagara,@} ‘crocodile’ (?); (4) ‘fish,’ {@Purīkaya, Jaṣa,@}
<div n="lb"/>and {@Matsya;@} (5) insects and worms (described as {%rajasāḥ%}).
<div n="lb"/>But this division is more ingenious than probable, and it is
<div n="lb"/>ignored by both Bloomfield<sup>21</sup> and Whitney.<sup>22</sup>
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 10, 1-4;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvi. 17; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 17; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 47-51, {%Cf.%} Av. xi. 2, 9; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 10, 1-3; v. 5, 1, 1. 2;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 5, 10, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xiv. 28-31, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. iii. 10, 6.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 8, 4, 16;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 3, 1, 20; xii. 8, 3, 13 (where they
<div n="lb"/>are called {%jāgatāḥ,%} perhaps as number-
<div n="lb"/>ing 12); Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, x.
<div n="lb"/>2, 7.</F>
<F>4) Translation of the Atharvaveda, 103.</F>
<F>5) On Av. iii. 10, 6. The St. Peters-
<div n="lb"/>burg Dictionary suggests ‘mule’ and
<div n="lb"/>‘ass’ as the two making up seven

<div n="lb"/>is that ‘goat,’ ‘sheep,’ ‘ox,’ ‘horse,’

<L>1751<pc>1-512<k1>pastyA<k2>pastyA
{@Pastyā@}¦ (fem. pl.) is a word occurring in several passages of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> Roth<sup>2</sup> ascribes to it the meaning of ‘house’ or
<div n="lb"/>‘dwelling,’ in the wide sense of the term, as well as that of the
<div n="lb"/>‘family’ living in the house; and this view is accepted by
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer.<sup>3</sup> On the other hand, Pischel<sup>4</sup> finds in two of the
<div n="lb"/>passages<sup>5</sup> usually referred to Pastyā the neuter Pastya, which
<div n="lb"/>appears in {@Pastya-sad@} and in {@Pastyā-vant@} (where the length
<div n="lb"/>of the second syllable is not primitive), and which is certainly
<div n="lb"/>found in the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> in the metaphorical sense of ‘dwelling,’
<div n="lb"/>ascribed to it in the Naighaṇṭuka.<sup>7</sup> In the other passages<sup>8</sup> he
<div n="lb"/>thinks the word means ‘rivers’ or ‘waters’; in particular,
<div n="lb"/>where Soma in the middle of the Pastyās<sup>9</sup> is spoken of, the
<div n="lb"/>sees a reference to {@Kurukṣetra,@} with its several rivers,<sup>10</sup> {@Āpayā,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Dṛṣadvatī,@} and {@Sarasvatī@} ({%cf.%} 2. {@Pastyāvant@}). In some passages<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>he sees in Pastyā the proper name of a stream, just as Sindhu
<div n="lb"/>primarily means ‘river,’ then the ‘Indus.’
<F>1) Rv. i. 25, 10; 40, 7; 164, 30; iv, 1,
<div n="lb"/>11; vi, 49, 9; vii. 97, 5; ix, 65, 23;
<div n="lb"/>x. 46, 6. See also iv. 55, 3; viii. 27, 5,
<div n="lb"/>where Pastyā appears as a goddess.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 149. {%Cf.%} Weber,
<div n="lb"/>{%Über den Rājasūya,%} 43, n. 4; 63.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 211-22. So
<div n="lb"/>Geldner, {%Rigveda, Glossar,%} 107.</F>
<F>5) vi. 49. 9; vii. 97, 5, where the
<div n="lb"/>sense is ‘householder’ ({%gṛha-stha%} or
<div n="lb"/>{%gṛhin,%} as Sāyaṇa renders it).</F>
<F>6) x. 96, 10. 11. In x. 96, 10, Roth
<div n="lb"/>takes {%pastyoḥ%} to denote the two parts of
<div n="lb"/>the Soma press, but Pischel, 2, 211,
<div n="lb"/>accepts Sāyaṇa's rendering ‘heaven
<div n="lb"/>and earth.’ In the compounds {%tri-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%pastya%} of Agni, Rv. viii. 39, 8; {%vāja-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%pastya%} of Pūṣan, vi. 58, 2, of Soma,
<div n="lb"/>ix. 98, 12; and {%vīra-pastya,%} v. 50, 4, the
<div n="lb"/>primitive word may very well be {%pastya,%}
<div n="lb"/>not {%pastyā.%}</F>
<F>7) iii. 4, misquoted by Sāyaṇa on
<div n="lb"/>Rv. i. 151, 2, as applying to {%pastyā,%}
<div n="lb"/>whereas it really refers to {%pastya.%}</F>
<F>8) Rv. i. 25, 10 = Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>i. 8, 16, 1 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 2;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 6, 12; 7, 16; iv. 4, 6 = Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, x. 27; Rv. i. 40, 7; 164, 30
<div n="lb"/>(used of Agni's home); iv. 1, 11;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 65, 23; x. 46, 6; Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>i. 8, 12, 1 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 8
<div n="lb"/>= Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 7.</F>
<F>9) Rv. ix. 65, 23.</F>
<F>10) Rv. iii. 23, 4.</F>
<F>11) Rv. iv. 55, 3; viii. 27, 5; and in
<div n="lb"/>{%pastyāvant%} in ix. 97, 18.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1752<pc>1-512<k1>pastyAvant<k2>pastyAvant<h>1
1. {@Pastyā-vant,@}¦ explained in the Pada text as Pastya-vant,
<div n="lb"/>occurs in several passages of the Rigveda. In two of them<sup>1</sup>
[Page1-513+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>a rich householder seems meant, and in the two others reference
<div n="lb"/>to a ‘house’ is clear.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) i. 151, 2; ix. 97, 18; but the latter
<div n="lb"/>passage is explained by Pischel as
<div n="lb"/>referring to {@Pastyā,@} the river, and by
<div n="lb"/>Böhtlingk, Dictionary, {%s.v.,%} as ‘kept in
<div n="lb"/>the stall.’</F>
<F>2) {%Barhis,%} Rv. ii. 11, 16, ‘of the house’; {%kṣayān pastyāvataḥ,%} iv. 54, 5,
<div n="lb"/>‘abodes having (fixed) habitations.’
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 212.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1753<pc>1-513<k1>pastyAvant<k2>pastyAvant<h>2
2. {@Pastyā-vant@}¦ occurs in one passage of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> in the
<div n="lb"/>locative parallel with {@Suṣoma, Śaryaṇāvant,@} and {@Ārjīka.@} It
<div n="lb"/>must apparently denote a place, as Pischel<sup>2</sup> argues, probably
<div n="lb"/>corresponding to the locality ‘in the middle of the streams’
<div n="lb"/>({%madhye pastyānām%}), elsewhere<sup>3</sup> referred to as the home of Soma.
<div n="lb"/>Pischel<sup>4</sup> suggests that Patiāla is meant, though he does not lay
<div n="lb"/>any stress on the similarity of name. In the north of Patiāla
<div n="lb"/>there are hills where the Soma might have grown. Roth<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thought that something connected with the Soma press was
<div n="lb"/>meant.
<F>1) viii. 7, 29.</F>
<F>2) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 209.</F>
<F>3) Rv. ix. 65, 23.</F>
<F>4) {%Op. cit.,%} 2, 219.</F>
<F>5) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 2.
<div n="lb"/>Max Müller, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>32, 260, 398, 399, takes Pastyāvant
<div n="lb"/>as a place-name, but thinks that {%pastyā%}
<div n="lb"/>denotes ‘hamlet,’ or, as an epithet of
<div n="lb"/>Aditi, refers to her as a ‘housewife’
<div n="lb"/>(Rv. iv. 55, 3; viii. 27, 5).</F>
<LEND>

<L>1754<pc>1-513<k1>pAMsu<k2>pAMsu
{@Pāṃsu@}¦ in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> denotes ‘dust’ or
<div n="lb"/>‘sand,’ usually in the plural. Among the portents enumerated
<div n="lb"/>in the Adbhuta Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> is a rain of dust or sand ({%pāṃsu-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%varṣa%}), a phenomenon not rare in India.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) vii. 109, 2; xii. 1, 26.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 10, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta, xii. 19, etc.</F>
<F>3) vi. 8 ({%Indische Studien,%} 1, 40). {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Varāhamihira, Bṛhatsaṃhitā, xxii. 6.</F>
<F>4) The adjective {%pāṃsura%} is found in
<div n="lb"/>Rv. i. 22, 17, with a variant, {%pāṃsula,%}
<div n="lb"/>Sāmaveda, i. 3, 1, 3, 9. {%Cf.%} Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iv. 5, 1, 9.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1755<pc>1-513<k1>pAkadUrvA<k2>pAkadUrvA
{@Pāka-dūrvā@}¦ is, in a verse of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> included with
<div n="lb"/>{@Kiyāmbu@} and {@Vyalkaśā@} among the plants used for growing on
<div n="lb"/>the spot where the corpse of the dead man has been consumed
<div n="lb"/>with fire.<sup>2</sup> The verse is repeated in the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka<sup>3</sup>
[Page1-514+ 38]
<div n="lb"/>with the variant Kyāmbu. In the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup> the word is
<div n="lb"/>read Śāṇḍadūrvā. Pākadūrvā is probably, as Sāyaṇa-under-
<div n="lb"/>stands it, {%paripakva-dūrvā,%} ‘ripe or edible millet.’ Śāṇḍadūrvā
<div n="lb"/>is explained by the commentator<sup>5</sup> in various ways, as millet
<div n="lb"/>‘having egg-shaped roots’ ({%i.e., sāṇḍa,%} not {%śāṇḍa%}), or as ‘having
<div n="lb"/>long joints,’ with the additional remark that it was called {%bṛhad-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%dūrvā,%} ‘large millet.’ In the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, on the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, the commentary explains Pākadūrvā as small millet.
<F>1) x. 16, 13.</F>
<F>2) See Bloomfield, {%American Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of Philology,%} 11, 342-350; {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%American Oriental Society,%} 15, xxxix.</F>
<F>3) vi. 4, 1, 2.</F>
<F>4) xviii. 3, 6.</F>
<F>5) Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 850.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 70.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1783<pc>1-518<k1>pArAvata<k2>pArAvata<h>2
2. {@Pārāvata@}¦ occurs in several passages of the Rigveda.
<div n="lb"/>Roth<sup>1</sup> thinks that in most places<sup>2</sup> it means ‘coming from a
<div n="lb"/>distance,’ but in two passages<sup>3</sup> he regards it as the proper
<div n="lb"/>name of a people on the {@Yamunā@} (Jumna). It is certain that
<div n="lb"/>in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa the Pārāvatas are a people on
<div n="lb"/>that river ({%cf.%} {@Turaśravas@}). Hillebrandt<sup>4</sup> sees in all the
<div n="lb"/>passages<sup>5</sup> the name of a people, comparing the <lang n="greek"></lang> of
[Page1-519+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>Ptolemy,<sup>6</sup> who apparently were settled on the northern border
<div n="lb"/>of Gedrosia, or the <lang n="greek"></lang>, who were found in <lang n="greek"></lang><sup>7</sup> He
<div n="lb"/>suggests that they were originally ‘mountaineers’ ({%Cf.%} {@Parvata@}).
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig<sup>8</sup> holds a similar view, and Geldner<sup>9</sup> recognizes a people
<div n="lb"/>as meant. The mention of the {@Sarasvatī@} in connexion with
<div n="lb"/>the Pārāvatas<sup>2</sup> in the Rigveda accords generally with their
<div n="lb"/>position on the Yamunā in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>2) Rv. v. 52, 11; viii. 100, 6; Av.
<div n="lb"/>xx. 135, 14; {%pārāvata-ghnī%} of the
<div n="lb"/>Sarasvatī, Rv. vi. 61, 2.</F>
<F>3) Rv. viii. 34, 18; Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ix. 4, 11. {%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%Transac-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%tions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts%}
<div n="lb"/>{%and Sciences,%} 15, 53.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 97 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>3, 310, following Brunnhofer, {%Iran und%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Turan,%} 99.</F>
<F>5) See notes 2 and 3.</F>
<F>6) vi. 20, 3. It is suggested by Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt that the <lang n="greek"></lang> of Herodotus,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 91, may be the same.</F>
<F>7) Ptolemy, vi. 17.</F>

<div n="lb"/>197.</F>
<F>9) {%Rigveda, Glossar,%} 109.

<L>1789<pc>1-520<k1>pArikzita<k2>pArikzita
{@Pārikṣita,@}¦ ‘descendant of {@Parikṣit,@}’ is the patronymic of
<div n="lb"/>{@Janamejaya@} in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> and the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> The Pārikṣitīya appear in the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>3</sup> and the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra<sup>4</sup> as performers of the
<div n="lb"/>horse sacrifice. In a Gāthā there cited they are called Pāri-
<div n="lb"/>kṣitas. Apparently they were the brothers of Janamejaya, named
<div n="lb"/>{@Ugrasena, Bhīmasena,@} and {@Śrutasena.@} In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad<sup>5</sup> the question whither they have gone is made the
<div n="lb"/>subject of a philosophical discussion. It is clear that the family
<div n="lb"/>had passed away before the time of the Upaniṣad, and it is also
<div n="lb"/>clear that there had been some serious scandal mingled with
<div n="lb"/>their greatness which they had, in the opinion of the Brahmins,
<div n="lb"/>atoned for by their horse sacrifice with its boundless gifts to
<div n="lb"/>the priests. Weber<sup>6</sup> sees in this the germ of the Epic stories
<div n="lb"/>which are recorded in the Mahābhārata.
<div n="P"/>The verses relating to Parikṣit in the Atharvaveda<sup>7</sup> are called
<div n="lb"/>Pārikṣityaḥ in the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) vii. 27 and 34; viii. 11.</F>
<F>2) xiii. 5, 4, 1. {%Cf.%} Gopatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 2, 6; ii. 6, 12.</F>
<F>3) xiii. 5, 4, 3.</F>
<F>4) xvi. 9. 7.</F>
<F>5) iii. 3, 1.</F>
<F>6) {%Indian Literature,%} 125, 126; 135, 136.
<div n="lb"/>The later legend of the Pārikṣitas and
<div n="lb"/>Vāmadeva's mares is dealt with by
<div n="lb"/>Weber in {%Vedische Beiträge%} (1894).</F>
<F>7) xx. 127, 7-10; Śāṅkhāyana Srauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xii. 17; Scheftelowitz, {%Die%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Apokryphen des Ṛgveda,%} 156, 157.</F>
<F>8) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vi. 32, 10;
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xxx. 5; Gopatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 12; Weber, {%op. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>136, n. 144.</F>

<L>1817<pc>1-525<k1>pitAmaha<k2>pitAmaha
{@Pitā-maha,@}¦ beside {@Tatāmaha,@} denotes from the Atharvaveda
<div n="lb"/>onwards<sup>1</sup> the ‘paternal grandfather,’ apparently as a ‘father in
<div n="lb"/>a higher sense.’<sup>2</sup> The great-grandfather is {@Prapitāmaha@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Pratatāmaha.@}<sup>3</sup> It is significant that there are no corrésponding
<div n="lb"/>Vedic words for maternal grandparents, and that the words
<div n="lb"/>used in the latter language, such as Mātāmaha, are imitations
<div n="lb"/>of the terms for paternal relations.
<div n="P"/>In one passage of the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> Delbrück<sup>5</sup> suggests that
<div n="lb"/>{%mahe pitre%} means ‘grandfather,’ a sense which would well suit
<div n="lb"/>the {%napātam,%} ‘grandson,’ following, but the sense of the whole
<div n="lb"/>passage is uncertain.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>We learn very little from the texts of the position of grand-
<div n="lb"/>parents. No doubt they were entitled to marks of respect
<div n="lb"/>similar to those shown to parents,<sup>7</sup> as the epic expressly
<div n="lb"/>testifies. A grandfather might easily be the head of the family,
<div n="lb"/>or be living with his eldest son, after he ceased to be able to
<div n="lb"/>control the family.
<div n="P"/>The grandmother (Pitāmahī) is not mentioned in the extant
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature.
<F>1) Av. v. 5, 1; ix. 5, 30; xi. 1, 19;
<div n="lb"/>xviii. 4, 35; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 8,
<div n="lb"/>5, 1; vii. 2, 7, 3; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xix. 36; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 5,
<div n="lb"/>5, 4.</F>
<F>2) Delbrück, {%Die indogermanischen Ver-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%wandtschaftsnamen,%} 474.</F>
<F>3) Av. xviii. 4, 75.</F>
<F>4) vi. 20. 11.</F>
<F>5) {%Ibid.,%} 473.</F>
<F>6) See Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 128,
<div n="lb"/>n. 1. Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.,%} also doubts the view which is
<div n="lb"/>accepted by Delbrück, and denies
<div n="lb"/>that in Rv. i. 71, 5, the sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘grandfather’ can be found.</F>
<F>7) Delbrück, {%op. cit.,%} 480, citing
<div n="lb"/>Mahābhārata, ii. 1634.</F>

<L>1819<pc>1-526<k1>pitf<k2>pitf
{@Pitṛ,@}¦ common from the Rigveda onwards, denotes ‘father,’
<div n="lb"/>not so much as the ‘begetter’ ({%janitṛ%}),<sup>1</sup> but rather as the pro-
<div n="lb"/>tector of the child, this being probably also the etymological
<div n="lb"/>sense of the word.<sup>2</sup> The father in the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> stands for all
<div n="lb"/>that is good and kind. Hence Agni is compared with a father,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>while Indra is even dearer than a father.<sup>5</sup> The father carries
<div n="lb"/>his son in his arms,<sup>6</sup> and places him on his lap,<sup>7</sup> while the child
<div n="lb"/>pulls his garment to attract attention.<sup>8</sup> In later years the son
<div n="lb"/>depends on his father for help in trouble,<sup>9</sup> and greets him
<div n="lb"/>with joy.<sup>10</sup>
<div n="P"/>It is difficult to ascertain precisely how far the son was
<div n="lb"/>subject to parental control, and how long such control con-
<div n="lb"/>tinued. Reference is made in the Rigveda<sup>11</sup> to a father's
<div n="lb"/>chastising his son for gambling, and {@Ṛjrāśva@} is said to have
<div n="lb"/>been blinded by his father.<sup>12</sup> From the latter statement
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>13</sup> infers the existence of a developed {%patria potestas,%} but
<div n="lb"/>to lay stress on this isolated and semi-mythical incident would
<div n="lb"/>be unwise. It is, however, quite likely that the {%patria potestas%}
<div n="lb"/>was originally strong, for we have other support for the thesis
<div n="lb"/>in the Roman {%patria potestas.%} If there is no proof that a father
[Page1-527+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>legally controlled his son's wedding,<sup>14</sup> and not much that he
<div n="lb"/>controlled his daughter's,<sup>15</sup> the fact is in itself not im-
<div n="lb"/>probable.
<div n="P"/>There is again no evidence to show whether a son, when
<div n="lb"/>grown up, normally continued to stay with his father, his wife
<div n="lb"/>becoming a member of the father's household, or whether he
<div n="lb"/>set up a house of his own: probably the custom varied. Nor
<div n="lb"/>do we know whether the son was granted a special plot of land
<div n="lb"/>on marriage or otherwise, or whether he only came into such
<div n="lb"/>property after his father's death. But any excessive estimate
<div n="lb"/>of the father's powers over a son who was no longer a minor
<div n="lb"/>and naturally under his control, must be qualified by the fact
<div n="lb"/>that in his old age the sons might divide their father's property,<sup>16</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or he might divide it amongst them,<sup>17</sup> and that when the
<div n="lb"/>father-in-law became aged he fell under the control of his son's
<div n="lb"/>wife.<sup>18</sup> There are also obscure traces that in old age a father
<div n="lb"/>might be exposed, though there is no reason to suppose that
<div n="lb"/>this was usual in Vedic India.<sup>19</sup>
<div n="P"/>Normally the son was bound to give his father full obedience.<sup>20</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The later Sūtras show in detail the acts of courtesy which he
<div n="lb"/>owed his father, and they allow him to eat the remnants of his
<div n="lb"/>father's food.<sup>21</sup> On the other hand, the father was expected
<div n="lb"/>to be kind. The story of {@Śunaḥśepa@} in the Aitareya Brāh-
[Page1-528+ 58]
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>22</sup> emphasizes the horror with which the father's heartless
<div n="lb"/>treatment of his son was viewed. The Upaniṣads<sup>23</sup> insist on the
<div n="lb"/>spiritual succession from father to son. The kissing of a son<sup>24</sup>
<div n="lb"/>was a frequent and usual token of affection, even in mature
<div n="lb"/>years.
<div n="P"/>On the failure of natural children, adoption was possible.<sup>25</sup>
<div n="lb"/>It was even resorted to when natural children existed, but
<div n="lb"/>when it was desired to secure the presence in the family of a
<div n="lb"/>person of specially high qualifications, as in Viśvāmitra's
<div n="lb"/>adoption of Śunaḥśepa.<sup>26</sup> It is not clear that adoption from
<div n="lb"/>one caste into another was possible, for there is no good
<div n="lb"/>evidence that Viśvāmitra was, as Weber<sup>27</sup> holds, a Kṣatriya
<div n="lb"/>who adopted a Brāhmaṇa. Adoption was also not always in
<div n="lb"/>high favour: it may be accidental or not that a hymn of the
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭha book of the Rigveda<sup>28</sup> condemns the usage. It was
<div n="lb"/>also possible for the father who had a daughter, but no sons,
<div n="lb"/>to appoint her to bear a son for him. At any rate the practice
<div n="lb"/>appears to be referred to in an obscure verse of the Rigveda<sup>29</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as interpreted by Yāska.<sup>30</sup> Moreover, it is possible that the
<div n="lb"/>difficulty of a brotherless maiden finding a husband<sup>31</sup> may have
<div n="lb"/>been due in part to the possibility of her father desiring to
<div n="lb"/>make her a Putrikā, the later technical name for a daughter
<div n="lb"/>whose son is to belong to her father's family.
<div n="P"/>There can be no doubt that in a family the father took
<div n="lb"/>precedence of the mother.<sup>32</sup> Delbrück<sup>33</sup> explains away the
<div n="lb"/>apparent cases to the contrary.<sup>34</sup> There is no trace of the
[Page1-529+ 74]
<div n="lb"/>family as a land-owning corporation.<sup>35</sup> The dual form Pitarau
<div n="lb"/>regularly means ‘father and mother,’ ‘parents.’<sup>36</sup>
<F>1) {%Pitā janitā,%} is used of gods in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda — {%e.g.,%} iv. 17, 12.</F>
<F>2) As derived from {%pā,%} ‘protect.’
<div n="lb"/>But, as Böhtlingk and Roth, St. Peters-
<div n="lb"/>burg Dictionary, {%s.v. Mātar,%} footnote,
<div n="lb"/>suggest, {%pa%} and {%mā%} were probably the
<div n="lb"/>much older original onomatopoetic
<div n="lb"/>names for ‘father’ and ‘mother,’ which
<div n="lb"/>in a later reflective age influenced the
<div n="lb"/>formation of {%pitṛ%} and {%mātṛ%} (which them-
<div n="lb"/>selves go back to the Indo-European
<div n="lb"/>period).</F>
<F>3) See, {%e.g.,%} iv. 17, 17; viii. 86, 4.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 7, 3.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 32, 19; viii. 1, 6.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 38, 1.</F>
<F>7) Rv. v. 43, 7.</F>
<F>8) Rv. iii. 53, 2.</F>
<F>9) In Rv. x. 48, 1, the {%jantavaḥ%} possibly
<div n="lb"/>are the sons.</F>
<F>10) Rv. vii. 103, 3. {%Cf.%} 1, 24, 1.</F>
<F>11) Rv. ii. 29, 5.</F>
<F>12) Rv. i. 116, 16; 117, 17. There is
<div n="lb"/>also the case of the sale of Sunaḥśepa,
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 12-18; and
<div n="lb"/>{%cf.%} Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 3, 3, 3.</F>
<F>13) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 316.</F>
<F>14) {%Cf.%} Delbrück, {%Die indogermanischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Verwandtschaftsnamen,%} 576. {%Ibid.,%} 582,
<div n="lb"/>he quotes Mahābhārata, xii. 6108 {%et seq.,%}
<div n="lb"/>which refers in one line to the control
<div n="lb"/>of the marriage of the son by the father,
<div n="lb"/>and in the next to a case of free marriage.
<div n="lb"/>The fact is, no doubt, that the son
<div n="lb"/>could marry freely, unless his father
<div n="lb"/>had arranged matters for him when he
<div n="lb"/>was too young to object.</F>
<F>15) Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 309, assumes this
<div n="lb"/>as certain, but it is far from proved.
<div n="lb"/>See, however, Jaiminīya Upaniṣad
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iii. 12, 2, which is in
<div n="lb"/>favour of Zimmer's view. {%Cf.%} Kaegi,
<div n="lb"/>{%Dev Rigveda,%} 15, and {@Pati.@}</F>
<F>16) Rv. i. 70, 10; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>v. 14; Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 156
<div n="lb"/>({%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>26, 61, 62).</F>
<F>17) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 9, 4-6.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} the handing over from father to
<div n="lb"/>son in the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, ii. 15.
<div n="lb"/>If the father recovered, he lived subject
<div n="lb"/>to his son.</F>
<F>18) Rv. x. 85, 46.</F>
<F>19) {%Cf.%} Rv. viii. 51, 2; Av. xviii. 2, 34.
<div n="lb"/>The first passage need not refer to
<div n="lb"/>exposure, and the second merely refers
<div n="lb"/>to the exposure of a dead body; but
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 326-328,
<div n="lb"/>thinks that they prove exposure. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>{@Dharma.@}</F>
<F>20) Rv. i. 68, 5</F>
<F>21) Āpastamba Dharma Sūtra, i. 1,
<div n="lb"/>4, 11.</F>
<F>22) vii. 12 {%et seq.;%} Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xv. 17 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>23) {%E.g.,%} Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, ii. 15;
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, i. 5, 25
<div n="lb"/>(Mādhyaṃdina = i. 5, 17, Kāṇva).</F>

<F>33) {%Die indogermanischen Verwandt-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%schaftsnamen,%} 577.</F>
<F>34) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iv. 7,
<div n="lb"/>5. Some passages in the Sūtras present
<div n="lb"/>difficulties, but they are of no im-
<div n="lb"/>portance for Vedic times proper.</F>
<F>35) Baden Powell, whose various
<div n="lb"/>works ({%Indian Village Community,%} 1896;
<div n="lb"/>{%Village Communities in India,%} 1899, etc.)
<div n="lb"/>have done most to combat the view of
<div n="lb"/>the village community in India as a
<div n="lb"/>land-holding institution, is prepared to
<div n="lb"/>recognize the family as a land-owning
<div n="lb"/>unit, considering that the {%patria potestas%}
<div n="lb"/>is a later growth, and not Indian (see,
<div n="lb"/>{%e.g., Village Communities in India,%} 128
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}). Hopkins, {%India, Old and New,%}
<div n="lb"/>218 {%et seq.,%} adopts a theory which allows
<div n="lb"/>of individual and joint family owner-
<div n="lb"/>ship side by side, the latter being
<div n="lb"/>apparently the earlier but the decadent
<div n="lb"/>stage. He expressly considers (p. 222)
<div n="lb"/>that the son had an indefeasible right to
<div n="lb"/>prevent the father from alienating the
<div n="lb"/>hereditary land, which could only be
<div n="lb"/>parted with by the consent of the village
<div n="lb"/>if it were a case of joint ownership
<div n="lb"/>({%cf.%} the verse cited by Jolly, {%Recht und%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sitte,%} 94). But it must be remembered
<div n="lb"/>that, as is very clearly shown in the
<div n="lb"/>case of English law by Pollock and
<div n="lb"/>Maitland ({%History of English Law,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>337-352), the recognition of the rights
<div n="lb"/>of sons may well be, not a sign of
<div n="lb"/>original joint or family ownership, but
<div n="lb"/>a development from the existence of
<div n="lb"/>intestate succession, and as in England,
<div n="lb"/>so in India, there is no trace of a
<div n="lb"/>corporate joint family in the early
<div n="lb"/>books. And, as Jolly ({%op. cit.,%} 76, 80)
<div n="lb"/>shows, there are clear traces, both in
<div n="lb"/>old and modern times, of a despotic
<div n="lb"/>control of the family by the father even
<div n="lb"/>after his sons grew up, provided only
<div n="lb"/>that he was physically able to control
<div n="lb"/>them. The same state of affairs seems
<div n="lb"/>proved for early English law, as it is
<div n="lb"/>beyond question for Roman law (see
<div n="lb"/>Smith's {%Dictionary of Antiquities,%} 2, 351
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}). In Greece also, which is some-
<div n="lb"/>times contrasted with Rome, there is
<div n="lb"/>the clearest trace of both a real {%patria%}
<div n="lb"/>{%potestas,%} and of the absolute ownership
<div n="lb"/>of the land by the father as against
<div n="lb"/>the son, especially in the archaic laws
<div n="lb"/>of Gortyn (see Gardner and Jevons,
<div n="lb"/>{%Greek Antiquities,%} 404, 405, 563, 566).</F>
<F>36) Rv. i. 20, 4; 160, 3; ii. 17, 7;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 67, 1; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxiii 10;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 11, etc.</F>
