<L>1820<pc>1-529<k1>pitfyARa<k2>pitfyARa
{@Pitṛ-yāṇa,@}¦ the ‘way of the fathers,’ mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later,<sup>2</sup> is opposed to the Deva-yāna, or ‘way of the gods.’
<div n="lb"/>Tilak<sup>3</sup> considers that the Devayāna corresponds with the
<div n="lb"/>Uttarāyaṇa, ‘northern journey’ of the sun, and the Pitṛyāṇa
<div n="lb"/>with the Dakṣiṇāyana, its ‘southern journey.’ He concludes
<div n="lb"/>from a passage of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>4</sup> where three of
<div n="lb"/>the seasons — spring, summer, and the rains — are ascribed to
<div n="lb"/>the gods, but the others to the Pitṛs, or Fathers, that the
<div n="lb"/>Devayāna began with the vernal equinox, and the Pitṛyāṇa
<div n="lb"/>with the autumnal equinox. With this he connects the curious
[Page1-530+ 37]
<div n="lb"/>distinction of Deva- and Yama-Nakṣatras in the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa.<sup>5</sup> These conclusions are, however, very improbable.

<div n="lb"/>x. 18, 1, as other than the Devavāna,

<L>1834<pc>1-533<k1>piSAca<k2>piSAca
{@Piśāca@}¦ is the name of a class of demon mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> In the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup> they are
<div n="lb"/>associated with Rakṣases and Asuras, while opposed to gods,

<div n="lb"/>{%kravyād,%} ‘eaters of raw flesh,’ which may be the etymological
<div n="lb"/>sense of the word Piśāca itself.<sup>5</sup> It is possible that the Piśācas
<div n="lb"/>were, as suggested by Grierson,<sup>6</sup> really human foes, like the
<div n="lb"/>north-western tribes, who even in later times were reputed
<div n="lb"/>eaters of raw flesh (not necessarily as cannibals, but rather as
<div n="lb"/>eaters of human flesh in ritual). This is, however, not at all
<div n="lb"/>likely, the Piśācas having in all probability only meant ‘ghouls’
<div n="lb"/>originally: when they appear as human tribes, they were
<div n="lb"/>presumably thus designated in scorn. A science called Piśāca-
<div n="lb"/>veda<sup>7</sup> or Piśāca-vidyā<sup>8</sup> is known in the later Vedic period.

<F>3) ii. 4, 1, 1; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xxxvii. 14.</F>

<L>1860<pc>1-538<k1>pur<k2>pur
{@Pur@}¦ is a word of frequent occurrence in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>later,<sup>2</sup> meaning ‘rampart,’ ‘fort,’ or ‘stronghold.’ Such fortifi-
<div n="lb"/>cations must have been occasionally of considerable size, as
<div n="lb"/>one is called ‘broad’ ({%pṛthvī%}) and ‘wide’ ({%urvī%}).<sup>3</sup> Elsewhere<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>a fort ‘made of stone’ ({%aśmamayī%}) is mentioned. Sometimes
<div n="lb"/>strongholds ‘of iron’ ({%āyasī%}) are referred to,<sup>5</sup> but these are
<div n="lb"/>probably only metaphorical. A fort ‘full of kine’ ({%gomatī%}) is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned,<sup>6</sup> showing that strongholds were used to hold cattle.
<div n="lb"/>‘Autumnal’ ({%śāradī%}) forts are named, apparently as belonging
<div n="lb"/>to the {@Dāsas:@} this may refer to the forts in that season being
[Page1-539+ 89]
<div n="lb"/>occupied against Āryan attacks or against inundations caused
<div n="lb"/>by overflowing rivers. Forts ‘with a hundred walls’ ({%śata-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%bhuji%}) are spoken of.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="P"/>It would probably be a mistake to regard these forts as
<div n="lb"/>permanently occupied fortified places like the fortresses of the
<div n="lb"/>mediæval barony. They were probably merely places of refuge
<div n="lb"/>against attack, ramparts of hardened earth with palisades and
<div n="lb"/>a ditch ({%cf.%} {@Dehī@}). Pischel and Geldner,<sup>8</sup> however, think that
<div n="lb"/>there were towns with wooden walls and ditches (<lang n="greek"></lang> and
<lang n="greek"></lang>) like the Indian town of Pāṭaliputra known to Megas-
<div n="lb"/>thenes<sup>9</sup> and the Pāli texts.<sup>10</sup> This is possible, but hardly
<div n="lb"/>susceptible of proof, and it is not without significance that the
<div n="lb"/>word {@Nagara@} is of late occurrence. On the whole it is hardly
<div n="lb"/>likely that in early Vedic times city life was much developed.
<div n="lb"/>In the Epic, according to Hopkins,<sup>11</sup> there are found the
<div n="lb"/>Nagara, ‘city’; {@Grāma,@} ‘village’; and Ghoṣa, ‘ranch.’ Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature hardly seems to go beyond the village, no doubt with
<div n="lb"/>modifications in its later period.
<div n="P"/>The siege of forts is mentioned in the Saṃhitās and Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇas.<sup>12</sup> According to the Rigveda,<sup>13</sup> fire was used.
<F>1) i. 53, 7, 58, 8; 131, 4; 166, 8;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 15, 4; iv. 27, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 7, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 23; ii. 11;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 4, 3; vi. 3,
<div n="lb"/>3, 25; xi. 1, 1, 2, 3; Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, viii. 5, 3, etc.</F>
<F>3) i. 189, 2.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iv. 30, 20. Perhaps sun-dried
<div n="lb"/>bricks are alluded to by {%āmā%} (lit. ‘raw,’
<div n="lb"/>‘unbaked’) in Rv. ii. 35, 6.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 58, 8; ii. 20, 8; iv. 27, 1.
<div n="lb"/>vii. 3, 7; 15, 4; 95, 1; x. 101, 8. See
<div n="lb"/>Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 2^2, 378 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>6) Av. viii. 6, 23.</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 166, 8; vii. 15, 14.</F>
<F>8) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, xxii, xxiii, where
<div n="lb"/>{%kṣiti dhruvā,%} i. 73, 4, is compared.</F>
<F>9) Strabo, p. 702; Arrian, {%Indica,%} 10.</F>
<F>10) Mahāparinibbānasutta, p. 12.  {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Rhys Davids, {%Buddhist India,%} 262.</F>
<F>11) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 13, 77; 174 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>12) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 3, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 23; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 4, 3-5; Gopatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ii. 2, 7, etc.</F>
<F>13) vii. 5, 3. Possibly, in some cases,
<div n="lb"/>the palisade was no more than a hedge
<div n="lb"/>of thorn or a row of stakes ({%cf.%} Rv.
<div n="lb"/>x. 101, 8), as suggested by Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 143, 145; and {%cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Rv. viii. 53, 5, as corrected by Roth,
<div n="lb"/>{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gesellschaft,%} 48, 109.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 142-
<div n="lb"/>148, who compares the fact that neither
<div n="lb"/>the Germans (Tacitus, {%Germania,%} 16)
<div n="lb"/>nor the Slavs (Procopius, {%De bello Gotico,%}
<div n="lb"/>iii. 14) lived in towns, but, like the
<div n="lb"/>ancient Indians, were scattered in
<div n="lb"/>villages, each consisting of the houses
<div n="lb"/>and steadings of the several families
<div n="lb"/>living in the village. The evidence
<div n="lb"/>seems pretty convincing. It is true
<div n="lb"/>that the Greeks, when we first find
<div n="lb"/>them, evidently knew castles and for-
<div n="lb"/>tresses of the mediæval type; but the
<div n="lb"/>Greeks were clearly an invading race,
<div n="lb"/>superimposed on an older and in
<div n="lb"/>civilization more advanced people (see,
<div n="lb"/>{%e.g.,%} Burrows, {%Discoveries in Crete%}). But
<div n="lb"/>the Pur may, as Zimmer allows, have
<div n="lb"/>sometimes been built within the limits
<div n="lb"/>of the village. Whether, as he urges
<div n="lb"/>(144), the {%śāradī pur%} was a protection
<div n="lb"/>against the floods of autumn is un-
<div n="lb"/>certain. {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 131, 4; 174, 2;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 20, 10. In particular, it is not
<div n="lb"/>legitimate to connect the mention of
<div n="lb"/>those forts with the fact that the Pūrus
<div n="lb"/>lived on either side of the Sindhu
<div n="lb"/>(Indus), and to assume that Purukutsa's
<div n="lb"/>attack on the aborigines was directed
<div n="lb"/>against the forts in which they normally
<div n="lb"/>protected themselves on the rising of
<div n="lb"/>the river. No argument for the large
<div n="lb"/>size of cities can be drawn from the
<div n="lb"/>mention in the Kāṭhaka Upaniṣad, v. 1,
<div n="lb"/>of {%ekādaśa-dvāra%} as an epithet of Pura
<div n="lb"/>({%cf.%} Śvetāśvatara Upaniśad, iii. 18;
<div n="lb"/>{%nava-dvāra pura,%} ‘the citadel of nine
<div n="lb"/>doors’), because it is used meta-
<div n="lb"/>phorically of the body, and the number
<div n="lb"/>of doors depends on the nature of the
<div n="lb"/>body (Keith, {%Aitareya Āraṇyaka,%} 185).
<div n="lb"/>The evidence of the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, xi. 1, 1, 2, 3, seems rather to
<div n="lb"/>point to only one gate in a city.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Schrader, {%Prehistoric Antiquities,%}
<div n="lb"/>412; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 451;

<L>1863<pc>1-540<k1>purARa<k2>purARa<h>1
1. {@Purāṇa,@}¦ denoting a tale ‘of olden times,’ is often found<sup>1</sup>

<div n="lb"/>Dvandva compound meaning ‘{@Itihāsa@} and Purāṇa.’ It some-
<div n="lb"/>times<sup>2</sup> occurs as a separate word, but beside Itihāsa, no doubt
<div n="lb"/>with the same sense as in the Dvandva. Sāyaṇa<sup>3</sup> defines a
<div n="lb"/>Purāṇa as a tale which deals with the primitive condition of
<div n="lb"/>the universe and the creation of the world, but there is no
<div n="lb"/>ground for supposing that this view is correct, or for clearly
<div n="lb"/>distinguishing Itihāsa and Purāṇa. See {@Itihāsa.@}

<L>1867<pc>1-541<k1>purukutsa<k2>purukutsa
{@Puru-kutsa@}¦ is the name of a king who is mentioned several
<div n="lb"/>times in the Rigveda. In one passage<sup>1</sup> he is mentioned as a
<div n="lb"/>contemporary of {@Sudās,@} but whether as a foe, according to
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig,<sup>2</sup> or merely as a contemporary, according to Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt,<sup>3</sup> is uncertain. In two other passages<sup>4</sup> he is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>as victorious by divine favour, and in another<sup>5</sup> he appears as a
<div n="lb"/>king of the {@Pūrus@} and a conqueror of the {@Dāsas.@} His son was
<div n="lb"/>{@Trasadasyu,@}<sup>6</sup> who is accordingly called {@Paurukutsya@}<sup>7</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>{@Paurukutsi.@}<sup>8</sup> Different conclusions have been drawn from one
<div n="lb"/>hymn of the Rigveda<sup>9</sup> in which the birth of Purukutsa's son,
[Page1-542+ 44]
<div n="lb"/>Trasadasyu, is mentioned. The usual interpretation is that
<div n="lb"/>Purukutsa was killed in battle or captured, whereupon his
<div n="lb"/>wife secured a son to restore the fortunes of the Pūrus. But
<div n="lb"/>Sieg<sup>10</sup> offers a completely different interpretation. According
<div n="lb"/>to him the word {@daurgahe,@} which occurs in the hymn, and
<div n="lb"/>which in the ordinary view is rendered ‘descendant of Durgaha,’
<div n="lb"/>an ancestor of Purukutsa, is the name of a horse, the hymn
<div n="lb"/>recording the success of an Aśvamedha (‘horse sacrifice’)
<div n="lb"/>undertaken by Purukutsa for his wife, as by kings in later
<div n="lb"/>times, to secure a son. This interpretation is supported by the
<div n="lb"/>version of {%daurgahe%} given in the Śatapatha,<sup>11</sup> but is by no
<div n="lb"/>means certain. Moreover, if Purukutsa was a contemporary of
<div n="lb"/>Sudās, the defeat of the Pūrus by Sudās in the {@Dāśarājña@}<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>might well have been the cause of the troubles from which
<div n="lb"/>{@Purukutsānī,@} by the birth of Trasadasyu, rescued the family.
<div n="lb"/>In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>13</sup> Purukutsa is called an Aikṣvāka.
<F>1) i. 63, 7.</F>
<F>2) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 174,
<div n="lb"/>emending {%sudāse%} in the text to {%sudāsam,%}
<div n="lb"/>plausibly, but not, of course, con-
<div n="lb"/>vincingly.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 115. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 204.
<div n="lb"/>205, 219.</F>
<F>4) i. 112, 7, 14; 174, 2.</F>
<F>5) vi. 20, 10. {%Cf.%} i. 63, 7, where
<div n="lb"/>Pūru also is mentioned. Ludwig sug-
<div n="lb"/>gests reading in vi. 20, 10, {%saudāsīḥ%} for
<div n="lb"/>{%dāsīḥ,%} referring to the forts of Sudās;
<div n="lb"/>but this must be regarded as illegiti-
<div n="lb"/>mate. {%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift,%} 55,
<div n="lb"/>330.</F>
<F>6) Rv. iv. 42, 8. 9.</F>
<F>7) Rv. v. 33, 8; viii. 19, 36.</F>
<F>8) Rv. vii. 19, 3.</F>
<F>9) Rv. iv. 42, 8. 9, with Sāyaṇa's
<div n="lb"/>note; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 266, 267.</F>
<F>10) {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 96-102.</F>
<F>11) xiii. 5, 4, 5.</F>
<F>12) vii. 18. {%Cf.%} also the reference to
<div n="lb"/>a Pūru defeat in vii. 8, 4.</F>
<F>13) xiii. 5, 4, 5. {%Cf.%} {@Ikṣvāku, Tryaruṇa,@}
<div n="lb"/>and Oldenberg, {%Buddha,%} 403.</F>

<L>1874<pc>1-543<k1>purumI|a<k2>purumI|a
{@Puru-mīḷha@}¦ is mentioned twice in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as an ancient
<div n="lb"/>sage, in which capacity he appears in the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> also.
<div n="lb"/>Perhaps the same<sup>3</sup> Purumīḷha is intended in an obscure hymn
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda,<sup>4</sup> where, according to the legends reported in
<div n="lb"/>the Bṛhaddevatā<sup>5</sup> and by Ṣaḍguruśiṣya in his commentary on
<div n="lb"/>the Sarvānukramaṇī,<sup>6</sup> and by Sāyaṇa in his commentary on the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>4</sup> he as well as {@Taranta@} was a son of Vidadaśva, and
<div n="lb"/>a patron of the singer {@Śyāvāśva.@} The correctness of the legend
<div n="lb"/>has been shown to be most improbable by Oldenberg,<sup>7</sup> who
<div n="lb"/>points out<sup>8</sup> that the legend misinterprets the Rigveda by
<div n="lb"/>making Purumīḷha a Vaidadaśvi, for he is there only compared
<div n="lb"/>in generosity to one.
<div n="P"/>In another legend found in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>9</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>based on a hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>10</sup> Purumīḷha and Taranta
<div n="lb"/>appear as persons who received gifts from {@Dhvasra@} and {@Puru-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@ṣanti,@} and as sons of Vidadaśva. The legend, which also
<div n="lb"/>occurs in the Śāṭyāyanaka,<sup>11</sup> is apparently best explained by
[Page1-544+ 12]
<div n="lb"/>Sieg,<sup>12</sup> who says that as the two were kings they could not
<div n="lb"/>under the rules of caste accept gifts, unless for the nonce they
<div n="lb"/>became singers. The legend has no claim at all, as Oldenberg<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>shows, to validity.
<F>1) i. 151, 2; 183. 5.</F>
<F>2) iv. 29, 4; xviii. 3, 15.</F>
<F>3) See, however, Weber, {%Episches im%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vedischen Ritual,%} 27, n. 3; Sieg, {%Die%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 62, n. 3</F>
<F>4) v. 61, 9.</F>
<F>5) v. 49 {%et seq.,%} with Macdonell's notes.</F>
<F>6) Edition Macdonell, pp. 118 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) v. 61, 9.</F>
<F>7) {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 353, 354. {%Cf.%} Max
<div n="lb"/>Müller, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32,
<div n="lb"/>359.</F>
<F>8) {%Op. cit.,%} 354, n. 1.</F>

; FOREWORD

[Page1-i+ 34]
<H>{@FOREWORD@}
<P>Messrs Motilal Banarsidas are to be congratulated on
<>bringing out this edition of Macdonald and Keith's Vedic Index
<>of names and subjects. This is a very useful compilation and
<>every student of Vedic literature finds it invaluable. It is much
<>more than what its name implies. There are illuminating notes
<>on a variety of subjects, Civil Law for instance, which supply
<>the background without which an exegesis of Vedic texts, inclu-
<>ding in the term the compendia of religion, ritual, tradition and
<>philosophy known as Brahamanas would not be possible. It is
<>not necessary to accept all the theses which the learned authors
<>have laid down for themselves. For instance, they are not
<>prepared to believe that Vedic literature is much earlier than
<>1200 B.C. for reasons which are not very difficult to understand.
<>Western scholars find it difficult to accord Indian culture and
<>civilization an antiquity as great as that of the Egyptians. They
<>are not prepared to admit, as Macdonald specifically states in
<>his preface, that the cult of Vedic gods like Indra, Varuna and
<>the Nasatyas could have travelled from India to Middle Asia.
<>For them the researches of Tilak and other Indian scholars who
<>find internal evidence in Vedic literature itself to carry Vedic
<>chronology back by several centuries and of an Aryan culture,
<>though not necessarily an Aryan race, rooted firmly in Indian
<>soil and sending out its off shoots to countries further west, have
<>no meaning. Normally, perhaps, such differences in matters
<>apparently of purely an academic interest should not affect
<>the value of a book like the present Index. But, it can easily be
<>seen that at times the interpretation of particular terms would
<>be affected by such considerations. To take the word ‘Sindhu’
<>by way of example, a person who is wedded to the theory of
<>the Central Asian origin of Aryan culture cannot but translate
<>the word as river. Obviously, there are no oceans in Central
<>Asia. On the other hand, a scholar who is convinced that the
<>original home of the Aryans as we know them in the Rig Veda
[Page1-ii+ 18]
<>was in the Sapta Sindhav region and who, at the same time,
<>take cognisance of recent researches in the geology of ancient
<>India, will probably be forced to the conclusion that several
<>passages can convey no sensible meaning unless Sindhu is taken
<>to stand for sea.
<P>Quite obviously, the occasions where such sharp differences
<>of interpretation can arise will not be many and Macdonald
<>and Keith's work is still, so far as I am aware, the only standard
<>work of reference on the subject with which it deals. It is a
<>happy sign of the times that there is growing interest in the
<>country in Sanskrit and Sanskrit literature which is a key to
<>our knowledge of the origin of Indian culture, and I am sure
<>the present edition will bring the book within easy reach of a
<>large number of Indian readers who cannot easily find access
<>to it otherwise.
<HS>LUCKNOW,
<>Sept. 2, 1958.
<HS>{@Sampurnanand@}
;
; PREFACE
;
[Page1-iii+ 27]
<H>PREFACE
<P>{@Inception and Progress of the Book.@} — The origination of the
<>present work was due to Professor T. W. Rhys Davids at the
<>time when, several years ago, he was appointed general editor
<>of the Indian Text Series to be published under the auspices
<>of the Secretary of State for India. He then asked me to
<>contribute a work supplying the historical material, as repre-
<>sented by proper names, to be found in the earliest period of
<>Indian literature antecedent to the rise of Buddhism towards
<>the close of the sixth century B.C. Since the subject came
<>within the range of my special studies and moreover appeared
<>to be one of considerable importance, I agreed to the proposal.
<>But I did so with hesitation, because my leisure for a long time
<>to come was already mortgaged by two works which involved
<>much labour and on which I was already engaged. I soon
<>came to the conclusion that till those works — the {%Bṛhaddevatā%}
<>and the {%Vedic Grammar%} — were out of my hands, I could spare
<>no time for the third book, the mere preparation, to say nothing
<>of the publication, of which would thus have to be postponed
<>for several years. Another hindrance would be caused by the
<>tour of study and research in India which I contemplated making
<>at the earliest opportunity. With the prospect of these long
<>delays before me, I was tempted to throw up a task that seemed
<>to have been rashly undertaken. At the same time, I was re-
<>luctant either to abandon or to put off indefinitely what I had
<>once begun. It also seemed a pity to relinquish an enterprise
<>which, if properly carried out, promised to be very useful.
[Page1-vi+ 34]
<NI>Under these circumstances, collaboration appeared the only
<>way out of the difficulty. I bethought myself of Mr. A. B.
<>Keith, who, as Boden Sanskrit scholar, had been my pupil for
<>four years, and who had already assisted me since 1899, not
<>only by reading the proofs of, but by suggesting improvements
<>in, my {%History of Sanskrit Literature%} and my {%Sanskrit Grammar%}
<>{%for Beginners,%} as well as my edition of the {%Bṛhaddevatā,%} then
<>commencing to be printed. I accordingly asked him if he had
<>the time and inclination to collaborate with me in the proposed
<>work by at once beginning to collect material for it. He con-
<>sented without hesitation, and the Secretary of State for India
<>readily sanctioned this modification of the arrangements already
<>made. There was no other man to whom I could have en-
<>trusted with such complete confidence the task of carrying out
<>this preliminary work accurately and rapidly.
<P>In 1909, about a year after my return from India, Mr. Keith
<>supplied me with a considerable part of his collectanea, while
<>my {%Vedic Grammar%} was still passing through the press. The
<>regular printing did not begin till early in 1910, about the time
<>when that work was published. The interval was taken up
<>with preparing a sufficient amount of ‘copy’ for the printer,
<>as well as with settling various questions of arrangement and
<>typography.
<P>{@Mode of Collaboration.@} — Our respective shares in the pro-
<>duction of the book are, generally stated, as follows: Dr. Keith
<>has collected the material, while I have acted chiefly as an
<>editor, planning the scope of the work, arranging the distribu-
<>tion of text and notes, selecting the type to be used, cutting
<>out, adding to or modifying the matter, weighing the evidence
<>for different interpretations and conclusions, and deciding as to
<>which view, in case of possible alternatives, should be preferred.
<>Having written up in its final form every article contained in
<>the book, I accept the responsibility for every statement and
<>opinion expressed in it. I do not think that Dr. Keith and I
<>have disagreed upon any material point. When we have differed
[Page1-vii+ 35]
<>on minor questions, he has deferred to my judgment, though
<>his view may have been right just as often as mine. Where
<>erroneous conclusions have been drawn, the reader will be
<>helped to correct them by the method I have pursued of
<>supplying from the original texts the evidence on which such
<>conclusions are based.
<P>{@Scope of the Work.@} — At the outset it was proposed, as I
<>have already stated, that the book should furnish the historical
<>material in Vedic literature as represented by proper names.
<>As soon, however, as I began to examine more carefully the
<>historical material thus available, I became convinced that
<>restriction to proper names would result in a harvest too
<>meagre to deserve being gathered in the form of a book. It
<>seemed essential to collect all the historical matter accessible
<>to us in the earliest literary documents of India, and thus to
<>furnish a conspectus of the most ancient phase of Aryan
<>civilization that can be realized by direct evidence. If properly
<>and thoroughly treated this matter would, I felt sure, yield a
<>book of genuine value, a comprehensive work on Vedic antiqui-
<>ties; for it would include all the information that can be
<>extracted from Vedic literature on such topics as agriculture,
<>astronomy, burial, caste, clothing, crime, diseases, economic
<>conditions, food and drink, gambling, kingship, law and justice,
<>marriage, morality, occupations, polyandry and polygamy, the
<>position of women, usury, village communities, war, wedding
<>ceremonies, widow burning, witchcraft, and many others. The
<>proper names would embrace not only persons, tribes, and
<>peoples, but also mountains, rivers, and countries. The geo-
<>graphical distribution of the Vedic population would thus also
<>be presented.
<P>From the historical data amplified in this way I proposed,
<>however, to exclude matter belonging to the domain of religion,
<>which it seemed better to relegate to a separate work. At the
<>same time it soon became clear that certain aspects of religious
<>activity inseparably connected with the social and political life
[Page1-viii+ 35]
<>of the age would have to be admitted, such as the functions of
<>the main priests and some festivals or ritual practices. Again,
<>certain names of perhaps purely mythological figures might
<>have to be mentioned. The evidence is occasionally insufficient
<>to show whether a name represents an actual historical person-
<>age: a demon or a mythical hero or priest may be meant. An
<>undoubted demon may even have to be included, such as the
<>one that is supposed to cause eclipses, because he belongs to
<>the domain of primitive astronomy.
<P>{@Chronological Limits.@} — The period which the book was
<>intended to embrace had been decided at the outset as that
<>of the Vedas and Brāhmaṇas. The upper limit here is the date
<>of the oldest hymns of the Rigveda. That date is uncertain, but
<>my conviction (set forth in my {%History of Sanskrit Literature,%}
<>pp. 11-12) that it is not much earlier than 1200 B.C. still remains
<>unshaken. It does not appear to me to be in the slightest degree
<>invalidated by Professor Hugo Winckler's discoveries at Bo-
<>ghaz-köi, in Asia Minor, in the year 1907. That scholar has
<>deciphered, in an inscription of about 1400 B.C. found there, the
<>names of certain deities as {%mi-it-ra, uru-w-na, in-da-ra,%} and {%na-%}
<>{%ša-at-ti-ia,%} which correspond to those of the important Vedic
<>gods Mitra, Varuṇa, Indra, and Nāsatya. Three inferences may
<>be drawn from the occurrence of these names. They may have
<>been derived from Vedic India; in that case the Vedic religion
<>must have flourished in India considerably before 1400 B.C.,
<>even though the hymns that have come down to us may not
<>have been composed before that date. But that these names
<>should have travelled all the way from India to Asia Minor
<>is a hypothesis so highly improbable that it may be dismissed.
<>Secondly, the names may belong to the early Iranian period
<>after the Iranians had separated from the Indians, but before
<>their language had reached the phonetic stage of the Avesta.
<>This seems the most probable theory, both chronologically and
<>geographically. It implies only that the Indian branch had
<>separated from the Iranian, not that it had already entered
[Page1-ix+ 35]
<>India. Lastly, the names, being common to the Iranian and
<>Indian languages, might be assigned to the Indo-Iranian period
<>when the two branches were still one people living in Iran.
<>This theory would still allow two centuries for separation,
<>migration to India, and the commencement of Vedic literature
<>in the north-west of India.
<P>The lower limit of the Vedic period is the epoch of the rise
<>and spread of Buddhism, or, roughly, 500 B.C. The Brāhmaṇa
<>literature to be exploited was assumed to be undoubtedly
<>anterior to that date. The boundary line would, however, to
<>some extent have to be overstepped by drawing on the Sūtras
<>for evidence where the Vedas and Brāhmaṇas fail. But though
<>the Sūtras are roughly contemporaneous with the first three
<>centuries of Buddhism, they are practically an epitome of the
<>practices of the Brāhmaṇa period, and are thus often of great
<>value in illustration or corroboration of the facts of that period.
<>They are also important as representing the Brahminical
<>evidence for those three centuries, especially as it is somewhat
<>uncertain how far even the earliest Buddhist literary sources
<>go back in an authentic form to the three centuries following the
<>death of Buddha. Names and practices not referred to before
<>the Sūtras were, however, to be mentioned only incidentally
<>if at all: the few cases to the contrary that actually occur are
<>not real exceptions, because they are derived from Vedic verses
<>quoted in Sūtras, or from Brāhmaṇa parts of Sūtras such as
<>Baudhāyana.
<P>{@Method Pursued.@} — Such was the scope of the work on which
<>I finally decided before it was begun, and the plan has been
<>adhered to in its execution as regards the contents. The
<>manner in which those contents were to be presented was
<>the next question to be settled and acted upon. Though both
<>Dr. Keith and myself are familiar with the literature of the
<>Vedic period from which the facts collected in these two
<>volumes are drawn, and the mutual check exercised by two
<>workers sifting the same material acts as a safeguard, it is
[Page1-x+ 35]
<>nevertheless not always possible to exclude the risk of error
<>or unconscious bias in estimating evidence often obscure and
<>doubtful. I have, therefore, throughout attached great im-
<>portance to stating not only the evidence of the texts them-
<>selves from a first-hand knowledge, but also to setting forth
<>fully the opinions of other authorities when the interpretation
<>is uncertain. The Sanskrit scholar will thus be enabled to
<>test without difficulty the correctness of the conclusions drawn
<>directly from the original sources, while others will be protected
<>from having to rely exclusively on what may possibly be one-
<>sided views. Articles have often been illustrated by adducing
<>parallels from the institutions of cognate Āryan nations, as that
<>on ‘Caste’ (treated under {@Varṇa,@} ii. 427-471). I have further
<>endeavoured to utilize, chiefly in the notes, knowledge gained
<>from a first-hand study of the archæological remains and of
<>the modern conditions of India. Such knowledge, acquired
<>during my tour in 1907-08, I have found to be of great value
<>to me both as a student and as a teacher.
<P>{@Arrangement.@} — The matter contained in these volumes is
<>treated not in chapters, but in articles disposed in alphabetical
<>order. That order was practically necessary when proper
<>names only were to be included; when subjects were sub-
<>sequently added to the plan, it still remained the most con-
<>venient method of arrangement. As all articles appear under
<>Sanskrit words, the order which the latter follow is naturally
<>that of the Sanskrit alphabet. This arrangement need, how-
<>ever, occasion no inconvenience to those users of the book who
<>are unfamiliar with Sanskrit, because all the information they
<>want can be found by reference to the full English Index at the
<>end of Vol. ii. The Sanskrit Index, which contains, in addition
<>to the terms representing the subjects treated, all incidental
<>Sanskrit words occurring in the articles, is of course arranged
<>in the Sanskrit order. For the purpose of obviating any possible
<>inconvenience, the sequence of the Sanskrit alphabet is given
<>on the last page of this preface. With the same end in view I
[Page1-xi+ 35]
<>have given translations or explanations of all Sanskrit words
<>and expressions, because the latter, though generally clear to
<>Sanskrit scholars, would be unintelligible to others. Compound
<>Sanskrit words have been divided into their component parts by
<>the use of hyphens. In the case of obscure or irregularly formed
<>Sanskrit words, I have sometimes added etymological explana-
<>tions, which may be useful even to the Sanskrit scholar.
<P>I have long had a rooted objection to crowding the letter-
<>press of a book with parentheses containing a string of references
<>or incidental explanations, because these distract the attention
<>of the reader and interfere with his grasping the argument
<>rapidly. I have accordingly in the present work (as in several
<>previous ones) cleared the text of such obstructive matter,
<>relegating references and minor explanations, illustrations, or
<>discussions, to the notes. The sole exceptions are short
<>references consisting of figures only, and occurring in articles
<>of two or three lines in length. Thus, in the article ‘Kauṣārava’
<>(i. 194), the figures (viii. 28) are added in parentheses at the
<>end of the line. To have made a footnote out of these figures
<>alone would have been a pedantic and an absurd application
<>of the general principle.
<P>The {@notes@} are placed in two columns, because this arrange-
<>ment enables the reader to find them more rapidly than any
<>other. They come at the end of, and immediately below, each
<>article. It is only when the article is a long one extending
<>beyond the first page that the notes do not all occupy this
<>position. Those referring to each page are then placed at the
<>foot of that page, and only those referring to the last page come
<>at the end of the article ({%cf., e.g.,%} 1. {@Akṣa@}).
<P>The {@headlines@} are so arranged as to help the reader in finding
<>what he wants quickly, as well as to convey the maximum of
<>information. A glance at the inner corners at the top will
<>show the alphabetical range of the articles occurring in any
<>two pages, the one indicating the first word on the left page,
<>the other the last word on the right page. The rest of the
[Page1-xii+ 35]
<>neadline of each page supplies a summary of the contents of
<>that page. I have never been able to find any rational ex-
<>planation why the title of the book held in one's hand should
<>be printed at the top of at least half, sometimes of all, the
<>pages it contains. How this practice can possibly assist the
<>reader is hard to understand.
<P>{@Typographical Details.@} — Every Sanskrit word used as the
<>title of an article is printed in thick type for the purpose of
<>catching the eye of the reader more readily. Every such word
<>mentioned in another article is on its first occurrence there
<>similarly printed. This is both a simpler and a clearer way of
<>referring to a word used in another place than the employ-
<>ment of parentheses and additional words or abbreviations, like
<>‘see’ or {%‘cf.,’%} which tend to distract the attention of the reader
<>(see, {%e.g.,%} {@Agastya@}). Both Sanskrit names (including titles of
<>books) and ordinary Sanskrit terms used as English words are
<>printed in Roman type, but then always with a capital ({%e.g.,%}
<>Purohita). Italic type is employed for Sanskrit words quoted
<>as such, for expressions from other languages such as Latin or
<>French, for the titles of all except Sanskrit books ({%e.g.,%} Olden-
<>berg, {%Buddha%}), and even of Sanskrit books when a particulal
<>edition is intended (thus Roth, {%Nirukta,%} but Yāska, Nirukta).
<>English words are italicized only when in long articles the
<>titles of subdivisions are given. All these uses of italics will
<>be found exemplified in the articles 2. {@Akṣa@} and 3. {@Akṣa.@}
<P>As regards numerals, Roman figures are employed to indicate
<>the main divisions of a work, the subordinate parts being
<>expressed by Arabic figures. Thus ‘Rigveda, ii. 3, 5,’ means
<>‘book 2, hymn 3, verse 5.’ The volume, on the other hand,
<>is referred to by an Arabic numeral, the following figure
<>indicating the page. Thus ‘Max Müller, {%Ṛgveda,%} 2, 135’
<>means ‘volume 2 of Max Müller's edition of the Rigveda,
<>page 135.’
<P>I have avoided abbreviating the titles of books or journals
<>even when they occur often, or are mentioned in the notes
[Page1-xiii+ 35]
<>only. Contracted titles are as a rule intelligible to the general
<>reader only by reference to an explanatory list appearing at
<>the beginning or the end of a book. When a work is written
<>consecutively, such an abbreviation can be looked up on its
<>first occurrence, and as it is usually met with again at short
<>intervals its explanation will be remembered. But in a book
<>arranged in dictionary form, the occurrence of abridged titles
<>becomes irksome to the reader because he meets them at any
<>part of the book he opens, and often many at the same time;
<>he will probably therefore be continually consulting the ex-
<>planatory list. Hence I have only admitted the contractions
<>‘Rv.’ for Rigveda and ‘Av.’ for Atharvaveda, as these texts are
<>constantly referred to, often several times in the same article.
<>In some works, such as the {%Encyclopœdia of Indo-Āryan Research,%}
<>excessively contracted titles, frequently assuming the appear-
<>ance of algebraic symbols, become necessary owing to the great
<>mass of bibliographical references required. In the present
<>work such economy of space was in no way called for. If,
<>however, the book had been intended for the use of Sanskrit
<>scholars only, I should certainly have shortened many titles
<>here given in full, for there are numerous formulaic abbrevia-
<>tions that are familiar to all specialists.
<P>{@Transliteration.@} — The system here followed is that which
<>has been adopted by the Royal Asiatic Society of Great Britain
<>and Ireland, and is generally employed elsewhere also. The
<>chief difficulties caused to the non-scholar by this method of
<>reproducing Sanskrit words are due, on the one hand, to the
<>inadequacy of the Roman alphabet, which necessitates the use
<>of diacritical marks, and, on the other, to the conventional use
<>of two consonants in English, in certain cases, to represent a
<>single sound, as {%ch, sh, ph,%} and {%th.%} The letter {%ṣ%} here is the
<>equivalent of {%sh%} in ‘shun’; {%ś%} is somewhat thinner in pro-
<>nunciation, like the {%ss%} in ‘session’; {%ṃ%} resembles the {%n%} in the
<>French ‘bon’; and {%ḥ%} the German {%ch%} in ‘ach.’ The palatal {%c%}
<>is to be sounded like the initial {%ch%} in Churchill; {%ch%} has an
[Page1-xiv+ 35]
<>aspirate sound like that of the {%ch%} in the middle of the same
<>word; {%ph%} and {%th%} are also aspirates, as in the English ‘up-hill’
<>and ‘ant-hill’ respectively. The vowels must all be pro-
<>nounced as in Italian: short when unmarked (except {%e%} and {%o,%}
<>which are always long), long when they have a horizontal
<>stroke above; thus {%i%} is sounded as in ‘pin,’ {%ī%} like {%ee%} in ‘seen.’
<>The vowel {%ṛ%} may be pronounced like {%ri%} in ‘risk.’
<P>{@The Map.@} — In order that the reader may be enabled to
<>visualize in a general way the territory known to and occupied
<>by the Vedic tribes, I have prefixed to the first volume a map
<>of Vedic India. Here the home of the Indo-Aryans of the
<>earliest period — that of the Rigveda — is the territory drained
<>by the Indus river system, lying between the 35th and 28th
<>parallel of northern latitude and between 70º and 78º eastern
<>longitude, and corresponding roughly to the North-West
<>Frontier Province and the Panjab of the present day. The
<>eastern limit was probably the Yamunā, though the Ganges
<>was already known. In the subsequent Vedic period — that
<>of the later Vedas and of the Brāhmaṇas — the Indo-Āryan
<>settlers gradually occupied the whole of the Ganges Valley
<>down to the delta of that river. But the home of the fully
<>developed culture of the Brāhmaṇas lay in the territory ex-
<>tending in a south-easterly direction from longitude 74º to
<>85º, between the confluence of the Sarasvatī and Dṛṣadvatī
<>in the west and that of the Sadānīrā and Ganges on the east,
<>and embracing roughly the south-eastern portion of the Panjab
<>and the United Provinces of to-day. East of longitude 85º
<>lay, to the north and south of the Ganges, the imperfectly
<>Brahminized country corresponding to the modern Tirhut and
<>Bihār, where Buddhism arose at the end of the Vedic period.
<P>I ought to warn readers against placing too much reliance
<>on the details of this map, because it is largely conjectural
<>owing to the lack of precise geographical statement in the
<>texts. The student, when using it, should always refer to the
<>evidence furnished by the articles under each name that appears
[Page1-xv+ 35]
<>on the map. The identification of many of the Vedic rivers
<>with those of modern India is certain; but even here the exact
<>channels in which they flowed in ancient times is doubtful.
<>Thus the Indus, some of the Panjab rivers, and the old
<>Sarasvatī have been shown by Raverty, in an article in the
<>{%Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal%} for 1892, to have changed
<>their courses considerably, even within historical times. It
<>must be remembered that all the rivers of Vedic India traversed
<>the alluvial plains of the north, and were, therefore, unlike the
<>rivers of the Deccan, which flow in rocky beds, liable to constant
<>fluctuations in their channels. Again, the Vedic tribes are
<>nearly always mentioned so vaguely in the texts that they can
<>only be approximately located by the rivers with which they
<>are connected, or by the way in which their names are asso-
<>ciated or grouped. Many such names had to be omitted
<>altogether in the map because of the total lack of evidence
<>for their localization. Some help may be obtained from the
<>geographical position in the post-Vedic period of tribes men-
<>tioned in Vedic literature. But this evidence is apt to be
<>doubtful, because the Vedic period was largely one of migra-
<>tion, and various tribes may then have occupied localities
<>much farther north or west than those in which they were
<>later permanently settled. The general evidence of the map,
<>however uncertain many of the details may be, leaves no room
<>for doubt as to the route by which the Āryans entered India,
<>or as to the direction of the successive stages of the migration
<>by which they eventually spread their civilization over the
<>whole of the peninsula.
<P>{@Conclusion.@} — The first volume was ready for issue more than
<>a year ago, but to publish it without the indexes, which would
<>necessarily have to appear at the end of the second volume,
<>seemed to me to be perfectly useless. I therefore preferred
<>to wait till the whole book could be brought out in a complete
<>form. As both Dr. Keith and myself have each read one proof
<>and nearly always two revises of every sheet before it went to
[Page1-xvi+ 12]
<>press, all but trivial errors and misprints ought to have been
<>eliminated. I hope, however, that these two volumes will
<>prove to be not only correct in form, but also valuable in
<>matter, after our joint efforts to bring together and present
<>their contents in a convenient and trustworthy manner.
<HS>A.A. MACDONELL.
<>OXFORD,
<>{%July%} 18, 1912.

<L>1878<pc>2-002<k1>puruzanti<k2>puruzanti
{@Puruṣanti@}¦ is a name that occurs twice in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>the first passage denoting a protégé of the Aśvins, in the second
<div n="lb"/>a patron who gave presents to one of the Vedic singers. In
<div n="lb"/>both cases the name is joined with that of {@Dhvasanti@} or
<div n="lb"/>{@Dhvasra.@} The presumption from the manner in which these
<div n="lb"/>three names are mentioned is that they designate men, but the
<div n="lb"/>grammatical form of the words might equally well be feminine.
<div n="lb"/>Females must be meant, if the evidence of the Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> is to be taken as decisive, for the form of the first
<div n="lb"/>of the two names there occurring, {%Dhvasre Puruṣantī,%} ‘Dhvasrā
<div n="lb"/>and Puruṣanti,’ is exclusively feminine, though {@here@} as well as
<div n="lb"/>elsewhere Sāyaṇa<sup>3</sup> interprets the names as masculines. See
<div n="lb"/>also {@Taranta@} and {@Purumīḷha.@}
<F>1) i. 112, 23; ix. 58, 3.</F>
<F>2) xiii. 7, 12. Roth thinks the feminine
<div n="lb"/>form {%Dhvasre%} here is a corruption, based
<div n="lb"/>on the dual form occurring in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, {%Dhvasrayoḥ,%} which might be
<div n="lb"/>feminine as well as masculine.</F>
<F>3) Also on the Śāṭyāyanaka, cited
<div n="lb"/>on Rv. ix. 58, 3, and on Rv. i. 112,
<div n="lb"/>23.

<L>1880<pc>2-003<k1>purUravas<k2>purUravas
{@Purū-ravas@}¦ is the name of a hero in a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>containing a curious dialogue between him and a nymph,
<div n="lb"/>Urvaśī, an Apsaras. He is also mentioned in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> where several verses of the Rigvedic dialogue find
<div n="lb"/>a setting in a continuous story. In the later literature he is
<div n="lb"/>recognized as a king.<sup>3</sup> His name is perhaps intended in one
<div n="lb"/>other passage of the Rigveda.<sup>4</sup> It is impossible to say whether
<div n="lb"/>he is a mythical figure pure and simple, or really an ancient
<div n="lb"/>king. His epithet, Aiḷa,<sup>5</sup> ‘descendant of Iḍā’ (a sacrificial
<div n="lb"/>goddess), is certainly in favour of the former alternative.
<F>1) x. 95.</F>
<F>2) xi. 5, 1, 1. {%Cf.%} iii. 4, 1, 22; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, viii. 10; Nirukta, x. 46.</F>

<div n="lb"/>283 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) i. 31, 4.</F>

<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 196;

<L>1888<pc>2-005<k1>purohita<k2>purohita
{@Puro-hita@}¦ (‘placed in front,’ ‘appointed’) is the name of a
<div n="lb"/>priest in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> The office of Purohita is
<div n="lb"/>called Purohiti<sup>3</sup> and {@Purodhā.@} It is clear that the primary
<div n="lb"/>function of the Purohita was that of ‘domestic priest’ of a
<div n="lb"/>king, or perhaps a great noble; his quite exceptional position
<div n="lb"/>is shown by the fact that only one Purohita seems ever to be
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in Vedic literature.<sup>4</sup> Examples of Purohitas in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda are {@Viśvāmitra@}<sup>5</sup> or {@Vasiṣṭha@}<sup>6</sup> in the service of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Bharata@} king; {@Sudās,@} of the {@Tṛtsu@} family; the Purohita of
<div n="lb"/>{@Kuruśravaṇa;@}<sup>7</sup> and {@Devāpi,@} the Purohita of {@Śantanu.@}<sup>8</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Purohita was in all religious matters the {%alter ego%} of the king.
<div n="lb"/>In the ritual<sup>9</sup> it is laid down that a king must have a Purohita,
<div n="lb"/>else the gods will not accept his offerings. He ensures the
<div n="lb"/>king's safety and victory in battle by his prayers;<sup>10</sup> he procures
[Page2-006+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>the fall of rain for the crops;<sup>11</sup> he is the flaming fire that
<div n="lb"/>guards the kingdom.<sup>12</sup> Divodāsa in trouble is rescued by
<div n="lb"/>Bharadvāja;<sup>13</sup> and King {@Tryaruṇa Traidhātva Aikṣvāka@}
<div n="lb"/>reproaches his Purohita, {@Vṛśa Jāna,@} when his car runs over
<div n="lb"/>a Brahmin boy and kills him.<sup>14</sup> The close relation of king and
<div n="lb"/>Purohita is illustrated by the case of {@Kutsa Aurava,@} who slew
<div n="lb"/>his Purohita, {@Upagu Sauśravasa,@} for disloyalty in serving
<div n="lb"/>Indra, to whom Kutsa was hostile.<sup>15</sup> Other disputes between
<div n="lb"/>kings and priests who officiated for them are those of {@Janam-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@ejaya@} and the {@Kaśyapas,@} and of {@Viśvantara@} and the {@Śyā-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@parṇas;@}<sup>16</sup> and between {@Asamāti@} and the {@Gaupāyanas.@}<sup>17</sup> In
<div n="lb"/>some cases one Purohita served more than one king; for
<div n="lb"/>example, {@Devabhāga Śrautarṣa@} was the Purohita of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Kurus@} and the {@Sṛṅjayas@} at the same time,<sup>18</sup> and {@Jala Jātū-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@karṇya@} was the Purohita of the kings of {@Kāśi, Videha,@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Kosala.@}<sup>19</sup>
<div n="P"/>There is no certain proof that the office of Purohita was
<div n="lb"/>hereditary in a family, though it probably was so.<sup>20</sup> At any
<div n="lb"/>rate, it seems clear from the relations of the Purohita with
<div n="lb"/>King {@Kuruśravaṇa,@} and with his son {@Upamaśravas,@}<sup>21</sup> that a
<div n="lb"/>king would keep on the Purohita of his father.
<div n="P"/>Zimmer<sup>22</sup> thinks that the king might act as his own Purohita,
<div n="lb"/>as shown by the case of King Viśvantara, who sacrificed with-
<div n="lb"/>out the help of the Śyāparṇas,<sup>23</sup> and that a Purohita need not
<div n="lb"/>be a priest, as shown by the case of Devāpi and Śantanu.<sup>24</sup>
<div n="lb"/>But neither opinion seems to be justified. It is not said that
[Page2-007+ 63]
<div n="lb"/>Viśvantara sacrificed without priests, while Devāpi is not
<div n="lb"/>regarded as a king until the Nirukta,<sup>25</sup> and there is no
<div n="lb"/>reason to suppose that Yāska's view expressed in that work
<div n="lb"/>is correct.
<div n="P"/>According to Geldner,<sup>26</sup> the Purohita from the beginning
<div n="lb"/>acted as the Brahman priest in the sacrificial ritual, being
<div n="lb"/>there the general superintendent of the sacrifice. In favour of
<div n="lb"/>this view, he cites the fact that Vasiṣṭha is mentioned both as
<div n="lb"/>Purohita<sup>27</sup> and as Brahman:<sup>28</sup> at the sacrifice of {@Śunaḥśepa@} he
<div n="lb"/>served as Brahman,<sup>29</sup> but he was the Purohita of Sudās;<sup>30</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhaspati is called the Purohita<sup>31</sup> and the Brahman<sup>32</sup> of the
<div n="lb"/>gods; and the Vasiṣṭhas who are Purohitas are also the Brah-
<div n="lb"/>mans at the sacrifice.<sup>33</sup> It is thus clear that the Brahman was
<div n="lb"/>often the Purohita; and it was natural that this should be the
<div n="lb"/>case when once the Brahman's place became, as it did in the
<div n="lb"/>later ritual, the most important position at the sacrifice.<sup>34</sup> But
<div n="lb"/>the Brahman can hardly be said to have held this place in the
<div n="lb"/>earlier ritual; Oldenberg<sup>35</sup> seems to be right in holding that
<div n="lb"/>the Purohita was originally the Hotṛ priest, the singer {%par%}
<div n="lb"/>{%excellence,%} when he took any part at all in the ritual of the great
<div n="lb"/>sacrifices with the {@Ṛtvijs.@} So Devāpi seems clearly to have
[Page2-008+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>been a Hotṛ;<sup>36</sup> Agni is at once Purohita<sup>37</sup> and Hotṛ;<sup>38</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>‘two divine Hotṛs’ referred to in the Āprī litanies are also
<div n="lb"/>called the ‘two Purohitas.’<sup>39</sup> Later, no doubt, when the
<div n="lb"/>priestly activity ceased to centre in the song, the Purohita, with
<div n="lb"/>his skill in magic, became the Brahman, who also required
<div n="lb"/>magic to undo the errors of the sacrifice.<sup>40</sup>
<div n="P"/>There is little doubt that in the original growth of the priest-
<div n="lb"/>hood the Purohita played a considerable part. In historical
<div n="lb"/>times he represented the real power of the kingship, and may
<div n="lb"/>safely be deemed to have exercised great influence in all public
<div n="lb"/>affairs, such as the administration of justice and the king's
<div n="lb"/>conduct of business. But it is not at all probable that the
<div n="lb"/>Purohita represents, as Roth<sup>41</sup> and Zimmer<sup>42</sup> thought, the
<div n="lb"/>source which gave rise to caste. The priestly class is already
<div n="lb"/>in existence in the Rigveda (see {@Varṇa@}).
<F>1) i. 1, 1; 44, 10. 12; ii. 24, 9; iii. 2, 8;
<div n="lb"/>3, 2; v. 11, 2; vi. 70, 4, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. viii. 5, 5; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>ix. 23; xi. 81; xxxi. 20; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, viii. 24, etc.; Nirukta,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 12; vii. 15.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 60, 12; 83, 4.</F>
<F>4) Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 144,
<div n="lb"/>thinks that several Purohitas were
<div n="lb"/>possible, quoting Sāyaṇa, on Rv. x. 57, 1,
<div n="lb"/>who gives the tale of the Gaupāyanas
<div n="lb"/>and King Asamāti from the Śāṭyāya-
<div n="lb"/>naka, and comparing the case of
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭha and Viśvāmitra as Purohitas,
<div n="lb"/>probably contemporaneously, of Sudās.
<div n="lb"/>But that the two were contemporaneous
<div n="lb"/>is most unlikely, especially if we adopt
<div n="lb"/>the very probable view of Hopkins
<div n="lb"/>({%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>15, 260 {%et seq.%}) that Viśvāmitra was
<div n="lb"/>with the ten kings (Rv. vii. 18) when
<div n="lb"/>they unsuccessfully attacked Sudās.
<div n="lb"/>The other narrative has, as Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Religion des Veda,%} 375, n. 3, observes,
<div n="lb"/>a markedly fictitious character; while
<div n="lb"/>every other passage that mentions a
<div n="lb"/>Purohita speaks of him in the singular,
<div n="lb"/>and as there was only one Brahman
<div n="lb"/>priest at the sacrifice, so the Purohita
<div n="lb"/>acted as Brahman.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 2, 150, 184.</F>

<F>10) See Av. iii. 19; Rv. vii. 18, 13,
<div n="lb"/>from which Geldner, {%op. cit.,%} 2, 135,

<L>1894<pc>2-009<k1>puzkara<k2>puzkara
{@Puṣkara@}¦ is the name in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> of the blue
<div n="lb"/>lotus flower. The Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> mentions its sweet perfume.
<div n="lb"/>The lotus grew in lakes, which were thence called {%puṣkariṇī,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘lotus-bearing.’<sup>4</sup> That the flower was early used for personal
<div n="lb"/>adornment is shown by an epithet of the Aśvins, ‘lotus-
<div n="lb"/>crowned’ ({%puṣkara-sraj%}).<sup>5</sup>
<div n="P"/>Presumably because of its likeness in shape to the flower
<div n="lb"/>of the lotus, the bowl of the ladle is called Puṣkara, perhaps
<div n="lb"/>already in the Rigveda,<sup>6</sup> and certainly in the Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa.<sup>7</sup> Moreover, according to the Nirukta,<sup>8</sup> Puṣkara means
<div n="lb"/>‘water,’ a sense actually found in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>9</sup>
<F>1) vi. 16, 13; vii. 33, 11, may be so
<div n="lb"/>taken, though Roth, St. Petersburg
<div n="lb"/>Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 3, and Geldner, {%Rigveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Glossar,%} 112, prefer to see in these
<div n="lb"/>passages a reference to the bowl of the
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial ladle.</F>
<F>2) Av. xi. 3, 8; xii. 1, 24; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, v. 1, 4, 1; 2, 6, 5; 6, 4, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 29; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 2, 1, 4; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iv. 5, 1, 16; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 5.</F>
<F>3) Av. xii. 1, 24.</F>
<F>4) Rv. v. 78, 7; x. 107, 10; Av.
<div n="lb"/>iv. 34, 5; v. 16, 17; Bṛhadāraṇyaka
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, iv. 3, 11, etc.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 184, 2; Av. iii. 22, 4; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, iv. 1, 5, 16, etc.</F>
<F>6) Rv. viii 72, 11, where the sense is
<div n="lb"/>doubtful, and the bowl of the ladle is
<div n="lb"/>not particularly appropriate. See also
<div n="lb"/>note 1.</F>
<F>7) vii. 5.</F>
<F>8) v. 14.</F>

<L>1904<pc>2-011<k1>pUru<k2>pUru
{@Pūru@}¦ is the name of a people and their king in the Rigveda.
<div n="lb"/>They are mentioned with the {@Anus, Druhyus, Turvaśas,@}
<div n="lb"/>and {@Yadus@} in one passage.<sup>1</sup> They also occur as enemies of
<div n="lb"/>the {@Tṛtsus@} in the hymn of {@Sudās’@} victory.<sup>2</sup> In another
[Page2-012+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>hymn<sup>3</sup> Agni of the {@Bharatas@} is celebrated as victorious over the
<div n="lb"/>Pūrus, probably a reference to the same decisive overthrow.
<div n="lb"/>On the other hand, victories of the Pūrus over the aborigines
<div n="lb"/>seem to be referred to in several passages.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>The great kings of the Pūrus were {@Purukutsa@} and his son
<div n="lb"/>{@Trasadasyu,@} whose name bears testimony to his prowess
<div n="lb"/>against aboriginal foes, while a later prince was {@Tṛkṣi Trāsa-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@dasyava.@}
<div n="P"/>In the Rigveda the Pūrus are expressly<sup>5</sup> mentioned as on
<div n="lb"/>the {@Sarasvatī.@} Zimmer<sup>6</sup> thinks that the {@Sindhu@} (Indus) is
<div n="lb"/>meant in this passage. But Ludwig<sup>7</sup> and Hillebrandt<sup>8</sup> with
<div n="lb"/>much greater probability think that the eastern Sarasvatī in
<div n="lb"/>Kurukṣetra is meant. This view accords well with the sudden
<div n="lb"/>disappearance of the name of the Pūrus from Vedic tradition,
<div n="lb"/>a disappearance accounted for by Oldenberg's<sup>9</sup> conjecture that
<div n="lb"/>the Pūrus became part of the great Kuru people, just as
<div n="lb"/>{@Turvaśa@} and {@Krivi@} disappear from the tradition on their being
<div n="lb"/>merged in the {@Pañcāla@} nation. Trāsadasyava, the patronymic
<div n="lb"/>of {@Kuruśravaṇa@} in the Rigveda,<sup>10</sup> shows that the royal
<div n="lb"/>families of the Kurus and the Pūrus were allied by inter-
<div n="lb"/>marriage.
<div n="P"/>Hillebrandt,<sup>11</sup> admitting that the Pūrus in later times lived
<div n="lb"/>in the eastern country round the Sarasvatī, thinks that in
<div n="lb"/>earlier days they were to be found to the west of the Indus
<div n="lb"/>with {@Divodāsa.@} This theory must fall with the theory that
<div n="lb"/>Divodāsa was in the far west. It might, however, be held to
<div n="lb"/>be supported by the fact that Alexander found a <lang n="greek"></lang> — that
<div n="lb"/>is, a Paurava prince on the Hydaspes,<sup>12</sup> a sort of half-way
<div n="lb"/>locality between the Sarasvatī and the West. But it is quite
<div n="lb"/>simple to suppose either that the Hydaspes was the earlier
<div n="lb"/>home of the Pūrus, where some remained after the others had
[Page2-013+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>wandered east, or that the later Paurava represents a success-
<div n="lb"/>ful onslaught upon the west from the east.
<div n="P"/>In several other passages of the Rigveda<sup>13</sup> the Pūrus as a
<div n="lb"/>people seem to be meant. The Nirukta<sup>14</sup> recognizes the general
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘man,’ but in no passage is this really necessary or
<div n="lb"/>even probable. So utterly, however, is the tradition lost that
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>15</sup> explains Pūru in the Rigveda<sup>16</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>an Asura Rakṣas; it is only in the Epic that Pūru revives as
<div n="lb"/>the name of a son of Yayāti and Śarmiṣṭhā.<sup>17</sup>
<F>1) i. 108. 8.</F>
<F>2) vii. 18, 13. {%Cf.%} {@Turvaśa.@} Ap-
<div n="lb"/>parently, as Hopkins, {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%American Oriental Society,%} 15, 263, n.,
<div n="lb"/>and Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 135,
<div n="lb"/>think, in this verse the words {%jeṣma%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Pūruṃ vidathe mṛdhravācam%} refer to the
<div n="lb"/>Pūru king and to the priest {@Viśvāmitra,@}
<div n="lb"/>who prayed for the defeat of Sudās,
<div n="lb"/>though in vain. Hopkins seems to take
<div n="lb"/>the words {%vidathe mṛdhravācam%} generally
<div n="lb"/>as ‘the false speaker in the assembly’;
<div n="lb"/>but, according to Geldner, the meaning
<div n="lb"/>intended is that, while the king fought,
<div n="lb"/>the Purohita prayed in the Sabhā, or
<div n="lb"/>meeting house of the people.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 8, 4.</F>
<F>4) i. 59, 6; 131, 4; 174, 2; iv. 21, 10;
<div n="lb"/>38, 1; vi. 20, 10; vii. 5, 3; 19, 3.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} note 13.</F>
<F>5) vii. 96, 2. Perhaps they are also
<div n="lb"/>meant as living on the Śaryaṇāvant in
<div n="lb"/>Rv. viii. 64, 10. 11.</F>
<F>6) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 124.</F>
<F>7) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 175.</F>
<F>8) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 50, 115;
<div n="lb"/>3, 374.</F>
<F>9) {%Buddha,%} 404. {%Cf.%} Ludwig, 3, 205.</F>
<F>10) x. 33, 4.</F>
<F>11) {%Op. cit.,%} 1, 114 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>12) Arrian, {%Indica,%} viii. 4; ix. 1; xix.
<div n="lb"/>3, etc. See Hillebrandt, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Mythologie,%} 1, 132, 133.</F>
<F>13) In Rv. i. 36, 1, {%Pūrūṇām%} might be
<div n="lb"/>read for {%purūṇām,%} with improvement
<div n="lb"/>in the sense. In i. 63, 7, there is a
<div n="lb"/>reference to the Pūru king, Purukutsa,
<div n="lb"/>and Sudās, but in what relation is
<div n="lb"/>uncertain (see {@Purukutsa@}). In i. 130, 7.
<div n="lb"/>the Pūru king and Divodāsa Atithigva
<div n="lb"/>are both mentioned, apparently as
<div n="lb"/>victorious over aboriginal foes. See
<div n="lb"/>also i. 129, 5; iv. 39, 2; v. 17, 1;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 46, 8; x. 4, 1; 48, 5.</F>
<F>14) vii. 23; Naighaṇṭuka, ii. 3.</F>
<F>15) vi. 8, 1, 14.</F>
<F>16) vii. 8, 4.</F>
<F>17) Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1910, 26, etc. {%Cf.%} Hillebrandt,
<div n="lb"/>{%op. cit.,%} 1, 110 {%et seq.;%} Max Müller,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 398.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1908<pc>2-013<k1>pUrpati<k2>pUrpati
{@Pūr-pati,@}¦ ‘lord of the fort,’ occurring only once in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is of somewhat doubtful interpretation. The term-
[Page2-014+ 41]
<div n="lb"/>may denote a regular office,<sup>2</sup> similar to that of the {@Grāmaṇī:@}
<div n="lb"/>the {@Pur@} would then be a permanently occupied settlement.
<div n="lb"/>The expression may, however, merely mean the chief over a
<div n="lb"/>fort when it was actually occupied against hostile attack. The
<div n="lb"/>rarity of the word seems to favour the latter sense.
<F>1) i. 173. 10.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} Sāyaṇa's note, on Rv. i. 173,
<div n="lb"/>10; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 456.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 204.</F>

<L>1920<pc>2-016<k1>pfTi<k2>pfTi
{@Pṛthi,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Pṛthī,@}<sup>2</sup> or {@Pṛthu@}<sup>3</sup> is the name of a semi-mythical
<div n="lb"/>personage who is mentioned in the Rigveda and later as a Ṛṣi,
<div n="lb"/>and more specially as the inventor of agriculture<sup>4</sup> and the lord
<div n="lb"/>of both worlds, of men and of animals.<sup>5</sup> He bears in several
<div n="lb"/>passages<sup>6</sup> the epithet Vainya, ‘descendant of Vena,’ and must
<div n="lb"/>probably be regarded as a culture hero rather than as a real
<div n="lb"/>man. According to other accounts,<sup>7</sup> he was the first of con-
<div n="lb"/>secrated kings. {%Cf.%} {@Pārthiva.@}
<F>1) Rv. i. 112, 15, as a seer; as Vainya,
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 7, 4, and
<div n="lb"/>perhaps ii. 7, 5, 1 ({%Pṛthaye%}).</F>
<F>2) As Vainya, Rv. viii. 9, 10; Av. viii.
<div n="lb"/>10, 24; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 5,
<div n="lb"/>19; as Pṛthi or Pṛthī, Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ii. 7, 5, 1; as Vainya, Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, v. 3, 5, 4; Kāṭhaka Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, xxxvii. 4 ({%Indische Studien,%} 3, 463).
<div n="lb"/>Venya mentioned with Pṛthī in Rv.
<div n="lb"/>x. 148, 5, may be meant for his patro-
<div n="lb"/>nymic (= Vainya): {%cf.%} {@Tugrya,@} n. 1.</F>
<F>3) Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 186 ({%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the American Oriental Society,%} 19, 125);
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 10, 9;
<div n="lb"/>34, 6; 45, 1.</F>

<F>5) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, {%loc. cit.%}

<F>6) See notes 1-3.</F>
<F>7) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, {%loc. cit.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, {%loc. cit.;%} Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 7, 4.

<div n="lb"/>{%disches Leben,%} 134. Eggeling, {%Sacred Books%}

<L>1921<pc>2-016<k1>pfTivI<k2>pfTivI
{@Pṛthivī@}¦ denotes the ‘earth’ as the ‘broad’ one in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later,<sup>2</sup> being often personified as a deity<sup>3</sup> both alone and

<div n="lb"/>the ‘firstborn of being,’ and its riches ({%vitta%}) are referred to;<sup>10</sup>

<L>1932<pc>2-019<k1>pfzatI<k2>pfzatI
{@Pṛṣatī@}¦ in some passages<sup>1</sup> clearly means a ‘speckled’ cow.
<div n="lb"/>The term is, however, generally<sup>2</sup> applied to the team of the
<div n="lb"/>Maruts, when its sense is doubtful. The commentators usually
<div n="lb"/>explain it as ‘speckled antelope.’ But Mahīdhara,<sup>3</sup> followed by
<div n="lb"/>Roth,<sup>4</sup> prefers to see in it a ‘dappled mare’: it is true that the
<div n="lb"/>Maruts are often called<sup>5</sup> {%pṛṣad-aśva,%} which is more naturally
<div n="lb"/>interpreted as ‘having dappled steeds,’ than as ‘having Pṛṣatīs
<div n="lb"/>as steeds.’<sup>6</sup> In the later literature, which Grassmann<sup>7</sup> prefers
<div n="lb"/>to follow, the word means the female of the dappled gazelle.
[Page2-020+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>Aufrecht<sup>8</sup> concurs in the view of Roth, but Max Müller<sup>9</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>inclined to accept the traditional interpretation, while Muir<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>leaves the matter open.
<F>1) Rv. viii. 64, 10. 11, where ‘deer’
<div n="lb"/>is nonsense, and ‘mares’ is improb-
<div n="lb"/>able. The regular donation is ‘cows’;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xii. 2; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, v. 5, 2, 9 (see Eggeling,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 41, 125);
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 2 (though
<div n="lb"/>this is not certain); Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xv. 14, 23, etc.</F>

<L>1938<pc>2-021<k1>petva<k2>petva
{@Petva@}¦ is found twice in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> In the first
<div n="lb"/>passage reference is made to its {%vāja,%} which Zimmer<sup>2</sup> argues
<div n="lb"/>can only mean ‘strength,’ ‘swiftness,’ though naturally the
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘male power’ would seem more appropriate in a spell
<div n="lb"/>intended to remove lack of virility. In the second passage the
<div n="lb"/>Petva is mentioned as overcoming the horse (see {@Ubhayādant@}),
<div n="lb"/>a miracle which has a parallel in the Rigveda,<sup>3</sup> where the
<div n="lb"/>Petva overcomes the female<sup>4</sup> lion. The animal also occurs in
<div n="lb"/>the list of victims at the Aśvamedha (‘horse sacrifice’) in the
<div n="lb"/>Yajurveda Saṃhitās,<sup>5</sup> and occasionally elsewhere.<sup>6</sup> It appears
<div n="lb"/>to be the ‘ram’ or the ‘wether,’ the latter<sup>7</sup> being the sense
<div n="lb"/>given to it by the commentator on the Taittirīya Saṃhitā.
<div n="lb"/>But there is no conclusive evidence in favour of this meaning,
<div n="lb"/>while on the whole the passage of the Atharvaveda, in which
<div n="lb"/>{%vāja%} is found, accords best with the sense of ‘ram.’ Hopkins,<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>however, renders the word as ‘goat,’ though for what reason is
<div n="lb"/>not clear. Whether it is connected in any way with {@Pitva@} or
<div n="lb"/>{@Pidva@} is quite uncertain.
<F>1) iv. 4, 8; v. 19, 2.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 229, 230.</F>
<F>3) vii. 18, 17.</F>
<F>4) {%Siṃhyam%} in the text. Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>15, 264, takes it as masculine, and as
<div n="lb"/>a play on {%śiṃyum,%} the name of one of
<div n="lb"/>the kings or peoples defeated in the
<div n="lb"/>battle of the ten kings. But, admitting
<div n="lb"/>the play, {%siṃhī%} as fem. seems to be still
<div n="lb"/>more pointed than {%siṃha,%} contrasting
<div n="lb"/>with the masculine {%petva.%}</F>
<F>5) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 22; 1.
<div n="lb"/>Though not in the parallel passage of
<div n="lb"/>the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, it appears to
<div n="lb"/>be found in the Kāṭhaka, according
<div n="lb"/>to Weber's note in his edition of the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā.</F>
<F>6) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 8, 4;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 58. 59;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 2, 5, 3. etc.</F>
<F>7) {%Galita-retasko meṣaḥ.%}</F>
<F>8) {%Loc. cit.; India, Old and New,%} 58.
<div n="lb"/>He thinks the born of the goat pierced
<div n="lb"/>the lion. Curiously enough, Whitney,
<div n="lb"/>Translation of the Atharvaveda, 253.
<div n="lb"/>renders the word a ‘goat’ in Av.
<div n="lb"/>v. 19, 2, but (p. 151) as ‘ram’ in iv. 4, 8;
<div n="lb"/>and Bloomfield {%Hymns of the Atharva-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%veda,%} 434, speaks Both of a ‘ram’ and a
<div n="lb"/>‘goat’ in connexion with v. 19, 2.</F>

<L>1941<pc>2-022<k1>pesas<k2>pesas
{@Pesas@}¦ denotes in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> an embroidered
<div n="lb"/>garment such as a female dancer would wear.<sup>3</sup> The fondness
<div n="lb"/>of the Indians for such raiment is noted by Megasthenes<sup>4</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>by Arrian,<sup>5</sup> who refer to their <lang n="greek"></lang>. So in one
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>6</sup> a garment ({%vastra%}) is called {%peśana,%} with which Roth<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>happily compares the Roman {%vestis coloribus intexta.%} The
<div n="lb"/>making of such garments was a regular occupation of women,
<div n="lb"/>as is indicated by the Peśas-kārī, the ‘female embroiderer,’
<div n="lb"/>figuring in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda,<sup>8</sup> though the, commentator on the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa interprets the word as ‘wife of a maker
<div n="lb"/>of gold.’<sup>9</sup> Pischel,<sup>10</sup> however, thinks that Peśas never means
<div n="lb"/>anything but colour or form.
<F>1) ii. 3, 6; iv. 36, 7; vii. 34, 11; 42, 1.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 82. 89;
<div n="lb"/>xx. 40; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 19, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 92, 4. 5.</F>
<F>4) See Štrabo, p. 509, where he refers
<div n="lb"/>to a <lang n="greek"></lang>.</F>
<F>5) {%Indica,%} 5, 9.</F>
<F>6) Rv. x. 1, 6.</F>
<F>7) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>8) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 9; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 5, 1.</F>
<F>9) {%Cf.%} perhaps {%suvarṇaṃ hiraṇyaṃ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%peśalam%} in the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 3, 4, 5, where {%peśala%} probably refers
<div n="lb"/>to cunningly-worked gold. But this
<div n="lb"/>does not suit the compound {%peśas-kārī,%}
<div n="lb"/>which must denote a ‘maker of {%peśas,%}’
<div n="lb"/>and {%peśas%} has not the sense of wrought
<div n="lb"/>gold in any passage. {%Cf.%} also Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iv. 4, 5; Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 261.</F>

<L>1946<pc>2-024<k1>pEjavana<k2>pEjavana
{@Paijavana,@}¦ ‘descendant of {@Pijavana,@}’ is the patronymic of
<div n="lb"/>{@Sudās.@}<sup>1</sup> It seems most probable that Pijavana intervened in
<div n="lb"/>the line of succession between {@Divodāsa@} and Sudās, because
<div n="lb"/>the two kings have, according to tradition, quite different
<div n="lb"/>Purohitas, the former being served by the {@Bharadvājas@} as his
<div n="lb"/>priests, the latter by {@Vasiṣṭha@} and {@Viśvāmitra;@}<sup>2</sup> this is more
<div n="lb"/>natural if they were divided by a period of time than if they had
<div n="lb"/>been, as is usually supposed, father and son. Geldner,<sup>3</sup> how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, identifies Divodāsa and Pijavana.
<F>1) Rv. vii. 18, 22. 25; Nirukta, ii. 24.
<div n="lb"/>25; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 34;
<div n="lb"/>Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xvi. 11, 14.</F>

<div n="lb"/>1, 104 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Rigveda, Glossar,%} 115.</F>

<L>1948<pc>2-024<k1>potf<k2>potf
{@Potṛ@}¦ is the name of one of the priests ({@Ṛtvij@}) of the sacri-
<div n="lb"/>ficial ritual. Already known to the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> he is frequently
<div n="lb"/>mentioned later in the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>2</sup> But as Oldenberg<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>observes, the Potṛ is not in the later literature a priest of any
<div n="lb"/>importance, but is practically a mere name. Judging by the
<div n="lb"/>derivation of the name from the root {%pū,%} ‘purify,’ it would
<div n="lb"/>seem that he was properly engaged in the purification of the
<div n="lb"/>{%Soma pavamāna,%} ‘Soma purifying itself,’ and was perhaps
<div n="lb"/>employed to sing hymns to this Soma. Potra<sup>4</sup> denotes both
<div n="lb"/>the office and the Soma vessel of the Potṛ.<sup>5</sup>
<F>1) i. 94, 6; ii. 5, 2; iv. 9, 3; vii. 16, 5;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 67, 22.</F>
<F>2) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vi. 10 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, iv. 3, 4, 22;
<div n="lb"/>v. 4, 5, 22; xii. 1, 1, 8, etc.</F>
<F>3) {%Religien des Veda,%} 383, 391, 395.</F>
<F>4) Rv. ii. 1, 2, and probably i. 76, 4,
<div n="lb"/>though the St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.,%} gives this as an example of the
<div n="lb"/>second use.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 15, 2; ii. 36, 2; 37, 2. 4.</F>

<L>1953<pc>2-025<k1>pOtakrata<k2>pOtakrata

<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, arguing that in the same hymn Pūtakratāyī, the
<div n="lb"/>wife of Pūtakratu, is referred to, and that therefore Pūtakratu
<div n="lb"/>is appropriate, Pūtakratāyī<sup>3</sup> being the feminine, like Manāyī,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>for Manāvī. But the ordinary reading in the sense of descendant
<div n="lb"/>is perfectly legitimate, as Oldenberg<sup>5</sup> has pointed out.
<F>1) viii. 56, 2.</F>
<F>2) {%Die Apokryphen des Ṛgveda,%} 41, 42.</F>
<F>3) See Pāṇini, iv. 1, 36.</F>
<F>4) Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 8, 6; Pāṇini,
<div n="lb"/>iv. 1, 38. Perhaps also Vasāvī, Rv.
<div n="lb"/>x. 73, 4.</F>
<F>5) {%Göttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,%} 1907,
<div n="lb"/>237.</F>
<LEND>

<L>1963<pc>2-027<k1>pOlkasa<k2>pOlkasa
{@Paulkasa@}¦ is the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣa-
<div n="lb"/>medha (‘human sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda.<sup>1</sup> The name also
<div n="lb"/>occurs in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>2</sup> as that of a despised
<div n="lb"/>race of men, together with the Cāṇḍāla. The Maitrāyaṇī

<div n="lb"/>as Pulkasa, of which Paulkasa is a derivative form, showing
<div n="lb"/>that a caste is meant ({%cf.%} {@Kaulāla, Pauñjiṣṭha@}). In the accepted
<div n="lb"/>theory<sup>4</sup> the Pulkasa is the son of a Niṣāda or Śūdra by a
<div n="lb"/>Kṣatriya woman, but this is merely speculative; the Paulkasa
<div n="lb"/>may either have been a functional caste, or, as Fick<sup>5</sup> believes,
<div n="lb"/>an aboriginal clan living by catching wild beasts, and only
<div n="lb"/>occasionally reduced to menial tasks.
<F>1) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 17; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 14, 1.</F>
<F>2) iv. 3, 22.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%Pukkaśa.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
<div n="lb"/>217, takes Paulkasa as a mixed caste.</F>
<F>5) {%Die sociale Gliederung,%} 206. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 44,
<div n="lb"/>416, n. 6.</F>

<L>1980<pc>2-029<k1>pratardana<k2>pratardana
{@Pra-tardana@}¦ is the name in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>1</sup> of a king
<div n="lb"/>who had a {@Bharadvāja@} for his Purohita. In the Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> he appears as arriving at the sacrifice of the Ṛṣis in
<div n="lb"/>the Naimiṣa forest, and asking them how errors in the sacrifice
<div n="lb"/>could be remedied; and as finding {@Alīkayu Vācaspata,@} the
<div n="lb"/>Brahman priest at the sacrifice, unable to say what was to be
[Page2-030+ 35]
<div n="lb"/>done. In the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad<sup>3</sup> it is said that Pratardana
<div n="lb"/>Daivodāsi went to Indra's world through his death in battle.
<div n="lb"/>The patronymic connects him with {@Divodāsa,@} the ancestor or
<div n="lb"/>father of {@Sudās,@} and the mention of Bharadvāja (probably ‘a
<div n="lb"/>Bharadvāja’ is meant) as his priest supports the patronymic,
<div n="lb"/>for Divodāsa is a special favourite of the singers of the Bharad-
<div n="lb"/>vāja family. The name, moreover, is reminiscent of the
<div n="lb"/>Tṛtsus (the root {%tard%} appears in both) and of the {%Pratṛdaḥ%} (see
<div n="lb"/>{@Pratṛd@}). But he is not in Vedic literature a king of Kāśi.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Geldner<sup>5</sup> regards him as Divodāsa's son, but this is not likely.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} {@Prātardani.@}
<F>1) xxi. 10.</F>
<F>2) xxvi. 5.</F>
<F>3) iii. 1.</F>
<F>4) As in the Epic; Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1910, 38</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 138.</F>
<LEND>

<div n="lb"/>authority.<sup>5</sup>

<div n="lb"/>all certain, and while the Epic may have derived its genealogy

<L>2009<pc>2-035<k1>praDi<k2>praDi

<div n="lb"/>probably the ‘felly.’ In one passage of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and in

<div n="lb"/>jecture, though it is clear that the passage as a whole symbolizes
[Page2-036+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>the year with three seasons, twelve months, and three hundred
<div n="lb"/>and sixty days. Elsewhere<sup>4</sup> the nave and the Pradhi alone are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned, or the Pradhi occurs by itself.<sup>5</sup>

<L>2016<pc>2-037<k1>prapitva<k2>prapitva
{@Pra-pitva@}¦ is found in several passages of the Rigveda as a
<div n="lb"/>designation of time. In one passage<sup>1</sup> the sense is made clear
<div n="lb"/>by the context: ‘at the rising of the sun’ ({%sūra udite%}), ‘at mid-
<div n="lb"/>day’ ({%madhyaṃdine divaḥ%}), and ‘at the Prapitva, bordering on
<div n="lb"/>the night’ ({%apiśarvare%}). In another passage<sup>2</sup> the sense of ‘late
<div n="lb"/>in the day’ also seems adequate, while the phrase<sup>3</sup> {%abhipitve%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ahnaḥ,%} ‘at the close of day,’ also denotes the evening. According
<div n="lb"/>to Geldner,<sup>4</sup> the sense of the word is the ‘decisive moment’ in
<div n="lb"/>a race or a battle, and so the ‘end of the day.’<sup>5</sup> {%Cf.%} {@Ahan.@}
<F>1) viii. 1, 29.</F>
<F>2) vii. 41, 4.</F>
<F>3) iv. 16, 12.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 174 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.,%} took it to mean ‘daybreak’; so
<div n="lb"/>also Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 362.
<div n="lb"/>Böhtlingk, Dictionary, {%s.v.,%} on the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, gives the meaning as ‘decline of
<div n="lb"/>day,’ ‘evening.’ See also Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>16, 24 {%et seq.;%} Oldenberg, {%Sacred Books%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the East,%} 46, 183 {%et seq.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>2020<pc>2-038<k1>pramaganda<k2>pramaganda
{@Pra-maganda@}¦ is the name of a prince in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where
<div n="lb"/>he is mentioned as the king of the {@Kīkaṭas,@} and where he
<div n="lb"/>seems to be designated by the epithet {%naicāśākha,%} ‘belonging
<div n="lb"/>to a low branch or race.’ On the other hand, Yāska<sup>2</sup> takes
<div n="lb"/>Pramaganda to mean the ‘son of a usurer,’ an explanation that
<div n="lb"/>is hardly probable. Hillebrandt<sup>3</sup> thinks that {%naicāśākha%} refers
<div n="lb"/>not to Pramaganda, but to the Soma plant, the plant being
<div n="lb"/>called {%nīcāśākha,%} ‘having shoots turned downwards,’ and that
<div n="lb"/>the passage refers to a raid against the Kīkaṭas, who were not
<div n="lb"/>observers of the milk cult or the Soma cult, with the intention
<div n="lb"/>of winning their lands where the Soma grew and where there
<div n="lb"/>were cows. Böhtlingk,<sup>4</sup> however, questions this view, which is
<div n="lb"/>not very probable. A place name is possibly meant by Naicā-
<div n="lb"/>śākha.<sup>5</sup> The name Pramaganda seems un-Āryan.
<F>1) iii. 53, 14.</F>
<F>2) Nirukta, vi. 32.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 14-16.
<div n="lb"/>241-245.</F>
<F>4) {%Proceedings of the Saxon Academy,%}
<div n="lb"/>December 12, 1891.</F>
<F>5) Sāyaṇa, in his introduction to his
<div n="lb"/>commentary on the Rigveda, p. 4.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 31;
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>6, 153; Geldner, {%Rigveda, Kommentar,%}
