<L>2038<pc>2-041<k1>praSAstf<k2>praSAstf
{@Pra-śāstṛ@}¦ is the name of one of the priests ({@Ṛtvij@}) at the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic sacrifice. In the lesser sacrifices he plays no part at all,
<div n="lb"/>but he appears in the animal ({%paśu%}) and Soma sacrifices, in the
<div n="lb"/>former as the only, in the latter as the main, assistant of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Hotṛ@} priest in the singing of the litanies. He is mentioned by
<div n="lb"/>name in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and often later.<sup>2</sup> He is also in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>3</sup> called {@Upavaktṛ,@} this name, like Praśāstṛ, being
<div n="lb"/>derived from the fact that one of his chief functions was to
<div n="lb"/>issue directions ({%praiṣa%}) to the other priests. Another name
<div n="lb"/>for him was Maitrāvaruṇa, because his litanies were mainly
<div n="lb"/>addressed to Mitra and Varuṇa, a connexion already visible in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda.<sup>4</sup> The ‘two divine Hotṛs’ of the Āprī litanies
<div n="lb"/>denote, according to Oldenberg,<sup>5</sup> the heavenly counterparts of
<div n="lb"/>the Hotṛ and the Praśāstṛ.
<F>1) i. 94, 6; ii. 5, 4; {%praśāstra,%} ‘the
<div n="lb"/>Soma bowl of the Praśāstṛ,’ 36, 6;
<div n="lb"/>{%praśāstra,%} ‘the office of the Praśāstṛ,’
<div n="lb"/>ii. 1, 2 = x, 91, 10.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 21; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, v. 34; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iv. 6, 6, 6; xi. 5, 5, 9, etc.</F>
<F>3) iv. 9, 5; vi. 71, 5; ix. 95, 5.
<div n="lb"/>According to Ludwig, Translation of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, 3, 226, the Upavaktṛ is
<div n="lb"/>the earliest equivalent of the Ashāvāka.</F>
<F>4) ii. 36, 6.</F>
<F>5) {%Religion des Veda,%} 391. Ludwig,
<div n="lb"/>{%op. cit.,%} 3, 227, identifies the Praśāstṛ
<div n="lb"/>with the {@Prastotṛ,@} but this is most
<div n="lb"/>improbable.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%op. cit.,%} 383, 390, 391;
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10, 141 {%et seq.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>2040<pc>2-042<k1>prazwi<k2>prazwi

<L>2043<pc>2-043<k1>prasfta<k2>prasfta

<L>2060<pc>2-046<k1>prAcya<k2>prAcya

<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup> as a car of the Easterns ({%prācya-ratha%}). In the
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitopaniṣad Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup> reference is made to the Prācya-
<div n="lb"/>Pāñcālas.

<L>2062<pc>2-047<k1>prARa<k2>prARa
{@Prāṇa,@}¦ properly denoting ‘breath,’ is a term of wide and
<div n="lb"/>vague significance in Vedic literature. It is frequently men-
<div n="lb"/>tioned from the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards; in the Āraṇyakas and
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣads it is one of the commonest symbols of the unity of
<div n="lb"/>the universe.<sup>2</sup> In the narrow sense Prāṇa denotes one of the
<div n="lb"/>vital airs, of which five are usually<sup>3</sup> enumerated — Prāṇa,
<div n="lb"/>{@Apāna, Vyāna, Udāna,@} and {@Samāna;@} but often only two,
<div n="lb"/>Prāṇa and Apāna,<sup>4</sup> or Prāṇa and Vyāna,<sup>5</sup> or Prāṇa and Udāna;<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or three, Prāṇa, Apāna, and Vyāna,<sup>7</sup> or Prāṇa, Udāna, and
<div n="lb"/>Vyāna,<sup>8</sup> or Prāṇa, Udāna, and Samāna;<sup>9</sup> or four, Prāṇa,
<div n="lb"/>Apāna, Vyāna, and Samāna,<sup>10</sup> or Prāṇa, Apāna, Udāna,
<div n="lb"/>Vyāna.<sup>11</sup> The exact sense of each of these breaths when all
<div n="lb"/>are mentioned cannot be determined.<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) i. 66, 1; x. 59, 6; 90, 13, etc.</F>
<F>2) Deussen, {%Philosophy of the Upani-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%shads,%} 89 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) See {@Udāna,@} n. 1.</F>
<F>4) Av. ii. 28, 3; v. 4, 7 (Paipp.);
<div n="lb"/>vii. 53, 4 (in vii. 53, 3, Apāna,
<div n="lb"/>Prāṇa); Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 1,
<div n="lb"/>4, etc.</F>
<F>5) Av. v, 4, 7; vi. 41, 2, etc.</F>
<F>6) See {@Udāna,@} n. 3.</F>
<F>7) Av. xiii. 2, 46; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, iv. 5, 6, 9; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xxii. 23; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 29;
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, vi. 10; Śāṅkh-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Āraṇyaka, viii. 8; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, ii. 2, etc.</F>
<F>8) See {@Udāna,@} n. 2.</F>
<F>9) {%Ibid.%}</F>
<F>10) Av. x. 2, 13.</F>
<F>11) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad iii. 4, 1.</F>
<F>12) {%Cf.%} Deussen, {%Philosophy of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Upanishads,%} 273 {%et seq.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>2063<pc>2-047<k1>prARa<k2>prARa
{@Prāṇa@}¦ is also used in a wider sense to denote the organs of
<div n="lb"/>sense,<sup>13</sup> or as Sāyaṇa<sup>14</sup> puts it, the ‘orifices of the head,’ etc.
<div n="lb"/>These are given as six in one passage of the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>15</sup> presumably the eyes, ears, and nostrils. More
<div n="lb"/>frequently there are stated to be seven in the head, the mouth
<div n="lb"/>being then included.<sup>16</sup> Sometimes again they are mentioned
[Page2-048+ 65]
<div n="lb"/>as nine,<sup>17</sup> or as seven in the head and two below.<sup>18</sup> Ten are
<div n="lb"/>counted in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>19</sup> and the Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>20</sup> while even eleven are mentioned in the Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad,<sup>21</sup> and twelve in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,<sup>22</sup> where the
<div n="lb"/>two breasts are added. Exactly what organs are taken to
<div n="lb"/>make up the numbers beyond seven is not certain.<sup>23</sup> The tenth
<div n="lb"/>is the navel ({%nābhi%}) in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā;<sup>24</sup> when eleven
<div n="lb"/>are named the Brahma-randhra<sup>25</sup> (suture in the crown) may be
<div n="lb"/>included; in the Atharvaveda,<sup>26</sup> as interpreted by the Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>27</sup> the seventh and eighth are the organs
<div n="lb"/>of taste and speech respectively. But usually these make one
<div n="lb"/>only, and the eighth and ninth are either in the breast<sup>28</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>below (the organs of evacuation).<sup>29</sup>
<div n="P"/>The word Prāṇa has sometimes merely the general sense of
<div n="lb"/>breath, even when opposed to Apāna.<sup>30</sup> But its proper sense
<div n="lb"/>is beyond question ‘breathing forth,’ ‘expiration,’ and not as
<div n="lb"/>the St. Petersburg Dictionary explains it, ‘the breath inspired,’
<div n="lb"/>a version due to the desire to interpret Apāna as ‘expiration,’
<div n="lb"/>a meaning suggested by the preposition {%apa,%} ‘away.’ This
<div n="lb"/>being clearly shown both by the native scholiasts<sup>31</sup> and by
<div n="lb"/>other evidence,<sup>32</sup> Böhtlingk<sup>33</sup> later accepted the new view.
<F>13) Colebrooke, {%Miscellaneous Essays,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 339, 355; St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.%} 1.</F>
<F>14) On Aitareya Āraṇyaka, i. 3, 7.</F>
<F>15) xiv. 1. 3, 32; 4, 1.</F>
<F>16) Av. ii. 12, 7; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>i. 17; iii. 3; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 1, 3, 21; vi. 4, 2, 5; xiii. 1, 7, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, ii. 5, 9,
<div n="lb"/>10; 6, 8, etc.</F>
<F>17) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 10, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 1, 7, 4; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, i. 5, 2, 5; Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxii. 12, 5; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, i. 4, 1; Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇ-
<div n="lb"/>yaka, ii. 2; Av. v. 28, 1; x. 8, 43
<div n="lb"/>({%navadvāram%}), etc.</F>
<F>18) Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 5, 9, 10; 6, 8.</F>
<F>19) xi. 6, 3, 17, where the eleventh is
<div n="lb"/>given as the Ātman.</F>
<F>20) ii. 77 ({%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 15, 240).</F>
<F>21) v. 1.</F>
<F>22) xxxiii. 3.</F>
<F>23) {%Cf.%} Deussen, {%op. cit.,%} 269; Keith,
<div n="lb"/>{%Aitareya Āraṇyaha,%} 185, 187.</F>
<F>24) iv. 6, 1; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, ix. 16.</F>
<F>25) Aitareya Upaniṣad, i. 3.</F>
<F>26) x. 8, 9.</F>

<div n="lb"/>and uncompounded in the Taittīriya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>2</sup> In the first

<L>2104<pc>2-055<k1>plakzaprAsravaRa<k2>plakzaprAsravaRa<h>3

<div n="lb"/>Plākṣa Prasravaṇa, and is apparently meant to designate the
<div n="lb"/>source of the Sarasvatī rather than the place of its reappearance.
<F>1) xxv. 10, 16. 22; Kātyāyana Srauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xxiv. 6, 7; Lāṭyāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, x. 17, 12. 14.</F>

<L>2136<pc>2-060<k1>bambAviSvavayasO<k2>bambAviSvavayasO

<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās,<sup>1</sup> invented a certain rite.

<L>2143<pc>2-061<k1>balAsa<k2>balAsa
{@Balāsa@}¦ is the name of a disease mentioned several times in
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and occasionally later.<sup>2</sup> Mahīdhara<sup>3</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa<sup>4</sup> interpret the term as ‘consumption.’ Zimmer<sup>5</sup> supports
<div n="lb"/>this view on the ground that it is mentioned<sup>6</sup> as a kind of
<div n="lb"/>{@Yakṣma,@} makes the bones and joints fall apart ({%asthi-sraṃsa,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%paruḥ-sraṃsa%}),<sup>7</sup> and is caused by love, aversion, and the heart,<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>characteristics which agree with the statements of the later
<div n="lb"/>Hindu medicine.<sup>9</sup> It is in keeping with a demon of the
<div n="lb"/>character of consumption that Balāsa should appear as an
<div n="lb"/>accompaniment of Takman.<sup>10</sup> Grohmann,<sup>11</sup> however, thought
[Page2-062+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>that a ‘sore’ or ‘swelling’ (in the case of fever caused by
<div n="lb"/>dropsy) was meant. Bloomfield<sup>12</sup> considers that the question
<div n="lb"/>is still open. Ludwig<sup>13</sup> renders the word by ‘dropsy.’
<div n="P"/>As remedies against the disease the salve ({@Āñjasa@}) from
<div n="lb"/>{@Trikakud@}<sup>14</sup> and the {@Jaṅgiḍa@}<sup>15</sup> plant are mentioned.
<F>1) iv. 9, 8; v. 22, 11; vi. 14; 1; 127, 1;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 8, 8; xix. 34, 10.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 97.</F>
<F>3) On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>4) On Av. xix. 34, 10.</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 385-387.</F>
<F>6) Av. ix. 8, 10.</F>
<F>7) Av. vi. 14, 1.</F>
<F>8) ix. 8, 8.</F>
<F>9) Wise, {%Hindu System of Medicine,%} 321,
<div n="lb"/>322.</F>
<F>10) Av. iv. 9, 8; xix. 34, 10.</F>
<F>11) {%Indische Studien,%} 9, 396 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>12) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 450.</F>
<F>13) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 510.</F>
<F>14) Av. iv. 9, 8.</F>
<F>15) Av. xix. 34, 10.</F>

<L>2144<pc>2-062<k1>bali<k2>bali
{@Bali@}¦ occurs several times in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and often later<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>in the sense of tribute to a king or offering to a god. Zimmer<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thinks that the offerings were in both cases voluntary. He
<div n="lb"/>compares the notices of the Germans in Tacitus,<sup>4</sup> where the
<div n="lb"/>kings of the tribes are said to receive gifts in kind as presents,
<div n="lb"/>but not a regular tribute. There seems to be no ground what-
<div n="lb"/>ever for this view. No doubt in origin the prerogatives of
<div n="lb"/>monarchy were due to voluntary action on the part of the
<div n="lb"/>tribesmen,<sup>5</sup> but that the Vedic peoples, who were essentially
<div n="lb"/>a body of conquering invaders, were in this state is most
<div n="lb"/>improbable, and the attitude of the Vedic Indian to his gods
<div n="lb"/>was at least as compatible with tribute as with voluntary gifts.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer admits that in the case of hostile tribes<sup>6</sup> tribute must
<div n="lb"/>be meant even in the Rigveda. See also {@Rājan.@}
<F>1) To a god, Rv. i. 70, 9; v. 1, 10;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 100, 9; to a king, in the compound
<div n="lb"/>{%bali-hṛt,%} ‘paying tribute,’ vii. 6, 5;
<div n="lb"/>x. 173, 6.</F>
<F>2) Metaphorically: Av. vi. 117, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 2, 3, 2; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xxix. 7; Taittirīya Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>i. 5, 3, etc.; {%bali-hṛt,%} Av. xi. 4, 19;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, {%loc. cit.; bali-hāra,%}
<div n="lb"/>Av. xi. 1, 20; literally: Av. iii. 4, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 7, 18, 3; iii. 12,
<div n="lb"/>2, 7; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 2, 15;
<div n="lb"/>5, 3, 18; 6, 3, 17; xi 2, 6, 14; Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xv. 7, 4; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vii. 29 ({%cf.%} vii. 34); {%bali-hṛt,%}
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxix. 9; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, i. 6, 2, 1.</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 166, 167.</F>
<F>4) {%Germania,%} 15.</F>
<F>5) Later, too, benevolences ({%praṇayā-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%kriyā%}) were known. See Fleet, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1909, 760-
<div n="lb"/>762.</F>
<F>6) See Rv. vii. 6, 5; 18, 19.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2147<pc>2-063<k1>balhika<k2>balhika<h>1
1. {@Balhika@}¦ is the name of a people in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> where
<div n="lb"/>the fever ({@Takman@}) is called upon to go to the {@Mūjavants,@} the
<div n="lb"/>{@Mahāvṛṣas,@} and the Balhikas. The Mūjavants are quite
<div n="lb"/>certainly a northern tribe, and though, as Bloomfield<sup>2</sup> suggests,
<div n="lb"/>the passage may contain a pun on Balhika as suggesting
<div n="lb"/>‘outsider’ (from {%bahis,%} ‘without’), still no doubt the name was
<div n="lb"/>chosen from a northern tribe. But the view of Roth<sup>3</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Weber,<sup>4</sup> which Zimmer<sup>5</sup> once accepted, that an Iranian tribe
<div n="lb"/>is referred to ({%cf.%} Balkh), is not at all probable. Zimmer<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>shows that there is no need whatever to assume Iranian
<div n="lb"/>influence. See also {@Parśu.@}
<F>1) v. 22, 5. 7. 9.</F>
<F>2) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 446.</F>
<F>3) {%Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Weda,%} 41.</F>
<F>4) {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 205; {%Proceedings%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Berlin Academy,%} 1892, 985-995.</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 130.</F>
<F>6) {%Op. cit.,%} 431-433.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Whitney, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 260; Hopkins, {%Great Epic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of India,%} 373.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2148<pc>2-063<k1>balhikaprAtipIya<k2>balhikaprAtipIya<h>2
2. {@Balhika Prātipīya@}¦ is the name of a {@Kuru@} king in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> where he appears as having been opposed
<div n="lb"/>to the restoration of {@Duṣṭarītu Pauṃsāyana@} to his hereditary
<div n="lb"/>sovereignty over the {@Sṛñjayas,@} but as having failed to prevent
[Page2-064+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>the restoration being carried out by {@Revottaras Pāṭava Cākra@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Sthapati.@} The epithet Prātipīya is curious: if it connects him
<div n="lb"/>with {@Pratīpa@} (whose son he is in the Epic), the form is
<div n="lb"/>remarkable, Zimmer<sup>2</sup> indeed tacitly altering it to Prātīpīya.
<div n="lb"/>In the Epic and the Purāṇas<sup>3</sup> he is in the form of Vāhlīka
<div n="lb"/>made a brother of {@Devāpi@} and {@Śantanu,@} and a son of Pratīpa.
<div n="lb"/>To base chronological conclusions on this<sup>4</sup> would be utterly
<div n="lb"/>misleading, for the facts are that Devāpi was son of Ṛṣṭiṣeṇa
<div n="lb"/>and a priest, while Śantanu was a Kuru prince of unknown
<div n="lb"/>parentage, but not probably a son of Pratīpa, who seems to be
<div n="lb"/>a late figure in the Vedic age, later than {@Parikṣit,@} being his
<div n="lb"/>great-grandson in the Epic. Very possibly Balhika was a
<div n="lb"/>descendant of Pratīpa. Why he bore the name Balhika
<div n="lb"/>must remain uncertain, for there is no evidence of any sort
<div n="lb"/>regarding it.
<F>1) xii. 9, 3, 3.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 432.</F>
<F>3) See Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 12, 273
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.;%} Sieg, {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%}
<div n="lb"/>131-136.</F>
<F>4) Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1910, 52.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2149<pc>2-064<k1>balbUTa<k2>balbUTa

<div n="lb"/>sava is identified with the Vājapeya; but such identity is
<div n="lb"/>clearly not primitive.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) ii. 7, 1, 2. {%Cf.%} Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 7; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xvii.
<div n="lb"/>11, 4; xxv. 1, 1, 7.</F>

<F>4) Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>41, xxiv, xxv; Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}

<L>2195<pc>2-073<k1>bekanAwa<k2>bekanAwa

<div n="lb"/>identifying Bekanāṭa with Bikanir.

<L>2204<pc>2-074<k1>brahmacarya<k2>brahmacarya
{@Brahma-carya@}¦ denotes the condition of life of the {@Brahma-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@cārin@}<sup>1</sup> or religious student. The technical sense is first found in
[Page2-075+ 70]
<div n="lb"/>the last Maṇḍala of the Rigveda.<sup>2</sup> The practice of studentship
<div n="lb"/>doubtless developed, and was more strictly regulated by custom
<div n="lb"/>as time went on, but it is regularly assumed and discussed in
<div n="lb"/>the later Vedic literature, being obviously a necessary part of
<div n="lb"/>Vedic society
<div n="P"/>The Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> has in honour of the Brahmacārin a hymn
<div n="lb"/>which already gives all the characteristic features of religious
<div n="lb"/>studentship. The youth is initiated ({%upa-nī%}) by the teacher<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>into a new life; he wears an antelope skin, and lets his hair
<div n="lb"/>grow long;<sup>5</sup> he collects fuel,<sup>6</sup> and begs,<sup>7</sup> learns, and practises
<div n="lb"/>penance. All these characteristics appear in the later literature.
<div n="lb"/>The student lives in the house of his teacher ({%ācārya-kula-vāsin;%}<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{%ante-vāsin%});<sup>9</sup> he begs,<sup>10</sup> looks after the sacrificial fires,<sup>11</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>tends the house.<sup>12</sup> His term of studentship might be long
<div n="lb"/>extended: it was normally fixed at twelve years,<sup>13</sup> but much
<div n="lb"/>longer periods, such as thirty-two years, are mentioned.<sup>14</sup> The
[Page2-076+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>age at which studentship began varied.<sup>15</sup> {@Śvetaketu@} com-
<div n="lb"/>menced at twelve and studied for twelve years.<sup>16</sup>
<div n="P"/>It is assumed in the Gṛhya Sūtras that the three Āryan castes
<div n="lb"/>were all required to pass through a period of studentship. But
<div n="lb"/>that this is much more than priestly schematism is uncertain.
<div n="lb"/>No doubt individuals of the {@Kṣatriya@} or {@Vaiśya@} caste might go
<div n="lb"/>through part of the period of studentship, just as Burmese boys
<div n="lb"/>of all classes now pass some time in a monastery as students.
<div n="lb"/>This is borne out by the reference in the Atharvaveda<sup>17</sup> to the
<div n="lb"/>king guarding his country by Brahmacarya — though that is
<div n="lb"/>susceptible of a different interpretation — and more clearly by
<div n="lb"/>the reference in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>18</sup> to a rite intended to
<div n="lb"/>benefit one who, although not a Brahmin, had studied ({%vidyām%}
<div n="lb"/>{%anūcya%}), but had not gained renown, and by references in the
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣads to kings who like {@Janaka@} studied the Vedas and the
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣads.<sup>19</sup> Normally, however, the Kṣatriya studied the art
<div n="lb"/>of war.<sup>20</sup>
<div n="P"/>One of the duties of the Brahmacārin was chastity. But
<div n="lb"/>reference is in several places<sup>21</sup> made to the possibility of mis-
<div n="lb"/>conduct between a student and the wife of his preceptor, nor is
<div n="lb"/>any very severe penance imposed in early times — later it is
<div n="lb"/>different — for such a sin. In certain cases the ritual required
<div n="lb"/>a breach of chastity, no doubt as a magic spell to secure
<div n="lb"/>fertility.<sup>22</sup>
<div n="P"/>Even an old man might on occasion become a pupil, as the
<div n="lb"/>story of {@Āruṇi@} shows.<sup>23</sup>
<F>1) Rv. x. 109, 5; Av. vi. 108, 2; 133, 3; xi. 5, 1 {%et seq.;%} Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xi. 3, 3, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv., {%loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>3) xi. 5. {%Cf.%} Gopatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 2,
<div n="lb"/>1-8, which contains an independent
<div n="lb"/>account of the Brahmacārin (Bloom-
<div n="lb"/>field, {%Atharvaveda,%} 110); Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xi. 3, 3, 1 {%et seq.;%} Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 10, 5.</F>
<F>4) Av. xi. 5, 3. It is used in the ritual
<div n="lb"/>of the Upanayana, according to the
<div n="lb"/>Kauśika Sūtra, lv. 18.</F>
<F>5) Av. xi. 5, 6.</F>
<F>6) Av. xi. 5, 4, 6.</F>
<F>7) Av. xi. 5, 9.</F>
<F>8) Chāndogya Upaniṣad, ii. 23, 2.
<div n="lb"/>So regularly {%brahma-caryeṇa vas,%} Av.
<div n="lb"/>vii. 109, 7; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, v. 14,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; or {%car,%} Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 3,

<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>9) {%Ibid.,%} iii. 11, 5; iv. 10, 1; Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 3, 15 (Mādhyaṃ-
<div n="lb"/>dina = vi. 3, 7 Kāṇva); Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, i. 3, 3; 11. 1.</F>
<F>10) Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iv. 3, 5.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Av. vi. 133, 3; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, xi. 3, 3, 5.</F>
<F>11) Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iv. 10, 2
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.;%} Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa. xi. 3,
<div n="lb"/>3, 4.</F>

<div n="lb"/>A Mantra in the Āśvalāyana Gṛhya
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, i. 22, 1. 2, and elsewhere, sums
<div n="lb"/>up the duties of the Brahmacārin as
<div n="lb"/>‘thou art a Brahmacārin: eat water;

<div n="lb"/>these grounds, too, the pupil would,
<div n="lb"/>no doubt, bring dried dung for fuel, as
<div n="lb"/>well as any available sticks. As regards
<div n="lb"/>obedience to the teacher, {%cf.%} Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xi. 3, 3, 6.</F>
<F>13) Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iv. 10;

<div n="lb"/>15 (for life), etc.</F>
<F>15) See Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10, 21.
<div n="lb"/>The Sūtras allowed for a Brāhmaṇa the
<div n="lb"/>ages 8-16; for a Kṣatriya, 11-22; for a
<div n="lb"/>Vaiśya, 12-24. The difference between
<div n="lb"/>the Brāhmaṇa and the Kṣatriya, com-
<div n="lb"/>pared with that between the Kṣatriya
<div n="lb"/>and the Vaiśya, shows that the two
<div n="lb"/>latter castes were in a different position
<div n="lb"/>from the Brāhmaṇa.</F>

<L>2207<pc>2-077<k1>brahman<k2>brahman<h>1
1. {@Brahman@}¦ (neut.) denotes the priestly class as opposed to
<div n="lb"/>the warrior class and the people ({@Kṣatra@} and {@Viś@}). The term
<div n="lb"/>is found in the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> and repeatedly later on.<sup>2</sup> For the
<div n="lb"/>position, etc., of this class, see {@Brāhmaṇa.@}
<F>1) ii. 15, 4; ix. 7, 9; xii. 5, 8; xv. 10,
<div n="lb"/>3, 4.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 1, 1, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 3; vii. 21, etc.
<div n="lb"/>See also {@Varṇa@} and {@Kṣatra.@}</F>
<LEND>

<L>2208<pc>2-077<k1>brahman<k2>brahman<h>2
2. {@Brahman@}¦ is found in many passages of the Rigveda and
<div n="lb"/>later in the sense of ‘priest.’ In many passages of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>he is referred to as praising the gods; in others<sup>2</sup> the sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘priest’ is adequate. In not a few cases<sup>3</sup> the priesthood as a
<div n="lb"/>profession is clearly alluded to, nor is there any reason to doubt<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>that in all cases the word has the technical sense of a member
<div n="lb"/>of the priesthood. There is, however, considerable doubt as to
<div n="lb"/>the number of cases in the Rigveda, where it has the technical
[Page2-078+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>sense of the priest who guides the sacrifice generally. It is
<div n="lb"/>undoubtedly found in that sense, both Muir<sup>5</sup> and Roth<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>recognizing instances of its being used thus. Geldner,<sup>7</sup> how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, is anxious to find that sense in a large number of passages,
<div n="lb"/>and insists that the {@Purohita@} was normally a Brahman in the
<div n="lb"/>narrower sense. Oldenberg,<sup>8</sup> on the other hand, holds with
<div n="lb"/>greater probability that in most of the passages adduced
<div n="lb"/>Brahman means simply ‘priest,’ and that the Purohita, who
<div n="lb"/>was essentially not a member of the ordinary body of sacri-
<div n="lb"/>ficing priests ({@Ṛtvij@}), was, when he officiated at the sacrifice,
<div n="lb"/>more usually the Hotṛ priest, and only later became the
<div n="lb"/>Brahman. This change he regards as having taken place when
<div n="lb"/>the importance of the hymns declined, and most weight was
<div n="lb"/>laid on the functions of the priest who superintended the sacrifice
<div n="lb"/>as a whole, and by his magic repaired the flaws in the sacrifice.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>In the later literature both senses of the word are quite
<div n="lb"/>common.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) i. 80, 1; 164, 34; ii. 2, 6; vi. 45, 7;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 33, 11; viii. 16, 7; x. 71, 11; 77, 1;
<div n="lb"/>85, 3, 16. 34; 107, 6; 117, 7; 125, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 12, 244-246.</F>
<F>2) i. 10, 1; 33, 9; 101, 5; 108, 7;
<div n="lb"/>158, 6; ii. 39, 1; iv. 50, 8, 9; 58, 2;
<div n="lb"/>v. 29, 3; 31, 4; 32, 12; 40, 8; vii. 7, 5;
<div n="lb"/>42, 1; viii. 7, 20; 17, 2; 31, 1; 32, 16;
<div n="lb"/>33 19; 45, 39; 64, 7; 77, 5; 92, 30;
<div n="lb"/>96, 5; ix. 96, 6; 112, 1; 113, 6; x. 28
<div n="lb"/>11; 71, 11; 85, 29; 141, 3; Muir,
<div n="lb"/>{%op. cit.,%} 12, 246-251.</F>
<F>3) i. 108, 7; iv. 50, 8, 9; viii. 7, 20;
<div n="lb"/>45, 39; 64, 7; 92, 30; ix. 112, 1; x. 85,
<div n="lb"/>29; Muir, 12, 258.</F>
<F>4) {%Loc. cit. Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Leben,%} 190 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) {%Op. cit.,%} 12, 251, citing ii. 1, 2
<div n="lb"/>(= ix. 91, 10); iv. 9, 4; x. 52, 2.</F>
<F>6) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>citing ii. 1, 2; ix. 96, 6; x. 71, 11;
<div n="lb"/>107, 6. In none of the last three
<div n="lb"/>passages is the specific sense cogently
<div n="lb"/>required.</F>
<F>7) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 145 {%et seq.;%} 3, 155.
<div n="lb"/>He thinks that the sense of ‘super-
<div n="lb"/>intending priest’ is the older, and sees
<div n="lb"/>it in i. 158, 6; iv. 9, 4; 50, 7. 8;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 7, 5; 33, 11; x. 141, 3, etc.</F>
<F>8) {%Religion des Veda,%} 396, 397, who
<div n="lb"/>thinks that the Brahman priest known
<div n="lb"/>to the Rigveda was the {@Brāhmaṇāc-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@chaṃsin@} and who in most passages
<div n="lb"/>({%e.g.,%} iv. 50, 7. 8) sees only the sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘priest.’ {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>10, 376, 377.</F>
<F>9) {%Cf.%} Pischel, {%Göttingische Gelehrte%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Anzeigen,%} 1894, 420; Hillebrandt, {%Ritual-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%litteratur,%} 13; Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Atharvaveda,%} lxviii; {%Atharvaveda,%} 32;
<div n="lb"/>and see {@Purohita.@}</F>
<F>10) As ‘priest,’ Av. ii. 7, 2; iv. 35,
<div n="lb"/>1. 2; v. 8, 5; 17, 8; 18, 7; 19, 8;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 122, 5; viii. 9, 3; x. 1, 3; 4, 30. 33;
<div n="lb"/>7, 24; xi. 1, 25; xii. 1, 38; xix. 32, 8;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 7, 1; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xxvi. 2; Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, v. 3, etc. As ‘superintending
<div n="lb"/>priest,’ Av. xviii. 4, 15; xx. 2, 3; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 1; ii. 3, 11, 4;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 5, 2, 1, etc.; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xxxvii. 17; and see Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 10, 34, 35; 114; 135-138; 327;
<div n="lb"/>330-337.</F>

<L>2222<pc>2-080<k1>brAhmaRa<k2>brAhmaRa<h>1
1. {@Brāhmaṇa,@}¦ ‘descendant of a Brahman’ ({%i.e.,%} of a priest), is
<div n="lb"/>found only a few times in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and mostly in its latest
[Page2-081+ 64]
<div n="lb"/>parts. In the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> and later<sup>3</sup> it is a very common
<div n="lb"/>word denoting ‘priest,’ and it appears in the quadruple division
<div n="lb"/>of the castes in the Puruṣa-sūkta (‘hymn of man’) of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>It seems certain that in the Rigveda this Brāhmaṇa, or
<div n="lb"/>Brahmin, is already a separate caste, differing from the warrior
<div n="lb"/>and agricultural castes.<sup>5</sup> The texts regularly claim for them a
<div n="lb"/>superiority to the {@Kṣatriya@} caste,<sup>6</sup> and the Brahmin is able by
<div n="lb"/>his spells or manipulation of the rite to embroil the people and
<div n="lb"/>the warriors<sup>7</sup> or the different sections of the warriors.<sup>8</sup> If it
<div n="lb"/>is necessary to recognize, as is sometimes done, that the
<div n="lb"/>Brahmin does pay homage to the king at the {@Rājasūya,@}<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>nevertheless the unusual fact is carefully explained away so
<div n="lb"/>as to leave the priority of the Brahmin unaffected. But it
<div n="lb"/>is expressly recognized that the union of the Kṣatriya and
<div n="lb"/>the Brāhmaṇa is essential for complete prosperity.<sup>10</sup> It is
<div n="lb"/>admitted<sup>11</sup> that the king or the nobles might at times oppress
<div n="lb"/>the Brahmins, but it is indicated that ruin is then certain
<div n="lb"/>swiftly to follow.
[Page2-082+ 55]
<div n="P"/>The Brahmins are gods on earth,<sup>12</sup> like the gods in heaven,
<div n="lb"/>but this claim is hardly found in the Rigveda.<sup>13</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>14</sup> the Brahmin is said to be the
<div n="lb"/>‘recipient of gifts’ ({%ādāyī%}) and the ‘drinker of the offering’
<div n="lb"/>({%āpāyī%}). The other two epithets applied, {%āvasāyī%} and {%yathā-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%kāma-prayāpya,%} are more obscure; the former denotes either
<div n="lb"/>‘dwelling everywhere’<sup>15</sup> or ‘seeking food’;<sup>16</sup> the latter is usually
<div n="lb"/>taken as ‘moving at pleasure,’ but it must rather allude to the
<div n="lb"/>power of the king to assign a place of residence to the Brahmin.
<div n="P"/>In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>17</sup> the prerogatives of the Brah-
<div n="lb"/>min are summed up as (1) Arcā, ‘honour’; (2) Dāna, ‘gifts’;
<div n="lb"/>(3) Ajyeyatā, ‘freedom from oppression’; and (4) Avadhyatā,
<div n="lb"/>‘freedom from being killed.’ On the other hand, his duties
<div n="lb"/>are summed up as (5) Brāhmaṇya, ‘purity of descent’;
<div n="lb"/>(6) Pratirūpa-caryā, ‘devotion of the duties of his caste’; and
<div n="lb"/>(7) Loka-pakti, ‘the perfecting of people’ (by teaching).
<div n="P"/>1. {%Respect paid to Brahmins.%} — The texts are full<sup>18</sup> of references
<div n="lb"/>to the civilities to be paid to the Brahmin. He is styled
<div n="lb"/>{%bhagavant,%}<sup>19</sup> and is provided with good food<sup>20</sup> and entertain-
<div n="lb"/>ment wherever he goes. Indeed, his sanctity exempts him
<div n="lb"/>from any close inquiry into his real claim to Brahminhood
<div n="lb"/>according to the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>21</sup>
<div n="P"/>2. {%Gifts to Brahmins.%} — The Dānastuti (‘Praise of gifts’) is a
<div n="lb"/>recognized feature of the Rigveda, and the greed of the poets
<div n="lb"/>for {@Dakṣiṇās,@} or sacrificial fees, is notorious. Vedic texts<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>themselves recognize that the literature thence resulting ({@Nārā-@}
[Page2-083+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>{@śaṃsī@}) was often false to please the donors. It was, however,
<div n="lb"/>a rule<sup>23</sup> that Brahmins should not accept what had been
<div n="lb"/>refused by others; this indicates a keen sense of the danger of
<div n="lb"/>cheapening their wares. So exclusively theirs was the right to
<div n="lb"/>receive gifts that the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>24</sup> has to explain
<div n="lb"/>how {@Taranta@} and {@Purumīḷha@} became able to accept gifts by
<div n="lb"/>composing a Rigvedic hymn.<sup>25</sup> The exaggerations in the
<div n="lb"/>celebration of the gifts bestowed on the priests has the curious
<div n="lb"/>result of giving us a series of numerals of some interest ({@Daśan@}).
<div n="lb"/>In some passages<sup>26</sup> certain gifts — those of a horse or sheep — are
<div n="lb"/>forbidden, but this rule was not, it is clear, generally observed.
<div n="P"/>3. {%Immunities of Brahmins.%} — The Brahmin claimed to be
<div n="lb"/>exempt from the ordinary exercise of the royal power. When
<div n="lb"/>a king gives all his land and what is on it to the priests, the gift
<div n="lb"/>does not cover the property of the Brahmin according to the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>27</sup> The king censures all, but not the
<div n="lb"/>Brahmin,<sup>28</sup> nor can he safely oppress any Brahmin other than
<div n="lb"/>an ignorant priest.<sup>29</sup> An arbitrator (or a witness) must decide
<div n="lb"/>(or speak) for a Brahmin against a non-Brahmin in a legal
<div n="lb"/>dispute.<sup>30</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Brahmin's proper food is the {@Soma,@}<sup>31</sup> not {@Surā@}<sup>32</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>{@Parisrut,@}<sup>33</sup> and he is forbidden to eat certain forms of flesh.<sup>34</sup>
<div n="lb"/>On the other hand, he alone is allowed to eat the remains of
<div n="lb"/>the sacrifice,<sup>35</sup> for no one else is sufficiently holy to consume
<div n="lb"/>food which the gods have eaten. Moreover, though he cannot
<div n="lb"/>be a physician,<sup>36</sup> he helps the physician by being beside him
[Page2-084+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>while he exercises his art.<sup>37</sup> His wife<sup>38</sup> and his cow<sup>39</sup> are both
<div n="lb"/>sacred.
<div n="P"/>4. {%Legal Position of Brahmins.%} — The Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>40</sup>
<div n="lb"/>lays down a penalty of a hundred (the unit meant is unknown)
<div n="lb"/>for an insult to a Brahmin, and of a thousand for a blow; but
<div n="lb"/>if his blood is drawn, the penalty is a spiritual one. The only
<div n="lb"/>real murder is the slaying of a Brahmin according to the
<div n="lb"/>Satapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>41</sup> The crime of slaying a Brahmin ranks
<div n="lb"/>above the sin of killing any other man, but below that of killing
<div n="lb"/>an embryo ({%bhrūṇa%}) in the Yajurveda;<sup>42</sup> the crime of slaying an
<div n="lb"/>embryo whose sex is uncertain is on a level with that of slaying
<div n="lb"/>a Brahmin.<sup>43</sup> The murder of a Brahmin can be expiated only
<div n="lb"/>by the horse sacrifice,<sup>44</sup> or by a lesser rite in the late Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka.<sup>45</sup> The ritual slaying of a Brahmin is allowed in the
<div n="lb"/>later ceremonial,<sup>46</sup> and hinted at in the curious legend of
<div n="lb"/>{@Śunaḥśepa;@}<sup>47</sup> and a Purohita might be punished with death for
<div n="lb"/>treachery to his master.<sup>48</sup>
<div n="P"/>5. {%Purity of Birth.%} — The importance of pure descent is seen
<div n="lb"/>in the stress laid on being a descendant of a Ṛṣi ({%ārṣeya%}).<sup>49</sup> But,
<div n="lb"/>on the other hand, there are clear traces of another doctrine,
<div n="lb"/>which requires learning, and not physical descent, as the true
<div n="lb"/>criterion of Ṛṣihood.<sup>50</sup> In agreement with this is the fact
<div n="lb"/>that {@Satyakāma Jābāla@} was received as a pupil, though his
<div n="lb"/>parentage was unknown, his mother being a slave girl who had
<div n="lb"/>been connected with several men,<sup>51</sup> and that in the Śatapatha
[Page2-085+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>52</sup> the ceremony on acceptance as a pupil required
<div n="lb"/>merely the name of the pupil. So {@Kavaṣa@} is taunted in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda Brāhmaṇas<sup>53</sup> as being the son of a female slave ({@Dāsī@}),
<div n="lb"/>and {@Vatsa@} cleared himself of a similar imputation by a fire
<div n="lb"/>ordeal.<sup>54</sup> Moreover, a very simple rite was adequate to remove
<div n="lb"/>doubts as to origin.<sup>55</sup> In these circumstances it is doubtful
<div n="lb"/>whether much value attaches to the {@Pravara@} lists in which the
<div n="lb"/>ancestors of the priest were invoked at the beginning of the
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice by the Hotṛ and the Adhvaryu priests.<sup>56</sup> Still, in
<div n="lb"/>many parts of the ritual the knowledge of two or more genera-
<div n="lb"/>tions was needed,<sup>57</sup> and in one ceremony<sup>58</sup> ten ancestors who
<div n="lb"/>have drunk the Soma are required, but a literal performance of
<div n="lb"/>the rite is excused. Moreover, there are clear traces of ritual
<div n="lb"/>variations in schools, like those of the {@Vasiṣṭhas@} and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Viśvāmitras.@}
<div n="P"/>6. {%The Conduct of the Brahmin.%} — The Brahmin was required
<div n="lb"/>to maintain a fair standard of excellence.<sup>59</sup> He was to be kind
<div n="lb"/>to all<sup>60</sup> and gentle,<sup>61</sup> offering sacrifice and receiving gifts.<sup>62</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Especial stress was laid on purity of speech;<sup>63</sup> thus {@Viśvan-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@tara's@} excuse for excluding the {@Śyāparṇas@} from his retinue was
<div n="lb"/>their impure ({%apūtā%}) speech.<sup>64</sup> Theirs was the craving for
<div n="lb"/>knowledge<sup>65</sup> and the life of begging.<sup>66</sup> False Brahmins are
<div n="lb"/>those who do not fulfil their duties<sup>67</sup> ({%cf.%} {@Brahmabandhu@}) .
[Page2-086+ 58]
<div n="lb"/>But the penances for breach of duty are, in the Sūtras, of a
<div n="lb"/>very light and unimportant character.<sup>68</sup>
<div n="P"/>7. {%Brahminical Studies.%} — The aim of the priest is to obtain
<div n="lb"/>pre-eminence in sacred knowledge ({%brahma-varcasam%}), as is
<div n="lb"/>stated in numerous passages of Vedic literature.<sup>69</sup> Such
<div n="lb"/>distinction is not indeed confined to the Brahmin: the king
<div n="lb"/>has it also, but it is not really in a special manner appropriate
<div n="lb"/>to the Kṣatriya.<sup>70</sup> Many ritual acts are specified as leading to
<div n="lb"/>Brahmavarcasa,<sup>71</sup> but more stress is laid on the study of the
<div n="lb"/>sacred texts: the importance of such study is repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>insisted upon.<sup>72</sup>
<div n="P"/>The technical name for study is Svādhyāya: the Satapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa is eloquent upon its advantages,<sup>73</sup> and it is asserted
<div n="lb"/>that the joy of the learned Śrotriya, or ‘student,’ is equal to
<div n="lb"/>the highest joy possible.<sup>74</sup> {@Nāka Maudgalya@} held that study
<div n="lb"/>and the teaching of others were the true penance ({%tapas%}).<sup>75</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>object was the ‘threefold knowledge’ ({%trayī vidyā%}), that of the
<div n="lb"/>Ṛc, Yajus, and Sāman,<sup>76</sup> a student of all three Vedas being
<div n="lb"/>called {%tri-śukriya%}<sup>77</sup> or {%tri-śukra,%}<sup>78</sup> ‘thrice pure.’ Other objects
<div n="lb"/>of study are enumerated in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>79</sup> in the
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka,<sup>80</sup> the Chāndogya Upaniṣad,<sup>81</sup> etc. (See
<div n="lb"/>{@Itihāsa, Purāṇa; Gāthā, Nārāśaṃsī; Brahmodya; Anuśās-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@ana, Anuvyākhyāna, Anvākhyāna, Kalpa,@} 2. {@Brāhmaṇa;@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Vidyā, Kṣatravidyā, Devajanavidyā, Nakṣatravidyā, Bhūta-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@vidyā, Sarpavidyā; Atharvāṅgirasaḥ, Daiva, Nidhi, Pitrya,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Rāśi; Sūtra,@} etc.)
[Page2-087+ 55]
<div n="P"/>Directions as to the exact place and time of study are given
<div n="lb"/>in the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka<sup>82</sup> and in the Sūtras. If study is
<div n="lb"/>carried on in the village, it is to be done silently ({%manasā%}); if
<div n="lb"/>outside, aloud ({%vācā%}).
<div n="P"/>Learning is expected even from persons not normally com-
<div n="lb"/>petent as teachers, such as the {@Carakas,@} who are recognized in
<div n="lb"/>the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>83</sup> as possible sources of information.
<div n="lb"/>Here, too, may be mentioned the cases of Brahmins learning
<div n="lb"/>from princes, though their absolute value is doubtful, for the
<div n="lb"/>priests would naturally represent their patrons as interested in
<div n="lb"/>their sacred science: it is thus not necessary to see in these
<div n="lb"/>notices any real and independent study on the part of the
<div n="lb"/>Kṣatriyas.<sup>84</sup> {@Yājñavalkya@} learnt from {@Janaka,@}<sup>85</sup> {@Uddālaka@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Āruṇi@} and two other Brahmins from {@Pravāhaṇa Jaivali,@}<sup>86</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{@Dṛptabālāki Gārgya@} from {@Ajātaśatru,@}<sup>87</sup> and five Brahmins
<div n="lb"/>under the lead of Aruṇa from {@Aśvapati Kaikeya.@}<sup>88</sup> A few
<div n="lb"/>notices show the real educators of thought: wandering scholars
<div n="lb"/>went through the country<sup>89</sup> and engaged in disputes and
<div n="lb"/>discussions in which a prize was staked by the disputants.<sup>90</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Moreover, kings like Janaka offered rewards to the most learned
<div n="lb"/>of the Brahmins;<sup>91</sup> Ajātaśatru was jealous of his renown, and
<div n="lb"/>imitated his generosity. Again, learned women are several
<div n="lb"/>times mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>92</sup>
<div n="P"/>A special form of disputation was the {@Brahmodya,@} for which
<div n="lb"/>there was a regular place at the Aśvamedha (‘horse sacrifice’)<sup>93</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and at the Daśarātra (‘ten-day festival’).<sup>94</sup> The reward of
<div n="lb"/>learning was the gaining of the title of Kavi or Vipra, ‘sage.’<sup>95</sup>
[Page2-088+ 56]
<div n="P"/>8. {%The Functions of the Brahmin.%} — The Brahmin was required
<div n="lb"/>not merely to practise individual culture, but also to give
<div n="lb"/>others the advantage of his skill, either as a teacher or as a
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial priest, or as a Purohita.
<div n="P"/>As a teacher the Brahmin has, of course, the special duty of
<div n="lb"/>instructing his own son in both study and sacrificial ritual.<sup>96</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The texts give examples of this, such as Āruṇi and {@Śvetaketu,@}<sup>97</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or mythically Varuṇa and Bhṛgu.<sup>98</sup> This fact also appears
<div n="lb"/>from some of the names in the Vaṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>99</sup> of the
<div n="lb"/>Sāmaveda and the Vaṃśa (list of teachers) of the Śāṅkhāyana
<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka.<sup>100</sup> On the other hand, these Vaṃśas and the
<div n="lb"/>Vaṃśas of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa show that a father often
<div n="lb"/>preferred to let his son study under a famous teacher. The
<div n="lb"/>relation of pupil and teacher is described under {@Brahmacarya.@}
<div n="lb"/>A teacher might take several pupils,<sup>101</sup> and he was bound to
<div n="lb"/>teach them with all his heart and soul.<sup>102</sup> He was bound to
<div n="lb"/>reveal everything to his pupil, at any rate to one who was
<div n="lb"/>staying with him for a year ({%saṃvatsara-vāsin%}),<sup>103</sup> an expression
<div n="lb"/>which shows, as was natural, that a pupil might easily
<div n="lb"/>change teachers. But, nevertheless, certain cases of learning
<div n="lb"/>kept secret and only revealed to special persons are enumer-
<div n="lb"/>ated.<sup>104</sup> The exact times and modes of teaching are elaborately
<div n="lb"/>laid down in the Sūtras,<sup>105</sup> but not in the earlier texts.
<div n="P"/>As priest the Brahmin operated in all the greater sacrifices;
<div n="lb"/>the simple domestic ({%gṛhya%}) rites could normally be performed
<div n="lb"/>without his help, but not the more important rites ({%śrauta%}).
[Page2-089+ 66]
<div n="lb"/>The number varied: the ritual literature requires sixteen priests
<div n="lb"/>to be employed at the greatest sacrifices (see {@Ṛtvij@}), but other
<div n="lb"/>rites could be accomplished with four,<sup>106</sup> five,<sup>107</sup> six,<sup>108</sup> seven,<sup>109</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or ten<sup>110</sup> priests. Again, the Kauṣītakins<sup>111</sup> had a seventeenth
<div n="lb"/>priest beside the usual sixteen, the Sadasya, so called because
<div n="lb"/>he watched the performance from the Sadas, ‘seat.’ In one
<div n="lb"/>rite, the Sattra (‘sacrificial session’) of the serpents, the
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>112</sup> adds three more to the sixteen, a
<div n="lb"/>second Unnetṛ, an Abhigara, and an Apagara. The later ritual
<div n="lb"/>places the Brahman at the head of all the priests, but this is
<div n="lb"/>probably not the early view (see {@Brahman@}).
<div n="P"/>The sacrifice ensured, if properly performed, primarily the
<div n="lb"/>advantages of the sacrificer ({%yajamāna%}),<sup>113</sup> but the priest shared
<div n="lb"/>in the profit, besides securing the {@Dakṣiṇās.@} Disputes between
<div n="lb"/>sacrificers and the priests were not rare, as in the case of
<div n="lb"/>{@Viśvantara@} and the {@Śyāparṇas,@}<sup>114</sup> or {@Janamejaya@} and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Asitamṛgas;@}<sup>115</sup> and the {@Aiṣāvīras@} are referred to as undesirable
<div n="lb"/>priests.<sup>116</sup> Moreover, {@Viśvāmitra@} once held the post of Puro-
<div n="lb"/>hita to {@Sudās,@} but gave place to {@Vasiṣṭha.@}
[Page2-090+ 53]
<div n="P"/>The position of {@Purohita@} differed considerably from that of
<div n="lb"/>the ordinary priest, for the Purohita not merely might officiate
<div n="lb"/>at the sacrifice, but was the officiator in all the private sacrifices
<div n="lb"/>of his king. Hence he could, and undoubtedly sometimes did,
<div n="lb"/>obtain great influence over his master in matters of secular
<div n="lb"/>importance; and the power of the priesthood in political as
<div n="lb"/>opposed to domestic and religious matters, no doubt rested on
<div n="lb"/>the Purohita.
<div n="P"/>There is no recognition in Vedic literature of the rule later
<div n="lb"/>prevailing by which, after spending part of his life as a Brahma-
<div n="lb"/>cārin, and part as a householder, the Brahmin became an
<div n="lb"/>ascetic<sup>117</sup> (later divided into the two stages of Vānaprastha,
<div n="lb"/>‘forest-dweller,’ and Saṃnyāsin, ‘mystic’). Yājñavalkya's
<div n="lb"/>case<sup>118</sup> shows that study of the Absolute might empty life of all
<div n="lb"/>its content for the sage, and drive him to abandon wife and
<div n="lb"/>family. In Buddhist times the same phenomenon is seen<sup>119</sup>
<div n="lb"/>applying to other than Brahmins. The Buddhist texts are
<div n="lb"/>here confirmed in some degree by the Greek authorities.<sup>120</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The practice bears a certain resemblance to the habit of kings,
<div n="lb"/>in the Epic tradition,<sup>121</sup> of retiring to the forest when active life
<div n="lb"/>is over.
<div n="P"/>From the Greek authorities<sup>122</sup> it also appears — what is
<div n="lb"/>certainly the case in the Buddhist literature<sup>123</sup> — that Brahmins
<div n="lb"/>practised the most diverse occupations. It is difficult to say
<div n="lb"/>how far this was true for the Vedic period. The analogy of the
<div n="lb"/>Druids<sup>124</sup> — in some respects very close — suggests that the
<div n="lb"/>Brahmins may have been mainly confined to their professional
<div n="lb"/>tasks, including all the learned professions such as astronomy<sup>125</sup>
[Page2-091+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>and so forth. This is not contradicted by any Vedic evidence,
<div n="lb"/>for instance, the poet of a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>126</sup> says he is a
<div n="lb"/>poet, his father a physician ({@Bhiṣaj@}), and his mother a grinder
<div n="lb"/>of corn ({@Upala-prakṣiṇī@}). This would seem to show that a
<div n="lb"/>Brahmin could be a doctor, while his wife would perform the
<div n="lb"/>ordinary household duties. So a Purohita could perhaps take
<div n="lb"/>the field to assist the king by prayer, as Viśvāmitra,<sup>127</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>later on Vasiṣṭha<sup>128</sup> do, but this does not show that priests
<div n="lb"/>normally fought. Nor do they seem normally to have been
<div n="lb"/>agriculturists or merchants. On the other hand, they kept
<div n="lb"/>cattle: a Brahmacārin's duty was to watch his master's
<div n="lb"/>cattle.<sup>129</sup> It is therefore needless to suppose that they could
<div n="lb"/>not, and did not, on occasion turn to agricultural or mercan-
<div n="lb"/>tile pursuits, as they certainly did later. But it must be
<div n="lb"/>remembered that in all probability there was more purity of
<div n="lb"/>blood, and less pressure of life, among the Brahmins of the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic age than later in Buddhist times, when the Vedic
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial apparatus was falling into grave disrepute.
<div n="P"/>It is clear that the Brahmins, whatever their defects, repre-
<div n="lb"/>sented the intellectual side of Vedic life, and that the Kṣatriyas,
<div n="lb"/>if they played a part in that life, did so only in a secondary
<div n="lb"/>degree, and to a minor extent. It is natural to suppose that
<div n="lb"/>the Brahmins also composed ballads, the precursors of the
<div n="lb"/>epic; for though none such have survived, a few stanzas of this
<div n="lb"/>character, celebrating the generosity of patrons, have been
<div n="lb"/>preserved by being embedded in priestly compositions. A
<div n="lb"/>legend in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>130</sup> shows clearly that the
<div n="lb"/>Brahmins regarded civilization as being spread by them only:
[Page2-092+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>{@Kosala@} and {@Videha,@} no doubt settled by Āryan tribes, are only
<div n="lb"/>rendered civilized and habitable by the influence of pious
<div n="lb"/>Brahmins. We need not doubt that the non-Brahminical
<div n="lb"/>tribes (see {@Vrātya@}) had attained intellectual as well as material
<div n="lb"/>civilization, but it is reasonable to assume that their civilization
<div n="lb"/>was inferior to that of the Brahmins, for the history of
<div n="lb"/>Hinduism is the conquest by the Brahmins — not by arms, but
<div n="lb"/>by mind — of the tribes Āryan and non-Āryan originally beyond
<div n="lb"/>the pale.

<L>2223<pc>2-092<k1>brAhmaRa<k2>brAhmaRa<h>2
2. {@Brāhmaṇa,@}¦ ‘religious explanation,’<sup>1</sup> is the title of a class
<div n="lb"/>of books which as such are only mentioned in the Nirukta<sup>2</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka,<sup>3</sup> and then in the Sūtras, where the
<div n="lb"/>names of the Brāhmaṇas occur, showing that literary works
<div n="lb"/>were in existence.
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 25, 15; iii.
<div n="lb"/>45, 8; vi. 25, 1, etc.; Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 1, 9, 5; 5, 2, 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 2, 4, 1, etc. In the Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa and the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇ-
<div n="lb"/>yaka, i. and ii., the use is constant.</F>
<F>2) ii. 16; xiii. 7.</F>
<F>3) ii. 10.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2225<pc>2-092<k1>brAhmaRAcCaMsin<k2>brAhmaRAcCaMsin
{@Brāhmaṇāc-chaṃsin@}¦ (‘reciting after the Brāhmaṇa — {%i.e.,%}
<div n="lb"/>Brahman’) is the name of a priest in the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>1</sup> In the
<div n="lb"/>technical division of the sacrificial priests ({@Ṛtvij@}) he is classed
<div n="lb"/>with the Brahman,<sup>2</sup> but it is clear that he was really a Hotraka
<div n="lb"/>or assistant of the Hotṛ.<sup>3</sup> According to Oldenberg,<sup>4</sup> he was
<div n="lb"/>known to the Rigveda as {@Brahman.@} This is denied by
<div n="lb"/>Geldner,<sup>5</sup> who sees in Brahman merely the ‘superintending
<div n="lb"/>priest’ or the ‘priest.’
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vi. 4, 2; 6, 3.
<div n="lb"/>4; 10, 1; 18, 5; vii. 1, 2; Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xxviii. 3; Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 7, 6, 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iv. 2, 3, 13, etc.</F>
<F>2) Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10, 144.</F>
<F>3) {%E.g.,%} Āśvalāyana Srauta Sūtra, v. 10,
<div n="lb"/>10; Weber, {%op. cit.,%} 9, 374-376.</F>
<F>4) {%Religion des Veda,%} 396.</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 145 {%et seq. Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>{@Purohita.@}</F>

<L>2229<pc>2-093<k1>BagIraTaEkzvAka<k2>BagIraTaEkzvAka
{@Bhagī-ratha Aikṣvāka@}¦ (‘descendant of {@Ikṣvāku@}’) is the
<div n="lb"/>name of a king in the Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa (iv. 6,
<div n="lb"/>1. 2). It is important to note that he is regarded as being on
<div n="lb"/>friendly terms with the {@Kuru-Pañcālas,@} which points to the
<div n="lb"/>Ikṣvākus being allied to that people, and not belonging (as is
<div n="lb"/>the case in the Buddhist books) to the east of India.
<LEND>

<L>2230<pc>2-093<k1>BaNga<k2>BaNga
{@Bhaṅga,@}¦ ‘hemp,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> In the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>2</sup> it is an epithet of Soma, presumably<sup>3</sup> in the sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘intoxicating,’ which then came to designate hemp.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) xi. 6, 15; conceivably in Śāṅkh-
<div n="lb"/>āyana Āraṇyaka, xii. 14, but not prob-
<div n="lb"/>ably.</F>
<F>2) ix. 61, 13.</F>
<F>3) Schrader, {%Prehistoric Antiquities,%} 299.</F>
<F>4) Hence the modern ‘Bang’ or
<div n="lb"/>Bhang,’ an intoxicant made from the
<div n="lb"/>dried leaves and small stalks of hemp,
<div n="lb"/>taken either by smoking or by eating
<div n="lb"/>when mixed up into a sweetmeat.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 68;
<div n="lb"/>Grierson, {%Indian Antiquary,%} 23, 260;
<div n="lb"/>Yule and Burnell, {%Hobson-Jobson, s.v.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Bang.%}</F>

<L>2238<pc>2-094<k1>Barata<k2>Barata
{@Bharata@}¦ is the name of a people of great importance in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda and the later literature. In the Rigveda they appear
<div n="lb"/>prominently in the third and seventh Maṇḍalas in connexion
[Page2-095+ 65]
<div n="lb"/>with {@Sudās@} and the {@Tṛtsus,@}<sup>1</sup> while in the sixth Maṇḍala they
<div n="lb"/>are associated with {@Divodāsa.@}<sup>2</sup> In one passage<sup>3</sup> the Bharatas
<div n="lb"/>are, like the Tṛtsus, enemies of the {@Pūrus:@} there can be little
<div n="lb"/>doubt that Ludwig's view of the identity of the Bharatas and
<div n="lb"/>and Tṛtsus is practically correct. More precisely Oldenberg<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>considers that the Tṛtsus are the {@Vasiṣṭhas,@} the family singers
<div n="lb"/>of the Bharatas; while Geldner<sup>6</sup> recognizes, with perhaps more
<div n="lb"/>probability, in the Tṛtsus the royal family of the Bharatas.
<div n="lb"/>That the Tṛtsus and Bharatas were enemies, as Zimmer<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>holds, is most improbable even on geographical grounds, for the
<div n="lb"/>Tṛtsus in Zimmer's view<sup>8</sup> occupied the country to the east of
<div n="lb"/>the {@Paruṣṇī@} (Ravi), and the Bharatas must therefore be
<div n="lb"/>regarded as coming against the Tṛtsus from the west, whereas
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>9</sup> recognizes two Bharata chiefs on the {@Sarasvatī,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Āpayā,@} and {@Dṛṣadvatī@} — that is, in the holy land of India, the
<div n="lb"/>{@Madhyadeśa.@} Hillebrandt<sup>10</sup> sees in the connexion of the
<div n="lb"/>Tṛtsus and the Bharatas a fusion of two tribes; but this is not
<div n="lb"/>supported by any evidence beyond the fact that in his opinion
<div n="lb"/>some such theory is needed to explain Divodāsa's appearing in
<div n="lb"/>connexion with the {@Bharadvāja@} family, while Sudās, his son,
<div n="P"/>^4 Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 172
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}
[Page2-096+ 65]
<div n="lb"/>or perhaps grandson ({%cf.%} {@Pijavana@}), is connected with the
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭhas and the {@Viśvāmitras.@}
<div n="P"/>In the later literature the Bharatas appear as especially
<div n="lb"/>famous. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup> mentions Bharata Dauḥ-
<div n="lb"/>ṣanti as a king, sacrificer of the Aśvamedha (‘horse sacrifice’)
<div n="lb"/>and {@Śatānīka Sātrājita,@} as another Bharata who offered that
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice. The Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>12</sup> mentions Bharata Dauḥ-
<div n="lb"/>ṣanti as receiving the kingly coronation from {@Dīrghatamas@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Māmateya,@} and Śatānīka as being consecrated by {@Somaśuṣman@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Vājaratnāyana,@} a priest whose name is of quite late origin.
<div n="lb"/>The geographical position of the Bharata people is clearly
<div n="lb"/>shown by the fact that the Bharata kings win victories over the
<div n="lb"/>{@Kāśis,@} and make offerings on the {@Yamunā@} (Jumna) and {@Gaṅgā@}
<div n="lb"/>(Ganges).<sup>13</sup> Moreover, in the formula of the king's proclama-
<div n="lb"/>tion for the people, the variants recorded<sup>14</sup> include {%Kuravaḥ,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Pañcālāḥ, Kuru-Pañcālāḥ,%} and {%Bharatāḥ;%} and the Mahābhārata
<div n="lb"/>consistently recognizes the royal family of the {@Kurus@} as a
<div n="lb"/>Bharata family.<sup>15</sup> It is therefore extremely probable that
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg<sup>16</sup> is right in holding that the Bharatas in the times
<div n="lb"/>of the Brāhmaṇas were merging in the Kuru-Pañcāla people.
<div n="P"/>The ritual practices of the Bharatas are repeatedly mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>17</sup> the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>18</sup> the
[Page2-097+ 67]
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>19</sup> and the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka.<sup>20</sup> Already
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda<sup>21</sup> there is mention made of Agni Bhārata (‘of
<div n="lb"/>the Bharatas’). In the Āprī hymns<sup>22</sup> occurs a goddess
<div n="lb"/>Bhāratī, the personified divine protective power of the
<div n="lb"/>Bharatas: her association in the hymns with Sarasvatī reflects
<div n="lb"/>the connexion of the Bharatas with the Sarasvatī in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>9</sup> Again, in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>23</sup> Agni is
<div n="lb"/>referred to as {%brāhmaṇa Bhārata,%} ‘priest of the Bharatas,’ and
<div n="lb"/>is invited to dispose of the offering {%Manuṣvat Bharatavat,%} ‘like
<div n="lb"/>Manu,’ ‘like Bharata.’<sup>24</sup>
<div n="P"/>In one or two passages<sup>25</sup> Sudās or Divodāsa and, on the
<div n="lb"/>other hand, Purukutsa or Trasadasyu appear in a friendly
<div n="lb"/>relation. Possibly this points, as Oldenberg<sup>26</sup> suggests, to the
<div n="lb"/>union of Bharatas and Pūrus with the Kurus.
<div n="P"/>A Bharata is referred to in the fifth Maṇḍala of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda:<sup>27</sup> who he was is uncertain.
<F>1) iii. 53, 9. 12, 24; 33, 11, 12 (Viśvā
<div n="lb"/>mitra, who is accordingly hailed as
<div n="lb"/>{%Bharata-ṛṣabha,%} ‘bull of the Bharatas,’
<div n="lb"/>in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 17, 7);
<div n="lb"/>vii. 8, 4; 33, 6, in which passage a
<div n="lb"/>defeat of the Bharatas, and their rescue
<div n="lb"/>by the aid of Vasiṣṭha, is clearly referred
<div n="lb"/>to; not, as was formerly thought ({%e.g.,%}
<div n="lb"/>Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 12, 354; Zimmer,

<L>2239<pc>2-097<k1>BaradvAja<k2>BaradvAja
{@Bharad-vāja@}¦ is the name of the reputed<sup>1</sup> author of the sixth
<div n="lb"/>Maṇḍala of the Rigveda. The attribution is so far correct that
<div n="lb"/>Bharadvāja<sup>2</sup> and the Bharadvājas<sup>3</sup> are repeatedly mentioned as
<div n="lb"/>singers in that Maṇḍala. Judging by the tone of the references
<div n="lb"/>to Bharadvāja, he can hardly be deemed to have been a con-
<div n="lb"/>temporary of any of the hymns.<sup>4</sup> According to the Pañcaviṃśa
[Page2-098+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>5</sup> he was the Purohita of {@Divodāsa.@} This interpreta-
<div n="lb"/>tion is to be preferred to that of Roth,<sup>6</sup> who suggests that he
<div n="lb"/>and Divodāsa were identical. His connexion with the house of
<div n="lb"/>Divodāsa also appears from the statement of the Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>7</sup> that Bharadvāja gave {@Pratardana@} the kingdom. It
<div n="lb"/>is unnecessary to suppose that the same Bharadvāja was meant
<div n="lb"/>in both cases, and that Pratardana was a son of Divodāsa: the
<div n="lb"/>later Saṃhitās refer to Bharadvāja, like the other great sages,
<div n="lb"/>irrespective of chronology.
<div n="P"/>The Bharadvājas in their poems mention {@Bṛbu, Bṛsaya,@} and
<div n="lb"/>the {@Pārāvatas.@}<sup>8</sup> Hillebrandt<sup>9</sup> has pointed out that they are also
<div n="lb"/>connected with the {@Sṛñjayas.@} In particular, the Śāṅkhāyana
<div n="lb"/>Śrauta Sūtra<sup>10</sup> mentions that Bharadvāja gained largesse from
<div n="lb"/>{@Prastoka Sārñjaya@} and Bṛbu. But it is very doubtful if it is
<div n="lb"/>correct to place all these people and Divodāsa in Arachosia
<div n="lb"/>and Drangiana.
<div n="P"/>Bharadvāja as an author and a seer is frequently referred to
<div n="lb"/>in the later Saṃhitās<sup>11</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) {%Cf.%} Āśvalāyana Gṛhya Sūtra, iii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>2; Śāṅkhāyana Gṛhya Sūtra, iv. 10;
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhaddevatā, v. 102 {%et seq.,%} where he
<div n="lb"/>is said to be a son of Bṛhaspati, and a
<div n="lb"/>grandson of Aṅgiras ({%cf.%} Rv. vi. 2, 10;
<div n="lb"/>11, 3, etc.); Arnold, {%Vedic Metre,%} 61, 62.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 15, 3; 16, 5. 33; 17, 4;
<div n="lb"/>31, 4; 48, 7. 13; 63, 10; 65, 6. See
<div n="lb"/>also Rv. i. 112, 13; 116, 18; x. 150, 5;
<div n="lb"/>181, 2.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vi. 10, 6; 16, 33; 17, 14;
<div n="lb"/>23, 10; 25, 9; 35, 4; 47, 25; 59, 15.
<div n="lb"/>See also Rv. i. 59, 7.</F>
<F>4) Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 210
<div n="lb"/>212.</F>
<F>5) xv. 3, 7.</F>
<F>6) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} See
<div n="lb"/>Rv. i. 116, 18; vi. 16, 5; 31, 4.</F>
<F>7) xxi. 10 ({%Indische Studien,%} 3, 478).</F>
<F>8) vi. 61, 1-3.</F>
<F>9) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 104.</F>
<F>10) xvi. 11, 11.</F>
<F>11) Av. ii. 12, 2; iv. 29, 5; xviii. 3, 16;
<div n="lb"/>xix. 48, 6; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvi. 19;
<div n="lb"/>xx. 9; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 19;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 8, 4; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 55,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>12) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vi. 18; viii. 3;

<div n="lb"/>{@Kakṣīvant.@} This combination is borne out by the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>where Kakṣīvant and Svanaya are mentioned in the same
<div n="lb"/>verse,<sup>3</sup> while Svanaya must be meant in the verse of the same

<div n="lb"/>(Indus). Roth's<sup>5</sup> view that Bhāvya here is perhaps a gerundive
<div n="lb"/>meaning to be ‘reverenced’ is not probable. Ludwig<sup>6</sup> thinks
<div n="lb"/>Svanaya was connected with the {@Nahuṣas.@}

<L>2273<pc>2-104<k1>Bizaj<k2>Bizaj
{@Bhiṣaj,@}¦ ‘physician,’ is a word of common occurrence in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> There is no trace whatever in the former
<div n="lb"/>text of the profession being held in disrepute: the Aśvins,<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Varuṇa,<sup>4</sup> and Rudra<sup>5</sup> are all called physicians. On the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, in the Dharma literature<sup>6</sup> this profession is utterly
[Page2-105+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>despised. This dislike is found as early as the Yajurveda
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās,<sup>7</sup> where the Aśvins are condemned because of their
<div n="lb"/>having to do with the practice of medicine ({%bheṣaja%}), on the
<div n="lb"/>ground that it brings them too much among men, an allusion
<div n="lb"/>to the caste dislike of promiscuous contact.
<div n="P"/>The Rigveda<sup>8</sup> contains a hymn in which a physician cele-
<div n="lb"/>brates his plants and their healing powers. Moreover, wonder-
<div n="lb"/>ful cures are referred to as performed by the Aśvins: the
<div n="lb"/>healing of the lame<sup>9</sup> and of the blind;<sup>10</sup> the rejuvenation of the
<div n="lb"/>aged {@Cyavana@}<sup>11</sup> and of {@Puraṃdhi's@} husband;<sup>12</sup> the giving of an
<div n="lb"/>iron leg ({%jaṅghā āyasī%}) to {@Viśpalā,@}<sup>13</sup> a deed only more wonderful
<div n="lb"/>if we assume that Viśpalā was a mare, as has been suggested by
<div n="lb"/>Pischel.<sup>14</sup> It would in all probability be a mistake to assume<sup>15</sup>
<div n="lb"/>that the Vedic Indians had any surgical skill: they no doubt
<div n="lb"/>applied simples to wounds,<sup>16</sup> but both their medicine and their
<div n="lb"/>surgery must have been most primitive. All that the Atharva-
<div n="lb"/>veda shows in regard to medicine is the use of herbs combined
<div n="lb"/>with spells,<sup>17</sup> and of water ({%cf.%} {@Jalāṣa@}), remedies Indo-European
<div n="lb"/>in character, but not of much scientific value. On the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, the knowledge of anatomy shown (see {@Śarīra@}), though
<div n="lb"/>betraying grave inaccuracies, is not altogether insignificant;
<div n="lb"/>but that was due no doubt mainly to the practice of dissecting
<div n="lb"/>animals at the sacrifice.
<div n="P"/>There is some evidence in the Rigveda<sup>18</sup> that the practice of
<div n="lb"/>medicine was already a profession; this is supported by the
<div n="lb"/>inclusion of a physician in the list of victims at the Puruṣa-
<div n="lb"/>medha (‘human sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda.<sup>19</sup> According to
[Page2-106+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield,<sup>20</sup> a hymn of the Atharvaveda<sup>21</sup> contains a physician's
<div n="lb"/>deprecation of the use of home-made remedies instead of
<div n="lb"/>reliance on his professional training.
<F>1) ii. 33, 4; vi. 50, 7; ix. 112, 1;
<div n="lb"/>{%bheṣaja,%} adjective, ii. 33, 7; x. 137, 6;
<div n="lb"/>substantive, i. 23, 19. 20; ii. 33, 2. 4;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 74, 3; vii. 46, 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 29, 1; vi. 24, 2; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 9, 2; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, xvi. 5; xix. 12. 88; xxx. 10, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>{%bheṣaja,%} adjective, Av. vi. 109, 3; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 45, etc.; sub-
<div n="lb"/>stantive, Av. v. 29, 1; vi. 21, 2; xi. 1,
<div n="lb"/>9, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 116, 16; 157, 6; viii. 18, 8;
<div n="lb"/>86, 1; x. 39, 3. 5; Av. vii. 53, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 18.</F>
<F>4) See Rv. i. 24, 9.</F>
<F>5) Rv. ii. 33, 4. 7.</F>
<F>6) See Āpastamba Dharma Sūtra, i. 6,

<L>2280<pc>2-107<k1>Burij<k2>Burij
{@Bhurij@}¦ (used in the dual only) is a word of somewhat
<div n="lb"/>doubtful sense. Roth<sup>1</sup> regarded it as meaning in some
<div n="lb"/>passages<sup>2</sup> ‘scissors,’ and in others<sup>3</sup> an apparatus consisting of
<div n="lb"/>two arms used by the chariot-maker for fixing the wood at
<div n="lb"/>which he worked, being of the nature of a carpenter's vice. See
<div n="lb"/>also {@Ksura@}
<F>1) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v. Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 466.</F>
<F>2) Rv. viii. 4, 16; Av. xx. 127, 4.</F>
<F>3) Rv. iv. 2, 14; ix. 26, 4; 71, 5.
<div n="lb"/>where Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 239-
<div n="lb"/>243, considers that the shafts of the
<div n="lb"/>chariot are meant ({%cf.%} Gobhila Gṛhya
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, iii. 4, 31, whence it appears that
<div n="lb"/>the chariot-pole, spoken of as having
<div n="lb"/>two arms, was forked). The same view
<div n="lb"/>regarding the passages cited in n. 2
<div n="lb"/>gives the sense of a stropping apparatus,
<div n="lb"/>consisting of two pieces of wood, be-
<div n="lb"/>tween which a grindstone moves.

<div n="lb"/>255.</F>

<L>2289<pc>2-109<k1>Bfgu<k2>Bfgu
{@Bhṛgu@}¦ is a sage of almost entirely mythical character in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda and later. He counts as a son of Varuṇa,<sup>1</sup> bearing
<div n="lb"/>the patronymic Vāruṇi.<sup>2</sup> In the plural the Bhṛgus are
<div n="lb"/>repeatedly<sup>3</sup> alluded to as devoted to the fire cult. They are
<div n="lb"/>clearly<sup>4</sup> no more than a group of ancient priests and ancestors
<div n="lb"/>with an eponymous Bhṛgu<sup>5</sup> in the Rigveda, except in three
<div n="lb"/>passages,<sup>6</sup> where they are evidently regarded as an historic
<div n="lb"/>family. It is not clear, however, whether they were priests or
<div n="lb"/>warriors: in the battle of the ten kings the Bhṛgus appear with
<div n="lb"/>the {@Druhyus,@} perhaps as their priests, but this is not certain.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the later literature the Bhṛgus are a real family, with sub-
<div n="lb"/>divisions like the {@Aitaśāyana,@} according to the Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa.<sup>8</sup> The Bhṛgus are mentioned as priests in connexion
<div n="lb"/>with various rites, such as the Agnisthāpana<sup>9</sup> and the Daśa-
<div n="lb"/>peyakratu.<sup>10</sup> In many passages they are conjoined with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Aṅgirases.@}<sup>11</sup> the close association of the two families is shown
[Page2-110+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>by the fact that Cyavana is called either a Bhārgava or an
<div n="lb"/>Āṅgirasa in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>12</sup> In the Atharvaveda<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the name of Bhṛgu is selected to exemplify the dangers incurred
<div n="lb"/>by the oppressors of Brahmans: the {@Sṛñjaya Vaitahavyas@}
<div n="lb"/>perish in consequence of an attack on Bhṛgu. In the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>14</sup> also Bhṛgu has this representative character. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>{@Bhṛgavāṇa@} and {@Bhārgava.@}
<F>1) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 6, 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, ix. 1. {%Cf.%} Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xviii. 9, 2; Nirukta,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 17.</F>
<F>2) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 34, and
<div n="lb"/>n. 14. For a different form of the legend,
<div n="lb"/>{%cf.%} Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 8, 2, 5.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 58, 6; 127, 7; 143, 4; ii. 4, 2;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 2, 4; iv. 7, 1, etc. See Macdonell,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedic Mythology,%} 51. The legend of
<div n="lb"/>their chariot-making (Rv. iv. 16, 20;
<div n="lb"/>x. 39, 14) may be due, as Roth, St.
<div n="lb"/>Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.,%} suggests,
<div n="lb"/>to a confusion with the Ṛbhus. It
<div n="lb"/>may, however, be an allusion to the
<div n="lb"/>historic Bhṛgus, whom we find in the
<div n="lb"/>battle of the ten kings.</F>
<F>4) As shown by the legend of fire
<div n="lb"/>having been brought to them by
<div n="lb"/>Mātariśvan, Rv. iii. 5, 10.</F>
<F>5) i. 60, 1, where, however, Roth,
<div n="lb"/>{%loc. cit.,%} takes the singular in a collective
<div n="lb"/>sense, an interpretation which may be
<div n="lb"/>correct, but is not necessary.</F>
<F>6) Rv. vii. 18, 6; viii. 3, 9; 6, 18, to
<div n="lb"/>which list, given by Macdonell, {%loc. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>Roth adds viii. 102, 4, {%Aurva-Bhṛgu-vat,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘like Aurva and Bhṛgu.’ {%Cf.%} the fact
<div n="lb"/>that the {@Aurvas,@} in the Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, vi. 33, take the place of the Bhṛgus
<div n="lb"/>of the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xxx. 5.</F>
<F>7) In viii. 3, 9; 6, 18; 102, 4, the
<div n="lb"/>reference to a priestly family is the
<div n="lb"/>more natural; in vii. 18, 6, warriors
<div n="lb"/>may be meant. {%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the American Oriental Society,%} 15,
<div n="lb"/>262, n., where he cites ix. 101, 13, as
<div n="lb"/>perhaps denoting the same thing.</F>
<F>8) xxx. 5. See n. 6.</F>
<F>9) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 5, 2;
<div n="lb"/>v. 6, 8, 6; Av. iv. 14, 5; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, i. 4, 1 (p. 48).</F>
<F>10) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 8, 18; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 8, 2, 5; Pañcavimśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xviii. 9, 2.</F>
<F>11) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 1, 7, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 1, 8; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, i. 18; Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 1, 4, 8; iii. 2, 7, 6; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 2, 1, 13, etc. {%Cf.%} Rv.
<div n="lb"/>viii. 35, 3; 43, 13; x. 14, 6, in the
<div n="lb"/>first and last of which passages the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvans also occur. See Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} xxvii. n. 2.
<div n="lb"/>Hence, in the Atharvanic ritual texts,
<div n="lb"/>the term {%Bhṛgvaṅgirasaḥ%} is applied to
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda (Bloomfield, {%Atharva-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%veda,%} 9, 10, 107 {%et seq.%}).</F>
<F>12) iv. 1, 5, 1.</F>
<F>13) v. 19, 1.</F>
<F>14) ii. 20. In the Jaiminīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 42-44 ({%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 15, 204), Bhṛgu Vāruṇi
<div n="lb"/>appears as a student. {%Cf.%} Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, iii. 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 169-173; Ludwig, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, 3, 140; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%}
<div n="lb"/>12, 443 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>2293<pc>2-110<k1>Beda<k2>Beda<h>1
1. {@Bheda,@}¦ one of the enemies of {@Sudās@} and the {@Tṛtsu-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Bharatas,@} was defeated by the former in the {@Yamunā@} (Jumna),<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>apparently in a second conflict fought after the battle of the ten
<div n="lb"/>kings, in which Sudās successfully defended his western frontier
<div n="lb"/>against the confederate foes. The {@Ajas, Śigrus,@} and {@Yakṣus,@}
<div n="lb"/>who are mentioned as also defeated, may have been united
<div n="lb"/>under his leadership if he was a king; or the Bhedas may have
<div n="lb"/>been a separate people, as Roth<sup>2</sup> thinks. Hopkins'<sup>3</sup> opinion
<div n="lb"/>that the defeat was on the {@Paruṣṇī,@} Yamunā being another
[Page2-111+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>name of that stream, is most improbable; nor is the view that
<div n="lb"/>Bheda was one of the ten kings essential.<sup>4</sup> {%Cf.%} {@Turvaśa.@}
<F>1) Rv. vii. 18, 18. 19; 33, 3; 83, 4.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 12
<div n="lb"/>(the word is always used in the
<div n="lb"/>singular).</F>
<F>3) {%India, Old and New,%} 52.</F>
<F>4) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 15, 260 {%et seq.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Griffith, {%Hymns of the Rigveda,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>20, n.; Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 126;
<div n="lb"/>Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 12, 319, 327.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2294<pc>2-111<k1>Beda<k2>Beda<h>2
2. {@Bheda@}¦ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> as having come
<div n="lb"/>to a bad end because he refused a cow ({%vaśā%}) to Indra when
<div n="lb"/>asked for it. That he is different from the preceding Bheda, as
<div n="lb"/>Roth<sup>2</sup> assumes, is not certain. Indeed, it may very well be
<div n="lb"/>that his defeat led to his being chosen as the representative of
<div n="lb"/>the evil end of the wicked man. Moreover, the irreligious
<div n="lb"/>character of Bheda may be ascribed to his being a leader of
<div n="lb"/>non-Āryan folk, if the {@Ajas@} and {@Śigrus,@} with whom in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda he is connected or associated were, as is possible,
<div n="lb"/>though by no means certain, un-Āryan tribes of totemists.<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) xii. 4, 49. 50.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 13.</F>
<F>3) {%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 153, who inclines to see in them
<div n="lb"/>totemistic tribes, but the names furnish
<div n="lb"/>the sole support of this conjecture. On
<div n="lb"/>this supposition they were probably
<div n="lb"/>non-Āryan. {%Cf.%} {@Aja.@}</F>
<LEND>

<L>2295<pc>2-111<k1>Bezaja<k2>Bezaja<h>1
1. {@Bheṣaja,@}¦ denoting a ‘remedial agent,’ ‘medicine,’ is often
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later,<sup>2</sup> being also used in a
<div n="lb"/>figurative sense.<sup>3</sup> Plants,<sup>4</sup> waters,<sup>5</sup> and spells<sup>6</sup> are repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>enumerated as medicines. Most of the medical practices of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda are merely examples of sympathetic magic. For
<div n="lb"/>example, in one hymn<sup>7</sup> the yellow of jaundice is entreated to
<div n="lb"/>pass into yellow birds. In another<sup>8</sup> fever is to be banished by
<div n="lb"/>means of a frog; for the frog, being a potent means of cooling
<div n="lb"/>fire<sup>9</sup> (because of its association with water), is regarded as
<div n="lb"/>analogously effective in banishing the fire of fever. See {@Bhiṣaj.@}
<F>1) i. 89, 4; ii. 33, 2, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 29, 1; vi. 21, 2, etc.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 3, 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>5, 4; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 41.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 97, and {%passim%} in the Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda.</F>
<F>5) i. 23, 19. 20; 34, 6, etc.; Taittirīya

<L>2307<pc>2-113<k1>BrAtf<k2>BrAtf
{@Bhrātṛ@}¦ is the common designation of ‘brother’ from the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> onwards. The word is also applied to a relation or
<div n="lb"/>close friend generally,<sup>2</sup> but here the persons concerned are, it
<div n="lb"/>should be noted, in the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> deities, who are brothers of
<div n="lb"/>one another or of the worshipper. Thus in the early literature
<div n="lb"/>the word has not really lost its precise sense. The derivation
<div n="lb"/>from the root {%bhṛ,%} ‘support,’ is probably correct, designating
<div n="lb"/>the brother as the support of his sister. This harmonizes with
<div n="lb"/>the fact that in Vedic literature the brother plays the part of
<div n="lb"/>protector of his sister when bereft of her father, and that
<div n="lb"/>maidens deprived of their brothers ({%abhrātṛ%}) meet an evil fate.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The gradation of the relations in the home is shown by the
<div n="lb"/>order in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad,<sup>5</sup> where father, mother,
<div n="lb"/>brother, and sister are successively mentioned. Strife between
<div n="lb"/>brothers is occasionally referred to.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) i. 164, 1; iv. 3, 13; v. 34, 4, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Av. i. 14, 2; ii. 13, 5; Taittirīya Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, vi. 2, 8, 4, etc.; {%bhrātṛtva,%} Rv.
<div n="lb"/>viii. 20, 22; 83, 8; x. 108, 10.</F>
<F>2) Böhtlingk and Roth, St. Peters-
<div n="lb"/>burg Dictionary, {%s.v.;%} Delbrück, {%Die%}
<div n="lb"/>{%indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,%}
<div n="lb"/>462.</F>
<F>3) i. 161, 1; 170, 2; iii. 53, 5; iv. 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 51, 5; viii. 43, 16. {%Cf.%} Av. iv. 4, 5;
<div n="lb"/>v. 22, 12.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 124, 7; iv. 5, 5; Av. i. 17, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 328. {%Cf.%}

<L>2308<pc>2-114<k1>BrAtfvya<k2>BrAtfvya
{@Bhrātṛvya@}¦ is found in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>where, being named with brother and sister, it must be an
<div n="lb"/>expression of relationship. The sense appears to be ‘(father's)
<div n="lb"/>brother's son,’ ‘cousin,’<sup>2</sup> this meaning alone accounting for the
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘rival,’ ‘enemy,’ found elsewhere in the Atharvaveda,<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and repeatedly in the other Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>4</sup> In
<div n="lb"/>an undivided family the relations of cousins would easily
<div n="lb"/>develop into rivalry and enmity. The original meaning may,
<div n="lb"/>however, have been ‘nephew,’<sup>5</sup> as the simple etymological
<div n="lb"/>sense would be ‘brother's son’; but this seems not to account
<div n="lb"/>for the later meaning so well. The Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>6</sup> pre-
<div n="lb"/>scribes the telling of a falsehood to a Bhrātṛvya, who, further,
<div n="lb"/>is often given the epithets ‘hating’ ({%dviṣan%}) and ‘evil’ ({%apriya,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%pāpman%}) in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>7</sup> The Athar-
<div n="lb"/>vaveda<sup>8</sup> also contains various spells, which aim at destroying or
<div n="lb"/>expelling one's ‘rivals.’
<F>1) v. 22, 12, and perhaps x. 3, 9.</F>
<F>2) The word is rendered ‘cousin’ by
<div n="lb"/>Whitney in his Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda (x. 6, 1; xv. 1, 8).</F>
<F>3) ii. 18, 1; viii. 10, 18. 33; x. 9, 1.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 9, 2,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, x. 7; xxvii. 8;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 17; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iii. 7, etc.; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 1, 1, 21, etc.; Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xii. 13, 2. {%Cf.%} Rv. viii. 21,
<div n="lb"/>13.</F>
<F>5) Whitney, in his Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda (ii. 18, 1), while rendering
<div n="lb"/>the word by ‘adversary,’ explains it in
<div n="lb"/>a note as meaning literally ‘nephew,’
<div n="lb"/>or ‘brother's son.’</F>
<F>6) xxvii. 8.</F>
<F>7) See several of the passages given
<div n="lb"/>in n. 4.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%Verwandtschaftsnamen,%} 501, 506, 507,
<div n="lb"/>who thinks it means a kind of brother,
<div n="lb"/>and through early family conditions
<div n="lb"/>was restricted to cousins; Böhtlingk

<L>2309<pc>2-114<k1>BrURahan<k2>BrURahan

<div n="lb"/>repeatedly and severely censured in the later Saṃhitās,<sup>1</sup> where

<div n="lb"/>crime is referred to, always with reprobation: this fact alone
<div n="lb"/>shows the erroneousness of the theory<sup>3</sup> that daughters could be
<div n="lb"/>allowed, once born, to die if their fathers so desired.
