<div n="lb"/>and Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 2, 8; 11,
<div n="lb"/>have {%brahma-han%} instead; but see {%ibid.,%}
<div n="lb"/>12.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 9, 15, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, ii. 8, 2; x. 1, 15;
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iv. 3, 22.

<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, ii. 7, 3; 8, 3; Kauṣītaki

<L>2315<pc>2-116<k1>magaDa<k2>magaDa
{@Magadha@}¦ is the name of a people who appear throughout
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature as of little repute. Though the name is not
<div n="lb"/>actually found in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> it occurs in the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>where fever is wished away to the {@Gandhāṛis@} and {@Mūjavants,@}
<div n="lb"/>northern peoples, and to the {@Aṅgas@} and Magadhas, peoples of
<div n="lb"/>the east. Again, in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha
<div n="lb"/>(‘human sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda,<sup>3</sup> the Māgadha, or man of
<div n="lb"/>Magadha, is included as dedicated to {%ati-kruṣṭa,%} ‘loud noise’(?),
<div n="lb"/>while in the {@Vrātya@} hymn of the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup> the Māgadha is
<div n="lb"/>said to be connected with the Vrātya as his Mitra, his Mantra,
<div n="lb"/>his laughter, and his thunder in the four quarters. In the
<div n="lb"/>Śrauta Sūtras<sup>5</sup> the equipment characteristic of the Vrātya is
<div n="lb"/>said to be given, when the latter is admitted into the Āryan
<div n="lb"/>Brahminical community, to a bad Brahmin living in Magadha
<div n="lb"/>({%brahma-bandhu Māgadha-deśīya%}), but this point does not occur
<div n="lb"/>in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>6</sup> On the other hand, respectable
<div n="lb"/>Brahmins sometimes lived there, for the Kauṣītaki Āraṇyaka<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>mentions {@Madhyama, Prātībodhī-putra,@} as {%Magadha-vāsin,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘living in Magadha.’ Oldenberg,<sup>8</sup> however, seems clearly right
<div n="lb"/>in regarding this as unusual.
[Page2-117+ 58]
<div n="P"/>The Magadhas are evidently a people in the Baudhāyana and
<div n="lb"/>other Sūtras,<sup>9</sup> possibly also in the Aitareya Āraṇyaka.<sup>10</sup> It is
<div n="lb"/>therefore most improbable that Zimmer<sup>11</sup> can be right in
<div n="lb"/>thinking that in the Yajurveda<sup>3</sup> and the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Māgadha is not a man of Magadha, but a member of the mixed
<div n="lb"/>caste produced by a {@Vaiśya@} marrying a {@Kṣatriya@} woman.<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>But the theory of mixed castes, in any case open to some
<div n="lb"/>doubt, cannot be accepted when used to explain such obviously
<div n="lb"/>tribal names as Māgadha. The fact that the Māgadha is
<div n="lb"/>often in later times a minstrel is easily accounted for by the
<div n="lb"/>assumption that the country was the home of minstrelsy and
<div n="lb"/>that wandering bards from Magadha were apt to visit the more
<div n="lb"/>western lands. This class the later texts recognize as a caste,
<div n="lb"/>inventing an origin by intermarriage of the old-established
<div n="lb"/>castes.
<div n="P"/>The dislike of the Magadhas, which may be Rigvedic, since
<div n="lb"/>the {@Kīkaṭas@} were perhaps the prototype of the Magadhas, was
<div n="lb"/>in all probability due, as Oldenberg<sup>13</sup> thinks, to the fact that
<div n="lb"/>the Magadhas were not really Brahminized. This is entirely in
<div n="lb"/>accord with the evidence of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>14</sup> that
<div n="lb"/>neither {@Kosala@} nor {@Videha@} were fully Brahminized at an early
<div n="lb"/>date, much less Magadha. Weber<sup>15</sup> suggests two other grounds
<div n="lb"/>that may have influenced the position — the persistence of
<div n="lb"/>aboriginal blood and the growth of Buddhism. The latter
<div n="lb"/>consideration is hardly applicable to the Yajurveda or the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda; but the imperfect Brahminization of the land, if
<div n="lb"/>substituted for it in accordance with Oldenberg's suggestion,
[Page2-118+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>would have some force. The former motive, despite Olden-
<div n="lb"/>berg's doubt, seems fully justified. Pargiter<sup>16</sup> has gone so
<div n="lb"/>far as to suggest that in Magadha the Āryans met and mingled
<div n="lb"/>with a body of invaders from the east by sea. Though there
<div n="lb"/>is no evidence for this view in the Vedic texts, it is reason-
<div n="lb"/>able to suppose that the farther east the Āryans penetrated,
<div n="lb"/>the less did they impress themselves upon the aborigines.
<div n="lb"/>Modern ethnology confirms this {%a priori%} supposition in so far as
<div n="lb"/>it shows Āryan types growing less and less marked as the
<div n="lb"/>eastern part of India is reached, although such evidence is not
<div n="lb"/>decisive in view of the great intermixture of peoples in India.
<F>1) See {@Kikaṭa.@}</F>
<F>2) v. 22, 14, where the Paippalāda
<div n="lb"/>recension has {%mayebhiḥ,%} which is a mere
<div n="lb"/>blunder, but substitutes the {@Kāśis@} for
<div n="lb"/>the Aṅgas.</F>
<F>3) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5, 22;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 1, 1.</F>
<F>4) xv. 2, 1-4.</F>
<F>5) Lāṭyāyar Śrauta Sūtra, viii. 6,

<L>2317<pc>2-118<k1>maGa<k2>maGa
{@Magha@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> denotes ‘bounty,’ and Maghavan<sup>2</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>the regular Vedic name for the ‘generous giver’ of bounties to
<div n="lb"/>priests. It is doubtful whether the Maghavans were more than
<div n="lb"/>this, or had any special rank as a class in Vedic society. See
<div n="lb"/>{@Sabhā.@}

<div n="lb"/>v. 39, 4; 42, 8; vi. 27, 8, etc. So
<div n="lb"/>Magha-tti, ‘giving of gifts,’ Rv. iv. 37,
<div n="lb"/>8; v. 79, 5; viii. 24, 10, etc.; Magha-

<div n="lb"/>x. 156, 2; Maghavat-tva, ‘liberality,’
<div n="lb"/>vi. 27, 3. The word Maghavan is the
<div n="lb"/>epithet {%par excellence%} of Indra in the

<L>2323<pc>2-119<k1>maRi<k2>maRi
{@Maṇi@}¦ is the name in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> of a ‘jewel’ used
<div n="lb"/>as an amulet against all kinds of evil. That either ‘pearl’<sup>3</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>‘diamond’<sup>4</sup> is denoted is not clear.<sup>5</sup> It is evident that the
[Page2-120+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>Maṇi could be strung on a thread ({%sūtra%}), which is referred to
<div n="lb"/>in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup> and elsewhere;<sup>7</sup> the Maṇi was
<div n="lb"/>certainly also worn round the neck, for in the Rigveda<sup>8</sup> occurs
<div n="lb"/>the epithet {%maṇi-grīva,%} ‘having a jewel on the neck.’ An
<div n="lb"/>amulet of Bilva is celebrated in the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka,<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and many varieties of amulet are there enumerated.<sup>10</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>‘jeweller’ ({%maṇi-kāra%}) is mentioned in the list of victims at the
<div n="lb"/>Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda.<sup>11</sup>
<F>1) i. 33, 8.</F>
<F>2) Av. i. 29, 1; ii. 4, 1, 2; viii. 5,
<div n="lb"/>1 {%et seq.;%} x. 6, 24; xii. 1, 44; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 4, 1; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xxxv. 15; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iv. 6;
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta, vii. 23, where Durga, in his
<div n="lb"/>commentary, takes Maṇi as {%āditya-maṇi,%}
<div n="lb"/>or ‘sun-stone,’ while the St. Petersburg
<div n="lb"/>Dictionary, {%s.v.,%} suggests that a crystal
<div n="lb"/>used as a burning glass may be meant.</F>
<F>3) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben%}
<div n="lb"/>53.</F>
<F>5) The expression {%hiraṇya maṇi%} in Rv
<div n="lb"/>i. 33, 8, might possibly mean ‘gold a
<div n="lb"/>an ornament,’ but ‘gold (and) jewels
<div n="lb"/>is more probable. {%Cf.%} Av. xii. 1, 44,
<div n="lb"/>where {%maṇiṃ hiraṇyam%} must mean a
<div n="lb"/>jewel (and) gold.’</F>

<div n="lb"/>i. 18, 8. {%Cf.%} iii. 4, 13; Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ii. 248; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, xii. 3, 4, 2.</F>

<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 3, 1.

<L>2326<pc>2-120<k1>maRqUka<k2>maRqUka
{@Maṇḍūka@}¦ is the name of ‘frog’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the feminine Maṇḍūkī also occurring.<sup>3</sup> The famous frog hymn
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> compares with Brahmins the frogs croaking
[Page2-121+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>as they awake to activity at the beginning of the rains. It has
<div n="lb"/>been explained by Max Müller<sup>5</sup> as a satire on the Brahmins.
<div n="lb"/>Geldner,<sup>6</sup> agreeing with this view, thinks that it is directed by
<div n="lb"/>its {@Vasiṣṭha@} composer against rival Brahmins, probably the
<div n="lb"/>{@Viśvāmitras.@}<sup>7</sup> The view, however, which interprets the hymn
<div n="lb"/>as a rain charm<sup>8</sup> seems on the whole more likely. The frog,
<div n="lb"/>from its connexion with water, was considered to have cooling
<div n="lb"/>properties. Thus after the burning of the dead body the frog
<div n="lb"/>is invited to come to the spot where the cremation has taken
<div n="lb"/>place in order to cool it down.<sup>9</sup> Similarly the frog is invoked
<div n="lb"/>in the Atharvaveda against the fire of fever.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) vii. 103, 1; x. 166, 5.</F>
<F>2) Av. vii. 112, 2; Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>v. 4, 4, 3; 7, 11, 1; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 1; xxi. 7; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 14, 2; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 36;
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xii. 4, 16;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ix. 1, 2, 20
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.;%} Nirukta, ix. 5.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 16, 14; Av. xviii. 3, 60;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 6; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 1, 2; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xvii. 17; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 10, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, vi. 4, 1.</F>
<F>4) vii. 103. {%Cf.%} Av. iv. 15, 12, as
<div n="lb"/>explained by Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 223, where reference is made to frogs
<div n="lb"/>in the clefts of the earth (Iriṇa).</F>
<F>5) {%Ancient Sanskrit Literature,%} 494, 495.</F>
<F>6) {%Rigveda, Kommentar,%} 117.</F>
<F>7) Geldner, {%loc. cit.,%} very plausibly
<div n="lb"/>points out that the last Pāda of this
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭha hymn is borrowed from the
<div n="lb"/>most important Viśvāmitra hymn (Rv.
<div n="lb"/>iii. 53, 7).</F>
<F>8) Yāska, {%Nirukta,%} ix. 5; Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>17, 173-179. {%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Mythology,%} p. 151; {%Sanskrit Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>121, 122.</F>
<F>9) Rv. x. 16, 14. See Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%American Journal of Philology,%} 11, 342-
<div n="lb"/>350; Lanman in Whitney's Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Atharvaveda, 850.</F>
<F>10) Av. vii. 116. See Bloomfield,
<div n="lb"/>{%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 565.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 95.</F>

<L>2328<pc>2-121<k1>matsya<k2>matsya<h>2
2. {@Matsya@}¦ appears to be the name of a people in one passage
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where they are ranged with the other enemies
<div n="lb"/>of {@Sudās,@} although it is possible to see merely the sense of
<div n="lb"/>‘fish’ in that passage. In the list of Aśvamedhins, ‘offerers of
<div n="lb"/>the horse sacrifice,’ in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>2</sup> {@Dhvasan@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Dvaitavana@} is mentioned as a Matsya king ({@Mātsya@}). The
<div n="lb"/>Matsyas as a people occur also in the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad<sup>3</sup> in
[Page2-122+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>connexion with the {@Vaśas,@}<sup>4</sup> and in the Gopatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>connexion with {@Śālvas.@} In Manu<sup>6</sup> the {@Kurukṣetra,@} the
<div n="lb"/>Matsyas, the {@Pancālas,@} and the {@Śūrasenakas@} comprise the
<div n="lb"/>land of the Brahmin Ṛṣis ({%brahmarṣi-deśa%}). There is no
<div n="lb"/>reason to doubt that the Matsyas occupied much the same
<div n="lb"/>territory as in Epic times, say Alwar, Jaipur, Bharatpur.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) vii. 18, 6.</F>
<F>2) xiii. 5, 4, 9.</F>
<F>3) iv. 1.</F>
<F>4) This is the most probable reading,
<div n="lb"/>which results from a comparison with
<div n="lb"/>Gopatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 2, 9, where
<div n="lb"/>{%Śālva-Matsyeṣu%} is followed by {%savaśa-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Uśīnareṣu%} (misprinted {%śavaśa-%}). See
<div n="lb"/>Keith, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>1908, 367. The older view was {%Satvan-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Matsyeṣu,%} Max Müller, {%Sacred Books of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the East,%} 1, lxxvii, following Cowell;
<div n="lb"/>St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v. Satvant.%}</F>
<F>5) i. 2, 9.</F>
<F>6) ii. 19; vii. 193.</F>
<F>7) See Vincent Smith, {%Zeitschrift der%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%}
<div n="lb"/>56, 675.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} von Schroeder, {%Indiens Literatur%}
<div n="lb"/>{%und Cultur,%} 166; Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 211; Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
<div n="lb"/>127.</F>

<L>2333<pc>2-123<k1>madra<k2>madra

<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad;<sup>1</sup> {@Kāpya Patañcala@} was then living among

<div n="lb"/>in that of a branch, the {@Uttara Madras,@} the ‘northern Madras,’
<div n="lb"/>who are referred to in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> as living

<div n="lb"/>the Upaniṣad were, like the {@Kurus,@} probably settled some-
<div n="lb"/>where in {@Kurukṣetra@} in the {@Madhyadeśa@} or ‘Middle Land.’

<L>2341<pc>2-125<k1>maDyadeSa<k2>maDyadeSa
{@Madhya-deśa,@}¦ the ‘Middle Country,’ is, according to the
<div n="lb"/>Mānava Dharma Śāstra,<sup>1</sup> the land between the Himālaya in
<div n="lb"/>the north, the Vindhya in the south, {@Vinaśana@} in the west,
<div n="lb"/>and Prayāga (now Allahabad) in the east — that is, between the
<div n="lb"/>place where the {@Sarasvatī@} disappears in the desert, and the
<div n="lb"/>point of the confluence of the {@Yamunā@} (Jumna) and the {@Gaṅgā@}
<div n="lb"/>(Ganges). The same authority<sup>2</sup> defines Brahmarṣi-deśa as
<div n="lb"/>denoting the land of {@Kurukṣetra,@} the {@Matsyas, Pañcālas,@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Śūrasenakas,@} and Brahmāvarta<sup>3</sup> as meaning the particularly
<div n="lb"/>holy land between the Sarasvatī and the {@Dṛṣadvatī.@} The
<div n="lb"/>Baudhāyana Dharma Sūtra<sup>4</sup> defines Āryāvarta as the land east
<div n="lb"/>of Vinaśana; west of the Kālaka-vana, ‘Black Forest,’ or rather
<div n="lb"/>Kanakhala, near Hardvār; south of the Himālaya; and north
<div n="lb"/>of the Pāriyātra or the Pāripātra Mountains; adding that, in
<div n="lb"/>the opinion of others,<sup>5</sup> it was confined to the country between
<div n="lb"/>the Yamunā and the Gaṅgā, while the {@Bhāllavins@}<sup>6</sup> took it as
<div n="lb"/>the country between the boundary-river (or perhaps the Saras-
[Page2-126+ 84]
<div n="lb"/>vatī)<sup>7</sup> and the region where the sun rises. The Mānava
<div n="lb"/>Dharma Śāstra,<sup>8</sup> in accord with the Vasiṣṭha Dharma Sūtra,<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>defines Āryāvarta as the region between the Vindhya and the
<div n="lb"/>Himālaya, the two ranges which seem to be the boundaries of
<div n="lb"/>the Āryan world in the Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad also.<sup>10</sup>
<div n="P"/>The term Madhyadeśa is not Vedic, but it is represented in
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup> by the expression {%madhyamā pratiṣṭhā%}
<div n="lb"/>{%diś,%} ‘the middle fixed region,’ the inhabitants of which are
<div n="lb"/>stated to be the Kurus, the Pañcālas, the {@Vaśas,@} and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Uśīnaras.@} The latter two peoples practically disappear later
<div n="lb"/>on, the Madhyadeśa being the country of the Kuru-Pañcālas,
<div n="lb"/>the land where the Brāhmaṇas and the later Saṃhitās were
<div n="lb"/>produced, bounded on the east by the {@Kosala-Videhas,@} and on
<div n="lb"/>the west by the desert. The western tribes are mentioned with
<div n="lb"/>disapproval both in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>12</sup> and the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>13</sup> while the tradition of the Brahminization of the
<div n="lb"/>Kosalas and the Videhas from the Kuru-Pañcāla country is
<div n="lb"/>preserved in the former Brāhmaṇa.<sup>14</sup>
<F>1) ii. 21.</F>
<F>2) ii. 19.</F>
<F>3) ii. 17. 19.</F>
<F>4) i. 2, 9; Vasiṣṭha Dharma Sūtra,
<div n="lb"/>i. 8.</F>
<F>5) Baudhāyana, i. 2, 10; Vasiṣṭha,
<div n="lb"/>i. 12. See on Kanakhala, Hultzsch,
<div n="lb"/>{%Indian Antiquary,%} 34, 179.</F>
<F>6) Baudhāyana, i. 2, 11. 12; Vasiṣṭha,
<div n="lb"/>i. 14. 15, quoting in each case a verse
<div n="lb"/>of the Nidāna (what work is referred
<div n="lb"/>to is not certain; there is similar doubt
<div n="lb"/>as to the quotation in the Nidāna of
<div n="lb"/>the Bhāllavi Brāhmaṇa, according to
<div n="lb"/>the Bṛhaddevatā, v. 23, where see
<div n="lb"/>Macdonell's note, and {%cf.%} Bühler, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 14, 3, n.).</F>
<F>7) The readings are doubtful, varying
<div n="lb"/>between {%sindhur vidhāraṇī%} or {%vidharaṇī%}
<div n="lb"/>and {%sindhur vicaraṇī%} or {%visavaṇī.%} The
<div n="lb"/>latter expression must refer to the
<div n="lb"/>Sarasvatī; the former may, but not
<div n="lb"/>necessarily. Conceivably the Sindhu
<div n="lb"/>(Indus) is meant; for it was a great
<div n="lb"/>boundary, with Āryan tribes to the east
<div n="lb"/>of it.</F>
<F>8) ii. 22.</F>
<F>9) i. 9.</F>
<F>10) ii. 13. {%Cf.%} Keith, {%Śāṅkhāyana%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Āraṇyaka,%} 28, n. 1.</F>
<F>11) viii. 14, 3. The Uśīnaras may be
<div n="lb"/>recognized as in the north, for the
<div n="lb"/>Buddhist texts give Usīragiri as the
<div n="lb"/>northern boundary of the middle
<div n="lb"/>country. See Hultzsch, {%Indian Anti-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%quary,%} 34, 179.</F>
<F>12) ix. 3, 1, 8.</F>
<F>13) iii. 44, 3; Ludwig, Translation of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, 3, 245.</F>
<F>14) i. 4, 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Bühler, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>14, 2, 3; 146, 147, who points out that
<div n="lb"/>the Pāripātra Mountains are a part of
<div n="lb"/>the Vindhya range in Mālvā, and who
<div n="lb"/>suggests that the western boundary was
<div n="lb"/>originally the Ādarśa Mountains; for
<div n="lb"/>the reading of the manuscripts, and
<div n="lb"/>of the scholiast Kṛṣṇapaṇḍita, in the
<div n="lb"/>Vasiṣṭha Dharma Sūtra, i. 8, is {%prāg%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ādarśanāt,%} not {%adarśanāt%} (corresponding
<div n="lb"/>with the Vinaśana of Baudhāyana
<div n="lb"/>Dharma Sūtra, i. 2, 9), and the Mahā-
<div n="lb"/>bhāṣya on Pāṇini, ii. 4, 10, has {%prāg%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ādarśāt.%} See also for the Buddhist
<div n="lb"/>‘Middle Country’ an article by Rhys
<div n="lb"/>Davids, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1904, 83 {%et seq.,%} with Fleet's
<div n="lb"/>corrections, {%ibid.,%} 1907, 657; and {%cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Keith, {%ibid.,%} 1908, 1143; Max Müller,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 58, 59;
<div n="lb"/>{%Indian Empire,%} 1, 303, 304, where the
<div n="lb"/>extraordinary theory is adopted that
<div n="lb"/>the Madhyadeśa was peopled by a new
<div n="lb"/>race of immigrant Āryans, who, travel-
<div n="lb"/>ling viâ Chitral and Gilgit, and bringing
<div n="lb"/>no women with them, married Dravidian
<div n="lb"/>women, and produced the so-called
<div n="lb"/>Āryo-Dravidians. It is quite impossible
<div n="lb"/>to find any support for this theory in
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature. To say, as is there
<div n="lb"/>said, that the ‘Vedic hymns contain
<div n="lb"/>no reference to the route by which the
<div n="lb"/>Āryans entered India or to their earlier
<div n="lb"/>settlements on the Indus,’ and that this
<div n="lb"/>is explained by the theory of the entry
<div n="lb"/>of the Vedic Indians viâ Chitral, is to
<div n="lb"/>assert absurdities. The theory is based
<div n="lb"/>on the later dialects and their affinities
<div n="lb"/>(see Grierson, {%Indian Empire,%} 1, 357
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}); it can probably not be regarded
<div n="lb"/>as at all valid for any period — at any
<div n="lb"/>rate, it is not cogent for the eighth
<div n="lb"/>century, B.C.</F>

<L>2343<pc>2-127<k1>maDyamavah<k2>maDyamavah

<L>2344<pc>2-127<k1>maDyamaSI<k2>maDyamaSI
{@Madhyama-śī@}¦ is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where
<div n="lb"/>Roth<sup>2</sup> assigns to the word the meaning of {%intercessor,%} which
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>3</sup> accepts, in the sense of ‘mediator’ or ‘arbiter,’ as a
<div n="lb"/>legal term, but which Roth may, as Lanman<sup>4</sup> suggests, have

<div n="lb"/>referred to in the hymn. Whitney<sup>5</sup> thinks that it means ‘mid-
[Page2-128+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>most man’ or ‘chief’ as the one round whom his followers
<div n="lb"/>encamp.<sup>6</sup> Geldner,<sup>7</sup> however, thinks that a third king, who is
<div n="lb"/>‘neutral’ between two enemies, is intended.
<F>1) x. 97, 12 = Av. iv. 9, 4 = Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xii. 86.</F>

<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 159. But see Roth, {%Sie-%}

<div n="lb"/>have overlooked, since he does not
<div n="lb"/>refer to it.</F>

<L>2348<pc>2-128<k1>manA<k2>manA
{@Manā@}¦ is found in one passage of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> in an enumera-
<div n="lb"/>tion of gifts, where it is described as ‘golden’ ({%sacā manā%}
<div n="lb"/>{%hiraṇyayā%}). It therefore seems to designate some ornament, or
<div n="lb"/>possibly a weight, and has accordingly been compared<sup>2</sup> with
<div n="lb"/>the Greek <lang n="greek"></lang> (Herodotus has <lang n="greek"></lang>), the Latin {%mina.%} All three
<div n="lb"/>words have been considered Semitic in origin, as borrowed from
<div n="lb"/>the Phœnicians<sup>3</sup> in the case of Greece, from Carthage by way
[Page2-129+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>of Etruria or Sicily in the case of Rome, and from Babylon in
<div n="lb"/>the case of India. The identification as regards Manā is very
<div n="lb"/>conjectural, depending merely on the probabilities of Babylonian
<div n="lb"/>borrowing<sup>4</sup> seen — {%e.g.,%} in the legend of the flood, and in the
<div n="lb"/>system of the {@Nakṣatras.@} On the other hand, Mahā may very
<div n="lb"/>well be identical with the word {%manā%} which occurs several
<div n="lb"/>times in the Rigveda<sup>5</sup> in the sense of ‘desire’ (from the root
<div n="lb"/>{%man,%} ‘think’), and which may have in this one passage the
<div n="lb"/>concrete sense of ‘desirable object.’ It is to be noted that in
<div n="lb"/>Böhtlingk's Dictionary a single word Manā appears, to which
<div n="lb"/>the only senses assigned are ‘wish,’ ‘desire,’ ‘jealousy.’
<F>1) viii. 78, 2.</F>
<F>2) As. {%e.g.,%} by Zimmer, {%Altindisches%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Leben,%} 50, 51; Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>5, 386; 17, 202, 203; Wackernagel,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindische Grammatik,%} 1, xxii; Hopkins,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>16, 278.</F>
<F>3) Or perhaps from Babylon viâ
<div n="lb"/>Asia Minor. The part played by the
<div n="lb"/>Phœnicians in Greek life is now reduced
<div n="lb"/>within narrow limits; in the case of
<div n="lb"/>the {%mina,%} probably their commercial
<div n="lb"/>activities may be considered as likely to
<div n="lb"/>have caused the adoption of the term.</F>
<F>4) See, {%e.g.,%} for borrowing, Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Religion des Veda,%} 276; {%Zeitschrift der%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%}
<div n="lb"/>50, 43 {%et seq.;%} Bühler, {%Indian Studies,%} 3,
<div n="lb"/>16 {%et seq.; Indische Palœographie,%} 17;
<div n="lb"/>Vincent Smith, {%Indian Antiquary,%} 34,
<div n="lb"/>230. On the other side, {%cf.%} Max Müller,
<div n="lb"/>{%India,%} 133-138; Hopkins, {%Religions of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%India,%} 160; Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 139 (as regards the flood legend):
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield, {%Religions of India,%} 133 {%et seq.%}
<div n="lb"/>(as regards the Ādityas).</F>
<F>5) i. 173, 2; iv. 33, 2, x. 6, 3; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 19; ‘jealousy,
<div n="lb"/>Rv. ii. 33, 5, Kanśika Sūtra, cvii. 2.
<div n="lb"/>There are also the derivatives {%manā-ya,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘think of,’ ‘be zealous’: Rv. i. 133, 4;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 26, 2; {%manā-ya,%} ‘desirous’: Rv.
<div n="lb"/>i. 92, 9; iv. 24, 7; {%manā-vasu,%} ‘rich in
<div n="lb"/>devotion’: Rv. v. 74, 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2350<pc>2-129<k1>manu<k2>manu
{@Manu@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> has no claim to historical
<div n="lb"/>reality. He is simply the first man, father of the race, and its
<div n="lb"/>guide in all matters, sacrificial and other. Hence the views of
<div n="lb"/>the texts on inheritance are foisted on Manu and his youngest
<div n="lb"/>son, {@Nābhānediṣṭha.@}<sup>3</sup> He also plays the part of the hero in the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic legend of the flood.<sup>4</sup>
[Page2-130+ 55]
<div n="P"/>Manu is called Vivasvan<sup>5</sup> or Vaivasvata,<sup>6</sup> ‘son of Vivasvant’
<div n="lb"/>(the god); Sāvarṇi,<sup>6</sup> ‘descendant of Savarṇā’ (the substitute of
<div n="lb"/>Saraṇyū in the legend of her wedding); and Sāṃvaraṇi,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>‘descendant of Saṃvaraṇa.’ The first name is, of course,
<div n="lb"/>mythical. The other two have been regarded as historical,
<div n="lb"/>Sāvarṇi being taken by Ludwig<sup>8</sup> as a king of the {@Turvaśas,@} but
<div n="lb"/>this is very doubtful.
<F>1) i. 80, 16; ii. 33. 13; viii. 63. 1;

<div n="lb"/>{%Mythology,%} 50.</F>

<div n="lb"/>6, 7, 1; iii. 3, 2, 1; v. 4, 10, 5; vi. 6.

<L>2354<pc>2-131<k1>mantra<k2>mantra
{@Mantra@}¦ (from the root {%man,%} ‘think’) denotes in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later<sup>2</sup> the ‘hymn’ as the product of the singer's creative
<div n="lb"/>thought. In the Brāhmaṇas<sup>3</sup> the word is regularly used of the
<div n="lb"/>poetic and prose utterances of the Ṛṣis, including not merely
<div n="lb"/>the verse parts of the Saṃhitās, but also the prose formulæ
<div n="lb"/>that betray by their style their special and archaic character.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) i. 31, 13; 40, 5; 67, 4; 74, 1;
<div n="lb"/>152, 2; ii. 35, 2, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. xv. 2, 1; xix. 54, 3; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, i. 5, 4, 1; 5, 1, etc.</F>
<F>3) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, v. 14, 23;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 1; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xxvi. 3. 5;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 4, 6; xi. 2,
<div n="lb"/>1, 6, Nirukta, vii. 1, etc.; Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, vii. 1, 3.</F>
<F>4) Bloomfield, {%Vedic Concordance,%} viii;
<div n="lb"/>Keith, {%Aitareya Āraṇyaka,%} 298. Mac-
<div n="lb"/>donel's {%Vedic Grammar%} covers the
<div n="lb"/>Mantra material of the Vedic Saṃhitās,
<div n="lb"/>prose as well as poetry.</F>

<L>2373<pc>2-136<k1>marka<k2>marka<h>1

<div n="lb"/>thinks, however, that if the word means

<div n="lb"/>root {%mṛc,%} ‘injure.’</F>

<div n="lb"/>from which is not phonetically justified.</F>
<F>4) Ludwig cites this passage, in his
<div n="lb"/>essay on eclipses in the Rigveda (Pro-
<div n="lb"/>ceedings of the Bohemian Academy,
<div n="lb"/>1885), as a proof that the Vedic Ṛṣis

<div n="lb"/>{%American Oriental Society,%} 13, lxi {%et seq.,%}
<div n="lb"/>and Sūrya.</F>

<L>2427<pc>2-145<k1>mAMsa<k2>mAMsa
{@Māṃsa,@}¦ ‘flesh.’ The eating of flesh appears as something
<div n="lb"/>quite regular in the Vedic texts, which show no trace of the
<div n="lb"/>doctrine of Ahiṃsā, or abstaining from injury to animals. For
<div n="lb"/>example, the ritual offerings of flesh contemplate that the gods
<div n="lb"/>will eat it, and again the Brahmins ate the offerings.<sup>1</sup> Again,
<div n="lb"/>the slaying of a ‘great ox’ ({%mahokṣa%}) or a ‘great goat’ ({%mahāja%})
<div n="lb"/>for a guest was regularly prescribed;<sup>2</sup> and the name {@Atithigva@}
<div n="lb"/>probably means ‘slaying cows for guests.’<sup>3</sup> The great sage
<div n="lb"/>{@Yājñavalkya@} was wont to eat the meat of milch cows and
<div n="lb"/>bullocks ({%dhenv-anaḍuha%}) if only it was {%aṃsala%} (‘firm’ or
<div n="lb"/>‘tender’).<sup>4</sup> The slaughter of a hundred bulls ({%ukṣan%}) was
<div n="lb"/>credited to one sacrificer, {@Agastya.@}<sup>5</sup> The marriage ceremony
<div n="lb"/>was accompanied by the slaying of oxen, clearly for food.<sup>6</sup>
[Page2-146+ 62]
<div n="P"/>That there was any general objection to the eating of flesh
<div n="lb"/>is most improbable. Sometimes it is forbidden, as when a
<div n="lb"/>man is performing a vow,<sup>7</sup> or its use is disapproved, as in
<div n="lb"/>a passage of the Atharvaveda,<sup>8</sup> where meat is classed with
<div n="lb"/>{@Surā,@} or intoxicating liquor, as a bad thing. Again, in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>9</sup> the slaying of the cows is said to take place in the
<div n="lb"/>{@Aghās,@} a deliberate variation for {@Maghās;@} but this may be
<div n="lb"/>the outcome merely of a natural association of death with
<div n="lb"/>gloom, even when cows alone are the victims in question.
<div n="lb"/>The Brāhmaṇas also contain the doctrine of the eater in this
<div n="lb"/>world being eaten in the next,<sup>10</sup> but this is not to be regarded
<div n="lb"/>as a moral or religious disapproval of eating flesh, though it
<div n="lb"/>no doubt contains the germ of such a view, which is also in
<div n="lb"/>harmony with the persuasion of the unity of existence, which
<div n="lb"/>becomes marked in the Brāhmaṇas. But Ahiṃsā as a deve-
<div n="lb"/>loped and articulate doctrine would seem to have arisen from
<div n="lb"/>the acceptance of the doctrine of transmigration, which in its
<div n="lb"/>fundamentals is later than the Brāhmaṇa period.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>On the other hand, it is to be noted that the cow was on the
<div n="lb"/>road to acquire special sanctity in the Rigveda,<sup>12</sup> as is shown
<div n="lb"/>by the name {%aghnyā,%}<sup>13</sup> ‘not to be slain,’ applied to it in several
<div n="lb"/>passages. But this fact cannot be regarded as showing that
[Page2-147+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>meat eating generally was condemned. Apart from mythical
<div n="lb"/>considerations, such as the identification of the cow with earth
<div n="lb"/>or Aditi (which are, of course, much more than an effort of
<div n="lb"/>priestly ingenuity), the value of the cow for other purposes
<div n="lb"/>than eating was so great as to account adequately for its
<div n="lb"/>sanctity, the beginnings of which can in fact be traced back to
<div n="lb"/>Indo-Iranian times.<sup>14</sup> Moreover, the ritual of the cremation
<div n="lb"/>of the dead required the slaughter of a cow as an essential
<div n="lb"/>part, the flesh being used to envelope the dead body.<sup>15</sup>
<div n="P"/>The usual food of the Vedic Indian, as far as flesh was
<div n="lb"/>concerned, can be gathered from the list of sacrificial victims:
<div n="lb"/>what man ate he presented to the gods — that is, the sheep, the
<div n="lb"/>goat, and the ox. The horse sacrifice was an infrequent
<div n="lb"/>exception: it is probably not to be regarded as a trace of the
<div n="lb"/>use of horseflesh as food, though the possibility of such being
<div n="lb"/>the case cannot be overlooked in view of the widespread use
<div n="lb"/>of horseflesh as food in different countries and times. It is,
<div n="lb"/>however, more likely that the aim of this sacrifice was to
<div n="lb"/>impart magic strength, the speed and vigour of the horse, to
<div n="lb"/>the god and his worshippers, as Oldenberg<sup>16</sup> argues.
<F>1) So Agni is called ‘eater of ox and

<L>2454<pc>2-152<k1>mAna<k2>mAna<h>1

<L>2455<pc>2-152<k1>mAna<k2>mAna<h>2
2. {@Māna@}¦ is the name of a man occurring in several passages
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda. In one place<sup>1</sup> express mention is made of his
<div n="lb"/>son ({%sūnu%}), by whom, despite Bergaigne's view to the contrary,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{@Agastya@} must be meant. In another passage,<sup>3</sup> apparently the
<div n="lb"/>same meaning applies to Māna — that is, Agastya as ‘a Māna.’
<div n="lb"/>In a third passage<sup>4</sup> the expression {%sūnave Mānena%} has been
<div n="lb"/>held by Sieg<sup>5</sup> to be an inversion of {%Mānasya sūnunā,%} ‘by the
<div n="lb"/>son of Māna’ — {%i.e.,%} Agastya; but it seems more likely<sup>6</sup> that
<div n="lb"/>either {%sūnor Māna%} is the fuller form of Agastya's name (‘pride
[Page2-153+ 39]
<div n="lb"/>of the son,’ with reference to his high ancestry), or that the
<div n="lb"/>son<sup>7</sup> of Māna (= Agastya) is alluded to as interested in
<div n="lb"/>{@Viśpalā.@}
<div n="P"/>The Mānas — that is, the descendants of Māna, are in several
<div n="lb"/>passages alluded to as singers.<sup>8</sup> {%Cf.%} {@Mānya, Māndārya.@}
<F>1) Rv. i. 189, 8.</F>
<F>2) {%Religion Védique,%} 2, 394. {%Cf.%} Pischel,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 173; Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gesellschaft,%} 42, 221, n. 5; {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 110; Sieg. {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛg-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%veda,%} 107; Geldner, {%Rigveda, Glossar,%}
<div n="lb"/>135.</F>
<F>3) vii. 33, 13. {%Cf.%} verse 10.</F>
<F>4) i. 117, 11.</F>
<F>5) {%Loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>6) Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten, loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>7) Bergaigne, {%loc. cit.;%} Pischel, {%loc. cit.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.,%} where {%sūnoḥ%} is taken as dependent
<div n="lb"/>on {%vājam.%}</F>
<F>8) Rv. i. 169, 8; 171, 5; 182, 8; 184, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 116, 117, who thinks the Mānas
<div n="lb"/>were settled on the {@Sindhu@} (Indus).

<L>2474<pc>2-156<k1>mAza<k2>mAza

<div n="lb"/>winter ({%hemanta%}).<sup>5</sup> In the ritual the human head for the
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice is bought for twenty-one Māṣas<sup>6</sup> : it does not appear
<div n="lb"/>that the word here means a weight of metal, as it often does
<div n="lb"/>later.<sup>7</sup> A taboo on beans is found in the Yajurveda Saṃhitās.<sup>8</sup>

<div n="lb"/>10; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 3,

<div n="lb"/>tioned.</F>

<L>2476<pc>2-156<k1>mAsa<k2>mAsa
{@Māsa@}¦ denotes a ‘month,’ a period of time repeatedly men-
<div n="lb"/>tioned in the Rigveda and later.
<div n="P"/>The characteristic days (or rather nights) of the month were
<div n="lb"/>those of the new moon, Amā-vasyā, ‘home-staying (night),’ and
<div n="lb"/>‘of the full moon,’ Paurṇa-māsī. Two hymns of the Atharva-
<div n="lb"/>veda<sup>1</sup> celebrate these days respectively. A personification of
<div n="lb"/>the phases of the moon is seen in the four names Sinīvālī,<sup>2</sup>
[Page2-157+ 72]
<div n="lb"/>the day before new moon; Kuhū,<sup>3</sup> also called Guṅgū,<sup>4</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>new moon day; Anumati,<sup>5</sup> the day before full moon; and
<div n="lb"/>Rākā,<sup>6</sup> the day of new moon. The importance of the new and
<div n="lb"/>full moon days is seen in the Darśa-pūrṇamāsau, or festivals
<div n="lb"/>of the new and full moon days respectively.
<div n="P"/>One special day in the month, the {@Ekāṣṭakā,@} or eighth day
<div n="lb"/>after full moon, was important. In the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>there are stated to be in the year twelve such, mentioned
<div n="lb"/>between the twelve days of full moon and the twelve days of
<div n="lb"/>new moon. But one Ekāṣṭakā is referred to in the Yajurveda
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās and elsewhere<sup>8</sup> as of quite special importance. This
<div n="lb"/>was, in the accordant opinion of most commentators, the
<div n="lb"/>eighth day after the full moon of {@Māgha.@} It marked the end
<div n="lb"/>of the year, or the beginning of the new year. Though the
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa<sup>9</sup> places the winter solstice in the new
<div n="lb"/>moon of Māgha, the latter date probably means the new moon
<div n="lb"/>preceding full moon in Māgha,<sup>10</sup> not the new moon following
[Page2-158+ 74]
<div n="lb"/>full moon; but it is perhaps possible to account adequately for
<div n="lb"/>the importance of the Ekāṣṭakā as being the first Aṣṭakā
<div n="lb"/>after the beginning of the new year.
<div n="P"/>It is not certain exactly how the month was reckoned, whether
<div n="lb"/>from the day after new moon to new moon — the system known
<div n="lb"/>as {%amānta,%} or from the day after full moon to full moon — the {%pūr-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ṇimānta%} system, which later, at any rate, was followed in North
<div n="lb"/>India, while the other system prevailed in the south. Jacobi<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>argues that the year began in the full moon of Phālguna, and
<div n="lb"/>that only by the full moon's conjunction with the Nakṣatra could
<div n="lb"/>the month be known. Oldenberg<sup>12</sup> points to the fact that the
<div n="lb"/>new moon is far more distinctively an epoch than the full
<div n="lb"/>moon; that the Greek, Roman, and Jewish years began with
<div n="lb"/>the new moon; and that the Vedic evidence is the division of
<div n="lb"/>the month into the former ({%pūrva%}) and latter ({%apara%}) halves,
<div n="lb"/>the first being the bright ({%śukla%}), the second the dark ({%kṛṣṇa%})
<div n="lb"/>period. Thibaut<sup>13</sup> considers that to assume the existence of
<div n="lb"/>the {%pūrṇimānta%} system for the Veda is unnecessary, though
<div n="lb"/>possible. Weber<sup>10</sup> assumes that it occurs in the Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa as held by the scholiasts. But it would probably
<div n="lb"/>be a mistake to press that passage, or to assume that the
<div n="lb"/>{%amānta%} system was rigidly accepted in the Veda: it seems at
<div n="lb"/>least as probable that the month was vaguely regarded as
<div n="lb"/>beginning with the new moon day, so that new moon preceded
<div n="lb"/>full moon, which was in the middle, not the end or the
<div n="lb"/>beginning of the month.
<div n="P"/>That a month regularly had 30 days is established by the
<div n="lb"/>conclusive evidence of numerous passages in which the year is
<div n="lb"/>given 12 months and 360 days. This month is known from the
<div n="lb"/>earliest records, being both referred to directly and alluded to.<sup>14</sup>
[Page2-159+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>It is the regular month of the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>15</sup> and must be
<div n="lb"/>regarded as the month which the Vedic Indian recognized.
<div n="lb"/>No other month is mentioned as such in the Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>literature; it is only in the Sūtras that months of different
<div n="lb"/>length occur. The Sāmaveda Sūtras<sup>16</sup> refer to (1) years with
<div n="lb"/>324 days — {%i.e.,%} periodic years with 12 months of 27 days each;
<div n="lb"/>(2) years with 351 days — {%i.e.,%} periodic years with 12 months of
<div n="lb"/>27 days each, plus another month of 27 days; (3) years with
<div n="lb"/>354 days — {%i.e.,%} 6 months of 30 days, and 6 with 29 days, in
<div n="lb"/>other words, lunar synodic years; (4) years with 360 days, or
<div n="lb"/>ordinary civil ({%sāvana%}) years; (5) years with 378 days, which,
<div n="lb"/>as Thibaut<sup>17</sup> clearly shows, are third years, in which, after
<div n="lb"/>two years of 360 days each, 18 days were added to bring about
<div n="lb"/>correspondence between the civil year and the solar year of
<div n="lb"/>366 days. But even the Sāmasūtras do not mention the year
<div n="lb"/>of 366 days, which is first known to the Jyotiṣa<sup>18</sup> and to
<div n="lb"/>Garga.<sup>19</sup>
<div n="P"/>That the Vedic period was acquainted with the year of
<div n="lb"/>354 days cannot be affirmed with certainty. Zimmer,<sup>20</sup> indeed,
<div n="lb"/>thinks that it is proved by the fact that pregnancy is estimated
<div n="lb"/>at ten months, or sometimes a year.<sup>21</sup> But Weber<sup>22</sup> may be
<div n="lb"/>right in holding that the month is the periodic month of
<div n="lb"/>27 days, for the period is otherwise too long if a year is taken.
<div n="lb"/>On the other hand, the period of ten months quite well suits
<div n="lb"/>the period of gestation, if birth takes place in the tenth month,
<div n="lb"/>so that in this sense the month of 30 days may well be meant.
[Page2-160+ 57]
<div n="P"/>The year of 12 months of 30 days each being admittedly
<div n="lb"/>quite unscientific, Zimmer<sup>23</sup> is strongly of opinion that it was
<div n="lb"/>only used with a recognition of the fact that intercalation took
<div n="lb"/>place, and that the year formed part of a greater complex,
<div n="lb"/>normally the five your Yuga or cycle. This system is well
<div n="lb"/>known from the Jyotṣa: it consists of 62 months of 29(16/31) days
<div n="lb"/>each = 1, 830 days (two of these months being intercalary, one
<div n="lb"/>in the middle and one at the end), or 61 months of 30 days,
<div n="lb"/>or 60 months of 30(1/2) days, the unit being clearly a solar year
<div n="lb"/>of 366 days. It is not an ideal system, since the year is too
<div n="lb"/>long;<sup>24</sup> but it is one which cannot be claimed even for the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa period, during which no decision as to the true
<div n="lb"/>length of the year seems to have been arrived at. The
<div n="lb"/>references to it seen by Zimmer in the Rigveda<sup>25</sup> are not even
<div n="lb"/>reasonably plausible, while the {%pañcaka yuga,%} cited by him from
<div n="lb"/>the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>26</sup> occurs only in a quotation in
<div n="lb"/>a commentary, and had no authority for the text itself.
<div n="P"/>On the other hand, there was undoubtedly some attempt to
<div n="lb"/>bring the year of 360 days — a synodic lunar year — roughly
<div n="lb"/>into connexion with reality. A Sāmasūtra<sup>27</sup> treats it as a
<div n="lb"/>solar year, stating that he sun perambulates each Naxatra in
<div n="lb"/>13(1/3) days, while others again evidently interpolated 18 days
<div n="lb"/>every third year, in order to arrive at some equality. But
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature, from the Rigveda<sup>28</sup> downwards,<sup>29</sup> teems with
<div n="lb"/>the assertion of the difficulty of ascertaining the month.
<div n="lb"/>The length is variously given as 30 days,<sup>30</sup> 35 days,<sup>31</sup> or
[Page2-161+ 63]
<div n="lb"/>36 days.<sup>32</sup> The last number possibly indicates an intercalation
<div n="lb"/>after six years (6×6 = 36, or for ritual purposes 35), but for
<div n="lb"/>this we have no special evidence. There are many references<sup>33</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to the year having 12 or 13 months.
<div n="P"/>The names of the months are, curiously enough, not at all
<div n="lb"/>ancient. The sacrificial texts of the Yajurveda give them in
<div n="lb"/>their clearest form where the Agnicayana, ‘building of the
<div n="lb"/>fire-altar,’ is described.<sup>34</sup> These names are the following:
<div n="lb"/>(1) Madhu, (2) Mādhava (spring months, {%vāsantikāv ṛtū%});
<div n="lb"/>(3) Śukra, (4) Śuci (summer months, {%graiṣmāv ṛtū%}); (5) Nabha
<div n="lb"/>(or Nabhas),<sup>35</sup> (6) Nabhasya (rainy months, {%vārṣikāv ṛtū%});
<div n="lb"/>(7) Iṣa, (8) Ūrja (autumn months, {%śāradāv ṛtū%}); (9) Saha (or
<div n="lb"/>Sahas),<sup>35</sup> (10) Sahasya (winter months, {%haimantikāv ṛtū%});
<div n="lb"/>(11) Tapa (or Tapas),<sup>35</sup> (12) Tapasya (cool months, {%śaiśirāv%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ṛtū%}).
<div n="P"/>There are similar lists in the descriptions of the Soma
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice<sup>36</sup> and of the horse sacrifice,<sup>37</sup> all of them agreeing in
<div n="lb"/>essentials. There are other lists of still more fanciful names,<sup>38</sup>
<div n="lb"/>but these have no claim at all to represent actual divisions in
<div n="lb"/>popular use. It is doubtful if the list given above is more than
<div n="lb"/>a matter of priestly invention. Weber points out that Madhu
<div n="lb"/>and Mādhava later appear as names of spring, and that these
<div n="lb"/>two are mentioned in the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka<sup>39</sup> as if actually
[Page2-162+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>employed; but the evidence is very inadequate to show that
<div n="lb"/>the other names of the months given in the list were in ordinary
<div n="lb"/>use.<sup>40</sup>
<div n="P"/>In some of these lists the intercalary month is mentioned.
<div n="lb"/>The name given to it in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>41</sup> is Aṃhasas-
<div n="lb"/>pati, while that given in the Taittirīya<sup>42</sup> and Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās<sup>43</sup> is Saṃsarpa. The Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>44</sup> gives it the
<div n="lb"/>name of Malimluca, which also occurs elsewhere, along with
<div n="lb"/>Saṃsarpa, in one of the lists of fanciful names.<sup>45</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>46</sup> describes it as {%sanisrasa,%} ‘slipping,’ owing no
<div n="lb"/>doubt to its unstable condition.
<div n="P"/>The other method of naming the months is from the
<div n="lb"/>{@Nakṣatras.@} It is only beginning to be used in the Brāhmaṇas,
<div n="lb"/>but is found regularly in the Epic and later. The Jyotiṣa<sup>47</sup>
<div n="lb"/>mentions that Māgha and Tapa were identical: this is the fair
<div n="lb"/>interpretation of the passage, which also involves the identifica-
<div n="lb"/>tion of Madhu with Caitra, a result corresponding with the
<div n="lb"/>view frequently found in the Brāhmaṇas, that the full moon in
<div n="lb"/>Citrā, and not that in Phalgunī, is the beginning of the year.<sup>48</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>49</sup> are found two curious ex-
<div n="lb"/>pressions, {%yava%} and {%ayava,%} for the light and dark halves of the
<div n="lb"/>month, which is clearly considered to begin with the light half.
<div n="lb"/>Possibly the words are derived, as Eggling<sup>50</sup> thinks, from {%yu,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘ward off,’ with reference to evil spirits. The word {@Parvan@}
[Page2-163+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>(‘joint’ = division of time) probably<sup>51</sup> denotes a half of the
<div n="lb"/>month, perhaps already in the Rigveda.<sup>52</sup> More precisely the
<div n="lb"/>first half, the time of the waxing light, is called {%pūrva-pakṣa,%}<sup>53</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the second, that of the waning light, {%apara-pakṣa,%}<sup>54</sup> Either of
<div n="lb"/>these might be called a half-month ({%ardha-māsa%}).<sup>55</sup>

<L>2491<pc>2-165<k1>muYja<k2>muYja<h>1
1. {@Muñja@}¦ denotes a grass, the {%Saccharum Muñja,%} which is
<div n="lb"/>of luxuriant growth, attaining to a height of ten feet. It is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> along with other kinds of grasses
<div n="lb"/>as the lurking-place of venomous creatures. In the same text<sup>2</sup>

<div n="lb"/>used as the material of a filter for Soma. The grass is often
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the later Saṃhitās<sup>3</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>4</sup> It is
<div n="lb"/>in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> said to be ‘hollow’ ({%suṣira%}) and
<div n="lb"/>to be used for the plaited part of the throne ({@Āsandī@}).<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) i. 191, 3.</F>

<div n="lb"/>v. 1, 9, 5; 10, 5, etc.</F>

<L>2495<pc>2-166<k1>mudgala<k2>mudgala
{@Mudgala@}¦ and {@Mudgalanī,@} ‘Mudgala's wife,’ both figure in
<div n="lb"/>a hopelessly obscure hymn of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> variously inter-
<div n="lb"/>preted by Pischel<sup>2</sup> and Geldner<sup>3</sup> and von Bradke<sup>4</sup> as telling
<div n="lb"/>of a real chariot race in which, despite difficulties, Mudgala
<div n="lb"/>won by his wife's aid. The Indian tradition is as variant as
<div n="lb"/>the interpretations of modern authorities. Ṣaḍguruśiṣya<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>explains that Mudgala's oxen were stolen, that he pursued the
<div n="lb"/>thieves with the one old ox he had left, and that hurling his
<div n="lb"/>hammer ({%dru-ghaṇa%}) he caught the marauders. Yāska,<sup>6</sup> on the
<div n="lb"/>other hand, says that Mudgala won a race with a {%drughaṇa%}
<div n="lb"/>and an ox instead of with two oxen. It is pretty clear that,
<div n="lb"/>as Roth<sup>7</sup> observed, the tradition is merely a guess, and a bad
<div n="lb"/>one, at the meaning of an obscure hymn, and this view is
[Page2-167+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>accepted by Oldenberg.<sup>8</sup> Bloomfield<sup>9</sup> has interpreted the
<div n="lb"/>legend as one of heavenly, not of human, events. Mudgala,
<div n="lb"/>probably a variant form of Mudgara,<sup>10</sup> which in the later
<div n="lb"/>language means a hammer or a similar weapon, may be meant
<div n="lb"/>as a personification of the thunderbolt of Indra, rather than
<div n="lb"/>a real man.<sup>11</sup> Later<sup>12</sup> Mudgala is a mythical sage.
<F>1) x. 102.</F>
<F>2) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 124.</F>
<F>3) {%Ibid.,%} 1, 138; 2, 1-22.</F>
<F>4) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 46, 445 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) Macdonell's edition of the Sarvānu-
<div n="lb"/>kramaṇī, p. 158.</F>
<F>6) Nirukta, ix. 23, 24.</F>
<F>7) {%Nirukta, Erlänterungen,%} 129.</F>
<F>8) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 39, 78.</F>
<F>9) {%Ibid.,%} 48, 547.</F>
<F>10) According to Geldner, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 2, 1, Indrasenā in x. 102, 2, is
<div n="lb"/>the name of Mudgalānī; but its sense,
<div n="lb"/>‘Indra's bolt,’ rather indicates the
<div n="lb"/>mythical character of the passage.</F>
<F>11) If the name means a real man, it
<div n="lb"/>may be connected with {@Mudga,@} ‘bean.’
<div n="lb"/>See Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 240.</F>
<F>12) Av. iv. 29, 6; Āśvalāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xii. 12; Bṛhaddevatā, vi. 46;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 12. 90.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 166, 167; Oldenberg, {%Religion%}
<div n="lb"/>{%des Veda,%} 280; Keith, {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Royal Asiatic Society%} 1911, 1005, n. 1.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2496<pc>2-167<k1>muni<k2>muni
{@Muni@}¦ occurs in one hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> where it seems to
<div n="lb"/>denote an ascetic of magic powers with divine afflatus ({%deveṣita%}),
<div n="lb"/>the precursor of the strange ascetics of later India. This
<div n="lb"/>agrees with the fact that {@Aitaśa,@} the Muni, is in the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> regarded by his son as deranged, a view not
<div n="lb"/>unjustified if the nonsense which passes as the Aitaśapralāpa.<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>‘Chatter of Aitaśa,’ was really his. The Rigveda<sup>4</sup> calls Indra
<div n="lb"/>the ‘friend of Munis,’ and the Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> refers to a ‘divine
<div n="lb"/>Muni’ ({%deva muni%}), by whom a similar ascetic may be meant.
<div n="P"/>In the Upaniṣads<sup>6</sup> the Muni is of a more restrained type:
<div n="lb"/>he is one who learns the nature of the Brahman, the Absolute,
<div n="lb"/>by study, or sacrifice, or penance, or fasting, or faith ({%śraddhā%}).
<div n="lb"/>It must not of course be thought that there is any absolute
<div n="lb"/>distinction between the older Muni and the later: in both
<div n="lb"/>cases the man is in a peculiar ecstatic condition, but the ideal
<div n="lb"/>of the Upaniṣads is less material than the earlier picture of the
<div n="lb"/>Muni, who is more of a ‘medicine man’ than a sage. Nor
<div n="lb"/>would it be wise to conclude from the comparative rareness
[Page2-168+ 39]
<div n="lb"/>of the mention of the Muni in the Vedic texts that he was
<div n="lb"/>an infrequent figure in Vedic times: he was probably not
<div n="lb"/>approved by the priests who followed the ritual, and whose
<div n="lb"/>views were essentially different from the ideals of a Muni,
<div n="lb"/>which were superior to earthly considerations, such as the
<div n="lb"/>desire for children and {@Dakṣiṇās.@}<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) x. 136, 2. 4. 5. In verse I he is
<div n="lb"/>described as ‘long-haired.’</F>
<F>2) vi. 33, 3.</F>
<F>3) See Bloomfield, {%Atharvaveda,%} 98
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) viii. 17, 14. {%Cf.%} vii. 56, 8; Max
<div n="lb"/>Müller, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 376.</F>
<F>5) vii. 74, 1. {%Cf.%} Whitney, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Atharvaveda, 440; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ix. 5, 2, 15, and {@Muni-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@maraṇa.@}</F>
<F>6) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iii. 4, 1;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 4, 25; Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, ii. 20.</F>
<F>7) {%Cf.%} Bṛhadāranyaka Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 4, 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Oldenberg, {%Religion des Veda,%} 406;
<div n="lb"/>{%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Gesellschaft,%} 49, 480; {%Buddha,%}^5 36.</F>

<L>2501<pc>2-168<k1>muzwihan<k2>muzwihan
{@Muṣṭi-han,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Muṣṭi-hatyā,@}<sup>2</sup> in the Rigveda and the Atharva-
<div n="lb"/>veda denote. respectively, the ‘hand to hand fighter’ — that is,
<div n="lb"/>the ordinary warrior as opposed to the charioteer, and the
[Page2-169+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>‘fight’ itself. So also in the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> the charioteer
<div n="lb"/>({%rathin%}) is opposed to the foot-soldier ({%patti%}), and in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>4</sup> the chariots are opposed to the troops ({%grāma%}) of the
<div n="lb"/>infantry. The parallel of the Greek and other Āryan races
<div n="lb"/>shows that the Kṣatriyas were the fighters from chariots, while
<div n="lb"/>the ordinary host fought on foot.
<F>1) Rv. v. 58, 4; vi. 26, 2; viii. 20, 20; Av. v. 22, 4.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 8, 2.</F>
<F>3) vii. 62, 1.</F>
<F>4) i. 100, 10.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 297.</F>

<L>2505<pc>2-169<k1>mUjavant<k2>mUjavant
{@Mūjavant@}¦ is the name of a people who, along with the
<div n="lb"/>{@Mahāvṛṣas,@} the {@Gandhāris,@} and the {@Balhikas,@} are mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> as dwelling far away, and to whom
<div n="lb"/>fever is to be banished. Similarly in the Yajurveda Saṃhitās<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the Mūjavants are chosen as a type of distant folk, beyond
[Page2-170+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>which Rudra with his bow is entreated to depart. In the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>3</sup> Soma is described as Maujavata, ‘coming from the
<div n="lb"/>Mūjavants,’ or, as Yāska<sup>4</sup> takes it, ‘from Mount Mūjavant.’
<div n="lb"/>The Indian commentators<sup>5</sup> agree with Yāska in taking Mūja-
<div n="lb"/>vant as the name of a mountain, and though Hillebrandt<sup>6</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>justified in saying that the identification of Mūjavant by
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>7</sup> with one of the lower hills on the south-west of
<div n="lb"/>Kaśmīr lacks evidence, it is not reasonable to deny that
<div n="lb"/>Mūjavant was a hill from which the people took their name.
<div n="lb"/>Yāska<sup>8</sup> suggests that Mūjavant is equivalent to Muñjavant,
<div n="lb"/>which actually occurs later, in the Epic,<sup>9</sup> as the name of a
<div n="lb"/>mountain in the Himālaya.

<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, ix. 7; xxxvi. 14;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 10. 20; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 61; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ii. 6, 2, 17.</F>
<F>3) x. 34, 1.</F>
<F>4) Nirukta, ix. 8.</F>
<F>5) Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>{%loc. cit.;%} Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 161, 8;
<div n="lb"/>Baudhāyana Śrauta Sūtra and Prayoga,
<div n="lb"/>cited by Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Myth-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ologie,%} 1, 63.</F>
<F>6) {%Op. cit.,%} 1, 65.</F>

<L>2510<pc>2-171<k1>mfga<k2>mfga<h>1
1. {@Mṛga@}¦ has the generic sense of ‘wild beast’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later.<sup>2</sup> Sometimes it is qualified by the epithet ‘terrible’
<div n="lb"/>({%bhīma%}),<sup>3</sup> which indicates that a savage wild beast is meant.
<div n="lb"/>Elsewhere the buffalo is shown to be denoted by the epithet
<div n="lb"/>{%mahiṣa,%}<sup>4</sup> ‘powerful,’ which later becomes the name of the
<div n="lb"/>buffalo. More particularly the word has the sense of an animal
<div n="lb"/>of the gazelle type.<sup>5</sup> In some passages<sup>6</sup> Roth<sup>7</sup> sees the sense
<div n="lb"/>of ‘bird.’ See also {@Mṛga Hastin, Puruṣa Hastin.@}
<F>1) i. 173, 2; 191, 4; viii. 1, 20; 5, 36;
<div n="lb"/>x. 146, 6, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 3, 6; x. 1, 26; xii. 1, 48
<div n="lb"/>({%sūkara,%} ‘boar’); xix. 38, 2; Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa, vi. 7, 10; xxiv. 11, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 31, 2; viii. 23,
<div n="lb"/>3, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 154, 2; 190, 3; ii. 33, 11;
<div n="lb"/>34, 1; x. 180, 2, etc.</F>
<F>4) Rv. viii. 69, 15; ix. 92, 6; x. 123, 4.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 38, 5; 105, 7; vi. 75, 11;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 32, 4; Av. v. 21, 4 (not a certain
<div n="lb"/>instance); Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1,
<div n="lb"/>3, 7; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 2, 5
<div n="lb"/>6; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 8, 4, 3, etc.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 182, 7; x. 136, 6, and per-
<div n="lb"/>haps i. 145, 5; vii. 87, 6.</F>
<F>7) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.,%} 1{%e.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} i. 99;
<div n="lb"/>2, 122.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2511<pc>2-171<k1>mfga<k2>mfga<h>2
2. {@Mṛga@}¦ in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> denotes, according to
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa's commentary, the constellation {@Mṛgaśiras.@} But it
<div n="lb"/>seems more probable<sup>2</sup> that Mṛga there really covers the whole
<div n="lb"/>of Orion, not merely the inconspicuous group of stars in the
<div n="lb"/>head of Orion that make up the Nakṣatra Mṛgaśiras, but also
<div n="lb"/>the star {%a%} in his shoulder, which is reckoned as Ārdrā, and <lang n="greek"></lang>
<div n="lb"/>in his left shoulder. Tilak,<sup>3</sup> however, makes Mṛga or Mṛgaśiras
<div n="lb"/>into a different group, consisting of the belt of Orion, with two
<div n="lb"/>stars in the knees and one in the left shoulder, which he
<div n="lb"/>deems to resemble a deer's head with an arrow through it,
<div n="lb"/>an implausible and unlikely theory. {%Cf.%} {@Mṛgavyādha.@}
<F>1) iii. 33, 5.</F>
<F>2) See Whitney, {%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%} 16, xcii.</F>
<F>3) {%Orion,%} 99 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>2512<pc>2-171<k1>mfgahastin<k2>mfgahastin<h>3
3. {@Mṛga Hastin,@}¦ the ‘animal with a hand,’ is mentioned in
<div n="lb"/>two passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> in which Roth<sup>2</sup> recognizes that
<div n="lb"/>the elephant is meant, but concludes that the compound name
[Page2-172+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>is a proof of the newness of the elephant to the Vedic Indians.<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Later the adjective Hastin alone became the regular name of
<div n="lb"/>the animal (like {@Mahiṣa@} of the ‘buffalo’). The elephant is
<div n="lb"/>also denoted in the Rigveda by the descriptive term Mṛga
<div n="lb"/>Vāraṇa,<sup>4</sup> the ‘wild or dangerous animal,’ the adjective {%vāraṇa%}
<div n="lb"/>similarly becoming one of the names for ‘elephant’ in the later
<div n="lb"/>language. Pischel's view<sup>5</sup> that the catching of elephants by
<div n="lb"/>the use of tame female elephants is already alluded to in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>6</sup> seems very doubtful. In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>elephants are described as ‘black, white-toothed, adorned with
<div n="lb"/>gold.’
<F>1) i. 64, 7; iv. 16, 14.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.; Nirukta, Erläuterungen,%} 79.</F>
<F>3) Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 99, 100,
<div n="lb"/>combats the view that the elephant was
<div n="lb"/>new to the Vedic Indian, because of
<div n="lb"/>the similar use of {%mṛga mahiṣa%} and
<div n="lb"/>{%mṛga sūkara%} (Av. xii. 1, 48) to denote
<div n="lb"/>the ‘buffalo’ and the ‘boar’ respec-
<div n="lb"/>tively. But {@Mahiṣa@} seems rather to
<div n="lb"/>bear out Roth's conclusion; while
<div n="lb"/>{@Sūkara@} appears alone in the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>and {%mṛga sūkara,%} ‘wild hog,’ seems to
<div n="lb"/>be used in one passage of the Av.
<div n="lb"/>(xii. 1, 48) to distinguish it from {@Varāha,@}
<div n="lb"/>‘boar,’ in the same verse.</F>
<F>4) Rv. viii. 33, 8; x. 40, 8.</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 121-123; 317-
<div n="lb"/>319. {%Cf.%} Strabo, pp. 704, 705; Arrian,
<div n="lb"/>{%Indica,%} 13. 14 (from Megasthenes).</F>
<F>6) viii. 2, 6; x. 40, 8.</F>
<F>7) viii. 23, 3 ({%hiraṇyena parīvṛtān kṛṣṇāñ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%chukladato mṛgān%}). See Pischel, {%op. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 122.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 80.</F>

<L>2514<pc>2-172<k1>mfgayu<k2>mfgayu
{@Mṛgayu,@}¦ ‘hunter,’ occurs in the later Saṃhitās<sup>1</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas,<sup>2</sup> but not very often. The Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>4</sup> however, in the list of victims
<div n="lb"/>at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) include a number of
<div n="lb"/>names which seem to be those of persons who make a liveli-
<div n="lb"/>hood by fishing or by hunting, such as the {@Mārgāra,@} ‘hunter,’
[Page2-173+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>the {@Kaivarta@} or {@Kevarta, Pauñjiṣṭha, Daśa, Maināla,@} ‘fisher
<div n="lb"/>man,’ and perhaps the {@Bainda@} and the Ānda,<sup>5</sup> who seem to
<div n="lb"/>have been some sort of fishermen.
<div n="P"/>It is not probable that even in the earliest Vedic period
<div n="lb"/>hunting formed the main source of livelihood for any of the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic tribes: pastoral pursuits and agriculture ({@Kṛṣi@}) were, no
<div n="lb"/>doubt, the mainstay of their existence. But it would be
<div n="lb"/>unreasonable to suppose that not much hunting was done,
<div n="lb"/>both for recreation and for purposes of food, as well as for
<div n="lb"/>protection of flocks from wild beasts. The Rigveda is naturally
<div n="lb"/>our chief source of information in regard to hunting. The
<div n="lb"/>arrow was sometimes employed,<sup>6</sup> but, as is usual with primitive
<div n="lb"/>man, the normal instruments of capture were nets and pitfalls.
<div n="lb"/>Birds were regularly caught in nets ({@Pāśa,@}<sup>7</sup> {@Nidhā,@}<sup>8</sup> {@Jāla@}),<sup>9</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>bird-catcher being called {%nidhā-pati,%}<sup>10</sup> ‘master of snares.’ The
<div n="lb"/>net was fastened on pegs<sup>11</sup> (as is done with modern nets for
<div n="lb"/>catching birds). Another name of net is apparently {@Mukṣījā.@}
<div n="P"/>Pits were used for catching antelopes ({@Ṛśya@}), and so were
<div n="lb"/>called {%ṛśya-da,%}<sup>12</sup> ‘antelope-catching.’ Elephants were captured
<div n="lb"/>as in Greek times, perhaps through the instrumentality of tame
<div n="lb"/>females (see {@Mṛga Hastin@}). Apparently the boar was captured
<div n="lb"/>in the chase, dogs being used,<sup>13</sup> but the passage from which
<div n="lb"/>this view is deduced is of uncertain mythological content.
<div n="lb"/>There is also an obscure reference<sup>14</sup> to the capture of the
<div n="lb"/>buffalo ({@Gaura@}), but it is not clear whether the reference is to
<div n="lb"/>shooting with an arrow or capturing by means of ropes,
<div n="lb"/>perhaps a lasso, or a net. The lion was captured in pitfalls,<sup>15</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or was surrounded by the hunters and slain;<sup>16</sup> one very obscure
<div n="lb"/>passage refers to the lion being caught by ambuscade, which
<div n="lb"/>perhaps merely alludes to the use of the hidden pit.<sup>17</sup>
<div n="P"/>The modes of catching fish are little known, for the only
<div n="lb"/>evidence available are the explanations of the various names
[Page2-174+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Yajurveda. Sāyaṇa<sup>18</sup> says that {@Dhaivara@} is
<div n="lb"/>one who takes fish by netting a tank on either side; Dāśa and
<div n="lb"/>{@Śauṣkala@} do so by means of a fish-hook ({%baḍiśa%}); Bainda,
<div n="lb"/>Kaivarta, and Maināla by means of a net ({%jāla%}); Mārgāra
<div n="lb"/>catches fish in the water with his hands; Ānda by putting in
<div n="lb"/>pegs at a ford (apparently by building a sort of dam); {@Parṇaka@}
<div n="lb"/>by putting a poisoned leaf on the water. But none of these
<div n="lb"/>explanations can claim much authority.
<F>1) Av. x. 1, 26; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 27; xxx. 7, etc. {%Cf. mṛgaṇyu,%} Rv.
<div n="lb"/>x. 40, 4.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 5, 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 4, 3, 1; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>xiv. 9, 12, etc.</F>
<F>3) xxx.</F>
<F>4) iii. 4.</F>
<F>5) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 12, 1.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ii. 42, 2.</F>
<F>7) {@Pāśin,@} ‘hunter,’ Rv. iii. 45, 1.</F>
<F>8) Rv. ix. 83, 4; x. 73, 11.</F>
<F>9) Av. x. 1, 30.</F>
<F>10) Rv. ix. 83, 4.</F>
<F>11) Av. viii. 8, 5.</F>
<F>12) Rv. x. 39, 8.</F>
<F>13) Rv. x. 86, 4.</F>
<F>14) Rv. x. 51, 6.</F>
<F>15) Rv. x. 28, 10.</F>
<F>16) Rv. v. 15, 3.</F>
<F>17) Rv. v. 74, 4. {%Cf.%} Griffith, {%Hymns%}

<L>2515<pc>2-174<k1>mfgavyADa<k2>mfgavyADa
{@Mṛga-vyādha,@}¦ ‘the hunter,’ is the name of Sirius in the
<div n="lb"/>legend of Prajāpati's daughter in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Prajāpati (Orion) pursues his daughter (Rohiṇī), and is shot

<div n="lb"/>Prajāpati to the sky is no doubt secondary, caused by the

<div n="lb"/>of an archer.

<L>2520<pc>2-175<k1>mftyu<k2>mftyu
{@Mṛtyu,@}¦ ‘death,’ is repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later<sup>2</sup> as a thing of terror. There are a hundred and one
<div n="lb"/>forms of death, the natural one by old age<sup>3</sup> ({%jarā%}), and a
<div n="lb"/>hundred others, all to be avoided.<sup>4</sup> To die before old age
<div n="lb"/>({%purā jarasaḥ%})<sup>5</sup> is to die before the allotted span ({%purā āyuṣaḥ%}),<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the normal length of life being throughout Vedic literature
<div n="lb"/>spoken of as a hundred years.<sup>7</sup> On the other hand, the evils
<div n="lb"/>of old age in the loss of physical strength were clearly realized.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>one of the feats of the Aśvins was to restore old {@Cyavāna@} to
<div n="lb"/>his former youth and powers, and another was the rejuvenation
<div n="lb"/>of {@Kali.@}<sup>9</sup> The Atharvaveda<sup>10</sup> is full of charms of all sorts to
<div n="lb"/>avert death and secure length of years ({%āyuṣya%}).
<div n="P"/>The modes of disposing of the dead were burial and cremation
<div n="lb"/>(see {@Agnidagdha@}). Both existed in the early Vedic period,<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>as in Greece;<sup>12</sup> but the former method was on the whole less
<div n="lb"/>favoured, and tended to be regarded with disapproval. The
<div n="lb"/>bones of the dead, whether burned or not, were marked by the
<div n="lb"/>erection of a tumulus ({@Śmaśāna@}): the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>preserves traces of strong differences of opinion as to the mode
<div n="lb"/>in which these tumuli should be constructed. There is little
<div n="lb"/>or no trace<sup>14</sup> of the custom common in northern lands of
<div n="lb"/>sending the dead man to sea in a burning ship: the reference
[Page2-176+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>to a ship<sup>15</sup> seems to point to mythical perils after death, not to
<div n="lb"/>the mode of burial.
<div n="P"/>The life after death was to the Vedic Indian a repetition of
<div n="lb"/>the life in this world. He passed into the next world {%sarva-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%tanuḥ sāṅgaḥ,%} ‘with whole body and all his members,’<sup>16</sup> enjoying
<div n="lb"/>there the same pleasures as he had enjoyed on earth. Even
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda<sup>17</sup> there are hints of evil awaiting evil-doers, but
<div n="lb"/>it is not until the Atharvaveda<sup>18</sup> and the Brāhmaṇas<sup>19</sup> that
<div n="lb"/>a hell of punishment is set out, and it is in the Brāhmaṇas<sup>20</sup>
<div n="lb"/>that good and evil deeds are said to produce happiness or hell
<div n="lb"/>hereafter. But there is no hint of extinction<sup>21</sup> in the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>as the fate of the wicked, as Roth<sup>22</sup> inclined to think. The
<div n="lb"/>Vedic poet not being deeply moral, his verses do not convey,
<div n="lb"/>as would those of a man convinced of sin, warnings of future
<div n="lb"/>judgment.
<F>1) vii. 59, 12; x. 13, 4; 18, 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>x. 48, 5; 60, 5. So {%mṛtyu-bandhu,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘akin to death,’ Rv. viii. 18, 22; x.
<div n="lb"/>95, 18.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 5, 9, 4, where
<div n="lb"/>the world is said to be ‘yoked with
<div n="lb"/>death’ ({%mṛtyu-saṃyuta%}); Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 5, 9, 6; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 8, 2; 14, 1. 2. 3; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, x. 6, 5, 1, etc. So often the
<div n="lb"/>‘bonds of death’ ({%mṛtyu-pāśa%}), Av.
<div n="lb"/>viii. 2, 2; 8, 10. 16; xvii. 1, 30; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 10, 8, 2; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, i. 18, etc.</F>
<F>3) Av. ii. 13, 2; 28, 2.</F>
<F>4) Av. i. 30, 3; ii. 28, 1; iii. 11, 5;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 2, 27; xi. 6, 16, etc.</F>
<F>5) Rv. viii. 67, 20; Av. v. 30, 17;
<div n="lb"/>x. 2, 30; xiii. 3, 56.</F>
<F>6) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 1, 4, 1.</F>
<F>7) Rv. i. 64, 14; 89, 9; ii. 33, 2, etc.

{@Medhātithi,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Medhyātithi@}<sup>2</sup> (‘having a guest at the sacrifice’)

<L>2533<pc>2-179<k1>menA<k2>menA<h>1
1. {@Menā@}¦ in a few passages of the Rigveda denotes ‘woman.’<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The word is also used in the sense of the ‘female’ of an
<div n="lb"/>animal, either mare<sup>2</sup> or cow.<sup>3</sup>

<L>2548<pc>2-182<k1>yakzu<k2>yakzu
{@Yakṣu@}¦ is mentioned, once in the singular and once in the
<div n="lb"/>plural, in the hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> which celebrates {@Sudās@}
<div n="lb"/>battle with the ten kings. Who they were and what part they
<div n="lb"/>played in that conflict is quite uncertain. They seem, from the
<div n="lb"/>wording of the text, to have taken part in two conflicts, as
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>2</sup> says — one on the {@Paruṣṇī@} (Ravi), and one on the
<div n="lb"/>{@Yamunā@} (Jumna) — with the aid of the {@Ajas@} and {@Śigrus,@} under
<div n="lb"/>the leadership of {@Bḥeda.@} It is, however, at least possible that
<div n="lb"/>in the former passage {@Yadu@} should be read for Yakṣu, or, at
<div n="lb"/>any rate, Yakṣu be deemed a contemptuous substitute of the
<div n="lb"/>name of a possibly un-Āryan or unimportant tribe (as their
<div n="lb"/>allies, the Ajas and Śigrus, clearly were) for the name of the
<div n="lb"/>certainly famous Yadus, as is suggested by Hopkins.<sup>3</sup> {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>{@Turvaśa.@}
<F>1) vii. 18, 6. 19.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 126, 127.</F>
<F>3) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 15, 259 {%et seq.%} It is not clear
<div n="lb"/>however, whether Hopkins thinks that
<div n="lb"/>the Yadus are alluded to, but it seems
<div n="lb"/>probable.</F>

<L>2552<pc>2-183<k1>yajus<k2>yajus
{@Yajus@}¦ is repeatedly distinguished from the Ṛc and the {@Sāman@}
<div n="lb"/>in Vedic literature.<sup>1</sup> The Yajus is the utterance accompanying
<div n="lb"/>the sacrifice, and may have the form of verse or prose, the tern
<div n="lb"/>covering both.
<F>1) Rv. x. 90, 9; Av. v. 26, 1; ix. 6, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 3, 1; 9, 4;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 30; iv. 1;
<div n="lb"/>xix. 28; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 29, 21;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 13, 2; Śatapatha Brahmaṇa, i. 2,
<div n="lb"/>1, 7; vi. 5, 1, 2; 3, 4, etc. In the
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 4, 33,
<div n="lb"/>there is a reference to the {%śuklāni%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Yajūṃṣi,%} ‘white or pure Yajus,’ as
<div n="lb"/>promulgated by {@Vājasaneya Yājña-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@valkya,@} whence the Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hītā is popularly known as the ‘White
<div n="lb"/>Yajurveda.’ The theory that this is

<div n="lb"/>{%Literature,%} 103, 104; Eggeling, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 12, xxvii, and others,

<div n="lb"/>Āraṇyaka, v. 10, the expression {%śukra-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yajāṃṣi%} seems to refer to books iv. and
<div n="lb"/>v. of that text. {%Cf.%} also Winternitz.
<div n="lb"/>{%Geschichte der indischen Literatur,%} 1, 149, n.</F>

<L>2558<pc>2-185<k1>yati<k2>yati
{@Yati@}¦ is the name of an ancient clan which is connected with
<div n="lb"/>the {@Bhṛgus@} in two passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where the Yatis
<div n="lb"/>certainly seem to be real persons. In another hymn,<sup>2</sup> however,
<div n="lb"/>they already appear as almost mythical. In the Yajurveda
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās,<sup>3</sup> and elsewhere,<sup>4</sup> the Yatis are a race whom Indra, in
<div n="lb"/>an evil moment, gave over to the hyænas ({@Sālāvṛka@}): exactly
<div n="lb"/>what is referred to is uncertain. Yati is mentioned with Bhṛgu

<L>2559<pc>2-185<k1>yadu<k2>yadu
{@Yadu@}¦ is the name of a tribe and of the king of the tribe.
<div n="lb"/>They are mentioned repeatedly in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> normally in
<div n="lb"/>conjunction with {@Turvaśa.@} They seem to have taken part in
<div n="lb"/>the great battle against {@Sudās:@}<sup>2</sup> the Yadu and the Turvaśa
<div n="lb"/>kings seem to have escaped with their lives, while the {@Anu@} and
<div n="lb"/>the {@Druhyu@} kings perished. This is at least the most natural
<div n="lb"/>explanation of several passages,<sup>3</sup> though these passages possibly
<div n="lb"/>refer to a successful raid across the {@Sarayu,@} and a defeat of two
<div n="lb"/>princes, Arṇa and Citraratha.<sup>4</sup> That Turvaśa was the Yadu
<div n="lb"/>king, as Hopkins<sup>5</sup> holds, is most improbable.
<F>1) i. 36, 18; 54, 6; 174, 9; iv. 30, 17;
<div n="lb"/>v. 31, 8; vi. 45, 1; viii. 4, 7; 7, 18;
<div n="lb"/>9, 14; 10, 5; 45, 27; ix. 61, 2; x. 49, 8;
<div n="lb"/>plural, i. 108, 8. See {@Turvaśa,@} and
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 15, 258 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) Whether Yadu should be read in
<div n="lb"/>Rv. vii. 18, 6, or not, the Yadus seem
<div n="lb"/>to be meant. {%Cf.%} {@Yakṣu.@}</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 174, 9; iv. 30, 17; v. 31, 3;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 20, 12.</F>
<F>4) Rv. iv. 30, 18.</F>
<F>5) {%Loc. cit.%}
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 122,
<div n="lb"/>124; Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 205; 5, 142; Weber, {%Episches%}
<div n="lb"/>{%im vedischen Ritual,%} 37.</F>

<L>2564<pc>2-186<k1>yamunA<k2>yamunA
{@Yamunā,@}¦ ‘twin,’ the name of a river, so called as running
<div n="lb"/>parallel with the Ganges, is mentioned thrice in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and not rarely later. According to the Rigveda,<sup>2</sup> the {@Tṛtsus@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Sudās@} won a great victory against their foes on the Yamunā;
<div n="lb"/>there is no reason<sup>3</sup> whatever to accept Hopkins'<sup>4</sup> view that the
<div n="lb"/>Yamunā here was another name of the {@Paruṣṇī@} (Ravi). In the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> the salve ({@Āñjana@}) of the Yamunā ({%Yāmuna%}) is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned along with that of {@Trikakud@} ({%Traikakuda%}) as of value.
<div n="lb"/>In the Aitareya<sup>6</sup> and the Śatapatha<sup>7</sup> Brāhmaṇas the {@Bharatas@}
<div n="lb"/>are famed as victorious on the Yamunā. Other Brāhmaṇas<sup>8</sup>
[Page2-187+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>also mention this river. In the Mantrapāṭha<sup>9</sup> the {@Sālvas@} are
<div n="lb"/>spoken of as dwelling on its banks.
<F>1) v. 52, 17; vii. 18, 19; x. 75, 5.</F>
<F>2) vii. 18, 19. See {@Bharata@} and {@Kuru.@}</F>
<F>3) The Tṛtsus’ territory lay between
<div n="lb"/>the Yamunā and the {@Sarasvatī@} on the
<div n="lb"/>east and the west respectively.</F>
<F>4) {%India, Old and New,%} 52.</F>
<F>5) iv. 9, 10.</F>
<F>6) viii. 23.</F>
<F>7) xiii. 5, 4, 11.</F>
<F>8) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, ix. 4, 11
<div n="lb"/>({%cf.%} {@Pārāvata@}); xxv. 10, 24; 13, 4;

<L>2566<pc>2-187<k1>yava<k2>yava<h>1
1. {@Yava@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> appears to be a generic term for
<div n="lb"/>any sort of ‘grain,’ and not merely ‘barley.’ The latter sense
<div n="lb"/>is probably found in the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> and is regular later.
<div n="lb"/>The barley harvest came after spring,<sup>3</sup> in the summer.<sup>4</sup> That
<div n="lb"/>barley was cultivated in the period of the Rigveda<sup>5</sup> is not
<div n="lb"/>certain, but on the whole very probable.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) i. 23, 15; 66, 3; 117, 21; 135, 8;
<div n="lb"/>176, 2; ii. 5, 6; 14, 11; v. 85, 3;
<div n="lb"/>vii. 3, 4; viii. 2, 3; 22, 6; 63. 9; 78,
<div n="lb"/>10, etc.</F>
<F>2) ii. 8, 3; vi. 30, 1; 50. 1. 2; 91, 1;
<div n="lb"/>141, 2; 142, 1. 2; viii. 7, 20; ix. 1, 22;
<div n="lb"/>6, 14; xii. 1, 42; Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>vi. 2, 10, 3; 4, 10, 5; vii. 2, 10, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxv. 10; xxvi. 5;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 2; Vāja-

<div n="lb"/>ii. 5, 2, 1; iii. 6, 1, 9. 10; iv. 2, 1, 11;

<L>2578<pc>2-189<k1>yAjYavalkya<k2>yAjYavalkya
{@Yājña-valkya,@}¦ ‘descendant of Yajñavalkya,’ is repeatedly
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> as an authority on
<div n="lb"/>questions of ritual. He is, however, also given as an authority
<div n="lb"/>on questions of philosophy in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>but Oldenberg<sup>3</sup> is, no doubt, right in thinking that no possible
<div n="lb"/>importance can be attached to the mention of Yājñavalkya in
<div n="lb"/>the latter capacity. He is said to have been a pupil of
<div n="lb"/>{@Uddālaka Āruṇi,@}<sup>4</sup> whom he opposed successfully in a dispute.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>His two wives, {@Maitreyī@} and {@Kātyāyanī,@} are mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad,<sup>6</sup> which concludes<sup>7</sup> with a passage
<div n="lb"/>ascribing to Yājñavalkya Vājasaneya the ‘white Yajus’ ({%śuklāni%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yajūṃṣi%}). It is remarkable that Yājñavalkya is never mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in any other Vedic text outside the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>except the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka,<sup>8</sup> where, however, both
<div n="lb"/>reference are merely transcripts from the Śatapatha.<sup>9</sup> It has
[Page2-190+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>been supposed by Oldenberg<sup>10</sup> and others that Yājñavalkya
<div n="lb"/>belonged to {@Videha,@} but despite the legend of Janaka's patronage
<div n="lb"/>of him, his association with {@Uddālaka,@} the {@Kuru-Pañcāla,@}
<div n="lb"/>renders this doubtful.
<F>1) i. 1, 1, 9; 3, 1, 21. 26; 9, 3, 16;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 3, 1, 21; 4, 3, 2; 5, 1, 2 (where he
<div n="lb"/>is said to be in contradiction with the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda); iii. 1, 1, 4; 2, 21; 3, 10;
<div n="lb"/>8, 2, 24 (cursed by a {@Caraka@} teacher);
<div n="lb"/>iv. 2, 1, 7; 6, 1, 10; 8, 7, etc. There
<div n="lb"/>are no references to Yājñavalkya in
<div n="lb"/>books v-ix, which, on the contrary,
<div n="lb"/>owe their doctrine to {@Tura Kāvaṣeya@}
<div n="lb"/>and Śāṇḍilya; but the fame of Yājña-
<div n="lb"/>valkya revives in books x-xiv — {%e.g.,%}
<div n="lb"/>xi. 3, 1, 2; 4, 2, 17; 3, 20; 6, 2, 1;
<div n="lb"/>3, 1; xii. 4, 1, 10, etc.</F>
<F>2) iii. 1, 2 {%et seq.;%} 2, 10 {%et seq.;%} 3, 1;
<div n="lb"/>4, 1; 5, 1; 6, 1; 7, 1, etc.</F>
<F>3) {%Buddha,%}^5 34, n. 1.</F>
<F>4) vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5,
<div n="lb"/>4 Kāṇva).</F>
<F>5) iii. 7, 1.</F>
<F>6) ii. 4, 1; iv. 5, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>7) vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5,
<div n="lb"/>4 Kāṇva).</F>
<F>8) ix. 7; xiii. 1.</F>
<F>9) Weber, {%Indian Literature,%} 132, n. *;
<div n="lb"/>Keith, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>1908, 374.</F>
<F>10) {%Buddha,%}^5 34, n. 1.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indian Literature,%} 120
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.; Indische Studien,%} 1, 173; 13, 265-
<div n="lb"/>269; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>12, xxx {%et seq.;%} von Schroeder, {%Indiens%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Literatur und Cultur,%} 188.</F>

<L>2579<pc>2-190<k1>yAjyA<k2>yAjyA
