<L>2593<pc>2-192<k1>yuga<k2>yuga<h>2
2. {@Yuga@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> frequently denotes a ‘generation’;
<div n="lb"/>but the expression {%daśame yuge%} applied to {@Dīrghatamas@} in one
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>2</sup> must mean ‘tenth decade’ of life.
<div n="P"/>There is no reference in the older Vedic texts to the five-year
<div n="lb"/>cycle (see {@Saṃvatsara@}). The quotation from the Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> given in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, and by
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>4</sup> and others, is merely a citation from a modern text
<div n="lb"/>in the commentary on that work.
<div n="P"/>Nor do the older Vedic texts know of any series of Yugas or
<div n="lb"/>ages such as are usual later. In the Atharvaveda<sup>5</sup> there are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in order a hundred years, an {%ayuta%} (10,000?), and
<div n="lb"/>then two, three, or four Yugas: the inference from this seems
<div n="lb"/>to be that a Yuga means more than an {%ayuta,%} but is not very
[Page2-193+ 67]
<div n="lb"/>certain. Zimmer<sup>6</sup> adduces a passage from the Rigveda,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>but the reference there, whatever it may be,<sup>8</sup> is certainly
<div n="lb"/>not to the four ages ({%cf.%} also {@Triyuga@}).<sup>9</sup> The Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>10</sup> recognizes long periods of time — {%e.g.,%} one of
<div n="lb"/>100,000 years.
<div n="P"/>To the four ages, Kali, Dvāpara, Tretā, and Kṛta, there is no
<div n="lb"/>certain reference in Vedic literature, though the names occur as
<div n="lb"/>the designations of throws at dice (see {@Akṣa@}). In the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup> the names occur, but it is not clear that the ages
<div n="lb"/>are really meant. Haug<sup>12</sup> thought that the dice were meant:
<div n="lb"/>this view is at least as probable as the alternative explanation,
<div n="lb"/>which is accepted by Weber,<sup>13</sup> Roth,<sup>14</sup> Wilson,<sup>15</sup> Max Müller,<sup>16</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and Muir.<sup>17</sup> Roth, indeed, believes that the verse is an inter-
<div n="lb"/>polation; but in any case it must be remembered that the
<div n="lb"/>passage is from a late book of the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa. Four
<div n="lb"/>ages — Puṣya, Dvāpara, Khārvā, and Kṛta — are mentioned in
<div n="lb"/>the late Ṣaḍviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>18</sup> and the Dvāpara in the Gopatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa.<sup>19</sup>
<F>1) {%Yuge-yuge,%} ‘in every age,’ i. 139, 8;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 26, 3; vi. 8, 5; 15, 8; 36, 5; ix. 94,
<div n="lb"/>12; {%uttarā yugāni,%} ‘future ages,’ iii. 33, 8;
<div n="lb"/>x. 10, 10; {%pūrvāṇi yugāni,%} vii. 70, 4;
<div n="lb"/>{%uttare yuge,%} x. 72, 1, etc. In i. 92, 11;
<div n="lb"/>103, 4; 115, 2; 124, 2; 144, 4, etc., the
<div n="lb"/>phrase ‘generations of men’ ({%manṣyā,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%manuṣaḥ, janānām%}) are referred
<div n="lb"/>to. See Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 12, 45, 46.</F>
<F>2) i. 158, 6. Wilson, Translation, 2,
<div n="lb"/>104, n., suggests that {%yuga%} here means
<div n="lb"/>a lustrum of five years; but the tenth
<div n="lb"/>decade is far more likely, as Dīrgha-
<div n="lb"/>tamas is said to be ‘aged’ ({%jujurvān%}).</F>
<F>3) xvii. 13, 17.</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 368.</F>
<F>5) viii. 2, 21.</F>
<F>6) {%Op. cit.,%} 371.</F>
<F>7) viii. 101, 4 = Av. x. 8, 3.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} Aitareya Āraṇyaka, ii. 1, 1, with
<div n="lb"/>Keith's note; Griffith, {%Hymns of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Rigveda,%} 2, 253.</F>
<F>9) In Rv. x. 72, 2, {%devānāṃ pūrvye%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yuge,%} ‘in the earlier age of the gods,’
<div n="lb"/>occurs.</F>
<F>10) iii. 12, 9, 2. {%Cf.%} Muir, 12, 42,
<div n="lb"/>n. 66.</F>
<F>11) vii. 15, 4 (in the description of the
<div n="lb"/>merits of exertion): ‘A man while lying
<div n="lb"/>is the Kali; moving himself, he is the
<div n="lb"/>Dvāpara; rising, he is the Tretā;
<div n="lb"/>walking, he becomes the Kṛta’ ({%Kaliḥ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%śayāno bhavati saṃjihānas tu Dvāparaḥ |%}
<div n="lb"/>{%uttiṣṭhaṃs Tretā bhavati, Kṛtaṃ saṃpad-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%yate caran||%}).</F>
<F>12) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, 2, 464, criti-
<div n="lb"/>cized by Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 9, 319.</F>
<F>13) {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 286; 9, 315
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>
<F>14) {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 460.</F>
<F>15) {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>1851, 99.</F>
<F>16) {%Ancient Sanskrit Literature,%} 412.</F>
<F>17) {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 12, 48, n. 86.</F>
<F>18) v. 6.</F>
<F>19) i. 1, 28; Weber, {%Indian Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>151, n. 166; Windisch, {%Buddha und%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Māra,%} 151.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 367-
<div n="lb"/>371; Weber, {%Indische Streifen,%} 1, 91.
<div n="lb"/>A quite different theory of the Yugas
<div n="lb"/>is given by Shamasastry, {%Gavām Ayana,%}
<div n="lb"/>141 {%et seq.,%} but his whole theory is quite
<div n="lb"/>impossible. Weber once ({%Indian Litera-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ture,%} 113, n. 127) found the mention of
<div n="lb"/>the quinquennial Yuga in Rv. iii. 55,
<div n="lb"/>18, but that passage refers to the five
<div n="lb"/>or six seasons (see Griffith, {%Hymns of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the Rigveda,%} 1, 382, n.), while i. 25, 8,
<div n="lb"/>merely alludes to the intercalary month.
<div n="lb"/>Weber also ({%op. cit.,%} 70, 247) considers
<div n="lb"/>that the Yugas are derived from the
<div n="lb"/>phases of the moon, but this idea was
<div n="lb"/>long since disposed of by Roth, {%Die%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Lehre von den vier Weltaltern%} (Tübingen,
<div n="lb"/>1860).</F>
<LEND>
[Page2-194+ 48]

<L>2604<pc>2-195<k1>yojana<k2>yojana
{@Yojana@}¦ occurs frequently in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> as a
<div n="lb"/>measure of distance,<sup>3</sup> but there is no reference defining its real
[Page2-196+ 40]
<div n="lb"/>length. Later it is reckoned at four {@Krośas,@} or about nine
<div n="lb"/>miles.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) i. 123, 8; ii. 16, 3; x. 78, 7; 86, 20,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 26, 1; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 9, 9; iii. 8, 4; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>ii. 4, 2, 7, etc. {%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Leben,%} 363, who finds in Rv. i. 123, 8,
<div n="lb"/>{%yojana%} as a division of time equivalent
<div n="lb"/>to the {@Muhūrta.@} But this is most
<div n="lb"/>improbable.</F>
<F>3) That is, the distance driven in
<div n="lb"/>one ‘harnessing’ (without unyoking),
<div n="lb"/>a ‘stage.’</F>
<F>4) Sometimes calculated at 8 krośas, or 18 miles. The estimate of 2(1/2) miles
<div n="lb"/>is also found.</F>

<L>2626<pc>2-199<k1>ratnin<k2>ratnin
{@Ratnin,@}¦ ‘receiving gifts,’ is the term applied to those people
<div n="lb"/>of the royal entourage in whose houses the Ratna-havis, a
[Page2-200+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>special rite, was performed in the course of the {@Rājasūya@} or
<div n="lb"/>‘royal consecration.’ The list given in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> consists of the Brahman ({%i.e.,%}
<div n="lb"/>the Purohita), the Rājanya, the Mahiṣī (the first wife of the
<div n="lb"/>king), the {@Vāvāta@} (the favourite wife of the king), the Parivṛktī
<div n="lb"/>(the discarded wife), the Senānī, ‘commander of the army’; the
<div n="lb"/>Sūta, ‘charioteer’; the Grāmaṇī, ‘village headman’; the
<div n="lb"/>Kṣattṛ, ‘chamberlain’; the Saṃgrahītṛ, ‘charioteer’ or
<div n="lb"/>‘treasurer’; the Bhāgadugha, ‘collector of taxes’ or ‘divider
<div n="lb"/>of food’; and the Akṣāvāpa, ‘superintender of dicing’ or
<div n="lb"/>‘thrower of dice.’ In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> the order is
<div n="lb"/>Senānī; Purohita; Mahisī; Sūta; Grāmaṇī; Kṣattṛ; Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>grahitṛ; Bhāgadugha; Akṣāvāpa; Go-nikartana, ‘slayer of
<div n="lb"/>cows’ or ‘huntsman’; and Pālāgala, ‘courier’; the ‘discarded
<div n="lb"/>wife’ being mentioned as forbidden to stay at home<sup>4</sup> on the
<div n="lb"/>day of the ceremony of offering a pap for Nirṛti in her house.
<div n="lb"/>In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>5</sup> the list is Brahman ({%i.e.,%} Puro-
<div n="lb"/>hita); Rājan; Mahiṣī; Parivṛktī; Senānī; Saṃgrahītṛ; Kṣattṛ;
<div n="lb"/>Sūta; Vaiśyagrāmaṇī; Bhāgadugha; Takṣa-Rathakārau, ‘car-
<div n="lb"/>penter and chariot-maker’; Akṣāvāpa; and Go-vikarta. The
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>6</sup> substitutes Go-vyacha for Govikarta, and
<div n="lb"/>omits Takṣa-Rathakārau.
<div n="P"/>It will be seen that the list is essentially that of the royal
<div n="lb"/>household, and of the king's servants in the administration of
<div n="lb"/>the country, though the exact sense of {@Saṃgrahītṛ, Bhāga-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@dugha, Sūta, Grāmaṇī, Kṣattṛ,@} is open to reasonable doubt,
<div n="lb"/>mainly as to whether public officers or private servants<sup>7</sup> are
<div n="lb"/>meant, for the names are of uncertain significance. A briefer
<div n="lb"/>list of eight {@Vīras,@} ‘heroes,’ as among the friends of the king,
[Page2-201+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>is given in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa:<sup>8</sup> brother, son, Purohita,
<div n="lb"/>Mahiṣī, Sūta, Grāmaṇī, Kṣattṛ, and Saṃgrahītṛ.
<F>1) i. 8, 9, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) i. 7, 3, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) v. 3, 1, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) According to Kātyāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xv. 3, 35, she goes to a Brahmin's
<div n="lb"/>house, where she shares his inviolability
<div n="lb"/>and exemption from jurisdiction.</F>
<F>5) ii. 6, 5; iv. 3, 8.</F>
<F>6) xv. 4.</F>
<F>7) Similarly Akṣāvāpa is either the
<div n="lb"/>man who dices for the king — {%i.e.,%} a
<div n="lb"/>professional dicer who plays with the
<div n="lb"/>king or watches his play — or a public
<div n="lb"/>officer who superintends the gambling
<div n="lb"/>halls of the state and collects the
<div n="lb"/>revenue, as was regularly done later on.
<div n="lb"/>Early English history shows similar
<div n="lb"/>evolution of household officers into
<div n="lb"/>ministers of state.</F>
<F>8) xix. 1, 4.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 200;
<div n="lb"/>{%Über den Rājasūya,%} 4; Hopkins, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the American Oriental Society,%} 13, 128;
<div n="lb"/>Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 41,
<div n="lb"/>58-65; Hopkins, {%Trañsactions of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,%}
<div n="lb"/>15, 30, n. 2.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2627<pc>2-201<k1>raTa<k2>raTa
{@Ratha@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> denotes ‘chariot’ as
<div n="lb"/>opposed to {@Anas,@} ‘cart,’ though the distinction is not absolute.
<div n="lb"/>Of differences in the structure of the two we have no informa-
<div n="lb"/>tion, except that the {@Kha,@} or nave hole, in the wheel of the
<div n="lb"/>chariot was greater than in that of the cart.<sup>3</sup>
<div n="P"/>The chariot has, as a rule, two wheels ({@Cakra@}), to which
<div n="lb"/>reference is frequently made.<sup>4</sup> The wheel consisted of a rim
<div n="lb"/>({@Pavi@}), a felly ({@Pradhi@}), spokes ({@Ara@}),<sup>5</sup> and a nave ({@Nabhya@}).
<div n="lb"/>The rim and the felly together constitute the {@Nemi.@} The hole
<div n="lb"/>in the nave is called {@Kha:@} into it the end of the axle was
<div n="lb"/>inserted; but there is some uncertainty whether {@Āṇi@} denotes
<div n="lb"/>the extremity of the axle that was inserted in the nave, or the
<div n="lb"/>lynch-pin used to keep that extremity in the wheel. Sometimes
<div n="lb"/>a solid wheel was used.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>The axle ({@Akṣa@}) was, in some cases, made of {@Araṭu@} wood;<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>round its ends the wheels revolved. To the axle was attached
<div n="lb"/>the body of the chariot ({@Kośa@}). This part is also denoted by
<div n="lb"/>the word {@Vandhura,@} which more precisely means the ‘seat’
<div n="lb"/>of the chariot. The epithet {%tri-vandhura%} is used of the chariot
<div n="lb"/>of the Aśvins, seemingly to correspond with another of its
<div n="lb"/>epithets, {%tri-cakra:%} perhaps, as Weber<sup>8</sup> thinks, a chariot with
<div n="lb"/>three seats and three wheels was a real form of vehicle; but
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>9</sup> considers that the vehicle was purely mythical. {@Garta@}
<div n="lb"/>also denotes the seat of the warrior.
[Page2-202+ 61]
<div n="P"/>At right angles to the axle was the pole of the chariot ({@Īṣā,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Praüga@}). Normally there was, it seems, one pole, on either
<div n="lb"/>side of which the horses were harnessed, a yoke ({@Yuga@}) being
<div n="lb"/>laid across their necks; the pole was passed through the hole
<div n="lb"/>in the yoke (called Kha<sup>10</sup> or Tardman),<sup>11</sup> the yoke and the pole
<div n="lb"/>then being tied together.<sup>12</sup>
<div n="P"/>The horses were tied by the neck ({%grīvā%}), where the yoke was
<div n="lb"/>placed, and also at the shoulder, presumably by traces fastened
<div n="lb"/>to a bar of wood at right angles to the pole, or fastened to the
<div n="lb"/>ends of the pole, if that is to be regarded, as it probably
<div n="lb"/>should, as of triangular shape, wide at the foot and coming to
<div n="lb"/>a point at the tip.<sup>13</sup> The traces seem to be denoted by {@Raśmi@}
<div n="lb"/>and {@Raśanā.@} These words also denote the ‘reins,’ which were
<div n="lb"/>fastened to the bit (perhaps {%śiprā%}) in the horse's mouth. The
<div n="lb"/>driver controlled the horses by reins, and urged them on with
<div n="lb"/>a whip ({%Kaśā%}).<sup>14</sup> The girths of the horse were called Kakṣyā.<sup>15</sup>
<div n="P"/>The normal number of horses seems to have been two, but
<div n="lb"/>three or four<sup>16</sup> were often used. It is uncertain whether, in
<div n="lb"/>these cases, the extra horse was attached in front or at the
<div n="lb"/>side; possibly both modes were in use. Even five steeds could
<div n="lb"/>be employed.<sup>17</sup> Horses were normally used for chariots, but
<div n="lb"/>the ass ({%gardabha%})<sup>18</sup> or mule ({%aśvatarī%})<sup>19</sup> are also mentioned.
<div n="lb"/>The ox was employed for drawing carts, and in fact derived its
[Page2-203+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>name, {@Anaḍvāh,@} from this use. Sometimes a poor man had to
<div n="lb"/>be content with a single steed, which then ran between two
<div n="lb"/>shafts.<sup>20</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the chariot the driver stood on the right, while the
<div n="lb"/>warrior was on the left, as indicated by his name, {@Savyeṣṭha@} or
<div n="lb"/>{@Savyaṣṭhā,@}<sup>21</sup> He could also sit when he wanted, for the
<div n="lb"/>chariot had seats, and an archer would naturally prefer to sit
<div n="lb"/>while shooting his arrows.
<div n="P"/>The dimensions of the chariot are given in the Śulba Sūtra<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>of Āpastamba at 188 Aṅgulis (finger-breadths) for the pole,
<div n="lb"/>104 for the axle, and 86 for the yoke. The material used in
<div n="lb"/>its construction was wood, except for the rim of the wheel.<sup>23</sup>
<div n="P"/>Many other parts of the chariot are mentioned, their names
<div n="lb"/>being often obscure in meaning: see {@Aṅka, Nyaṅka, Uddhi,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Pakṣas, Pātalya, Bhurij, Rathopastha, Rathavāhana.@}
<F>1) i. 20, 3; iii. 15, 5; iv. 4, 10; 16,
<div n="lb"/>20; 36, 2; 43, 25, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 14, 5; x. 1, 8: Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vii. 12, 3, etc.</F>
<F>3) viii. 91, 7, with Sāyaṇa's note;
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 333.</F>

<L>2628<pc>2-203<k1>raTakAra<k2>raTakAra
{@Ratha-kāra,@}¦ ‘chariot-maker,’ is mentioned in the Atharva-
<div n="lb"/>veda<sup>1</sup> as one of those who are to be subject to the king, seeming
<div n="lb"/>to stand generally as an example of the industrial population.
<div n="lb"/>He is also referred to in the Yajurveda Saṃhitās<sup>2</sup> and in the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas:<sup>3</sup> in all these passages, as well a probably in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda also, the Rathakāra already forms a caste. The
[Page2-204+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>later system<sup>4</sup> regards the Rathakāra as the offspring of a
<div n="lb"/>Māhiṣya (the son of a Kṣatriya husband and a Vaiśya wife) and
<div n="lb"/>a Karaṇī (the daughter of a Vaiśya husband and a Śūdra wife),
<div n="lb"/>but it is unreasonable to suppose that such an origin is
<div n="lb"/>historically accurate. The Rathakāras must rather be deemed
<div n="lb"/>to have been a functional caste. Hillebrandt<sup>5</sup> suggests that
<div n="lb"/>the {@Anu@} tribe formed the basis of the Rathakāra caste, referring
<div n="lb"/>to their worship of the Ṛbhus, who are, of course, the chariot-
<div n="lb"/>makers {%par excellence.%} But there is little ground for this view.
<F>1) iii. 5, 6.</F>
<F>2) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvii. 13; Maitrā-
<div n="lb"/>yaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xvi. 17; xxx. 6.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 4, 8;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 4, 2, 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>2, 17.</F>
<F>4) Yājñavalkya, i. 95. On the special
<div n="lb"/>position, in the later ritual, of the
<div n="lb"/>Rathakāra as a caste below the Vaiśya,
<div n="lb"/>but superior to the Śūdra, {%cf.%} Weber,
<div n="lb"/>{%Indische Studien,%} 10, 12, 13, and {%cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Varṇa, see also Fick, {%Die sociale Glie-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%derung,%} 209, 210.</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 3, 152, 153.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 196
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>

<L>2656<pc>2-209<k1>rasA<k2>rasA
{@Rasā@}¦ is found in three passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> clearly as the
<div n="lb"/>name of a real stream in the extreme north-west of the Vedic
<div n="lb"/>territory. Elsewhere<sup>2</sup> it is the name of a mythic stream at
<div n="lb"/>the ends of the earth, which as well as the atmosphere it
<div n="lb"/>encompasses. It is reasonable to assume that, as in the case of
<div n="lb"/>the {@Sarasvatī,@} the literal is the older sense, and to see in the
<div n="lb"/>river a genuine stream, perhaps originally the Araxes or
<div n="lb"/>Jaxartes, because the Vendidad mentions the Raṅhā, the
<div n="lb"/>Avestan form of Rasā. But the word seems originally to allude
<div n="lb"/>merely to the ‘sap’ or ‘flavour’ of the waters,<sup>3</sup> and so could be
<div n="lb"/>applied to every river, like Sarasvatī.
<F>1) i. 112, 12; v. 53, 9; x. 75, 6. In
<div n="lb"/>v. 53, 9, the phrase {%rasānitabhā%} is found.
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3,
<div n="lb"/>202, is inclined to regard {%anitabhā%} as an
<div n="lb"/>epithet of Rasā, perhaps for {%amitabhā,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘of unmeasured splendour,’ but this is
<div n="lb"/>hardly probable. It seems better to
<div n="lb"/>take Anitabhā as the name of an other-
<div n="lb"/>wise unknown river. {%Cf.%} Max Müller,
<div n="lb"/>{%India,%} 166, 173, n.</F>
<F>2) Rv. v. 41, 15; ix. 41, 6; x. 100,
<div n="lb"/>1, 2 ({%cf.%} Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, ii. 348;
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%}
<div n="lb"/>19, 100 {%et seq.%}); 121, 4.</F>
<F>3) Rv. iv. 43, 6; viii. 72, 13.

<LEND>

<L>2664<pc>2-210<k1>rAjan<k2>rAjan<h>1
1. {@Rājan,@}¦ ‘king,’ is a term repeatedly occurring in the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda<sup>1</sup> and the later literature.<sup>2</sup> It is quite clear that the
<div n="lb"/>normal, though not universal form of government, in early
<div n="lb"/>India was that by kings, as might be expected in view of the
<div n="lb"/>fact that the Āryan Indians were invaders in a hostile territory:
<div n="lb"/>a situation which, as in the case of the Āryan invaders of
<div n="lb"/>Greece and of the German invaders of England, resulted almost
<div n="lb"/>necessarily in strengthening the monarchic element of the
<div n="lb"/>constitution.<sup>3</sup> The mere patriarchal organization of society
<div n="lb"/>is not sufficient, as Zimmer<sup>4</sup> assumes, to explain the Vedic
<div n="lb"/>kingship.
[Page2-211+ 53]
<div n="P"/>{%Tenure of Monarchy.%} — Zimmer<sup>5</sup> is of opinion that while the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic monarchy was sometimes hereditary, as is indeed shown
<div n="lb"/>by several cases where the descent can be traced,<sup>6</sup> yet in others
<div n="lb"/>the monarchy was elective, though it is not clear whether the
<div n="lb"/>selection by the people was between the members of the royal
<div n="lb"/>family only or extended to members of all the noble clans. It
<div n="lb"/>must, however, be admitted that the evidence for the elective
<div n="lb"/>monarchy is not strong. As Geldner<sup>7</sup> argues, all the passages
<div n="lb"/>cited<sup>8</sup> can be regarded not as choice by the cantons ({@Viś@}), but
<div n="lb"/>as acceptance by the subjects ({%viś%}): this seems the more prob-
<div n="lb"/>able sense. Of course this is no proof that the monarchy was
<div n="lb"/>not sometimes elective: the practice of selecting one member
<div n="lb"/>of the family to the exclusion of another less well qualified is
<div n="lb"/>exemplified by the legend in Yāska<sup>9</sup> of the Kuru brothers,
<div n="lb"/>{@Devāpi@} and {@Śantanu,@} the value of which, as evidence of
<div n="lb"/>contemporary views, is not seriously affected by the legend
<div n="lb"/>itself being of dubious character and validity.
<div n="P"/>Royal power was clearly insecure: there are several references
<div n="lb"/>to kings being expelled from their realms, and their efforts to
<div n="lb"/>recover their sovereignty,<sup>10</sup> and the Atharvaveda contains spells
<div n="lb"/>in the interest of royalty.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%The King in War.%} — Naturally the Vedic texts, after the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, contain few notices of the warlike adventures that no
<div n="lb"/>doubt formed a very considerable proportion of the royal
<div n="lb"/>functions. But the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>12</sup> contains the state-
<div n="lb"/>ment that the {@Kuru-Pañcāla@} kings, who, like the Brahmins of
[Page2-212+ 71]
<div n="lb"/>those tribes, stand as representatives of good form, used to
<div n="lb"/>make their raids in the dewy season. The word {@Udāja,@} too,
<div n="lb"/>with its variant Nirāja, records that kings took a share of the
<div n="lb"/>booty of war. The Rigveda<sup>13</sup> has many references to Vedic
<div n="lb"/>wars: it is clear that the Kṣatriyas were at least as intent on
<div n="lb"/>fulfilling their duty of war as the Brahmins on sacrificing and
<div n="lb"/>their other functions. Moreover, beside offensive war, defence
<div n="lb"/>was a chief duty of the king: he is emphatically the ‘protector
<div n="lb"/>of the tribe’ ({%gopā janasya%}), or, as is said in the {@Rājasūya@}
<div n="lb"/>(‘royal consecration’), ‘protector of the Brahmin.’<sup>14</sup> His
<div n="lb"/>{@Purohita@} was expected to use his spells and charms to secure
<div n="lb"/>the success of his king's arms. The king no doubt fought in
<div n="lb"/>person: so {@Pratardana@} met death in war according to the
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad;<sup>15</sup> and in the Rājasūya the king is invoked
<div n="lb"/>as ‘sacker of cities’ ({%purāṃ bhettā%}).
<div n="P"/>{%The King in Peace.%} — In return for his warlike services the
<div n="lb"/>king received the obedience<sup>16</sup> — sometimes forced<sup>17</sup> — of the
<div n="lb"/>people, and in particular their contributions for the mainten-
<div n="lb"/>ance of royalty. The king is regularly<sup>18</sup> regarded as ‘devouring
[Page2-213+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>the people,’ but this phrase must not be explained as meaning that
<div n="lb"/>he necessarily oppressed them. It obviously has its origin in a
<div n="lb"/>custom by which the king and his retinue were fed by the
<div n="lb"/>people's contributions, a plan with many parallels. It is also
<div n="lb"/>probable that the king could assign the royal right of mainten-
<div n="lb"/>ance to a Kṣatriya, thus developing a nobility supported by the
<div n="lb"/>people. Taxation would not normally fall on Kṣatriya or
<div n="lb"/>Brahmin; the texts contain emphatic assertions of the exemp-
<div n="lb"/>tion of the goods of the latter from the royal bounty.<sup>19</sup>In
<div n="lb"/>the people, however, lay the strength of the king.<sup>20</sup> See also
<div n="lb"/>{@Bali.@}
<div n="P"/>In return the king performed the duties of judge. Himself
<div n="lb"/>immune from punishment ({%a-daṇḍya%}), he wields the rod of
<div n="lb"/>punishment ({@Daṇḍa@}).<sup>21</sup> It is probable that criminal justice
<div n="lb"/>remained largely in his actual administration, for the Sūtras<sup>22</sup>
<div n="lb"/>preserve clear traces of the personal exercise of royal criminal
<div n="lb"/>jurisdiction. Possibly the jurisdiction could be exercised by a
<div n="lb"/>royal officer, or even by a delegate, for a Rājanya is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>as an overseer ({%adhyakṣa%}) of the punishment of a Śūdra in the
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā.<sup>23</sup> In civil justice it may be that the king
<div n="lb"/>played a much less prominent part, save as a court of final
<div n="lb"/>appeal, but evidence is lacking on this head. The {@Madhyamaśī@}
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda was probably not a royal, but a private
<div n="lb"/>judge or arbitrator. A wide criminal jurisdiction is, how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, to some extent supported<sup>24</sup> by the frequent mention of
<div n="lb"/>Varuṇa's spies, for Varuṇa is the divine counterpart of the
<div n="lb"/>human king.<sup>25</sup> Possibly such spies could be used in war
<div n="lb"/>also.<sup>26</sup>
<div n="P"/>There is no reference in early Vedic literature to the exercise
<div n="lb"/>of legislative activity by the king, though later it is an essential
[Page2-214+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>part of his duties.<sup>27</sup> Nor can we say exactly what executive
<div n="lb"/>functions devolved on the king.
<div n="P"/>In all his acts the king was regularly advised by his {@Puro-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@hita;@} he also had the advantage of the advice of the royal
<div n="lb"/>ministers and attendants (see {@Ratnin@}). The local administra-
<div n="lb"/>tion was entrusted to the {@Grāmaṇī,@} or village chief, who may
<div n="lb"/>have been selected or appointed by the king. The outward signs
<div n="lb"/>of the king's rank were his palace<sup>28</sup> and his brilliant dress.<sup>29</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%The King as Landowner.%} — The position of the king with
<div n="lb"/>regard to the land is somewhat obscure. The Greek notices,<sup>30</sup>
<div n="lb"/>in which, unhappily, it would be dangerous to put much trust,
<div n="lb"/>since they were collected by observers who were probably little
<div n="lb"/>used to accurate investigations of such matters, and whose
<div n="lb"/>statements were based on inadequate information, vary in their
<div n="lb"/>statements. In part they speak of rent being paid, and declare
<div n="lb"/>that only the king and no private person could own land, while
<div n="lb"/>in part they refer to the taxation of land. Hopkins<sup>31</sup> is strongly
<div n="lb"/>of opinion that the payments made were paid for protection
<div n="lb"/>-{%i.e.,%} in modern terminology as a tax, but that the king was
<div n="lb"/>recognized as the owner of all the land, while yet the individual
<div n="lb"/>or the joint family also owned the land. As against Baden-
<div n="lb"/>Powell,<sup>32</sup> who asserted that the idea of the king as a landowner
<div n="lb"/>was later, he urges for the Vedic period that the king, as we
<div n="lb"/>have seen, is described as devouring the people, and that,
<div n="lb"/>according to the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,<sup>33</sup> the {@Vaiśya@} can be
<div n="lb"/>devoured at will and maltreated (but, unlike the {@Śūdra,@} not
<div n="lb"/>killed); and for the period of the legal Sūtras and Śāstras he
<div n="lb"/>cites Bṛhaspati and Nārada as clearly recognizing the king's
<div n="lb"/>overlordship, besides a passage of the Mānava Dharma Śāstra<sup>34</sup>
<div n="lb"/>which describes the king as ‘lord of all,’ a phrase which
[Page2-215+ 59]
<div n="lb"/>Bühler<sup>35</sup> was inclined to interpret as a proof of landowning.
<div n="lb"/>The evidence is, however, inadequate to prove what is sought.
<div n="lb"/>It is not denied that gradually the king came to be vaguely con-
<div n="lb"/>ceived — as the English king still is — as lord of all the land in a
<div n="lb"/>proprietorial sense, but it is far more probable that such an idea
<div n="lb"/>was only a gradual development than that it was primitive.
<div n="lb"/>The power of devouring the people is a political power, not a
<div n="lb"/>right of ownership; precisely the same feature can be traced in
<div n="lb"/>South Africa,<sup>36</sup> where the chief can deprive a man arbitrarily of
<div n="lb"/>his land, though the land is really owned by the native. The
<div n="lb"/>matter is ultimately to some extent one of terminology, but the
<div n="lb"/>parallel cases are in favour of distinguishing between the
<div n="lb"/>political rights of the crown, which can be transferred by way
<div n="lb"/>of a grant, and the rights of ownership. Hopkins<sup>37</sup> thinks
<div n="lb"/>that the gifts of land to priests, which seems to be the first
<div n="lb"/>sign of land transactions in the Brāhmaṇas, was an actual gift
<div n="lb"/>of land; it may have been so in many cases, but it may easily
<div n="lb"/>also have been the grant of a superiority: the Epic grants are
<div n="lb"/>hardly decisive one way or the other.
<div n="P"/>For the relations of the king with the assembly, see {@Sabhā;@}
<div n="lb"/>for his consecration, see {@Rājasūya.@} A-rāja-tā, ‘lack of a king,’
<div n="lb"/>means ‘anarchy.’<sup>38</sup>

<L>2665<pc>2-215<k1>rAjan<k2>rAjan<h>2
2. {@Rājan@}¦ in several passages-means no more than a ‘noble of
<div n="lb"/>the ruling house,’ or perhaps even merely a ‘noble,’ there being
<div n="P"/>1 {%Cf.%} Rv. i. 40, 8; 108, 7; x. 42, 10;
<div n="lb"/>97, 6; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 8, 3;
<div n="lb"/>v. 7, 6, 4; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xl. 13;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 48; xxvi. 2;
<div n="lb"/>Av. xix. 62, 1, and possibly ii. 6, 4, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3,
<div n="lb"/>236, 237. Possibly {%rājñaḥ%} in Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 5, may be
<div n="lb"/>taken in this sense. The king there is
<div n="lb"/>said to be a non-Āryan, but the reading
<div n="lb"/>is corrupt, and Oertel's conjecture is
<div n="lb"/>not probable. {%Cf.%} {@Rājya,@} n. 2.
[Page2-216+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>no decisive passage. Zimmer<sup>2</sup> sees traces in one passage of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda<sup>3</sup> that in times of peace there was no king in some
<div n="lb"/>states, the members of the royal family holding equal rights.
<div n="lb"/>He compares this with the state of affairs in early Germany.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>But the passage merely shows that the nobles could be called
<div n="lb"/>Rājan, and is not decisive for the sense ascribed to it by
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer. Of course this state of affairs is perfectly possible,
<div n="lb"/>and is exemplified later in Buddhist times.<sup>5</sup>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 176, 177.</F>
<F>3) x. 97, 6. He also compares Av.
<div n="lb"/>i. 9; iii. 4; iv. 22, where the king is
<div n="lb"/>referred to as superior to the other
<div n="lb"/>royal personages.</F>
<F>4) The case of the Cherusci and
<div n="lb"/>Arminius' attempt to make himself
<div n="lb"/>king, which his relatives, the royal
<div n="lb"/>family, foiled (see Tacitus, {%Annals,%} ii.
<div n="lb"/>88).</F>
<F>5) {%Cf.%} Rhys Davids, {%Buddhist India,%}
<div n="lb"/>19.</F>

<L>2667<pc>2-216<k1>rAjanya<k2>rAjanya
{@Rājanya@}¦ is the regular term in Vedic literature<sup>1</sup> for a man of
<div n="lb"/>the royal family, probably including also those who were not
<div n="lb"/>actually members of that family, but were nobles, though it
<div n="lb"/>may have been originally restricted to members of the royal
<div n="lb"/>family. This, however, does not appear clearly from any
<div n="lb"/>passage; the term may originally have applied to all the nobles
<div n="lb"/>irrespective of kingly power. In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the Rājanya is different from the Rājaputra, who is literally a
<div n="lb"/>son of the king. The functions and place of the Rājanya are
<div n="lb"/>described under {@Kṣatriya,@} which expression later normally
<div n="lb"/>takes the place of Rājanya as a designation for the ruling class.
<div n="lb"/>His high place is shown by the fact that in the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā<sup>3</sup> he is ranked with the learned Brahmin and the
[Page2-217+ 37]
<div n="lb"/>{@Grāmaṇī@} (who was a {@Vaiśya@}) as having reached the height of
<div n="lb"/>prosperity ({%gata-śrī%}).
<F>1) Only once in the Rv. in the late
<div n="lb"/>Puruṣa-sūkta, x. 90, 12; but often in
<div n="lb"/>the Av.: v. 17, 9; 18, 2; vi. 38, 4;
<div n="lb"/>x. 10, 18; xii. 4, 32 {%et seq.;%} xv. 8, 1;
<div n="lb"/>xix. 32, 8; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>13, 1; 5, 4, 4; 10, 1; v. 1, 10, 3, etc.
<div n="lb"/>Even in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>where, on the whole, the later use of
<div n="lb"/>Kṣatriya prevails, the Rājanya is often
<div n="lb"/>mentioned. See Eggeling's index, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 44, 561.</F>
<F>2) {%Cf.%} xiii. 4, 2, 17, with xiii. 1, 6, 2.</F>
<F>3) ii. 5, 4, 4.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 258
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.;%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%}
<div n="lb"/>191. It is quite likely that the noble
<div n="lb"/>families not related to the royal family
<div n="lb"/>were families of minor princes whose
<div n="lb"/>rule was merged in that of the king
<div n="lb"/>on the formation of a powerful tribe,
<div n="lb"/>as was the case in Germany.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2668<pc>2-217<k1>rAjanyabanDu<k2>rAjanyabanDu
{@Rājanya-bandhu@}¦ denotes a Rājanya, but usually with a
<div n="lb"/>depreciating sense. Thus in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> {@Janaka@}
<div n="lb"/>is called by the Brahmins, whom he defeated in disputation, ‘a
<div n="lb"/>fellow of a Rājanya’; the same description is applied to {@Pravāh-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@aṇa Jaivali@} in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>2</sup> for a similar
<div n="lb"/>reason. On the other hand, in one passage<sup>3</sup> where reference is
<div n="lb"/>made to men eating apart from women, princes are said to do
<div n="lb"/>so most of all: the term Rājanyabandhu cannot here be
<div n="lb"/>deemed to be contemptuous, unless, indeed, it is the expression
<div n="lb"/>of Brahmin contempt for princes, such as clearly appears in
<div n="lb"/>the treatment of {@Nagnajit@} in another passage.<sup>4</sup> Again, in a
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>5</sup> in which the four castes are mentioned, the {@Vaiśya@}
<div n="lb"/>precedes the Rājanyabandhu, a curious inversion of the order
<div n="lb"/>of the second and third castes.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) xi. 6, 2, 5.</F>
<F>2) vi. 1, 5.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, x. 5, 2. 10,
<div n="lb"/>where {%cf.%} Eggeling's note, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 43, 370, n. 1. A
<div n="lb"/>similar case is apparently i. 2, 4, 2,
<div n="lb"/>where any special contempt cannot be
<div n="lb"/>meant.</F>
<F>4) viii. 1, 4, 10. {%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Texts,%} 12, 515.</F>
<F>5) i. 1, 4, 12.</F>
<F>6) Eggeling, {%op. cit.,%} 12, 28.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2670<pc>2-217<k1>rAjapati<k2>rAjapati

<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa (xi. 4, 3, 9) as an epithet of Soma. It is not used
<div n="lb"/>elsewhere as a title of imperial temporal supremacy: see
<div n="lb"/>{@Rājya.@}

<L>2671<pc>2-218<k1>rAjapitf<k2>rAjapitf
{@Rāja-pitṛ@}¦ is one of the titles given to the king in the rite of
<div n="lb"/>the {@Rājasūya@} (‘royal consecration’) according to the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa (viii. 12, 5; 17, 5). It probably designates the king
<div n="lb"/>as ‘father of a king,’ and indicates the hereditary character of
<div n="lb"/>the monarchy. Possibly the later plan<sup>1</sup> of associating the
<div n="lb"/>king's son in the monarchy prevailed in earlier times also.
<F>1) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American Oriental Society,%} 13, 139. The sense of ‘having
<div n="lb"/>a king as father’ is also possible.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2672<pc>2-218<k1>rAjaputra<k2>rAjaputra
{@Rāja-putra,@}¦ ‘king's son,’ ‘prince,’ seems to be capable of
<div n="lb"/>being interpreted literally in every passage of the older litera-

<div n="lb"/>wider interpretation.<sup>2</sup> Later the Rājaputra degenerates into a
<div n="lb"/>mere ‘landowner.’<sup>3</sup>
<F>1) Rv. x. 40, 3; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,

<div n="lb"/>xiv. 8; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 8, 5, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiii. 4, 2, 5;
<div n="lb"/>5, 2, 5, etc.</F>
<F>2) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxviii. 1, may
<div n="lb"/>be cited as identifying the {@Rājanya@} and

<F>3) Jolly, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}

<L>2676<pc>2-219<k1>rAjayakzma<k2>rAjayakzma

<div n="lb"/>sumption: this identification seems certain, being supported by
<div n="lb"/>the later view of the disease.<sup>4</sup> Bloomfield<sup>5</sup> suggests ‘king's
<div n="lb"/>evil,’ or syphilis, as the sense, but this is not probable.

<div n="lb"/>xi. 3; xxvii. 3; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,

<L>2677<pc>2-219<k1>rAjasUya<k2>rAjasUya
{@Rāja-sūya@}¦ is the name in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and the later
<div n="lb"/>literature<sup>2</sup> of the ceremony of the ‘royal consecration.’ The
<div n="lb"/>rite is described at great length in the Sūtras,<sup>3</sup> but its main
<div n="lb"/>features are clearly outlined in the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>4</sup> while the
<div n="lb"/>verses used in the ceremony are preserved in the Saṃhitās of
<div n="lb"/>the Yajurveda.<sup>5</sup> Besides much mere priestly elaboration, the
<div n="lb"/>ritual contains traces of popular ceremonial. For example, the
<div n="lb"/>king is clothed in the ceremonial garments of his rank, and
<div n="lb"/>provided with bow and arrow as emblems of sovereignty. He
<div n="lb"/>is formally anointed; he performs a mimic cow raid against a
<div n="lb"/>relative of his;<sup>6</sup> or engages in a sham fight with a {@Rājanya.@}<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>A game of dice is played in which he is made to be the victim;<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>he symbolically ascends the quarters of the sky as an indication
<div n="lb"/>of his universal rule; and steps on a tiger skin, thus gaining
<div n="lb"/>the strength and the pre-eminence of the tiger.
[Page2-220+ 47]
<div n="P"/>A list of the consecrated kings is given in the Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa,<sup>9</sup> where the royal inauguration is called the ‘great
<div n="lb"/>unction’ ({%mahābhiṣeka%}) connected with Indra. It corresponds
<div n="lb"/>generally with a list of Aśvamedhins, ‘performers of the horse
<div n="lb"/>sacrifice,’ given in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>10</sup> and the Śāṅkhā-
<div n="lb"/>yana Śrauta Sūtra.<sup>11</sup>
<F>1) iv. 8, 1; xi. 7, 7.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 6, 2, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, vii. 15, 8; Sata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, v. 1, 1, 12, etc.</F>
<F>3) See Weber, {%Über die Königsweihe, den%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Rājasūya;%} Hillebrandt, {%Rituallitteratur,%}
<div n="lb"/>144-147; Oldenberg, {%Religion des Veda,%}
<div n="lb"/>472, 491. The relation of the {@Śunaḥ-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@śepa@} episode formed part of the ritual.
<div n="lb"/>That this points to human sacrifice
<div n="lb"/>having once formed part of the ritual
<div n="lb"/>of the Rājasūya as supposed by Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt, {%loc. cit.;%} Weber, 47; and Olden-
<div n="lb"/>berg, 366, n. 1, seems very doubtful.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Keith, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1907, 844, 845.</F>
<F>4) Especially Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>v. 2, 3, 1 {%et seq.%} See also Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 1 {%et seq.;%} Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, i. 8, 1, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) See Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 8;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xv; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 6; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x.</F>
<F>6) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 4, 3, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>7) {%Cf.%} Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 8, 15
<div n="lb"/>with commentary; Eggeling, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 41, 100, n. 1.</F>
<F>8) See 2. {@Akṣa@} (p. 3)</F>
<F>9) viii. 21-23. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Episches im%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vedischen Ritual,%} 8.</F>
<F>10) xiii. 5, 4.</F>
<F>11) xvi. 9.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>41, xxiv, xxv.</F>

<L>2682<pc>2-220<k1>rAjya<k2>rAjya
{@Rājya@}¦ in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> regularly denotes
<div n="lb"/>‘sovereign power,’ from which, as the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>notes, the Brahmin is excluded.
<div n="P"/>In addition to Rājya, the texts give other expressions of
<div n="lb"/>sovereign power. Thus the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> contends
[Page2-221+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>that the Rājasūya sacrifice is that of a king, the {@Vājapeya@} that
<div n="lb"/>of a Samrāj or emperor, the status of the latter (Sāmrājya)
<div n="lb"/>being superior to that of the former (Rājya). The sitting on a
<div n="lb"/>throne ({@Āsandī@}) is given in the same text<sup>5</sup> as one of the
<div n="lb"/>characteristics of the Samrāj. Elsewhere<sup>6</sup> Svārājya, ‘uncon-
<div n="lb"/>trolled dominion,’ is opposed to Rājya. In the ritual of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Rājasūya@} the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup> gives a whole series of
<div n="lb"/>terms: Rājya, Sāmrājya, Bhaujya, Svārājya, Vairājya, Pāra-
<div n="lb"/>meṣṭhya, and Māhārājya, while Ādhipatya, ‘supreme power,’ is
<div n="lb"/>found elsewhere.<sup>8</sup> But there is no reason to believe that these
<div n="lb"/>terms refer to essentially different forms of authority. A king
<div n="lb"/>might be called a {@Mahārāja@} or a {@Samrāj,@} without really being
<div n="lb"/>an overlord of kings; he would be so termed if he were an
<div n="lb"/>important sovereign, or by his own entourage out of compli-
<div n="lb"/>ment, as was {@Janaka@} of {@Videha.@}<sup>9</sup> That a really great monarchy
<div n="lb"/>of the Aśoka or Gupta type ever existed in the Vedic period
<div n="lb"/>seems highly improbable.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) iii. 4, 2; iv. 8, 1; xi. 6, 15; xii. 3,
<div n="lb"/>31; xviii. 4, 31.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3, 4;
<div n="lb"/>6, 6, 5; vii. 5, 8, 3, etc.; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vii. 23, etc.; Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 5, as emended
<div n="lb"/>by Roth, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 16, ccxliii.</F>
<F>3) v. 1, 1, 12.</F>
<F>4) v. 1, 1, 3.</F>
<F>5) xii. 8, 3, 4.</F>
<F>6) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xiv. 5; Maitrā-
<div n="lb"/>yaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 11, 5. {%Cf.%} Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 2, 2.</F>
<F>7) viii. 12, 4. 5. {%Cf.%} Śāṅkhāyana
<div n="lb"/>Śrauta Sūtra, xvii. 16, 3.</F>
<F>8) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xv. 3, 35;
<div n="lb"/>Chāndogya Upaniṣad, v. 2, 6.</F>
<F>9) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 3, 1, 2. 6;
<div n="lb"/>2, 2, 3, etc.</F>
<F>10) {%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%Transactions of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,%}
<div n="lb"/>15, 30.</F>

<L>2743<pc>2-230<k1>lavaRa<k2>lavaRa
{@Lavaṇa,@}¦ ‘salt,’ is never mentioned in the Rigveda, only once
<div n="lb"/>in the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> and not after that until the latest part of
<div n="lb"/>the Brāhmaṇas,<sup>2</sup> where it is regarded as of extremely high
<div n="lb"/>value.<sup>3</sup> This silence in the early period is somewhat surprising
<div n="lb"/>if the regions then occupied by the Indians were the Panjab
<div n="lb"/>and the Indus valley, where salt abounds; it would at first
<div n="lb"/>sight seem less curious if the home of the early Vedic Indian is
<div n="lb"/>taken to be {@Kurukṣetra.@}<sup>4</sup> It is, however, quite conceivable
<div n="lb"/>that a necessary commodity might happen to be passed over
<div n="lb"/>without literary mention in a region where it is very common,
<div n="lb"/>but to be referred to in a locality where it is not found, and
<div n="lb"/>consequently becomes highly prized.
<F>1) vii. 76, 1.</F>
<F>2) Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iv. 17, 7 =
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Upaniṣad, iii. 17, 3. {%Cf.%} also
<div n="lb"/>Chāndogya Upaniṣad, vi. 13, 1; Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, ii. 4, 12; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, v. 2, 1, 16; and see
<div n="lb"/>Strabo, xv. 1, 30.</F>
<F>3) It seems to be placed above gold in
<div n="lb"/>value in Chāndogya Upaniṣad, iv. 17, 7.</F>
<F>4) {%Cf.%} Map 19 in the Atlas of the
<div n="lb"/>{%Imperial Gazetteer of India,%} vol. 26, and see
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins, {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 19, 21 {%et seq.; India, Old and%}
<div n="lb"/>{%New,%} 30 {%et seq.%}

<L>2756<pc>2-233<k1>loka<k2>loka
{@Loka@}¦ denotes ‘world’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> Mention
<div n="lb"/>is often made of the three worlds,<sup>3</sup> and {%ayaṃ lokaḥ,%} ‘this
<div n="lb"/>world,’<sup>4</sup> is constantly opposed to {%asau lokaḥ,%}<sup>5</sup> ‘yonder world’
<div n="lb"/>-{%i.e.,%} ‘heaven.’ Loka itself sometimes means ‘heaven,’<sup>6</sup>

<div n="lb"/>mentioned.<sup>7</sup>

<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.%} 2, quotes no example of this mean-
<div n="lb"/>ing for the Rigveda, where he sees the

<div n="lb"/>‘room,’ ‘free or open space.’ But Rv.
<div n="lb"/>x. 14, 9, is a fairly certain example of
<div n="lb"/>the wider sense.</F>
<F>2) Av. viii. 9, 1. 15; iv. 38, 5; xi. 5, 7;
<div n="lb"/>8, 10, etc.; in ix. 5, 14, the worlds of
<div n="lb"/>heaven ({%divya%}) and of earth ({%pārthiva%})

<div n="lb"/>maṇa, xiii. 1, 7, 3, etc.</F>

<F>5) Av. xii. 5, 38. 57; Taittirīya Saṃ-

<L>2782<pc>2-238<k1>vatsa<k2>vatsa<h>1

<div n="lb"/>the calves at certain times.<sup>4</sup>

<div n="lb"/>them); Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 11, 4

<div n="lb"/>from {@Tirindara Pāraśavya.@}

<F>2) xiv. 6, 6.</F>

<div n="lb"/>Āpastamba Śrauta Sūtra, xxiv. 5, 11.

<L>2789<pc>2-239<k1>vaDU<k2>vaDU<h>1
1. {@Vadhū@}¦ is a frequent word for ‘woman’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later.<sup>2</sup> It denotes, according to Delbrück,<sup>3</sup> the woman as
<div n="lb"/>either married or as seeking a husband, or as a bride in the
<div n="lb"/>wedding ceremony. The word appears to be derived from a
<div n="lb"/>form of the root {%vah,%} ‘to carry,’ as is {%vahatu,%} ‘the bridal pro-
<div n="lb"/>cession,’ thus meaning ‘she who is to be or has been conducted
<div n="lb"/>home.’ Zimmer,<sup>4</sup> however, objects to this explanation,
<div n="lb"/>regarding {%vadhū%} as a derivative from a different root meaning
<div n="lb"/>‘to marry.’
<F>1) v. 37, 3; 47, 6; vii. 69, 3; viii. 26,
<div n="lb"/>13; x. 27, 12; 85, 30; 107, 9.</F>
<F>2) Av. i. 14, 2; iv. 20, 3; x. 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>xiv. 2, 9, 41, etc.</F>
<F>3) {%Die indogermanischen Verwandtschafts-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%namen,%} 414, 439.</F>
<F>4) {%Altindsiches Leben,%} 108.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2790<pc>2-239<k1>vaDU<k2>vaDU<h>2
2. {@Vadhū@}¦ is in one passage of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> taken by Roth<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to denote a ‘female animal,’ while Zimmer<sup>3</sup> urges that it
<div n="lb"/>means a ‘female slave.’ As far as the use of Vadhū goes,
<div n="lb"/>either meaning is abnormal, for if Vadhū never elsewhere
[Page2-240+ 44]
<div n="lb"/>means a female animal (from {%vah,%} to ‘draw’ a cart), neither does
<div n="lb"/>it denote a slave: as the passage refers to a gift of fifty Vadhūs
<div n="lb"/>by {@Trasadasyu Paurukutsya@} to the singer, the latter must
<div n="lb"/>have been a polygamist of an advanced type to require fifty
<div n="lb"/>wives. The same doubt arises in the case of {%vadhūmant,%} which
<div n="lb"/>is used in the Rigveda and Atharvaveda as an epithet of the
<div n="lb"/>chariot ({@Ratha@}),<sup>4</sup> of horses ({@Aśva@}),<sup>5</sup> and of buffaloes ({@Uṣṭra@}).<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer sees in all cases a reference to slaves in the chariots or
<div n="lb"/>with the horses: this interpretation has the support of the
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhaddevatā.<sup>7</sup> Roth's version of the references to horses or
<div n="lb"/>buffaloes as ‘suitable for draught’ is not very happy; if {%vadhū%}
<div n="lb"/>is really a female animal {%vadhūmant%} means rather ‘together with
<div n="lb"/>mares,’ or ‘together with female buffaloes,’ which makes reason-
<div n="lb"/>able sense.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) viii. 19, 36. {%Cf.%} also v. 47, 6, as
<div n="lb"/>taken by Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2,
<div n="lb"/>319.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 3.</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 108, 109.</F>
<F>4) i. 126, 3; vii. 18, 22.</F>
<F>5) viii. 68, 17. {%Cf.%} vi. 27, 8.</F>
<F>6) Av. xx. 127, 2.</F>
<F>7) iii. 147 {%et seq.,%} with Macdonell's
<div n="lb"/>notes.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns of the Athar-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 197; Pischel, {%Zeitschrift der%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%}
<div n="lb"/>35, 712 {%et seq.;%} Böhtlingk, Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.%}</F>
<LEND>
