<L>2888<pc>2-286<k1>vAmadeva<k2>vAmadeva
{@Vāma-deva@}¦ is credited<sup>1</sup> by tradition with the authorship of
<div n="lb"/>the fourth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda, and he is once mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in that Maṇḍala.<sup>2</sup> He is, moreover, credited with the
<div n="lb"/>authorship of the fourth hymn of the Maṇḍala by the Yajur-
<div n="lb"/>veda Saṃhitās.<sup>3</sup> He there appears as a son of {@Gotama,@} while
<div n="lb"/>in one hymn of the fourth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> Gotama
<div n="lb"/>is mentioned as the father of the singer, and in another<sup>5</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Gotamas occur as praising Indra. In the Bṛhaddevatā<sup>6</sup> two
<div n="lb"/>absurd legends are narrated of Vāmadeva. One describes
<div n="lb"/>Indra as revealing himself in the form of an eagle to the seer
<div n="lb"/>as he cooked the entrails of a dog; the other tells of his
<div n="lb"/>successful conflict with Indra, whom he sold among the
<div n="lb"/>seers. Sieg<sup>7</sup> has endeavoured to trace these tales in the
[Page2-287+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>8</sup> but without any success. Moreover, though Vāmadeva
<div n="lb"/>is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<sup>9</sup> and often in the Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇas,<sup>10</sup> he never figures there as a hero of these legends.
<F>1) Aitareya Āraṇyaka, ii. 2, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) iv. 16, 18.</F>
<F>3) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, x. 5; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 11; iii. 2, 6.</F>
<F>4) iv. 4, 11.</F>
<F>5) iv. 32, 9. 12.</F>
<F>6) iv. 126 131 {%et seq.,%} with Macdonell'
<div n="lb"/>notes.</F>
<F>7) {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 76 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>8) Rv iv. 27 and iv. 24 respectively.
<div n="lb"/>On the former hymn, see Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Ṛigveda-Noten,%} 1, 291 {%et seq.;%} on the
<div n="lb"/>latter, {%ibid.,%} 419 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>9) See Av. xviii. 3, 15. 16.</F>
<F>10) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iv. 30, 2;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 18, 1. 2; Aitareya Āraṇyaka, ii. 5, 1
<div n="lb"/>(= Aitareya Upaniṣad, ii. 5, where
<div n="lb"/>Vāmadeva is credited with knowledge
<div n="lb"/>before birth); Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upani-
<div n="lb"/>ṣad, i. 4, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = i. 4,
<div n="lb"/>10 Kāṇva); Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 9, 27.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 123, 124; Weber, Proceedings
<div n="lb"/>of the Berlin Academy, 1894, 789 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 42, 215.</F>

<L>2918<pc>2-291<k1>vAsas<k2>vAsas
{@Vāsas@}¦ is the most usual word in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> for
<div n="lb"/>‘clothing.’ Clothes were often woven of sheep's wool ({%cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>{@Ūrṇā@}); the god Pūṣan is called a ‘weaver of garments’ ({%vāse-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vāya%})<sup>3</sup> because of his connexion with the fashioning of forms.
<div n="lb"/>The garments worn were often embroidered ({%cf.%} {@Peśas@}), and
<div n="lb"/>the Maruts are described as wearing mantles adorned with
<div n="lb"/>gold.<sup>4</sup> When the ‘giver of garments’ ({%vāso-dā%})<sup>5</sup> is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>along with the giver of horses and gold, ornamental garments are
<div n="lb"/>probably meant. There are several references in the Rigveda<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to the Indians' love of ornament, which is attested by Megas-
[Page2-292+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>thenes for his day.<sup>7</sup> The Rigveda also presents epithets like
<div n="lb"/>{%su-vasana%}<sup>8</sup> and {%su-rabhi,%}<sup>9</sup> implying that garments were becoming
<div n="lb"/>or well-fitting.
<div n="P"/>The Vedic Indian seems often to have worn three garments
<div n="lb"/>-an undergarment ({%cf.%} {@Nīvi@}),<sup>10</sup> a garment,<sup>11</sup> and an over-
<div n="lb"/>garment ({%cf.%} {@Adhīvāsa@}),<sup>12</sup> which was presumably a mantle, and
<div n="lb"/>for which the names {@Atka@} and {@Drāpi@} also seem to be used.
<div n="lb"/>This accords with the description of the sacrificial garments
<div n="lb"/>given in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>13</sup> which comprise a {@Tārpya,@}
<div n="lb"/>perhaps a ‘silken undergarment’; secondly, a garment of
<div n="lb"/>undyed wool, and then a mantle, while the ends of the turban,
<div n="lb"/>after being tied behind the neck, are brought forward and
<div n="lb"/>tucked away in front. The last point would hardly accord
<div n="lb"/>with the usual practice in ordinary life, but seems to be a
<div n="lb"/>special sacrificial ritual act. A similar sort of garments in the
<div n="lb"/>case of women appears to be alluded to in the Atharvaveda<sup>14</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>15</sup> There is nothing to show
<div n="lb"/>exactly what differences there were between male and female
<div n="lb"/>costume, nor what was exactly the nature of the clothes in
<div n="lb"/>either case.
<div n="P"/>It is important to note that the Vedic Indian evidently
<div n="lb"/>assumed that all civilized persons other than inspired Munis
<div n="lb"/>would wear clothing of some sort.<sup>16</sup>
<div n="P"/>See also {@Vasana, Vastra, Otu, Tantu.@} For the use of skin
<div n="lb"/>garments, see {@Mala.@}
<F>1) i. 34, 1; 115, 4; 162, 16; viii. 3,
<div n="lb"/>24; x. 26, 6; 102, 2, etc.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 9, 7;
<div n="lb"/>11, 2; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 32;
<div n="lb"/>xi. 40; Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, etc.
<div n="lb"/>A garment of Kuśa grass is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 2, 1, 8, as
<div n="lb"/>worn by the wife of the sacrificer at
<div n="lb"/>the consecration, but it is doubtful
<div n="lb"/>whether such dresses were normally
<div n="lb"/>worn. {%Cf.%} also {%kausumbha-paridhāna,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘a silken garment,’ Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇ-
<div n="lb"/>yaka, xi. 4.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 26, 6.</F>
<F>4) Rv. v. 55, 6 ({%hiraṇyayān athān%}).</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 107, 2. {%Cf. vastra-dā,%} v. 24, 8.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 85, 1; 92, 4; ix. 96, 1,
<div n="lb"/>x. 1, 6.</F>
<F>7) See Strabo, p. 709; Arrian, {%Indica,%}
<div n="lb"/>v. 9.</F>
<F>8) Rv. ix. 97, 50.</F>
<F>9) With {%atka,%} vi. 29, 3; x. 123, 7.
<div n="lb"/>this word may possibly indicate that
<div n="lb"/>early Vedic dress was fitted like the
<div n="lb"/>Minoan style of dress, and unlike the
<div n="lb"/>later Achæan style as seen in Homer
<div n="lb"/>({%cf.%} Lang, {%The World of Homer,%} 60 {%et%}
<div n="lb"/>{%seq.%}).</F>
<F>10) Av. viii. 2, 16; xiv. 2, 50. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 3; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>sanevi Saṃhitā, iv. 10, etc.</F>
<F>11) Vāsas in the narrower sense, Av.
<div n="lb"/>viii. 2, 16.</F>
<F>12) Rv. i. 140, 9; 162, 16; x. 5, 4.</F>
<F>13) v. 3, 5, 20 {%et seq.%} See Eggeling,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 41, 85 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>14) viii. 2, 16; xiv. 2, 50.</F>
<F>15) v. 2, 1, 8.</F>
<F>16) {%Cf.%} Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5,
<div n="lb"/>1, 1; and iii. 1, 2, 13-17, where the
<div n="lb"/>fact that man alone wears clothes is
<div n="lb"/>accounted for by a silly legend.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 261,
<div n="lb"/>262.</F>
<LEND>

<div n="lb"/>veda, 361, points out that Vicṛtau are
<lang n="greek"></lang> and <lang n="greek"></lang> Scorpionis, while Mūla includes
<div n="lb"/>the tail as a whole.</F>

<L>2935<pc>2-295<k1>vitastA<k2>vitastA
{@Vitastā,@}¦ the most westerly of the five rivers of the Panjab, is
<div n="lb"/>only mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> in the Nadīstuti (‘Praise of
<div n="lb"/>Rivers’).<sup>2</sup> It is the Hydaspes of Alexander's historians, more
<div n="lb"/>correctly reproduced by Ptolemy as Bidaspes. The name
<div n="lb"/>appears in the Mohammedan historians corrupted to Bihat or
<div n="lb"/>Wihat, and survives in the modern Kashmīrī form of Veth.
<F>1) x. 75, 5; {@Nirukta,@} ix. 26; {%cf.%} Kāśikā
<div n="lb"/>Vṛtti on Pāṇini, i. 4, 31. {%Cf.%} Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 12; {%Imperial Gazetteer%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of India,%} 14, 160.</F>
<F>2) The rareness of the name in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda points to the Panjab not
<div n="lb"/>having been the seat of the activity of
<div n="lb"/>the greater part of the Vedic Indians.</F>

<L>2936<pc>2-295<k1>vitta<k2>vitta

<L>2938<pc>2-296<k1>vidaTa<k2>vidaTa
{@Vidatha@}¦ is a word of obscure sense, confined mainly to the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda. According to Roth,<sup>1</sup> the sense is primarily ‘order,’
<div n="lb"/>then the concrete body which gives orders, then ‘assembly’ for
<div n="lb"/>secular<sup>2</sup> or religious ends,<sup>3</sup> or for war.<sup>4</sup> Oldenberg<sup>5</sup> once
<div n="lb"/>thought that the main idea is ‘ordinance’ (from {%vi-dhā,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘dispose,’ ‘ordain’), and thence ‘sacrifice.’ Ludwig<sup>6</sup> thinks
<div n="lb"/>that the root idea is an ‘assembly,’ especially of the {@Maghavans@}
<div n="lb"/>and the Brahmins. Geldner<sup>7</sup> considers that the word pri-
<div n="lb"/>marily means ‘knowledge,’ ‘wisdom,’ ‘priestly lore,’ then
<div n="lb"/>‘sacrifice’ and ‘spiritual authority.’ Bloomfield,<sup>8</sup> on the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, insists that Vidatha refers to the ‘house’<sup>9</sup> in the first
<div n="lb"/>place (from {%vid,%} ‘acquire’), and then to the ‘sacrifice,’ as
<div n="lb"/>connected with the house; this interpretation, at any rate,
<div n="lb"/>appears to suit all the passages. The term {%vidathya,%} once<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>applied to the king ({%samrāṭ%}), might seem to be against this
<div n="lb"/>view, but it may refer to his being ‘rich in homesteads’; and
<div n="lb"/>the connexion of the woman with the Vidatha, as opposed to
[Page2-297+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>the {@Sabhā,@} tells in favour<sup>11</sup> of Bloomfield's explanation. That
<div n="lb"/>the word ever denotes an asylum, like the house of the
<div n="lb"/>Brahmin,<sup>12</sup> as Ludwig<sup>13</sup> suggests, is doubtful.<sup>14</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 31, 6; 117, 25; iii. 1, 18;
<div n="lb"/>27, 7; iv. 38, 4; vi. 8, 1; x. 85, 26;
<div n="lb"/>92, 2; Av. iv. 25, 1; v. 20, 12; xviii. 3,
<div n="lb"/>70, etc.</F>
<F>2) ii. 1, 4; 27, 12, 17; iii. 38, 5, 6;
<div n="lb"/>v. 63, 2; vii. 66, 10; viii. 39, 1; x. 12, 7;
<div n="lb"/>Av. xvii. 1, 15. So Whitney renders
<div n="lb"/>the word in Av. i. 13, 4, as ‘council,’
<div n="lb"/>Translation of the Atharvaveda, 15.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 60, 1; ii. 4, 8; 39, 1; iii. 1, 1;
<div n="lb"/>56, 8, etc.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 166, 2; 167, 6; v. 59, 2,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>5) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 46, 26
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%} But in {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,%} 54, 609-611,
<div n="lb"/>he falls back on the derivation from
<div n="lb"/>{%vidh,%} ‘worship.’ {%Cf.%} Macdonell, {%Vedic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Grammar,%} p. 23, n. 10.</F>
<F>6) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 259
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>
<F>7) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 147; {%Zeitschrift%}
<div n="lb"/>{%der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%schaft,%} 52, 757; {%Rigveda, Glossar,%} 161.</F>
<F>8) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 19, 12 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>9) See Rigveda, x. 85, 26. 27 (of the
<div n="lb"/>wife in the marriage ritual); i. 117,
<div n="lb"/>25; ii. 1, 6; Av. xviii. 3, 70.</F>
<F>10) iv. 27, 2. In i. 91, 20; 167, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Av. xx. 128, 1, {%vidathya,%} ‘having an
<div n="lb"/>establishment,’ seems adequate.</F>
<F>11) {%Cf.%} Av. vii. 38, 4; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 4.</F>
<F>12) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 3, 1, 13,
<div n="lb"/>with Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xv. 3,
<div n="lb"/>35.</F>
<F>13) {%Op. cit.,%} 3, 261.</F>
<F>14) Rv. i. 31, 6; v. 62, 6; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 30, 27, 28, certainly does
<div n="lb"/>not show this clearly.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 177,
<div n="lb"/>who suggests that Vidatha sometimes
<div n="lb"/>means ({%e.g.,%} in {%vidatheṣu praśastaḥ,%} Rv.
<div n="lb"/>ii. 27, 12) a smaller assembly than the
<div n="lb"/>Samiti. But we have no ground to be
<div n="lb"/>certain that such smaller assemblies
<div n="lb"/>ever existed at an early date either

<div n="lb"/>peoples.</F>

<L>2945<pc>2-298<k1>videha<k2>videha
{@Videha@}¦ is the name of a people who are not mentioned
<div n="lb"/>before the Brāhmaṇa period. In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the legend of {@Videgha Māthava@} preserves clearly a tradition
<div n="lb"/>that in Videha culture came from the Brahmins of the West,
<div n="lb"/>and that {@Kosala@} was brahminized before Videha. The Videhas,
<div n="lb"/>however, derived some fame later from the culture of their king
<div n="lb"/>{@Janaka,@} who figures in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad<sup>2</sup> as one of
<div n="lb"/>the leading patrons of the Brahman doctrine. In the Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad<sup>3</sup> the Videhas are joined with the {@Kāśis;@} in the list of
<div n="lb"/>peoples in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> the Videhas are passed
<div n="lb"/>over, probably because, with Kosala and Kāśi, they are included
<div n="lb"/>in the term {@Prācyas,@} ‘easterners.’ Again, in the Śāṅkhāyana
<div n="lb"/>Śrauta Sūtra<sup>5</sup> it is recorded that the Kāśi, Kosala, and Videha
<div n="lb"/>kingdoms had each the one Purohita, {@Jala Jātūkarṇya;@} and
<div n="lb"/>in another passage of the same text<sup>6</sup> the connexion between
<div n="lb"/>the Videha king, {@Para Āṭṇāra,@} and the Kosala king, {@Hiraṇya-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@nābha,@} is explained, while the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup> speaks of
<div n="lb"/>Para Āṭṇāra as the Kosala king, descendant of Hiraṇyanābha.
<div n="P"/>Another king of Videha was {@Namī Sāpya,@} mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.<sup>8</sup> In the Saṃhitās of the Yajurveda<sup>9</sup>
<div n="lb"/>‘cows of Videha’ seem to be alluded to, though the com-
<div n="lb"/>mentator on the Taittirīya Saṃhitā merely takes the adjective
<div n="lb"/>{%vaidehī%} as ‘having a splendid body’ ({%viśiṣṭa-deha-sambandhinī%}),
<div n="lb"/>and the point of a place name in the expression is not very
<div n="lb"/>obvious. The Videhas also occur in the Baudhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra<sup>10</sup> in Brāhmaṇa-like passages.
<div n="P"/>The boundary of Kosala and Videha was the {@Sadānīrā,@}
[Page2-299+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>probably the modern Gandak<sup>11</sup> (the Kondochates of the Greek
<div n="lb"/>geographers), which, rising in Nepal, flows into the Ganges
<div n="lb"/>opposite Patna. Videha itself corresponds roughly to the
<div n="lb"/>modern Tirhut.
<F>1) i. 4, 1, 10 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) iii. 8, 2. {%Cf.%} iv. 2, 6; 9, 30; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 3, 1, 2; 6, 2, 1;
<div n="lb"/>3, 1; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 10, 9, 9.</F>
<F>3) iv. 1.</F>
<F>4) viii. 14.</F>
<F>5) xvi. 29. 5.</F>
<F>6) xvi. 9, 11. 13.</F>
<F>7) xiii. 5, 4, 4.</F>
<F>8) xxv. 10, 17.</F>
<F>9) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 4, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xiv. 5.</F>
<F>10) ii. 5; xxi. 13.</F>
<F>11) {%Cf. Imperial Gaxetteer of India,%}
<div n="lb"/>12, 125.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 1, 170;
<div n="lb"/>{%Indian Literature,%} 10, 33, 53, 127, 129,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>12, xli; Oldenberg, {%Buddha,%} 398, 399;
<div n="lb"/>Rhys Davids, {%Buddhist India,%} 26, 37;
<div n="lb"/>Pargiter, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 1910, 19 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>2948<pc>2-299<k1>viDavA<k2>viDavA

<L>2955<pc>2-301<k1>vipAS<k2>vipAS
{@Vi-pāś@}¦ (‘fetterless’) is the name of a river mentioned twice in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> It is the modern Beās in the Panjab, the Hyphasis,
<div n="lb"/>Hypanis or Bipasis of the Greeks. Its small importance for the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic Indians is indicated by the fact that it is never mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in the earlier Vedic literature except in two hymns of the Rigveda.
<div n="lb"/>The Nirukta<sup>2</sup> preserves the notice that its earlier name was
<div n="lb"/>{@Uruñjirā,@} while the Gopatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> places in the middle
<div n="lb"/>of it the {%Vasiṣṭha-śilāḥ.%} Pāṇinī<sup>4</sup> mentions the name, which
<div n="lb"/>otherwise in post-Vedic literature appears as Vipāśā. This
<div n="lb"/>river has changed its course considerably since ancient times.<sup>5</sup>
<F>1) iii. 33, 1. 3; iv. 30, 11. Yāska,
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta, xi. 48, sees in the latter
<div n="lb"/>passage an adjective {%vi-pāśin,%} but this
<div n="lb"/>is very improbable. See Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 294.</F>
<F>2) ix. 26. The Vipāś is also mentioned
<div n="lb"/>in connexion with the {@Śutudrī@} in ii. 24;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 36.</F>
<F>3) i. 2, 7.</F>
<F>4) iv. 2, 74.</F>
<F>5) See {%Imperiat Gazctteer of India,%} 7,
<div n="lb"/>138 (Beās).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 11.</F>

<L>2979<pc>2-305<k1>viS<k2>viS
{@Viś@}¦ is an expression of somewhat doubtful significance. In
<div n="lb"/>many passages of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> the sense of ‘settlement’ or
<div n="lb"/>‘dwelling’ is adequate and probable, since the root {%viś%} means
<div n="lb"/>to ‘enter’ or ‘settle.’ In other passages, where the Viśaḥ
[Page2-306+ 64]
<div n="lb"/>stand in relation to a prince, the term must mean ‘subject’;<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>so, for example, when the people of {@Tṛṇaskanda@}<sup>3</sup> or of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Tṛtsus@} are mentioned.<sup>4</sup> Again, in some passages<sup>5</sup> the general
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘people’ is adequate; as when the Rigveda speaks of
<div n="lb"/>the ‘Āryan people,’<sup>6</sup> or the ‘divine people,’<sup>7</sup> or the ‘Dāsa
<div n="lb"/>people,’ and so on.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>Sometimes,<sup>9</sup> however, the Viś appear in a more special sense
<div n="lb"/>as a subdivision of the {@Jana@} or whole people. This is, how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, not common, for in most passages one or other of the
<div n="lb"/>senses given above is quite possible. Moreover, it is very
<div n="lb"/>difficult to decide whether the Viś as a subdivision of the Jana
<div n="lb"/>is to be considered as being a local subdivision (canton) or a
<div n="lb"/>blood kinship equivalent to a clan in the large sense of the
<div n="lb"/>word, while the relation of the Viś to the {@Grāma@} or to the
<div n="lb"/>{@Gotra@} is quite uncertain. In one passage of the Atharvaveda<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the Viśaḥ are mentioned along with the {%sabandhavaḥ%} or relatives,
<div n="lb"/>but no definite conclusion can be drawn from that fact. Nor
<div n="lb"/>does the analogy of the Roman {%curia%} or the Greek <lang n="greek"></lang> throw
<div n="lb"/>much light, as these institutions are themselves of obscure
<div n="lb"/>character, and the parallelism need not be cogent. It is, at
<div n="lb"/>any rate, possible that the Viś may in some cases have been no
<div n="lb"/>more than a Gotra or clan, or different clans may sometimes
[Page2-307+ 72]
<div n="lb"/>have made up a Viś, while Grāma is more definitely, perhaps, a
<div n="lb"/>local designation. But the Vedic evidence is quite inconclusive.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} {@Viśpati.@}
<div n="P"/>In the later period the sense of Viś is definitely restricted in
<div n="lb"/>some cases<sup>12</sup> to denote the third of the classes of the Vedic
<div n="lb"/>polity, the people or clansmen as opposed to the nobles ({@Kṣatra,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Kṣatriya@}) and the priests ({@Brahman, Brāhmaṇa@}). For the
<div n="lb"/>position of this class, see {@Vaiśva.@}
<F>1) iv. 4, 3; 37, 1; v. 3. 5; vi. 21, 4; 48, 8; vii. 56, 22; 61, 3, 70, 3; 104, 18;
<div n="lb"/>x. 91, 2, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. iv. 50, 8; vi. 8, 4; x. 124, 8;
<div n="lb"/>173, 6; Av. iii. 4, 1; iv. 8, 4; 22, 1. 3;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 8, 6; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 46; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 8, 2. 17; iv. 2, 1, 3;
<div n="lb"/>v. 3, 3, 12; 4, 2, 3; x. 6, 2, 1; xiii. 6,
<div n="lb"/>2, 8; Kauṣītaki Upaniṣad, iv, 12, etc.
<div n="lb"/>Many of the passages cited under
<div n="lb"/>note 11 may also belong here, while in
<div n="lb"/>Av. iii. 4, 1, etc., reference to the cantons
<div n="lb"/>as electing a king has been seen; but
<div n="lb"/>see {@Rājan@} and {%cf.%} Pischel, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 1, 179; Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>2, 303; Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 113.</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 172, 3.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vii. 33, 6; Geldner, {%op. cit.,%} 136.</F>
<F>5) E.g., Rv. vi. 1, 8; 26, 1; viii. 71, 11;
<div n="lb"/>{%manuṣo viśāḥ,%} vi. 14, 2; viii. 23, 13;
<div n="lb"/>{%mānuṣīḥ,%} x. 80, 6, etc.</F>
<F>6) Rv. x. 11, 4.</F>
<F>7) Rv. iii. 34, 2; Av. vi. 98, 2; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 86.</F>
<F>8) Rv. iv. 28, 4; vi. 25, 2; {%adevīḥ,%}
<div n="lb"/>viii. 96, 15; {%asiknīḥ,%} vii. 5, 3, etc.</F>
<F>9) Rv. ii. 26, 3, where it is opposed
<div n="lb"/>to {%jana, janman,%} and {%putrāḥ;%} x. 84, 4,
<div n="lb"/>where in battle {%viśaṃ-viśam%} apparently
<div n="lb"/>refers to divisions of the host {%cf.%} also
<div n="lb"/>iv. 24, 4. {%viśo yudhmāḥ%}); x. 91, 2, where
<div n="lb"/>it is opposed to {%gṛha%} and {%jana;%} Av.
<div n="lb"/>xiv. 2, 27, where {%gṛhebhyaḥ%} is followed
<div n="lb"/>by {%asyai sarvasyai viśe,%} which must mean
<div n="lb"/>a division less than a whole people.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 159, reckons
<div n="lb"/>here Rv. i. 172, 3; vii. 33, 6; ix. 7, 5;
<div n="lb"/>x. 124, 8; 173, 1; but these cases and
<div n="lb"/>many others are rather instances of
<div n="lb"/>‘subjects’ than of a division of the
<div n="lb"/>tribe such as ‘canton.’</F>
<F>10) xv. 8, 2, 3, {%Cf.%} xiv. 2, 27, and
<div n="lb"/>Rv. x. 91, 2, in n. 9.</F>
<F>11) The Viś may have been originally
<div n="lb"/>a clan settled in one place: there is
<div n="lb"/>no passage where ‘Gotra’ would not
<div n="lb"/>probably make sense; Rv. ii. 26, 3,
<div n="lb"/>cannot be pressed unduly to distinguish
<div n="lb"/>{%ianman%} and Viś. Compare the phrase
<div n="lb"/>used of the Maruts {%śardhaṃ śardham,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vrātaṃ vrātam, gaṇaṃ gaṇam,%} in Rv.
<div n="lb"/>v. 53. 11, where no precise sense can
<div n="lb"/>fairly be attributed to the words, though

<div n="lb"/>of the host corresponding to Jana, Viś,
<div n="lb"/>and Grāma. The rendering ‘Gau’ has
<div n="lb"/>therefore little foundation.</F>

<div n="lb"/>numerous passages in the Brāhmaṇas

<div n="lb"/>peasantry and the nobles — {%e.g.,%} Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 11, 2; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii, 1, 9; iii. 3, 10; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhita, xix. 9 and often. See also
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xvii. 10, 9;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 1, 3, 5; viii. 7,
<div n="lb"/>2, 3; xiii. 2, 2, 17. 19; 9, 6; xiv. 1, 3,
<div n="lb"/>27, etc.; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, viii. 14.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Ātindisches Leben,%} 15
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.;%} Schrader. {%Prehistoric Autiquities,%}
<div n="lb"/>800 {%et seq.;%} Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Litera-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ture,%} 158; von Schroeder, {%Indiens Literalur%}
<div n="lb"/>{%und Cultur,%} 32, 33; St. Petersburg Dic-
<div n="lb"/>tionary, {%s.v.%} For the Roman {%curia,%}
<div n="lb"/>which was apparently a collection of
<div n="lb"/>{%gentes,%} perhaps local, {%cf.%} Mommsen,

<L>2982<pc>2-308<k1>viSpati<k2>viSpati
{@Viś-pati@}¦ is a word of somewhat uncertain signification,
<div n="lb"/>reflecting in this respect the nature of {@Viś.@} Zimmer holds that
<div n="lb"/>in its strict sense it denotes the head of a canton, but he admits
<div n="lb"/>that there is no passage requiring this sense, the only one
<div n="lb"/>quoted by him<sup>2</sup> being certainly indecisive. In the great
<div n="lb"/>majority of passages the word simply means the ‘lord of the
<div n="lb"/>dwelling,’ whether used of a man or of the god Agni as the
<div n="lb"/>householder {%par excellence,%} or possibly as the fire of the {@Sabhā@} or
<div n="lb"/>assembly house of the people. This sense suits even the
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> in which the Viśpati, as well as the
<div n="lb"/>father and the mother of a maiden,<sup>5</sup> are to be lulled to sleep in
<div n="lb"/>order to allow her lover to approach her, for the household may
<div n="lb"/>well be deemed to have been a joint family, in which the
<div n="lb"/>Viśpati could easily be different from the father of the
<div n="lb"/>girl — {%e.g.,%} a grandfather or uncle. In other passages<sup>6</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Viśpati is the king as ‘lord of the subject-people’ ({%viśām%}),
<div n="lb"/>though here Zimmer<sup>7</sup> thinks reference is made to the election
<div n="lb"/>of a king.<sup>8</sup> Or again,<sup>7</sup> the Viśpati is the chief of the Viś,
<div n="lb"/>probably in the sense of ‘subjects.’
<div n="P"/>1) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 171.
<div n="P"/>9) {%E.g.,%} Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 1, 3,
<div n="lb"/>where Viś must clearly be the people
<div n="lb"/>or subject class, and the Viśpati their
<div n="lb"/>chief representative; we cannot from
<div n="lb"/>such a passage infer a formal office of
<div n="lb"/>Viśpati even as head of the Viś.
<F>2) Rv. i. 37. 8.</F>
<F>4) vii. 55, 5 = Av. iv. 5, 6.</F>
<F>5) So Aufrecht, {%Indische Studien,%} 4,
<div n="lb"/>337 {%et seq.;%} Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 308. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Lanman, {%Sanskrit Reader,%} 370. Geldner,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 55 {%et seq.,%} accepts
<div n="lb"/>the view of the Bṛhaddevatā, vi. 11
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%} (where see Macdonell's note),
<div n="lb"/>that the hymn refers to Vasiṣṭha's
<div n="lb"/>approaching a house as a thief! The
<div n="lb"/>interpretation does not affect the sense
<div n="lb"/>of Viśpati, which here is clearly not
<div n="lb"/>the title of a cantonal chief. Viś is
<div n="lb"/>sometimes equivalent to {@Sajāta;@} {%cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3, 2. 3.</F>
<F>6) Av. iii. 4, 1; iv. 22, 3. Perhaps Rv.
<div n="lb"/>iii. 13, 5, is so to be taken; {%cf.%} vii. 39, 2.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 18, 22.</F>
<F>7) {%Op. cit.,%} 164, 165.</F>
<F>8) But see {@Rājan.@}</F>
<F>7) {%Op. cit.,%} 164. 165.</F>

<L>2985<pc>2-309<k1>viSvakarmanBOvana<k2>viSvakarmanBOvana
{@Viśva-karman Bhauvana@}¦ (‘descendant of Bhuvana’) is the
<div n="lb"/>name of a quite mythical king. He is said in the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa to have been consecrated by {@Kaśyapa,@} to whom he
<div n="lb"/>offered the earth ({%i.e.,%} presumably a piece of land) as a sacrificial
<div n="lb"/>fee; in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> he performed the Sarvamedha
<div n="lb"/>(‘universal sacrifice’), and made a similar offer; in both cases
<div n="lb"/>the earth refused to be given. The story seems to contain a
<div n="lb"/>reference to the early dislike of gifts of land,<sup>3</sup> but it cannot be
<div n="lb"/>stated with certainty that this is the meaning.
<div n="P"/>^1 viii. 21, 8.
<F>2) xiii. 7, 1, 15.</F>
<F>3) Rhys Davids, {%Buddhist India,%} 47.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>44, 421, n, 1; Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2,
<div n="lb"/>456, 457.</F>
<LEND>

<L>2992<pc>2-310<k1>viSvAmitra<k2>viSvAmitra
{@Viśvā-mitra@}¦ (‘friend of all’) is the name of a Ṛṣi who is
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and to whom the third Maṇḍala is
<div n="lb"/>attributed by tradition. In one hymn<sup>2</sup> which appears to be his
<div n="lb"/>own composition, he praises the rivers {@Vipāś@} (Beas) and
<div n="lb"/>{@Śutudrī@} (Sutlej). There he calls himself the son of {@Kuśika,@}
<div n="lb"/>and seems unquestionably to be the helper of the {@Bharatas,@}
<div n="lb"/>whom he mentions. The tribe, engaged in a raid, apparently
<div n="lb"/>came to the rivers from the east.<sup>4</sup> Anxious to cross them, they
<div n="P"/>^3 Rv. iii. 33, 5.
[Page2-311+ 57]
<div n="lb"/>found them in high flood, but Viśvāmitra by prayer induced
<div n="lb"/>the waters to subside. The same feat appears to be referred
<div n="lb"/>to in another passage of the same book of the Rigveda.<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Curiously enough, Sāyaṇa<sup>6</sup> quite misunderstands the situation:
<div n="lb"/>according to him, Viśvāmitra having obtained wealth by the
<div n="lb"/>exercise of his office, went off with it to the rivers, pur-
<div n="lb"/>sued by others. Yāska's<sup>7</sup> version of the tale merely seems
<div n="lb"/>to mean that the king paid Viśvāmitra to act as his {@Puro-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@hita,@} or domestic priest. For the relations of Viśvāmitra
<div n="lb"/>to Vasiṣṭha connected with their service of {@Sudās, see@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Vasiṣṭha.@}
<div n="P"/>The Viśvāmitras are mentioned in several other passages of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda,<sup>8</sup> and are also designated as a family by the term
<div n="lb"/>{@Kuśikas.@}<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the later literature Viśvāmitra becomes, like Vasiṣṭha, a
<div n="lb"/>mythical sage, usually<sup>10</sup> mentioned in connection with {@Jamad-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@agni;@} he was Hotṛ priest at the sacrifice of {@Śunaḥśepa,@} whom
<div n="lb"/>he adopted, and to whom he gave the name of {@Devarāta.@}<sup>11</sup> He
<div n="lb"/>was a protégé of Indra, with whom he had an interview
<div n="lb"/>according to the Rigveda Āraṇyakas.<sup>12</sup> He is also often
<div n="lb"/>mentioned as a Ṛṣi.<sup>13</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Epic<sup>14</sup> Viśvāmitra is represented as a king, who
<div n="lb"/>becomes a Brahmin. There is no trace of his kingship in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, but the Nirukta<sup>15</sup> calls his father, Kuśika, a king; the
[Page2-312+ 52]
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>16</sup> refers to Śunaḥśepa as succeeding to
<div n="lb"/>the lordship of the {@Jahnus,@} as well as the ‘divine lore’ ({%daiva%}
<div n="lb"/>{%veda%}) of the {@Gāthins;@} and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>17</sup>
<div n="lb"/>mentions Viśvāmitra as a king. But there is no real-trace of
<div n="lb"/>this kingship of Viśvāmitra: it may probably be dismissed as a
<div n="lb"/>mere legend, with no more foundation at most than that Viśvā-
<div n="lb"/>mitra was of a family which once had been royal. But even
<div n="lb"/>this is doubtful.
<F>1) As son of Kuśika in Rv. iii. 33, 5;
<div n="lb"/>as Viśvāmitra in iii. 53, 7, 12.</F>
<F>2) iii. 33. Ludwig, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, 3, 121, thinks the hymn too
<div n="lb"/>poetical to be a real composition of the
<div n="lb"/>reputed author.</F>
<F>4) So Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 3, 152.
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 127, 128,
<div n="lb"/>takes a different view: with Roth, {%Zur%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,%} 90,
<div n="lb"/>he assumes that the Bharatas were
<div n="lb"/>different from the Tṛtsus, and that they
<div n="lb"/>came under Viśvāmitra from the West,
<div n="lb"/>but were defeated (see Rv. vii. 33, 6).
<div n="lb"/>But see Weber, {%Episches im vedischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Ritual,%} 34, n. 1; Pischel, {%Vedische%}

<div n="lb"/>{%the American Oriental Society,%} 16, 41, 42,
<div n="lb"/>still defends Roth's view.</F>
<F>5) iii. 53, 9-11. This hymn is prob-
<div n="lb"/>ably later.</F>

<F>7) Nirukta, ii. 24.</F>

<div n="lb"/>17; Av. xviii. 3, 6; 4, 54; Jaiminīya

<L>2996<pc>2-312<k1>vizARakA<k2>vizARakA
{@Viṣāṇakā@}¦ is the name of a plant in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> Bloom-
<div n="lb"/>field,<sup>2</sup> however, thinks that the word may merely mean ‘horn.’
<div n="lb"/>It is used as a remedy against the disease Vātīkāra.<sup>3</sup> That
[Page2-313+ 50]

<div n="lb"/>‘caused by wounds,’ comparing the adjective {%a-vāta,%} ‘uninjured,’
<div n="lb"/>in the Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> but Bloomfield<sup>6</sup> shows that ‘wind’ in the
<div n="lb"/>body is meant as causing the disease.
<F>1) vi. 44, 3. {%Cf.%} Viṣāṇikā in Wise,
<div n="lb"/>{%Hindu System of Medicine,%} 146, perhaps the
<div n="lb"/>{%Asclepias geminata;%} Bloomfield, {%American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of Philology,%} 12, 426; Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 68. But {%cf.%} Whit-
<div n="lb"/>ney. Translation of the Atharvaveda,
<div n="lb"/>313.</F>
<F>2) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 482.</F>
<F>3) Av. ix. 8, 20; Vātī-kṛta, vi. 44, 3;
<div n="lb"/>109, 3.</F>
<F>4) {%Op. cit.,%} 389. 390.</F>

<L>2997<pc>2-313<k1>vizARin<k2>vizARin

<L>3003<pc>2-314<k1>vizWAvrAjin<k2>vizWAvrAjin

<L>3019<pc>2-318<k1>vfka<k2>vfka<h>1
1. {@Vṛka,@}¦ ‘wolf,’ is mentioned frequently in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and also later.<sup>2</sup> It was an enemy of sheep<sup>3</sup> and of calves,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>being dangerous even to men.<sup>5</sup> Its colour is stated to be
<div n="lb"/>reddish ({%aruṇa%}).<sup>6</sup> The ‘she-wolf,’ Vṛkī, is also mentioned several
<div n="lb"/>times in the Rigveda.<sup>7</sup>

<L>3032<pc>2-321<k1>vfSajAna<k2>vfSajAna<h>2
2. {@Vṛśa Jāna@}¦ (‘descendant of Jana’) is the name of a famous
<div n="lb"/>Purohita, who was unfortunate enough, while with his royal
<div n="lb"/>master, {@Tryaruṇa,@} to see a boy killed by the chariot which the
<div n="lb"/>king drove too fast. He thereupon recalled the boy to life.
<div n="lb"/>The story is told briefly in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> the
<div n="lb"/>Śāṭyāyanaka,<sup>2</sup> the Tāṇḍaka,<sup>3</sup> was also narrated in the Bhāllavi
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>4</sup> and is preserved in the Bṛhaddevatā,<sup>5</sup> Sieg<sup>6</sup> has
<div n="lb"/>endeavoured to trace the story in part in the Rigveda,<sup>7</sup> but
<div n="lb"/>there is a consensus of opinion<sup>8</sup> against the correctness of
<div n="lb"/>such a view.
<F>1) xiii. 3, 12.</F>

<F>4) Referred to in the Bṛhaddevatā,

<div n="lb"/>with {@Sasya,@} stating that they ripen in Vasanta, ‘spring.’
<div n="lb"/>Apparently bamboo reeds are meant.<sup>7</sup>

<div n="lb"/>vii. 4, 19, 2; Kāthaka Saṃhitā, xiii. 12;

<div n="lb"/>2, 17, etc.</F>

<L>3048<pc>2-324<k1>vetasu<k2>vetasu

<L>3087<pc>2-331<k1>vEra<k2>vEra
{@Vaira@}¦<sup>1</sup> and {@Vaira-deya@}<sup>2</sup> seem to have in the later Saṃhitās
<div n="lb"/>and the Brāhmaṇas the definite and technical sense of ‘wergeld,’
<div n="lb"/>the money to be paid for killing a man as a compensation to
<div n="lb"/>his relatives. This view is borne out by the Sūtras of Āpa-
<div n="lb"/>stamba<sup>3</sup> and Baudhāyana.<sup>4</sup> Both prescribe the scale of
<div n="lb"/>1,000 cows for a {@Kṣatriya,@}<sup>5</sup> 100 for a {@Vaiśya,@} 10 for a {@Śūdra,@}
<div n="lb"/>and a bull over and above in each case. Āpastamba leaves the
<div n="lb"/>destination of the payment vague, but Baudhāyana assigns it
<div n="lb"/>to the king. It is reasonable to suppose that the cows were
<div n="lb"/>intended for the relations, and the bull was a present to the
<div n="lb"/>king for his intervention to induce the injured relatives to
<div n="lb"/>abandon the demand for the life of the offender. The Āpa-
<div n="lb"/>stamba Sūtra<sup>6</sup> allows the same scale of wergeld for women, but
<div n="lb"/>the Gautama Sūtra<sup>7</sup> puts them on a level with men of the
<div n="lb"/>Śūdra caste only, except in one special case. The payment is
<div n="lb"/>made for the purpose of {%vaira-yātana%} or {%vaira-niryātana,%} ‘requital
<div n="lb"/>of enmity,’ ‘expiation.’
<div n="P"/>The Rigveda<sup>8</sup> preserves, also, the important notice that a
<div n="lb"/>man's wergeld was a hundred (cows), for it contains the epithet
<div n="lb"/>{%śata-dāya,%} ‘one whose wergeld is a hundred.’ No doubt the
<div n="lb"/>values varied, but in the case of {@Śunaḥśepa@} the amount is a
<div n="lb"/>hundred (cows) in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>9</sup> In the Yajurveda
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitās<sup>10</sup> {%śata-dāya%} again appears.
[Page2-332+ 37]
<div n="P"/>The fixing of the price shows that already public opinion, and
<div n="lb"/>perhaps the royal authority, was in Rigvedic times diminishing
<div n="lb"/>the sphere of private revenge; on the other hand, the existence
<div n="lb"/>of the system shows how weak was the criminal authority of
<div n="lb"/>the king ({%cf.%} {@Dharma@}).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Roth, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 41, 672-
<div n="lb"/>676; Bühler and von Schroeder, {%Fest-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%gruss an Roth,%} 44-52; Bühler, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 2, 78, 79; 14, 201
<div n="lb"/>Schrader, {%Prehistoric Antiquities,%} 402
<div n="lb"/>Jolly, {%Recht und Sitte,%} 131, 132; Delbrück
<div n="lb"/>in Leist, {%Altarisches Jus Gentium,%} 297.
<F>1) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xvi. 1, 12.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 5, 2, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, ix. 2; Kapiṣṭhala
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, viii. 5; Maitrāyaṇī, Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>i. 7, 5, all of which have {%vīram%} for
<div n="lb"/>{%vairam,%} perhaps wrongly.</F>
<F>2) Rv. v. 61, 8 (on the exact sense of
<div n="lb"/>which, {%cf.%} Max Müller, {%Sacred Books of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the East,%} 32, 361; Hillebrandt, {%Vedische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Mythologie,%} 1, 92; Oldenberg, {%Rgveda-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Noten,%} 1, 354); Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā
<div n="lb"/>xxiii. 8; xxviii. 2. 3. 6.</F>
<F>3) i. 9, 24, 1-4.</F>
<F>4) i. 10, 19, 1, 2.</F>
<F>5) The crime of slaying a Brahmin is
<div n="lb"/>too heinous for a wergeld. See Āpa-
<div n="lb"/>stamba, i. 9, 24, 7 {%et seq.;%} Baudhāyana,
<div n="lb"/>i. 10, 18, 18.</F>
<F>6) i. 9, 24, 5.</F>

<L>3095<pc>2-333<k1>vESya<k2>vESya
{@Vaiśya@}¦ denotes a man, not so much of the people, as of the
<div n="lb"/>subject class, distinct from the ruling noble ({@Kṣatriya@}) and the
<div n="lb"/>{@Brāhmaṇa,@} the higher strata of the Āryan community on the
<div n="lb"/>one side, and from the aboriginal {@Śūdra@} on the other. The
<div n="lb"/>name is first found in the Puruṣa-sūkta (‘hymn of man’) in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and then frequently from the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>onwards,<sup>3</sup> sometimes in the form of Viśya.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Vaiśya plays singularly little part in Vedic literature,
<div n="lb"/>which has much to say of Kṣatriya and Brahmin. His
<div n="lb"/>characteristics are admirably summed up in the Aitareya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>5</sup> in the adjectives {%anyasya bali-kṛt,%} ‘tributary to another’;
<div n="lb"/>{%anyasyādya,%} ‘to be lived upon by another’; and {%yathākāma-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%jyeyaḥ,%} ‘to be oppressed at will.’ He was unquestionably taxed
<div n="lb"/>by the king ({@Rājan@}), who no doubt assigned to his retinue the
<div n="lb"/>right of support by the people, so that the Kṣatriyas grew more
<div n="lb"/>and more to depend on the services rendered to them by the
<div n="lb"/>Vaiśyas. But the Vaiśya was not a slave: he could not be
<div n="lb"/>killed by the king or anyone else without the slayer incurring
<div n="lb"/>risk and the payment of a wergeld ({@Vaira@}), which even in the
<div n="lb"/>Brahmin books extends to 100 cows for a Vaiśya. Moreover,
<div n="lb"/>though the Vaiśya could be expelled by the king at pleasure, he
<div n="lb"/>cannot be said to have been without property in his land.
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins<sup>6</sup> thinks it is absurd to suppose that he could really be
<div n="lb"/>a landowner when he was subject to removal at will, but this
<div n="lb"/>is to ignore the fact that normally the king could not remove
<div n="lb"/>the landowner, and that kings were ultimately dependent on
<div n="lb"/>the people, as the tales of exiled kings show.
<div n="P"/>On the other hand, Hopkins<sup>7</sup> is clearly right in holding that
<div n="lb"/>the Vaiśya was really an agriculturist, and that Vedic society
<div n="lb"/>was not merely a landholding aristocracy, superimposed upon
<div n="lb"/>an agricultural aboriginal stock, as Baden Powell<sup>8</sup> urged.
<div n="lb"/>Without ignoring the possibility that the Dravidians were
<div n="lb"/>agriculturists, there is no reason to deny that the Āryans were
[Page2-334+ 44]
<div n="lb"/>so likewise, and the goad of the plougher was the mark of a
<div n="lb"/>Vaiśya in life<sup>9</sup> and in death.<sup>10</sup> It would be absurd to suppose
<div n="lb"/>that the Āryan Vaiśyas did not engage in industry and com-
<div n="lb"/>merce ({%cf.%} {@Paṇi, Vaṇij@}), but pastoral pursuits and agriculture
<div n="lb"/>must have been their normal occupations.
<div n="P"/>In war the Vaiśyas must have formed the bulk of the force
<div n="lb"/>under the Kṣatriya leaders (see {@Kṣatriya@}). But like the
<div n="lb"/>Homeric commoners, the Vaiśyas may well have done little of
<div n="lb"/>the serious fighting, being probably ill-provided with either
<div n="lb"/>body armour or offensive weapons.
<div n="P"/>That the Vaiśyas were engaged in the intellectual life of the
<div n="lb"/>day is unlikely; nor is there any tradition, corresponding to
<div n="lb"/>that regarding the Kṣatriyas, of their having taken part in the
<div n="lb"/>evolution of the doctrine of Brahman, the great philosophic
<div n="lb"/>achievement of the age. The aim of the Vaiśya's ambition
<div n="lb"/>was, according to the Taittirīya Saṃhitā,<sup>11</sup> to become a
<div n="lb"/>{@Grāmaṇī,@} or village headman, a post probably conferred by the
<div n="lb"/>king on wealthy Vaiśyas, of whom no doubt there were many.
<div n="lb"/>It is impossible to say if in Vedic times a Vaiśya could attain to
<div n="lb"/>nobility or become a Brahmin. No instance can safely be
<div n="lb"/>quoted in support of such a view,<sup>12</sup> though such changes of
<div n="lb"/>status may have taken place (see {@Kṣatriya@} and {@Varṇa@}).
<div n="P"/>It is denied by Fick<sup>13</sup> that the Vaiśyas were ever a caste, and
<div n="lb"/>the denial is certainly based on good grounds if it is held that
<div n="lb"/>a caste means a body within which marriage is essential, and
<div n="lb"/>which follows a hereditary occupation ({%cf.%} {@Varṇa@}). But it
<div n="lb"/>would be wrong<sup>14</sup> to suppose that the term Vaiśya was merely
<div n="lb"/>applied by theorists to the people who were not nobles or
<div n="lb"/>priests. It must have been an early appellation of a definite
<div n="lb"/>class which was separate from the other classes, and properly
<div n="lb"/>to be compared with them. Moreover, though there were
<div n="lb"/>differences among Vaiśyas, there were equally differences
<div n="lb"/>among Kṣatriyas and Brāhmanas, and it is impossible to deny
[Page2-335+ 41]
<div n="lb"/>the Vaiśyas' claim to be reckoned a class or caste it the other
<div n="lb"/>two are such, though at the present day things are different.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 213
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.;%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10,
<div n="lb"/>1 {%et seq.;%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 7 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>3, 242, 243; Hopkins, {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%American Oriental Society,%} 13, 76 {%et seq.%}
<div n="lb"/>(for the Epic Vaiśya).
<F>1) x. 90, 12.</F>
<F>2) v. 17. 9.</F>
<F>3) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5. etc.
<div n="lb"/>See Varṇa.</F>
<F>4) Av. vi. 13, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xviii. 48, etc.</F>
<F>5) vii. 29. {%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%}
<div n="lb"/>1^2, 439.</F>
<F>6) {%India, Old and New,%} 222 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>7) {%Op. cit.,%} 210 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>8) {%Indian Village Community,%} 190 {%et%}
<div n="lb"/>{%seq.%}</F>
<F>9) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 1.</F>
<F>10) Kauśika Sūtra, lxxx.</F>
<F>11) ii. 5, 4, 4.</F>
<F>12) Rhys Davids, {%Buddhist India,%} 55
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.,%} argues to the contrary from
<div n="lb"/>Buddhist evidence; but this has no
<div n="lb"/>cogency for the Vedic period, and much,
<div n="lb"/>if not all, of it is hardly in point as
<div n="lb"/>concerns this issue.</F>
<F>13) {%Die sociale Gliederung,%} 163, {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>14) {%Cf. Indian Empire,%} 1, 347.</F>

<L>3102<pc>2-336<k1>vyaSva<k2>vyaSva
{@Vy-aśva@}¦ is the name of a Ṛṣi, a protégé of the Aśvins,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in several hymns of the eighth Maṇḍala,<sup>2</sup> which
<div n="lb"/>may have been the composition of a descendant of his, {@Viśva-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@manas.@} In two other passages<sup>3</sup> he is referred to only as a Ṛṣi
<div n="lb"/>of the past, and Oldenberg<sup>4</sup> points out that none of his own
<div n="lb"/>work appears in the Saṃhitā. The Rigveda also mentions<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the Vyaśvas, with whom Ludwig<sup>6</sup> is inclined to connect {@Vaśa@}

<div n="lb"/>frequently occurs in the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> as well as the lion
<div n="lb"/>This fact is legitimately regarded as an indication that the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda belongs to a period when the Vedic Indian had

<div n="lb"/>trated by the fact that the king at the {@Rājasūya@} (‘royal
<div n="lb"/>consecration’) steps<sup>7</sup> on a tiger's skin to win himself the
<div n="lb"/>strength of the animal. {%Cf.%} also {@Śārdūla, Petva.@}

<L>3107<pc>2-338<k1>vyADi<k2>vyADi
{@Vyādhi,@}¦ ‘disease,’ occurs several times in Vedic literature.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The specific diseases are dealt with under the separate names,
<div n="lb"/>but the Vedic texts also mention innumerable bodily defects.
<div n="lb"/>The list of victims<sup>2</sup> at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’)
<div n="lb"/>includes a ‘dwarf’ ({%vāmana, kubja%}), a ‘bald’ person ({%khalati%}),<sup>3</sup> a
<div n="lb"/>‘blind’ man ({%andha%}),<sup>4</sup> a ‘deaf’ man ({%badhira%}),<sup>5</sup> a ‘dumb’ man
<div n="lb"/>({%mūka%}),<sup>6</sup> a ‘fat’ man ({%pīvan%}), a ‘leper’ ({%sidhmala, kilāsa%}),<sup>7</sup> a
<div n="lb"/>‘yellow-eyed’ man ({%hary-akṣa%}), a ‘tawny-eyed’ man ({%piṅg-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ākṣa%}), a ‘cripple’ ({%pīṭha-sarpin%}), a ‘lame’ man ({%srāma%}), a
<div n="lb"/>‘sleepless’ man ({%jāgaraṇa%}), a ‘sleepy’ man ({%svapana%}), one<sup>8</sup> ‘too
<div n="lb"/>tall’ ({%ati-dīrgha%}), one ‘too short’ ({%ati-hrasva%}), one ‘too stout’
<div n="lb"/>({%ati-sthāla%} or {%aty-aṃsala%}), one ‘too thin’ ({%ati-kṛśa%}), one ‘too
<div n="lb"/>white’ ({%ati-śukla%}), one ‘too dark’ ({%ati-kṛṣṇa%}), one ‘too bald’
<div n="lb"/>({%ati-kulva%}), and one ‘too hairy’ ({%ati-lomaśa%}).
<div n="P"/>In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>9</sup> the man with bad nails and the
<div n="lb"/>man with brown teeth are mentioned along with sinners like

<div n="lb"/>‘white-spotted ({%śukla%}), bald-headed man, with projecting teeth

<div n="lb"/>means ‘spotty’ as an intermixture of races, but it is only a

<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>14</sup> various epithets are applied to women,

<div n="lb"/>the feminine adjectives, ‘antelope-footed’ ({%ṛśya-padī%}) and ‘bull-
<div n="lb"/>toothed’ ({%vṛṣa-datī%}), probably refer to bodily defects.

<L>3112<pc>2-340<k1>vraja<k2>vraja
{@Vraja@}¦ denotes in the first instance, in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> the place
<div n="lb"/>to which the cattle resort (from {%vraj,%} ‘go’), the ‘feeding ground’
<div n="lb"/>to which the milk-giving animals go out<sup>2</sup> in the morning from
<div n="lb"/>the village ({@Grāma@}), while the others stay in it all day and
<div n="lb"/>night.<sup>3</sup> Secondarily it denotes the ‘herd’<sup>4</sup> itself. This is
<div n="lb"/>Geldner's view,<sup>5</sup> which seems clearly better than that of Roth<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>who regards Vraja as primarily the ‘enclosure’ (from {%vṛj%}), and
<div n="lb"/>only thence the ‘herd’; for the Vraja does not normally mean
<div n="lb"/>an ‘enclosure’ at all: the Vedic cattle were not stall-fed as a
<div n="lb"/>general rule. In some passages, however, ‘pen,’<sup>7</sup> in others
<div n="lb"/>‘stall,’<sup>8</sup> is certainly meant. The word is often used in the
<div n="lb"/>myth of the robbing of the kine.<sup>9</sup> It occasionally denotes a
<div n="lb"/>‘cistern.’<sup>10</sup>

<div n="lb"/>i. 40, 17.</F>
<F>2) Rv. ii. 38, 8.</F>

<L>3115<pc>2-341<k1>vrAjapati<k2>vrAjapati
{@Vrāja-pati@}¦ is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> where it
<div n="lb"/>is said that comrades attend Indra, as the {@Kulapas@} the Vrāja-
<div n="lb"/>pati, when he goes about. Zimmer<sup>2</sup> thinks that this refers to

<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘in troops.’

<L>3117<pc>2-341<k1>vrAta<k2>vrAta
{@Vrāta@}¦ is found in several passages of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>later<sup>2</sup> in the sense of ‘troop.’ In one passage of the Rigveda<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the troops of the Maruts are referred to by three different
<div n="lb"/>terms — {%śardha, vrāta,%} and {%gaṇa.%} From this fact Zimmer<sup>4</sup> has
[Page2-342+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>deduced that a Vedic host fought according to clan ({@Viś@}),
<div n="lb"/>village ({@Grāma@}), and family, but this conclusion is hardly
<div n="lb"/>warranted, there being nothing to show that there is any
<div n="lb"/>intention to present a distinct series of divisions. It is not
<div n="lb"/>probable that the word ever has the technical sense of ‘guild,’ as
<div n="lb"/>Roth<sup>5</sup> thinks. {%Cf.%} {@Vrātapati.@}

<div n="lb"/>ix. 14, 2 (perhaps an allusion to the
<div n="lb"/>five tribes); x. 34, 8. 12 (of dice). In
<div n="lb"/>x. 57, 5, the host of the living ({%jīva%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vrāta%}) is referred to.</F>

<L>3119<pc>2-342<k1>vrAtya<k2>vrAtya
{@Vrātya@}¦ is included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha
<div n="lb"/>(‘human sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda,<sup>1</sup> where, however, no
<div n="lb"/>further explanation of the name is given. Fuller information
<div n="lb"/>is furnished by the Atharvaveda,<sup>2</sup> the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the Sūtras.<sup>4</sup> which describe at length a certain rite intended
<div n="lb"/>for the use of Vrātyas. According to the Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, there are four different kinds of ‘outcasts’ — viz., the
<div n="lb"/>{%hīna,%} who are merely described as ‘depressed’; those who have
<div n="lb"/>become outcasts for some sin ({%nindita%}); those who become out-
<div n="lb"/>casts at an early age, apparently by living among outcasts; and
<div n="lb"/>those old men who, being impotent ({%śama-nīcameḍhra%}), have
<div n="lb"/>gone to live with outcasts. The last three categories are by no
<div n="lb"/>means of the same importance as the first. The motive of
<div n="lb"/>the fourth is hard to understand: according to Rājārām Rām-
[Page2-343+ 41]
<div n="lb"/>krishṇa Bhāgavat,<sup>5</sup> they were men who had enfeebled their
<div n="lb"/>constitutions by undue intercourse with women in the lands of
<div n="lb"/>the outcasts, and returned home in a debilitated state. But
<div n="lb"/>this is not stated in the text.
<div n="P"/>It seems probable that the really important Vrātyas were
<div n="lb"/>those referred to as {%hīna,%} and that the other classes were only
<div n="lb"/>subsidiary. According to Rājārām,<sup>6</sup> there were two categories
<div n="lb"/>of the first class: ({%a%}) The depressed ({%hīna%}), who were non-
<div n="lb"/>Āryan; and ({%b%}) degraded Āryans ({%gara-gir%}). This, however, is
<div n="lb"/>a mere guess, and devoid of probability. There seems to have
<div n="lb"/>been but one class of Vrātyas. That they were non-Āryan is
<div n="lb"/>not probable, for it is expressly said<sup>7</sup> that, though unconse-
<div n="lb"/>crated, they spoke the tongue of the consecrated: they were
<div n="lb"/>thus apparently Āryans. This view is confirmed by the state-
<div n="lb"/>ment that ‘they call what is easy of utterance, difficult to
<div n="lb"/>utter’: probable they and already a somewhat Prakritic form of
<div n="lb"/>speech ({%cf.%} {@Vāc@}). The Sūtras mention their Arhants (‘saints’)
<div n="lb"/>and Yaudhas (‘warrioes’), corresponding to the Brahminical
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa and Kṣatriya.
<div n="P"/>Other particulars accord with the view that they were
<div n="lb"/>Āryans outside the sphere of Brahmin culture. Thus they
<div n="lb"/>are said<sup>8</sup> not to practise agriculture or commerce (an
<div n="lb"/>allusion to a nomadic life), not to observe the rules of
<div n="lb"/>{@Brahmacarya@} — {%i.e.,%} the principle regulating the Brahminic
<div n="lb"/>order of life. They were also allowed to become members
<div n="lb"/>of the Brahminical community by performance of the ritual
<div n="lb"/>prescribed, which would hardly be so natural in the case
<div n="lb"/>of non-Āryans.
<div n="P"/>Some details are given of the life and dress of the Vrātyas.
<div n="lb"/>Their principles were opposed to those of the Brahmins: they
<div n="lb"/>beat those unworthy of correction.<sup>9</sup> Their leder (Gṛhapati) or
<div n="lb"/>householder wore a turban ({@Uṣṇīṣa@}), carried a whip ({@Pratoda@}),
<div n="lb"/>a kind of bow ({@Jyāhroḍa@}), was clothed in a black ({%kṛṣṇaśa%})
<div n="lb"/>garment and two skins ({@Ajina@}), black and white ({%kṛṣṇa-valakṣa%}),
<div n="lb"/>and owned a rough wagon ({@Vipatha@}) covered with planks
[Page2-344+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>({%phalakāstīrṇa%}). The others,<sup>10</sup> subordinate to the leader, had
<div n="lb"/>garments with fringes of red ({%valūkāntāni dāmatūṣāṇi%}), two
<div n="lb"/>fringes on each, skins folded double ({%dviṣaṃhitāny ajināni%}), and
<div n="lb"/>sandals ({@Upānah@}). The leader wore also an ornament ({@Niṣka@})
<div n="lb"/>of silver, which Rājārām<sup>11</sup> converts into a silver coinage. The
<div n="lb"/>Vrātyas, on becoming consecrated, were expected to hand over
<div n="lb"/>their goods to the priest. Many other details are given in the
<div n="lb"/>Sūtras ({%e.g.,%} that the shoes or sandals were of variegated black
<div n="lb"/>hue and pointed), but these are not authenticated by the
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.
<div n="P"/>The locality in which the Vrātyas lived cannot be stated with
<div n="lb"/>certainty, but their nomad life<sup>12</sup> suggests the western tribes
<div n="lb"/>beyond the Sarasvatī. But they may equally well have been in
<div n="lb"/>the east: this possibility is so far supported by the fact that the
<div n="lb"/>Sūtras make the Brahmin receiving the gift of the Vrātya's
<div n="lb"/>outfit an inhabitant of {@Magadha.@} The Atharvaveda<sup>13</sup> does not
<div n="lb"/>help, for it treats the Vrātya in so mystical a way that he is
<div n="lb"/>represented as being in all the quarters. Indeed, Roth<sup>14</sup>
<div n="lb"/>believed that it was here not a case of the Vrātya of the Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa at all, but of a glorification of the Vrātya as
<div n="lb"/>the type of the pious vagrant or wandering religious mendicant
<div n="lb"/>({@Parivrājaka@}). This view is clearly wrong, as the occurrence
<div n="lb"/>of the words {%uṣṇīsa, vipatha,%} and {%pratoaa%} shows. It is probable
<div n="lb"/>that the 15th Book of the Atharvaveda, which deals with the
<div n="lb"/>Vrātya, and is of a mystical character, exalts the converted
<div n="lb"/>Vrātya as a type of the perfect {@Brahmicārin,@} and, in so far, of
<div n="lb"/>the divinity.<sup>15</sup>
<F>1) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 8; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 5, 1.</F>
<F>2) xv. 1, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) xvii. 1-4.</F>
<F>4) Kātyāyana Srauta Sūtra, xii. 1;
<div n="lb"/>xxii. 4; Lāṭyāyana Śrauta Sūtra, viii. 6;
<div n="lb"/>Āpastamba Śrauta Sūtra, xxii. 5, 4-14.
<div n="lb"/>See Hillebrandt, {%Ritualliteratur,%} 139, 140.</F>
<F>5) {%Journal of the Bombay Branch of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Royal Asiatic Society,%} 19, 360.</F>
<F>6) {%Ibid.,%} 359.</F>
<F>7) Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xvii. 1</F>
<F>8) {%Ibid.,%} xvii. 1, 2.</F>
<F>9) {%Ibid.,%} xvii. 1, 14.</F>

<div n="lb"/>of the passages is obscure; and was, as
<div n="lb"/>Lāṭyāyana shows, already obscure in
<div n="lb"/>his time and earlier; the translations
<div n="lb"/>given are all vague. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische%}

<div n="lb"/>‘belonging to a roving band’ ({%vrāta%}),
<div n="lb"/>‘vagrant.’</F>
<F>13) See Whitney, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 770 {%et seq.,%} with {@Lanman's@}
<div n="lb"/>additions.</F>
<F>14) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>15) Boomfield, {%Atharvaveda,%} 94.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} i. 33, 52,
<div n="lb"/>445, n.; {%Indian Literature,%} 67, 78, 110-
<div n="lb"/>112, 14, 146; Aufrecht, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 130 {%et seq.;%} Ludwig, Translation of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, 3, xxvi {%et seq.;%} Zimmer,

<L>3120<pc>2-345<k1>vrIhi<k2>vrIhi
{@Vrīhi,@}¦ ‘rice,’ is never mentioned in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> but is
<div n="lb"/>frequently alluded to in the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> and later.<sup>3</sup> Rice
<div n="lb"/>seems to be indigenous in the south-east of India:<sup>4</sup> this fact
<div n="lb"/>accounts well for the absence of any mention of it in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda. Black and white rice is contrasted in the Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā,<sup>5</sup> where also<sup>6</sup> the distinctions of dark, swift-growing
<div n="lb"/>({%āśu%}), and large rice ({%mahā-vrīhi%}) are found. Probably the
<div n="lb"/>swift-growing variety is that later known as {%ṣaṣṭika,%} ‘ripening
<div n="lb"/>in sixty days.’ Vrīhi and {@Yava,@} ‘barley,’ are normally con-
<div n="lb"/>joined in the texts.^7 {%Cf.%} {@Plāśuka.@}

<L>3124<pc>2-346<k1>SakaDUma<k2>SakaDUma
{@Śaka-dhūma@}¦ is found in one hymn of the Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>where it is celebrated as the king of the asterisms. The word
<div n="lb"/>seems to mean the ‘smoke of (burning) cow-dung,’ or else the
<div n="lb"/>‘smoke (rising) from (fresh) cow-dung’: it may well be, as
<div n="lb"/>Weber<sup>2</sup> thinks, that this was deemed to be significant of the
<div n="lb"/>weather. Bloomfield,<sup>3</sup> however, considers that the word is to
<div n="lb"/>be rendered as ‘weather prophet,’ that is, one who foretells the
<div n="lb"/>weather by means of the smoke of a fire. Whitney<sup>4</sup> objects to
<div n="lb"/>this view with reason. It is not at all improbable that, as
<div n="lb"/>Roth<sup>5</sup> believed, an asterism of some sort is meant, probably
<div n="lb"/>the ‘milky way.’

<div n="lb"/>{%vaveda,%} 532, 533.</F>

<div n="lb"/>Śakuntalā.

<L>3137<pc>2-348<k1>Sakft<k2>Sakft
{@Śakṛt,@}¦<sup>1</sup> {@Śakan,@}<sup>2</sup> denotes ‘dung’ in the Rigveda and later. It
<div n="lb"/>is clear that the value of manure was early appreciated (see
<div n="lb"/>{@Karīṣa@}). For the use of the smoke of dung or of a dung fire for
<div n="lb"/>prognosticating the weather, see {@Śakadhūma.@}
<F>1) Used only in nominative and accu-
<div n="lb"/>sative: Rv. i. 161, 10; Av. xii. 4, 9;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 19, 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) In the oblique cases Śakan is the
<div n="lb"/>base, Av. xii. 4, 4; Taittirīya Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>v. 7, 23, 1; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xxxvii. 9.

<L>3138<pc>2-348<k1>Sakti<k2>Sakti<h>1
1. {@Śakti@}¦ is said in the Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> to have been
<div n="lb"/>the son of {@Vasiṣṭha,@} and to have been cast into the fire by the
<div n="lb"/>{@Viśvāmitras.@} According to Ṣaḍguruśiṣya,<sup>2</sup> who appears to
<div n="lb"/>follow the Śāṭyāyanaka,<sup>3</sup> the story of Śakti is as follows:
<div n="lb"/>Viśvāmitra, being defeated in a contest by Śakti, had recourse
[Page2-349+ 48]
<div n="lb"/>to {@Jamadagni,@} who taught him the {@Sasarparī;@} later he
<div n="lb"/>revenged himself on Śakti by having him burnt in the forest.
<div n="lb"/>The Bṛhaddevatā<sup>4</sup> relates the first part of the tale only.
<div n="lb"/>Geldner<sup>5</sup> sees in the Rigveda<sup>6</sup> a description of the death
<div n="lb"/>struggle of Śakti, but this interpretation is more than doubtful.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) ii. 390 ({%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 18, 47).</F>
<F>2) Sarvānukramaṇī, ed. Macdonell,
<div n="lb"/>p. 107, and on Rv. vii. 32.</F>
<F>3) Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 159, n. 3.</F>
<F>4) iv. 112 {%et seq.,%} with Macdonell's
<div n="lb"/>notes.</F>
<F>5) {%Op. cit.,%} 2, 159 {%et seq.;%} more doubt-
<div n="lb"/>fully, {%Rigveda, Kommentar,%} 89.</F>
<F>6) iii. 53, 22.</F>
<F>7) Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 254.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3152<pc>2-351<k1>Satapati<k2>Satapati
{@Śata-pati@}¦ occurs in a verse of the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>2</sup> as an epithet of Indra, who is
<div n="lb"/>described as alone the ‘lord of a hundred’ among men. To
<div n="lb"/>interpret the expression as ‘lord of a hundred gods,’ as does
<div n="lb"/>the commentary on the Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, is obviously
<div n="lb"/>impossible. It seems clear that there is a reference to an
<div n="lb"/>analogous human functionary — viz., the lord of a hundred
<div n="lb"/>villages, known in the later law<sup>3</sup> — who was probably at once a
<div n="lb"/>judicial deputy of the sovereign and a revenue collector, an
<div n="lb"/>ancient magistrate and collector.
<F>1) iv. 14, 12.</F>
<F>2) ii. 8, 4, 2.</F>
<F>3) See Foy, {%Die königliche Gewalt,%} 74.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3161<pc>2-353<k1>SaMtanu<k2>SaMtanu
{@Śaṃ-tanu@}¦ is the hero of a tale told by Yāska,<sup>1</sup> and often
<div n="lb"/>found later.<sup>2</sup> He supersedes his elder brother {@Devāpi@} as king
<div n="lb"/>of the {@Kurus.@} When his improper deed brings on a prolonged
<div n="lb"/>drought in his realm, he is compelled to ask his brother to
<div n="lb"/>assume the kingship; Devāpi, however, refuses, but instead
<div n="lb"/>performs a sacrifice which produces rain. Sieg<sup>3</sup> endeavours to
<div n="lb"/>trace this story in the Rigveda,<sup>4</sup> but all that is there stated is
<div n="lb"/>that Devāpi {@Ārṣṭiṣeṇa@} obtained (no doubt as priest) rain for
<div n="lb"/>Śaṃtanu (no doubt a king). There is no hint of relationship
<div n="lb"/>at all.
<F>1) Nirukta, ii. 10.</F>
<F>2) Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 155 {%et seq.,%} with
<div n="lb"/>Macdonell's notes; Sieg, {%Die Sagenstoffe%}
<div n="lb"/>{%des Ṛgveda,%} 129 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) {%Loc. cit.%}</F>
<F>4) x. 98.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3162<pc>2-353<k1>SapaTa<k2>SapaTa

<div n="lb"/>‘oath,’ as a judicial process. But that an oath of such a kind
<div n="lb"/>was possible as it was later,<sup>2</sup> is shown by at least one passage
<div n="lb"/>of the Rigveda,<sup>3</sup> where the speaker, possibly {@Vasiṣṭha,@} impre-
<div n="lb"/>cates death on himself if he is a wizard, and death on his foes if
<div n="lb"/>he is not.
<F>1) x. 87, 15; Nirukta, vii. 3.</F>
<F>2) Av. iii. 9, 5; iv. 9, 5; 18, 7; 19, 7.
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. iii. 9, 5; iv. 9, 5; 18, 7; 19, 7.
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>3) vii. 104, 15.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 1^2, 326,
<div n="lb"/>327.</F>

<L>3163<pc>2-353<k1>SaPa<k2>SaPa<h>1
1. {@Śapha,@}¦ ‘hoof,’ comes to be used to denote the fraction
<div n="lb"/>‘one-eighth,’ because of the divided hoofs of the cow, just as
<div n="lb"/>{@Pāda,@} the ‘foot’ of a quadruped, also means a ‘quarter.’ This
<div n="lb"/>sense in found as early as the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and is not rare later.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) viii. 47, 17.</F>
<F>2) Av. vi. 46, 3; xix. 57, 1; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 10, 1; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iii. 3, 3, 3, etc.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 16, 278; 17, 47; Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 259.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3164<pc>2-353<k1>SaPa<k2>SaPa<h>2
2. {@Śapha@}¦ in the Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> is the name (used in the dual) of
<div n="lb"/>a wooden implement, acting like a pair of tongs, for lifting an
<div n="lb"/>iron pot from the fire. It is probably so called because it
<div n="lb"/>resembled a hoof in being divided.
<F>1) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 22, 14;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xiv. 2, 1, 16. {%Cf.%}

<L>3165<pc>2-354<k1>SaPaka<k2>SaPaka
{@Śaphaka@}¦ is the name of some plant in the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> It
<div n="lb"/>is also mentioned in the Āpastamba Śrauta Sūtra,<sup>2</sup> where it
<div n="lb"/>seems to denote an edible water plant or fruit, perhaps a water
<div n="lb"/>nut. It may be so called from its leaves being shaped like
<div n="lb"/>hoofs ({@Śapha@}).
<F>1) iv. 34, 5.</F>
<F>2) ix. 14, 14.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 18, 138;
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 70; Whit-
<div n="lb"/>ney, Translation of the Atharvaveda
<div n="lb"/>207.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3169<pc>2-354<k1>SamI<k2>SamI
{@Śamī@}¦ is the name of a tree in the Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>It is described in the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> as destructive to the hair,<sup>4</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>producing intoxication, and as broad-leaved. These charac-
<div n="lb"/>teristics are totally wanting in the two trees, {%Prosopis spicigera%}
<div n="lb"/>or {%Mimosa suma,%} with which the Śamī is usually identified.<sup>5</sup>
[Page2-355+ 56]
<div n="lb"/>From the soft wood of the Śamī was formed the lower of the
<div n="lb"/>two sticks ({%araṇī%}) used for kindling the sacred fire,<sup>6</sup> the upper
<div n="lb"/>one (the drill) being of {@Aśvattha.@} The fruit of the tree is
<div n="lb"/>called Śamīdhānya.<sup>7</sup>
<F>1) Av. vi. 11, 1; 30, 2, 3.</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 1, 9, 6;
<div n="lb"/>4, 7, 4 (for the lower {%araṇī%}); Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 6; Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 1, 3, 11 {%et seq.;%} 6, 4, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 5, 2, 12;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 2, 3, 37, etc.</F>
<F>3) Av. vi. 30, 2. 3.</F>
<F>4) In the Dhanvantarīya Nighaṇṭu,
<div n="lb"/>p. 188 (ed. Poona), the Śamī and its
<div n="lb"/>fruit are said to destroy the hair.</F>
<F>5) See Roth in Whitney, Translation
<div n="lb"/>of the Atharvaveda, 302.</F>
<F>6) Av. vi. 11, 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>xi. 5, 1, 15; {%Cf.%} 13; iii. 4, 1, 22;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 1, 9, 6; 4, 7, 4.</F>
<F>7) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 1, 10.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 59, 60.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3170<pc>2-355<k1>Sambara<k2>Sambara
{@Śambara@}¦ is the name of an enemy of Indra in the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="lb"/>He is mentioned along with {@Śuṣṇa, Pipru,@} and {@Varcin,@} being
<div n="lb"/>in one passage called a {@Dāsa,@} son of Kulitara.<sup>2</sup> In another
<div n="lb"/>passage<sup>3</sup> he is said to have deemed himself a godling ({%devaka%}).
<div n="lb"/>His forts, ninety,<sup>4</sup> ninety-nine,<sup>5</sup> or a hundred<sup>6</sup> in number, are
<div n="lb"/>alluded to, the word itself in the neuter plural once<sup>7</sup> meaning
<div n="lb"/>the ‘forts of Śambara.’ His great foe was {@Divodāsa Ati-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@thigva,@} who won victories over him by Indra's aid.<sup>8</sup>
<div n="P"/>It is impossible to say with certainty whether Śambara was
<div n="lb"/>a real person or not. Hillebrandt<sup>9</sup> is strongly in favour of the
<div n="lb"/>theory that he was a real chief as enemy of Divodāsa: he
<div n="lb"/>relies on the statistics<sup>10</sup> of the mention of the name to show
<div n="lb"/>that, where as he was conceived as a real foe in the hymns of
<div n="lb"/>the time of Divodāsa, later texts, like those of the seventh
<div n="lb"/>Maṇḍala, make him into a demon, as a result of the change of
<div n="lb"/>scene from Arachosia to India. As a matter of fact, apart from
<div n="lb"/>this theory, Śambara was quite possibly an aboriginal enemy
<div n="lb"/>in India, living in the mountains.<sup>11</sup>
<F>1) i. 51, 6; 54, 4; 59, 6; 101, 2;
<div n="lb"/>103, 8; 112, 14; 130, 7; ii. 12, 11;
<div n="lb"/>14, 6; 19, 6; iv. 26, 3; 30, 14; vi. 18, 8;
<div n="lb"/>26, 5; 31, 4; 43, 1; 47, 2. 21; vii. 18,
<div n="lb"/>20; 99, 5.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 26, 5.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 18, 20.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 130, 7.</F>
<F>5) Rv. ii. 19, 6.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ii. 14, 6.</F>
<F>7) Rv. ii. 24, 2.</F>
<F>8) Rv. i. 51, 6; 130, 7; ii. 19, 6;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 26, 3, etc.</F>
<F>9) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 103, 108;
<div n="lb"/>3, 273.</F>
<F>10) Seven times in Maṇḍala i; four
<div n="lb"/>in ii; two in iv; six in vi; two in vii.
<div n="lb"/>These references show {%primâ facis%}
<div n="lb"/>greater reality in Maṇḍala vi than else-
<div n="lb"/>where. The references in ii. are certainly
<div n="lb"/>all of the mythical kind, and those in
<div n="lb"/>vii are of much the same sort.</F>
<F>11) Rv. i. 130, 7; iv. 30, 14; vi. 26, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 177; Macdonell, {%Vedic Myth-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ology,%} p. 161; Oldenberg, {%Zeitschrift der%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%}
<div n="lb"/>42, 210; Geldner, {%Rigveda, Glossar,%}
<div n="lb"/>178.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3182<pc>2-357<k1>SaraBa<k2>SaraBa<h>1

<div n="lb"/>veda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> In the {@classical@} literature it is a fabulous,
<div n="lb"/>eight-legged beast, dwelling in the snowy mountains, a foe of
<div n="lb"/>lions and elephants: the commentator Mahīdhara sees this
<div n="lb"/>sense, but without reason, in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā. The
[Page2-358+ 41]
<div n="lb"/>animal is spoken of as akin to the goat;<sup>3</sup> it was probably a
<div n="lb"/>kind of deer.
<F>1) ix. 5, 9. {%Cf.%} {@Śalabha.@}</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 10, 4;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 51; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ii. 8, 5; Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, i. 2, 3, 9, etc.</F>
<F>3) Av., {%loc. cit.;%} Satapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>{%loc. cit.%} Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%East,%} 12, 52, n. 1, accepts the traditional
<div n="lb"/>rendering.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 89.</F>

<L>3186<pc>2-358<k1>SarIra<k2>SarIra
{@Śarīra,@}¦ ‘body,’ is a word of frequent occurrence in Vedic
<div n="lb"/>literature.<sup>1</sup> The interest of the Vedic Indians seems early to
<div n="lb"/>have been attracted to the consideration of questions connected
<div n="lb"/>with the anatomy of the body. Thus a hymn of the Atharva-
<div n="lb"/>veda<sup>2</sup> enumerates many parts of the body with some approach
<div n="lb"/>to accuracy and orderly arrangement.<sup>3</sup> It mentions the heels
<div n="lb"/>({%pārṣṇī%}), the flesh ({%māṃsa%}), the ankle-bones ({%gulphau%}), the
<div n="lb"/>fingers ({%aṅgulīḥ%}), the apertures ({%kha%}), the two metatarsi
<div n="lb"/>({%uchlakau%}), the tarsus ({%pratiṣṭhā%}), the two knee-caps ({%aṣṭhī-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vantau%}), the two legs ({%jaṅghe%}), the two knee-joints ({%jānunoḥ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%sandhī%}). Then comes above the two kness ({%jānū%}) the four-
<div n="lb"/>sided ({%catuṣṭaya%}), pliant ({%śithira%}) trunk ({%kabandha%}). The two
<div n="lb"/>hips ({%śroṇī%}) and the two thighs ({%ārū%}) are the props of the frame
[Page2-359+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>({%kusindha%}). Next come the breast-bone ({%uras%}), the cervical
<div n="lb"/>cartilages ({%grīvāḥ%}), the two breast pieces ({%stanau%}), the two
<div n="lb"/>shoulder-blades ({%kaphoḍau%}), the neck-bones ({%skandhau%}), and the
<div n="lb"/>backbones ({%pṛṣṭīḥ%}), the collar-bones ({%aṃsau%}), the arms ({%bāhū%}),
<div n="lb"/>the seven apertures in the head ({%sapta khāni śīrṣaṇi%}), the ears
<div n="lb"/>({%karṇau%}), the nostrils ({%nāsike%}), the eyes ({%cakṣaṇī%}), the mouth
<div n="lb"/>({%mukha%}), the jaws ({%hanū%}), the tongue ({%jihvā%}), the brain ({%mas-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%tiṣka%}), the forehead ({%lalāṭa%}), the facial bone ({%kakāṭikā%}), the
<div n="lb"/>cranium ({%kapāla%}), and the structure of the jaws ({%cityā hanvoḥ%}).
<div n="P"/>This system presents marked similarities with the later
<div n="lb"/>system of Caraka and Suśruta,<sup>4</sup> which render certain the names
<div n="lb"/>ascribed to the several terms by Hoernle. {%Kaphoḍau,%} which is
<div n="lb"/>variously read in the manuscripts,<sup>5</sup> is rendered ‘collar-bone’ by
<div n="lb"/>Whitney, but ‘elbow’ in the St. Petersburg Dictionary.
<div n="lb"/>{%Skandha%} in the plural regularly<sup>6</sup> denotes ‘neck-bones,’ or, more
<div n="lb"/>precisely, ‘cervical vertebræ,’ a part denoted also by {%uṣṇihā%} in
<div n="lb"/>the plural.<sup>7</sup> {%Pṛṣṭī%}<sup>8</sup> denotes not ‘rib,’ which is {%parśu,%}<sup>9</sup> but a
<div n="lb"/>transverse process of a vertebra, and so the vertebra itself,
<div n="lb"/>there being in the truncal portion of the spinal column seventeen
<div n="lb"/>vertebræ and thirty-four transverse processes. The vertebræ
<div n="lb"/>are also denoted by {%kīkasā%} in the plural,<sup>10</sup> which sometimes<sup>11</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>limited to the upper portion of the vertebral column, sometimes<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to the thoracic portion of the spine. {%Anūka%} also denotes the
<div n="lb"/>vertebral column,<sup>13</sup> or more specially the lumbar<sup>14</sup> or thoracic<sup>15</sup>
<div n="lb"/>portion of the spine; it is said in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>15</sup>
[Page2-360+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>that there are twenty transverse processes in the lumbar spine
<div n="lb"/>({%udara%}) and thirty-two in the thoracic, which gives twenty-six
<div n="lb"/>vertebræ, the true number (but the modern division is seven
<div n="lb"/>cervical, twelve thoracic, five lumbar, and two false — the
<div n="lb"/>sacrum and the coccyx). The vertebral column is also denoted
<div n="lb"/>by {%karūkara,%}<sup>16</sup> which, however, is usually found in the plural<sup>17</sup>
<div n="lb"/>denoting the transverse processes of the vertebræ, a sense
<div n="lb"/>expressed also by {%kuntāpa.%}<sup>18</sup>
<div n="P"/>{%Grīvā,%} in the plural, denotes cervical vertebræ, the number
<div n="lb"/>seven being given by the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>19</sup> but usually<sup>20</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the word simply means windpipe, or, more accurately, the
<div n="lb"/>cartilaginous rings under the skin. {@Jatru,@} also in the plural,
<div n="lb"/>denotes the cervical cartilages,<sup>21</sup> or possibly the costal carti-
<div n="lb"/>lages, which are certainly so called in the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa,<sup>22</sup> where their number is given as eight.
<div n="P"/>{%Bhaṃsas,%} which occurs thrice in the Atharvaveda,<sup>23</sup> seems to
<div n="lb"/>denote the pubic bone or arch rather than the ‘buttocks’ or
<div n="lb"/>‘fundament,’ as Whitney<sup>24</sup> takes it.
<div n="P"/>In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>25</sup> the number of bones in the
<div n="lb"/>the human body is given as 360. The number of the bones
<div n="lb"/>of the head and trunk are given in another passage<sup>26</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>follows: The head is threefold, consisting of skin ({%tvac%}), bone
<div n="lb"/>({%asthi%}), brain ({%matiṣka%}); the neck has 15 bones: 14 transverse
<div n="lb"/>processes ({%karūkara%}) and the strength ({%vīrya%}) — {%i.e.,%} the bone of
<div n="lb"/>the centre regarded as one — as the 15th; the breast has 17:
<div n="lb"/>16 cervical cartilages ({%jatru%}), and the sternum ({%uras%}) as the
<div n="lb"/>17th; the abdominal portion of the spine has 21: 20 trans-
[Page2-361+ 45]
<div n="lb"/>verse processes ({%kuntāpa%}), and the abdominal portion ({%udara%}) as
<div n="lb"/>the 21st; the two sides have 27: 26 ribs ({%parśu%}), and the two
<div n="lb"/>sides as the 27th; the thoracic portion of the spine ({%anūka%})
<div n="lb"/>has 33: 32 transverse processes, and the thoracic portion
<div n="lb"/>as 33rd.
<div n="P"/>There are several enumerations of the parts of the body, not
<div n="lb"/>merely of the skeleton, in the Yajurveda Saṃhitās.<sup>27</sup> They
<div n="lb"/>include the hair ({%lomāni%}), skin ({%tvac%}), flesh ({%māṃsa%}), bone
<div n="lb"/>({%asthi%}), marrow ({%majjan%}), liver ({%yakṛt%}), lungs ({%kloman%}), kidneys
<div n="lb"/>({%matasne%}), gall ({%pitta%}), entrails ({%āntrāṇi%}), bowels ({%gudāḥ%}), spleen
<div n="lb"/>({%plīhan%}), navel ({%nābhi%}), belly ({%udara%}), rectum ({%vaniṣṭhu%}), womb
<div n="lb"/>({%yoni%}), penis ({%plāśi%} and {%śepa%}), face ({%mukha%}), head ({%śiras%}),
<div n="lb"/>tongue ({%jihvā%}), mouth ({%āsan%}), rump ({%pāyu%}), leech ({%vāla%}), eye
<div n="lb"/>({%cakṣus%}), eyelashes ({%pakṣmāṇi%}), eyebrows ({%utāni%}), nose ({%nas%}), breath
<div n="lb"/>({%vyāna%}), nose-hairs ({%nasyāni%}), ears ({%karṇau%}), brows ({%bhrū%}), body
<div n="lb"/>or trunk ({%ātman%}), waist ({%upastha%}), hair on the face ({%śmaśrūṇi%}),
<div n="lb"/>and on the head ({%keśāḥ%}). Another enumeration<sup>28</sup> gives {%śiras,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%mukha, keśāḥ, śmaśrūṇi, prāṇa%} (breath), {%cakṣus, śrotra%} (ear), {%jihvā,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vāc%} (speech), {%manas%} (mind), {%aṅgulīḥ, aṅgāni%} (limbs), {%bāhū, hastau%}
<div n="lb"/>(hands), {%karṇau, ātmā, uras%} (sternum), {%pṛṣṭīḥ%} (vertebræ), {%udara,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%aṃsau, grīvāḥ, śroṇī, ūrū, aratnī%} (elbows), {%jānūni, nābhi, pāyu,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%bhasat%} (fundament), {%āṇḍau%} (testicles), {%pasas%} (membrum virile),
<div n="lb"/>{%jaṅghā, pad%} (foot), {%lomāni, tvac, māṃsa, asthi, majjan.%} Another
<div n="lb"/>set of names<sup>29</sup> includes {%vaniṣṭhu, purītat%} (pericardium), {%lomāni,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%tvac, lohita%} (blood), {%medas%} (fat), {%māṃsāni, snāvāni%} (sinews),
<div n="lb"/>{%asthīni, majjānaḥ, retas%} (semen), {%pāyu, kośya%} (flesh near the
<div n="lb"/>heart), {%pārśvya%} (intercostal flesh), etc.
<div n="P"/>The bones of the skeleton of the horse are enumerated in the
<div n="lb"/>Yajurveda Saṃhitās.<sup>30</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>31</sup> the human body is regarded as
<div n="lb"/>made up of one hundred and one items; there are four parts,
[Page2-362+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>each of twenty-five members, with the trunk as one hundred
<div n="lb"/>and first. In the two upper parts there are five four-jointed<sup>32</sup>
<div n="lb"/>fingers, two {%kakṣasī%} (of uncertain meaning),<sup>33</sup> the arm ({%dos%}), the
<div n="lb"/>collar-bone ({%akṣa%}), and the shoulder-blade ({%aṃsa-phalaka%}). In
<div n="lb"/>the two lower portions there are five four-jointed toes, the
<div n="lb"/>thigh, the leg, and three articulations, according to Sāyaṇa's
<div n="lb"/>commentary.
<div n="P"/>The Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka<sup>34</sup> enumerates three bones in the
<div n="lb"/>head,<sup>35</sup> three joints ({%parvāṇi%}) in the neck,<sup>36</sup> the collar-bone
<div n="lb"/>({%akṣa%}),<sup>37</sup> three joints in the fingers,<sup>38</sup> and twenty-one transverse
<div n="lb"/>processes in the spine ({%anūka%}).<sup>39</sup> The Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<sup>40</sup>
<div n="lb"/>enumerates four constituents in the head ({%prāṇa, cakṣus, śrotra,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%vāc%}), but there are many variations, the number going up to
<div n="lb"/>twelve on one calculation.<sup>41</sup> In the Taittirīya Upaniṣad<sup>42</sup> an
<div n="lb"/>enumeration is given consisting of {%carma%} (skin), {%māṃsa, snāvan,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%asthi,%} and {%majjan;%} and the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>43</sup> has {%lomāni, māṃsa,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%tvac, asthi, majjan,%} and the Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>44</sup> couples {%majjānaḥ,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%snāvāni,%} and {%asthīni.%} Other terms relating to the body are
<div n="lb"/>{%kaṅkūṣa,%}<sup>45</sup> perhaps a part of the ear,<sup>46</sup> {%yoni%} (female organ),
<div n="lb"/>{%kakṣa%}<sup>47</sup> (armpit), {@Danta@} (tooth), {%nakha%} (nail), {%prapada%}<sup>48</sup> (forepart
<div n="lb"/>of the foot), {%halīkṣṇa%}<sup>49</sup> (gall).

<L>3187<pc>2-363<k1>Saru<k2>Saru
{@Śaru@}¦ denotes in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> a missile
<div n="lb"/>weapon, often certainly an ‘arrow,’<sup>3</sup> but perhaps sometimes a
<div n="lb"/>‘dart’ or ‘spear.’<sup>4</sup>

<div n="lb"/>10; iv. 3, 7; 28, 3, etc.</F>

<F>3) {%E.g.,%} Rv. x. 125, 6; and x. 87, 6.</F>
<F>4) Perhaps Rv. iv. 3, 7, where {%bṛhatī%}
<div n="lb"/>is applied to it, and where ‘lance’
<div n="lb"/>seems the best sense, the use being
<div n="lb"/>metaphorical.
