<L>3194<pc>2-364<k1>SaryaRAvant<k2>SaryaRAvant
{@Śaryaṇāvant@}¦ occurs in several passages of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>all of which Sāyaṇa sees a local name. According to his
<div n="lb"/>account, Śaryaṇāḥ (masc. plur.) is a district in {@Kurukṣetra,@}
<div n="lb"/>Śaryaṇāvant being a lake not far from it in the back part
<div n="lb"/>({%jaghanārdhe%}) of Kurukṣetra. The unusual consistency of his
<div n="lb"/>statements on this point is in favour of the word being a place
<div n="lb"/>name; it is also to be noted that Kurukṣetra contained the
<div n="lb"/>lake {@Anyataḥplakṣā.@} Roth,<sup>2</sup> however, thought that in two
<div n="lb"/>passages<sup>3</sup> the word denoted merely a ‘lake,’ literally ‘(water)
<div n="lb"/>covered with a thicket of reeds’ ({%śaryaṇa%}), and in the others a
<div n="lb"/>Soma vessel. Zimmer<sup>4</sup> inclines to this rendering. On the
<div n="lb"/>other hand, Pischel<sup>5</sup> accepts Sāyaṇa's view. Hillebrandt<sup>6</sup> also
<div n="lb"/>sees in the word a place name, but he is inclined to locate it
<div n="lb"/>among the ‘five tribes,’<sup>7</sup> which is not quite inconsistent with its
<div n="lb"/>being in Kurukṣetra, for the connexion of the {@Pūrus@} with the
<div n="lb"/>later {@Kurus@} is known;<sup>8</sup> or perhaps, he suggests, Śaryaṇāvant
<div n="lb"/>is an old name for the Wular sea of Kaśmīr, which was only a
<div n="lb"/>reminiscence in Vedic times. This is not probable; still less
<div n="lb"/>so is Ludwig's hypothesis<sup>9</sup> that the Śaryaṇāvant is the later
<div n="lb"/>eastern {@Sarasvatī.@} Bergaigne<sup>10</sup> regards the name as that of
<div n="lb"/>a celestial preparer of Soma.
<F>1) i. 84, 14; viii. 6, 39; 7, 29; 64, 11;
<div n="lb"/>ix. 65, 22; 113, 1; x. 35, 2. See
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 64 ({%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the American Oriental Society,%} 18,
<div n="lb"/>17); Śāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. i.
<div n="lb"/>84, 13.</F>
<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>3) i. 84, 14; x. 35, 2.</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 19, 20.</F>
<F>5) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 217. So Max
<div n="lb"/>Müller, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32,
<div n="lb"/>398, 399.</F>
<F>6) {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 126, {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>7) This is deduced, not with any
<div n="lb"/>certainty, from Rv. ix. 65, 22.</F>
<F>8) Hillebrandt, {%op. cit.,%} 1, 142, n. 4,
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda,
<div n="lb"/>3, 205.</F>
<F>9) {%Op. cit.,%} 3, 201.</F>
<F>10) {%Religion Védique,%} 1, 206.</F>

<L>3195<pc>2-364<k1>SaryAta<k2>SaryAta
{@Śaryāta@}¦ is mentioned once in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as a protégé of
<div n="lb"/>the Aśvins. Of him in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa^2 and the
[Page2-365+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>3</sup> is told a story how {@Cyavana@} was annoyed
<div n="lb"/>by the {@Śāryātas,@} and appeased by the gift of {@Sukanyā,@}
<div n="lb"/>Śaryāta's daughter, as a wife, and how Cyavana was then
<div n="lb"/>restored to youth by the Aśvins. He is there called {@Mānava@}
<div n="lb"/>(‘descendant of Manu’). He appears also as Śaryāta Mānava,
<div n="lb"/>a sacrificer, in the Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa.<sup>4</sup>
<F>1) i. 112, 17.</F>
<F>3) iii. 120-122 ({%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 11, cxlv).</F>
<F>4) iv. 7, 1; 8, 3, 5.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Muir, {%Sanskrit Texts,%} 5, 250 {%et seq.;%}
<div n="lb"/>Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 26,
<div n="lb"/>272 {%et seq.;%} Oertel, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 16, 236, 237.</F>

<L>3214<pc>2-368<k1>Sastra<k2>Sastra

<div n="lb"/>Niṣkevalya; at the evening offering, the Vaiśvadeva and the
<div n="lb"/>Āgnimāruta.

<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxix. 2, etc.; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 25. 28, etc.; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, iv. 2, 4, 20, etc.

<div n="lb"/>and Caland and Henry, {%L'Agniṣṭoma,%}

<div n="lb"/>length.</F>

<L>3231<pc>2-371<k1>SARqilya<k2>SARqilya
{@Śāṇḍilya,@}¦ ‘descendant of Śaṇḍila,’ is the patronymic of
<div n="lb"/>several teachers (see {@Udara@} and {@Suyajña@}). The most important
<div n="lb"/>Śāṇḍilya is the one cited several times as an authority in the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> where his Agni, or ‘sacrificial fire,’ is
<div n="lb"/>called Śāṇḍila.<sup>2</sup> From this it appears clearly that he was one
<div n="lb"/>of the great teachers of the fire ritual which occupies the fifth
<div n="lb"/>and following books of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa. In the
<div n="lb"/>Vaṃśa (list of teachers) at the end of the tenth book<sup>3</sup> he is
<div n="lb"/>given as a pupil of {@Kuśri@} and a teacher of {@Vātsya;@} another list
<div n="lb"/>at the end of the last book in the Kāṇva recension<sup>4</sup> gives him
<div n="lb"/>as a pupil of Vātsya, and the latter as a pupil of Kuśri. In the
<div n="lb"/>confused and worthless<sup>5</sup> lists of teachers at the end of the
<div n="lb"/>second and fourth books of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad he is
<div n="lb"/>said to be the pupil of various persons — {@Kaiśorya Kāpya,@}<sup>6</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{@Vaiṣṭapureya,@}<sup>7</sup> {@Kauśika,@}<sup>8</sup> {@Gautama,@}<sup>9</sup> {@Baijavāpa,@}<sup>10</sup> and {@Āṇa-@}
[Page2-372+ 39]
<div n="lb"/>{@bhimlāta.@}<sup>11</sup> No doubt different Śāṇḍilyas may be meant, but
<div n="lb"/>the lists are too confused to claim serious consideration.
<F>1) ix. 4, 4, 17; 5, 2, 15; x. 1, 4, 10;
<div n="lb"/>4, 1, 11; 6, 3, 5; 5, 9. {%Cf.%} Chāndogya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, iii. 11, 4.</F>
<F>2) ix. 1, 1, 43; 3, 3, 18; 5, 1, 61, 68, etc.</F>
<F>3) x. 6, 5, 9.</F>
<F>4) vi. 5, 4.</F>
<F>5) Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>12, xxxiv. n. 2.</F>
<F>6) ii. 5, 22; iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina
<div n="lb"/>= ii. 6, 3; iv. 6, 3 Kāṇva).</F>
<F>7) ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26 Mādhyaṃdina.</F>
<F>8) ii. 6, 1; iv. 6, 1 Kāṇva.</F>
<F>9) ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26 (Mādhyaṃdina
<div n="lb"/>= ii. 6, 1; iv. 6, 1 Kāṇva).</F>
<F>10) ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26 Mādhyaṃdina.</F>
<F>11) ii. 6, 2 Kāṇva.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%}
<div n="lb"/>12, xxxi {%et seq.;%} 43, xviii {%et seq.;%} Weber,
<div n="lb"/>{%Indian Literature,%} 71, 76 {%et seq.;%} 120,
<div n="lb"/>131, 132; Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>213.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3232<pc>2-372<k1>SARqilyAyana<k2>SARqilyAyana
{@Śāṇḍilyāyana,@}¦ ‘descendant of {@Śāṇḍilya,@}’ is the patronymic
<div n="lb"/>of a teacher in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.<sup>1</sup> Apparently he is
<div n="lb"/>identical with {@Celaka,@} also mentioned in that text;<sup>2</sup> it is thus
<div n="lb"/>reasonable to suppose that {@Cailaki Jīvala@}<sup>3</sup> was his son. It is
<div n="lb"/>much more doubtful whether he was<sup>4</sup> the grandfather of
<div n="lb"/>{@Pravāhaṇa Jaivala,@} who was a prince rather than a Brahmin.
<F>1) ix. 5, 1, 64.</F>
<F>2) x. 4, 5, 3. The name Śāṇḍily-
<div n="lb"/>āyana, like that of Sāṇḍilya, is common
<div n="lb"/>in the Sūtras. See Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 1, 45, {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 3, 1, 34.</F>
<F>4) Weber, {%op. cit.,%} 1, 259.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indian Literature,%} 53, 76,
<div n="lb"/>120.</F>

<L>3243<pc>2-373<k1>SAri<k2>SAri<h>1
1. {@Śāri@}¦ occurs in the list of victims at the Aśvamedha
<div n="lb"/>(‘horse sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda Saṃhitās.<sup>1</sup> It seems clear,
<div n="lb"/>since it is described as ‘of human speech’ ({%puruṣa-vāc%}), that it
<div n="lb"/>was some kind of bird, possibly the later Sārikā (‘starling’), as
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>2</sup> suggests. See also {@Śāriśākā.@}
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xxiv. 33.</F>
<F>2) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 90, 91.</F>
<LEND>
[Page2-374+ 46]

<L>3244<pc>2-374<k1>SAri<k2>SAri<h>2
2. {@Śāri,@}¦ occurring in one passage of the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> is said by
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa to mean ‘arrow.’ This is uncertain, but connexion
<div n="lb"/>with {@Śara@} or 1. {@Śāri@} is quite possible.<sup>2</sup>
<F>1) i. 112, 16.</F>
<F>2) Oldenberg, {%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 103.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3245<pc>2-374<k1>SAriSAkA<k2>SAriSAkA
{@Śāriśākā@}¦ is an utterly obscure expression found in one
<div n="lb"/>passage of the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> Weber<sup>2</sup> thinks it means ‘dung
<div n="lb"/>({%śakan%}) of the Śāri bird’; Grill<sup>3</sup> sees in the word the {%śārikā,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘the hooded crow’; Roth<sup>4</sup> suggests the emendation ({%śāriḥ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%(= śāliḥ) śaka iva,%} ‘like rice in manure’; and Bloomfield<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>emends {%śāri-śukeva,%} ‘like starlings and parrots.’
<F>1) iii. 14, 5.</F>
<F>2) {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 246.</F>
<F>3) {%Hundert Lieder,^2%} 112.</F>
<F>4) In Whitney, Translation of the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda, 110.</F>
<F>5) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 351. But
<div n="lb"/>see Lanman's note in Whitney, {%loc.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%cit.%}</F>
<LEND>

<L>3249<pc>2-375<k1>SArNga<k2>SArNga
{@Śārṅga.@}¦ — The Anukramaṇī<sup>1</sup> (Index) of the Rigveda ascribes
<div n="lb"/>a hymn of that text<sup>2</sup> to the Śārṅgas, Jaritṛ, Droṇa, Sārisṛkva,
<div n="lb"/>and Stambamitra. The Mahābhārata<sup>3</sup> contains a tale describing
<div n="lb"/>how the four Śārṅgas, sons of the Ṛṣi Mandapāla, were saved
<div n="lb"/>from the great fire in the Khāṇḍava forest by means of
<div n="lb"/>prayers. Sieg<sup>4</sup> has attempted to use this tale for the elucida-
<div n="lb"/>tion of the hymn in question, but without substantial success.
<div n="lb"/>As Oldenberg<sup>5</sup> says, the tale is based on the hymn rather than
<div n="lb"/>{%vice versa.%}
<F>1) See also Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 142;
<div n="lb"/>Ṣaḍguruśiṣya on the Sarvānukramaṇī
<div n="lb"/>(ed. Macdonell), p. 163.</F>
<F>2) x. 142.</F>
<F>3) i. 8334 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>4) {%Die Sagenstoffe des Ṛgveda,%} 44-50.</F>
<F>5) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%ländischen Gesellschaft,%} 39, 79.</F>
<LEND>

<div n="lb"/>maṇa.<sup>6</sup> In both these passages the Śāryātas are mentioned as
<div n="lb"/>his descendants, and his daughter is called Śāryātī.

<F>2) iv. 32, 7.</F>

<L>3277<pc>2-379<k1>SiprA<k2>SiprA
{@Śiprā@}¦ is a word of somewhat uncertain sense: it seems to
<div n="lb"/>mean ‘cheeks’ in several passages;<sup>1</sup> in others<sup>2</sup> it appears to

<div n="lb"/>iron,’ ‘of gold,’ or ‘yellow,’ Similarly {%śiprin%}<sup>8</sup> would mean
<div n="lb"/>‘wearing a helmet.’

<div n="lb"/>i. 101, 10, as ‘lip’ ({%cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altin-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%disches Leben,%} 249, n.), and sees in
<div n="lb"/>iii. 32, 1; viii. 76, 10; x. 96, 9, the
<div n="lb"/>sense of ‘moustache.’ Yāska, Nirukta,
<div n="lb"/>vi. 17, gives the alternative senses of
<div n="lb"/>‘jaw’ and ‘nose.’</F>
<F>2) Rv. v. 54, 11; viii. 7, 25. Geldner,

<F>3) Rv. i. 101, 10; Zimmer, {%loc. cit.%}</F>

<F>5) Rv. ii. 34, 3.</F>
<F>6) Rv. x. 96, 4.</F>

<L>3312<pc>2-385<k1>SunaHSepa<k2>SunaHSepa
{@Śunaḥ-śepa,@}¦ ‘Dog’s tail,’ is the name of a man with the
<div n="lb"/>patronymic {@Ājīgarti.@} According to a tale told in the Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> and the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra,<sup>2</sup> he was
<div n="lb"/>purchased as a victim by {@Rohita,@} King {@Hariścandra's@} son,
<div n="lb"/>who had been promised by his father to Varuṇa as a sacrifice.
<div n="lb"/>He was actually bound to the stake, but was released in time
<div n="lb"/>through his supplications, supposed to be preserved in certain
<div n="lb"/>hymns of the Rigveda.<sup>3</sup> He was adopted by {@Viśvāmitra,@} to
<div n="lb"/>whose advice he owed the inspiration to ask the gods to release
<div n="lb"/>him, and became his son as {@Devarāta,@} much to the annoyance
[Page2-386+ 44]
<div n="lb"/>of some of Viśvāmitra's sons, who in consequence were cursed
<div n="lb"/>by their father. The Rigveda, however, contains merely the
<div n="lb"/>statement of Śunaḥśepa's deliverance from peril of death by
<div n="lb"/>the divine help, and the Yajurvedas<sup>4</sup> simply say that he was
<div n="lb"/>seized by Varuṇa (perhaps with dropsy),<sup>5</sup> but saved himself from
<div n="lb"/>Varuṇa's bonds.
<F>1) vii. 13-18.</F>
<F>2) xv. 20, 1 {%et seq. Cf.%} xvi. 11, 2.</F>
<F>3) i. 24 {%et seq. Cf.%} v. 2, 7.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 2, 1, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xix. 11. The story
<div n="lb"/>is not found in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 2, 1.</F>
<F>5) {%Cf.%} Varuna gṛhīta.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Max Müller, {%Ancient Sanskrit%}

<L>3323<pc>2-388<k1>SUdra<k2>SUdra
{@Śūdra@}¦ is the designation of the fourth caste in the Vedic
<div n="lb"/>state (see {@Varṇa@}). It is quite unknown in the Rigveda except
<div n="lb"/>in the Puruṣasūkta<sup>1</sup> (‘hymn of man’) in the tenth Maṇḍla,
<div n="lb"/>where is the earliest version of the origin of the castes the
<div n="lb"/>Śudra for the first time appears. The Rigveda, on the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, knows {@Dasyu@} and {@Dāsa,@} both as aborigines independent
<div n="lb"/>of Āryan control and as subjugated slaves: it is reasonable to
<div n="lb"/>reckon the Śūdra of the later texts as belonging to the
<div n="lb"/>aborigines who had been reduced to subjection by the Āryans.
<div n="lb"/>Strictly speaking, the defeated aborigines must have been
<div n="lb"/>regarded as slaves, but it is obvious that, except on occasions
<div n="lb"/>when most of the men were slain, which may have occurred
<div n="lb"/>quite often, there must have remained too many of them to be
<div n="lb"/>used as slaves of individual owners. The villages of the
<div n="lb"/>aborigines must have continued to subsist, but under Āryan
<div n="lb"/>lordship and control: there may be this amount of truth in
<div n="lb"/>Baden Powell's theory, which practically traced all the early
<div n="lb"/>cultivating villages in India to Dravidian origin. On the other
<div n="lb"/>hand, the term Śūdra would also cover the wild hill tribes
<div n="lb"/>which lived by hunting and fishing, and many of which would
<div n="lb"/>acknowledge the superiority of their Āryan neighbours: it
<div n="lb"/>could, in fact, be applied to all beyond the pale of the Āryan
<div n="lb"/>state.
<div n="P"/>This view of the Śūdra suits adequately the Vedic references
<div n="lb"/>to his condition, which would not apply adequately to domestic
<div n="lb"/>slaves only. The Śūdra is continually opposed to the Āryan,<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and the colour of the Śūdra is compared with that of the
<div n="lb"/>Āryan,<sup>3</sup> just as his ways are so contrasted.<sup>4</sup> The Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa,<sup>5</sup> in its account of the castes, declares that the
[Page2-389+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>Śūdra is {%anyasya preṣya,%} ‘the servant of another’; {%kāmotthāpya,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘to be expelled at will’; and {%yathākāmavadhya,%} ‘to be slain at
<div n="lb"/>will.’ All these terms well enough describe the position of the
<div n="lb"/>serf as the result of a conquest: the epithets might have been
<div n="lb"/>applied to the English serf after the Norman Conquest with
<div n="lb"/>but slight inaccuracy, especially if his master had received a
<div n="lb"/>grant of jurisdiction from the Crown. The Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>6</sup> explains that even if prosperous ({%bahu-paśu,%} ‘having
<div n="lb"/>many cows’) a Śūdra could not be other than a servant: his
<div n="lb"/>business was {%pādāvanejya,%} ‘the washing of the feet’ of his
<div n="lb"/>superiors. The Mahābhārata<sup>7</sup> says out and out that a Śūdra
<div n="lb"/>has no property ({%na hi svam asti śūdrasya,%} ‘the Śūdra has
<div n="lb"/>nothing he can call his own’). On the other hand, just as in
<div n="lb"/>England the royal justice would protect the serf in life and
<div n="lb"/>limb,<sup>8</sup> so it appears that the slaying of a Śūdra involved a
<div n="lb"/>wergeld of ten cows according to both Baudhāyana<sup>9</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>Āpastamba.<sup>10</sup> It may, indeed, be held that this wergeld was
<div n="lb"/>only due in case of murder by another than the master, but
<div n="lb"/>such limitation is nowhere stated.
<div n="P"/>In sacred matters the distinction between Āryan and {@Śūdra@}
<div n="lb"/>was, of course, specially marked. The texts<sup>11</sup> do not hesitate
<div n="lb"/>to declare that the upper castes were ‘all,’ ignoring the Śūdras;
<div n="lb"/>the Śūdra is prohibited<sup>12</sup> from milking the cow for the milk
<div n="lb"/>required at the Agnihotra (‘oblation to Agni’); and the Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa<sup>13</sup> forbids a man who has been consecrated
<div n="lb"/>({%dīkṣita%}) for a sacrifice to speak to a Śūdra at all for the time,
<div n="lb"/>though the Śāṭyāyanaka<sup>14</sup> seems to have relaxed this rule by
<div n="lb"/>confining it to cases in which the Śūdra was guilty of some sin.
[Page2-390+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>At the sacrifice itself the Śūdra could not be present in the
<div n="lb"/>{%śālā,%} ‘hall’; he is definitely classed in the Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>máṇa<sup>15</sup> and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>16</sup> as unfit for ‘sacrifice’
<div n="lb"/>({%ayajñiya%}); and declared in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>17</sup> not to be
<div n="lb"/>admitted to drink Soma. At the Pravargya (introductory
<div n="lb"/>Soma) rite the performer is not allowed to come in contact
<div n="lb"/>with a Śūdra,<sup>18</sup> who here, as in the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,<sup>17</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>reckoned as excluded from a share in the Soma-draught. On
<div n="lb"/>the other hand, the Śūdra is one of the victims at the Puruṣa-
<div n="lb"/>medha (‘human sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda,<sup>19</sup> and a fight
<div n="lb"/>between an Āryan and a Śūdra, in which, of course, the former
<div n="lb"/>wins, forms a part of the Mahāvrata rite, being perhaps a pre-
<div n="lb"/>cursor of the Indian drama.<sup>20</sup>
<div n="P"/>Other indications, however, exist, showing that it would be
<div n="lb"/>undesirable to ignore the real importance of the Śūdra, which
<div n="lb"/>again reminds us of the condition of the serf, who, though
<div n="lb"/>legally restrained, still gradually won his way to the rank of a
<div n="lb"/>free man. Rich Śūdras are mentioned in the early texts,<sup>21</sup> just
<div n="lb"/>as Śūdra {%gahapatis,%} ‘householders,’ occur in the Buddhist texts,
<div n="lb"/>and Śūdra kings in the legal literature.<sup>22</sup> Sin against Śūdra and
<div n="lb"/>Āryan is mentioned;<sup>23</sup> prayers for glory on behalf of Śūdras,
<div n="lb"/>as well as of the other castes<sup>24</sup> occur; and the desire to be dear
<div n="lb"/>to Śūdra as well as to Āryan is expressed.<sup>25</sup>
[Page2-391+ 71]
<div n="P"/>The Sūtras also, while they emphasize as general rules
<div n="lb"/>points earlier not insisted on, such as their inferiority in
<div n="lb"/>sitting, etc.,<sup>26</sup> their exclusion from the study of the Vedas,<sup>27</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the danger of contact with them<sup>28</sup> or their food,<sup>29</sup> still recog-
<div n="lb"/>nize that Śūdras can be merchants,<sup>30</sup> or even exercise any
<div n="lb"/>trade.<sup>31</sup>
<div n="P"/>Moreover, the Sūtras<sup>32</sup> permit the marriage of a Śūdrā
<div n="lb"/>woman with members of all castes. Though it was a reproach
<div n="lb"/>to {@Vatsa@}<sup>33</sup> and to {@Kavaṣa@}<sup>34</sup> that they were the sons of a Śūdrā
<div n="lb"/>and a Dāsī respectively, still the possibility of such a reproach
<div n="lb"/>shows that marriages of this kind did take place. Moreover,
<div n="lb"/>illicit unions of Ārya and Śūdrā, or Śūdra and Āryā, are
<div n="lb"/>referred to in the Saṃhitās of the Yajurveda.<sup>35</sup>
<div n="P"/>The origin of the term Śūdra is quite obscure, but Zimmer<sup>36</sup>
<div n="lb"/>points out that Ptolemy<sup>37</sup> mentions <lang n="greek"></lang> as a people, and he
<div n="lb"/>thinks that the Brāhui may be meant. Without laying any
<div n="lb"/>stress on this identification,<sup>38</sup> it is reasonable to accept the
[Page2-392+ 53]
<div n="lb"/>view<sup>39</sup> that the term was originally the name of a large tribe
<div n="lb"/>opposed to the Āryan invasion. See also {@Niṣāda.@}

<F>38) The Brāhui are now held not to be
<div n="lb"/>Dravidian ethnologically, but Turco-
<div n="lb"/>Iranian ({%Indian Empire,%} 1, 292, 310).
<div n="lb"/>It is suggested ({%ibid.,%} 1, 382) that they
<div n="lb"/>represent the original Dravidian type,
<div n="lb"/>which in India has been merged in the
<div n="lb"/>Muṇḍā type; but this suggestion is
<div n="lb"/>invalidated by the fact that the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>speaks of the Dasyus as {%anās,%} ‘nose-
<div n="lb"/>less’ ({%cf.%} {@Dasyu,@} 1, 347, n. 7). a term
<div n="lb"/>admirably applicable to Dravidians,
<div n="lb"/>but ludicrous as applied to the Turco-
<div n="lb"/>Iranian type. It is much more plausible
<div n="lb"/>to assume that the Brāhuis are a mixed
<div n="lb"/>race, which in course of time has lost
<div n="lb"/>most of its Dravidian features. On
<div n="lb"/>the relation of Dravidians and speakers
<div n="lb"/>of Muṇḍā tongues, the Vedic texts
<div n="lb"/>throw no light.</F>

<L>3355<pc>2-397<k1>SmaSAna<k2>SmaSAna

<div n="lb"/>a funeral mound like a fire-altar is prescribed. The Easterners
<div n="lb"/>({%Prācyāḥ%}) made their mounds round.

<L>3368<pc>2-400<k1>SyAvASva<k2>SyAvASva
{@Śyāvāśva@}¦ is the name of a man mentioned several times in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> The Anukramaṇī (Index) assigns to him a
<div n="lb"/>series of hymns in the fifth, eight, and ninth books.<sup>2</sup> In one
<div n="lb"/>of the hymns<sup>3</sup> Śyāvāśva mentions, apparently as his patrons,
<div n="lb"/>{@Taranta@} (a son of {@Vidadaśva@}) and {@Purumīlha,@} as well as
<div n="lb"/>{@Rathavīti.@} On this hymn is based a legend found in the
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhaddevatā,<sup>4</sup> that he was the son of {@Arcanānas,@} who was
<div n="lb"/>sacrificing for Rathavīti Dālbhya. The father was anxious to
<div n="lb"/>obtain the king's daughter for his son in marriage; but though
<div n="lb"/>the father was willing, his wife insisted on her son-in-law being
<div n="lb"/>a Ṛṣi. The father and son, repulsed, were returning home,
<div n="lb"/>when they met on the way Taranta and Purumīḍha, former
<div n="lb"/>patrons of the father. These showed him respect, while
<div n="lb"/>Taranta's wife, Śaśīyasī, presented Śyāvāśva with much wealth.
<div n="lb"/>The son was then fortunate enough to meet the Maruts in the
<div n="lb"/>forest, and praised them, thus becoming a seer. As a result
<div n="lb"/>the king himself ultimately offered his daughter to Śyāvāśva.
<div n="lb"/>Sieg<sup>5</sup> seeks to show that this legend is presupposed in the Rigveda;
<div n="lb"/>but it is difficult to accept this view, since the references in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda are very obscure, and Śaśīyasī is probably no more
<div n="lb"/>than an epithet.<sup>6</sup> That there is some Itihāsa at the back of the
<div n="lb"/>hymn is clear: what it is can hardly now be determined.
<div n="P"/>Śyāvāśva's obtaining gifts from Vaidadaśvi is referred to also
<div n="lb"/>in the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra.<sup>7</sup> His name occurs in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>8</sup> in two lists of persons, of which the former
<div n="lb"/>includes Purumīḍha, the latter also Arcanānas and Atri. A
<div n="lb"/>Sāman is ascribed to him in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>9</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>he is perhaps referred to in the Taittirīya Āraṇyaka.<sup>10</sup> In the
[Page2-401+ 58]
<div n="lb"/>Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>11</sup> he
<div n="lb"/>is styled Ārcanānasa, ‘son of Arcanānas,’ and later<sup>12</sup> he is called
<div n="lb"/>Ātreya, ‘descendant of Atri.’
<F>1) v. 52, 1; 61, 5. 9 (Syāva, a short
<div n="lb"/>form of the name, is here used); 81, 5;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 35, 19; 36, 7; 37, 7; 38, 8.</F>
<F>2) v. 52-61; 81; 82; viii. 35-38; ix. 32.</F>
<F>3) v. 61.</F>
<F>4) v. 49 {%et seq.%} See also Ṣaḍguruśiṣya
<div n="lb"/>on Anukramaṇī to Rv. v. 61 (ed. Mac-
<div n="lb"/>donell, p. 117 {%et seq.%}); Sāyaṇa on Rv.

<div n="lb"/>{%vedischen Ritual,%} 27, n. 4, bases on this
<div n="lb"/>an improbable conjecture that he was

<L>3369<pc>2-401<k1>Syena<k2>Syena
{@Śyena@}¦ is the name in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> of a strong bird of prey,
<div n="lb"/>most probably the ‘eagle’; later<sup>2</sup> (as in post-Vedic Sanskrit)
<div n="lb"/>it seems to mean the ‘falcon’ or ‘hawk.’ It is the swiftest of
<div n="lb"/>birds,<sup>3</sup> and a source of terror to smaller birds.<sup>4</sup> It is the
<div n="lb"/>strongest of birds,<sup>5</sup> and even attacks herds.<sup>6</sup> It watches over
<div n="lb"/>men ({%nṛ-cakṣas%}),<sup>7</sup> a reference, no doubt, to its lofty flight in air.
<div n="lb"/>It brings the Soma from heaven.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) i. 32, 14; 33, 2; 118, 11; 163, 1;
<div n="lb"/>165, 2, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. iii. 3, 4; vii. 41, 2; xi. 9, 9, etc.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 7, 1; v. 4,
<div n="lb"/>11, 1; Ṣaḍviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, iii. 8.</F>
<F>4) Rv. ii. 42, 2; Av. v. 21, 6.</F>
<F>5) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 14.</F>
<F>6) Rv. iv. 38, 5. This corresponds
<div n="lb"/>well enough with the eagle's known
<div n="lb"/>habit of carrying off young lambs.</F>
<F>7) Av. vii. 41, 2.</F>
<F>8) See Bloomfield, {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%American Oriental Society,%} 16, 1-24, who
<div n="lb"/>cites all relevant passages.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 87,
<div n="lb"/>88, who points out that the epithet
<div n="lb"/>{%ṛjipya,%} ‘flying upwards,’ applied to the
<div n="lb"/>eagle, appears as an actual name of the
<div n="lb"/>eagle in Iranian.</F>

<L>3386<pc>2-403<k1>SrezWin<k2>SrezWin

<div n="lb"/>times.

<L>3394<pc>2-405<k1>Svan<k2>Svan
{@Śvan@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> is the word for ‘dog,’ the
<div n="lb"/>feminine being Śunī.<sup>3</sup> The dog was a tame animal,<sup>4</sup> and used
[Page2-406+ 55]
<div n="lb"/>to guard the house from thieves or other intruders.<sup>5</sup> He was
<div n="lb"/>also employed in hunting the boar ({%varāha-yu%}),<sup>6</sup> but was no
<div n="lb"/>match for the lion.<sup>7</sup> A hundred dogs are mentioned as a gift in
<div n="lb"/>a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in a Vālakhilya hymn.<sup>8</sup> Else-
<div n="lb"/>where the dog is regarded as unfit for sacrifice, as being
<div n="lb"/>unclean,<sup>9</sup> and is driven away from the sacrifice.<sup>10</sup> To eat dog's
<div n="lb"/>flesh was a last resort of despair and hunger.<sup>11</sup> The bones of
<div n="lb"/>the feast were given to the dog.<sup>12</sup> Saramā figures in legend
<div n="lb"/>as Indra's faithful dog<sup>13</sup> searching for the cows. Rudra is lord
<div n="lb"/>of dogs ({%śva-pati%}) in the Yajurveda;<sup>14</sup> the ‘dog-keeper’
<div n="lb"/>({%śvanin%}) is mentioned in the list of sacrificial victims at the
<div n="lb"/>Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the same Saṃhitā.<sup>15</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>four-eyed ({%catur-akṣa%}) dogs of certain texts<sup>16</sup> are, of course,

<L>3398<pc>2-407<k1>SvaSura<k2>SvaSura
{@Śvaśura@}¦ from the Rigveda onwards<sup>1</sup> denotes the ‘father-in-
<div n="lb"/>law’ of the wife; not till the Sūtra period does it include the
<div n="lb"/>‘father-in-law’ of the husband.<sup>2</sup> The daughter-in-law ({@Snuṣā@}),
<div n="lb"/>in the normal case when the father-in-law was the head of the
<div n="lb"/>family to which her husband belonged in fact as well as in age,
<div n="lb"/>was bound to pay him all respect.<sup>3</sup> When the old man had
<div n="lb"/>ceased to exercise control, she became mistress ({%samrājñī%})
<div n="lb"/>over him and his wife.<sup>4</sup> In the plural<sup>5</sup> the word denotes the
<div n="lb"/>‘parents-in-law.’
<F>1) x. 28, 1; 85, 46; 95, 4; Av. viii. 6,
<div n="lb"/>24; xiv. 2, 26, etc.</F>
<F>2) Pāraskara Gṛhya Sūtra, iii. 10, 46.</F>
<F>3) See Rv. x. 95, 4; Av. viii. 6, 24;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 2; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xii. 12 ({%Indische Studien,%} 5,
<div n="lb"/>260); Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 22, 7.
<div n="lb"/>So in Av. xiv. 2, 26, the daughter-in-law
<div n="lb"/>is to be ‘helpful’ to the father-in-law.</F>
<F>4) Rv. x. 85, 46. See Pati.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 95, 12; Av. xiv. 2, 27;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, {%loc. cit.%} Or it may
<div n="lb"/>be a plural {%majestatis,%} but not a sign

<div n="lb"/>{%Verwandtschaftsnamen,%} 515, 516.</F>

<L>3407<pc>2-409<k1>Svetaketu<k2>Svetaketu
{@Śveta-ketu@}¦ Aruṇeya<sup>1</sup> (‘descendant of {@Aruṇa@}’) or {@Auddālaki@}<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>(‘son of {@Uddālaka@}’) is mentioned repeatedly in the Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa and the Chāndogya Upaniṣad. In the Kauṣītaki
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad<sup>3</sup> he appears as Śvetaketu, son of {@Āruṇi,@} and as a
<div n="lb"/>{@Gautama.@} In the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> he is quoted as an
<div n="lb"/>authority on the vexed question of the duty of the {@Sadasya,@} or
<div n="lb"/>the seventeenth priest, at the ritual of the Kauṣītakins, to
<div n="lb"/>notify errors in the sacrifice; Āruṇi, his father, is also cited.
<div n="lb"/>He was a person of some originality, for he insisted on eating
<div n="lb"/>honey despite the general prohibition of the use of that
<div n="lb"/>delicacy by Brahmacārins or religious students.<sup>5</sup> He was a
<div n="lb"/>contemporary of, and was instructed by the {@Pañcāla@} king
<div n="lb"/>{@Pravāhaṇa Jaivala.@}<sup>6</sup> He was also a contemporary of {@Janaka,@}
<div n="lb"/>of {@Videha,@} and figured among the Brahmin disputants at his
<div n="lb"/>court.<sup>7</sup> A story is told of him in the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra:<sup>8</sup> {@Jala Jātūkarṇya@} was lucky enough to become the
<div n="lb"/>Purohita of three peoples or kings, of {@Kāśi, Kosala,@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Videha.@} Seeing this, Śvetaketu felt annoyed and reproached
<div n="lb"/>his father with his excessive devotion to sacrifice, which merely
<div n="lb"/>enriched and glorified others, not himself. His father replied,
<div n="lb"/>forbidding him to speak thus: he had learned the true method
<div n="lb"/>of sacrificing, and his ambition in life had been to discuss it
<div n="lb"/>with every Brahmin.
<div n="P"/>All the references to Śvetaketu belong to the latest period of
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature. It is, therefore, not surprising that the Āpa-
<div n="lb"/>stamba Dharma Sūtra<sup>9</sup> should refer to him as an Avara, or
[Page2-410+ 47]
<div n="lb"/>person of later days, who still became a Ṛṣi by special merit.
<div n="lb"/>His date, however, must not be fixed too low, because the
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa in which he plays so marked a part is
<div n="lb"/>certainly earlier than Pāṇini, and was apparently even in that
<div n="lb"/>grammarian's time believed to be an ancient work: hence
<div n="lb"/>500 B.C. is probably rather too late than too early a period for
<div n="lb"/>Śvetaketu as a rough approximation to a date.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 2, 7, 12;
<div n="lb"/>5, 4, 18; 6, 2, 1; xii. 2, 1, 9; Bṛhad-
<div n="lb"/>āraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iii. 7, 1; vi. 1, 1
<div n="lb"/>(Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1 Kāṇva); Chān-
<div n="lb"/>dogya Upaniṣad, v. 3, 1; vi. 1, 1; 8, 1.</F>
<F>2) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 3, 13;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 2, 5, 14.</F>
<F>3) i. 1.</F>
<F>4) xxvi. 4.</F>
<F>5) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 5, 4, 18.</F>
<F>6) Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, vi. 1, 1
<div n="lb"/>(Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1 Kāṇva); Chān-
<div n="lb"/>dogya Upaniṣad, v. 3, 1.</F>
<F>7) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 6, 2, 1
<div n="lb"/>(it is to be noted that he came upon
<div n="lb"/>Janaka when travelling about with some
<div n="lb"/>other Brahmins: he was never settled
<div n="lb"/>in the Videha country, but was clearly
<div n="lb"/>a {@Kuru-Pañcāla,@} like his father);
<div n="lb"/>Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iii. 7, 1,
<div n="lb"/>where he shares the usual fate of
<div n="lb"/>defeat in argument by Yājñavalkya.</F>
<F>8) xvi. 27, 6 {%et seq.%} The exact sense
<div n="lb"/>of {%kṛtsnake brahmabandhau vyajijñāsiṣi%} is
<div n="lb"/>not quite certain. But Āruṇi seems to
<div n="lb"/>assert the love of knowledge, not of
<div n="lb"/>material advantages accruing to the
<div n="lb"/>Purohita, to have been his concern

<div n="lb"/>{%of the East,%} 2, xxxvii {%et seq.;%} Eggeling,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 12, xxxv {%et seq.;%}

<L>3414<pc>2-411<k1>saMvatsara<k2>saMvatsara
{@Saṃ-vatsara,@}¦ ‘year,’ is repeatedly mentioned from the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda onwards.<sup>1</sup>
<div n="P"/>It duration was, according to the concurrent evidence of
<div n="lb"/>the Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas, 360 days, divided into 12 months,
<div n="lb"/>being, no doubt, roughly a lunar synodic year, which, however,
<div n="lb"/>it exceeded in length by 6 days.<sup>2</sup> As a solar year it appears
<div n="lb"/>only in the Nidāna Sūtra<sup>3</sup> of the Sāmaveda, where the sun is
<div n="lb"/>stated to spend 13(1/3) days in each of the 27 Nakṣatras.
[Page2-412+ 53]
<div n="P"/>The year being obviously out of harmony with the solar year
<div n="lb"/>(whether sidereal or tropical), efforts were certainly made to
<div n="lb"/>effect an assimilation of the natural and the accepted year. As
<div n="lb"/>has been seen (see {@Māsa@}), the evidence goes strongly to show
<div n="lb"/>that the intercalation was not an easy matter in the Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa period, though there are traces of what may be re-
<div n="lb"/>garded as a five-yearly or six-yearly intercalation. But there
<div n="lb"/>is no conclusive evidence that these periods were really
<div n="lb"/>observed.
<div n="P"/>Zimmer,<sup>4</sup> indeed, considers that the evidence required is
<div n="lb"/>afforded by the lists of the years, which are sometimes
<div n="lb"/>enumerated as five: Saṃvatsara, Parivatsara, Idāvatsara,
<div n="lb"/>Idvatsara, and Vatsara;<sup>5</sup> or Saṃvatsara, Parivatsara, Idāvat-
<div n="lb"/>sara, Iduvatsara, Vatsara;<sup>6</sup> or Saṃvatsara, Idāvatsara, Iduvat-
<div n="lb"/>sara, Idvatsara, Vatsara;<sup>7</sup> or Saṃvatsara, Parivatsara, Idāvat-
<div n="lb"/>sara, Anuvatsara, Udvatsara;<sup>8</sup> or Saṃvatsara, Parivatsara,
<div n="lb"/>Idāvatsara, Anuvatsara, Idvatsara.<sup>9</sup> But it must be noted not
<div n="lb"/>merely that the names vary considerably, but that four only are
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in some places,<sup>10</sup> in others<sup>11</sup> three, in others<sup>12</sup> two,
<div n="lb"/>and in yet others<sup>13</sup> six. Moreover, in none of these enumera-
<div n="lb"/>tions is there any reference to the names being connected with
<div n="lb"/>a system of intercalation. It is most probable that here we
<div n="lb"/>have no more that a mere series of priestly variations of
<div n="lb"/>Vatsara, based on the older and more genuine Saṃvatsara and
<div n="lb"/>Parivatsara as variants of the simple Vatsara, ‘year.’ The key
<div n="lb"/>to the invention of the series is probably to be found in
<div n="lb"/>passages like that of the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>14</sup> where the
<div n="lb"/>several {@Cāturmāsya@} (‘four-monthly’) sacrifices are equated
[Page2-413+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>with the different years.<sup>15</sup> Particularly unjustifiable is the
<div n="lb"/>attempt of Zimmer to see in the two-year series a series of two
<div n="lb"/>years of 354 days each, with an intercalary month in the
<div n="lb"/>second; for the year of 354 days, as such, is not known to have
<div n="lb"/>existed before the Sūtra period.
<div n="P"/>Zimmer<sup>16</sup> also finds an attempt at intercalation in the
<div n="lb"/>famous 12 days in which the Ṛbhus are said to have slept in
<div n="lb"/>the house of Agohya.<sup>17</sup> He thinks that they represent twelve
<div n="lb"/>days added at the winter solstice to equate the lunar year of
<div n="lb"/>354 days and the solar year of 366 days; and from the rever-
<div n="lb"/>ence paid in German antiquity to the ‘12 nights,’ he infers
<div n="lb"/>that this mode of intercalation is Indo-Germanic.<sup>18</sup> There can
<div n="lb"/>be little doubt that this view is wrong, and that the 12 days are
<div n="lb"/>merely the ‘reflexion of the year’ ({%saṃvatsarasya pratimā%})<sup>19</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>the sense that they represent the twelve months, and have no
<div n="lb"/>relation to chronology at all.
<div n="P"/>A reference to the use of Saṃvatsara alone as the fifth year
<div n="lb"/>of the cycle is seen by Shamasastry<sup>20</sup> in the peculiar dating of
<div n="lb"/>certain notices in the Baudhāyana Śrauta Sūtra,<sup>21</sup> but this view
<div n="lb"/>is improbable.<sup>22</sup>

<L>3433<pc>2-416<k1>saMgrAma<k2>saMgrAma
{@Saṃ-grāma@}¦ denotes primarily, it seems, ‘assembly’ either in
<div n="lb"/>peace<sup>1</sup> or in war,<sup>2</sup> when it means an ‘armed band.’ Its normal
<div n="lb"/>sense in the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> and later<sup>4</sup> is ‘war,’ ‘battle.’
[Page2-417+ 50]
<div n="P"/>Little is known of Vedic warfare, but it seems to have been
<div n="lb"/>simple. A body of foot soldiers with charioteers composed
<div n="lb"/>every army, the two going together,<sup>5</sup> and the foot soldiers being
<div n="lb"/>often overthrown by the charioteers,<sup>6</sup> who were doubtless
<div n="lb"/>the Kṣatriyas and their foremost retainers. Probably the
<div n="lb"/>foot soldiers bore little armour, and used only the bow for
<div n="lb"/>offence, as is suggested by the account that Herodotus gives of
<div n="lb"/>the Indian contingent of the army with which Xerxes invaded
<div n="lb"/>Greece.<sup>7</sup> The nobles, on the other hand, may have had cuirass
<div n="lb"/>({@Varman@}), helmet ({@Śiprā@}), and hand-guard ({@Hastaghna@}) as a
<div n="lb"/>protection from the friction of the bowstring. On the car was
<div n="lb"/>the charioteer, and on his left the warrior ({@Sārathi, Savyaṣṭhā@}).
<div n="lb"/>Riding is never mentioned in war,<sup>8</sup> and would hardly have
<div n="lb"/>been suited to Vedic ideas, for the warrior mainly depended on
<div n="lb"/>his bow, which he could not have used effectively from horse-
<div n="lb"/>back. The offensive weapon ({@Āyudha@}) was practically the
<div n="lb"/>bow; spear and sword and axe were very seldom used.
<div n="P"/>Whether there was a strict tribal organization of the host,
<div n="lb"/>such as is once alluded to in the Homeric poems,<sup>9</sup> and is also
<div n="lb"/>recognized in Germany by Tacitus,<sup>10</sup> is uncertain ({%cf.%} {@Vrāta@}),
<div n="lb"/>but in the Epic relations ({@Jñāti@}) fight together,<sup>11</sup> and this rule,
<div n="lb"/>no doubt, applied more or less in Vedic times also.
<div n="P"/>Cities were besieged and invested ({%upa-sad, pra-bhid%}),<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>probably as a rule by blockade, since the ineffective means of
<div n="lb"/>assault of the time would have rendered storming difficult and
<div n="lb"/>expensive. Hillebrandt<sup>13</sup> thinks that the {%pur cariṣṇū%} of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>14</sup> was a kind of chariot; it may — like the Trojan
<div n="lb"/>horse — have been an Indian anticipation of the Roman means
<div n="lb"/>of assaulting a town.
<div n="P"/>Besides ordinary wars of defence and conquest, raids into
[Page2-418+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>neighbouring territory seem to have been frequent and normal,<sup>15</sup>
<div n="lb"/>no doubt because of the booty ({@Udāja, Nirāja@}) which was to be
<div n="lb"/>won, and which the king had to share with the people.
<div n="P"/>Banners ({@Dhvaja@}) were borne in war, and musical instru-
<div n="lb"/>ments ({@Dundubhi, Bakura@})<sup>16</sup> were used by the combatants.
<F>1) Av. xii. 1, 56, where it is joined
<div n="lb"/>with {@Samiti.@} We might see in this
<div n="lb"/>passage, and that cited in n. 2, the
<div n="lb"/>technical name of the village assembly
<div n="lb"/>as opposed to the larger assemblies of
<div n="lb"/>the people, but there is no good warrant
<div n="lb"/>for so doing.</F>
<F>2) Av. iv. 24, 7, where {%saṃgrāmān%} is
<div n="lb"/>read; but the parallel passages (Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 15, 2; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iii. 16, 5) have {%saṃgrāmani.%}</F>
<F>3) v. 21, 7; xi. 9, 26.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Samhitā, ii. 1, 3, 1; 8, 4,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>5) Rv. ii. 12, 8.</F>
<F>6) Av. vii. 62, 1. {%Cf.%} {@Muṣṭihan@}</F>
<F>7) Herodotus, vii. 65.</F>
<F>8) Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 296,
<div n="lb"/>where he admits riding to be men-
<div n="lb"/>tioned elsewhere; Whitney, {%Journal%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the American Oriental Society,%} 3,
<div n="lb"/>312.</F>
<F>9) {%Ibid,%} ii. 362.</F>
<F>10) {%Germania,%} 7.</F>
<F>11) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 193.</F>
<F>12) {%Cf.%} Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 3, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 4, 3-5;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, i. 23, 2, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>Gopatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 2, 7; Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 300, n.</F>
<F>13) {%Op. cit.%} 3, 289, n.</F>
<F>14) viii. 1, 2-8, where it is attributed
<div n="lb"/>to the demon Śuṣṇa.</F>

<div n="lb"/>4, 1 (of the model Kuru kings).</F>
<F>16) So, later, Arrian, {%Indica,%} vii. 9.
<div n="lb"/>The shouts of either side are shown

<div n="lb"/>mean the ‘shouting host.’ {%Cf.%} also

<L>3436<pc>2-418<k1>sajAta<k2>sajAta
{@Sa-jāta@}¦ (‘born together’) is found once in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>very often later.<sup>2</sup> The word must clearly mean a ‘relative,’ and
<div n="lb"/>then more widely a man of the same position or rank, but the
<div n="lb"/>senses cannot be distinguished, so much do they merge into
<div n="lb"/>each other. The Sajātas of a king are of course princes;<sup>3</sup> of an
[Page2-419+ 42]
<div n="lb"/>ordinary man, Vaiśyas;<sup>4</sup> of a military man, Kṣatriyas. But
<div n="lb"/>there is no clear reference to caste as in the later Sajāti<sup>5</sup> (‘man
<div n="lb"/>of the same caste’). The disputes of Sajātas were notorious.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) i. 109, 1.</F>
<F>2) Av. i. 9, 3; 19, 3; ii. 6, 4; iii. 3, 6;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 5, 2; 73, 1; xi. 1, 6, 7; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3, 2; 2, 1, 2; 6, 9, 7;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 8; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xi. 12, 13; xii. 1; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, v. 23; x. 29; xxvii. 5, and
<div n="lb"/>often in the Brāhmaṇas.</F>
<F>3) Av. iii. 3, 4. 6; Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 17, 188.</F>
<F>4) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 4, 4, 19
<div n="lb"/>(the Sajātas of a {@Grāmaṇī@}).</F>
<F>5) Manu, ix. 87; x. 41, etc. The
<div n="lb"/>abstract {%sajātya%} (‘kinship’) is found in
<div n="lb"/>Rv. ii. 1, 5; iii. 54, 16; viii. 18, 19;
<div n="lb"/>20, 21; 27, 10; x. 64, 13; but even it
<div n="lb"/>has no definite caste reference.</F>
<F>6) {%Cf.%} Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 7,
<div n="lb"/>12, 2.</F>

<L>3480<pc>2-426<k1>saBA<k2>saBA
{@Sabhā@}¦ is the name of an ‘assembly’ of the Vedic Indians as
<div n="lb"/>well as of the ‘hall’ where they met in assembly. It is often
<div n="lb"/>mentioned in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later,<sup>2</sup> but its exact character is
<div n="lb"/>not certain. The hall was clearly used for dicing,<sup>3</sup> presumably
<div n="lb"/>when the assembly was not transacting public business: a
<div n="lb"/>dicer is called {%sabhā-sthāṇu,%} ‘pillar of the assembly hall,’ doubt-
<div n="lb"/>less because of his constant presence there.<sup>4</sup> The hall also
<div n="lb"/>served, like the Homeric <lang n="greek"></lang>, as a meeting-place for social
<div n="lb"/>intercourse and general conversation about cows and so forth,<sup>5</sup>
<div n="lb"/>possibly for debates and verbal contests.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>According to Ludwig,<sup>7</sup> the Sabhā was an assembly not of all
<div n="lb"/>the people, but of the Brahmins and {@Maghavans@} (‘rich
<div n="lb"/>patrons’). This view can be supported by the expressions
[Page2-427+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>{%sabheya,%} ‘worthy of the assembly,’ applied to a Brahmin,<sup>8</sup> {%rayiḥ%}
<div n="lb"/>{%sabhāvān,%} ‘wealth fitting for the assembly,’<sup>9</sup> and so on. But
<div n="lb"/>Bloomfield<sup>10</sup> plausibly sees in these passages a domestic use of
<div n="lb"/>Sabhā, which is recognized by the St. Petersburg Dictionary
<div n="lb"/>in several passages<sup>11</sup> as relating to a house, not to the assembly
<div n="lb"/>at all. Zimmer<sup>12</sup> is satisfied that the Sabhā was the meeting-
<div n="lb"/>place of the village council, presided over by the {@Grāmaṇī.@}
<div n="lb"/>But of this there is no trace whatever. Hillebrandt<sup>13</sup> seems
<div n="lb"/>right in maintaining that the Sabhā and the {@Samiti@} cannot be
<div n="lb"/>distinguished, and that the reference to well-born ({%su-jāta%})<sup>14</sup>
<div n="lb"/>men being there in session is to the Āryan as opposed to the
<div n="lb"/>Dāsa or Śūdra, not to one class of Āryan as opposed to the
<div n="lb"/>other. Hillebrandt also sees in Agni ‘of the hall’ ({%sabhya%}) a
<div n="lb"/>trace of the fire used in sacrifice on behalf of the assembly
<div n="lb"/>when it met.<sup>15</sup>
<div n="P"/>Women did not go to the Sabhā,<sup>16</sup> for they were, of course,
<div n="lb"/>excluded from political activity. For the Sabhā as a court-
<div n="lb"/>house, {%cf.%} {@Grāmyavādin.@} There is not a single notice of the
<div n="lb"/>work done by the Sabhā.
<F>1) vi. 28, 6; viii. 4, 9; x. 34, 6. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>{%sabhā-saha,%} ‘eminent in the assembly,’
<div n="lb"/>x. 71, 10.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 31, 6; vii. 12, 1, 2; viii. 10, 5;
<div n="lb"/>xii. 1, 56; xix. 55, 6; Taittirīya Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, i. 7, 6, 7; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iv. 7, 4; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45;
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 24; xx. 17; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>i. 1, 10, 6; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 3,
<div n="lb"/>2, 3; v. 3, 1, 10; Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>vii. 9, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 34, 6; Av. v. 31, 6; xii. 3, 46
<div n="lb"/>(here {%dyūta%} is used in place of Sabhā).</F>
<F>4) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 18; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 16, 1, with
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa's note. Zimmer, {%Altindisches%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Leben,%} 172, inclines to see in the formula
<div n="lb"/>(Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45; xx. 17;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 8, 3, 1; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ix. 4; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>i. 10, 2) ‘what sin we have committed
<div n="lb"/>in the village, the jungle, the Sabhā’
<div n="lb"/>a reference to attacks on the great
<div n="lb"/>(Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 45), or partiality in deciding dis-
<div n="lb"/>putes (Mahīdhara, {%ibid.,%} xx. 17). But
<div n="lb"/>it may refer to gambling or other non-
<div n="lb"/>political activity, as Eggeling, {%Sacred%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Books of the East,%} 12, 398, takes it,
<div n="lb"/>though he renders it differently, {%ibid.,%}
<div n="lb"/>44, 265.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vi. 28, 6. {%Cf.%} viii. 4, 9. So
<div n="lb"/>in Av. vii. 12, 2, the assembly is hailed
<div n="lb"/>as {%nariṣṭā,%} ‘merriment.’ But the same
<div n="lb"/>hymn (vii. 12, 3) contains a clear refer-
<div n="lb"/>ence to serious speech in the Sabhā.

<div n="lb"/>work and amusement, {%cf.%} Tacitus,
<div n="lb"/>{%Germania,%} 22.</F>
<F>6) So Zimmer, {%op. cit.,%} 174, takes

<F>10) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}

<F>11) Av. viii. 10, 5 (where the sense

<L>3481<pc>2-427<k1>saBAcara<k2>saBAcara
{@Sabhā-cara@}¦ is one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha
<div n="lb"/>(‘human sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda.<sup>1</sup> The St. Petersburg
[Page2-428+ 33]
<div n="lb"/>Dictionary thinks it is an adjective equivalent in sense to
<div n="lb"/>{%sabhā-ga,%}’ ‘going to the assembly.’ As he is dedicated to
<div n="lb"/>Dharma, ‘Justice,’ it is difficult not to see in him a member of
<div n="lb"/>the Sabhā as a law court, perhaps as one of those who sit
<div n="lb"/>to decide cases: there is nothing to show whether the whole
<div n="lb"/>assembly did so, or only a chosen body. The special use of
<div n="lb"/>Sabhācara suggests the latter alternative. See also {@Sabhāsad.@}
<F>1) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 6; Tait-
<div n="lb"/>tirīya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 2, 1 with
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa's note. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Streifen,%} 1, 77, n. 1.</F>

<L>3485<pc>2-428<k1>saBAsad<k2>saBAsad
{@Sabhā-sad,@}¦ ‘sitter in the assembly,’ is probably a technical
<div n="lb"/>description of the assessors who decided legal cases in the
<div n="lb"/>assembly ({%cf.%} {@Sabhācara@}). The term, which is found in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda<sup>1</sup> and later,<sup>2</sup> cannot well merely denote any member
<div n="lb"/>of the assembly. It is also possible that the Sabhāsads, perhaps
<div n="lb"/>the heads of families, were expected to be present at the Sabhā
<div n="lb"/>oftener than the ordinary man: the meetings of the assembly
<div n="lb"/>for justice may have been more frequent than for general discus-
<div n="lb"/>sion and decision.
<F>1) iii. 29, 1 (of Yama); vii. 12, 2;
<div n="lb"/>xix. 55, 6.</F>

<L>3489<pc>2-429<k1>samana<k2>samana
{@Samana@}¦ is a word of somewhat doubtful sense in the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda. Roth<sup>1</sup> renders it either ‘battle’<sup>2</sup> or ‘festival.’<sup>3</sup> Pischel<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thinks that it was a general popular festivity to which women
<div n="lb"/>went to enjoy themselves,<sup>5</sup> poets to win fame,<sup>6</sup> bowmen to gain
<div n="lb"/>prizes at archery,<sup>7</sup> horses to run races;<sup>8</sup> and which lasted until
<div n="lb"/>morning<sup>9</sup> or until a conflagration, caused by the fires kept
<div n="lb"/>burning all night, scattered the celebrators.<sup>10</sup> Young women,<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>elderly women,<sup>12</sup> sought there to find a husband, and
<div n="lb"/>courtezans to make profit of the occasion.<sup>13</sup>
<F>1) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>2) Rv. vi. 75, 3. 5; ix. 96, 9; x. 143, 4;
<div n="lb"/>Av. vi. 92, 2; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>ix. 9.</F>
<F>3) Rv. ii. 16, 7; vi. 60, 2; vii. 2, 5;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 12, 9; ix. 97, 47; x. 55, 5; 86, 10;
<div n="lb"/>Av. ii. 36, 1.</F>
<F>4) {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 314.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 124, 8 ({%cf.%} {@Vrā@}); iv. 58, 8;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 75, 4; vii. 2, 5; x. 86, 10; 168, 2.</F>
<F>6) Rv. ii. 16, 7; ix. 97, 47. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 2, 38.</F>
<F>7) Rv. vi. 75, 3. 5.</F>
<F>8) Rv. ix. 96, 9; Av. vi. 92, 2.</F>
<F>9) Rv. i. 48, 6, which Roth takes
<div n="lb"/>as referring to men going to busi-
<div n="lb"/>ness.</F>
<F>10) Rv. x. 69, 11. {%Cf.%} vii. 9, 4.</F>
<F>11) Av. ii. 36, 1.</F>
<F>12) Rv. vii. 2, 5.</F>
<F>13) Rv. iv. 58, 8, where, as in vi. 75, 4;
<div n="lb"/>x. 168, 2, Roth sees the sense of ‘em-
<div n="lb"/>brace.’ The parallel with the festivals
<div n="lb"/>of Greece, where only young girls were
<div n="lb"/>able freely to mix with strangers, and
<div n="lb"/>which afforded the basis of so many
<div n="lb"/>of the comedies of the later school, is
<div n="lb"/>striking ({%cf.%} Mahaffy, {%Greek Literature,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 2, 259 {%et seq.%}).
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Geldner, {%Rigveda, Glossar,%} 190.</F>

<L>3491<pc>2-429<k1>samA<k2>samA

<div n="lb"/>which may be seen in a few passages of the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup>
[Page2-430+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>Hence it also denotes more generally ‘season,’ a rare use.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>More commonly it is simply ‘year’;<sup>3</sup> but in one place the Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> interprets it in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>5</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>meaning ‘month,’ a doubtful sense.

<L>3495<pc>2-430<k1>samiti<k2>samiti
{@Sam-iti@}¦ denotes an ‘assembly’ of the Vedic tribe. It is
<div n="lb"/>already mentioned in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and often later,<sup>2</sup> sometimes
<div n="lb"/>in connexion with {@Sabhā.@}<sup>3</sup> Ludwig<sup>4</sup> considers that the Samiti
<div n="lb"/>included all the people, primarily the {%viśaḥ,%} ‘subjects,’ but also
<div n="lb"/>the {@Maghavans@} and Brahmins if they desired, though the
<div n="lb"/>Sabhā was their special assembly. This view is not probable,
<div n="lb"/>nor is that of Zimmer,<sup>5</sup> that the Sabhā was the village assembly.
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt appears to be right in holding that Samiti and
<div n="lb"/>Sabhā are much the same, the one being the assembly, the
<div n="lb"/>other primarily the place of assembly.<sup>6</sup>
[Page2-431+ 63]
<div n="P"/>The king went to the assembly<sup>7</sup> just as he went to the
<div n="lb"/>Sabhā. That he was elected there, as Zimmer<sup>8</sup> thinks, is as
<div n="lb"/>uncertain as whether he was elected at all (see {@Rājan@}). But
<div n="lb"/>there are clear signs that concord between king and assembly
<div n="lb"/>were essential for his prosperity.<sup>9</sup>
<div n="P"/>It is reasonable to assume that the business of the assembly
<div n="lb"/>was general deliberation on policy of all kinds, legislation so
<div n="lb"/>far as the Vedic Indian cared to legislate, and judicial work ({%cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>{@Sabhāsad@}). But of all these occupations there is, perhaps as a
<div n="lb"/>result of the nature of the texts, little or no evidence directly
<div n="lb"/>available.
<div n="P"/>The gods had a Samiti, hence called {%daivī,%} ‘divine,’<sup>10</sup> just as
<div n="lb"/>they had a Sabhā.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>The assembly disappears as an effective part of government
<div n="lb"/>in the Buddhist texts,<sup>12</sup> the Epic,<sup>13</sup> and the law-books.<sup>14</sup>
<F>1) i. 95, 8; ix. 92, 6; x. 97, 6; 166, 4;
<div n="lb"/>191, 3.</F>
<F>2) Av. v. 19, 15; vi. 88, 3; vii. 12, 1;
<div n="lb"/>xii. 1, 56, etc.</F>

<div n="lb"/>2. 3; viii. 10, 5. 6.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.%}</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 172 {%et seq.%}</F>

<F>7) Rv. ix. 92, 6; x. 97, 6 (where the
<div n="lb"/>reference is hardly to an oligarchy, as
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer, 176, 177, holds, but merely to
<div n="lb"/>the princes of the blood going to the
<div n="lb"/>assembly with the rest).</F>
<F>8) {%Op. cit.,%} 175, quoting Av. vi. 87, 88,
<div n="lb"/>with Rv. x. 173, and Av. v. 19, 15, with
<div n="lb"/>Av. iii. 4, 6.</F>
<F>9) Av. vi. 88, 3. Roth, St. Peters-
<div n="lb"/>burg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 2, takes Samiti

<div n="lb"/>the Parīsa.</F>
<F>13) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 148-152, who traces
<div n="lb"/>the decay of the old assembly through
<div n="lb"/>the aristocratic war council and the
<div n="lb"/>secret priestly conclave. It is, of course,
<div n="lb"/>very probable that at no time was the
<div n="lb"/>Samiti a place where any or much
<div n="lb"/>attention was paid to the views of the
<div n="lb"/>common man. Princes and great men
<div n="lb"/>spoke; the rest approved or disap-
<div n="lb"/>proved, as in Homeric times and in
<div n="lb"/>Germany ({%cf.%} Lang, {%Anthropology and%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the Classics,%} 51 {%et seq.;%} Tacitus, {%Germania,%}

<div n="lb"/>cussion and their criminal jurisdiction
<div n="lb"/>are mentioned).</F>

<div n="lb"/>10.</F>

<L>3497<pc>2-431<k1>samudra<k2>samudra
{@Sam-udra@}¦ (literally ‘gathering of waters’), ‘ocean,’ is a
<div n="lb"/>frequent word in the Rigveda and later. It is of importance in
[Page2-432+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>so far as it indicates that the Vedic Indians knew the sea.
<div n="lb"/>This is, indeed, denied by Vivien de Saint Martin,<sup>1</sup> but not
<div n="lb"/>only do Max Müller<sup>2</sup> and Lassen<sup>3</sup> assert it, but even Zimmer,<sup>4</sup>
<div n="lb"/>who is inclined to restrict their knowledge of the sea as far as
<div n="lb"/>possible, admits it in one passage of the Rigveda,<sup>5</sup> and of
<div n="lb"/>course later.<sup>6</sup> He points out that the ebb and flow of the sea
<div n="lb"/>are unknown, that the mouths of the Indus are never men-
<div n="lb"/>tioned, that fish is not a known diet in the Rigveda ({%cf.%} {@Matsya@}),
<div n="lb"/>and that in many places Samudra is metaphorically used, as of
<div n="lb"/>the two oceans,<sup>7</sup> the lower and the upper oceans,<sup>8</sup> etc. In
<div n="lb"/>other passages he thinks that Samudra denotes the river Indus
<div n="lb"/>when it receives all its Panjab tributaries.<sup>9</sup> It is probable that
<div n="lb"/>this is to circumscribe too narrowly the Vedic knowledge of the
<div n="lb"/>ocean, which was almost inevitable to people who knew the
<div n="lb"/>Indus. There are references to the treasures of the ocean,<sup>10</sup>
<div n="lb"/>perhaps pearls or the gains of trade,<sup>11</sup> and the story of {@Bhujyu@}
<div n="lb"/>seems to allude to marine navigation.
<div n="P"/>That there was any sea trade with Babylon in Vedic times
<div n="lb"/>cannot be proved: the stress Iaid<sup>12</sup> on the occurrence in the
<div n="lb"/>Hebrew Book of Kings<sup>13</sup> of {%qof%} and {%tukhiīm,%} ‘monkey’ ({%kapi%})
<div n="lb"/>and ‘peacock,’ is invalidated by the doubtful date of the Book
<div n="lb"/>of Kings. There is, besides, little reason to assume an early
<div n="lb"/>date for the trade that no doubt developed later, perhaps
<div n="lb"/>about 700 B.C.<sup>14</sup>
[Page2-433+ 52]
<div n="P"/>In the later texts Samudra repeatedly means the sea.<sup>15</sup>
<F>1) {%Étude sur la géographie du Véda,%} 62
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq. Cf.%} Wilson, {%Rigveda,%} 1, xii.</F>
<F>2) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 61
<div n="lb"/>{%et seq.,%} quoting Rv. i. 71, 7; 190, 7;
<div n="lb"/>v. 78, 8; vii. 49, 2; 95, 2; x. 58.</F>
<F>3) {%Indische Alterthumskunde,%} 1^2, 883.</F>
<F>4) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 22 {%et seq. Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Literature,%} 143, 144.</F>
<F>5) vii. 95, 2.</F>
<F>6) Av. iv. 10, 4 (pearl shell); vi. 105, 3
<div n="lb"/>(the outflow, {%vi-kṣara,%} of the ocean);
<div n="lb"/>xix. 38, 2; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 4,
<div n="lb"/>13, 1, etc.</F>
<F>7) Rv. x. 136, 5. {%Cf.%} Av. xi. 5, 6.</F>
<F>8) Rv. vii. 6, 7; x. 98, 5.</F>
<F>9) See, {%e.g.,%} Rv. i. 71, 7; iii. 36, 7;
<div n="lb"/>46, 4; v. 85, 6; vi. 36, 3; vii. 95, 2;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 16, 2; 44, 25; ix. 88, 6; 107, 9;
<div n="lb"/>108, 16 (where reference is made to
<div n="lb"/>streams); or Rv. i. 163, 1; iv. 21, 3;
<div n="lb"/>v. 55, 5; viii. 6, 29, where land and
<div n="lb"/>Samudra are contrasted.</F>

<div n="lb"/>and the general parallelism of the
<div n="lb"/>Dioscuri and the Aśvins.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%ture,%} 3.</F>

<div n="lb"/>{%Asiatic Society,%} 1898, 241-288; Bühler,
<div n="lb"/>{%Indische Studien,%} 3, 79 {%et seq.; Indisehe%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Palœographie,%} 17-19, who much exag-
<div n="lb"/>gerates the antiquity of the traffic;
<div n="lb"/>Vincent Smith, {%Early History of India,%}
<div n="lb"/>25, n.</F>

<div n="lb"/>vii. 5, 1, 2. It is described as unfailing
<div n="lb"/>in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, v. 16, 7 ({%cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>iii. 39, 7); it encircles the earth, {%ibid.,%}

<div n="lb"/>oceans in Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, i. 6, 3,

<L>3498<pc>2-433<k1>samrAj<k2>samrAj
{@Samrāj@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> means ‘superior ruler,
<div n="lb"/>‘sovereign,’ as expressing a greater degree of power than ‘king’
<div n="lb"/>({@Rājan@}). In the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>3</sup> in accordance with its
<div n="lb"/>curious theory of the {@Vājapeya@} and {@Rājasūya,@} the Samrāj is
<div n="lb"/>asserted to be a higher authority than a king, and to have
<div n="lb"/>become one by the sacrifice of the Vājapeya. There is, how-
<div n="lb"/>ever, no trace of the use of the word as ‘emperor’ in the sense
<div n="lb"/>of an ‘overlord of kings,’ probably because political conditions
<div n="lb"/>furnished no example of such a status, as for instance was
<div n="lb"/>attained in the third century B.C. by Aśoka. At the same time
<div n="lb"/>Samrāj denotes an important king like {@Janaka@} of {@Videha.@}<sup>4</sup> It
<div n="lb"/>is applied in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>5</sup> as the title of the eastern
<div n="lb"/>kings. {%Cf.%} {@Rājya.@}
<F>1) iii. 55, 7; 56, 5; iv. 21, 1; vi. 27, 8;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 19, 32.</F>
<F>2) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 32; xiii. 35;
<div n="lb"/>xx. 5, etc.</F>
<F>3) v. 1, 1, 13. {%Cf.%} xii. 8, 3, 4;
<div n="lb"/>xiv. 1, 3, 8.</F>
<F>4) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xi. 3, 2, 1. 6;
<div n="lb"/>2, 2, 3; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad, iv. 1,
<div n="lb"/>1; 3, 1. {%Cf.%} Weber, {%Über den Vājapeya,%} 8.</F>
<F>5) viii. 14, 2. 3. The other names are
<div n="lb"/>given as follows: For the northerners
<div n="lb"/>it is Virāj: for the southerners, Svarāj;
<div n="lb"/>for the Satvants, Bhoja: for the middle
<div n="lb"/>people (Kuru-Pañcāla, Vaśa, and Uśī-
<div n="lb"/>nara), Rājan simply. This is probably
<div n="lb"/>a sound tradition.</F>

<L>3500<pc>2-433<k1>sarayu<k2>sarayu
{@Sarayu@}¦ is mentioned thrice in the Rigveda as the name of
<div n="lb"/>river. {@Citraratha@} and Arṇa are said to have been defeated
<div n="lb"/>apparently by the {@Turvaśas@} and {@Yadus@} who crossed the
[Page2-434+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>Sarayu.<sup>1</sup> Sarayu appears in one passage with {@Sarasvatī@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Sindhu,@}<sup>2</sup> and in another with {@Rasā, Anitabhā,@} and {@Kubha.@}<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Later, in the post-Vedic period, Sarayū, rarely Sarayu, is the
<div n="lb"/>name of a river in Oudh, the modern Sarjū.<sup>4</sup> Zimmer<sup>5</sup> regards
<div n="lb"/>this as the river meant in all the Vedic passages, seeing in the
<div n="lb"/>last,<sup>3</sup> which may be used as an argument for locating the
<div n="lb"/>Sarayu in the Panjab, a reference to the north-east monsoon as
<div n="lb"/>well as to the usual monsoon from the west. Hopkins<sup>6</sup> thinks
<div n="lb"/>that the Sarayu is to be found in the west, and Ludwig<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>identifies it with the Kurum ({@Krumu@}). Vivien de St. Martin
<div n="lb"/>considered it to be probably identical with the united course of
<div n="lb"/>the {@Śutudrī@} (Sutlej) and {@Vipāś@} (Beas).
<F>1) iv. 30, 18. This passage gives no
<div n="lb"/>help, because the possibility is open
<div n="lb"/>either to suppose that the Turvaśa,
<div n="lb"/>Yadu are not mentioned as defeating
<div n="lb"/>the Āryans Citraratha and Arṇa; or,
<div n="lb"/>if they are, to suppose that they may
<div n="lb"/>have come east against the two.</F>
<F>2) x. 64, 9.</F>
<F>3) v. 53, 9.</F>
<F>4) This is a tributary joining the
<div n="lb"/>Gogrā, the great river of Oudh, on
<div n="lb"/>the left of its upper course. The name
<div n="lb"/>Sarjū is also applied to the Gogrā itself
<div n="lb"/>below {@Bahrāmghāt.@} A branch of the
<div n="lb"/>Lower Gogrā, given off on the right,
<div n="lb"/>flowing in an old bed of the Gogrā,
<div n="lb"/>and falling into the Ganges after passing
<div n="lb"/>Balliā, is called the Chhotī (Lesser)
<div n="lb"/>Sarjū. {%Cf. Imperial Gazetteer of India,%}
<div n="lb"/>22, 109; 12, 302 (Gogrā); 23, 418
<div n="lb"/>(Eastern Tons); 26, Plate 31.</F>
<F>5) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 17, 45. {%Cf.%} Muir,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sanskrit Texts,%} 2^2, xxv; Max Müller,
<div n="lb"/>{%Sacred Books of the East,%} 32, 323.</F>
<F>3) v. 53, 9.</F>
<F>6) {%Religions of India,%} 34.</F>
<F>7) Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 280.</F>

<L>3502<pc>2-434<k1>sarasvatI<k2>sarasvatI
{@Sarasvatī@}¦<sup>1</sup> is the name of a river frequently mentioned in
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda and later. In many passages<sup>2</sup> of the later texts it
<div n="lb"/>is certain the river meant is the modern Sarasvatī, which loses
[Page2-435+ 70]
<div n="lb"/>itself in the sands of Patiala (see {@Vinaśana@}). Even Roth<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>admits that this river is intended in some passages of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda. With the {@Dṛṣadvatī@}<sup>4</sup> it formed the western boundary
<div n="lb"/>of Brahmāvarta (see {@Madhyadeśa@}). It is the holy stream of
<div n="lb"/>early Vedic India. The Sūtras<sup>5</sup> mention sacrifices held on its
<div n="lb"/>banks as of great importance and sanctity.
<div n="P"/>In many other passages of the Rigveda,<sup>6</sup> and even later,<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>Roth held that another river, the {@Sindhu@} (Indus), was really
<div n="lb"/>meant: only thus could it be explained why the Sarasvatī is
<div n="lb"/>called the ‘foremost of rivers’ ({%nadītamā%}),<sup>8</sup> is said to go to the
<div n="lb"/>ocean,<sup>9</sup> and is referred to as a large river, on the banks of which
<div n="lb"/>many kings,<sup>10</sup> and, indeed, the five tribes, were located.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>This view is accepted by Zimmer<sup>12</sup> and others.<sup>13</sup>
<div n="P"/>On the other hand, Lassen<sup>14</sup> and Max Müller<sup>15</sup> maintain the
<div n="lb"/>identity of the Vedic Sarasvatī with the later Sarasvatī.<sup>16</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>latter is of opinion that in Vedic times the Sarasvatī was as
<div n="lb"/>large a stream as the Sutlej, and that it actually reached the
[Page2-436+ 51]
<div n="lb"/>sea either after union with the Indus or not, being the ‘iron
<div n="lb"/>citadel,’ as the last boundary on the west, a frontier of the
<div n="lb"/>Panjab against the rest of India. There is no conclusive
<div n="lb"/>evidence of there having been any great change in the size or
<div n="lb"/>course of the Sarasvatī, though it would be impossible to deny
<div n="lb"/>that the river may easily have diminished in size. But there
<div n="lb"/>are strong reasons to accept the identification of the later and
<div n="lb"/>the earlier Sarasvatī throughout. The insistence on the divine
<div n="lb"/>character of the river is been in the very hymn<sup>17</sup> which refers
<div n="lb"/>to it as the support of the five tribes, and corresponds well with
<div n="lb"/>its later sacredness. Moreover, that hymn alludes to the
<div n="lb"/>{@Pārāvatas,@} a people shown by the later evidence of the Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa<sup>18</sup> to have been in the east, a very long way
<div n="lb"/>from their original home, if Sarasvatī means the Indus. Again,
<div n="lb"/>the {@Pūrus,@} who were settled on the Sarasvatī,<sup>19</sup> could with great
<div n="lb"/>difficulty be located in the far west. Moreover, the five tribes
<div n="lb"/>might easily be held to be on the Sarasvatī, when they were, as
<div n="lb"/>they seem to have been, the western neighbours of the {@Bharatas@}
<div n="lb"/>in {@Kurukṣetra,@} and the Sarasvatī could easily be regarded
<div n="lb"/>as the boundary of the Panjab in that sense. Again, the
<div n="lb"/>‘seven rivers’ in one passage<sup>20</sup> clearly designate a district: it
<div n="lb"/>is most probable that they are not the five rivers with the
<div n="lb"/>Indus and the {@Kubhā@} (Cabul river), but the five rivers, the
<div n="lb"/>Indus and the Sarasvatī. Nor is it difficult to see why the river
<div n="lb"/>is said to flow to the sea: either the Vedic poet had never
<div n="lb"/>followed the course of the river to its end, or the river did
<div n="lb"/>actually penetrate the desert either completely or for a long
<div n="lb"/>distance, and only in the Brāhmaṇa period was its disappear-
[Page2-437+ 50]
<div n="lb"/>ance in the desert found out. It is said, indeed, in the
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<sup>21</sup> that the five rivers go to the Sarasvatī,
<div n="lb"/>but this passage is not only late (as the use of the word {@Deśa@}
<div n="lb"/>shows), but it does not say that the five rivers meant are those
<div n="lb"/>of the Panjab. Moreover, the passage has neither a parallel
<div n="lb"/>in the other Saṃhitās, nor can it possibly be regarded as an
<div n="lb"/>early production; if it is late it must refer to the later
<div n="lb"/>Sarasvatī.
<div n="P"/>Hillebrandt,<sup>22</sup> on the whole, adopts this view of the Saras-
<div n="lb"/>vatī,<sup>23</sup> but he also sees in it, besides the designation of a
<div n="lb"/>mythical stream, the later Vaitaraṇī,<sup>24</sup> as well as the name of the
<div n="lb"/>Arghandab in Arachosia.<sup>25</sup> This opinion depends essentially
<div n="lb"/>on his theory that the sixth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda places the
<div n="lb"/>scene of its action in Iranian lands, as opposed to the seventh
<div n="lb"/>Maṇḍala: it is as untenable as that theory itself.<sup>26</sup> Brunn-
<div n="lb"/>hofer<sup>27</sup> at one time accepted the Iranian identification, but
<div n="lb"/>later<sup>28</sup> decided for the Oxus, which is quite out of the question.
<div n="lb"/>See also {@Plakṣa Prāsravaṇa.@}
<F>1) Literally, ‘abounding in pools,’
<div n="lb"/>perhaps with reference to its condition
<div n="lb"/>when the water was low. The name
<div n="lb"/>corresponds phonetically to the Iranian
<div n="lb"/>Haraqaiti (the modern Helmand).</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 1, 4;
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxv. 10, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa, xii. 2, 3; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 1, 14; Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ii. 19, 1. 2; probably Av.
<div n="lb"/>vi. 30, 1. This list is according to
<div n="lb"/>Roth's view, St. Petersburg Dictionary,
<div n="lb"/>{%s.v.%} 3{%c.%}</F>

<div n="lb"/>appears); x. 64, 9: 75, 5 (where the
<div n="lb"/>Śindhu also is mentioned).</F>

<L>3516<pc>2-440<k1>salva<k2>salva

<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> which records a boast by {@Śyāparṇa@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Sāyakāyana@} that if a certain rite of his had been completed,
<div n="lb"/>his race would have been the nobles, Brahmins, and peasants

<div n="lb"/>the Salvas. This people appears also to be alluded to as
<div n="lb"/>{%Sālvīḥ (prajāḥ)%} in the Mantra Pāṭha,<sup>2</sup> where they are said to
<div n="lb"/>have declared that their king was {@Yaugandhari@} when they
<div n="lb"/>stayed their chariots<sup>3</sup> on the banks of the {@Yamunā.@} There is
<div n="lb"/>later evidence<sup>4</sup> indicating that the Sālvas or Śālvas were
<div n="lb"/>closely connected with the {@Kuru-Pañcālas,@} and that apparently
<div n="lb"/>some of them, at least, were victorious near the banks of
<div n="lb"/>the Yamunā. There is no good evidence to place them in the
<div n="lb"/>north-west in Vedic times.<sup>5</sup>
<F>1) x. 4, 1, 10.</F>
<F>2) ii. 11, 12.</F>

<div n="lb"/>aible.</F>

<div n="lb"/>(45), 14. The Yugandharas are also

<L>3521<pc>2-441<k1>saha<k2>saha

<L>3522<pc>2-441<k1>sahadeva<k2>sahadeva

<L>3526<pc>2-442<k1>sAMvaraRi<k2>sAMvaraRi
{@Sāṃvaraṇi@}¦ is found in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> in one passage, where it
<div n="lb"/>naturally seems to be a patronymic (‘descendant of Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>varaṇa’) of Manu. According to Bloomfield,<sup>2</sup> it is a corrup-
<div n="lb"/>tion for {@Sāvarṇi,@} a reference to Manu's birth from the {%savarṇā,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘similar’ female who was substituted for Saraṇyū according to
<div n="lb"/>the legend (see {@Manu@}). This is possible, but not certain.
<div n="lb"/>Scheftelowitz<sup>3</sup> thinks that the reading of the Kaśmir manu-
<div n="lb"/>script of the Rigveda, which has {%sāṃvaraṇam,%} ‘found on the
<div n="lb"/>sacrificial ground,’ as an epithet of Soma, is to be preferred.
<div n="lb"/>But this seems quite improbable.<sup>4</sup> We must either recognize
<div n="lb"/>a real man called Manu Sāṃvaraṇi; or take Manu as one name,
<div n="lb"/>Sāṃvaraṇi as another; or admit that Manu Sāṃvaraṇi is
<div n="lb"/>simply Manu with a patronymic derived from an unknown
<div n="lb"/>legend.
<F>1) viii. 51, 1.</F>
<F>2) {%Journal of the American Oriental%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Society,%} 15, 180, n.</F>
<F>3) {%Die Apokryphen des Ṛgveda,%} 38.</F>
<F>4) See Oldenberg, {%Göttingische Gelehrte%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Anzeigen,%} 1907, 237.</F>

<div n="lb"/>same hymn, but this conclusion is not very cogent. He was
<div n="lb"/>clearly a patron of the {@Bharadvājas.@} The same epithet
<div n="lb"/>belongs to {@Sahadeva,@} {%alias%} {@Suplan.@}
<div n="P"/>^3 Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 4, 4, 4;
<div n="lb"/>xii. 8, 2, 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 104, 105.
<F>1) vi. 47, 25.</F>
<F>2) xvi. 11, 11.</F>

<L>3565<pc>2-448<k1>siMha<k2>siMha
{@Siṃha@}¦ denotes the ‘lion’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>roaring ({%nad%}) of the lion is often alluded to,<sup>2</sup> and is called
<div n="lb"/>thundering ({%stanatha%}).<sup>4</sup> He wanders about ({%ku-cara%}) and lives
<div n="lb"/>in the hills ({%giri-ṣṭha%}),<sup>5</sup> and is clearly the ‘dread wild beast that
<div n="lb"/>slays’ ({%mṛgo bhīma upahatnuḥ%})<sup>6</sup> to which Rudra is compared.
<div n="lb"/>When Agni, who has entered the waters, is compared to a
<div n="lb"/>lion,<sup>7</sup> the reference may be to the lion's habit of springing on
<div n="lb"/>animals at drinking places. That a jackal should defeat the
<div n="lb"/>lion is spoken of as a marvel.<sup>8</sup> The lion, being dangerous to
<div n="lb"/>men,<sup>9</sup> was trapped,<sup>10</sup> lain in wait for in ambush,<sup>11</sup> or chased by
<div n="lb"/>hunting bands.<sup>12</sup> But dogs were terrified of lions.<sup>13</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>lioness ({%siṃhī%}) was also famous for her courage: the aid given
<div n="lb"/>by Indra to {@Sudās@} against the vast host of his enemies is
<div n="lb"/>compared to the defeat of a lioness by a ram ({@Petva@}).<sup>14</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>gaping jaws of the lioness when attacking men are alluded to in
[Page2-449+ 43]
<div n="lb"/>the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>15</sup> The lioness is also mentioned in
<div n="lb"/>the Yajurveda Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<sup>16</sup> See also
<div n="lb"/>{@Halīkṣṇa.@}

<L>3579<pc>2-451<k1>sIra<k2>sIra
{@Sīra,@}¦ ‘plough,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> and often later.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>It was large and heavy, as is shown by the fact that six oxen,<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>or eight,<sup>4</sup> or twelve,<sup>5</sup> or even twenty-four,<sup>6</sup> were used to drag it.
<div n="lb"/>The animals which drew the plough were oxen, which were, no
<div n="lb"/>doubt, yoked and harnessed with traces.<sup>7</sup> The ox was guided
<div n="lb"/>by the {@Aṣṭrā,@} or ‘goad,’ of the ploughman ({%cf.%} {@Vaiśya@}).<sup>8</sup> Little
<div n="lb"/>is known of the parts of the plough. See {@Lāṅgala@} and {@Phāla.@}
<F>1) iv. 57, 8; x. 101, 3, 4.</F>
<F>2) Av. vi. 30, 1; 91, 1; viii. 9, 16,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>ii. 5, 8, 12; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 7;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 11, 4.</F>
<F>3) Av. vi. 91, 1; viii. 9, 16; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, v. 2, 5, 2; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xv. 2; xx. 3; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,

<div n="lb"/>v. 2, 5, 2; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xv. 2;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 2, etc.</F>
<F>6) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xv. 2. {%Cf.%} Weber,

<L>3598<pc>2-454<k1>sudAs<k2>sudAs
{@Su-dās@}¦ is the name of the {@Tṛtsu@} king who won a famous
<div n="lb"/>victory over the ten kings, as described in a hymn of the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>1</sup> At one time {@Viśvāmitra@} was his {@Purohita,@} and
<div n="lb"/>accompanied him in his victorious raids over the {@Vipāś@}
<div n="lb"/>(Beās) and {@Śutudrī@} (Sutlej).<sup>2</sup> The Aśvins gave him a queen,
<div n="lb"/>{@Sudevī,@}<sup>3</sup> and also helped him on another occasion.<sup>4</sup> He
<div n="lb"/>appears with {@Trasadasyu@} in a late hymn without hint of
<div n="lb"/>rivalry,<sup>5</sup> but elsewhere he seems to be referred to as defeated by
<div n="lb"/>{@Purukutsa,@} Trasadasyu's father.<sup>6</sup> In the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>he is recognized as a great king, with {@Vasiṣṭha@} as his Puro
<div n="lb"/>hita, and similarly in the Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sūtra,<sup>8</sup> where his
<div n="lb"/>generosity to his priest is related.
<div n="P"/>His exact ancestry is a little uncertain, because he is called
<div n="lb"/>{@Paijavana,@} ‘son of Pijavana,’ as Yāska explains the patro-
<div n="lb"/>nymic. If this explanation is correct, {@Divodāsa@} must have
<div n="lb"/>been his grandfather. If he was the son of Divodāsa, Pijavana
<div n="lb"/>must be understood as a more remote ancestor. The former
<div n="lb"/>alternative seems the more probable. {%Cf.%} {@Turvaśa, Dāśarājña.@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Paijavana, Bharata, Saudāsa.@}
<F>1) vii. 18. See also Rv. vii. 20, 2;
<div n="lb"/>25, 3; 32, 10; 33, 3; 64, 3; 83, 1 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) Rv. iii. 53, 9, 11. See also {@Viśvā-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@mitra@} and {@Vaṣiṣṭha.@}</F>
<F>3) Rv. i. 112, 19.</F>
<F>4) Rv. i. 47, 9, where, however, Roth,
<div n="lb"/>St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 1, takes
<div n="lb"/>{%su-dās%} as an adjective (‘worshipping
<div n="lb"/>well’).</F>
<F>5) Rv. vii. 19, 3.</F>
<F>6) Rv. i. 63, 7, reading {%Sudāsam%} for
<div n="lb"/>{%Sudāse%} with Ludwig, Translation of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda, 3, 174. {%Cf.%} Hillebrandt,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 112, n. 1; Geldner,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 153; Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Ṛgveda-Noten,%} 1, 63.</F>
<F>7) vii. 34, 9.</F>
<F>8) xvi. 11, 14.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%}
<div n="lb"/>1, 107 {%et seq.;%} Weber, {%Episches im vedischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Ritual,%} 31 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>3606<pc>2-455<k1>suparRa<k2>suparRa<h>1
1. {@Su-parṇa,@}¦ ‘well-winged,’ designates a large bird of prey,
<div n="lb"/>the ‘eagle’ or the ‘vulture,’ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later.<sup>2</sup> In
<div n="lb"/>the passages in which it appears as an eater of carrion<sup>3</sup> it must
<div n="lb"/>be the vulture. The Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> mentions an eagle
<div n="lb"/>which separates milk from water like the {@Kruñc.@} In the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>5</sup> the Suparṇa is said to be the child of the {@Śyena,@} and
<div n="lb"/>is distinguished from the latter in another passage:<sup>6</sup> this led
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>7</sup> to think that the falcon is probably meant.<sup>8</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda alludes to its cry,<sup>9</sup> and describes it as living in
<div n="lb"/>the hills.<sup>10</sup>
<F>1) i. 164, 20; ii. 42, 2; iv. 26, 4;
<div n="lb"/>viii. 100, 8; ix. 48, 3, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. i. 24, 1; ii. 27. 2; 30, 3; iv. 6, 3,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 8, 5,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>3) Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 9, 19;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Āraṇyaka, iv. 29.</F>
<F>4) ii. 438 ({%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 19, 101).</F>
<F>5) x. 144, 4.</F>
<F>6) ii. 42, 2.</F>
<F>7) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 88.</F>
<F>8) In the post-Vedic period Suparṇa
<div n="lb"/>became a mythical bird, identified with
<div n="lb"/>Viṣnu's vehicle, Garuḍa, who, however,
<div n="lb"/>is also regarded as king of the Suparṇas.</F>
<F>9) ii. 30, 3.</F>
<F>10) v. 4, 2.</F>

<L>3611<pc>2-456<k1>subanDu<k2>subanDu

<div n="lb"/>to be a proper name; but this is not certain, Roth<sup>2</sup> seeing in

<div n="lb"/>called {@Gaupāyanas,@} were priests of {@Asamāti,@} who cast them off

<div n="lb"/>by his three brothers, who recited certain hymns.<sup>4</sup>

<F>2) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%} 1.</F>

<div n="lb"/>Macdonell's notes. See also {@Asamāti,@}
<div n="lb"/>n. 1.</F>
