<L>3623<pc>2-458<k1>surA<k2>surA
{@Surā@}¦ is the name of an intoxicating ‘spirituous liquor,’
<div n="lb"/>often mentioned in Vedic literature. In some passages<sup>1</sup> it is
<div n="lb"/>referred to favourably, in others with decided disapproval.<sup>2</sup> It
<div n="lb"/>is classed with the use of meat and with dicing as an evil in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>3</sup> and often with dicing.<sup>4</sup> It was, as opposed to
<div n="lb"/>{@Soma,@} essentially a drink of ordinary life.<sup>5</sup> It was the drink of
<div n="lb"/>men in the {@Sabhā,@}<sup>6</sup> and gave rise to broils.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="P"/>Its exact nature is not certain. It may have been a strong
<div n="lb"/>spirit prepared from fermented grains and plants, as Eggeling<sup>8</sup>
[Page2-459+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>holds, or, as Whitney<sup>9</sup> thought, a kind of beer or ale.
<div n="lb"/>Geldner<sup>10</sup> renders it ‘brandy.’ It is sometimes mentioned in
<div n="lb"/>connexion with {@Madhu.@}<sup>11</sup> It was kept in skins.<sup>12</sup>
<F>1) Rv. i. 116, 7; x. 131, 4, 5. {%Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Av. iv. 34, 6; x. 6, 5; Taittirīya Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, i. 3, 3, 2; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>xii. 7, 3, 8.</F>
<F>2) Rv. vii. 86, 6; viii. 2, 12; 21, 14;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 11, 6; ii. 4, 2;
<div n="lb"/>iv. 2, 1, etc.</F>
<F>3) vi. 70, 1. {%Cf.%} Bloomfield, {%Hymns%}
<div n="lb"/>{%of the Atharvaveda,%} 493.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vii. 86, 6; Av. xiv. 1, 35. 36;
<div n="lb"/>xv. 9, 1. 2.</F>
<F>5) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 3, 2.</F>
<F>6) See n. 4.</F>
<F>7) Rv. viii. 2, 12; 21, 14. {%Cf.%} Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xiv. 6; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>i. 6, 3, 4; Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 2,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>8) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 44, 223,
<div n="lb"/>n. 2; Caland, {%Altindisches Zauberritual,%}

<div n="lb"/>{%ties,%} 326.</F>

<F>11) Av. vi. 69, 1; ix. 1, 18, 19; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 95. See Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 251, who
<div n="lb"/>attempts to show that Surā and Soma
<div n="lb"/>were rival priestly drinks at one time,

<L>3639<pc>2-461<k1>sUkara<k2>sUkara
{@Sū-kara@}¦ ‘wild-boar,’ has the appearance of being an onomato-
<div n="lb"/>poetic word (‘making the sound {%sū%}’); it is more probably a
<div n="lb"/>very old word going back to the Indo-European period, and
<div n="lb"/>cognate with the Latin {%su-culus%} (‘little pig’), being transformed
<div n="lb"/>in sense by popular etymology.<sup>1</sup> It occurs in the Rigveda<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>and later.<sup>3</sup> It appears once in the Atharvaveda accompanied
<div n="lb"/>by {%mṛga,%}<sup>4</sup> the combined words apparently meaning ‘wild hog,’
<div n="lb"/>as opposed to {@Varāha,@} ‘boar.’
<F>1) The {%sū-%} corresponding to Lat. {%sū-s,%}
<div n="lb"/>Gk. <lang n="greek"></lang>-{%s,%} Old High German, {%sū. Cf.%}
<div n="lb"/>Brugmann, {%Grundriss,%} 2^2, 483.</F>
<F>2) vii. 55, 4.</F>
<F>3) Av. ii. 27, 2; v. 14, 1; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 21; Vājasaneyi Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, xxiv. 40; Chāndogya Upaniṣad,
<div n="lb"/>v. 10, 2, etc. None of the passages
<div n="lb"/>refer to the flesh as eaten: Buddha's
<div n="lb"/>death was due to a meal of {%sūkara-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%maddava,%} which may well mean ‘tender
<div n="lb"/>parts of pork’ (see Fleet, {%Journal of the%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1906, 881, n.),
<div n="lb"/>though the Rājanighaṇṭu, vii. 85, gives
<div n="lb"/>{%sūkara%} as meaning the {%Batatas edulis.%}</F>
<F>4) xii. 1, 48. The use of {%mṛga%} here
<div n="lb"/>does not indicate that {%sūkara%} is a new
<div n="lb"/>name, because the latter word elsewhere
<div n="lb"/>always occurs alone both in the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>and later (n. 3). {%Cf.%} {@Mṛga@} above, 2,
<div n="lb"/>172, n. 3.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 82;
<div n="lb"/>Pischel, {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 100.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3643<pc>2-462<k1>sUta<k2>sUta
{@Sūta@}¦ is the name of a court official who is often mentioned
<div n="lb"/>with the {@Grāmaṇī.@} He is one of the eight {@Vīras@} in the Pañca-
<div n="lb"/>viṃśa Brāhmaṇa,<sup>1</sup> and of the eleven {@Ratnins@} in other texts.<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>He also appears in the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> among the kingmakers
<div n="lb"/>({@Rājakṛt@}) and in the Śatrarudriya<sup>4</sup> (‘section dealing with the
<div n="lb"/>hundred Rudras’) of the Yajurveda. The commentators are
<div n="lb"/>agreed in seeing in him the ‘charioteer’ ({@Sārathi@}) or ‘master of
<div n="lb"/>the horse,’ of the king; this sense is accepted by Roth,<sup>5</sup> by
<div n="lb"/>Whitney,<sup>6</sup> and by Bloomfield.<sup>7</sup> But the fact that the {@Saṃ-@}
[Page2-463+ 49]
<div n="lb"/>{@grahītṛ,@} who occurs in several passages beside the Sūta, is the
<div n="lb"/>‘charioteer,’ renders this version improbable. Eggeling<sup>8</sup> thinks
<div n="lb"/>that he was, in the Brāhmaṇas at least, a minstrel and court
<div n="lb"/>poet, while Weber<sup>9</sup> considers that his name denotes him as
<div n="lb"/>‘consecrated’ — that is, one who has constant access to the
<div n="lb"/>king. In the Epic the Sūta serves as a royal herald and
<div n="lb"/>bard:<sup>10</sup> it may be that the curious words {%ahanti,%}<sup>11</sup> {%ahantya,%}<sup>12</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>{%ahantva%}<sup>13</sup> applied to him<sup>14</sup> in the Śatarudriya denote his sacred
<div n="lb"/>character at once as minstrel and as herald — a combination of
<div n="lb"/>functions not unknown elsewhere.
<F>1) ix. 1, 4, where he follows the
<div n="lb"/>chief queen ({@Mahiṣī@}), and precedes the
<div n="lb"/>Grāmaṇī in the list.</F>
<F>2) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xv. 4; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5; iv. 3, 8; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, i. 7, 3, 1; Taittirīya Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, i. 8, 9, 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>v. 3, 1, 5.</F>
<F>3) iii. 5, 7.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, iv. 5, 2, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvii. 2; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 3; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 18. So also in the list of victims at
<div n="lb"/>the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’),
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 6; Taittirīya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 2, 1. For other refer-
<div n="lb"/>ences to the Sūta, see Taittirīya Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, ii. 7, 18, 4; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>v. 4, 4, 7; xiii. 4, 2, 5; 7, 1, 43; Kāṭhaka
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xxviii. 3; Bṛhadāraṇyaka
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad, iv. 3, 37, 38.</F>
<F>5) St. Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.%}</F>
<F>6) Translation of the Atharvaveda, 62.</F>
<F>7) {%Hymns of the Atharvaveda,%} 114.</F>
<F>8) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 41, 62, n. 1.</F>
<F>9) {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 200.</F>
<F>10) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 254, 255.</F>
<F>11) Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 18. This
<div n="lb"/>word means ‘non-fighter’ according
<div n="lb"/>to Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 17, 200.</F>
<F>12) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 2, 1.</F>
<F>13) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvii. 2; Maitrā-
<div n="lb"/>yaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 3.</F>
<F>14) The last two forms appear to be
<div n="lb"/>equivalent in sense to {%ahanya,%} ‘not to
<div n="lb"/>be slain,’ ‘inviolable.’</F>

<L>3646<pc>2-463<k1>sUda<k2>sUda
{@Sūda,@}¦ according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, means
<div n="lb"/>‘well’<sup>1</sup> and the ‘mud of a dried-up pool.’<sup>2</sup> Pischel,<sup>3</sup> however,
<div n="lb"/>shows clearly that Sūda denotes what is added to Soma to
[Page2-464+ 44]
<div n="lb"/>make it fit for use, especially the warm milk, and this sense suits
<div n="lb"/>all the passages. Eggeling<sup>4</sup> renders it ‘well,’ and Grassmann
<div n="lb"/>‘sweet drink.’
<F>1) Rv. vii. 36, 3; ix. 97, 4.</F>
<F>2) Rv. x. 61, 2; Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 13; Taittirīya brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 3, 5;
<div n="lb"/>2, 1, 3; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, viii. 7,
<div n="lb"/>3, 21.</F>
<F>3) {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 72, 73.</F>
<F>4) {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 43, 144.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Hillebrandt, {%Vedische Mythologie,%} 1, 211.</F>

<L>3649<pc>2-464<k1>sUnu<k2>sUnu
{@Sūnu@}¦ is a common word for ‘son’ from the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>onwards.<sup>1</sup> The etymological sense seems to be ‘he who is
<div n="lb"/>borne,’ and then ‘the begotten.’<sup>2</sup> But the use of Sūnu in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>3</sup> is predominantly in relation to the father, and only
<div n="lb"/>rarely in its connexion with words for mother.<sup>4</sup> Thus a father
<div n="lb"/>is ‘easy of access’ ({%sāpāyana%}) to his son ({%sūnu%});<sup>5</sup> but in another
<div n="lb"/>passage,<sup>6</sup> where the same term is applied to earth as a mother,
<div n="lb"/>the word used for son is {@Putra.@} No conclusion as to matriarchy
<div n="lb"/>can of course be drawn from the etymology. On the relation
<div n="lb"/>of son and father, see {@Pitṛ.@}
<F>1) Rv. i. 26, 3; ii. 38, 5; vi. 52, 9,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Av. vi. 1, 2; vii. 2, 2; xii. 3, 23,
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>2) Delbrück, {%Die indogermanischen Ver-%}
<div n="lb"/>{%wandischaftsnamen,%} 453.</F>
<F>3) Usually in a figurative sense — {%e.g%}
<div n="lb"/>{%sahasaḥ, adreḥ Sūruḥ.%}</F>
<F>4) v. 42, 2.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 1, 9.</F>
<F>6) Rv. x. 18, 11.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3650<pc>2-465<k1>sUri<k2>sUri

<div n="lb"/>performing the rite, and reaps the benefit of that service. The
<div n="lb"/>Sūris are often coupled with the {@Maghavans,@}<sup>1</sup> described as
<div n="lb"/>heroes or warriors,<sup>2</sup> and as related to the priests by their
<div n="lb"/>patronage<sup>3</sup> or as companions.<sup>4</sup>

<L>3652<pc>2-465<k1>sUrya<k2>sUrya
{@Sūrya,@}¦ the ‘sun,’ plays a great part in Vedic mythology and
<div n="lb"/>religion,<sup>1</sup> corresponding with the importance of the sun as a
<div n="lb"/>factor in the physical life of the peninsula. In the Rigveda<sup>2</sup>
<div n="lb"/>the sun is normally regarded as a beneficent power, a not
<div n="lb"/>unnatural view in a people which must apparently have issued
<div n="lb"/>from the cold regions of the Himālaya mountains. Its heat
<div n="lb"/>is, however, alluded to in some passages of the Rigveda,<sup>3</sup> as
<div n="lb"/>well as referred to in the Atharvaveda and the literature of the
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇas.<sup>4</sup>
<div n="P"/>In one myth Indra is said to have vanquished Sūrya and to
<div n="lb"/>have stolen his wheel:<sup>5</sup> this is possibly a reference to the
[Page2-466+ 62]
<div n="lb"/>obscuration of the sun by a thunderstorm.<sup>6</sup> The Aitareya
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa<sup>7</sup> presents a naive conception of the course of the
<div n="lb"/>sun, which it regards as bright on one side only, and as
<div n="lb"/>returning from west to east by the same road, but with the
<div n="lb"/>reverse side turned towards the earth, thus at night illumining
<div n="lb"/>the stars in heaven.<sup>8</sup> In the Rigveda<sup>9</sup> wonder is expressed
<div n="lb"/>that the sun does not fall.
<div n="P"/>There are several references to eclipses in the Rigveda. In
<div n="lb"/>one passage<sup>10</sup> Svarbhānu, a demon, is said to have eclipsed the
<div n="lb"/>sun with darkness, while {@Atri@} restores the light of the sun, a
<div n="lb"/>similar feat being elsewhere attributed to his family, the Atris.<sup>11</sup>
<div n="lb"/>In the Atharvaveda<sup>12</sup> {@Rāhu@} appears for the first time in con-
<div n="lb"/>nexion with the sun. Indra's defeat of Sūrya<sup>6</sup> may also be
<div n="lb"/>explained as alluding to an eclipse; in two other passages<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>such an interpretation seems at least probable. Ludwig<sup>14</sup> not
<div n="lb"/>only argues that the Rigveda knows the theory of eclipses
<div n="lb"/>caused by an occultation of the sun by the moon, and regards
<div n="lb"/>the sun as going round the earth,<sup>15</sup> but even endeavours to
<div n="lb"/>identify an eclipse referred to in the Rigveda with one that
<div n="lb"/>occurred in 1029 B.C. These views are completely refuted by
<div n="lb"/>Whitney.<sup>16</sup>
<div n="P"/>The sun as a maker of time<sup>17</sup> determines the year of 360 days,
<div n="lb"/>which is the civil year and the usual year ({@Saṃvatsara@}) of
[Page2-467+ 70]
<div n="lb"/>Vedic literature. This solar year is divided into two halves — 
<div n="lb"/>the Uttarāyaṇa,<sup>18</sup> when the sun goes north, and the Dakṣiṇā-
<div n="lb"/>yana,<sup>19</sup> when it goes south. There can be no doubt that these
<div n="lb"/>periods denote the time when the sun turns north from the
<div n="lb"/>winter solstice, and when it turns south from the summer
<div n="lb"/>solstice, for the Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa<sup>20</sup> says so in perfectly clear
<div n="lb"/>language. The alternative theory is to regard the periods as
<div n="lb"/>those when the sun is in the north — {%i.e.,%} when it is north of the
<div n="lb"/>equator, and when it is in the south, taking as points of depar-
<div n="lb"/>ture the equinoxes, not the solstices; but this view has no
<div n="lb"/>support in Vedic literature, and is opposed to the fact that
<div n="lb"/>the equinoxes play no part in Vedic astronomical theory.<sup>21</sup>
<div n="lb"/>There are only doubtful references to the solstices in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda.<sup>22</sup>
<div n="P"/>The Brāhmaṇas,<sup>23</sup> and perhaps the Rigveda,<sup>24</sup> regard the
<div n="lb"/>moon as entering the sun at new moon. According to Hille-
<div n="lb"/>brandt,<sup>25</sup> the Rigveda<sup>26</sup> recognizes that the moon shines
<div n="lb"/>by the borrowed light of the sun, but this seems very doubt-
[Page2-468+ 54]
<div n="lb"/>ful. See also {@Aryamṇaḥ Panthā,@}<sup>27</sup> {@Nakṣatra,@} and {@Sapta@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Sūryāḥ.@}
<F>1) See Macdonell, {%Vedic Mythology,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 30 {%et seq.%}</F>
<F>2) {%E.g.,%} i. 50, 6; 115, 1. 3; 164, 11.
<div n="lb"/>13; 191, 8. 9; vii. 63, 1; x. 37, 4;
<div n="lb"/>85, 9; 88, 11; 139, 3, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. vii. 34, 19; ix. 107, 20.</F>
<F>4) Ehni, {%Yama,%} 134; Macdonell, {%op. cit.,%}
<div n="lb"/>p. 31.</F>

<F>7) iii. 44, 4.</F>

<div n="lb"/>Rv. i. 115. 5; x. 37, 3. See also Speyer,

<div n="lb"/>723; Thibaut, {%Astronomie, Astrologie und%}

<L>3653<pc>2-468<k1>sUryanakzatra<k2>sUryanakzatra
{@Sūrya-nakṣatra@}¦ is found in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>1</sup> in a
<div n="lb"/>passage where Sāyaṇa takes it as denoting a {@Nakṣatra,@} which
<div n="lb"/>gives out rays of light like the sun. But the real sense (as the
<div n="lb"/>Kāṇva text helps to show) is that the sacrificer may take the
<div n="lb"/>sun for his Nakṣatra — {%i.e.,%} he may neglect the Nakṣatras
<div n="lb"/>altogether and rely on the sun.
<F>1) ii. 1, 2, 19. {%Cf.%} Eggeling, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 12, 288.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3657<pc>2-469<k1>sfjaya<k2>sfjaya
{@Sṛjaya@}¦ is the name of one of the victims at the Aśvamedha
<div n="lb"/>(‘horse sacrifice’) in the Yajurveda.<sup>1</sup> What it was is unknown:
<div n="lb"/>Mahīdhara on the Vājasaneyi passage calls it a kind of bird;
<div n="lb"/>Sāyaṇa on the Taittirīya Saṃhitā gives the alternatives ‘black
<div n="lb"/>fly’ (when {%sṛjayā%} must be read), ‘white serpent,’ and ‘black
<div n="lb"/>buffalo.’
<F>1) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 14, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 23. {%Cf.%} Zimmer,
<div n="lb"/>{%Altindisches Leben,%} 99.</F>

<L>3658<pc>2-469<k1>sfYjaya<k2>sfYjaya
{@Sṛñjaya@}¦ is the name of a people mentioned as early as the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda. Sṛñjaya (that is, the king of this people) {@Daivavāta@}
<div n="lb"/>is celebrated as victorious over the {@Turvaśas@} and the {@Vṛcī-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@vants,@}<sup>1</sup> and his sacrificial fire is referred to.<sup>2</sup> In connexion
<div n="lb"/>with Daivavāta is also mentioned {@Sāhadevya Somaka,@}<sup>3</sup> no
<div n="lb"/>doubt another prince; for in the Aitareya Brāhmaṇa<sup>4</sup> we find
<div n="lb"/>Somaka Sāhadevya and his father, Sahadeva (originally {@Suplan@})
<div n="lb"/>Sārñjaya, as kings who were anointed by {@Parvata@} and
<div n="lb"/>{@Nārada.@} The Rigveda<sup>5</sup> has also a Dānastuti (‘praise of gifts’)
<div n="lb"/>of {@Prastoka,@}<sup>6</sup> a Sṛñjaya, who is lauded along with {@Divodāsa.@}
<div n="lb"/>Moreover, {@Vītahavya@}<sup>7</sup> seems to have been a Sṛñjaya, though
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>8</sup> prefers to take the derivative word, {@Vaitahavya,@} not
<div n="lb"/>as a patronymic, but as an epithet.
<div n="P"/>It seems probable that the Sṛñjayas and the {@Tṛtsus@} were
<div n="lb"/>closely allied, for Divodāsa and a Sṛñjaya prince are celebrated
<div n="lb"/>together,<sup>9</sup> and the Turvaśas were enemies of both.<sup>10</sup> This view
<div n="lb"/>is borne out by the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,<sup>11</sup> which recognizes
<div n="lb"/>{@Devabhāga Śrautarṣa@} as Purohita of the {@Kurus@} and the
<div n="lb"/>Sṛñjayas.
[Page2-470+ 49]
<div n="P"/>On the other hand, some disaster certainly befel the Sṛñjayas,
<div n="lb"/>at least the Vaitahavyas, for they are said in the Atharvaveda<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>to have offended the {@Bhṛgus@} and to have ended miserably.
<div n="lb"/>There is, it is true, no precise confirmation of this notice, but
<div n="lb"/>both the Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā<sup>13</sup> and the Taittirīya Saṃhitā,<sup>14</sup> in
<div n="lb"/>independent passages, refer to the Sṛñjayas having sustained
<div n="lb"/>some serious loss, though the notice is in each case coupled
<div n="lb"/>with a ritual error, much as in the Old Testament the fate
<div n="lb"/>of kings depends on their devotion to Jahve or their dis-
<div n="lb"/>obedience. It is justifiable to recognize some disaster in this
<div n="lb"/>allusion.
<div n="P"/>The geographical position of the Sṛñjayas is uncertain.
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt<sup>15</sup> suggests that in early times they must be looked
<div n="lb"/>for west of the Indus with Divodāsa; he also mentions, though
<div n="lb"/>he does not definitely adopt, the suggestion of Brunnhofer that
<div n="lb"/>the Sṛñjayas are to be compared with the <lang n="greek"></lang><sup>16</sup> of the
<div n="lb"/>Greeks, and to be located in Drangiana. Zimmer<sup>17</sup> is inclined
<div n="lb"/>to locate them on the upper Indus; but it is difficult to decide
<div n="lb"/>definitely in favour of any particular location. They may well
<div n="lb"/>have been a good deal farther east than the Indus, since their
<div n="lb"/>allies, the Tṛtsus, were in the {@Madhyadeśa,@} and were certainly
<div n="lb"/>absorbed in the Kurus.
<div n="P"/>Of the history of this clan we have one notice.<sup>18</sup> They
<div n="lb"/>expelled {@Duṣṭarītu Pauṃsāyana,@} one of their kings, from the
<div n="lb"/>hereditary monarchy — of ten generations — and also drove out
<div n="lb"/>{@Revottaras Pāṭava Cākra Sthapati,@} probably his minister,
<div n="lb"/>who, however, succeeded in effecting the restoration of the
<div n="lb"/>king, despite the opposition of the Kuru prince, {@Balhika@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Prātīpya.@} Very probably this Kuru prince may have been at
<div n="lb"/>the bottom of the movement which led to the expulsion of the
<div n="lb"/>king and his minister. But the restoration of the king can
[Page2-471+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>hardly be regarded, in accordance with Bloomfield's view,<sup>19</sup> as a
<div n="lb"/>defeat of the Sṛñjayas.
<F>1) Rv. vi. 27, 7.</F>
<F>2) Rv. iv. 15, 4.</F>
<F>3) Rv. iv. 15, 7.</F>
<F>4) vii. 34, 9.</F>
<F>5) Rv. vi. 47, 22. 25.</F>
<F>6) {%Cf.%} Śāṅkhāyana Śrauta Sutra,
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 11, 11.</F>

<div n="lb"/>and their connexion with the Sṛñjayas

<L>3673<pc>2-474<k1>soma<k2>soma
{@Soma@}¦ was the famous plant which was used for the prepara-
<div n="lb"/>tion of the libation of Soma made at the Vedic sacrifice. Its
<div n="lb"/>importance is sufficiently shown by the fact that the whole of
<div n="lb"/>the ninth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda, and six hymns in other
<div n="lb"/>Maṇḍalas, are devoted to its praise.
<div n="P"/>Nevertheless, little is actually known of the plant. Its twigs
<div n="lb"/>or shoots are described as brown ({%babhru%}),<sup>1</sup> ruddy ({%aruṇa%}),<sup>2</sup> of
<div n="lb"/>tawny ({%hari%}).<sup>3</sup> Possibly its twigs hang down if the epithet
<div n="lb"/>{@Naicāśākha@}<sup>4</sup> refers to the plant as Hillebrandt<sup>5</sup> thinks. The
<div n="lb"/>shoot is called {%aṃśu,%}<sup>6</sup> while the plant as a whole is called
<div n="lb"/>{%andhas,%}<sup>7</sup> which also denotes the juice.<sup>8</sup> {%Parvan%}<sup>9</sup> is the stem.
<div n="lb"/>{%Kṣip,%}<sup>10</sup> ‘finger,’ is used as a designation of the shoots, which may
<div n="lb"/>therefore have resembled fingers in shape; {%vakṣaṇā%}<sup>11</sup> and {%vāṇa%}<sup>12</sup>
<div n="lb"/>also seem to have the sense of the shoot. There is some slight.
<div n="lb"/>evidence to suggest that the stem was not round, but angular.<sup>13</sup>
[Page2-475+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>The plant grew on the mountains,<sup>14</sup> that of {@Müjavant@} being
<div n="lb"/>specially renowned.
<div n="P"/>These notices are inadequate to identify the plant. It has
<div n="lb"/>been held<sup>15</sup> to be the {%Sarcostemma viminale%} or the {%Asclepias acida%}
<div n="lb"/>{%(= Sarcostemma brevistigma).%} Roth<sup>16</sup> held that the {%Sarcostemma%}
<div n="lb"/>{%acidum%} more nearly met the requirements of the case. Watt<sup>17</sup>
<div n="lb"/>suggested the Afghan grape as the real Soma, and Rice<sup>18</sup>
<div n="lb"/>thought a sugar-cane might be meant, while Max Müller and
<div n="lb"/>Rājendralāla Mitra suggested that the juice was used as an
<div n="lb"/>ingredient in a kind of beer — {%i.e.,%} that the Soma plant was a
<div n="lb"/>species of hop. Hillebrandt<sup>19</sup> considers that neither hops nor
<div n="lb"/>the grape can explain the references to Soma. It is very
<div n="lb"/>probable that the plant cannot now be identified.<sup>20</sup>
<div n="P"/>In the Yajurveda<sup>21</sup> the plant is purchased ere it is pressed.
<div n="lb"/>Hillebrandt<sup>22</sup> considers that the sale must be assumed for the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda. It grew on a mountain, and could not be obtained
<div n="lb"/>by ordinary people: perhaps some special tribe or prince
<div n="lb"/>owned it, like the {@Kīkaṭas.@}<sup>23</sup> As it stands, the ritual perform-
<div n="lb"/>ance is clearly an acquisition of the Soma from the Gandharvas
<div n="lb"/>(represented by a Śūdra), a ritual imitation of the action which
<div n="lb"/>may have been one of the sources of the drama. Owing
<div n="lb"/>to the difficulty of obtaining the real plant from a great
[Page2-476+ 61]
<div n="lb"/>distance, several substitutes were allowed in the Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb"/>period.<sup>24</sup>
<div n="P"/>The plant was prepared for use by being pounded with stones
<div n="lb"/>or in a mortar. The former was the normal method of pro-
<div n="lb"/>cedure, appearing in the Rigveda as the usual one. The stones
<div n="lb"/>are called {%grāvan%}<sup>25</sup> or {%adri,%}<sup>26</sup> and were, of course, held in the
<div n="lb"/>hands.<sup>27</sup> The plant was laid on boards one beside the other
<div n="lb"/>({@Adhiṣavana@}), and, according at least to the later ritual,<sup>28</sup> a
<div n="lb"/>hole was dug below, so that the pounding of the plant by
<div n="lb"/>means of the stones resulted in a loud noise, doubtless a
<div n="lb"/>prophylactic against demoniac influences.
<div n="P"/>The plant was placed on a skin and on the Vedi<sup>29</sup> — which
<div n="lb"/>was no longer done in the later ritual — {@Dhiṣaṇā@} in some
<div n="lb"/>passages denoting the Vedi.<sup>30</sup>
<div n="P"/>Sometimes the mortar and pestle were used in place of the
<div n="lb"/>stones.<sup>31</sup> This use, though Iranian, was apparently not common
<div n="lb"/>in Vedic times.

<L>3674<pc>2-476<k1>camU<k2>camU
{@Camū@}¦ denotes the vessel used for the offering to the god,<sup>32</sup>
<div n="lb"/>{@Kalaśa@} and {@Camasa@} those used for the priests to drink from.
<div n="lb"/>Sometimes<sup>33</sup> the Camū denotes the mortar and pestle. Perhaps
<div n="lb"/>the vessel was so called because of its mortar-like shape.
<div n="P"/>The skin on which the shoots were placed was called
<div n="lb"/>{@Tvac,@}<sup>34</sup> or twice {%go%} (‘cow-hide’).<sup>35</sup> {@Kośa,@}<sup>36</sup> Sadhastha,<sup>37</sup> {@Dru,@}<sup>38</sup>
[Page2-477+ 76]
<div n="lb"/>{@Vana,@}<sup>39</sup> {@Droṇa,@}<sup>40</sup> are all terms used for Soma vessels, while
<div n="lb"/>{@Sruva@}<sup>41</sup> denotes the ‘ladle.’
<div n="P"/>Apparently the plant was sometimes steeped in water to
<div n="lb"/>increase its yield of juice.<sup>42</sup>
<div n="P"/>It is not possible to describe exactly the details of the process
<div n="lb"/>of pressing the Soma as practised in the Rigveda. It was
<div n="lb"/>certainly purified by being pressed through a sieve<sup>43</sup> ({@Pavitra@}).
<div n="lb"/>The Soma was then used unmixed ({%śukra,%}<sup>44</sup> {%śuci%})<sup>45</sup> for Indra and
<div n="lb"/>{@Vāyu,@} but the {@Kaṇvas@} seem to have dropped this usage.<sup>46</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>juice is described as brown ({%babhru%}),<sup>47</sup> tawny ({%hari%}),<sup>48</sup> or ruddy
<div n="lb"/>({%aruṇa%}),<sup>49</sup> and as having a fragrant smell,<sup>50</sup> at least as a
<div n="lb"/>rule.<sup>51</sup>
<div n="P"/>Soma was mixed with milk ({@Gavāśir@}),<sup>52</sup> curd or sour milk
<div n="lb"/>({@Dadhyāśir@}),<sup>53</sup> or grain ({@Yavāśir@}).<sup>54</sup> The admixtures are
[Page2-478+ 67]
<div n="lb"/>alluded to with various figurative expressions, as {@Atka,@}
<div n="lb"/>‘armour’;<sup>55</sup> {@Vastra@}<sup>56</sup> or {@Vāsas,@}<sup>57</sup> ‘garment’; {@Abhiśrī,@}<sup>58</sup> ‘admix-
<div n="lb"/>ture’; {%rūpa,%}<sup>59</sup> ‘beauty’; {%śrī,%}<sup>60</sup> ‘splendour’; {%rasa,%}<sup>61</sup> ‘flavour’;
<div n="lb"/>{%prayas,%}<sup>62</sup> ‘dainty’; and perhaps {%nabhas,%}<sup>63</sup> ‘fragrance.’ The
<div n="lb"/>adjective {%tīvra%}<sup>64</sup> denotes the ‘pungent’ flavour of Soma when
<div n="lb"/>so mixed. The Soma shoots, after the juice has been pressed
<div n="lb"/>out, are denoted by {%ṛjīṣa,%} ‘residue.’<sup>65</sup>
<div n="P"/>It seems probable that in some cases honey was mixed with
<div n="lb"/>Soma: perhaps the {%kośa madhu-ścut,%} ‘the pail distilling sweet-
<div n="lb"/>ness,’ was used for the mixing.<sup>66</sup> It seems doubtful if Surā was
<div n="lb"/>ever so mixed.<sup>67</sup>
<div n="P"/>There were three pressings a day of Soma, as opposed to the
<div n="lb"/>two of the Avesta.<sup>68</sup> The evening pressing was specially
<div n="lb"/>connected with the Ṛbhus, the midday with Indra, the
<div n="lb"/>morning with Agni, but the ritual shows that many other gods
<div n="lb"/>also had their share.<sup>69</sup> The drinker of Soma and the non-
<div n="lb"/>drinker are sharply discriminated in the texts.<sup>70</sup> Localities
<div n="lb"/>where Soma was consumed were {@Ārjīka, Pastyāvant, Śarya-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@ṇāvant, Suṣomā,@} the territory of the {@Pañcajanāḥ@} or ‘five
[Page2-479+ 64]
<div n="lb"/>peoples,’ and so on.<sup>71</sup> The effects of Soma in exhilarating and
<div n="lb"/>exciting the drinkers are often alluded to.<sup>72</sup>
<div n="P"/>It is difficult to decide if Soma was ever a popular, as opposed
<div n="lb"/>to a hieratic drink. The evidence for its actual popularity is
<div n="lb"/>very slight,<sup>73</sup> and not decisive.
<F>32) Not the pressing boards, which
<div n="lb"/>are unknown in the Rigveda. {%Cf.%} Rv.
<div n="lb"/>ix. 99, 8; x. 91, 15, etc.</F>
<F>33) Rv. i. 28, 9; iv. 18, 3; vi. 57, 2,
<div n="lb"/>etc.; Hillebrandt, 1, 170, 173.</F>
<F>34) Rv. ix. 65, 25; 66, 29; 70, 7;
<div n="lb"/>79, 4, etc.</F>
<F>35) Rv. x. 94, 9; 116, 4.</F>
<F>36) Rv. vii. 101, 4; viii. 20, 8, etc.
<div n="lb"/>It denotes the larger vessel from which
<div n="lb"/>the Soma is poured into the Kalaśas,
<div n="lb"/>or cups.</F>
<F>37) Rv. iii. 62, 15; ix. 1, 2; 17, 8, etc.</F>
<F>38) Rv. ix. 1, 2; 65, 6; 98, 2; in
<div n="lb"/>x. 101, 10, {%dru%} = mortar.</F>
<F>39) Rv. ii. 14, 9; ix. 66, 9, etc. The
<div n="lb"/>word can mean both the vessel into
<div n="lb"/>which the Soma was poured after pre-
<div n="lb"/>paration, and the vessel from which it
<div n="lb"/>was offered to the gods.</F>
<F>40) Rv. ix. 15, 7; 33, 2, etc. The

<L>3717<pc>2-485<k1>strI<k2>strI
{@Strī@}¦ is the ordinary word in poetry and prose for ‘woman,’
<div n="lb"/>without special reference to her as a wife or as a maiden. {@Nārī@}
<div n="lb"/>has the same sense, but disappears in later prose, while {@Gnā@}
<div n="lb"/>refers only to the wives of the gods, and {@Yoṣit,@} with its cognate
<div n="lb"/>words, denotes the young woman as ripe for marriage.<sup>1</sup> In the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>2</sup> Strī stands opposed to {@Pumāṃs,@} ‘man,’ and once to
<div n="lb"/>{%vṛṣan,%} ‘male person’; not until the Atharvaveda<sup>3</sup> does it mean
<div n="lb"/>‘wife’ as opposed to {@Pati,@} ‘husband,’ and even in the Sūtras it
<div n="lb"/>is sharply opposed to {@Jāyā.@}
<div n="P"/>In Vedic India by far the greater part of a woman's life was
<div n="lb"/>taken up in her marriage and marital relations (see Pati and
<div n="lb"/>{@Mātṛ@}). There is no trace in the Rigveda of the seclusion
<div n="lb"/>of women, which was practically complete in all but the
<div n="lb"/>earliest Epic:<sup>4</sup> the maiden may be assumed to have grown up
<div n="lb"/>in her father's house, enjoying free intercourse with the youth
<div n="lb"/>of the village, and sharing in the work of the house. Educa-
<div n="lb"/>tion<sup>5</sup> was not denied to them, at any rate in certain cases, for
<div n="lb"/>we hear in the Upaniṣads of women who could take no
<div n="lb"/>unimportant part in disputations on philosophical topics.
<div n="lb"/>Moreover, women were taught to dance and sing, which were
<div n="lb"/>unmanly accomplishments.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>Of the exact legal position of daughters the notices are few
<div n="lb"/>and meagre. The Rigveda,<sup>7</sup> however, shows that in the place
[Page2-486+ 60]
<div n="lb"/>of a father the brother was looked to for aid, and that brother-
<div n="lb"/>less maidens were apt to be ruined, though religious terrors
<div n="lb"/>were believed to await the man who took advantage of their
<div n="lb"/>defencelessness.<sup>8</sup> Moreover, women could not take an inherit-
<div n="lb"/>ance,<sup>9</sup> and were not independent persons in the eyes of the
<div n="lb"/>law, whether married or not. Presumably before marriage
<div n="lb"/>they lived on their parents or brothers, and after that on their
<div n="lb"/>husbands, while in the event of their husbands predeceasing
<div n="lb"/>them, their relatives took the property, burdened with the
<div n="lb"/>necessity of maintaining the wife.<sup>10</sup> Their earnings would be
<div n="lb"/>appropriated by their nearest relative — usually father or brother
<div n="lb"/>-in the few cases in which unmarried women could earn
<div n="lb"/>anything, as in the case of courtezans.
<F>1) {%Cf.%} Delbrück, {%Die indogermanischen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Verwandtsehaftsnamen,%} 417.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 164, 16; v. 61, 8, etc. So
<div n="lb"/>also often later — {%e.g.,%} Maitrāyaṇī Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, iv. 7, 4; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 5,
<div n="lb"/>8, 2.</F>
<F>3) xii. 2, 39. {%Cf.%} Aitareya Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>iii. 22, 1.</F>
<F>4) Hopkins, {%Journal of the American%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Oriental Society,%} 13, 349, 350.</F>
<F>5) {%Cf.%} Hopkins, {%op. cit.,%} 351, 352.
<div n="lb"/>See {@Gārgī Vācaknavī@} and others
<div n="lb"/>enumerated in the Āśvalāyana Gṛhya
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, iii. 4, 4; Weber, {%Indische Studien,%}
<div n="lb"/>10, 118, 119.</F>
<F>6) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 6, 5,
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 7, 3; Śata-
<div n="lb"/>patha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 2, 4, 3-6.</F>
<F>7) i. 124, 7. {%Cf.%} Av. i. 14, 2;
<div n="lb"/>17, 1; Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 328;
<div n="lb"/>Hopkins, {%op. cit.,%} 341, and see {@Syāla,@}
<div n="lb"/>{@Putrikā.@}</F>
<F>8) Rv. iv. 5, 5.</F>
<F>9) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 8, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 4; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, iv. 4, 2, 13; Nirukta, iii. 4.</F>
<F>10) {%Cf.%} the Attic <lang n="greek"></lang>, Keith,
<div n="lb"/>{%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1912,
<div n="lb"/>427.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3718<pc>2-486<k1>sTapati<k2>sTapati
{@Stha-pati@}¦ is the name of a royal official mentioned in the
<div n="lb"/>Atharvaveda,<sup>1</sup> and often later.<sup>2</sup> {@Revottaras Cākra@} was the
<div n="lb"/>Sthapati of the exiled {@Duṣṭarītu Pauṃsāyana,@} a king of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Sṛñjayas,@} and succeeded in restoring him to his royal dignity.<sup>3</sup>
<div n="lb"/>The exact sense of the term is not certain: ‘governor’<sup>4</sup> is
<div n="lb"/>possible, but perhaps ‘chief judge’<sup>5</sup> is more likely; as in the
<div n="lb"/>case of the early English judges, his functions may have been
<div n="lb"/>both executive and judicial. He is inferior in position to the
<div n="lb"/>king's brother.<sup>6</sup>
<F>1) ii. 32, 4; v. 23, 11 (of the chief of
<div n="lb"/>the worms in both cases).</F>
<F>2) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 2, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xvii. 12; Maitrāyaṇī
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 3; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,
<div n="lb"/>xvi. 19; Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xvii. 11,
<div n="lb"/>6. 7; xxiv. 18, 2; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<div n="lb"/>v. 4, 4, 17, etc.</F>
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xii. 8, 1, 17;
<div n="lb"/>9, 3, 1 {%et seq.%} Sthapati here is part, as
<div n="lb"/>it were, of the name of the man.</F>
<F>4) In the Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra,
<div n="lb"/>i. 1, 12; Āpastamba Śrauta Sūtra, ix.
<div n="lb"/>14, 12, is found Niṣāda-sthapati;
<div n="lb"/>perhaps ‘governor of {@Niṣādas.@}’ But
<div n="lb"/>it may also mean ({%cf.%} Weber, {%Indische%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Studien,%} 1, 207, n.) a Niṣāda as a
<div n="lb"/>Sthapati; thus, little can be deduced
<div n="lb"/>from this passage in particular. Eggel-
<div n="lb"/>ing, {%Sacred Books of the East,%} 41, 111,
<div n="lb"/>renders it ‘governor.’ {%Cf.%} also St.
<div n="lb"/>Petersburg Dictionary, {%s.v.,%} and {@Aupo-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@diti.@}</F>
<F>5) Weber, {%Indische Studien,%} 10, 13,
<div n="lb"/>n. 3; 13, 203; 17, 200; 18, 260; {%Über%}
<div n="lb"/>{%den Rājasūya,%} 15, n. 6; {%Über den Vājapeya,%}
<div n="lb"/>9, 10. {%Cf.%} Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra,
<div n="lb"/>xxii. 5, 28; 11, 11; Lāṭyāyana Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, viii. 7, 11; Āpastamba Śrauta
<div n="lb"/>Sūtra, xxii. 7, 6.</F>
<F>6) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 4, 4, 17.</F>

<L>3753<pc>2-492<k1>svaDiti<k2>svaDiti<h>1
1. {@Svadhiti@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> denotes the ‘axe’ or ‘knife’
<div n="lb"/>used for dissecting the sacrificial horse. In all the other
<div n="lb"/>passages in that Saṃhitā<sup>2</sup> the sense of ‘axe’ for cutting wood
<div n="lb"/>is adequate; reference is made in one place<sup>3</sup> to sharpening the
<div n="lb"/>axe on the whetstone ({%kṣṇotra%}). In the Atharvaveda<sup>4</sup> the term
<div n="lb"/>seems once to denote the copper ({%lohita%})<sup>5</sup> knife used to mark
<div n="lb"/>the ears of cattle; the carpenter's knife or axe is also twice
<div n="lb"/>referred to there.<sup>6</sup> Later the word means ‘axe’ generally.<sup>7</sup>
<div n="lb"/>As a weapon it does not appear at all.<sup>8</sup>
<F>1) i. 162, 9. 18. 20.</F>
<F>2) ii. 39, 7; iii. 2, 10; 8, 6, 11;
<div n="lb"/>v. 7, 8; vii. 3, 9; viii. 102, 19; x. 89, 7.

<L>3759<pc>2-493<k1>svara<k2>svara
{@Svara@}¦ denotes in the Upaniṣads<sup>1</sup> the sound of a vowel:
<div n="lb"/>these are described<sup>2</sup> as being {%ghoṣavant,%} ‘sonant,’ and also as
<div n="lb"/>{%balavant,%} ‘uttered with force.’ The precise word for a mute is
<div n="lb"/>{%sparśa,%}<sup>3</sup> ‘contact,’ while {%ūṣman%} denotes a ‘sibilant,’ and {%svara%} a
<div n="lb"/>‘vowel,’ in the Aitareya<sup>3</sup> and Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyakas.<sup>4</sup> The
<div n="lb"/>semivowels are there denoted by {%anta-sthā%} (‘intermediate’)<sup>5</sup> or
<div n="lb"/>{%akṣara.%}<sup>6</sup> Another division in the Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>7</sup> is into
<div n="lb"/>{%ghoṣa, ūṣman,%} and {%vyañjana,%} apparently ‘vowels,’ ‘sibilants,’
<div n="lb"/>and ‘consonants’ respectively. {%Ghoṣa%} elsewhere in that Āraṇ-
<div n="lb"/>yaka<sup>8</sup> seems to have the general sense of ‘sounds.’ The
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Upaniṣad<sup>9</sup> refers to {%mātrā,%} a ‘mora’;<sup>10</sup> {%bala,%} ‘force’
<div n="lb"/>of utterance, and {%varṇa,%} ‘letter,’ an expression found else-
<div n="lb"/>where<sup>11</sup> in the explanation of {%om,%} as compacted of {%a + u + m.%}
[Page2-494+ 53]
<div n="P"/>The Aitareya Āraṇyaka<sup>12</sup> and the Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>recognize the three forms of the Rigveda text as {%pratṛṇṇa,%}
<div n="lb"/>{%nirbhuja,%} and {%ubhayam-antareṇa,%} denoting respectively the Saṃ-
<div n="lb"/>hitā, Pada, and Krama Pāṭhas of the Rigveda.<sup>14</sup> The same
<div n="lb"/>authorities<sup>15</sup> recognize the importance of the distinction of the
<div n="lb"/>cerebral and dental {%n%} and {%s,%} and refer<sup>16</sup> to the {@Māṇḍūkeyas'@}
<div n="lb"/>mode of recitation. They also discuss<sup>17</sup> Sandhi, the euphonic
<div n="lb"/>‘combination’ of letters.
<div n="P"/>The Prātiśākhyas of the several Saṃhitās develop in detail
<div n="lb"/>the grammatical terminology, and Yāska's Nirukta<sup>18</sup> contains a
<div n="lb"/>good deal of grammatical material. The Śatapatha Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>19</sup> distinguishes the genders, and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa<sup>20</sup> the division of words in the Sāman recitation.

<F>2) Chāndogya Upaniṣad, {%loc. cit.%}</F>

<L>3766<pc>2-495<k1>svasf<k2>svasf
{@Svasṛ@}¦ is the regular word from the Rigveda onwards<sup>1</sup> for
<div n="lb"/>‘sister.’ Like the word {@Bhrātṛ,@} the term sister can be applied
[Page2-496+ 42]
<div n="lb"/>to things not precisely so related. For example, in the Rigveda
<div n="lb"/>the fingers and the seasons are ‘sisters,’ and night is the sister
<div n="lb"/>of dawn, for whom, as the elder, she makes way.<sup>2</sup> The {@Paṇis@}
<div n="lb"/>offer to adopt Saramā as their sister;<sup>3</sup> but this use is not
<div n="lb"/>applied — any more than in the case of Bhrātṛ — to ordinary
<div n="lb"/>human beings.
<div n="P"/>The sister stood in a close relation to her brother. If the
<div n="lb"/>father was dead or feeble, the sister was dependent on her
<div n="lb"/>brother and on his wife, as appears from the Rigveda<sup>4</sup> and the
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa.<sup>5</sup> Moreover, maidens without brothers
<div n="lb"/>were apt to find marriage difficult, and to degenerate into
<div n="lb"/>Hetairai;<sup>6</sup> but it is not certain whether this was due, as
<div n="lb"/>Zimmer<sup>7</sup> thinks, to brothers being required to arrange
<div n="lb"/>marriages for orphan girls, or because sonless fathers were
<div n="lb"/>anxious to make their daughters {@Putrikās,@} in order that they
<div n="lb"/>themselves, instead of the husbands, should count the daughters'
<div n="lb"/>sons as their own.<sup>8</sup> See also {@Jāmi.@}
<F>1) Rv. ii. 32, 6; vi. 55, 4. 5; viii. 101, 15; x. 108, 9, etc.</F>
<F>2) Rv. i. 124, 8. See Delbrück, {%Die%}
<div n="lb"/>{%indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,%}
<div n="lb"/>463; Rv. i. 62, 10; 64, 7, 71, 1, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 108, 9.</F>
<F>4) x. 85, 46. {%Cf.%} ix. 96, 22.</F>
<F>5) iii. 37, 5.</F>
<F>6) Av. i. 17, 1; Rv. i. 124, 7; iv. 5, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Nirukta, iii. 5.</F>
<F>7) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 328.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} Geldner, {%Rigveda, Kommentar,%}
<div n="lb"/>22, 48, 49 (on Rv. iii. 31, 1 {%et seq.%}).</F>

<L>3784<pc>2-499<k1>hariyUpIyA<k2>hariyUpIyA
{@Hari-yūpīyā@}¦ is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> as the
<div n="lb"/>scene of the defeat of the {@Vṛcīvants@} by {@Abhyāvartin Cāya-@}
<div n="lb"/>{@mana.@} It may denote either a place or a river, since many
<div n="lb"/>battles seem to have been fought on the banks of rivers.
<div n="lb"/>Ludwig<sup>2</sup> took it as the name of a town on the river {@Yavyāvatī,@}
<div n="lb"/>which is identified with it in Sāyaṇa's commentary on the
<div n="lb"/>passage. Hillebrandt<sup>3</sup> thinks that it is the river Iryāb (Haliāb),
<div n="lb"/>a tributary of the Kurum ({@Krumu@}), but this is not at all
<div n="lb"/>probable.

<L>3796<pc>2-501<k1>hastin<k2>hastin
{@Hastin,@}¦ ‘having a hand,’ with {@Mṛga,@} ‘beast,’ denotes in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and the Atharvaveda<sup>2</sup> the ‘elephant.’ Later the
<div n="lb"/>adjective alone comes to mean ‘elephant.’<sup>3</sup> The animal was
<div n="lb"/>famed for its strength<sup>4</sup> as well as its virility.<sup>5</sup> It is mentioned
<div n="lb"/>with man and monkey as one of the beasts that take hold by
<div n="lb"/>the hand ({%hastādāna%}), as opposed to those that take hold by the
<div n="lb"/>mouth ({%mukhādāna%}).<sup>6</sup> It was tamed, as the expression {@Hastipa,@}
<div n="lb"/>‘elephant-keeper,’ shows, and tame elephants were used to
<div n="lb"/>catch others (see {@Vāraṇa@}). But there is no trace of its use in
<div n="lb"/>war, though Ktesias and Megasthenes both record such use for
[Page2-502+ 46]
<div n="lb"/>their times.<sup>7</sup> The Atharvaveda<sup>8</sup> alludes to its being pestered
<div n="lb"/>by mosquitoes.
<F>1) i. 64, 7; iv. 16, 14.</F>
<F>2) xii. 1, 25. Elsewhere Hastin is
<div n="lb"/>used alone: iii. 22, 3; iv. 36, 9;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 38, 2; 70, 2; xix. 1, 32.</F>
<F>3) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 8; Vāja-
<div n="lb"/>saneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 29; Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, vi. 8, 8; xxiii. 13, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iv. 1, 14; v. 31, 2;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 27, 2; Satapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 1,
<div n="lb"/>3, 4, etc.; Chāndogya Upaniṣad, vii. 24,
<div n="lb"/>2 (coupled with gold), etc.; Jaiminīya
<div n="lb"/>Upaniṣad Brāhmaṇa, iii. 22, 1.</F>
<F>4) Rv. {%loc. cit.;%} Av ii. 22, 1, 3.</F>
<F>5) Av. iii. 22, 6; vi. 70, 2.</F>
<F>6) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 5, 7;
<div n="lb"/>Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv, 5, 7.</F>
<F>7) Von Schroeder, {%Indiens Literatur und%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Cidtur,%} 434.</F>
<F>8) Av. iv. 36, 9.
<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 80.</F>

<L>3807<pc>2-503<k1>himavant<k2>himavant
{@Himavant,@}¦ ‘snowy,’ appears as an epithet of mountains in
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> It is also used both there<sup>2</sup> and in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda,<sup>3</sup> as well as later,<sup>4</sup> as a noun. There seems no reason
<div n="lb"/>to deny that in all the passages the word refers vaguely to the
<div n="lb"/>mountains now called Himālaya, though it is possible that the
<div n="lb"/>name may include mountains not strictly in that system, like
<div n="lb"/>the Suleiman hills.<sup>5</sup> See also {@Mūjavant@} and {@Trikakubh.@}
<F>1) xii. 1, 11.</F>
<F>2) vi. 95, 3. See also iv. 9, 9; v. 4,
<div n="lb"/>2. 8; 25. 7; vi. 24, 1 (where reference
<div n="lb"/>is made to the rivers of the Himālayas);
<div n="lb"/>xix. 39, 1.</F>
<F>3) x. 121, 4.</F>
<F>4) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30; xxv. 12;
<div n="lb"/>Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, viii. 14, 3 (the
<div n="lb"/>{@Uttara Kurus@} and {@Uttara Madras@} live
<div n="lb"/>beyond it; perhaps in Kaśmīr), etc.</F>
<F>5) Ludwig, Translation of the Rig-
<div n="lb"/>veda, 3, 198.

<L>3811<pc>2-504<k1>hiraRya<k2>hiraRya
{@Hiraṇya@}¦ in the Rigveda<sup>1</sup> and later<sup>2</sup> denotes ‘gold.’ It is
<div n="lb"/>hardly possible to exaggerate the value attached to gold by the
<div n="lb"/>Vedic Indians. The metal was, it is clear, won from the bed of
<div n="lb"/>rivers. Hence the Indus is called ‘golden’<sup>3</sup> and ‘of golden
<div n="lb"/>stream.’<sup>4</sup> Apparently the extraction of gold from the earth was
<div n="lb"/>known,<sup>5</sup> and washing for gold is also recorded.<sup>6</sup>
<div n="P"/>Gold is the object of the wishes of the Vedic singer,<sup>7</sup> and
<div n="lb"/>golden treasures ({%hiraṇyāni%}) are mentioned as given by patrons<sup>8</sup>
<div n="lb"/>along with cows and horses. Gold was used for ornaments for
<div n="lb"/>neck and breast ({@Niṣka@}), for ear-rings ({@Karṇa-śobhana@}), and
<div n="lb"/>even for cups.<sup>9</sup> Gold is always associated with the gods.<sup>10</sup>
[Page2-505+ 62]
<div n="P"/>In the plural Hiraṇya denotes ‘ornaments of gold.’<sup>11</sup>
<div n="P"/>A gold currency was evidently beginning to be known in so
<div n="lb"/>far as definite weights of gold are mentioned: thus a weight,
<div n="lb"/>{%aṣṭā-prūḍ,%} occurs in the Saṃhitās,<sup>12</sup> and the golden {%śatamāna,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘weight of a hundred ({@Kṛṣṇalas@})’ is found in the same texts.<sup>13</sup>
<div n="lb"/>In several passages,<sup>14</sup> moreover, {%hiraṇya%} or {%hiraṇyāni%} may mean
<div n="lb"/>‘pieces of gold.’
<div n="P"/>Gold is described sometimes as {%harita,%}<sup>15</sup> ‘yellowish,’ some-
<div n="lb"/>times as {%rajata,%}<sup>16</sup> ‘whitish,’ when probably. ‘silver’ is alluded
<div n="lb"/>to. It was obtained from the ore by smelting.<sup>17</sup> Mega-
<div n="lb"/>sthenes<sup>18</sup> bears testimony to the richness in gold of India in
<div n="lb"/>his time.
<F>1) i. 43, 5; iii. 34, 9; iv. 10, 6;
<div n="lb"/>17, 11, etc.</F>
<F>2) Av. i. 9, 2; ii. 36, 7; v. 28, 6;
<div n="lb"/>vi. 38, 2, etc.</F>
<F>3) Rv. x. 75, 8.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vi. 61, 7; viii. 26, 18.</F>
<F>5) Rv. i. 117, 5; Av. xii. 1, 6. 26. 44.</F>
<F>6) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 7, 1;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, ii. 1, 1, 5.</F>
<F>7) Rv. vi. 47, 23; viii. 78, 9; Pischel
<div n="lb"/>and Geldner, {%Vedische Studien,%} 1, xxiv.</F>
<F>8) {%Cf.%} also {@Hiraṇyastūpa@} as a proper
<div n="lb"/>name.</F>
<F>9) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 7, 1, 3;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 3, 3, 7;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 1, 2, 19;
<div n="lb"/>5, 28.</F>
<F>10) All that is connected with them
<div n="lb"/>is of gold; the horses of the sun are
<div n="lb"/>{%hiraṇya-tvacas,%} ‘gold-skinned’ (Av.
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 2, 8), and so on.</F>
<F>11) Rv. i. 122, 2; 162, 16; ii. 33, 9;
<div n="lb"/>v. 60, 4; Av. iv. 10, 6; Vājasaneyi
<div n="lb"/>Saṃhitā, xv. 50; xx. 37; also in the
<div n="lb"/>singular, Av. i. 35, 1; xviii. 4, 56.</F>
<F>12) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 1, 4;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, xi. 1; xiii. 10;
<div n="lb"/>von Schroeder, {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen%}
<div n="lb"/>{%Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 49, 164.</F>
<F>13) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, v. 5, 5, 16;
<div n="lb"/>xii. 7, 2, 13; 9, 1, 4. {%Cf.%} xiii. 1, 1, 4;
<div n="lb"/>2, 3, 2; 4, 1, 13; 2, 7. 13; xiv. 3, 1,
<div n="lb"/>32; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 11, 5;
<div n="lb"/>Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, viii. 5; xxii. 8;
<div n="lb"/>Weber, {%Indische Streifen,%} 1, 101. Geldner,
<div n="lb"/>{%Vedische Studien,%} 1, 268, is inclined to
<div n="lb"/>think that a gold unit is alluded to in
<div n="lb"/>the vague phrases ‘thousands,’ etc., of
<div n="lb"/>the Rigveda. See viii. 1, 13; 65, 12;
<div n="lb"/>x. 95, 3, etc.</F>
<F>14) Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 7, 4;
<div n="lb"/>iii. 8, 2, 2; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xii. 7,
<div n="lb"/>1, 7; xiii. 4, 1, 6, etc.</F>
<F>15) Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā, x. 4; Śatapatha
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xii. 4, 4, 6; Ṣaḍviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, ii. 9.</F>
<F>16) Taittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 5, 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, xii. 4, 4, 7;
<div n="lb"/>xiii. 4, 2, 10, etc.</F>
<F>17) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, vi. 1, 3, 5.
<div n="lb"/>{%Cf.%} ii. 2, 3, 28; xii. 4, 3, 1; Pañcaviṃśa
<div n="lb"/>Brāhmaṇa, xvii. 6, 4 ({%niṣ-ṭap,%} ‘heat’);
<div n="lb"/>Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 10 ({%Journal of%}
<div n="lb"/>{%the American Oriental Society,%} 16, 234,
<div n="lb"/>ccxliii); Lāṭyāyana Śrauta Sūtra, iii. 1,
<div n="lb"/>9, etc.; Jaiminīya Upaniṣad Brāh-
<div n="lb"/>maṇa, iii. 34, 6.</F>
<F>18) See Diodorus Siculus, ii. 36;

<div n="P"/>{%Cf.%} Zimmer, {%Altindisches Leben,%} 49-51;
<div n="lb"/>Macdonell, {%Sanskrit Literature,%} 151.</F>

<L>3823<pc>2-507<k1>hemanta<k2>hemanta
{@Hemanta,@}¦ ‘winter,’ occurs only once in the Rigveda,<sup>1</sup> but
<div n="lb"/>often in the later texts.<sup>2</sup> Zimmer<sup>3</sup> is inclined to trace
<div n="lb"/>differences of climate in the Rigveda: he thinks that certain
<div n="lb"/>hymns,<sup>4</sup> which ignore winter and insist on the rains, indicate a
<div n="lb"/>different place and time of origin from those which refer to the
<div n="lb"/>snowy mountains.<sup>5</sup> It is, however, quite impossible to separate
<div n="lb"/>parts of the Rigveda on this basis. It is probable that that
<div n="lb"/>text owes its composition in the main to residents in the later
<div n="lb"/>{@Madhyadeśa;@} hence the references to cold and snow are rather
<div n="lb"/>a sign of local than of temporal differences. It is otherwise
<div n="lb"/>with the later expansion of the three into four seasons,
[Page2-508+ 36]
<div n="lb"/>which represents clearly the earlier advance of the Indians
<div n="lb"/>(see {@Ṛtu@}).
<div n="P"/>The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa<sup>6</sup> describes winter as the time
<div n="lb"/>when the plants wither, the leaves fall from the trees, the birds
<div n="lb"/>fly low and retire more and more.
<F>1) x. 161, 4.</F>
<F>2) Av. vi. 55, 2; viii. 2, 22; xii.
<div n="lb"/>1, 36; Taittirīya Saṃhitā, v. 7, 2,
<div n="lb"/>4; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 58;
<div n="lb"/>Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa, xxi. 15, 2;
<div n="lb"/>Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa, i. 4, 10, 10;
<div n="lb"/>Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, x. 4, 5, 2
<div n="lb"/>etc.</F>
<F>3) {%Altindisches Leben,%} 40.</F>
<F>4) Rv. vii. 103; x. 90.</F>
<F>5) Rv. x. 68, 10; 121, 4 (both these
<div n="lb"/>are not early hymns).</F>
<F>6) i. 5, 4, 5.</F>
<LEND>

<L>3826<pc>2-508<k1>hotf<k2>hotf
{@Hotṛ@}¦ is the name of one of the oldest and most important
<div n="lb"/>priests of the Vedic ritual, the counterpart of the Zaotar of the
<div n="lb"/>Avestan priesthood.<sup>1</sup> The word must be derived from {%hu,%}
<div n="lb"/>‘sacrifice,’ as was held by {@Aurṇavābha;@}<sup>2</sup> this indicates a time
<div n="lb"/>when the Hotṛ was at once sacrificer (the later Adhvaryu) and
<div n="lb"/>singer. But the functions were already clearly divided in the
<div n="lb"/>Rigveda, where the Hotṛ's chief duty was the recitation of the
<div n="lb"/>{@Śastras.@} He was also in the older period often the {@Purohita@}
<div n="lb"/>of the king, an office later filled by the {@Brahman@} priest.
<F>1) Rv. i. 1, 1; 14, 11; 139, 10, etc.;
<div n="lb"/>{@Hotra,@} the ‘Hotṛ's office,’ Rv. ii. 1, 2;
<div n="lb"/>36, 1; 37, 1, etc.</F>
<F>2) Nirukta. iv. 26. {%Cf.%} Oldenberg,
<div n="lb"/>{%Religion des Veda,%} 380 {%et seq.%}</F>

<L>3833<pc>2-509<k1>hrUqu<k2>hrUqu
{@Hrūḍu@}¦ is a word of unknown meaning applied to {@Takman@} in
<div n="lb"/>the Atharvaveda.<sup>1</sup> It is variously spelled in the manuscript as
<div n="lb"/>{%hruḍa, hūḍu, rūḍu,%} and so forth; the Paippalāda recension
<div n="lb"/>reads {%huḍu,%} ‘ram.’ Henry<sup>2</sup> has conjectured that the word is
<div n="lb"/>the equivalent of a proto-Semitic {%ḥarāḍu,%} ‘gold’ (Assyrian
<div n="lb"/>{%huraçu%} and Hebrew {%ḥarāç%}), while Halévy<sup>3</sup> suggests that it may
<div n="lb"/>be the Greek <lang n="greek"></lang> ‘greenish-yellow’; but both conjectures
<div n="lb"/>are highly improbable.<sup>4</sup> Weber<sup>5</sup> thinks ‘cramp’ is meant.
<F>1) i. 25, 2. 3.</F>

<H>ADDENDA AND CORRIGENDA
<P>{@Aṅguli,@} ‘finger-breadth,’ is mentioned as the ‘lowest
<>measure’ in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa.
<F>1) x. 2, 1, 2. See Fleet, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1912, 231.</F>
<P>{@Anas.@} — In the Sūtras
<F>1) Baudhāyana Śrauta Sūtra, xiii. 38; Āpastamba Śrauta Sūtra, xix. 26, 4. {%Cf.%}
<>{%tri-gadha, ibid.,%} xix. 26, 2.</F> mention is made of a part of the cart
<>called Gadhā, which in Garbe's
<F>2) Edition of Āpastamba, 3, 356.</F> opinion means ‘roof.’
<P>{@Araṇī@} is the designation, in the Rigveda
<F>1) i. 127, 4; 129, 5; iii. 29, 2; v. 9, 3;
<>vii. 1, 1; x. 184, 3.</F> and later,
<F>2) Av. x. 8, 20; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<>iii. 1, 1, 11; iv. 6, 8, 3; xii. 4, 3, 3.
<>10; Kaṭha Upaniṣad, iv. 7; Śvetā-
<>śvatara Upaniṣad, i. 14. 15; Āśval-
<>āyana Gṛhya Sūtra, iv. 6.</F> of the
<>two pieces of wood used in producing the sacrificial fire by
<>friction. The upper ({%uttarā%}) and the lower ({%adharā%}) are
<>distinguished.
<F>3) Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 1, 22;
<>xi. 5, 1, 15; Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra,
<>v. 1, 30, etc.</F> The upper, in the form of a drill, is made of
<>the hard wood of the {@Aśvattha,@}
<F>4) Av. vi. 11, 1; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa,
<>xi. 5, 1, 13; Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra,
<>iv. 7, 22.</F> the lower, in the form of a
<>slab, of the soft wood of the {@Śamī.@}
<F>5) Av. vi. 11, 1; 30, 2. 3; Taittirīya
<>Brāhmaṇa, i. 1, 3, 11 {%et seq.%}</F> The drill is twirled
<>forcibly ({%sahasā%})
<F>6) Rv. vi. 48, 5.</F> backwards and forwards with the arms ({%bāhu-%}
<>{%bhyām%})
<F>7) Aitareya Brāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 7. {%Cf.%}
<>Rv. x. 7, 5.</F> by means of cords ({%raśanābhiḥ%}).
<F>8) {%Cf.%} Rv. x. 4, 6. See Macdonell,
<>{%Vedic Mythology,%} p. 91.</F> The action doubtless
<>resembled that by which butter is separated from milk in India
[Page2-512+ 41]
<>at the present day, the same verb ({%math,%} ‘twirl,’ ‘churn’)
<F>9) Fire: Rv. vi. 15, 17; 48, 5, etc.
<>Butter: {%dugdhaṃ mathitam ājyaṃ bhavati,%}
<>Taittirīya Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 10, 2; Śata-
<>patha Brāhmaṇa, v. 3, 2, 6; Kātyāyana
<>Śrauta Sūtra, v. 8, 18.</F>
<>being used for both processes. This method of producing the
<>sacrificial fire still survives in India. Specimens of the modern
<>apparatus may be seen in the Indian Institute and in the Pitt-
<>Rivers Museum at Oxford.
<P>{@Aratni,@} ‘cubit.’ According to the Śulvasūtra of Baudhā-

<>{%East,%} 43, 300, n. 3.</F>

<>{%palāśa,%} i. 2, 3, 12. 13).

<P>{@Kamboja.@} — For these Iranian connexions, see Kuhn, {%Avesta,%}

<P>{@Krośa.@} — In note
<F>1) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 62, 459-470.</F> for ‘about two miles’ read ‘1(1/8) miles.’ See
<>Fleet, {%Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,%} 1912, 237.
<P>{@Grāma.@} — The phrase Grāmin, ‘possessing a village,’ occurs
<>often in the Taittirīya Saṃhitā (ii. 1, 3, 2; 6, 7; 2, 8, 1; 11, 1;
<>3, 3, 5; 9, 2), usually in connexion with various rites for
<>acquiring a village. Since in these cases repeated mention is
<>made of obtaining pre-eminence over {@Sajātas@} and Samānas,
<>‘equals,’ it is probable that allowance must also be made for
<>the control over his fellow-villagers which an ambitious man
<>could obtain ({%e.g.,%} by loans), and which might end by giving
<>him the position of a great landlord, even without the interven-
<>tion of the king.
<P>{@Caṇḍātaka@} in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa (v. 2, 1, 8) and the
<>Kātyāyana Śrauta Sūtra (xiv. 5, 3) denotes an undergarment
<>worn by women.
<P>{@Camū.@} — Oldenberg
<F>1) {%Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,%} 62, 459-470.</F> considers that even in the dual the word
<>denotes two vessels into which the Soma, often mixed with
<>water in the {@Kośa@} and purified with the sieve, was poured, and
<>that, in the plural, reference is made to these and other vessels
<>into which the Soma was put at the various stages of the
[Page2-514+ 34]
<>process. {@Kalaśa@} similarly denoted either one (sing.) or several
<>(plur.) of the vessels, the dual not being used, since the dual of
<>{@Camū@} was reserved for the two vessels {%par excellence.%} In the
<>later ritual the Camūs are replaced by the Droṇa-Kalaśa and
<>the Pūtabhṛt, which was, however, assimilated in form and
<>material (being made of clay, not of wood) to the Ādhāvanīya,
<>the later name of the Kośa. The main difficulty of this theory
<>is that it is hard to explain why Kalaśa never occurs in the
<>dual. Geldner
<F>2) {%Ṛgveda, Glossar,%} 60.</F> falls back on the older view that in Camū
<>(dual) the two boards of the Soma press are meant.
<P>{@Cāṇḍāla,@} 1, 258, should come after {@Cākṣuṣa.@}
<P>{@Jābāla.@} — For ‘descendant of {@Jabāla@}’ read ‘descendant of
<>{@Jabālā.@}’

<>{%Society of Bengal,%} 61, 422), or Chitrung (Oldham, {%Journal of the%}
<>{%Royal Asiatic Society,%} 25, 58; {%cf.%} the sketch map opposite
<>p. 49). See {@Sarasvatī,@} 2, 435, note^4.

<H>1. SANSKRIT INDEX
<>{%When a word is given without a meaning, it is either clearly a patronymic or of%}
<>{%doubtful signification.%}
<HI>1. Aṃśu, a man, i. 1
